site_title: Six stations on Thomson-East Coast Line handed over to SMRT; to open in Q3
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has handed over six stations on the Thomson-East Coast Line (TEL) to operator SMRT, marking a key milestone for the line's stage two. The stations, including Woodlands North, Woodlands, and Bright Hill, are expected to open to commuters in the third quarter of this year. The handover follows completion of civil and structural works, with only some architectural, electrical, and mechanical works remaining. The TEL aims to reduce travel time for commuters, with some journeys cut short by half.

site_title: EU hits Apple with music streaming charge in boost for Spotify
summary: The European Union has accused Apple of distorting competition in the music streaming market, siding with Spotify in a case that could lead to a fine of up to $27 billion. Apple was accused of restricting rivals to its own music streaming service Apple Music through its App Store rules, which force developers to use its in-app payment system and prevent them from informing users of other purchasing options. Spotify welcomed the EU move, while Apple rebuffed the charge, calling it "unfair competition." This is the first EU antitrust charge against Apple.

site_title: Hin Leong founder OK Lim charged with 23 counts of forgery-related offences
summary: Singapore tycoon OK Lim Oon Kuin was charged with 23 counts of forgery-related offences, bringing the total number of charges against him to 25. Lim, founder of Hin Leong, was charged with 12 counts under Section 468 for forgery for the purpose of cheating and 11 counts under Section 465 for forgery, carrying maximum jail terms of 10 and 4 years, respectively. Lim appeared in court after three previous no-shows.

images.alt_text: Based on the charge sheets, Lim allegedly committed the offences between June 12, 2019 and March 9, 2020. The offences involve him instigating or conspiring with Freddy Tan Jie Ren, a contracts executive of Hin Leong Trading, in forgery.

site_title: Optimism rising in Singapore's manufacturing, services sectors
summary: Business optimism in Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors has risen, with 38% of manufacturing firms and 11% of services firms expecting favorable conditions for the next six months. The manufacturing sector has seen a net weighted balance of 38% optimistic, with clusters such as electronics and biomedical manufacturing showing significant improvement. In contrast, the accommodation industry remains pessimistic due to weak demand. Overall, the rise in optimism suggests a positive outlook for the Singapore economy.

site_title: Mothers bore the brunt of pandemic pain: IMF
summary: A new IMF study confirms mothers bore the brunt of pandemic pain, with women with young children suffering an outsized economic impact from the Covid-19 pandemic. The study found mothers in the US, Britain, and Spain were disproportionately affected, with nearly 2 million women over 20 leaving the labor force in the US. The IMF is calling for prioritizing reopening schools and providing monetary support for mothers, particularly those with young children.

site_title: Shock and tears: behind Vanguard's retreat from China market
summary: Vanguard Group has retreated from its push to establish a mutual fund license in China, citing concerns over costs and regulations. The decision, made by regional head Scott Conking, comes after years of scrutiny by top management on the feasibility of Vanguard's low-cost model in the Chinese market. The firm will instead rely on an advisory venture with Ant Group to maintain a presence in China. The move serves as a cautionary tale for other global asset managers eyeing China's $13 trillion wealth market, highlighting the challenges of competing with local firms and navigating regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Palladium surpasses US$3,000 for first time on supply shortfall
summary: Palladium surpasses $3,000 for the first time, driven by a supply shortage fueled by Russia's Nornickel mine flooding. Prices have risen over 20% since March 16, driven by increased demand from the auto industry and electronics sector. Analysts predict prices will fall as automakers switch to cheaper platinum and environmental rules erode demand. Meanwhile, gold has risen 3.7% this month, while silver and platinum remain steady.

site_title: Singapore tightens border measures for four South Asian countries and Thailand
summary: Singapore has tightened border measures, barring non-resident visitors from four South Asian countries (Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) and requiring visitors from Thailand to serve a stay-home notice. The move follows a sharp increase in cases reported by these countries. Effective May 1, long-term pass holders and short-term visitors with recent travel history to these countries will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore.

site_title: Keppel Land subsidiaries enter JV with HK-listed Sino-Ocean Group
summary: Keppel Land's subsidiaries have entered a joint venture with Sino-Ocean Group to develop eight plots of land in Tianjin, China's Binhai New Area. The plots, totaling 28.7 hectares, will be developed by two Keppel Land subsidiaries and two Sino-Ocean subsidiaries. This partnership aims to drive growth in China's real estate market, with the development expected to contribute to Keppel Land's expansion in the region.

site_title: Intel seeks eight billion euros in subsidies for European chip plant
summary: Intel is seeking 8 billion euros in public subsidies to build a semiconductor factory in Europe, aiming to reduce reliance on Asian imports amid a global shortage. CEO Pat Gelsinger stated that the aid would make it competitive for Intel to manufacture in Europe compared to Asia. This move is part of Intel's multibillion-dollar drive to counter Asian rivals in contract manufacturing.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenues surges 11-fold in April
summary: Macau's gambling revenue surged 11-fold in April to 8.4 billion patacas ($1.39 billion) year-on-year, driven by a pick-up in visitors from mainland China following the relaxation of coronavirus travel restrictions. This marks the highest monthly toll this year, after revenues slumped in 2020 due to coronavirus travel restrictions.

site_title: 3M hit with US$6m punitive damages by US jury in first combat earplug trial
summary: A US jury has awarded 3M punitive damages of US$6 million in a trial related to its combat earplugs, which were used by the US military between 2007 and 2013. Three veterans accused 3M of hiding design flaws and failing to instruct proper use, resulting in hearing damage. The verdict is part of over 200,000 similar claims against 3M, with the company facing potential appeals and further trials, including a bellwether trial starting on May 17.

site_title: Yangzijiang's strong earnings raise analysts' optimism
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings released strong first-quarter earnings, boosting analysts' optimism. OCBC Investment Research raised its fair value to S$1.45 from S$1.18, while DBS Group Research reviews its target price at S$1.50. The positive earnings report has turned analysts more bullish on the stock, indicating a potential increase in the shipbuilder's value.

site_title: Investment opportunities in the energy transition process
summary: Investment opportunities in the energy transition process are expanding across sectors, including green buildings, low carbon materials, and precision agriculture. A lack of funding poses a major obstacle for 70% of companies transitioning to net zero by 2050. Financing these companies can help accelerate progress and generate financial gains. Central banks warn that climate change risks could lead to a 25% decline in global GDP by 2100, emphasizing the need for investment in the energy transition.

site_title: Pick Network launches first batch of over 200 parcel lockers
summary: Pick Network, a government-owned parcel locker operator, has launched its first batch of over 200 parcel lockers island-wide. The lockers are located in community clubs, HDB blocks, and transport nodes, with the goal of rolling out 1,000 lockers by year's end, a year ahead of the original schedule.

site_title: Is private equity more resilient than other asset classes?
summary: Private equity returns are highly correlated to public markets, contradicting the notion of its resilience. Contrary to popular belief, PE firms can go out of business, and their performance is not immune to economic cycles. Private equity investment returns are unreliable and unpredictable, making it challenging to predict its performance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors show optimism for the next six months, with all clusters predicting favourable business conditions from April to September. The outlook is based on expectations of stable demand and supply chain management. This optimism is a significant improvement from previous periods, indicating a positive turn in the economy.

site_title: Venture Q1 net profit rises 8.3% to S$65.3m
summary: Venture Corp's Q1 net profit rose 8.3% to S$65.3m, driven by improved profitability, despite a 2% revenue growth due to global parts and components shortages. The company attributed the shortage to supply challenges and set up working groups to address them. Earnings per share increased to 22.4 cents, and net cash position grew to S$989.6m. Venture expects a quarter-on-quarter improvement in Q2 and a stronger H1 performance.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality's CEO to retire on Oct 1
summary: Frasers Hospitality's CEO Koh Teck Chuan will retire on October 1, relinquishing all management duties. Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, Frasers Property's group chief executive, will oversee Frasers Hospitality. Koh will support the transition process over the next five months. He praised his teams' commitment and passion, particularly during the COVID-19 challenges.

site_title: Singapore has to tighten Covid-19 measures promptly if needed to curb spread, avoid second circuit breaker: PM Lee
summary: Singapore must tighten Covid-19 measures promptly to curb the spread of new clusters and avoid a second circuit breaker, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. With new strains of the virus emerging, the situation can deteriorate rapidly. The country has seen a spike in community transmission, with 35 cases reported in the past week, prompting tighter restrictions. Lee emphasized the need for Singaporeans to work together and not let their guard down, warning against premature celebrations and relaxation. The government is also working on emergency legislation to address the severe disruption to the construction sector.

site_title: As auctioneers and artists rush into NFTs, many collectors choose to stay away
summary: A growing divide exists in the art market, with blue-chip collectors hesitant to invest in NFTs due to concerns over quality, ownership, and authenticity. Despite the success of high-profile NFT sales, many collectors, including industry experts, remain wary of the market's legal grey areas and copyright issues. Established artists like Takashi Murakami and digital artists like Rafaël Rozendaal are embracing NFTs, but the market's future remains uncertain, with risks including hacking, platform instability, and uncertainty over recognition of copyright rights across borders.

images.alt_text: Collectors Peter and Jill Kraus in their apartment with artist Pope.L's Sunny Day White Power. Mr Kraus asks: "Why pay US$69 million for something anyone can see online?"

site_title: Tax cut drives biggest jump in UK house prices since 2004
summary: The UK saw its largest monthly rise in house prices since 2004, with prices increasing by 2.1% in April, according to Nationwide. The tax cut on property sales, introduced by finance minister Rishi Sunak in July last year, has driven the growth, with house prices now 7.1% above their level last April. The tax break has been extended until the end of June, with a £250,000 tax-free allowance until the end of September. Experts warn that activity could slow later this year if unemployment increases.

site_title: Ex-Netflix executive convicted in vendor bribery-kickback scheme
summary: A former Netflix executive, Michael Kail, has been convicted of wire and mail fraud, and money laundering for taking kickbacks from vendors in exchange for approving millions of dollars in contracts. Kail, a former vice president of information technology operations, accepted bribes of over $500,000 and stock options from nine tech companies. The conviction undermines fair competition and innovation in Silicon Valley, where Netflix operates. Kail's lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, citing a lack of evidence.

site_title: US: Stocks end choppy week on a downcast note
summary: US stocks closed down on Friday, ending a choppy week on a downcast note, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.5% to 33,874.85. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.7% and 0.9% respectively. Despite strong earnings reports from companies like Amazon, which saw its profit triple, concerns about rising supply chain and commodity costs weighed on the markets. Personal income surged 21.1% in March, but the week's close was marred by warnings of higher costs and a potential risk to the year's outlook.

site_title: UOB to trim office space, but does not expect major reduction in real estate: CEO
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong announced the bank is considering downsizing its office space as hybrid work arrangements gain momentum, but expects a relatively small reduction in real estate. The bank has already transformed 200,000 sq ft of office space into "high-performance workspaces" and plans to allow most of its 26,000-strong workforce to work remotely two days a week once Covid-19 restrictions are lifted. The bank aims to improve employee welfare and maintain productivity while embracing sustainability and green financing.

site_title: Grammy organisers change rules after allegations of corruption
summary: The Recording Academy has ended the use of "secret" committees for Grammy nominations, shifting to all-voting member selection for the 2022 awards. This change comes after allegations of corruption, highlighted by The Weeknd's 2020 snub despite a critically acclaimed album. The move aims to increase transparency and fairness in the nomination process.

images.alt_text: The Academy was slammed last year when Canadian artist The Weeknd got zero Grammy nominations, even though his critically acclaimed album "After Hours" was one of the biggest sellers of 2020.

site_title: Chinese factory data, clampdown on Internet players sink Asia-Pacific markets
summary: Asian-Pacific markets declined due to Chinese factory data and a Beijing clampdown on Internet companies. The Straits Times Index fell 0.1% to 3,218.27 points, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 1.97%. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's quarterly earnings boosted its shares, but others, such as Sembcorp Marine and Raffles Education Corporation, declined. The decline was less pronounced in Singapore, where the Straits Times Index fell only 0.1%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Friday, mirroring a retreat in Asian markets, after a disappointing Chinese factory data report. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.97% to 28,724.88, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.81% to 3,446.86. The losses were attributed to the Chinese factory data, which fell short of expectations, and are part of a broader Asian market downturn.

site_title: Biden bans most travel to US from India to limit Covid-19 spread
summary: US President Joe Biden has imposed new travel restrictions on India due to the country's surge in COVID-19 cases, barring most non-US citizens from entering the US. The restrictions, effective May 4, are based on the advice of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and aim to protect the nation's public health. Most non-US citizens who have been in India within the last 14 days are not eligible to travel to the US, except for permanent residents, family members, and some other non-US citizens.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden on Friday imposed new travel restrictions on India in light of the Covid-19 epidemic, barring most non-US citizens from entering the US.

site_title: Displacement and collapse of berth at EC World Reit's Chongxian Port Investment
summary: The manager of EC World Reit's Chongxian Port Investment announced that a berth at the facility collapsed, damaging two adjacent gantry cranes. The incident has suspended operations at the damaged berth and two adjacent berths, with no reported injuries. The port's total designed annual throughput capacity is around six million tonnes. The incident is being investigated, and the rest of the port's operations remain unaffected.

site_title: Brokers' Take: OCBC raises fair value for YZJ, DBS reviews target price
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) reported a 89% increase in net profit for Q1 2021, with revenue falling 25% year-over-year. The company secured orders for 54 vessels worth $1.8 billion, boosting its outstanding order book to $6.6 billion. OCBC raised its fair value for YZJ to S$1.45, citing improving prospects in the shipbuilding market and potential privatisation offers. DBS is reviewing its target price of S$1.50, citing strong cash flow generation and a mitigating effect from a firmer USD.

site_title: Renaissance United's indirect subsidiary reaches out-of-court settlement with contractor
summary: Renaissance United's indirect subsidiary, Hubei Zonglianhuan Energy Investment Management (HZLH), reached an out-of-court settlement with contractor Wuhan Yuyun Municipal Engineering (WYME) for 28.11 million yuan over 40 months, after being ordered to pay 40.39 million yuan in a court judgment. The settlement was approved by the court and the company plans to refinance HZLH's trade payables through alternative avenues, including a possible fund-raising.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Group sets up new board committees for sustainability efforts
summary: ComfortDelGro Group has established new board committees focused on sustainability efforts, signaling its deep commitment to environmental, social, and corporate governance issues. The three committees will oversee strategic and investment decisions related to sustainability, reflecting the company's growing emphasis on ESG performance. The move comes as ComfortDelGro continues its sustainability push, including a S$50 million commitment to clean energy technology and research. The company's shares ended the day down 2.27% at S$1.72.

site_title: China's battery maker CATL invests in EV startup
summary: China's battery maker CATL has invested in EV startup Aiways, according to a corporate registration filing. The exact amount of the investment is unclear. Aiways, founded in 2017, plans to work on battery technologies with CATL. This investment follows CATL's earlier investment in Byton. Aiways, which produces cars in China's Shangrao and sells them in China and Europe, has also received investment from Didi Chuxing, China's ride-hailing giant.

site_title: Federer-backed shoemaker said to eye IPO at US$5b valuation
summary: Swiss sports-shoe maker On, backed by tennis great Roger Federer, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) valued at approximately US$5 billion. The company plans to list in the US autumn and is working with banks including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Founded in 2010, On is known for its proprietary Cloudtec technology and has seen business progress despite the COVID-19 pandemic. No final decisions have been made, and details of the potential transaction may change. A spokeswoman for the company declined to comment on any IPO plans.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: US stocks declined from record highs amid tariff threats from President Trump targeting Canada. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of below target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: ExxonMobil, Chevron return to profitability in Q1 on higher oil prices
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported a return to profitability in the first quarter of 2021, driven by higher oil prices. ExxonMobil reported a profit of $2.7 billion, while Chevron earned $1.4 billion. The companies' earnings come amid a recovering economy and improved demand outlook, but they still face challenges, including weak demand for petroleum products and pressure from activist shareholders over climate change. ExxonMobil and Chevron plan to continue investing in renewable energy and carbon capture technologies, but face criticism from activist groups over their efforts.

site_title: They survived Covid. Now they need new lungs
summary: A wave of COVID-19 survivors are requiring lung transplants due to severe lung damage, with some hospitals considering transplanting patients who were previously healthy. Doctors and families must navigate complex ethical questions about equitable access and defining suitable candidates, as the process can be costly and emotionally taxing. The average survival rate for lung transplant recipients is six years, and the procedure is often met with significant out-of-pocket expenses for patients. Despite these challenges, medical professionals are working to educate and support patients and families, emphasizing the importance of taking steps towards transplant, even if success is uncertain.

site_title: Fresh curbs on social gatherings a blow to hopes of consumer rebound
summary: Singapore has imposed fresh restrictions on social activities amid a growing Covid-19 cluster linked to Tan Tock Seng Hospital. The Health Ministry urges the public to avoid crowds, stay home, and limit social gatherings to two a day. The measures include closing public spaces, reducing occupancy in malls and stores, and slashing the operating capacity of attractions to 50% until May 14. Business leaders acknowledge the restrictions are needed, but warn of short-term business impact, particularly for retailers and the attractions industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.85 points to 1,601.65. Losers outnumbered gainers 582 to 508, and trading volume was 6.752 billion lots worth RM4.614 billion.

site_title: Bitcoin rises 6.54% to US$57,098.08
summary: Bitcoin surged 6.54% to $57,098.08, its highest price since April 14, with a 105.9% gain from its year-low of $27,734. Meanwhile, ether rose 1.06% to $2,787.35. These price movements come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin rose 6.54 per cent to US$57,098.08 on Friday, adding US$3,504.11 to its previous close.

site_title: Singaporean Chew Shou Zi named new CEO of TikTok
summary: TikTok has named Singaporean Chew Shou Zi as its new CEO, replacing Kevin Mayer who left last year. Chew, who joined ByteDance as CFO, will remain in his role and oversee corporate governance and long-term business initiatives. TikTok's interim head, Vanessa Pappas, has been named COO. The move suggests ByteDance is moving towards an IPO of some of its businesses. Chew brings experience from Xiaomi Corp and Goldman Sachs, and has ties to ByteDance founder Zhang Yiming.

images.alt_text: TikTok, the popular short-video app, has named ByteDance chief financial officer Chew Shou Zi as chief executive officer, filling the top leadership position after the departure of Kevin Mayer last year. Vanessa Pappas, who has served as interim head, has been named chief operating officer.

site_title: DBS Research says banks' office downsizing 'less than projected'
summary: DBS Research estimates that major financial institutions will return 0.5 million square feet of office space, less than projected, with 30-40% of that space already backfilled. The brokerage expects banks to convert some space to co-working facilities and notes that the return of space is manageable for the office market. DBS also predicts a positive stance for the Singapore office sector as the economy recovers and reopening begins.

site_title: WHO lists anti-Covid Moderna vaccine for emergency use
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has listed the Moderna anti-Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use, making it the fifth jab to receive this designation. The vaccine has an efficacy of 94.1% and is expected to be produced in large quantities in 2022. The WHO's Strategic Advisory Group of Experts on Immunization (Sage) made this decision to help countries access the vaccine quickly, particularly in poorer countries through the Covax vaccine sharing scheme. This move follows similar approvals for Pfizer BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Serum Institute of India, and Janssen vaccines.

site_title: Sukmawati Widjaja makes S$0.39 per share offer to privatise Top Global
summary: Sukmawati Widjaja, executive director and controlling shareholder of Top Global, has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to privatize the company at S$0.39 per share. As of April 30, she owns 86.96% of the company's shares. The offer, made through her investment holding company, aims to exercise compulsory acquisition rights and delist Top Global from the Singapore Exchange. CIMB believes the offer presents shareholders with an opportunity to realize their investment at a premium over historical trading prices.

site_title: US consumer spending, income rebound in March
summary: US consumer spending rebounded 4.2% in March, driven by a surge in income from pandemic relief, exceeding forecasted 4.1% increase. Personal income jumped 21.1% after declining 7.0% in February, building a strong foundation for consumption growth in the second quarter. This rebound suggests a strong recovery in the US economy, despite previous declines in consumer spending and income.

site_title: India's state is failing its Covid test
summary: India's government is failing to cope with the COVID-19 crisis, leaving citizens to fend for themselves. Despite the country's large economy and vast resources, the government has struggled to provide adequate healthcare, with many hospitals lacking oxygen and ICU beds. In some states, such as Uttar Pradesh, the administration has warned citizens against spreading "rumours" about the shortage of oxygen, while in others, like Kerala and Tamil Nadu, more effective online triage systems have been implemented. The crisis has highlighted the need for a strong and capable government to support the private sector during emergencies.

images.alt_text: Patients suffering from Covid-19 in the ICU ward of a Delhi hospital on April 29. India's capital city has only 5,000 usable ICU beds for its roughly 20 million citizens.

site_title: HK locks down apartment block due to variant Covid-19 case
summary: Hong Kong has locked down a 400-unit apartment building for 21 days after a resident tested positive for a locally acquired case of the Covid-19 N501Y variant. The infected individual, a 39-year-old domestic helper, also infected a 10-month-old baby. Residents are required to undergo Covid tests and serve a three-week quarantine in government centers, even if they test negative. The lockdown is the latest measure to combat the variant, which may help the pathogen resist vaccines and antibody treatments, and has raised concerns about the city's Covid response.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 marks third month of gains on earnings, recovery hopes
summary: European stocks ended the week lower due to dismal GDP data, but marked a third consecutive month of gains on strong corporate earnings and optimism about an economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% and ended the month 1.8% higher, despite a technical recession in the euro zone economy. Strong earnings from companies such as AstraZeneca, Swedish Match, and British American Tobacco drove the gains, with 71% of companies beating profit expectations.

site_title: Fed's key rate slips closer to zero, raising prospect of tweaks
summary: The US Federal Reserve's key benchmark effective fed funds rate dropped to 0.06% for the first time this month, slipping closer to zero. The rate's decline may prompt tweaks to interest rates on excess reserves and the Fed's reverse repurchase agreement facility, despite the main target range remaining unchanged. Officials are open to adjusting administered rates as needed, and recent transactions in fed funds futures suggest a possible upward adjustment by policymakers.

site_title: Oil posts April gain with focus on upcoming demand revival
summary: Oil prices rose 7.5% in April, driven by positive economic data and a potential fuel consumption revival in the US, China, and the UK, despite a worsening coronavirus crisis in countries like India. OPEC and Goldman Sachs predict a rebound in global consumption, with the US leading the demand recovery. However, a resurgent pandemic in India and a strengthening dollar may weigh on prices, with US benchmark crude futures posting their largest daily loss in almost four weeks.

site_title: Nomura's US trading chief Raiff steps down after Archegos loss
summary: Nomura Holdings' US trading chief Jonathan Raiff is stepping down after the Japanese bank lost almost $3 billion on trades with Archegos Capital Management. Raiff, who oversees trading in the Americas, will focus on other projects, while duties will be assumed by Samir Patel, Gordon Sweely, and Richard Volpe. The move follows a series of shakeups at Nomura, including the suspension of several traders and the stepping aside of its global head of credit risk, echoing turmoil at Credit Suisse Group.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings' most senior trader at its US unit is stepping down from his role, the latest shakeup at the Japanese bank after it lost almost US$3 billion on trades with Archegos Capital Management.

site_title: Yale-NUS student tests positive for Covid-19; some students to self-isolate for a week
summary: A Yale-NUS College student has tested positive for Covid-19, according to a circular issued to the college's students and those from the National University of Singapore. The student, from Cendana College, developed flu-like symptoms on Monday and tested positive on Thursday. As a precaution, students in Cendana College Tower A have been told to self-isolate in their rooms for a week, while others are advised to practice safe distancing and monitor their health closely. The college is deep cleaning and disinfecting areas visited by the individual, and close contacts are being identified for quarantine.

site_title: 6.8-magnitude quake rattles northeast Japan, no tsunami risk
summary: A 6.8-magnitude earthquake struck northeast Japan's coast, producing strong shaking, but no tsunami warning was issued. The quake, located 47km deep off Ishinomaki, Miyagi prefecture, was felt in Tokyo but no immediate damage reports were made. Japan's location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire" makes it prone to earthquakes, and the country has strict construction regulations to ensure buildings can withstand strong tremors.

site_title: US personal incomes soar by most on record with fiscal stimulus
summary: US personal incomes surged 21.1% in March, the largest monthly increase on record, driven by pandemic relief checks and increased spending. The 4.2% gain in purchases of goods and services follows a 7% decline in February. The American Rescue Act, signed by President Joe Biden, provided stimulus checks and extended unemployment benefits, boosting transfer receipts and disposable income. The personal savings rate jumped to 27.6% and inflation-adjusted personal spending increased 3.6%. Economists expect sustained price pressures, but Fed officials anticipate temporary inflation.

site_title: Indonesian hospitals boom as Singapore medical tourism hit
summary: Indonesian hospitals are experiencing a surge in demand as Singapore's medical tourism industry remains closed due to the pandemic. PT Siloam International Hospitals reported a record Q4 profit, with a 25% margin for earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization. The hospital's stock has jumped 67% in April, outperforming its rivals. Wealthier Indonesians are opting for local treatment due to a lack of trust in the local system and infrastructure, as well as a shortage of health facilities and medical talent.

site_title: Indonesia to salvage submarine after deadly sinking disaster
summary: Indonesia plans to salvage a submarine, KRI Nanggala 402, that sank off the coast of Bali after a deadly disaster, killing dozens of crew members. The submarine was spotted cracked in three pieces on the seafloor over 800 meters deep. Two ships, including a Chinese vessel, are expected to arrive with equipment for deep-sea salvage operations. Options include using high-powered magnets and air balloons, but the timing and method of recovery are uncertain. The navy is waiting for confirmation before attempting to salvage the submarine, which was last seen losing contact during live torpedo training exercises.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Friday, driven by a record performance on Wall Street. The FTSE 100 index climbed 0.3% to 6,982.23 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.4% and 0.2%, respectively. Despite earlier losses in Asia, investors took cues from the US market, where stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Myanmar to export 2 million tons of rice even as hunger grows
summary: Myanmar plans to export 2 million tons of rice despite warnings from the World Food Programme that millions of people may struggle to afford food due to the ongoing strife and economic crisis. Shipments fell 35% in February to April from the previous year, but the country is still on track to meet its export target. The nation's economy is expected to shrink by 10% this year, and transport difficulties are making it harder for poor people to access domestic food supplies. China remains the largest buyer of Myanmar's rice.

site_title: AstraZeneca says on track to deliver on Covid-19 shots as sales hit US$275m
summary: AstraZeneca reports $275 million in Covid-19 vaccine sales for the first quarter, exceeding expectations. The company is on track to deliver 200 million doses a month starting from April, despite past production and delivery issues. CEO Pascal Soriot defended the vaccine rollout, stating that the company had not overpromised on supply. AstraZeneca's core business has proved resilient, with quarterly sales growth driven by best-selling lung cancer and heart diabetes drugs. The company's shares rose 5.2% following the announcement, with a forecast of no profit from the vaccine during the pandemic period expected to end next year.

site_title: Football icon Maradona was left to 'fate' ahead of death: expert panel
summary: An expert medical panel concluded that Argentine football icon Diego Maradona received inadequate medical care before his death, leaving him to "fate" for a prolonged, agonizing period. Maradona died from a heart attack in November 2020, 12 hours after symptoms began, despite having liver, kidney, and cardiovascular disorders. The panel blames a lack of adequate treatment, "deficiencies and irregularities" in his care, and medical team negligence. The findings could lead to a case of wrongful death and a prison sentence of up to 15 years.

site_title: Biden administration sets new North Korea policy of 'practical' diplomacy
summary: President Joe Biden has adopted a new approach to North Korea policy, focusing on "practical" diplomacy rather than seeking a grand bargain with leader Kim Jong Un. The goal remains complete denuclearization, but the US will pursue a calibrated approach, exploring diplomacy and making practical progress to increase US and ally security. This middle-ground approach differs from the previous policies of Trump and Obama, which failed to achieve breakthroughs or reduce tensions. The Biden administration will discuss this new policy with allies, including South Korea, but has yet to provide details on next steps.

site_title: Food pantries spread in Philippines as virus restrictions bite
summary: Community-run food pantries have proliferated in the Philippines as coronavirus restrictions and limited government assistance exacerbate food insecurity. The pantries, often run by volunteers, provide free food to those in need, including families like Juliet Reyes, who struggles to feed her eight-person household on a daily wage of 200 pesos. With hundreds of thousands of Filipinos thrown out of work, these makeshift pantries are filling a critical gap in support, offering a lifeline to those most affected by the pandemic.

site_title: NTUC sets up foundation with S$250m to fund assistance schemes, grants
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has established a foundation with an initial funding of S$250 million to support its members through financial assistance schemes and grants. The foundation will provide a stable income stream, enabling NTUC to diversify its support and respond to changing member needs. The NTUC foundation aims to boost the welfare, working conditions, and social and economic status of its members, as well as provide education opportunities for lower-income families' children. The foundation will help NTUC take care of its members' needs, even in economically difficult years.

images.alt_text: Labour chief Ng Chee Meng (pictured) said the NTUC foundation will provide a steady stream of income for NTUC's financial assistance schemes and grants.

site_title: Micro-Mechanics Q3 net profit rises 7.9% to S$4.2m
summary: Micro-Mechanics Holdings reported a 7.9% increase in net profit to S$4.2 million for its third quarter ended March 31, 2021, driven by buoyant sales growth in Singapore and China. Revenue rose 9.1% to S$17.7 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of six Singapore cents per share. CEO Chris Borch attributed the results to the global semiconductor industry's positive start in 2021 and the company's strong customer focus and rigorous evaluation process.

site_title: EU aims to cut foreign reliance on chips, pharma materials: document
summary: The European Union aims to reduce its dependency on foreign suppliers in six strategic areas, including raw materials, pharmaceuticals, and semiconductors, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on supply chains. The EU will conduct an in-depth review and consider measures such as diversifying supply, stockpiling, and pooling resources for key projects. The goal is to increase the bloc's competitiveness and resilience in areas like batteries, hydrogen, and cloud technologies, while also setting standards for industries like cybersecurity and space data.

site_title: Indonesian hospitals boom as Singapore medical tourism hit
summary: Indonesian hospitals are experiencing a surge in medical tourism due to the pandemic, with over 1.2 million Indonesians traveling abroad for health checkups annually. As Singapore's borders remain shut, hospitals like PT Siloam International Hospitals are seeing a record influx of patients, with Siloam expecting a 25% margin for earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization in 2021. Wealthier Indonesians are turning to local hospitals due to a lack of trust in the local system and infrastructure. If these hospitals can prove their quality of care, they can retain patients and prevent them from seeking treatments abroad.

site_title: OUELH receives S$249,000 from judgments
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare (OUELH) received approximately S$249,000 from judgments in its legal proceedings, including S$80,000 from Crest Capital Asia, S$50,000 from Ms Lim's solicitors, and S$119,077.54 from her solicitors. OUELH also updated on its legal proceedings, including a request to the Court of Appeal for the return of S$10.7 million by Value Monetization III. Meanwhile, the receivers of a Hong Kong private company prevailed in a dispute with Mr Lin, and OUELH shares closed flat at S$0.041 on Friday.

site_title: Nine new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, four linked to TTSH cluster
summary: Singapore reported 24 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 61,145. Nine community cases were confirmed, including four linked to the TTSH cluster, with measures in place to prevent further transmission. The remaining 15 cases were imported, with 19 arriving on stay-home notices. A fully vaccinated cleaner at a community care facility in Tuas South tested positive, highlighting the possibility of vaccinated individuals getting infected.

site_title: Epicurious has a beef with beef
summary: Epicurious, a popular online recipe bank, has phased out new beef recipes and is phasing out existing ones, citing sustainability concerns as the main reason. The decision, made over a year ago, aims to reduce the site's carbon footprint and promote alternatives such as mushrooms, tofu, and chicken. The move has received mixed reactions online, with some praising the shift and others criticizing it for not going far enough. Existing beef recipes will remain available, and the site plans to continue providing alternatives and promoting sustainable cooking.

images.alt_text: Epicurious' shift means no new recipes for filet or stroganoff, and no brisket, rib-eye, or any primal cuts on its Instagram feed. The future of burgers here looks like turkey, beans, Impossible and Beyond.

site_title: BNP Paribas beats quarterly expectations as equity trading rebounds
summary: BNP Paribas reported a 37.9% increase in net profit to 1.77 billion euros in the first quarter, beating analyst expectations. Revenue rose 8.6% to 11.83 billion euros. The bank's equity trading business rebounded, contributing to the better-than-expected results. The bank aims to expand this business. BNP Paribas' earnings beat forecasts, despite a challenging economic environment.

images.alt_text: France's BNP Paribas on Friday reported a better-than-expected first-quarter profit, helped by lower provisions for pandemic-related bad loans and a rebound in its equity trading business that the bank aims to expand.

site_title: SingapoRediscovers Vouchers scheme to be extended to Dec 31
summary: The SingapoRediscovers Vouchers (SRV) scheme, launched last year, will be extended until December 31, giving Singaporeans six more months to use their vouchers on attractions, tours, and hotel bookings. The extension aims to reduce unnecessary crowding and enable Singaporeans to space out their visits to various attractions amid the pandemic. The vouchers, worth S$100 each, can be redeemed online or at selected community centers. The extension was welcomed by booking partners, including Klook, which will offer more monthly deals and a smoother booking process.

site_title: Mandatory online theory test for e-scooter and e-bike riders to start from June 30: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore will introduce a mandatory online theory test for e-scooter and e-bike riders starting June 30. The test will cover three modules and include multiple-choice questions, aiming to educate riders on active mobility devices, rules, and codes of conduct. The test was proposed after a series of accidents involving mobility devices, and the goal is to ensure all riders know the rules to minimize accidents. The test handbooks have been published online in English, with plans to release them in other languages later.

site_title: Optimism for next six months on the rise in Singapore's manufacturing, services sectors
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors are showing signs of optimism, with a rise in business expectations for the next six months. In the manufacturing sector, 38% of firms expect favorable conditions, the highest reading since 2004. The services sector saw a 11% net weighted balance of optimistic firms, up from 7% in the previous quarter. Electronics and biomedical manufacturing were key drivers of optimism, with electronics seeing a 66% positive outlook and biomedical a 32% positive outlook. Overall, the rise in optimism is seen as a positive sign for the Singapore economy.

site_title: Biden says too-small Republican infrastructure plan would be a non-starter
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that a Republican infrastructure plan with a funding amount of $568 billion, which is only a fraction of his proposed $2.3 trillion package, would be a "non-starter." Biden expressed willingness to continue talks with Republican Senator Shelley Moore Capito, but emphasized that the proposal's funding amount is too low to be considered. Biden said that he would only accept a proposal that covers a significant portion of his plans, and that Republicans' rejection of funding for "human infrastructure" components is a major obstacle to agreement.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall on disappointing tech outlook, pandemic concerns
summary: Japanese shares fell on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 Index declining 0.83% to 28,812.63, and the Topix Index slipping 0.57% to 1,898.24. Disappointing earnings reports from technology firms, including BT and Sony Group, weighed on the market. Concerns over rising Covid-19 infections in Tokyo and Osaka also contributed to the decline. Analysts cited limited upside potential for the market, citing Japan's lagging vaccination rate compared to other countries.

site_title: Japan's ANA Q4 loss almost doubles as Covid slump persists
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings reported a fourth quarter operating loss of 102.37 billion yen (S$1.24 billion), nearly doubling its loss from the same period last year, due to ongoing COVID-19 travel restrictions. The airline's result was worse than estimated, with analysts anticipating a 60 billion yen loss. The slump in demand continues to impact the airline industry, with travel curbs persisting globally.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on China worries
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Friday due to strong foreign sell-off and losses in tech heavyweights. The Kospi closed down 26.21 points, or 0.83%, at 3,147.86, extending losses to a fourth straight session. China's downbeat PMI and concerns about Beijing's internet clampdown weighed on sentiment, with chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix falling 0.24% and 1.54%, respectively. Foreigners were net sellers of $499.94 million worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Audi RS Q8 review: The new King of the 'Ring
summary: The Audi RS Q8 is a high-performance SUV that holds the record for the fastest production SUV to lap the Nurburgring test track, with a lap time of 7:42 minutes. Powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V8 engine producing 592 horsepower, the RS Q8 outperforms the Lamborghini Urus, its sister car from the Volkswagen Group, by five seconds. The SUV offers a luxurious interior, ample space, and advanced features, making it a versatile and desirable option for those seeking a high-performance vehicle.

site_title: StarHub CEO reiterates plans for more enterprise M&A at AGM
summary: StarHub CEO Nikhil Eapen reiterated the company's plans for more enterprise mergers and acquisitions, as part of its ongoing transformation strategy. Eapen emphasized the importance of 5G technology in delivering market-leading experiences. The company expects to see improvements in its mobile business, driven by 5G products and services. Eapen's comments were made during his first annual general meeting since joining the company in January.

site_title: Future Economy Council appoints 16 new members, unveils new structure
summary: The Future Economy Council (FEC) appointed 16 new members and unveiled a new structure at its first meeting of the new term, with a focus on strengthening Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) for the next five years. The ITMs have contributed to Singapore's 2.7% annual labour productivity growth and 3.7% annual median income increase since 2016. The new structure will comprise seven FEC clusters aligned with the Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2025 plan, focusing on jobs and skills, and building on the Emerging Stronger Taskforce's work. The FEC will review and refresh the ITMs to address systemic shifts and seize new opportunities brought about by Covid-19.

site_title: Covid-19 border crossings have changed real estate patterns in South-east Asia: Report
summary: A report by Maybank Kim Eng economists reveals that the COVID-19 pandemic has altered real estate patterns in Southeast Asia, particularly in Singapore, the Philippines, and Thailand. Residents are moving out of central regions due to growing telecommuting, while expatriates are leaving, dampening residential rentals and sales. This shift is expected to weigh on the real estate sector and remittance income, affecting local economies. The report suggests that the pandemic's impact on labor markets is a significant factor in the changing real estate landscape in the region.

site_title: Slack buys Woven to boost calendar app offering
summary: Slack Technologies has acquired Woven, a popular calendar app, to boost its calendar app offering. The terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Woven's CEO, Tim Campos, who previously worked at Facebook, announced the acquisition, stating it was the "best path forward" for his company. The acquisition aims to compete with Google and Microsoft's calendar apps, aligning with Slack's mission to simplify and enhance workplace productivity.

images.alt_text: Slack Technologies has acquired Woven, a popular calendar app, as it adds features to compete with Alphabet Inc's Google and Microsoft Corp.

site_title: New Zealanders face mental health, economic challenges in pandemic recovery
summary: New Zealanders continue to face mental health and economic challenges despite the country's relatively low coronavirus cases and strict lockdowns. The nation is experiencing a 'K-shaped' recovery, where wealth inequalities are widening due to surging property prices and a housing shortage. Economists warn of a prolonged recovery, as New Zealand's strict measures have helped to slow the spread of the virus, but the country's economic and social recovery remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: New Zealanders are still reporting negative impacts on mental health and income from the coronavirus pandemic, despite living in one of the world's few countries to have largely returned to normal.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as traders fail to take up Wall Street baton
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, failing to build on a record performance on Wall Street. The S&P 500 hit a new record despite a slowdown in Chinese factory activity, with growth in the sector slowing last month due to global shipping shortages and supply chain issues. Tech firms in Hong Kong took a hit after China's crackdown on fintech operations. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic about the outlook, citing continued support from fiscal and monetary policy and accelerating corporate earnings.

site_title: Industry Transformation Maps to be refreshed over the next five years
summary: Singapore's Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) will be refreshed over the next five years, with the aim of seizing new opportunities in a post-Covid-19 world. The refreshed maps, dubbed ITM 2025, will incorporate recommendations from the Emerging Stronger Taskforce and focus on research and innovation, jobs, and skills. The effort is part of a broader plan to integrate ITMs with the national Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2025 plans, which invest S$25 billion over five years. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of jobs and skills in helping workers reach their fullest potential.

site_title: MAS commits S$42m to tech-adoption grants for financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has committed S$42 million to a new RegTech grant scheme and enhanced Digital Acceleration Grant (DAG) scheme to accelerate technology adoption in the financial sector. The RegTech grant scheme aims to promote technology solutions in risk management and compliance functions, available to Singapore-based financial institutions. The grants aim to support the adoption of technology in the financial sector and enhance its resilience.

site_title: Singapore bank lending points to 'green shoots' in recovery
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.7% in March to S$691.23 billion, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, with home loans driving the increase. Housing loans grew 0.6% to S$203.92 billion, while consumer loans rose 0.7% to S$263.70 billion. Business loans, however, fell 1.5% year-over-year, with the manufacturing sector showing a 2.8% increase. The Monetary Authority of Singapore sees "green shoots" in the recovery, with modest positive growth expected in the coming months.

site_title: India demand fears, weak Japan crude imports knock oil prices 2%
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Friday, driven by weak Japanese crude imports and concerns over fuel demand in India, where Covid-19 cases have soared. US crude and global benchmark Brent were set for their biggest daily drops in about three weeks, but still on track for monthly gains. India, the world's third-largest oil consumer, is in crisis, while Japan's factory activity expanded despite 25% decline in crude imports in March. The tug of war between summer demand growth prospects and worsening Covid-19 infections continues.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS rises 2.4% to 52-week high after release of Q1 results
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reached a 52-week high after posting a 72% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$2.01 billion for the first quarter. The bank attributed its record performance to sustained inflows into current and savings accounts, as well as broad-based loan growth. Analysts from top research houses, including Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, and JPMorgan, remain bullish on the stock, citing its consistent delivery of best-in-class return on equity and highest multiple in at least two decades.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: South Korean President Moon to visit White House on May 21
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In will visit the White House on May 21 for talks with US President Joe Biden, highlighting the "ironclad alliance" between the two countries. The meeting will focus on strengthening the alliance, denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, and cooperation on global challenges such as climate change and Covid-19. This marks the second in-person summit with a foreign leader of Mr Biden's presidency, following a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga earlier this month. The US is seeking to counter China's rise and abusive market and human rights practices.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Moon Jae In will visit the White House on May 21 for talks with US President Joe Biden, highlighting the "ironclad alliance" between the two countries, the White House said on Thursday.

site_title: AT&T shareholders vote against approving executive compensation
summary: AT&T shareholders voted against approving executive compensation, with 49% casting votes in favor. The total compensation package for Jason Kilar, WarnerMedia's CEO, was over $52 million, more than double that of AT&T CEO John Stankey's $21 million. The vote marked a rejection of the company's executive pay.

site_title: California Disneyland re-opens but you can't hug Mickey Mouse
summary: California Disneyland reopened to California residents on May 1, 2021, with limited capacity and social distancing measures in place due to the coronavirus pandemic. Masks and temperature checks are mandatory, and guests aged 2 and older must wear face masks. Character interactions, such as hugs with Mickey Mouse, are not allowed. The park's reopening comes after the Walt Disney Company closed its theme parks worldwide in March 2020. Despite initial availability issues, tickets to Disneyland are now sold out through mid-June.

site_title: Sunpower Group receives escrow of consideration for divestment of business
summary: Sunpower Group has received an escrow of consideration for the divestment of its manufacturing and services business, Sunpower Technology (Jiangsu), with 10% already escrowed and 86.5% due by April 28. The remaining 3.5% will be escrowed prior to the second tranche's completion date. This follows the divestment for 2.3 billion yuan, with 1.3 billion yuan set to be used for a special dividend. Key executives have also resigned, with new appointments made to the group's leadership.

site_title: US: S&P 500 retreats from record as market digests more earnings
summary: The S&P 500 retreated from its record high as investors weighed data showing a surge in US personal income and mostly solid earnings results from large companies. Personal income surged 21.1% in March, while tech giants like Amazon reported blowout quarterly earnings. However, social media company Twitter plunged 12.5% after announcing weaker-than-expected earnings and disappointing user growth. Analysts say earnings have been strong, but investors expect little upside left for stocks in the near-term.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Friday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower at 9:02am on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,219.23. Advancers outnumbered decliners 70 to 67, with Sembcorp Marine rising 2.3% and Wilmar International gaining 1.5%. ComfortDelGro fell 1.7%. The US markets closed at record highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7%, while European shares fell 0.3% amid rising eurozone bond yields.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS initiates coverage on Q&M with 'buy', 81 S cents target price
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Q&M Dental Group with a "buy" call, assigning a target price of S$0.81. The research house believes Q&M can sustain a high dividend payout ratio of 90% with its asset-light model and strong cash flow generation ability, resulting in an attractive dividend yield of 7.5% in FY2021. Q&M's stock price is undemanding at 14.4 times projected FY2022 earnings.

site_title: Germany orders Deutsche Bank to do more to prevent money laundering
summary: Germany's financial regulator BaFin has ordered Deutsche Bank to implement additional safeguards to prevent money laundering. The move follows a series of lapses and comes after a special auditor was installed in 2018 to oversee progress. BaFin aims to improve controls on customer reviews, correspondent banking, and transactions. Deutsche Bank has acknowledged the need for improvement and is working to comply with the new requirements within a given timeframe. The order is a blow to the bank's efforts to repair its reputation, which has been marred by previous money laundering scandals.

site_title: Gold succumbs to higher yields while palladium continues breaking records
summary: Gold prices fell to a two-week low on Thursday as traders liquidated long positions amid rising global bond yields, despite the US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on emergency support. Palladium prices, however, continued to break records, reaching a new high near $2,965 per ounce due to auto catalyst demand and expectations of further deficits in the metal. China's gold demand rose to 286.4 tonnes in the first quarter of 2021, but is expected to revert to pre-pandemic levels if global economic conditions remain stable.

site_title: Citi asks appeals court to reverse ruling on errant US$500m Transfer
summary: Citi urges a federal appeals court to reverse a ruling allowing Revlon creditors to keep over $500 million mistakenly sent by the bank last summer. The bank claims the court's decision "sent shockwaves through the markets" and expanded an exception to an industry standard. Citi argues that the discharge-for-value defense does not apply regardless of the recipient's notice of the mistake. The bank seeks to overturn the ruling, which was made by US District Judge Jesse Furman in February, and oral arguments are set for August or September.

site_title: First US Covid-19 emergency aid supplies arrive in India
summary: The US has delivered its first emergency Covid-19 aid supplies to India, consisting of over 400 oxygen cylinders and nearly 1 million rapid coronavirus tests. The shipment, worth over $100 million, was transported from California and is part of a larger international aid operation responding to India's record-breaking infection rate of over 370,000 cases per day. The US and India have been in talks, with US President Joe Biden and Prime Minister Narendra Modi discussing the aid delivery. The US plans to continue special flights with additional aid in the coming days.

site_title: China factory activity edges down in April
summary: China's factory activity slowed in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 51.1, slightly lower than in March but still above the 50-point mark. A global shortage of shipping containers hindered the movement of goods, causing chip shortages, blockages in logistics, and rising freight rates. However, import and export indexes expanded for two straight months, and the outlook for smaller businesses is positive, with production and new orders increasing. The non-manufacturing PMI fell to 54.9, with the services industry continuing its recovery.

site_title: On top of zero-emission vehicles, GM looks to clean up its own operations
summary: General Motors (GM) has set new sustainability goals, targeting the elimination of tailpipe emissions from all light vehicles by 2035 and a 35% reduction in operational energy intensity by 2035. The company also aims to divert 90% of waste sent to landfills and increase returnable packaging by 2030. Additionally, GM plans to source 100% renewable energy for its US sites by 2030 and global sites by 2035, five years ahead of its previous goal.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.35% lower on Friday, April 30, 2021, due to subdued trading amid Japan's Golden Week holidays. The benchmark index closed at 28,953.08. In contrast, the broader Topix Index gained 0.06% to 1,910.12. This decline was attributed to investors avoiding active trading during the holidays.

site_title: Singapore's outlook brighter this year, global recession less protracted than initially feared: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economic outlook has brightened, with the global recession expected to be less protracted than initially feared. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said external trends support the Republic's economic recovery, with the country's unemployment rate gradually coming down and gross domestic product growth expected to exceed 6% this year. The government is transforming the economy to capitalize on post-pandemic trends, including digitalization and sustainability. Lee also praised the National Trades Union Congress for its collaborative stance during the crisis, ensuring fair retrenchments and job placements.

site_title: Japan's March factory output rebounds as car production jumps
summary: Japan's industrial output increased 2.2% in March, driven by a sharp jump in car production, easing concerns about the economic impact of the coronavirus. The jobless rate fell to 2.6% and the average number of available jobs per applicant rose slightly, indicating strength in employment conditions. The government's assessment of industrial production remains unchanged, with manufacturers expecting output to rise another 8.4% in April. However, a third state of emergency in Tokyo may hurt the services sector and slow domestic demand.

site_title: Harvey Weinstein extradition delayed, new challenge expected
summary: Harvey Weinstein's extradition to California on rape and sexual assault charges has been delayed, with a new 30-day challenge expected. The California court granted prosecutors 30 days to file new extradition paperwork, which may speed up the process due to Weinstein's opposition to the earlier paperwork. Weinstein, serving a 23-year prison term in New York, plans to file a new legal challenge and may seek Governor Andrew Cuomo's intervention. Weinstein faces up to life in prison if convicted of the 11-count indictment in California, which concerns alleged attacks on five women from 2004 to 2013.

site_title: Twitter shares crushed after disappointing quarterly results
summary: Twitter shares plummeted 11% in after-hours trade following the company's disappointing quarterly results, with profit rising to $68 million and revenues growing 28% to $1.04 billion. However, user growth fell short of expectations at 199 million, and weaker guidance for the next quarter sparked concerns about the platform's growth. Despite this, analysts noted that Twitter's performance was better than the market reaction suggested, with some praising the company's efforts to improve its product and address misinformation.

site_title: Australia: Beach Energy drags shares lower, Mesoblast limits losses
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 7,042.1, driven by a 20% drop in Beach Energy and 2% decline in gold stocks. The energy sub-index was 1.3% lower despite rising oil prices. Mesoblast shares rose 9% after trial data showed its Covid-19 treatment reduced mortality in under-65 patients. Financial stocks fell 0.4%, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group losing 0.3% due to exposure to the Malaysia 1MBD scandal.

site_title: Amazon caps blockbuster Big Tech earnings reports
summary: Amazon reported a 44% increase in revenue to $108.5 billion, with profit tripling to $8.1 billion, driven by pandemic-revived online shopping and growing reliance on internet-hosted services. The company's cloud computing unit, Amazon Web Services, saw revenue climb to $13.5 billion. The strong earnings report comes as Big Tech companies, including Apple, Facebook, and Google, also reported soaring quarterly profits, sparking calls for increased regulation and stronger antitrust enforcement to counter economic inequality.

site_title: Hin Leong's OK Lim charged with 23 counts of forgery-related offences
summary: Singaporean tycoon OK Lim, 79, has been charged with 23 counts of forgery-related offences, including 12 counts under Section 468 and 11 counts under Section 465 of the Penal Code. The charges, brought by prosecutors, allegedly involve Lim instigating or conspiring with a former employee to forge certificates and cheat investors between June 2019 and March 2020. Lim's court bail was extended to S$3 million, and he will appear in court again on June 24.

images.alt_text: Singapore tycoon Lim Oon Kuin finally showed up at the State Courts on Friday, after three previous adjournments, and was charged by Singapore prosecutors with 23 counts of forgery-related offences.

site_title: FEHT Q1 net property income falls 8.4% on lower gross revenue
summary: Far East Hospitality Trusts (FEHT) reported a 6.9% decline in gross revenue to S$21.3 million in Q1 2021, and a 8.4% decline in net property income to S$18.2 million. Despite lower occupancies in serviced residences, the hotel segment performed above fixed rent. The trust's finance expenses decreased by 21.4% due to short-term interest rates, and income available for distribution was S$12.5 million. FEHT expects muted average new room supply from 2021 to 2024, but remains optimistic on vaccine rollouts and international travel recovery.

site_title: ANZ warns of profit hit from AmBank exposure to 1MDB scandal
summary: ANZ has warned of a profit hit from its exposure to the 1MDB scandal, with a A$817 million loss from its 24% stake in AmBank. The bank also announced a A$251 million write-down on its share investment business and A$108 million for customer refunds. ANZ had previously warned of a A$212 million write-down in March. The scandal involves the alleged theft of US$4.5 billion from 1Malaysia Development Berhad, a state fund set up by former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate falls to 2.6% in March: government
summary: Japan's jobless rate fell to 2.6% in March, beating the median forecast of 2.9%. The jobs-to-applicants ratio improved to 1.10, up from 1.09 in the previous month. This marks the second consecutive month of declining unemployment.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Wilmar, FEHT, MIT, Yangzijiang, Japfa, FHT
summary: DBS posted a 72% year-on-year net profit rise to S$2.01 billion for Q1 2021, beating Refinitiv's estimate. Wilmar International's net profit doubled to US$450.2 million, setting a record for the group's first-quarter results since its listing. FEHT's Q1 2021 gross revenue declined 6.9% to S$21.3 million, while MIT posted a 15.8% year-on-year increase in DPU to 3.30 Singapore cents. Japfa's net profit rose 37% to US$48.5 million, driven by a 16% increase in revenue.

site_title: US cruise ships could sail again by July: CDC
summary: US health authorities have announced new guidelines allowing cruise ships to resume sailing from Florida ports by mid-July, provided they meet requirements of at least 98% crew and 95% passenger vaccination against Covid-19. Cruise lines, including Norwegian, Carnival, and Royal Caribbean, have been asked to submit plans to maintain the July timeline. The multi-billion dollar industry, which employs thousands in Florida, has been shut down since March 2020 due to the pandemic. A return to normal activity is expected by 2025, according to industry expert Didier Arino.

site_title: FAA to audit Boeing's 'minor' design changes after latest MAX issue
summary: US air safety regulators are auditing Boeing's procedures for making "minor" design changes to planes amid the latest issue with its 737 MAX, following a grounding of over 100 planes due to an electrical problem. The Federal Aviation Administration's review aims to improve Boeing's processes, following a congressional investigation that criticized the agency's oversight. Boeing has been working on modifications to address the issue, with the FAA releasing an airworthiness directive and the company preparing to provide service bulletins to airlines once approved.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off Friday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.55% to 29,143.43. This decline comes despite a record performance on Wall Street and positive US economic data. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also dropped, with the latter easing 0.20%. The losses are attributed to investors' uncertainty amid tariff threats.

site_title: US to ban menthol cigarettes
summary: The US FDA announced plans to ban menthol cigarettes, citing studies that show menthol facilitates progression to regular smoking, particularly among youths and young adults. The ban is expected to save hundreds of thousands of lives, as 85% of Black smokers and 30% of white smokers use menthol cigarettes. The measure will not apply to e-cigarettes, and proposed rules are expected to be published within a year. The ban aims to reduce racial disparities in health and address tobacco's leading cause of preventable deaths in the US.

site_title: Spending on cloud computing hits US$42b worldwide: tracker
summary: US spending on cloud computing reached a record high of $41.8 billion in the recently ended quarter, with a 27% increase from the same period last year, according to market tracker Canalys. Cloud infrastructure services saw a $11 billion surge, with Amazon Web Services leading the market with 32% market share, followed by Microsoft's Azure and Google Cloud. Despite this growth, most businesses have yet to undergo "digital transformation," with Canalys analyst Blake Murray expecting continued migration to the cloud as confidence in the economy improves.

site_title: China warns US against imposing democratic ideals
summary: China warned the US against imposing its democratic ideals, criticizing trade sanctions and military moves in Beijing's backyard. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said the US should engage in competition through diplomacy, not conflict. China also criticized US trade practices, including subsidies for state-owned enterprises and intellectual property theft. The US had maintained a strong military presence in the Indo-Pacific, prompting China to oppose increased US warships and reconnaissance aircraft activity in its maritime territory. China vowed to resist such moves and promote stability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.89 points, or 0.18%, to 1,611.39 as of 9:06am on Friday, driven by gains in 275 stocks over 151. Volume reached 329.69 million lots worth RM178.69 million.

site_title: First case of Covid Indian variant detected in France: health agency
summary: A case of the Indian Covid-19 variant has been detected in mainland France, according to a regional health agency director. The individual had recently returned from India, contradicting an earlier statement from the Health Minister that no such case had been found. This marks the first case of the Indian variant in France.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding posts 89% year-on-year jump in Q1 net profit
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 89% year-on-year increase in Q1 net profit to 761.73 million yuan, despite a 25% decline in revenue to 2.62 billion yuan. The company's core shipbuilding revenue fell to 1.8 billion yuan due to lower shipbuilding activities, despite delivering 12 vessels in the two quarters.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record on strong earnings after volatile session
summary: The S&P 500 finished at a record high on Thursday, ending with a 0.7% gain, after strong earnings from tech giants Apple and Facebook offset concerns about market growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with the Nasdaq advancing 0.2%. Strong US economic data and low jobless claims contributed to the gains, but concerns about "peak" growth and potential supply chain problems led to declines in Caterpillar and ride-hailing companies Lyft and Uber.

site_title: Are spiking community cases going to deflate Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble?
summary: Singapore has reported a spike in COVID-19 community cases, prompting concerns about the relaunch of its air travel bubble with Hong Kong. The bubble was initially set to resume on May 26, but recent cases in Singapore may lead to a delay or deflation of the arrangement. Experts warn that the bubble's fragile nature and the risk of long-term consequences make it premature to conclude its viability. The seven-day average of unlinked community cases must be five or fewer for the bubble to proceed.

site_title: Few takers for business event venues despite raised capacity cap
summary: Despite the loosening of business event capacity restrictions in Singapore, only a few event venues have seen actual bookings for physical meetings. The main reasons cited by hotel and venue operators include the cost and hassle of pre-event testing, continued border closures, and restrictions on mingling and capacity. Only two hotels out of 10 contacted reported an increase in venue bookings, with larger venues such as Resorts World Sentosa and Marina Bay Sands receiving more enquiries but declining to provide specifics. Venue operators remain cautious, with many companies pivoting to hybrid events as an alternative solution.

site_title: Gig companies oppose US push for worker employee status, suggest compromise
summary: Gig economy companies, including Uber, Lyft, and DoorDash, oppose the US push to reclassify their workers as employees, citing concerns over the impact on their business model. The companies suggest a compromise, proposing additional benefits for workers while maintaining their independent contractor status. US Labour Secretary Marty Walsh has intensified the debate, stating that many gig workers should be classified as employees, which would jeopardize the companies' business model. The gig workers' group Gig Workers Rising calls for regulators to step in and protect working people, while the companies' proposal has been met with criticism from labour groups.

site_title: Oil climbs to fresh six-week high on bullish demand
summary: Oil prices rose to fresh six-week highs, with Brent futures increasing 1.9% to $68.56 a barrel and US WTI crude rising 1.8% to $65.01 a barrel. Strong US economic data, a weak dollar, and expected demand recovery outweighed concerns about higher Covid-19 cases in Brazil and India. Analysts predict record-high oil demand over the northern hemisphere summer months, driven by vaccination campaigns in North America and Europe.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: A new exhibition 'A Table' at the Alliance Francaise showcases French dining culture with exquisite table settings, historical menus, etiquette workshops, and gourmet-themed movies. The event features a curated list of gourmet food and drinks, including champagne and wine tastings. The exhibition ends on May 3. Meanwhile, Raffles Hotel's Tiffin Room has teamed up with Meatsmith Little India for a limited four hands gig, blending authentic North Indian specialties with modern South American-influenced spicy bites until May 6.

site_title: US dollar trades just off 9-week lows on dovish Fed
summary: The US dollar traded near nine-week lows against a basket of currencies due to the Federal Reserve's dovish outlook and the White House's spending plans. Despite a strong US economy, the dollar was negatively impacted by a record trade deficit and rising imports. The euro surged to its highest level since late February, while the dollar shed gains against the yen and Norwegian crown. The Fed's decision to keep asset buying also reduced expectations of an early tapering, further weakening the dollar.

site_title: Japfa Q1 net profit rises 37% to US$48.5m
summary: Japfa, an industrialised agri-food company, reported a 37% rise in net profit to US$48.5 million in Q1 2021, driven by revenue growth of 16% to US$1.1 billion. The company's segments contributed to the growth, with PT Japfa Tbk's operating profit more than doubling to US$101.4 million due to stabilised poultry prices in Indonesia, and its Animal Protein Other segment seeing a 11.8% increase in operating profit due to strong results from its swine operations in Vietnam.

site_title: Refinancing to surge with record Asia bonds due
summary: A record $1.8 trillion worth of bonds are set to mature in Asia this year, leading to a surge in refinancing and a fee bonanza for banks. Most of the maturing bonds are from China, South Korea, Australia, and India, with dollar bonds of $283.4 billion being the highest on record. Despite caution over Chinese issuers and growing risk in markets like India, banks are expected to benefit from the refinancing surge, with some analysts predicting a modest increase in new issuance.

site_title: India Covid deaths surge again, more global aid flown in
