summary: India's COVID-19 death toll surged to over 3,600 on Thursday, with 379,257 new cases reported, a global record. The country's total cases surpassed 18 million. The pandemic has claimed at least 3.1 million lives worldwide, with India accounting for over 200,000 fatalities. International aid, including test kits from the US, has been flown in to support India's vaccination efforts, which will be expanded to all adults starting Saturday. The World Health Organization has confirmed the virus variant contributing to India's crisis has been found in over a dozen countries.

site_title: Good value Japanese menus at Fukui
summary: A new Japanese restaurant, Fukui, has opened in Singapore offering good value menus at digestible prices. The elegant eatery serves serviceable omakase, allowing diners to relive memories of Japan without needing to travel. Located at Mohamed Sultan Road, Fukui is open for lunch and dinner from Monday to Saturday. The restaurant's concept is inspired by the Sea of Japan and its famous echizen crabs.

images.alt_text: The sashimi platter features fresh, medium quality fish and shellfish beautifully composed on ceramic platters.
Smoky 'warayaki' butterfish that's adequately fleshy and oily drizzled in a soy dressing with a hint of truffle oil and scattering of black truffle shavings.
Otoro and uni sushi.
Mini chirashi sushi - thick slabs of seafood covering a small amount of rice.

site_title: Tudor Black Bay gets bigger and better for 2021
summary: Tudor has introduced several new models to its Black Bay collection for 2021, including the Black Bay Chrono to commemorate the golden anniversary of the Oysterdate chronograph. The new models feature the brand's first use of gold and silver in divers' watches, with the Black Bay Fifty-Eight 925 Silver being the first silver diver watch and the Black Bay Fifty-Eight 18K in gold. The collection also includes new silver-dialed versions of the Black Bay 41, 36, and 32 models.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip on high yields and profit-taking; banks rally
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% to 438.77, despite bank shares hitting 14-month highs on strong quarterly earnings, due to a rise in euro zone bond yields. The sector rally was driven by US economic growth and German inflation data, but cyclical stocks such as travel and leisure fell 0.7%. Earnings are expected to jump 71.3% in the first quarter, with a majority of reported firms sounding constructive on the outlook for the remainder of the year.

site_title: NTUC on big drive to draw more PMEs to unions
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore is launching a drive to increase union membership among professionals, managers and executives (PMEs), a group currently under-represented in the labour movement. The PME taskforce has reached out to 8,000 PMEs, citing concerns of job security and lack of employment opportunities. The NTUC aims to enhance support for PMEs, particularly mature ones, and is exploring ideas such as "ring-fencing" certain jobs to protect local talent. The labour movement is also stepping up support for lower-wage workers and those in the gig economy.

site_title: Tokyo consumer prices slide as lower cellphone fees weigh on inflation
summary: Tokyo consumer prices fell 0.2% year-on-year in April, driven by a 26.5% decline in cellphone charges, according to government data. The decrease, which includes a 0.44% point drop in the Tokyo CPI, raises concerns about a potential return to deflation. The central bank's 2% inflation target appears elusive, and analysts warn that lower cellphone fees may exert downward pressure on prices. The Bank of Japan also expects prices to drop further in the summer months.

images.alt_text: Tokyo consumer prices fell unexpectedly in April due to cuts in mobile phone fees by major carriers, government data showed on Friday, making the central bank's 2 per cent inflation target appear even more elusive.

site_title: 35 new Covid cases on Thurs, including 16 community cases
summary: There were 35 new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 61,121. 16 cases are community cases, linked to a Filipino nurse at Tan Tock Seng Hospital and a family of an ICA officer at Changi Airport. 19 imported cases are in quarantine. 32 ICA officers are under quarantine order after being in close contact with a positive case, while 100 will be tested.

site_title: US SEC probes VW 'Voltswagen' marketing stunt: source
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has launched an inquiry into Volkswagen AG's US unit over a marketing stunt in which the company falsely claimed it was changing its name to "Voltswagen" to highlight its electric vehicle efforts. The initial statement was widely reported and sparked criticism, but Volkswagen apologized and claimed it was a "gag" intended to bring humor and attention to its electrification focus. The investigation is the latest in a series of controversies for the company, which previously admitted to using illegal software in diesel engine tests in the US.

images.alt_text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into the US unit of Volkswagen's AG over a marketing stunt in which it falsely said it was changing its name in the United States to "Voltswagen," a person briefed on the matter confirmed.

site_title: European office landlord offers gyms, concierges as post-pandemic perks
summary: Nuveen Real Estate, a European office landlord, plans to offer firms perks such as concierges and gyms to attract tenants in the post-pandemic workspace. The company is launching a new pan-European office operating platform with BNP Paribas to overhaul its relationships with tenants. This move recognizes the shift towards flexibility and services, accelerated by the pandemic. By asking tenants what they want, Nuveen aims to provide a more personalized experience, blurring the lines between landlord and tenant. The platform will take over the management of the Devonshire Square office estate from WeWork.

site_title: China seeks to quash reports of shrinking population
summary: China's population grew last year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics, contradicting reports of a decline. The bureau delayed publishing the results of the 2020 census, citing preparatory work, but said the population continued to grow. Births in China have fallen 15% since 2019, but the 2020 growth may be measured from 2019 or 2010, leaving the exact population figure uncertain. The delay in publishing census results has sparked speculation about a potential decline in population, which could lead to pressure on Beijing to encourage people to have more children.

site_title: Samsung reclaims smartphone crown from Apple; Xiaomi surges
summary: Samsung regained its position as the world's largest smartphone producer, accounting for a fifth of global sales in Q1, with 21.2 million units shipped. China's Xiaomi surged with a 62% increase in shipments to 49 million units, taking the third spot. Global sales rose 27% to 347 million units, driven by China's reopening and vaccine roll-outs, with Apple and Samsung competing for market share.

site_title: Global chip shortage hits Apple, BMW, Ford as crisis worsens
summary: The global chip shortage is worsening, affecting major automakers like BMW, Ford, and Honda, as well as tech giants Apple and Samsung Electronics. Production cuts and lost revenue are expected, with some companies predicting a decline in earnings due to the crisis. The shortage is forcing the car industry to cut output, leaving thin inventories at dealerships, and may last into next year, according to analysts. The shortage is also threatening the smartphone market, with worldwide shipments expected to slow down in the coming quarters.

site_title: Blackstone puts 100m euros of European warehouses up for sale
summary: Blackstone is selling approximately 100 million euros (S$161 million) of European urban warehouse properties from its Mileway unit, a move to streamline the business and focus on urban warehouses. The properties, mostly small Nordic assets, were acquired through larger portfolios and will be sold to a buyer via Savills. This sale follows Blackstone's rapid expansion of Mileway, which is now valued at over 10 billion euros. The move aligns with the firm's strategy of concentrating on urban warehouses, a key bet for sustained demand and rising rents.

site_title: Battered US office market perks up with workers trickling back
summary: US office market sees a surge in demand, with national demand jumping 28% in March and reaching 91% of pre-pandemic levels. About 26% of office workers returned to their desks in major cities by April 21, with companies like Exxon Mobil and JPMorgan Chase setting plans for full-time returns. The rise in office occupancy is attributed to easing social distancing rules, vaccines, and cheaper rents. Despite varying rates of occupancy across regions, signs of a revival are emerging, with tech companies like Apple and Facebook reopening offices, and Wall Street firms eyeing a return to Manhattan.

site_title: IBM to acquire software provider Turbonomic
summary: IBM has agreed to acquire Turbonomic, a software provider that helps companies monitor business application performance, for between $1.5 billion and $2 billion. The deal, valued at $1.5 billion to $2 billion, is IBM's largest since its $34 billion acquisition of Red Hat in 2019. Turbonomic's software boosts application performance and compliance in real-time. The transaction is IBM's 11th acquisition since CEO Arvind Krishna took office last year, and it follows the company's expansion into the cloud and AI markets.

site_title: Demand for gold in Asia surges in Q1
summary: Demand for gold in Asia surged in Q1, driven by a relaxation of lockdowns and lower prices, helping counter large-scale sales. The World Gold Council's report found a boost in jewellery and coin demand. Despite a 14% drop from the all-time peak, the current price of US$1,780 an ounce is still attractive. This increase counters investment and speculative sales, indicating a shift in Asian consumer preferences.

site_title: US economy accelerates in Q1 and jobless claims edge lower
summary: The US economy accelerated in Q1, with a 6.4% annualized GDP growth rate, the second-fastest since 2003. The growth was fueled by massive government aid to households and businesses, and easing pandemic anxiety. Despite this, the economy remains a couple of years away from fully recovering from the pandemic recession. The Federal Reserve has acknowledged the growing domestic activity but has not signaled a reduction in its support. Economists forecast the economy will fully recover by late 2023, with potential growth topping 7% this year.

site_title: 10 New York state wines to drink now
summary: New York state wines have evolved rapidly over the last 20 years, particularly in the Finger Lakes and Long Island regions. The Finger Lakes is known for its exceptional cool-climate wines, such as Riesling and Cabernet Franc, while Long Island's maritime climate makes it challenging to produce full-bodied wines. Recent producers have shifted towards more moderate styles, offering wines like Pinot Blanc and Chenin Blanc. Notable wines include Red Tail Ridge's Blaufränkisch, Bloomer Creek's White Horse Red, and Ravines' Argetsinger Vineyard Dry Riesling.

site_title: DBS sets pace for peers as record Q1 profit shrugs off Covid-19 pain
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a record Q1 profit of S$2.01 billion, a 72% year-over-year rise, beating Refinitiv's estimate. The bank expects to cut its physical footprint by 20% as it moves towards a hybrid work model. DBS is open to acquiring assets, including Citi's, and is upgrading its full-year loan growth and fee income targets. The bank's shares rose to a 52-week high on the results, with CEO Piyush Gupta pointing to China's Greater Bay Area as an important part of the bank's franchise. DBS has also announced plans for an initial public offering (IPO) in China.

images.alt_text: DBS Group trumped market estimates on Friday with a 72 per cent rise in quarterly profit after a strong all-round-performance by South-east Asia's largest bank.

site_title: Japan business leaders suggest ways for government to speed up vaccination rate
summary: Japan's business leaders and a biologist have urged the government to reform its vaccination program to speed up inoculation rates amid the country's slow vaccination pace. Japan has only inoculated 1.6% of its population, with only 20% of imported vaccine doses used. The leaders propose simplifying vaccine application procedures, allowing drive-through inoculations, and using private-sector expertise to manage vaccination records. They also suggest large-scale facilities to administer vaccines. The government has not commented on the proposals, which come as Japan prepares for the summer Olympics.

site_title: US economy is stronger, but it's not yet time for policy shift: Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve has maintained its stance on keeping monetary policy loose, despite the US economy showing signs of recovery and pandemic risks easing. The Fed wants to avoid rolling back emergency support until employment and inflation goals are met, citing ongoing joblessness and a long way to go to achieve the 2% inflation target. The central bank has left interest rates and bond buying unchanged, and will continue to monitor the economy, with the possibility of discussing policy changes as early as the June meeting if economic indicators continue to improve.

site_title: ECB set to adopt hybrid home-office work post-pandemic, says Lagarde
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to adopt a hybrid work model, combining home- and office-based work, after the pandemic, according to ECB President Christine Lagarde. This approach acknowledges the effectiveness of remote work while recognizing the importance of in-person interactions. Lagarde stated that a mix of both will be implemented, as seen in some major banks and companies, such as Deutsche Bank, which is considering a flexible return-to-office policy. The decision aims to balance productivity and employee well-being.

images.alt_text: The ECB president acknowledges that the crisis has shown how much can be done remotely.

site_title: Liberals, stop getting cozy with corporations
summary: Republican senators have issued warnings to corporate America, urging them to stay out of politics and avoid backlash for "woke" policies. Senators Mitch McConnell, Rick Scott, and Marco Rubio have made these statements amid corporations' efforts to counter anti-democratic laws, such as Georgia's voter turnout limit. In response, dozens of executives have convened a conference call to discuss how to push back against these laws, indicating a growing divide between big business and the right. This move reflects the intensifying battle between corporate interests and conservative politicians over issues like politics and civic engagement.

site_title: Hybrid work drives a new employer-employee reality
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to the emergence of hybrid work, a new work arrangement that combines work at the office and remote work. Employers must evolve workplace culture and supercharge employees' performance by understanding their needs, providing the right technology and support, and prioritizing transparency and flexibility. A recent survey found that employees struggle with accessing internal resources, in-person communication, and training, highlighting the importance of employers' oversight and support. To succeed, leaders must equip and empower employees, set expectations, and foster a positive employee-employer relationship.

site_title: Dispute over Mirazur chef's Singapore presence leaves sour taste for some diners
summary: A dispute arose among Mandala Club members in Singapore over Mirazur chef Mauro Colagreco's cameo-only appearance at a pop-up event. The chef will only be in Singapore for the opening two weeks, with his team handling the operation afterwards. Members had initially been informed that Colagreco would be present for the full three-month event, leading to calls for refunds. The club management honored the requests, citing a perceived lack of transparency. Despite this, the event remains popular, with over 90% of seats sold.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article content provided for a summary.

site_title: Manulife CEO embraces flexible schedules, unhurried return to office
summary: Manulife CEO Roy Gori has expressed no urgency to bring employees back to the office, instead opting for flexible schedules that allow them to work from home. The company will continue to invest in technology to maintain productivity while employees work remotely. Even when workers return, firms are signaling a shift towards flexible work environments, with companies like HSBC reducing business travel and office footprints. Manulife has preserved its culture by providing perks and virtual events, resulting in an annual engagement survey placing it in the top quartile among financial firms.

site_title: This Labour Day, choose how you want to connect to your job
summary: Singaporeans increasingly prefer working remotely, with 8 in 10 preferring to work from home or have more flexibility. However, research shows that remote work arrangements can lead to a decrease in mental well-being, with workers feeling more stressed and having to be available for work-related tasks during personal time. To reconcile these findings, employees need perceived psychological control over their work-life boundaries, allowing them to be productive without affecting their mental health negatively. Flexible work policies can be tailored to meet individual preferences, with interactive team calendars and virtual meetings that respect personal time.

site_title: Biden embraces comparisons with Roosevelt
summary: US President Joe Biden has outlined ambitious plans to transform the nation, drawing comparisons with Franklin D. Roosevelt's crisis management approach. Biden emphasized job creation, supporting families, and education, unveiling a bill to replace lead pipes, build electrical transmission lines, and expand public education. He also pledged to maintain a strong military presence and champion human rights, racial justice, and gender equality. The plans have been met with skepticism from Republicans, but economists note the Standard & Poor's 500 has risen by over 10% since Biden took office, the largest gain of any president's first 100 days.

site_title: HSBC starts service in Singapore, Hong Kong for Asia family offices
summary: HSBC has launched a new institutional family office service in Hong Kong and Singapore, catering to Asian family offices. The service offers financing solutions and product capabilities, including institutional market access and private deals. This move aims to enable Asian families to invest sustainably, as demand for sustainable investment solutions grows. The service blends HSBC's family office and wealth planning strengths with its investment banking expertise, following Singapore's continued growth as a wealth centre.

site_title: Haute highlights
summary: The article showcases three luxury watches: IWC's Big Pilot's Watch Perpetual Calendar, Hublot's Big Bang Integral Tourbillon Full Sapphire, and Montblanc's 1858 Geosphere Limited Edition 1858. The Big Pilot's Watch Perpetual Calendar features a 46.2mm stainless case with a Pellaton winding system and a price of 31,000 Swiss francs. The Big Bang Integral Tourbillon Full Sapphire boasts a 43mm sapphire case and a price of US$422,000. The Montblanc 1858 Geosphere Limited Edition 1858 combines a world-time complication with a bronze case and a price of US$7,000.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Kimly Limited has entered a joint venture agreement to manage two coffee shops in Bukit Batok and Serangoon North for S$1.86 million. CSE Global secured S$106.2 million in new orders for the first quarter of 2021, a 50.3% increase in the infrastructure sector. Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager is being sold to ARA Asset Management for a 50% stake and 5% units. SBS Transit appointed BOB Tan as chairman of the board, replacing Lim Jit Poh.

site_title: SPACs: When retail investors ride with private equity
summary: Special Purpose Acquisition Vehicles (SPACs) allow retail investors to tap into private equity opportunities, offering access to previously exclusive markets. However, this shift also increases risks. The article explores the blurred lines between private and public markets, and the risks associated with these new instruments. It also touches on other topics, including the energy transition, private equity returns, and emerging trends in the automotive and lifestyle sectors. The article concludes that while SPACs offer potential for outsized returns, investors must carefully consider the associated risks.

site_title: China's April factory activity growth expected to slow
summary: China's factory activity is expected to grow at a slightly slower pace in April, with a median forecast of 51.7 for the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI), down from 51.9 in March. Despite this, the economy is expected to maintain momentum as it recovers from Covid-19 disruptions internationally. Profits at industrial firms nearly doubled in March, driven by demand for raw materials, but higher costs are putting pressure on some enterprises. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: India's first 3D-printed home offers affordable housing solution
summary: India has successfully built its first 3D-printed home, a single-storey residence measuring 56 square meters, in collaboration with Habitat for Humanity's Terwilliger Center for Innovation in Shelter. The affordable housing solution, built by Tvasta Manufacturing Solutions, promises to be quicker, cheaper, and more efficient than traditional construction. This innovative technology may help address India's shortage of affordable housing, offering a potential solution for the country's growing housing needs.

site_title: Will warehouse supply keep pace with demand?
summary: Warehouse supply faces pressure to meet growing demand, with some areas experiencing shortages. The US saw a rise in mortgage rates, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches may test demand for prime projects above $3,000 per square foot. Additionally, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. These trends indicate a shift in the real estate market, with increasing competition for limited supply.

site_title: Sarine Technologies says no material impact currently from India's Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Sarine Technologies reported that the current Covid-19 outbreak in India has not had a material impact on its business, with only a 5% absence of workers due to illness or quarantine. The company expects no significant impact in May, as India's summer shutdown typically lasts two to three weeks. Sarine is adhering to health directives and curtailing travel to and from India, citing strong demand for diamond jewellery in the US and Asia-Pacific regions.

site_title: Sarine Technologies says no material impact currently from India's Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Sarine Technologies, a Singapore-listed company, reports that the current Covid-19 outbreak in India has had no material impact on its business. The company's workforce has been affected by around 5% of its workers being absent due to illness or quarantine, but this has not significantly affected operations. Despite the outbreak, Sarine Technologies remains confident in its business prospects.

site_title: Mastercard gains as vaccines help consumers get back on the road
summary: Mastercard reported a 4% increase in net revenue to $4.2 billion in the first quarter, surpassing analyst estimates. The company's overseas spending fees declined 23% to $932 million, smaller than expected. The rebound in travel and domestic spending, fueled by the return of consumers to the road, drove the growth. Mastercard's overall spending on its cards rose 10% to $1.3 trillion, boosted by stimulus payments and a 27% surge in debit volume.

site_title: StanChart Q1 profit beats forecasts on recovery from Covid-19
summary: Standard Chartered posted a higher-than-expected 18% rise in quarterly pre-tax profit, driven by reduced bad loan provisions and strong performance in its wealth management business. The bank's pre-tax profit reached $1.4 billion, beating analyst forecasts. Despite a 32% decline in cash management division income, StanChart's wealth management business saw a 21% increase in income, and the bank expects similar income to 2020 and growth in 2022.

images.alt_text: One bright spot for StanChart is its often underperforming wealth management business, which saw a record quarter with income up 21 per cent.

site_title: Take comfort in history: Vaccine hesitancy is as old as vaccines
summary: The article highlights that vaccine hesitancy has been a recurring issue throughout history, with critics arguing that immunization is more dangerous than the disease itself. Despite this, vaccination campaigns have consistently succeeded, as seen in the case of smallpox, which was eradicated in 1980. The article cites examples of successful vaccination efforts, including the British Vaccination Act of 1840 and the introduction of compulsory vaccination laws in the US. It also notes that anti-vaccination movements have never succeeded in stopping rollouts, and that increased access to medical information and the success of previous vaccinations have made populations less receptive to anti-vaccination messaging.

site_title: China Vanke prepares for US$2b property management IPO
summary: China Vanke, the country's largest developer, is preparing for a potential US$2 billion initial public offering (IPO) of its property management business in Hong Kong. The company is working with an adviser to finalize the offering, which could take place by the end of this year. The IPO is expected to boost the unit's valuation, thanks to its use of technology in real estate management. This move follows similar IPOs by other Chinese developers, which have seen significant returns.

site_title: Four Big Tech firms, Samsung set blistering pace this earnings season
summary: Big Tech firms, including Apple, Facebook, Alphabet, and Samsung, reported strong revenue and profit growth in their latest earnings reports. Apple's profit more than doubled to $23.63 billion, driven by robust iPhone sales. Facebook's profit nearly doubled to $9.5 billion, fueled by sharp gains in digital advertising. Alphabet's revenue rose 34% to $55.31 billion, while Netflix saw a 24% year-over-year revenue increase to $7.16 billion. Samsung's profit jumped 46.3% to $7.14 trillion won, driven by sales of its Galaxy S21 smartphone series.

site_title: Huawei dives deeper into EVs, seeks control of small automaker
summary: Huawei is in talks to acquire a controlling stake in Chongqing Sokon's electric vehicle unit, Chongqing Jinkang New Energy Automobile, allowing it to establish an end-to-end presence in the EV business. The move is seen as a strategic shift for the telecommunications equipment maker, which has been looking to expand its presence in the EV sector. The deal, if finalized, would provide Huawei with a smart vehicle operating system and enable the company to produce intelligent cars bearing its own nameplate, marking a significant shift in business focus after two years of US sanctions.

site_title: Sam Goi re-elected to Hanwell's board; two other directors ousted
summary: Sam Goi has been re-elected as non-executive chairman of Hanwell Holdings, garnering over 94% of the votes at the annual general meeting. Two directors, Tang Cheuk Chee and Yeo See Liang, were ousted with less than 45% of the votes in support of their return to the board. Goi, who has a 23% stake in the company, praised the opportunity to reposition Hanwell and reset its growth strategy. The company also voted down plans to allot and issue new shares, and is exploring e-commerce platforms for its products.

site_title: Long underrated, 6 artists finally get the spotlight
summary: The National Gallery Singapore has launched an exhibition showcasing six post-independence Singapore artists who have been overlooked by the establishment. The exhibition, titled "Something New Must Turn Up: Six Singaporean Artists After 1965," features works by Chng Seok Tin, Mohammad Din Mohammad, Goh Beng Kwan, Eng Tow, Jaafar Latiff, and Lin Hsin Hsin. The artists, including three women and two Malays, are recognized for their contributions to Singapore's art scene, with the exhibition running from May 7 to August 22, 2021.

site_title: As Merkel era ends, German post-war system is in flux
summary: Germany's post-war political landscape is in flux as Angela Merkel's era comes to an end, with the Green Party topping national polls for the first time, surpassing the Christian Democratic Union/Christian Social Union (CDU/CSU) and the Social Democratic Party (SPD). The two-party system, which has dominated Germany since World War II, is shifting towards a multi-party system, potentially leading to more unstable and unpredictable politics. The Greens' rise to popularity is driven by their stance on climate change and reducing inequality, while the CDU/CSU and SPD struggle with their candidates and uncertain leadership.

site_title: Will CICT exit One George Street?
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) is considering divesting its half-stake in One George Street, a 400-meter office building in Singapore. The trust's manager has indicated a plan to reconstitute its portfolio, and analysts suggest the building could be sold to entities linked to Gaw Capital Partners, JP Morgan Asset Management, and Morgan Stanley. The sale price is expected to be higher than the S$2,517 psf valuation of the asset as of last year, potentially yielding a 15% gain for unitholders. The proceeds could be used to trim leverage and invest in higher-yielding assets.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust enters into sale and purchase agreement with two subsidiaries of ARA Asset Management
summary: DASIN Retail Trust's trustee-manager and controlling shareholder Zhang Zhencheng, along with Aqua Wealth Holdings, entered into a sale and purchase agreement with ARA Asset Management's two subsidiaries. The agreement involves selling a 50% stake in the trustee-manager and 5% of total units issued in the trust. ARA DSRT (Holdings) will acquire the 50% stake, while ARA Real Estate Investors 22 will acquire 5% of the total units in two tranches.

site_title: Olam unit eyes better margins, earnings with acquisition of spice supplier Olde Thompson
summary: Olam International's unit, Olam Food Ingredients, acquired US private-label spice supplier Olde Thompson for $950 million, aiming to expand its private label solutions in the spices segment. The acquisition is expected to improve margins and earnings, according to OFI's CEO. The deal will "dramatically expand" the group's private label business, making products for sale under another company's brand.

site_title: Japfa Q1 net profit rises 37% to US$48.5m
summary: Japfa, an industrialised agri-food company, reported a 37% increase in net profit to US$48.5 million for the first quarter of 2021, driven by 16% revenue growth to US$1.1 billion. Earnings per share rose to 2.4 US cents from 1.8 US cents in Q1 2020. The company attributed the growth to contributions from all three of its segments.

site_title: A US$246 billion bonanza means stock ETF inflows already beat 2020
summary: Investors have poured $246 billion into US stock ETFs in the first three months of 2021, exceeding last year's total of $231 billion. This surge in inflows is driven by new traders seeking a piece of the rebounding economy and tax-efficient investment options. Equity ETFs have outperformed mutual funds, with passive management seeing gains of $46.5 billion and actively managed funds facing outflows of $11 billion. The top-performing ETFs include Vanguard's S&P 500 and Total Stock Market ETFs, with BlackRock's iShares Core S&P 500 ETF also attracting significant investments.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by tech earnings, economic data
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday following strong earnings from Apple and Facebook, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the way. Apple's profits doubled to $23.6 billion and Facebook's profits rose to $9.5 billion in the first quarter. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 also advanced, driven by a 6.4% growth in gross domestic product and a decline in jobless claims. However, inflation concerns remained, and investors digested President Biden's call for trillions in infrastructure spending.

site_title: India infections top 18 million as gravediggers work round the clock
summary: India has surpassed 18 million Covid-19 cases, with 379,257 new infections and 3,645 deaths reported on Thursday, amid a severe crisis with hospitals and morgues overwhelmed. Gravediggers work around the clock to bury victims, while thousands search for hospital beds and oxygen for sick relatives. India's vaccination campaign has been hindered by a lack of stocks, with only 9% of the population vaccinated. The government has begun moving supplies and opening healthcare facilities to civilians, and international aid is pouring in, including oxygen generators, ventilators, and vaccines.

site_title: Is COE auction system broken?
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) auction system has seen record-high prices, with some predicting COEs could reach S$70,000. The issue lies not with the system itself, but with the assumption that car dealers are the primary villains. Dealers bid on behalf of customers, but their incentives are to get COEs cheaply, not hoard them. Suggestions to reform the system, such as banning dealers from bidding or requiring cash payments, are misguided and would not address the underlying issue of willingness and ability to pay. The COE system may be "broken" but it is doing what it was designed to do: excluding people from car ownership.

images.alt_text: Overwhelmingly, car dealers here bid for COEs on their customers' behalf, which leads people to assume that they are the villains of the story.

site_title: Britain's Prince William and Kate mark 10th wedding anniversary with video
summary: Britain's Prince William and Kate, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, celebrated their 10-year wedding anniversary with a video of the couple and their children enjoying the countryside. The video was posted on social media, accompanied by a tweet thanking everyone for their kind messages. The couple also released two new photos to commemorate the occasion, expressing their gratitude for the 10 years of support they have received as a family.

site_title: SkillsFuture funding revised to focus on manpower development outcomes
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture funding will undergo revisions to focus on manpower development outcomes. Starting January 1, 2022, subsidies for SSG-funded courses will be adjusted to prioritize training tied to job placements, with up to 50% subsidies for certifiable courses and up to 70% fee offsets for courses offered by SSG-appointed Continuing Education and Training centers. The goal is to direct more funds towards training that delivers strong employment outcomes.

site_title: Gaming industry worth US$300b after pandemic surge: study
summary: The gaming industry has surpassed $300 billion in value, driven by a pandemic-fueled surge, with 2.7 billion players worldwide. The sector is shifting towards experience-oriented platforms, with new gaming platforms and changing demographics contributing to its growth. The industry has seen a 50% increase in players over the past three years, with 400 million new gamers expected by 2023. The newest gamers are predominantly women, under 25, and non-white, with a focus on community interaction and live streaming. The gaming industry is evolving into a superplatform ecosystem.

site_title: China's big five banks boost profits, but margins shrink
summary: China's five largest state-owned banks reported higher first-quarter profits, with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) seeing a 1.5% net profit rise. However, margins shrank due to low interest rates, with four of the five banks experiencing this trend. The banks benefited from China's economic recovery, with GDP up 18.3% in the first quarter. Lending remains a significant contributor to earnings, but analysts warn of a potential spike in non-performing loans when a government-mandated grace period expires at the end of this year.

images.alt_text: Five of China's largest state-owned banks have reported higher first-quarter net profits, helped by a rebound in the country's economy from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: 32 ICA officers placed under quarantine while about 100 tested for Covid-19
summary: Thirty-two Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) officers at Changi Airport have been placed under quarantine after being identified as close contacts of a 38-year-old officer who tested positive for Covid-19. Around 100 officers will be tested for the virus as a precaution. The officer, who was deployed at the duty officer counter at Terminal 1, was among the three community cases announced on Wednesday. The ICA has taken these measures to prevent the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Thirty two Immigration & Checkpoints Authority (ICA) officers at Changi Airport have been placed under quarantine order while around 100 will be tested for Covid-19 as a precaution.

site_title: NTUC going all out to attract more PMEs to unions
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is launching a push to attract more professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) to union membership in Singapore. Since setting up a PME taskforce last October, the NTUC has reached out to over 8,000 PMEs, who cite job security and lack of employment opportunities as their main concerns. The taskforce is particularly focused on mature PMEs aged 40 and above, who are more likely to be affected by their advanced age. The NTUC aims to address these concerns and increase PME representation in the labour movement.

site_title: SBS Transit appoints Bob Tan as new chairman
summary: SBS Transit appoints Bob Tan as new chairman, succeeding Lim Jit Poh, effective Friday. Tan brings extensive experience in corporate governance, having held directorships for four decades. He also has prior experience in the public transport sector, having served on the SMRT board from 2006 to 2017. Tan will work with the board and management to navigate the public transport sector's structural change and ongoing challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic. Lim will stay on as senior adviser to ensure continuity.

site_title: US jobless claims fell last week to fresh pandemic-era low
summary: US jobless claims fell to a fresh pandemic-era low of 553,000 in the week ended April 24, down 13,000 from the prior week. This decline is attributed to more Americans getting vaccinated and returning to work. Continuing claims for ongoing state benefits rose to 3.66 million for the week ended April 17, while applications for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance for self-employed and gig workers totalled 121,749. The drop in unemployment benefits applications indicates the job market is steadily returning to its pre-pandemic strength.

site_title: The new 'protein' diet
summary: Singapore is a hub for alternative protein companies, with several startups and established brands launching innovative plant-based and cell-based meat products. The global plant-based protein market is projected to grow to US$14.5 billion by 2025, driven by increasing demand for sustainable and healthy food options. Companies like Karana, Next Gen Foods, and Agrocorp are developing products such as pork made from young jackfruit, plant-based 'chicken', and pea paneer cheese. Cell-based meat companies like Shiok Meats and TurtleTree Labs are also gaining traction, with plans to commercialize their products by 2022. The Singapore government's support for food innovation and improving food security has created a favorable ecosystem for alternative protein companies to thrive.

site_title: Kimly unit in joint venture to run coffee shops in Bukit Batok, Serangoon North
summary: Kimly unit enters into a joint venture to manage two coffee shops in Bukit Batok and Serangoon North. Kimly Makan Place will manage the shops under a 49-51% joint venture with Tade Group, with Kimly injecting S$147,000 in working capital. The joint venture is part of Kimly's strategy to expand its network of food outlets and diversify revenue streams.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q4 DPU up 15.8% year on year
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 15.8% year-over-year increase in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.30 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 18.9% to S$121.06 million, driven by consolidation of US data centre revenue, while net property income increased 17.3% to S$91.81 million. However, the company also reported a net loss of S$45.8 million due to deferred tax expenses and fair value losses. Distributions stood at S$70.75 million, up 2.3% from the previous year.

site_title: British workers move off furlough as economy reopens
summary: British workers have largely returned to work as lockdown restrictions eased, with 13% of employees on furlough, down from 17% in the previous period. Spending on non-essential goods, such as clothes and furniture, rose 10% above pre-pandemic levels in the week following shop reopenings. Pubs and restaurants initially saw a surge in demand, but outdoor dining has been less appealing due to chilly weather. Indoor service is expected to resume on May 17, subject to social distancing requirements.

site_title: US recovery gains steam as spending fuels 6.4% GDP growth
summary: US economic growth accelerated in the first quarter to a 6.4% annualized rate, driven by a surge in consumer spending. Personal consumption increased 10.7% annually, the second-fastest since the 1960s, and the inflation-adjusted GDP value reached $19.09 trillion. Rising vaccinations, job growth, and federal stimulus payments fueled household spending, while business investment and housing also showed strength. The median forecast for the January to March period was 6.7% growth, and the Federal Reserve is sticking with its easy monetary policy to support the economy.

site_title: CSE Global secures S$106m in new orders for Q1 FY21
summary: CSE Global secured S$106.2 million in new orders for Q1 FY21, with energy sector orders at S$56.6 million and infrastructure sector orders increasing 50.3% year-over-year to S$38.3 million. The company's order book stands at S$231 million, with a 7.9% quarter-on-quarter increase. Amid the pandemic, CSE's group managing director noted the encouraging sequential increase in new orders, and plans to focus on digitalization and security solutions to remain relevant.

site_title: Footballers unpaid and angry as Chinese teams fold
summary: Chinese football clubs have been accused of forging signatures of foreign players to cover up unpaid wages, leaving over 20 clubs to fold in the last two years. Players, including Zambian striker Jacob Mulenga and Croatian midfielder Marko Basic, claim their signatures were faked to conceal non-payment of salaries. The issue raises concerns about the sustainability of professional football in China and the protection of players' livelihoods, with FIFA and the global footballers' union FIFPro voicing concerns to the Chinese Football Association.

site_title: McDonald's sales soar as consumers binge on chicken sandwiches
summary: McDonald's reported a 13.6% increase in US sales at restaurants open for over a year, beating Wall Street estimates, as consumers flocked to its crispy chicken sandwiches. The company's global comparable sales growth of 7.5% surpassed pre-pandemic levels, with international markets, such as the UK, Australia, and Canada, also showing strong growth. Net income rose to $1.54 billion, and revenue increased 9% to $5.12 billion. The company's success is attributed to its extensive delivery networks and competitive pricing, which have helped it weather pandemic restrictions better than other fast-food chains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at close
summary: Hong Kong stocks advanced for a second day, driven by a positive US economy summary and the Federal Reserve's pledge to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.80%, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.52%. The gains followed a rally in Asian markets.

site_title: China seeks to douse speculation of shrinking population
summary: China's population grew in 2020, contrary to speculation of a decline, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Births in 2020 fell 15% to 10.035 million, but the overall population continued to grow, with detailed figures to be released when the census results are published. The delay in publishing census results has sparked concerns about the potential for a shrinking population, with implications for Beijing's population growth targets and measures to encourage more births.

site_title: Thai tourism outlook downgrade dashes hopes of strong rebound from pandemic
summary: UOB has downgraded Thailand's 2021 GDP forecast to 1.5% due to a negative impact of the pandemic on tourism, consumer consumption, and investment. The Thai government has also reduced its annual visitor forecast to 2 million and tourism revenue to 170 billion baht. The Asian Development Bank notes that a tourism bounce-back requires good worldwide vaccination progress. Despite this, the country's improving export environment and a rosier global economic environment may provide some support to overall growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is modernizing cross-border payments through partnerships, aiming to ease long-standing payment pains. NTUC is pushing for more professionals, managers, and executives to join unions, citing under-representation. Tycoon OK Lim missed court due to acute sinusitis, while OCBC may cut branches and review office space. Olam is buying US spice maker Olde Thompson for $950m. Sam Goi was re-elected as non-executive chairman of Hanwell Holdings. Corporate earnings showed a 10% increase in Ascott Residence Trust's Q1 revenue and a 1% rise in CDLHT's Q1 NPI.

site_title: DP World launches wholesale e-commerce platform
summary: DP World has launched Dubuy, a wholesale e-commerce platform connecting buyers and sellers worldwide through its logistics network. The platform aims to cover half of Africa in 2.5 years and the entire continent in 4 years. Dubuy is linked to sellers in Dubai and offers digital wallet payments, with plans to expand to east African countries and markets outside Africa. DP World hopes to make the platform the world's largest business-to-business e-commerce platform, generating revenue without relying on port operations.

site_title: 16 community infections among 35 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 35 new Covid-19 cases, including 16 community infections, bringing the total to 61,121. The cases are linked to a possible cluster at Tan Tock Seng Hospital and include family members of an Immigration & Checkpoints Authority officer. There were no new cases from migrant workers' dormitories. Globally, the virus has infected over 149 million people, with 3.15 million deaths.

site_title: Two-week lockdown in Manila? More like two months, Nomura report warns
summary: A two-week lockdown extension in Manila may last up to two months, according to a Nomura report, citing the significant economic impact of the lockdown and limited fiscal support. Economists forecast a 5.5% GDP rebound, down from an earlier estimate of 6.8%. The Asian Development Bank also projects a 4.5% GDP growth in 2021, citing downside risks from the pandemic and virus mutations. The lockdown's prolonged duration may drag on confidence and contribute to rising unemployment.

site_title: Wilmar Q1 net profit doubles to US$450.2m
summary: Wilmar International's net profit doubled to US$450.2 million in Q1 2021, with core net profit rising 38.3% to US$423.7 million. Revenue increased 30.6% to US$14.3 billion, driven by a strong recovery in China's food market and higher commodity prices. The company expects sustained high palm oil prices to benefit its oil palm plantation business, but faces lower earnings from the feed and industrial products segment.

site_title: OCBC may cut down on number of branches, reviewing office space requirements: chairman
summary: OCBC Bank is reviewing its office space requirements and may cut down on its number of branches, according to chairman Ooi Sang Kuang. The bank aims to move towards a hybrid workspace with flexibility to work from home and office. This move is in response to the pandemic, which has led to a surge in digital banking services. OCBC is also evaluating the adoption of cryptocurrency and considering setting up a standalone digital bank. The bank's new CEO, Helen Wong, has outlined her focus on capitalising on Asean-Greater China flows, expanding wealth management, and accelerating digitalisation.

site_title: Singapore moves to take cross-border payments into the future
summary: Singapore has partnered with Thailand to create the world's first instant cross-border payments infrastructure, linking Singapore's PayNow and Thailand's PromptPay. The new linkage allows for real-time, low-cost transfers of up to S$1,000 (25,000 baht) between participating banks in Singapore and Thailand, reducing remittance costs by half. The partnership aims to simplify cross-border payments, making them faster and cheaper, with the goal of expanding the network across the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region.

site_title: BioNTech eyes Covid vaccine for 12-15 year olds from June in EU
summary: BioNTech expects its Covid-19 vaccine, jointly developed with Pfizer, to be available to 12-15 year olds in Europe from June. The company's CEO Ugur Sahin stated it's "in the final stretches" of preparing its submission for European regulatory approval, with trial data evaluation taking 4-6 weeks. Vaccinating older children is seen as crucial for herd immunity and ending the pandemic, and BioNTech plans to submit a similar request to the European Medicines Agency next week. The vaccine has shown 100% effectiveness in warding off the disease in children aged 12-15 in phase 3 clinical trials.

site_title: Shell raises dividend after strong Q1 profit rise
summary: Royal Dutch Shell raised its dividend by 4% after reporting a strong Q1 profit of $3.23 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts. This marks the second dividend increase since the company reduced its payout by two-thirds in 2020 due to the pandemic. First-quarter earnings rose over seven-fold from the previous quarter, driven by asset sales and higher oil and liquefied natural gas prices.

site_title: Olam unit eyes better margins, earnings with acquisition of spice supplier Olde Thompson
summary: Olam International's unit, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI), is acquiring US private-label spice supplier Olde Thompson for $950 million, expected to be earnings and margin-accretive from the first year. The acquisition will expand OFI's private label solutions in the spices segment, with a projected incremental margin improvement. Olde Thompson's capacity and systems will enable OFI to create retail formats and spice-added solutions, potentially increasing margins. The deal is expected to deliver $25-30 million in Ebitda synergies, mainly from lower logistics costs and reduced inventory holding costs.

site_title: German regulator warns Binance over stock tokens
summary: Germany's financial regulator BaFin warned Binance, a world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, that it risks a fine of up to 5 million euros for selling security-tracking tokens without publishing an investor prospectus, violating EU securities law. Binance plans to offer tokens denominated in its own cryptocurrency, giving investors exposure to major companies like MicroStrategy, Microsoft, and Apple. The regulator stated that securities investments should be based on necessary information, and Binance has committed to following local regulator requirements.

site_title: Sam Goi re-elected non-executive chairman of Hanwell with ouster of two directors
summary: Sam Goi has been re-elected as non-executive chairman of Hanwell Holdings, garnering over 94% of the votes at the annual general meeting. Two directors, Tang Cheuk Chee and Yeo See Liang, were ousted with less than 45% support. Goi's re-election follows his offer to become executive chairman for a nominal fee, which was not accepted. The company is working with e-commerce platforms and assessing the feasibility of its own e-commerce platform.

site_title: Asian markets generally up, Singapore shares little changed
summary: Asian markets rose, driven by strong earnings from Wall Street and the Federal Reserve's stable monetary policy. The Straits Times Index increased 0.06% to 3,221.58 points, with gainers outnumbering losers 262 to 195. Jiutian Chemical's stellar first-quarter profit led heavy trading, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Lufthansa stems losses despite slower recovery outlook
summary: Lufthansa narrowed its quarterly losses by 30% to 1.14 billion euros, driven by cost-cutting measures and a 19% workforce reduction. The airline lowered its full-year capacity forecast to 40% of pre-pandemic levels, citing a gradual demand pick-up in April-June and a significant market recovery in the second half. Despite this, Lufthansa's net debt rose to 10.9 billion euros, and the company plans to raise up to 5.5 billion euros in new capital at a shareholder meeting.

site_title: Standard Chartered Q1 profit rises 18% as it begins recovery from Covid-19 impact
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 18% rise in Q1 pre-tax profit to $1.4 billion, driven by reduced bad loan provisions and strong performance in its markets business. This surpasses analyst forecasts of $1.08 billion. The bank took a $20 million credit impairment, down from $354 million in the previous quarter, and expects income to be similar to 2020, with growth expected in 2022. The recovery marks a beginning for the bank after the Covid-19 pandemic's economic impact.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered posted on Thursday a higher- than-expected 18 per cent rise in first-quarter pre-tax profit, as the emerging markets-focused bank began recovering from the economic hit caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains to close near 14-month peak
summary: Australian shares closed near a 14-month peak at 7,082.3, extending gains from mild inflation data, which ended a two-day losing streak. Tech and gold stocks drove gains, outweighing disappointing trading updates from Woolworths and Fortescue Metals. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% on the day, its highest level in nearly 14 months.

site_title: Singapore, Thailand link real-time payment rails for faster, cheaper cross-border transfers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Bank of Thailand (BOT) have linked their real-time payment rails, PayNow and PromptPay, to facilitate faster and cheaper cross-border transfers. The linkage allows customers to transfer up to S$1,000 (25,000 baht) daily within minutes using their mobile phone numbers. The initiative aims to halve remittance costs, reduce fees to affordably priced and transparently displayed, and complete transfers within five minutes. This is the first instant cross-border payments infrastructure globally, and MAS plans to expand the network across Asean.

site_title: Airbus gets cash boost from flurry of new jet deliveries
summary: Airbus reported positive cash flow for the third consecutive quarter, with 1.2 billion euros in adjusted free cash flow, beating analysts' estimates. The company delivered 125 aircraft in the first quarter, surpassing last year's figure, and reiterated its target to increase production of its A320-series jets later this year. Despite a surge in COVID-19 cases in India, Airbus warned that the outlook hinges on no further disruptions to air travel or the global economy, and CEO Guillaume Faury cautioned that the path to recovery will not be linear.

site_title: Europe: Unilever, Nokia earnings push shares towards record high
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% to near record highs on Thursday, driven by upbeat earnings reports from Unilever and Nokia. Unilever's 3.2% gain was fueled by a strong economic recovery in China and a share buyback program. Nokia's 13.7% surge was attributed to growth in network and 5G equipment sales. Other oil majors, including Royal Dutch Shell and Total, also reported strong quarterly earnings, while Airbus posted higher core earnings. The Stoxx 600 index is now just 3 points below its record peak.

site_title: China readies Tencent penalty in antitrust crackdown: sources
summary: China is preparing a substantial fine for Tencent Holdings, with a penalty of at least 10 billion yuan (S$2.05 billion), as part of its antitrust crackdown on internet giants. Tencent faces penalties for not reporting past acquisitions and investments and for anticompetitive practices in its businesses, including music streaming. The fine is expected to be less than the record US$2.75 billion imposed on Alibaba earlier this month. Tencent's core businesses, such as video games and WeChat, are likely to remain intact.

site_title: GIC leads 300m reais funding round in Brazil fintech Warren
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC led a 300 million reais (S$74.4 million) funding round in Brazilian fintech startup Warren, with existing investors Ribbit, Kaszek, and Quartz also participating. This marks Warren's third funding round, totaling 445 million reais. The company plans to use the funds to invest in technology and consider acquisitions, aiming to double its assets under management to 10 billion reais this year.

site_title: ECB tells banks to 'drastically' improve climate risk management
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has urged Euro zone banks to drastically improve their climate risk management, stating that climate-related risks can drive other types of risks such as credit and liquidity risks. ECB board member Frank Elderson emphasized the need for banks to incorporate climate goals into their risk management processes, which currently do not exist. The ECB will assess lenders' climate risk management starting immediately, with no wait for regulatory developments.

site_title: Two Myanmar air bases come under attack: reports
summary: Unidentified attackers launched assaults on two Myanmar air bases, with blasts reported at one base and rocket fire seen at another. The attacks come after three months of turmoil in Myanmar triggered by a February military coup. There were no reported casualties or claims of responsibility, and a military spokesman did not comment. The incidents follow fighting between the military and ethnic minority insurgents and the military's use of lethal force against pro-democracy protesters, resulting in over 750 deaths.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide on profit-taking after corporate earnings
summary: South Korean stocks slid on Thursday, closing down 0.23% at 3,174.07 points, following a series of corporate earnings reports from technology giants. LG Chem surged 7% after reporting a six-fold jump in quarterly operating profit, while Samsung Electronics slipped 0.49% despite a 46% rise in first-quarter profit. The won rose, and foreigners were net sellers of 14.5 billion won worth of shares. The US central bank noted progress on vaccines and economic recovery but said it's not time to discuss policy change.

site_title: Huawei deepens dive into EVs, seeks control of small automaker: source
summary: Huawei is in talks to acquire a controlling stake in Chongqing Sokon's Chongqing Jinkang New Energy Automobile, a small domestic automaker, to develop electric vehicles bearing its own nameplate. This strategic move would allow Huawei to expand its presence in the EV market, despite US sanctions. The acquisition would also give Huawei access to Jinkang's main asset, a US EV brand called Seres. The deal is seen as a shift for Huawei, which has been focusing on telecom equipment.

site_title: China drafts rules to secure data from internet-connected cars
summary: China has published draft rules to secure data from internet-connected cars, amid concerns over privacy and national security. The move comes after Tesla's cars were banned from Chinese military complexes due to security concerns over vehicle cameras. Founder Elon Musk had previously threatened to shut down Tesla if it used cars to spy in China. The draft rules aim to protect sensitive data from cyber threats and ensure the security of connected vehicles. The rules are part of China's efforts to regulate the rapidly growing smart car market.

site_title: Vaccinated HK residents ready to party till 2am curfew as bars reopen
summary: Hong Kong's party zone Lan Kwai Fong is reopening with new rules, allowing vaccinated residents to visit bars and clubs until 2am. Patrons must register with a government app and show their vaccination record, while staff need at least one vaccine dose. Restaurants can also reopen until 2am, but must seat vaccinated customers separately. The measures aim to encourage vaccination and prevent Covid-19 transmission, with the goal of completing the vaccine course for those who want to socialize.

site_title: Five tech companies charging ahead this results season
summary: The Nasdaq reached new records as investors anticipate a busy week of earnings from tech companies. Notable names, including Apple, have posted strong revenue and profit growth. Key reports include Apple's revenue and profit growth, as well as the launch of an AI-focused innovation hub by Amazon Web Services and a creator commerce program by Lazada. Other notable mentions include the launch of an AI hub in Singapore by BHP and Oracle, and the expansion of an AI-focused sandbox by Synapxe.

site_title: Sin Ghee Huat receives offer to be taken private at S$0.27 per share
summary: Sin Ghee Huat Corporation announced a voluntary conditional cash offer from HHH Co, owned by Low Chui Heng and Low Ah Hoo, to take the company private at S$0.27 per share, valuing the company at S$60 million. The offer price exceeds the highest closing price in over two years, representing a premium of 48.4% to the volume-weighted average price. The offer is conditional on achieving a shareholding of more than half of the shares, and if successful, HHH Co intends to exercise its rights of compulsory acquisition and delist Sin Ghee Huat from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST).

site_title: Chinese officials plan next steps in oil spill clean-up off Qingdao
summary: Chinese officials are considering siphoning the remaining cargo at sea from a tanker that spilled 400 tonnes of oil into the Yellow Sea after a collision with a bulk vessel. The spill, initially estimated at 500 tonnes, has been contained, according to officials. The tanker, carrying a 150,000-tonne cargo of bitumen blend, remains at sea with no change in the level of oil on board. Chinese officials are planning next steps in the clean-up efforts, but details are not yet available.

site_title: Baidu to launch paid driverless ride-hailing services in Beijing
summary: Baidu, a Chinese tech giant, will launch paid driverless robotaxi services in Beijing on May 2, marking the first time a Chinese company offers autonomous driving services to paying users. The service, called Apollo Robotaxi, will operate without a safety driver, and will be initially launched in Shougang Park. This move is part of Baidu's efforts to expand its autonomous driving capabilities and provide a new transportation option for users in the Chinese capital.

site_title: Hot stock: Jiutian Chemical up 3% after reporting strong Q1 results
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group reported strong Q1 results, with a net profit of 90.3 million yuan, more than 30 times that of its Q1 FY20 net profit. Revenue surged 120% year-over-year to 439.3 million yuan, driven by increased sales volume and average selling prices of its main products. The company attributed its results to China's recovery from the Covid-19 crisis and strong demand for its products. This marks a turnaround from the company's previous Q4 net profit of 86.2 million yuan and net losses in the same period last year.

site_title: China's April factory activity growth expected to slow slightly: poll
summary: China's factory activity is expected to grow at a slightly slower pace in April, with a median forecast of 51.7 for the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), down from 51.9 in March. Profits at industrial firms nearly doubled in March, driven by demand for raw materials, but higher costs are putting pressure on some enterprises. China's exports rose sharply in March, but growth may lose momentum due to industrial production recovering from pandemic-related disruptions. The country's economic growth quickened sharply in the first quarter to 18.3%, but an annual target of above 6% may be challenging.

site_title: CDC 'committed' to US cruise industry resuming operations by mid-summer
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has stated its commitment to the resumption of cruise industry passenger operations in the US by mid-summer. The agency has introduced new steps to speed up approvals, including allowing ships to skip simulated voyages if 98% of crew and 95% of passengers are fully vaccinated. The CDC also plans to update testing and quarantine requirements for passengers and crew to align with its guidance for fully vaccinated individuals. This move comes after the state of Alaska joined a lawsuit to overturn the CDC's ban on immediate cruise industry resumption.

site_title: China 'closing in fast', Biden warns US Congress, as he asks for trillions in spending
summary: US President Joe Biden warned Congress that China is "closing in fast" and urged a $1.8 trillion spending plan to compete with the nation, totaling $4 trillion. The plan includes $1 trillion in education and childcare spending, $800 billion in tax credits, and $200 billion for free preschool. Biden argues that the US must invest in its future to counter China's growing economic and strategic influence. The plan faces opposition from Republicans and liberal Democrats, with Biden to meet with lawmakers to find common ground.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH starts coverage on Hong Leong Asia with S$1.38 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated a "buy" rating on Hong Leong Asia with a target price of S$1.38, citing attractive valuation and growth prospects for the company's diesel engine and building materials segments. Analyst John Cheong expects the commercial vehicles industry in China to experience a cyclical upturn, driving growth for the company's China Yuchai International business. Additionally, Cheong forecasts strong recovery in the building materials segment, driven by improved sales volumes and prices. This is expected to lead to a 52% year-on-year growth in the company's FY2021 earnings.

site_title: China launches first module for new space station
summary: China successfully launched the first module of its new space station, Tianhe core module, from Wenchang in Hainan province on a Long-March 5B rocket. The module houses life support equipment and a living space for astronauts, and is expected to become fully operational in 2022 after 10 missions. China aims to assert its global stature and technological might with its space exploration efforts, which have included sending a probe to Mars orbit earlier this year. The space station will remain in low Earth orbit for 15 years.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,225.31. The gains were driven by the Federal Reserve's indication that accommodative monetary policies would continue, despite the economy's recovery. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 34, with Jardine Matheson being the top gainer, while ComfortDelGro was the top loser. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% on Wall Street, and European stocks ended flat, as investors awaited the Fed's policy decision.

site_title: AMTD's full-year profit up 37.1% on ongoing strategic development, global expansion
summary: HONG KONG-headquartered AMTD International reported a 37.1% year-on-year increase in net profit to HK$1.14 billion for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2020. The company also saw assets under management grow to over HK$26 billion, a "new height" in its operating history. Notable transactions included the IPOs of Yum China Holdings and Weihai City Commercial Bank, as well as a successful dual-currency US dollar and Singapore dollar perpetual bond issuance. Despite a challenging operating environment, CEO William Fung attributed the strong results to strategic development and global expansion.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Japan's financial markets closed on Thursday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. In Asia, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth day ahead of GDP data. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached fresh records. eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Time difference caused delay in clarifying Honeywell agreement, says Aspen
summary: Aspen Holdings delayed disclosing a non-consummated US$210 million gloves supply order from Honeywell due to a 12-hour time difference between Malaysia and the US. The agreement was received by Aspen on April 10, but Honeywell did not execute it, requiring internal approvals. Aspen retracted its initial announcement after 11 working days, stating the delay was due to the time difference. The group clarified that a fully-executed agreement would have been a material event requiring disclosure.

site_title: Uber to sign up 20,000 more UK drivers as Covid-19 rules ease
summary: Uber plans to sign up 20,000 more UK drivers as COVID-19 restrictions ease, following a 50% increase in trips after restaurants reopened for outdoor dining. The move comes after Uber granted its existing 70,000 drivers workers' rights in March. The company aims to capitalize on the lifting of further restrictions and a roadmap to unlock the economy, with Northern and Eastern Europe boss Jamie Heywood encouraging new drivers to sign up.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by upbeat Federal Reserve, strong results
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, driven by upbeat earnings from Wall Street titans, including Apple and Facebook, and a positive assessment from the Federal Reserve on the US economic outlook. The Fed upgraded its outlook for the US economy and pledged to stick to its ultra-low monetary policy. Meanwhile, US President Joe Biden outlined a $1.8 trillion spending plan aimed at helping American families, which is expected to be paid for with taxes on the wealthy.

site_title: Gold gains after US Fed maintains accommodative stance
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its accommodative monetary policy stance, supporting gold prices. Gold rose 0.2% to $1,784.94 per ounce, driven by a weaker dollar and the Fed's pledge to aid economic recovery. US gold futures also increased 0.6%. The dollar index fell 0.1% against rivals, boosting gold's appeal for other currency holders.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose on Thursday bolstered by the US Federal Reserve's pledge to maintain easy monetary policy to aid economic recovery, while a weaker dollar provided further support.

site_title: Tycoon OK Lim, ailed by acute sinusitis, fails to show up in court again
summary: Singapore tycoon OK Lim, owner of the collapsed Hin Leong empire, failed to appear in court for a third time due to acute sinusitis. Lim's lawyer, Navin Thevar, requested a two-week adjournment, but District Judge Terence Tay rejected the request, citing the lack of clarity in the application. The court will adjourn the hearing to Friday, with Lim's medical status to be reassessed then. Lim, 79, has been undergoing treatment for his condition and is on blood thinners, awaiting surgery.

site_title: Indonesia aims to cut 2022 fiscal deficit to below 5%
summary: Indonesia aims to reduce its 2022 fiscal deficit to below 5% of gross domestic product and under 3% in 2023 as part of post-crisis fiscal consolidation measures. The country relaxed its fiscal rules in 2020 to allow for bigger government spending amid the pandemic, but now seeks to bring deficits back under 3% starting in 2023. The government expects a 5.7% deficit this year and will design the 2022 budget with a shortfall of 4.51-4.85%, while the 2023 budget will have a gap of 2.71-2.97%.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to reduce its budget deficit next year to less than 5 per cent of gross domestic product and under 3 per cent in 2023 as part of post-crisis fiscal consolidation measures, a finance ministry official said on Thursday.

site_title: CDLHT posts 1% rise in Q1 NPI amid tentative recovery in hospitality industry
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 1% increase in net property income (NPI) in Q1 2021 to S$19.8 million, driven by substantive contributions from Singapore, New Zealand, and Maldives hotels. However, NPI fell 19.1% from Q4 2020 due to the continued impact of travel restrictions and lockdowns on the hospitality industry. RevPAR for Singapore hotels declined 39.4% year-over-year, while hotel portfolios in the Maldives, Perth, New Zealand, and Japan were affected by travel restrictions. CDLHT is in active discussions with banks on refinancing its borrowings.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Aspen, Ascott Residence Trust, CDLHT, Keppel DC Reit, ESR-Reit
summary: Olam International is proposing to buy US spice maker Olde Thompson at an enterprise value of $950 million, expected to be earnings and margin accretive from the first year onwards. Aspen (Group) Holdings delayed disclosing a glove supply agreement with Honeywell due to long turnaround times in discussions. Olam shares rose 1.2% to S$1.74, while Aspen ended flat at 22.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Ford says Q2 car output will fall 50% on semiconductor shortage
summary: Ford estimates its Q2 auto production will fall 50% due to the global semiconductor shortage, resulting in a 1.1 million unit production loss and a $2.5 billion earnings hit. The shortage, exacerbated by a recent supplier fire in Japan, is expected to worsen before improving by the end of 2022. This downcast outlook comes despite Ford's better-than-expected first-quarter earnings of $3.3 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 0.68% on Thursday, driven by the Federal Reserve's positive outlook on the US economy and its commitment to ultra-low monetary policy. The Hang Seng Index rose 196.87 points to 29,268.21. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index saw minimal changes. The rally follows a broader global market trend, with US stocks edging closer to records despite tariff threats.

site_title: New Zealand business sentiment improves as trans-Tasman travel resumes
summary: New Zealand business sentiment improved in April, with a net 2% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, down from 4.1% in March. The number of respondents expecting their own businesses to grow also increased to 22.2%, up from 16.6% in March. This improvement is attributed to the resumption of trans-Tasman travel between New Zealand and Australia after over a year of closure.

site_title: HSBC sets up new family office service in Singapore and Hong Kong for Asian families
summary: HSBC has launched a new institutional family office service in Hong Kong and Singapore, catering to Asian families with a full array of financing solutions and product capabilities. The service blends HSBC Private Banking and Global Banking expertise, enabling clients to explore sustainable investment solutions. With growing demand, HSBC aims to help Asian families adopt institutional approaches to build continuity, diversification, and resilience in their portfolios. This move follows Singapore's rise as a wealth centre, with increasing interest from Asian clients setting up and expanding family offices.

images.alt_text: HSBC has launched a new institutional family office in Hong Kong and Singapore that will cater to family offices in Asia.

site_title: UK car output up nearly 50% in March after 2020 Covid-19 hit
summary: British car production rose 47% in March compared to the same time last year, reaching 115,498 cars, the first increase since August 2019. However, output remains below average due to pandemic losses of £11 billion. The industry faces challenges, including a shortage of semi-conductor chips and adjusting to new EU trade terms, which has led to increased costs and resource management. Companies predict a minimum of six months to recover from the pandemic, with some anticipating up to two years.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust Q1 RevPAU up 10% on quarter to S$55
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 10% quarter-on-quarter increase to S$55 in its revenue per available unit (RevPAU) for its properties under management contracts and minimum guaranteed income, excluding rental housing and student accommodation. Average portfolio occupancy rose to 50% in Q1 2021, driven by block bookings. Despite a 47% year-on-year decline in RevPAU, ART's stable income sources provided downside protection against the COVID-19 impact. The trust posted strong capital management with a net asset value per unit of S$1.15 and a gearing level of 36.1%.

site_title: With eye on election, Australia ditches austerity for economic repair
summary: Australia's conservative government has shifted its focus from austerity to economic repair ahead of its next election. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg announced a plan to boost the economy, aiming to drive the jobless rate lower, despite a forecasted budget deficit of at least A$150 billion. The government will prioritize fiscal largesse and monetary stimulus, which has already led to a surge in new jobs and consumer spending. Frydenberg emphasized that the goal is to maintain a steady decline in debt-to-GDP ratio over the medium term, rather than pursuing austerity measures.

site_title: Uber adds 'valet' car rentals as it looks to rev rides
summary: Uber has introduced "valet" car rentals, allowing users to book vehicles from partners such as Avis, Budget, and Hertz, and have them delivered to their doorstep. This service, available in Washington, DC, aims to reduce the hassle of renting cars and is part of Uber's efforts to become a "one-stop-shop" for post-pandemic activities.
