The move follows a surge in food delivery demand during the pandemic and a focus on innovation to help the world "return to a better normal."

site_title: Samsung Electronics sees higher chip earnings as Q1 profit jumps 46%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its highest first-quarter operating profit since 2018, with a 46% jump in operating profit to 4.4 trillion won, driven by strong sales of its Galaxy S21 smartphone series and increased demand for televisions and home appliances. However, chip profits fell due to production costs and losses at its Texas plant. Net profit rose 46% to 7.1 trillion won, with revenue climbing 18% to 65.4 trillion won.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher on gold, energy stocks; Woolworths caps gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.15% to 7,075.6, driven by gains in energy and gold stocks, despite a disappointing earnings report from Woolworths. Ansell and Resolute Mining were top gainers, while Woolworths fell 3.4%. Gold stocks rose 2% following overnight price jumps, and the energy index rose 0.74%. The metals and mining index also rose, driven by Newcrest Mining's 2% gain.

site_title: Olam to buy US spice maker Olde Thompson at US$950m enterprise value
summary: Olam International is proposing to buy US spice maker Olde Thompson from management shareholders and private equity firm Kainos Capital at an enterprise value of US$950 million. The acquisition is expected to close in Q2 2021 and generate earnings and margin-accretive results for Olam Food Ingredients. The deal is aligned with Olam's growth strategy and will create a substantive growth platform for its spices business.

site_title: Australia to investigate two deaths for possible links to Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Australia's medicines regulator will investigate two deaths for possible links to the Covid-19 vaccine, amid concerns over the country's immunization program. The deaths occurred in New South Wales, with a 71-year-old man and a 55-year-old man dying days after receiving AstraZeneca vaccine shots. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) stated that reporting of adverse events does not necessarily mean the vaccine caused the deaths. This investigation raises fresh concerns for Australia's vaccination targets, which have largely missed initial goals due to concerns over the AstraZeneca vaccine.

site_title: Britons don't plan to spend all their lockdown savings: poll
summary: A poll by Kantar Public found that most Britons who saved money during the pandemic lockdowns plan to hold on to some of it. 20% increased their savings, while 21% saw their savings fall. Only 3% intended to spend their savings by the end of the year, with 38% planning to spend some and 18% none at all. The Bank of England views the speed at which people spend lockdown savings as crucial for the economy's recovery.

site_title: EU slams 'manipulation' of vaccine info by China, Russia
summary: The European Union has accused China and Russia of "state-sponsored disinformation" campaigns to undermine trust in Western-developed COVID-19 vaccines. Since December, Russian media and authorities have promoted the Sputnik V vaccine while spreading false claims about the EU's vaccine approval process. Beijing has also promoted its vaccines as "more suitable for developing countries," despite deploying "misleading narratives" about the safety of Western vaccines. The EU's foreign service has warned that these campaigns follow a "zero-sum game logic" that seeks to undermine Western-made vaccines.

images.alt_text: Since December, Russian media, authorities and state companies have united behind pushing the Sputnik V vaccine while using "antagonistic messaging" to accuse the EU of "sabotaging" the Russian jab, the report said.

site_title: Apple profit doubles in quarter to US$23.6b
summary: Apple's profits more than doubled to US$23.6 billion in the past quarter, driven by strong iPhone sales and growth in other products and services. Revenue reached a record US$89.6 billion, a 54% increase from the previous quarter. The company's iPhone sales jumped 65% from a year ago, with revenue from new iPhone 12 models contributing to the growth. Apple's shares rose over 3% in after-hours trade following the earnings report, which analysts attribute to the company's adaptation to 5G wireless technology and the "5G supercycle."

images.alt_text: Apple said on Wednesday profits more than doubled in the past quarter to US$23.6 billion amid a surge in iPhone sales and robust growth in other products and services purchased by pandemic-hit consumers.

site_title: DeClout says no plan for now to mount counter offer for Procurri
summary: Singapore technology incubator DeClout has no plans to mount a counter offer for Procurri, a private equity firm's bid to acquire 51% of the company for S$0.365 per share. DeClout chairman Vesmond Wong stated that the company is not in talks with other shareholders who have expressed opposition to the offer. These shareholders have been long-term investors in DeClout, and Wong believes they understand the value of Procurri.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end flat between earnings optimism, Federal Reserve caution
summary: European stocks ended flat on Wednesday, with the Stoxx 600 index largely unchanged, as optimism over positive bank earnings was offset by caution before the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. Bank stocks led gains, with Deutsche Bank and Santander rising 10.7% and 2.7% respectively. Earnings at European companies are expected to surge 71.3% in the first quarter, driven by a rotation towards cyclical names like banks and autos.

site_title: US: Stocks, dollar pull back as Federal Reserve stays dovish
summary: US stocks declined and the dollar fell on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve maintained accommodative monetary policies, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaling a continued benchmark lending rate near zero. The central bank will also continue its massive bond buying program until employment recovers. This move followed President Joe Biden's expected congressional address calling for massive investment and tax hikes.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks dipped and the dollar fell on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve signaled a continuation of accommodative monetary policies ahead of a congressional address by President Joe Biden expected to call for massive additional investment and tax hikes.

site_title: Singapore banks may shop for buys as fears over bad debts recede
summary: Singapore banks are expected to pursue regional growth strategies, with DBS and OCBC among those set to bid for Citi's consumer assets in Asia. Despite asset quality improving, the trio will remain cautious, with provision write-backs unlikely in Q1. Higher dividends are expected, with analysts forecasting at least a 50% payout ratio, driven by stabilizing net interest margins and stronger fee income. The banks' capital buffers remain robust, allowing for potential special dividends from FY22, should provisions meet expectations. The first-quarter results season is set to begin on April 30.

site_title: DPM Heng receives NTUC's top May Day award
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat received the Medal of Honour, the top May Day award, for his contributions to the labour movement. Heng was recognised for his policies that balance pro-worker and pro-business views, and for helping businesses stay afloat during the COVID-19 pandemic. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) praised his role in tripartism and collaboration with union leaders and workers. Heng accepted the award on behalf of all tripartite partners, saying that strong collaboration had made a difference to workers' lives.

site_title: Trump lawyer Giuliani's apartment raided in federal probe
summary: Federal investigators raided Rudy Giuliani's New York apartment as part of a probe into his dealings in Ukraine, seizing electronic devices and a phone from a Washington attorney. The investigation may focus on Giuliani's paid work for Ukrainian businessmen, potentially violating US laws against unregistered lobbying for foreign entities. Giuliani's son condemned the raid as "disgusting" and accused the Justice Department of a political agenda, while Giuliani's attorney described the raids as "legal thuggery." The raid comes amid ongoing investigations and lawsuits against Giuliani, including a $1.3 billion lawsuit over election claims.

site_title: Biden launches audacious middle class spending package in speech to Congress
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to unveil a $2 trillion spending package aimed at boosting the middle class and "forgotten" American workers. The plan, dubbed the American Families Plan, would increase funding for education, childcare, and other programs, and reverse tax cuts for the rich. To fund it, Biden plans to raise taxes on the top income earners and close loopholes for the wealthy. The proposal is seen as a bid to address economic inequality and allow millions more Americans to join the middle class.

site_title: Vital to increase focus on adaptability and empathy in compliance conversation
summary: Technology leaders agree that the past year's rapid changes have made compliance a significant challenge. The pandemic has introduced new regulatory requirements, making it difficult for organisations to adjust and maintain business continuity. To overcome this, a focus on adaptability and empathy in compliance conversations is crucial. Organisations must cultivate an adaptable mindset, collaborate with technology partners to simplify complex regulatory issues, and foster a culture of empathy and approachability among employees. By doing so, they can drive efficiency and compliance while staying customer-centric and data-secure.

site_title: Facebook profit nearly doubles as user ranks grow
summary: Facebook reported a nearly double profit of $9.5 billion in the recently ended quarter, driven by a 46% increase in online ad revenue to $25.4 billion. The social network's monthly user base grew 10% to 2.85 billion, and overall monthly users reached 3.45 billion, a 15% increase. Shares jumped nearly 5% in after-market trades, beating market expectations. However, Facebook warned of "increased ad targeting headwinds" due to regulation and Apple's new iOS privacy feature, which could impact digital ad revenue growth.

site_title: Federal Reserve nods to strengthening US economy but waves off policy shift talk
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its stance on keeping interest rates and emergency support unchanged, citing that the economy is not yet out of the pandemic's recovery phase. Despite a rosier view of the economic recovery, Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that it's too early to consider rolling back policies, with the central bank wanting to keep monetary policy loose for the foreseeable future. The Fed's policy statement also noted that inflation is expected to rise but will likely be of a passing nature, and the economy will take time to reach its goals.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday took a rosier view of the US economic recovery and the nation's war against the coronavirus, but said it was too early to consider rolling back its emergency support with so many workers still left jobless by the pandemic.

site_title: China's approach to digital currency would not work in US: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that China's rapid development of a digital yuan will not prompt the US to rush its own digital currency project. The Fed prioritizes avoiding a "calamitous misstep" in executing digitalization of the dollar, rather than speed. China's approach, which allows the government to track payments in real-time, may not be suitable for the US. The US central bank is researching a joint programme with MIT to develop a central bank digital currency, with a projected two- to three-year timeline.

images.alt_text: China's rapid development of a digital version of the yuan will not push the Federal Reserve to rush its own digital currency project, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday, adding that China's approach would not work in the United States.

site_title: The new 'protein' diet
summary: The alternative protein industry is gaining momentum as consumers increasingly opt for plant-based "mock" meats due to climate change concerns. Singapore is at the forefront of this movement, with various players setting up operations and restaurants incorporating these products into their menus. Examples include jackfruit "pork chops" and pea protein "cheese." This shift is driven by consumers seeking sustainable food options, and it is expected to continue as the industry expands.

site_title: Jokowi pushes foreign investment drive with Cabinet makeover
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo established the Ministry of Investment to boost foreign investment and job creation, aiming to achieve 5% growth this year. The new ministry, led by Bahlil Lahadalia, will focus on improving investment quality and supporting small- and medium-sized businesses. This move follows a cabinet makeover in April, which included new appointments for trade, social affairs, and tourism posts. Indonesia has implemented an omnibus law to cut red tape and is targeting US$200 billion in direct investment this year, up from 826 trillion rupiah last year.

site_title: Saudi crown prince to further centralise policy-making
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Salman plans to further centralize policymaking to achieve the kingdom's economic diversification goals. He will establish a new Policies Office and transfer budget setting to a Budget Bureau, reducing the finance ministry's role. This move follows the formation of a Council of Economic and Development Affairs, headed by the prince, and aims to strengthen the state's role in delivering on its vision. The prince also reiterated his opposition to introducing income tax.

site_title: China's north-south economic divide set to widen
summary: China's economic divide between the north and south is expected to widen, with southern provinces benefiting from export dependence and the internet boom, while northern regions struggle with slower fixed investment and population migration. The gap has grown over the past decade, with northern China's share of the national economy shrinking to 35.2% in 2020 from 42.9% in 2012. This widening divide has led to rising fiscal pressures and debt in the north, with over 60% of bond defaults coming from northern China in 2020. The divide may persist due to low birth rates and population outflows.

site_title: Should investors cheer Top Glove's scaled-back capital-raising exercise?
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysia-based glove manufacturer, has scaled back its capital-raising plans, reducing the amount of new shares it plans to issue from 1.495 billion to 793.5 million. This move aims to minimize dilution to existing shareholders. Despite this, the company's expansion plans remain unchanged, with a focus on increasing production capacity and developing a data-driven manufacturing system. Top Glove's earnings have surged during the pandemic, and it may be able to fund its plans internally, but a potential slump in profitability looms due to increased supply and lower prices.

site_title: When can we declare the pandemic over?
summary: The article discusses when the COVID-19 pandemic can be declared over. Despite improvements, cases are still rising and hospitalizations and deaths continue, especially among unvaccinated populations. Experts recommend a gradual relaxation of restrictions, monitoring cases and positivity rates, and tracking vaccination progress. A balanced approach between the ideal and doable is necessary, as the risk of COVID-19 is still present but manageable. The author suggests setting benchmarks for relaxation of guidelines and promoting long-term behaviors such as vaccination and mask-wearing to reduce morbidity and mortality from infectious diseases.

site_title: SoftBank nears end of its US$23 billion buyback
summary: SoftBank Group is nearing the end of its $23 billion buyback program, with only 10% of the committed capital remaining. This could lead to a stock price decline as share performance slides. The company has spent over $20 billion on share purchases over the past year, more than doubling the value of the stock. With buybacks potentially ending, short bets may emerge, and SoftBank's stock could face further headwinds if the sale of chip designer Arm Ltd to Nvidia falls through.

site_title: 'Asia's Major' is back at Sentosa, with top golfers in town
summary: The HSBC Women's World Championship golf tournament is set to take place at Sentosa Golf Club's New Tanjong course, with 69 golfers competing for the US$300,000 top prize. South Korean golfers, including Park Inbee and Ko Jin-young, are favored to win, having produced four champions in the four editions of the tournament. The event, which starts on Thursday, comes after a series of contrasting performances by top golfers, including Lydia Ko and Patty Tavatanakit, who have won and missed the cut in recent tournaments.

site_title: Oil gains more than 1% on fuel demand optimism
summary: Crude oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday, driven by US distillate inventories drawing down and refiners increasing activity to their highest in over a year. Opec+ reaffirmed its plan to ease oil production restrictions from May to July, boosting hopes for rising fuel demand. Brent crude futures gained 1.3% to $67.27 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1.5% to $63.86 a barrel. Refining rates reached 85.4% of capacity, and distillate stockpiles fell by 3.3 million barrels.

images.alt_text: Crude prices rose more than 1 per cent on Wednesday, after US distillate inventories posted a large drawdown and refiners ramped up activity to the highest in over a year, boosting hopes for rising fuel demand in the world's top oil consumer.

site_title: Tough for Sheng Siong to repeat run: analysts
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 2.7% increase in revenue and a 6.5% increase in profit for the quarter ended March 31. However, analysts warn that the stock may not have much more room to run, citing that last year's performance may be difficult to beat. The company's recent growth may not be sustainable, leading to a potential correction in the stock market.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong's revenue increased by 40 per cent in 2020, to S$1.4 billion. This was the first time that the company's topline crossed the S$1 billion mark.

site_title: Johnson's woes deepen as UK watchdog launches apartment probe
summary: The UK's Electoral Commission has launched a formal investigation into how Prime Minister Boris Johnson paid for a lavish makeover of his Downing Street flat, amid allegations of cronyism and favouritism. The probe, which can demand repayment of questionable donations, fines, or police prosecution, comes as Johnson faces opposition pressure ahead of local elections. Johnson has denied wrongdoing, stating he conformed to the code of conduct and ministerial code, but his aides have failed to explain how party funds were used initially, sparking further scrutiny.

site_title: In a time of the pandemic, Spain's flamenco clubs and dancers may not survive
summary: Spain's flamenco clubs, known as tablaos, face extinction due to the pandemic, with 34 of the 93 national association's tablaos shutting their doors for good since the pandemic began. Despite the government's financial support, many tablaos struggle to reopen due to reduced audience capacity and social distancing rules, making it economically unviable. Flamenco artists value the creative benefits of working in tablaos, where they can test new ideas and share emotions with audiences. If the government doesn't provide more financial support, the loss of these institutions could threaten the very essence of Spain's national art form.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LHN Limited has acquired a 30-unit property in Singapore for S$13.5 million to convert into a co-living space. Jiutian Chemical posted a net profit of 90.31 million yuan (S$18.48 million) and a 120% year-on-year increase in revenue. KrisEnergy's Apsara field's performance was downgraded due to lower hydrocarbon-in-place and well productivity. Tee International changed its financial year-end to September 30 to improve resource management.

site_title: 2021 wage growth likely to be 'relatively muted': MAS
summary: MAS expects 2021 wage growth to be "relatively muted" due to lingering economic uncertainties and weakened corporate balance sheets, with resident wage growth projected to rise only slightly from 1.4% in 2020. Total employment fell by 4.8% in 2020, with labour demand shifting structurally lower, and the labour market still showing spare capacity. Inflation is expected to rise, mainly due to global oil price increases, but the MAS believes the increases will be temporary.

images.alt_text: This year's wage growth is expected to remain "relatively muted", even though the pandemic-led increase in labour productivity is likely to be permanent, the April edition of the Macroeconomic Review has said.

site_title: Huarong repays offshore bond with help from ICBC
summary: China's Huarong Asset Management repaid an offshore bond maturing on April 27 with a loan from Industrial & Commercial Bank of China's Singapore branch, a sign of lenders supporting the distressed-debt manager. The S$600 million bond was repaid using funds provided by the state-owned bank. This move indicates Chinese lenders are responding to government calls to support Huarong, which has been embattled. The repayment comes amid China's economic slowdown and pressure on policymakers to stimulate growth.

site_title: Crews start cleaning up oil spill off China's Qingdao port
summary: Crews in China's Qingdao port began cleaning up an oil spill in the Yellow Sea after a collision between a tanker and a bulk vessel in thick fog. A preliminary estimate suggests around 500 tonnes of oil were spilled, with no reported casualties. A probe is underway into the incident. Twelve vessels were dispatched to contain the spill, which authorities described as "minor".

images.alt_text: Activity in the cargo port, located in northern Shandong province, stayed busy with several trucks driving in and out of a terminal, reporters witnessed.

site_title: Biden unveils massive family aid plan funded by taxing rich
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to unveil the American Families Plan, a $1.8 trillion plan to expand educational opportunities and child care for families, funded by tax increases on wealthy Americans. The plan combines $1 trillion in spending with $800 billion in tax cuts and credits for middle- and lower-income families. This is Biden's third major legislative proposal, aiming to support low- and middle-income families. The tax increases will be the largest on wealthy Americans in decades.

site_title: US dollar drifts higher before Fed decision
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% to 91.047, driven by investors moving to the sidelines ahead of a US Federal Reserve policy statement and a speech by President Joe Biden, where he's expected to announce more stimulus plans. The dollar index bounced back from a one-month low, while the euro slipped 0.2% to $1.2070. Investors expect the Fed to maintain its policy settings, with yields on 10-year US Treasury notes rising above 1.60%. The dollar's recovery is seen as a response to strong inflation expectations, which rose above 2.40% on Tuesday.

site_title: Tan Tock Seng Hospital nurse, doctor, 3 patients test positive for Covid-19
summary: A possible Covid-19 cluster has emerged at Tan Tock Seng Hospital in Singapore, with a nurse testing positive and likely infections in a doctor and three patients. The nurse, who received both Covid-19 vaccine doses, developed symptoms on April 27 and was warded at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases. The hospital has locked down the affected ward and tested staff and patients, with four more cases preliminarily testing positive. All staff and visitors to the ward are on quarantine as epidemiological investigations and contact tracing continue.

site_title: Financed emissions 700 times more than banks' direct emissions
summary: Banks and asset managers contribute significantly to climate change through their loan books and investment portfolios, emitting 700 times more greenhouse gases than their direct emissions. The financial sector's role in financing polluting industries and enabling the high-carbon economy is a major concern, with major banks committing to measuring and reporting their carbon emissions. However, many institutions underestimate climate-related risks and do not report their financed emissions, with only 25% of companies providing data. The true figure is likely significantly higher, with banks providing over $3.8 trillion in fossil-fuel financing since the Paris Agreement.

site_title: Accountants have a big role in enabling climate action
summary: Accountants play a crucial role in enabling climate action by educating, consulting, and measuring businesses' sustainability agendas. A recent survey found that the pandemic has heightened environmental awareness, with 70% of respondents stating they are more aware of the threat to the climate. Chartered accountants can help businesses pivot their models to be more sustainable, assess climate risk, and integrate green policies into organizational strategies. By providing guidance on ESG reporting, benchmarking, and measuring success, accountants can encourage businesses to adopt sustainability initiatives, ultimately driving a virtuous cycle of sustainable change.

site_title: Developing Asia's 2021 rebound could be stronger than thought, but risks remain: ADB
summary: Developing Asia's economy is forecast to grow 7.3% in 2021, stronger than initially thought, driven by a solid global recovery and progress on vaccines. However, risks remain, including new Covid-19 outbreaks and delays in vaccine roll-out, which could prolong disruptions to mobility and stall regional economic activity. The region is expected to grow 5.3% in 2022. China's economy is predicted to rebound with 8.1% growth this year, followed by 5.5% in 2022, while South Asia is expected to record the fastest economic recovery, driven by India's economic revival.

site_title: Biden's first 100 days: looking good but not great
summary: President Joe Biden's first 100 days in office have shown mixed results, with high marks for handling the coronavirus pandemic but less success in uniting the nation and overcoming political divisions. His approval rating of 52% is historically low, with only 13% of Republicans approving. The economy has also been a point of contention, with many Americans critical of the Biden administration's immigration policies. Despite this, the pandemic response and economic stimulus plan have received strong public support, with 64% of adults approving of his handling of the pandemic and 65% supporting the economic stimulus plan.

site_title: Alpha DX proposes acquisition of education institute for S$24 million
summary: Alpha DX Group has proposed the acquisition of ERC Institute (ERCI) for approximately S$24 million. The transaction will be financed through internal funds and a fund-raising exercise. Alpha DX aims to leverage ERCI's expertise in educational services and expand its customer base and network with global institutions. Performance conditions include securing S$4 million in annual revenue from the Uzbekistan government and increasing student enrolments by at least 40%. The acquisition is expected to generate potential commercial, operational, and cost synergies for Alpha DX.

site_title: US watchdog mulls guidance to curb SPAC's projections, protection
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is considering new guidance to curb the growth projections made by listed blank-cheque companies, known as SPACs, and clarify when they qualify for certain legal protections. The move aims to address concerns that SPACs are putting investors at risk due to frequently optimistic or misleading earnings growth projections. The guidance would likely prompt more due diligence and caution on the part of SPAC dealmakers. The SEC's crackdown on SPACs follows recent warnings over marketing and investor communications, and comes as the market has already started to slow down.

site_title: UBS sees Singapore shine amid rise of region's family offices
summary: UBS Asia Pacific has reported a record high in Q1 2021, with pre-tax profit up 21% to US$900 million, driven by the growth of family offices and wealth management in Singapore, which is capturing the rise of South-east Asia's new companies. The bank's Asia Pacific region has grown in importance, making up 37% of the group's profit before tax, with Singapore now soaking up new money at a quicker pace than Hong Kong. UBS aims to grow the business to at least two times the gross domestic product of the region.

site_title: No silver bullet for decarbonisation; stakeholders must act in unison
summary: Singapore is stepping up its efforts to tackle climate change and decarbonization in the shipping industry. The city-state has launched a Maritime Singapore Decarbonisation Blueprint 2050, which outlines long-term strategies for the local maritime sector. The International Advisory Panel on Maritime Decarbonisation recommends nine pathways to increase momentum in the maritime sector's decarbonisation efforts, including harmonizing standards, implementing new solutions, and financing projects. Singapore aims to lead the way in meeting the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2030 and 2050 decarbonization goals, with the establishment of a global maritime decarbonisation centre and the development of green financing initiatives.

site_title: Tan Tock Seng Hospital nurse, doctor and three patients in general ward test positive for Covid-19
summary: A possible Covid-19 cluster has emerged at Tan Tock Seng Hospital in Singapore, with a 46-year-old nurse testing positive for the virus. The nurse was deployed to Ward 9D, where a doctor and three patients have also tested positive. The hospital has locked down the ward and placed staff and visitors on quarantine. The cluster is believed to have started when the nurse developed symptoms on April 27 and sought medical treatment. Further testing is ongoing to determine the total number of cases.

site_title: LHN buys hotel property at 115 Geylang Road
summary: LHN Limited acquired a 30-unit hotel property at 115 Geylang Road in Singapore for S$13.5 million, with the remaining balance to be paid through internal sources and bank borrowings by July 21, 2021. The property is currently operated as a hotel under a three-year agreement that commenced on November 15, 2020.

site_title: Journalists create their brands in growing 'direct' sales model
summary: Freelance journalists are creating their own brands and charging subscription fees to connect with readers, bypassing traditional outlets. The trend, driven by the media sector's economic woes, has led to a growing movement of writers using platforms like Substack, with 500,000 subscribers paying an average of $5-10 per month. Notable journalists, including Pulitzer Prize winner Glenn Greenwald, are capitalizing on this model, while new entrants and large platforms like Twitter and Facebook are also entering the market, highlighting both opportunities and challenges for independent writers.

site_title: MOM looking at ways to help companies hit by India travel ban: Josephine Teo
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower is exploring ways to help companies impacted by the India travel ban, which has made it difficult for employers to bring in workers to replace those who have returned home. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo cited the construction sector as a key area in need of support, citing project deadlines and a tight manpower crunch. The ministry is looking at meaningful options, including easing skills-certification rules for workers from China, to alleviate the situation.

site_title: Thai Tycoons step in to speed up vaccination for quick reopening
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha has met with top business groups to accelerate a mass Covid-19 vaccination rollout, aiming to cover 70% of the population by year's end. Billionaires Dhanin Chearavanont's Charoen Pokphand Group and VGI have agreed to participate, as the country grapples with its worst coronavirus outbreak since the pandemic began. The private sector's involvement aims to support the government's efforts in a bid for a quick reopening.

site_title: BofA hit hardest as EU fines bond-trading trio US$34m
summary: The European Union has fined Bank of America, Credit Suisse, and Credit Agricole a total of $46.6 million for colluding in chatrooms on trading of US bonds from 2009 to 2015. The traders, known as "the Kumars," shared sensitive pricing information and coordinated prices, restricting competition in the market. Deutsche Bank, which participated in the cartel, was not fined due to its early reporting. The fines are smaller than previous EU cartels, reflecting the small size of the US dollar SSA trading market.

site_title: India's Covid-19 resurgence is a disaster; developed nations must help
summary: India's Covid-19 resurgence is a major humanitarian and economic disaster, with the country setting records for new cases and deaths. Hospital facilities are strained, and the vaccine rollout has been sluggish. The death toll is expected to peak, with over 13,000 daily deaths predicted over the next three to four weeks. Complacency, poor virus protocols, and a surge in new variants are blamed for the crisis. Developed nations must act to help, as India's crippling caseload threatens global vaccine supply and restricts exports to lower- and middle-income countries.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices hit 20-month high
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a 20-month high in March, rising 0.8% from the previous month. The prices are supported by robust demand and a recovering economy, despite a supply shortage. The market is expected to see the highest transaction volumes in eight years, with values at a 23-year high. Mainland Chinese buyers accounted for 40% more purchases in the first two months of 2021 than last year, driven by improved sentiment and expectations of price increases after borders reopen.

site_title: US: Stocks open mixed, awaiting Fed decision
summary: US stocks opened mixed on April 28, 2021, amid corporate earnings and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Analysts attributed the lackluster response to the mixed earnings news. Meanwhile, President Joe Biden is set to unveil his $1.8 trillion American Families Plan, which aims to fund it by ending tax cuts and closing loopholes for the wealthy. The plan is expected to be announced later in the day.

site_title: Thai PM granted sweeping powers to curb Covid-19
summary: Thailand's Premier Prayut Chan-O-Cha has been granted sweeping new powers to curb the country's COVID-19 outbreak, which critics fear could be used to suppress dissent. The move comes as Thailand struggles to contain a third wave of cases, with over 32,000 new cases reported since an outbreak in the capital's nightlife district. The new powers allow Prayut to oversee laws related to surveillance and censorship, and opposition leaders have criticized the move as an attempt to consolidate power.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$803m in Indiana to build new SUVs
summary: Toyota is investing $803 million in its Indiana assembly plant to build two new larger SUVs, adding 1,400 jobs. The vehicles will feature semi-automated driving systems and are expected to be unveiled in 2022. The company will also introduce two new electric vehicles in the US market next year, including an SUV model.

site_title: Total employment up for first time in Q1 since outbreak: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment grew by 4,800 persons in Q1 2021, marking the first expansion since Q4 2019, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Unemployment rates fell to 2.9%, down from 3% in the previous quarter, with overall employment reaching 3.61 million. Retrenchments declined to 2,100, equivalent to pre-Covid levels. While businesses are regaining confidence to hire, economists expect the recovery to be slow due to strict border controls and foreign worker measures.

images.alt_text: The tide is finally turning for Singapore's labour market, with total employment estimated to have expanded by 4,800 persons in Q1 2021 after four consecutive quarters of decline.

site_title: Myanmar junta launches fresh air raids in rebel territory
summary: Myanmar's military launched air raids into rebel-held territory for the second consecutive day, following gunfire in neighboring Thailand. The Karen National Union (KNU), a prominent anti-junta group, has been targeted by the junta's air assaults, which have displaced over 24,000 people since the military's first strikes last month. The KNU denies attacking any military targets, criticizing the junta's extensive use of air power that harms civilians. Over 750 civilians have been killed by the junta's security forces since the coup in February 1.

site_title: ESR-Reit divests two properties for S$53m
summary: ESR-Reit is divesting two properties in Singapore for S$53 million, a 5% premium to their total fair value. The divestment will reduce the Reit's pro forma gearing to 40.9% and be completed in the second half of the year. The proceeds will be used to repay borrowings, fund asset enhancements, and support general working capital requirements. The divestment is part of ESR-Reit's portfolio optimisation strategy to monetise non-core assets and improve the quality of its portfolio, optimising returns for unitholders.

images.alt_text: The property at 11 Serangoon North Avenue 5 is a six-storey multi-tenanted general industrial building in the Ang Mo Kio Industrial Estate. It has a remaining land lease tenure of 36.3 years and a gross floor area of 146,619 square feet.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde sees rapid rebound as vaccinations take off
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde expects rapid growth in the euro zone economy in the second half of 2021 as vaccination rates surge and life returns to normal. Less than a quarter of the population has received their first shot, but vaccine supply bottlenecks are expected to ease. Lagarde predicts 70% of the population will be vaccinated by the end of summer, supporting the ECB's 4% growth projections. The ECB has committed to keeping financing conditions favorable, with Lagarde dismissing criticism that bond purchases have not met March pledges.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical net profit jumps more than 30 times year on year
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group reported a net profit of 90.31 million yuan, more than 30 times its net profit of 2.87 million yuan in the same period last year, driven by a 120% year-on-year increase in revenue to 439.25 million yuan. Average selling prices of its main products, dimethylformamide (DMF) and methylamine, rose 98% and 38% respectively, while sales volume increased 65% and 32% year-on-year. The company's gross profit margin rose to 32%, up from 7% last year, due to higher average selling prices.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 organisers announce tougher Covid-19 countermeasures
summary: Tokyo 2020 Olympics organisers have announced tougher Covid-19 countermeasures, including daily testing of athletes, amid a resurgence of the virus in Japan and growing public scepticism. With under three months to go before the postponed Games, organisers are taking measures to reassure citizens and athletes, but Japan's vaccination drive lags behind other wealthy nations, raising safety concerns. The joint statement by the Tokyo 2020 organising committee, IOC, Japanese government, and International Paralympic Committee prioritises safety, but the move may impact Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's efforts to host the Games.

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens in March
summary: The US trade deficit in goods widened 4.0% to $90.6 billion in March, suggesting it may have hindered economic growth in the first quarter. Despite this, domestic demand likely offset the impact, driven by massive fiscal stimulus and easing pandemic stress. This report precedes the release of GDP data, which is expected to show a 6.1% annualized growth rate for the first quarter.

images.alt_text: The United States' trade deficit in goods surged in March, suggesting trade was likely a drag on economic growth in the first quarter, but that was probably offset by strong domestic demand amid massive fiscal stimulus and easing pandemic stress.

site_title: World economy rebound on track; Singapore 2021 growth could exceed 6%
summary: The world economy is on track to recover from the second quarter, with global growth expected to regain its end-2019 level by Q2 and expand by 6.2% for the year. Singapore's full-year growth is forecast to exceed 6%, driven by firming external demand. However, emerging market economies, such as India, face challenges due to the ongoing Covid-19 crisis, which could exacerbate the unevenness of the global recovery. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that the relationship between the response to Covid-19 and economic activity will become more muted over time.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.82 points higher at 1608.50 on Wednesday, with 6.586 billion lots traded worth RM3.855 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 586 to 457.

site_title: Standard Chartered considers slashing Singapore office space
summary: Standard Chartered is considering downsizing its office space in Singapore by giving up a minimum of four floors, equivalent to about 80,000 square feet, at Marina Bay Financial Tower 1. This move could be the biggest floor cut by a bank in Singapore in recent years. The bank is among several global banks shifting to permanent hybrid working arrangements following the Covid-19 pandemic, with plans to retain only essential floors to keep its logo on the building's facade.

site_title: Taiwan chipmaker UMC to spend NT$100b to expand capacity
summary: Taiwan chipmaker UMC plans to invest NT$100 billion (S$4.75 billion) over three years to expand capacity at a plant in southern Taiwan, amid a global chip shortage. The expansion, scheduled to start in 2023, aims to alleviate capacity tightness across the supply chain. This move follows similar announcements from UMC competitor TSMC and Intel, as the global chip shortage affects automakers, smartphone manufacturers, and household appliance makers. The investment will bring UMC's total investment in the Tainan Science Park to NT$150 billion over the next three years.

site_title: Johnson faces formal probe over funding of apartment renovation
summary: Britain's electoral commission launched a formal investigation into the financing of the refurbishment of Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Downing Street apartment, citing grounds to suspect an offence may have been committed. The commission will determine whether any transactions relating to the works fell within regulated funding regimes and whether such funding was reported as required. The opposition Labour Party demanded an explanation, and allegations have been made about Johnson's handling of the Covid-19 crisis and potential secret funding for the renovation.

site_title: Office rents could bottom out by end-2021 amid uneven property segment recovery: report
summary: Office rents in Singapore are expected to bottom out by the end of 2021, according to a report by Edmund Tie. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, office expansion plans by tech giants like Tencent, Alibaba, and ByteDance are expected to support growth. Rents of premium-grade offices held steady or declined slightly in Q1 2021, while occupancy rates remained stable at 93.3%. However, the report notes that recovery in the office segment is uneven, with investment and residential sales showing stronger performance.

site_title: STI up 0.16% as equities markets across Asia gain despite a flat Wall Street overnight
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.16% to close at 3,219.56 points, despite a flat Wall Street overnight. The Straits Times Index gained despite gapping down earlier. Key Asian markets, except South Korea, posted gains, driven by favorable macroeconomic data. Sembcorp Marine traded heavily, with shares rising 10% to S$0.22. Aviation-related stocks, including Singapore Airlines, fell after benefiting from the air-travel bubble between Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Embattled Boeing posts smaller loss as more Americans fly
summary: Boeing reported a smaller quarterly loss of $353 million, driven by increased deliveries of the 737 MAX jet, which reflected a cautious rebound in air travel from the pandemic. However, concerns over COVID variants and geopolitical tensions in China and India cloud the industry's recovery. Boeing reaffirmed plans to increase 737 MAX production and has delivered over 85 jets since the plane's re-entry into service. The company also faces challenges in its 787 production and Air Force One program.

site_title: Large unit at Queensway Shopping Centre put on market for S$7.5m
summary: A 2,734 sq ft unit at Queensway Shopping Centre in Singapore, occupied by Anytime Fitness, has been put on the market for S$7.5 million via private treaty. The freehold development failed a collective-sale attempt two years ago due to insufficient owner consent. The unit features 24-hour access and a glass facade, and is one of only two large floor-plate units in the mall.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on Wednesday with gains, mirroring Asian markets, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.45%, and the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.42%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also saw a 0.83% increase. These gains follow recent market movements, with stocks in Asia and the US reaching new records despite ongoing trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Hong Kong passes new immigration Bill raising fears of exit ban
summary: Hong Kong's government passed a new immigration Bill, raising concerns it could prevent dissidents from leaving the city. The Bill, effective August 1, speeds up refugee handling, reduces visa overstays, and gives the immigration director power to prevent passengers from boarding flights. The government has dismissed concerns as "nonsense," but the Hong Kong Bar Association fears it could give "unfettered power" to impose travel bans. This move follows China's tightening grip on Hong Kong, including a national security law and amendments to the city's Basic Law.

site_title: Lloyds smashed quarterly profit forecasts
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported £1.9 billion in pretax profit for the first quarter, exceeding analyst forecasts and beating the £74 million reported last year. The bank's loan books remained firm despite the pandemic, and it released £459 million set aside for bad loans. CEO António Horta-Osório is leaving to become chairman of Credit Suisse, and Charlie Nunn will take over as CEO in August. The bank's economic outlook has improved, leading to revised guidance and cost cuts.

site_title: Ikea to open small-format store at Jem, its first in South-east Asia
summary: Ikea, a Swedish furniture giant, is set to open its first small-format store in South-east Asia at Jem shopping mall in Jurong East, Singapore. The 70,000 sq ft store will offer the full range of Ikea products, a restaurant, and a click-and-collect ordering service. It will be completely cashless and is expected to attract 3 million visitors annually. The move is part of Ikea's strategy to become more accessible to consumers worldwide, with plans for five standalone planning studios in Singapore.

site_title: Google's results show surge in ad sales
summary: Google's first-quarter revenue surged to $45.6 billion, exceeding Wall Street estimates, driven by a surge in ad sales related to travel and retail. The company's YouTube ad revenue jumped 49% to $6 billion, while its cloud division saw growth. Alphabet's shares rose 5.5% to an intraday record high, and the company announced a $50 billion share buyback. The strong earnings reflect a post-pandemic shift towards online spending, with consumers increasingly interacting with Google services before venturing out.

images.alt_text: Google's results, showing a surge in ad sales related to travel and retail, offered a glimpse of online spending in a post-pandemic world: businesses are boosting digital marketing to capture a public eager to resume something resembling normal life again.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The global economy is expected to regain its pre-pandemic level by Q2 and expand 6.2% in 2021 due to fiscal stimulus and vaccination rollout. Total employment in Singapore grew for the first time in Q1 since the pandemic, with wage growth likely to be "relatively muted". Meanwhile, Singapore property developers are bracing for cooling measures, and Ikea is set to open its first small-format store in South-east Asia. The Straits Times Index gained 0.16% today, despite a flat US market overnight.

site_title: Singapore Prestige Brand Award 2020/21 celebrates firms that have overcome Covid-19 challenges
summary: The Singapore Prestige Brand Award (SPBA) 2020/21 was launched to celebrate local brands that have overcome Covid-19 challenges. The award, now in its 20th year, has a new theme "On to Higher Ground" to encourage resilience and excellence. The award recognizes brands that have adapted and emerged stronger, with examples like LHN Group, which doubled its revenue by converting spaces into e-commerce and co-living facilities. The award has four categories and will be announced at a later date, with Huawei International as its technology partner.

site_title: Del Monte unit filing for IPO in the Philippines
summary: Del Monte Pacific's Philippine subsidiary, Del Monte Philippines, has submitted a registration statement to the Philippine Securities and Exchange Commission to propose an initial public offering (IPO) of its common shares. The food-and-beverage company plans to offer up to 15% of its stake to meet the minimum public float requirement, while retaining a majority stake in the subsidiary. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to reduce gearing and retire preference shares.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit, M1 to create special purpose vehicle to house M1 network assets
summary: Keppel DC Reit and M1 have signed a non-binding term sheet to establish a special purpose vehicle (SPV) to own and operate M1's network assets for S$580 million. The SPV will be funded through external financing and an S$87 million investment by Keppel DC Reit, with M1 retaining 100% ownership. The transaction is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals, and aims to free up capital for M1 to invest in new capabilities and growth initiatives.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open with eyes on US
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, driven by investors' anticipation of US President Joe Biden's spending plan and the Federal Reserve's policy update. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose 0.4%. The gains come as investors await key events in the US, including Mr. Biden's first speech to Congress.

site_title: Solar shines as Singapore's energy alternative; international collaboration is key
summary: Singapore aims to transform its energy production, transportation, and usage by harnessing natural gas, solar energy, regional power grids, and low-carbon alternatives. The country plans to quadruple its solar deployment by 2025, aiming to power 350,000 households annually by 2030. International collaboration is key to advancing the energy transition, with Singapore seeking to leverage regional power grids and technology-enabled innovation. The country's efforts aim to reduce emissions and contribute to a global low-carbon energy future, aligning with the Paris Agreement.

site_title: South Korea eyes early herd immunity to fuel economic growth
summary: South Korea is considering moving up its herd immunity target to November, potentially achieving it earlier than planned, due to a faster-than-expected economic expansion. The country's economic growth beat estimates in the first quarter, surpassing the pre-pandemic size of its economy. However, consumption remains slow, and vaccination rates lag behind other developed nations. Acting Prime Minister Hong Nam-ki attributed the recovery to semiconductor and vehicle exports, estimating 0.8% growth in each of the remaining quarters to achieve a 4% annual expansion.

site_title: High-floor strata office at Suntec Tower 2 up for sale
summary: A strata office at Suntec Tower 2 in Singapore has been put up for sale via expression of interest with an indicative price of S$37.5 million. The high-floor office features an exclusive lift lobby, panoramic city views, and a 12,281 sq ft strata area valued at S$3,050 per sq ft. The lease is set to expire by the end of the year, making it suitable for immediate occupation. Both locals and foreigners are eligible to purchase the property, which is zoned "commercial" under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's 2019 Master Plan.

site_title: Ant-backed startup Zomato files for 82.5b rupee Mumbai IPO
summary: Zomato, an Indian food delivery startup backed by Jack Ma's Ant Group, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) worth up to 82.5 billion rupees (S$1.47 billion). The company plans to issue new shares to raise 75 billion rupees, while its major shareholder Info Edge India will offer 7.5 billion rupees. Zomato is also considering raising an additional 15 billion rupees before the IPO. The IPO filing confirms a previous report and marks the company's move towards becoming a publicly traded entity.

site_title: Five global mega banks signalling a recovery this results season
summary: Five global mega banks, including HSBC, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, UBS, and Credit Suisse, have reported improved financial performance in the first quarter of 2021, beating analyst expectations. HSBC reported a profit of $5.78 billion, while JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup posted profits of $14.3 billion and $7.94 billion, respectively. UBS reported a 14% increase in net profit to $1.82 billion, and Credit Suisse reported a lower-than-expected loss despite an expected Q2 hit from the Archegos collapse. These results signal a recovery in the banking sector.

site_title: Singapore could consider quarantine exemption for vaccinated residents travelling to some countries
summary: Singapore may consider exempting vaccinated residents from quarantine upon return from low-Covid-19 case countries, Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung said. This move could allow Singaporeans to travel to countries like Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, and the US without quarantine, as long as the destination country keeps the number of cases low. The exemption would be tested on a case-by-case basis and not considered a full travel bubble.

site_title: Huawei's quarterly sales slump as sanctions hit phone business
summary: Huawei's quarterly sales declined 17% to 150.1 billion yuan due to US sanctions that devastated its smartphone business. This marks the second straight quarter of decline. Despite the revenue drop, the company's net income rose 25% to 16.8 billion yuan due to cost-cutting measures. Huawei is shifting focus to new growth areas such as smart agriculture, healthcare, and electric cars, with a pledged investment of $1 billion in self-driving and electric-car technologies. The company aims to compete with tech giants like Baidu and Xiaomi in emerging fields.

site_title: Shophouses at Lavender, Geylang up for sale by tender, expression of interest
summary: Three shophouses in Singapore's city fringe area are up for sale by tender and expression of interest. The properties, located at 53 Lavender Street, 35 Tyrwhitt Road, and 8 Lorong 22 Geylang, offer varying price points, ranging from S$7.8 million to S$9.5 million. The sale by tender for 53 Lavender Street and 35 Tyrwhitt Road will close on June 8, while the expression of interest for 8 Lorong 22 Geylang will close on June 29. The properties are expected to attract investors due to their proximity to amenities and gentrification of the area.

site_title: Sony Q4 profit doubles, helped by gaming, movies and other content
summary: Sony reported a 88% increase in Q4 operating profit to 66.5 billion yen, driven by strong demand for gaming, movies, and content during the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's PlayStation 5 console and subscription services contributed to the growth. To focus on entertainment, Sony is streamlining its consumer electronics business and expanding its content offerings, including a deal to buy AT&T's animation business Crunchyroll. The company forecasts a 4.3% decline in profit this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end slightly higher, corporate outlook concerns cap gains
summary: Japanese shares closed slightly higher on Wednesday, led by technology stocks, but concerns about corporate outlook capped gains. The Nikkei average rose 0.21% to 29,053.97, while the Topix increased 0.29% to 1,903. Investor concerns about corporate outlook, despite recent strong earnings reports, led to a cautious mood.

site_title: Three community infections among 23 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 23 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 61,086. Three community cases were confirmed, while 20 were imported cases linked to countries such as India, Ivory Coast, and Malaysia. The number of unlinked community cases remains stable at four cases per week. With 22 cases discharged, 60,689 patients have recovered, and 108 remain in hospital. Globally, the virus has infected over 148 million people, resulting in over 3.13 million deaths.

site_title: Deutsche Bank swings to Q1 profit on investment bank strength
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a net profit of 908 million euros in Q1 2021, exceeding expectations of 600 million euros, driven by strong performance at its investment bank. This marks the strongest quarter for the German lender in years, as fixed-income trading and origination/advisory services revenue surged. The result offset headwinds from the pandemic and restructuring efforts.

site_title: BTExplains: What Suntec Reit's numbers say about risks in the office segment
summary: Suntec Reit's Q1 2021 results show office occupancy in Singapore at 96.1%, with retail occupancy at 91.5%. The Reit's net property income rose 10.2% year-over-year, driven by new contributions from 9 Penang Road and improved performance of Marina Bay Financial Centre properties. However, concerns about vacancy and net absorption moderate the subsequent magnitude of rental uptick. Large tenants may exit, and office space supply uncertainty remains, with JPMorgan predicting lower demand amid work-from-home arrangements. The Reit's gearing is sector-high at 44%, prompting exploration of divestments or partnerships.

images.alt_text: As work-from-home arrangements cut the amount of office workers in nearby buildings even as tourism numbers fell, Suntec City Mall suffered a 26.2 per cent fall in headline retail rent reversion.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on profit-taking in heavyweight firms
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Wednesday, marking their steepest fall in a week, as investors took profits ahead of an expected policy change on short-selling ban in May. The benchmark Kospi fell 1.06% to 3,181.47, with heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix experiencing declines. Foreigners net sold 608.1 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won weakened, with a 0.23% drop against the dollar.

site_title: India's Covid-19 death toll passes 200,000: official data
summary: India's coronavirus death toll surpassed 200,000 on April 28, 2021, with 3,000 new fatalities reported in 24 hours. The total number of deaths stands at 201,187, although experts suspect the true toll is higher. India has also reported 18 million infections, with a significant increase of 360,000 in the past 24 hours, and 6 million new cases this month alone.

site_title: Wage growth likely to be 'relatively muted', a tad higher than last year's 1.4%: MAS
summary: Singapore's wage growth is expected to be "relatively muted" this year, with resident wage growth anticipated to rise only slightly from last year's 1.4%, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. This is due to lingering economic uncertainties and weakened corporate balance sheets. The expected wage growth reflects a lagged response to improving labour conditions.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices hit 20-month high
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a 20-month high in March, rising 0.8% due to robust demand and a recovering economy. The prices are 2.2% lower than the historical high in May 2019. The market, known for its serious supply shortage, remains resilient despite the pandemic and anti-government protests. Transaction volumes are expected to be the highest in eight years, with property values at a 23-year high.

site_title: SoftBank to retire treasury shares after group's largest-ever buyback
summary: SoftBank Group will retire 16.3% of its treasury shares, leaving 0.6% of total shares issued, after its largest-ever buyback. The move is seen as in line with industry practice and not a signal for future buybacks. SoftBank has spent over 2.2 trillion yen on buybacks since March last year, largely completing its program. The cancellation boosts the ownership of founder Masayoshi Son, who holds a 25% stake. SoftBank's shares are trading 7% down from two-decade highs.

site_title: Micro-businesses need support even as South-east Asia readies for recovery: report
summary: A report by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) highlights the need for support to micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in South-east Asia as the region prepares for recovery. MSMEs, which account for a large share of private businesses, face varying trajectories shaped by domestic outbreaks, vaccine roll-outs, and global recovery. The ADB anticipates a regional rebound driven by a "healthy global recovery" and vaccination progress, but warns that economies are on diverging paths. The report emphasizes the importance of targeted support for MSMEs to ensure a sustainable recovery.

site_title: Data is changing the way offices are run
summary: Data analytics is revolutionizing the way offices are run, with developers harnessing the power of data collection and artificial intelligence to improve operations and cut costs. Proptech startups are receiving significant investments, and investors are pouring money into companies like Cherre and HqO. However, concerns over cybersecurity and data protection are arising, with hackers increasingly using Internet-connected sensors to gain access to networks. Despite these concerns, the industry believes the post-pandemic re-evaluation of corporate real estate plans will lead to a significant increase in data-driven decision-making, transforming the way offices are built and managed.

site_title: Ad group WPP returns to growth as clients spend for the recovery
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, reported a 3.1% jump in underlying net sales in the first quarter, exceeding expectations. The company attributed the growth to clients' spending to prepare for a global economic recovery, with key figures in Asia Pacific and Britain driving growth. WPP's chief executive Mark Read said the recovery is coming, and the company is launching new products and brands to capitalize on the trend. The company reiterated its financial outlook for the year and won $1.3 billion of new work from clients such as Absolut and JPMorgan Chase.

site_title: Journalists create their brands in growing direct sales model
summary: Journalists are increasingly creating their own brands and charging subscription fees for newsletters, bypassing traditional outlets. Independent writers, such as Anna Codrea-Rado, are using platforms like Substack to monetize their content, with some earning significant revenue. The trend is driven by the media sector's economic woes and consumers' willingness to pay for micro-subscriptions. Popular newsletters generate millions of dollars in revenue, with some journalists earning over $80,000 per month. The model allows for independent, non-corporate media outlets to challenge power, but also presents challenges, such as building a meaningful relationship with a larger audience.

site_title: Malaysia's March exports surge 31% y-o-y, fastest in nearly four years
summary: Malaysia's exports surged 31% in March, the fastest pace in nearly four years, surpassing analysts' expectations of 22.9% growth. The country's trade surplus widened to RM24.2 billion, driven by a 19.2% rise in imports. This marks the highest export growth since May 2017. The strong export performance is seen as a sign that Malaysia is recovering from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse operator's first quarter profits rise 70%
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) reported a 70% rise in first-quarter profits to HK$3.84 billion, driven by high trading volumes. This represents a significant increase from HK$2.26 billion in the same period last year. The bourse operator's strong performance is attributed to robust market activity.

site_title: Toyota sales reach record on recovering demand for automobiles
summary: Toyota's global sales in March reached a record 982,912 units, a 44% increase from the previous year, driven by a resurgence in demand for cars. The company's ability to maintain production amid a global semiconductor shortage has positioned it to capitalize on the recovery. Sales were particularly strong in China and North America, with Toyota's global production rising 32% to 843,393 units. This success contrasts with other automakers struggling to meet demand due to the chip shortage, which has impacted global car output by 1.3 million units.

site_title: Australia: Mild inflation data helps shares snap two-day loss
summary: Australia's shares snapped a two-day losing streak, closing 0.44% higher on mild quarterly inflation data. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 7,064.7 points, with financials and energy stocks leading gains. Lower-than-expected inflation (0.6%) eased investor concerns about a sooner interest rate hike, keeping the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) dovish. This led to a rise in the "Big Four" banks, with National Australia Bank and Commonwealth Bank of Australia gaining 1.6% and 1.4% respectively.

site_title: Taiwan says China waging economic warfare against tech sector
summary: Taiwan's government accused China of waging economic warfare against its tech sector by stealing technology and enticing away engineers. The allegations come as parliament considers strengthening legislation to prevent industrial espionage. China's efforts to copy Taiwan's semiconductor industry are seen as a major threat to democracies, with the aim of making Taiwan poorer and weaker. The proposed amendments aim to widen the scope of commercial secrets and toughen penalties, but it's unclear when or if the changes will be passed into law.

site_title: LG Display posts strong Q1 profit on panel price boost
summary: LG Display reported its third consecutive quarterly profit, driven by rising panel prices due to strong demand for TVs and laptops during the pandemic. The company's operating profit increased to 523 billion won (S$623.1 million) in Q1, compared to a loss of 362 billion won in the same period last year. However, a semiconductor shortage is expected to impact production for the months ahead.

site_title: DBS, JPMorgan and Temasek set up open platform to tackle pains behind interbank payments
summary: DBS, JPMorgan, and Temasek have launched a new open industry platform called Partior to tackle the issues behind interbank payments. The platform, utilizing blockchain technology, aims to facilitate 24/7 infrastructure for financial institutions and developers to co-create applications for foreign exchange payments and settlement. The platform's launch is subject to regulatory approvals and pilot trials are expected to begin in the second half of 2021. The goal is to disrupt the traditional "hub and spoke" model, reducing costly and inefficient post-transaction exception handling and reconciliation activities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% at the start of trade on Wednesday, driven by cautious investors watching rising US Treasury yields and potential interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index increased 50.40 points to 28,991.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.30% to 3,432.16.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine up as much as 7.5% on active trading
summary: SembCorp Marine's shares surged 7.5% on active trading, reaching an intraday high of 21.5 Singapore cents. The company's shares were the most traded by volume with over 132.3 million shares changing hands. This follows its recent partnership with Penguin International and Shell to trial hydrogen fuel cells for ships in Singapore.

site_title: Sunseap expanding in Japan with new investors in latest Series E funding round
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore-based solar-energy system developer, has secured investments from three Japanese corporations - Sumitomo Corporation, Shikoku Electric Power Company, and Sumitomo Mitsui Finance and Leasing Company - in its Series E funding round. The investment will be used to expand Sunseap's business in Japan, aligning with the country's goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050. This marks the first time Japanese corporations are investing in Sunseap, allowing the company to introduce clean technology and business solutions to the Japanese market.

site_title: Europe companies' Q1 profits expectations surge as earnings season gets underway
summary: Europe's Q1 profits are expected to surge 71.3% from a year earlier, according to Refinitiv IBES data, marking the best quarter for European stocks since 2012. Revenues are forecast to rise 2.5%, exceeding analyst estimates in 64.8% of reported companies. This represents a jump from last week's forecast of a 61.2% increase. The strong earnings season comes as Europe's economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Global recovery on track from Q2; Singapore could exceed 6% GDP growth in 2021: MAS
summary: Singapore's economy is on track for 6.2% growth in 2021, exceeding the 6% target, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Macroeconomic Review. The global economy is expected to regain its 2019 level of output by Q2 and expand 6.2% for the year. Despite a slowdown in Q1 2021 due to COVID-19 restrictions, the recovery is expected to pick up pace from Q2, with several economies projected to contract.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Sheng Siong to 'hold', sees few catalysts after Q1
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded Sheng Siong Group to "hold" from "add" due to limited earnings catalysts, citing delays in HDB construction projects and a potential slowdown in store openings. The brokerage lowered its forecast for store acreage addition and earnings per share, expecting a 9.3% revenue decline in FY2021. Analysts at DBS Group Research also maintained a "buy" recommendation, citing a positive outlook for new HDB shop supply and a potential recovery in revenue and earnings.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB has downgraded Sheng Siong Group to "hold" from "add" while lowering its target price to S$1.60 from S$1.88 previously, on the belief that limited earnings catalysts are in sight for the supermarket operator.

site_title: Total employment grows for first time in Q1 since start of pandemic: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment grew in Q1 2021 for the first time since the pandemic, with a 0.1 percentage point drop in unemployment rates to 2.9%. The growth was driven by services, particularly information & communications, financial services, and professional services. Unemployment rates for residents, citizens, and non-residents also decreased, with the number of unemployed residents falling from 104,300 in December 2020 to 95,500 in March 2021.

site_title: Gold falls as US Treasury yields firm; all eyes on Fed rate decision
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,767.76 per ounce as US Treasury yields rose, making gold less appealing for investors. The Federal Reserve's meeting is expected to provide policy cues, affecting gold prices. Palladium also declined 0.6% after hitting a record peak. Analysts have slashed gold price forecasts due to economic recovery, which tarnishes the metal's appeal as a safe-haven.

site_title: Hot stock: Nanofilm falls 3.8% on possible project delays due to chip shortage
summary: Nanofilm Technologies shares fell 3.8% on Wednesday due to possible delays in selected 3C projects due to the global chip shortage. The company stated it is preparing for the possibility of deferring projects from its initial production schedules. Despite this, Nanofilm believes the supply chain will recover and be ready for new product launches in the coming months. The company's shares ended the day down 4.3% at S$5.08.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as Federal Reserve meeting looms, Biden prepares to speak
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting and Joe Biden's speech to Congress. Despite a positive lead from US earnings, investors remain cautious due to concerns over global economic recovery, particularly in India and Brazil. The rally may have run out of steam, and traders are focusing on the Fed's meeting and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH starts coverage on mm2 Asia with 'buy', 9.8 S cents target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has initiated coverage on mm2 Asia with a 'buy' call, citing the company as a "good proxy for the recovery" in the entertainment industry. mm2 Asia's core production business has a significant pipeline of content, and its lower risk in film production makes it an attractive investment opportunity. The research house sets a target price of 9.8 Singapore cents, indicating a potential upside for the company as the industry recovers.

site_title: Reimagining the technological pathways to APAC's sustainable future
summary: The Asia-Pacific region is facing a slow pace of progress in achieving sustainable development goals, particularly in addressing climate change and responsible consumption. To overcome this, a combination of technology and policy solutions is needed. Governments and businesses should prioritize existing technologies and data creatively to deliver better outcomes for business and the world. Leveraging current technology, such as big data and analytics, IoT, and artificial intelligence, can transform sectors rapidly and at scale, driving sustainable outcomes. Additionally, a human-centered approach to sustainability, including workforce adaptability and reskilling, is essential to harnessing the potential of existing technologies and driving innovation for impact.

site_title: Australian dollar unsettled by soft inflation, finds strength in commodities
summary: The Australian dollar experienced a 0.3% decline to US$0.7740 following soft inflation data, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to maintain record-low interest rates until 2024. The country's consumer prices rose 0.6% in the first quarter, below the RBA's target range of 2-3%. Commodity prices, however, have surged, with copper up 27% this year and iron ore reaching a record high. The decline in inflation has reduced the need for borrowing, potentially cutting the government's 2020/21 budget deficit by A$50 billion.

site_title: As Saudi prince rises, Bin Laden business empire declines
summary: Saudi Arabia's construction empire, Bin Laden Group, founded by Osama bin Laden's father, has declined significantly under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's rise to power. The government took management control of the company after its leaders were caught in an anti-corruption purge. The Bin Laden family, who were once close to the Saudi royal family, are now facing crushing debt and asset seizures. The company's fortunes began to decline after King Salman inherited the throne in 2015, and the 2017 crackdown is seen as a "shock therapy" to jolt the elite out of corrupt habits.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 3.74 points lower, 0.23% down, to 1,602.94, on Wednesday. The market saw 283.78 million lots traded worth RM110.24 million. Gainers outpaced losers 231-125.

site_title: Japan's retail sales rise at fastest pace in five months
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 5.2% in March, the fastest pace in five months, driven by consumer demand recovery from the pandemic. This marks the first positive growth in four months, with sales increasing on fashion items and general merchandise. However, analysts remain concerned about a hit to spending on services, such as restaurants and leisure activities, due to the ongoing pandemic. The country's economy has emerged from last year's slump on an export recovery, but a glacial vaccine rollout and resurgence in infections threaten households' spending appetite.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,206.46. The market was influenced by a flat performance on Wall Street overnight and global economic concerns. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also fell, while Mapletree Commercial Trust was the top gainer. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Australian inflation surprisingly weak in Q1
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 0.6% in the March quarter, below market forecasts of 0.9% and the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. Core inflation was also tame, with a trimmed mean inflation rate of 0.3% and an annual pace of 1.1%. The low inflation reading suggests monetary policy will remain loose for a long time, potentially limiting interest rate hikes. This outcome contrasts with previous expectations, highlighting a softer economic outlook in Australia.

site_title: Australia: Energy stocks push shares higher, New Zealand rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.11% to 7,041.5 points, driven by gains in energy stocks, led by Viva Energy Group's 3.8% rise, and financial stocks, including QBE Insurance Group's 2.28% gain. Technology stocks fell 0.6%, while miners and gold stocks declined 1.23% and 2.28%, respectively. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.31% to 12,659.6 points.

site_title: US Federal Reserve set to reaffirm recovery mission, face down inflation fears
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to reaffirm its commitment to sustaining stimulus until the US economy recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.
