The metal's role in the green-energy transition and aggressive climate targets from countries worldwide also fueled the rally. Goldman Sachs and Trafigura Group expect prices to surpass the 2011 record of $10,190. Disruptions to Chile's exports, which account for a quarter of the world's supply, may further impact the market.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stock market sees tracking fund flows. NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue shortfall. Meanwhile, US stocks fell amid tariff threats. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green finance. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Honouring homegrown companies with strong branding messages
summary: The Singapore Prestige Brand Award (SPBA) 2020/21 will launch officially on April 28, honoring homegrown companies with strong branding messages and strategies. The award, now in its 20th year, features four categories: Promising Brands, Established Brands, Heritage Brands, and Special Merit. Winners will be announced at a later date and can be watched via Zoom. The award is jointly organized by the Association of Small & Medium Enterprises (ASME) and Lianhe Zaobao.

site_title: Oil falls on India's Covid-19 surge; Opec+ limits drop
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies considered the impact of surging Covid-19 cases in India, which may reduce fuel demand. Despite this, the group indicated it was watching the situation and may discuss output policy at a meeting this week. Brent crude settled 46 cents lower at $65.65 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude ended down 23 cents at $61.91 a barrel. Oil demand in India is expected to drop by 100,000-170,000 barrels per day in April and May due to the surge.

images.alt_text: Oil pared its losses on Monday as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies indicated that it was watching surging Covid-19 cases in India, which may dent fuel demand in the world's third-biggest oil importer.

site_title: Biden to propose tax hike on richest to pay for investments: White House
summary: President Joe Biden plans to propose a tax hike on the richest individuals to fund his $1.8 trillion American Families Plan, which includes national child care, paid family leave, and free community college. The tax would increase the capital gains tax rate to 39.6% for those earning over $1 million annually, affecting 0.3% of taxpayers. The plan aims to offset the cost by making tax reforms that reward work over wealth, and revenue from the tax would fund investments in families and economic competitiveness.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden will propose a tax hike on the investment gains of the wealthiest individuals to pay for his new plan to help US families, a top White House economist said on Monday.

site_title: Top Glove resolves all 11 International Labour Organization indicators of forced labour
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove manufacturer, has resolved all 11 International Labour Organization indicators of forced labour, verified by independent consultant Impactt Limited. The company, which employs 21,000 workers, had been engaging with Impactt since July 2020 to improve labour policies and practices. The resolution comes after a ban on Top Glove's gloves in the US in 2020 due to allegations of poor labour practices and forced labour. The company will continue to improve worker welfare, despite the positive outcome.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher as miners scale 10-year peaks
summary: European stocks ended higher on Monday, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.3% after its first weekly loss in eight weeks. Basic resources stocks, supported by 10-year highs in Shanghai copper prices, rose 1.9% to a record closing high. Bank stocks also rose 2%, driven by rising euro zone bond yields. Travel and leisure stocks rose 1.8% after a top EU official stated Americans who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 can travel to Europe by summer.

site_title: STB takes over running of Chinatown Heritage Centre
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has taken over the management of the Chinatown Heritage Centre from a local consortium, citing the impact of COVID-19 and international travel restrictions. The centre, which was renovated in 2015, will remain closed until further notice instead of reopening as previously planned. STB will review the centre's operating model and announce future plans in due course. The centre, opened in 2002, was operated by a consortium of local companies Singapore River Cruise, Journeys, and Splash Entertainment.

site_title: Kanye West sneakers shatter sale records at US$1.8m
summary: A pair of Nike Air Yeezy 1s worn by rapper Kanye West sold for US$1.8 million, breaking the record for the highest price paid for sneakers. The shoes, worn during the 2008 Grammy Awards, were prototypes that didn't go on sale until 2009. The sale marks the first time sneakers have topped US$1 million and highlights the growing interest in rare sports shoes. The sale price exceeded Sotheby's estimate of US$1 million, and the shoes will be listed on a sneaker investment marketplace.

images.alt_text: A pair of Nike Air Yeezy 1s worn by rapper Kanye West sold for US$1.8 million, triple the previous record for sneakers, Sotheby's said on Monday, as the market for rare sports shoes soars.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Darco Water Technologies has been served with a High Court summons by a group of 10 shareholders, who are seeking to commence a statutory derivative action against non-executive deputy chairman Wang Zhi and Pek Thiam Keong for alleged breaches of director's duties and/or fiduciary duties. China Sky Chemical Fibre has missed a final deadline to submit its proposal for trading resumption, leading to its delisting from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST). A voluntary conditional offer for CEI Limited has turned unconditional and is now closed, with AEM Holdings proceeding to exercise its right of compulsory acquisition of all remaining shares.

site_title: Oscars audience halved in massive ratings drop
summary: The 2021 Oscars saw a record-low audience of 9.85 million viewers, a 58% drop from last year's 23.6 million, amid a pandemic-affected year for movie releases. Despite this, the ceremony still managed to award several notable winners, including Anthony Hopkins for Best Actor and Chloe Zhao for Best Picture. The show's lack of humor and musical performances was criticized by some, while others praised the more personal and fast-paced ceremony. This marks a continued downward trend for the Academy Awards, which have seen a decline in viewership in recent years.

images.alt_text: This year's Oscars audience plummeted by more than half to a record low 9.85 million viewers, broadcaster ABC said on Monday - a staggering if widely expected drop for a ceremony that many viewers found short on humour and star power.

site_title: ARA Logos to divest Kidman Park in Australia for A$41.5m
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has agreed to sell its Kidman Park property in Australia for A$41.5 million, nearly 3.8% above its A$40 million valuation. The sale, expected to be completed by H1 2021, will net ARA Logos approximately A$40.5 million, with an estimated gain of A$400,000. The proceeds will be used to fund new acquisitions, repay debt, and work capital. This is ARA Logos' second proposed divestment in less than a week, following a sale of ALOG Changi DistriCentre 2 for S$16.7 million.

site_title: Lyft to sell autonomous driving unit for US$550m to Toyota
summary: Lyft has agreed to sell its autonomous driving unit, Level 5, to Toyota for $550 million. The move follows a similar divestment by Uber last year as the companies focus on core operations amid pandemic struggles. The acquisition will create a team of 1,200 working on self-driving technology in Japan, US, and Britain. Lyft will receive $550 million in cash, with $200 million upfront and $350 million over five years. The deal aims to advance mobility technologies and transform the world through clean, autonomous mobility.

images.alt_text: US ride hailing service Lyft agreed to sell its autonomous driving division to a unit of Japan's Toyota for US$550 million, the companies said on Monday.

site_title: When it comes to a travel restart, not all vaccines are equal
summary: A global travel restart is underway, but it may be hindered by a patchwork of vaccine approvals across countries and regions. The European Union plans to allow Americans vaccinated with shots approved by their drug agency, excluding Chinese-made vaccines like Sinovac and Sinopharm. This creates a dilemma for individuals who need to travel to China or work with Chinese companies, and may limit travel for fully inoculated people with varying efficacy rates. Governments are discussing vaccine passports, but it's unclear if countries will pursue universal recognition or be selective on which shots they choose to recognize.

site_title: Westlite Woodlands dorm resident staying in different block from earlier cases among 2 local Covid-19 cases
summary: A 35-year-old Bangladeshi construction worker at Westlite Woodlands dormitory tested positive for Covid-19 on April 23, despite being asymptomatic. He had tested negative during his stay-home notice and routine testing. Another test on April 25 was negative, but serology test results showed a positive result. The worker is likely to have been infected while overseas. The sole community case is a 19-year-old Singaporean who studied in the UK and may have been infected with a past infection.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records as tech shares gain
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Monday as the Nasdaq and S&P 500 indices gained 0.9% and 0.2% respectively, led by tech shares. Despite a White House announcement on increasing capital gains taxes, investors remained unconcerned. The Dow Jones shed 0.2%. A disappointing increase in big-ticket manufactured goods orders and a busy week of economic news ahead characterized the session. Tesla reported a big jump in profits, but ended with a 1.2% loss in after-hours trading. The Federal Reserve begins its policy meeting on Tuesday, but is not expected to change its easy-money policies.

site_title: Reinvented Oscars hands Nomadland big win on diversity-packed night
summary: The 2021 Academy Awards, held on a diversity-packed night, saw "Nomadland" win Best Picture and two other awards, including Best Director for China-born Chloe Zhao, the first Asian woman and second woman to take home the Best Director trophy. Anthony Hopkins won Best Actor for "The Father," while Frances McDormand won her third Oscar for her role in "Nomadland." The ceremony featured a record-breaking 14 female winners, including Youn Yuh-jung for Best Supporting Actress and Kathryn Bigelow for Best Director in 2010.

site_title: European, UK lenders to show if they can match US peers
summary: European and UK lenders will report first-quarter earnings this week, with a focus on their deal-making and trading performance. UBS, Deutsche Bank, BNP Paribas, HSBC, and Barclays will be in the spotlight, with investors looking for signs of market share gains and revenue growth. European banks may release reserves for bad loans, potentially bolstering profits, while US banks have already started to do so. Analysts expect revenue from trading and advising on deals to be lower this year, but some banks, like Deutsche Bank, are expected to continue to profit.

site_title: Canadians avoiding hotel quarantines for air travellers fuel taxi boom on US border
summary: Canada's restrictions on international travel, which require air travellers to spend up to three days in a hotel quarantine, have led to a surge in taxi business from Canadians crossing the US border to avoid the hotel stay. Taxi companies in states like New York are seeing a boom in business, with drivers receiving calls from 6am to 12am, and some companies are now doing more business driving Canadians to their homes in Ontario than with US clients.

images.alt_text: Nick Boccio, general manager and chauffeur with Buffalo Limousine, arrives to pick up a Canadian client to drive them home in the midst of Covid-19 travel restrictions, at Buffalo Niagara International Airport in Cheektowaga, New York, recently.

site_title: Leisure travellers splurge on business-class seats
summary: Leisure travelers are splurging on business-class seats as they try to minimize the risk of catching Covid-19 in economy class. With a record number of air miles and cash, they're seeking a safer and more comfortable experience. Airlines are benefiting from this trend, which could lead to a permanent shift in the business travel market. Fares for business-class tickets are already lower than pre-Covid levels, and premium-economy cabins may play a key role in the aviation recovery.

images.alt_text: The popularity of lucrative business-class seats - especially among passengers who were usually shoehorned into economy - is an unexpected boon for airlines weathering a crisis that is forecast to have cost them a staggering US$174 billion in losses by the end of 2021.

site_title: Singapore-HK bubble has limited impact, but is worth pursuing: analysts
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong plan to launch an "air travel bubble" on May 26, allowing eligible travelers to bypass quarantine and stay-home notices upon arrival. The initial daily flights will be capped at 200 passengers, and analysts expect limited economic impact, with most bookings being from the VFR (visiting friends and relatives) segment. The bubble is seen as a symbolic step towards normalcy and may pave the way for additional travel bubbles with key partners and destinations. Long-term, analysts expect Covid-19 border controls to be eliminated as vaccination progress accelerates.

site_title: For China's property developers, Hong Kong is becoming Shenzhen's backyard
summary: Chinese property developers are shifting their focus from Hong Kong to its border districts, particularly Shenzhen, as mainlanders from the neighboring city seek more affordable long-term housing options. Shenzhen's stature has grown significantly, with hundreds of thousands moving there each year, and its prime districts now offer higher house prices than northern Hong Kong. This trend is seen as a turning point, with Hong Kong's international economic prestige under pressure due to pro-democracy protests and national security laws.

site_title: Biotech innovations remain at forefront as pandemic continues
summary: The biotechnology industry faced challenges in the first quarter of 2021, with a sell-off in March and investors rotating out of biotech into cyclicals and financials. Despite this, the sector remains resilient, with operations recovering as vaccinations enable a gradual reopening. The industry is expected to recover in the latter half of the year, driven by clinical development and commercial sales. The sector's long-term view is positive, with advancements in gene therapy, immuno-oncology, and precision oncology, and opportunities to address rare diseases and unmet medical needs.

site_title: Cambodian-Chinese pair pays S$33.5 million for Hilltops penthouse
summary: A Cambodian-Chinese pair has purchased a S$33.5 million penthouse at SC Global Developments' Hilltops condo in Singapore for S$3,995 per square foot. This is the third penthouse sold in the completed freehold development, following a S$26 million unit sold last year and a S$25.08 million unit in 2019. Strong buying demand for luxury homes extends to the leasing market, with UHNWIs seeking refuge from the pandemic, driving up rents by 10-15% in the past few months.

images.alt_text: The 8,385 sq ft duplex unit transacted last month is the third penthouse to be sold at Hilltops. This leaves the super penthouse of 12,669 sq ft with five bedrooms and a dedicated lift, still available.

site_title: Two Swiss firms set up protein innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Swiss multinationals Givaudan and Buhler have set up a protein innovation centre in Singapore, a 400 square-metre facility that can produce up to 40kg of plant proteins per hour. The centre aims to develop plant-based protein alternatives with authentic flavours, meeting consumer needs and expectations. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan hailed the collaboration as a "boost to the alternative protein industry", citing Singapore's efforts to bolster food security through technology and meat alternatives. The centre will support start-ups and food businesses through co-creation and access to expertise and technology.

site_title: As en-bloc market heats up, agency space gets more crowded
summary: Singapore's collective-sale market is experiencing intense competition among marketing agencies, with newcomers undercutting rivals on commission rates and proposing high reserve prices to secure jobs. This trend is driven by renewed buying and selling interest, with fresh faces joining the crowded arena. Incumbents and newcomers are vying for a piece of the action, threatening to compress commissions. As a result, agents are being offered "unrealistically" high reserve prices to secure deals, further intensifying the competition in the market.

images.alt_text: Commissions today can go up to 1 per cent for small sites, BT understands. Larger projects priced at S$500 million or more garner commissions of 0.3-0.5 per cent, which may be further shaved down if more agents are jostling for the appointment.

site_title: Euro holds at 8-week high against the US dollar
summary: The euro held at an 8-week high against the US dollar on Monday, despite a disappointing German business morale survey, due to expectations of a dovish stance from the US Federal Reserve. The euro stood at $1.2095, while the dollar index fell to 90.80, its lowest level since March 3. Analysts believe the euro zone economy is on its way out of the Covid-19 crisis, with the German government raising its growth forecast to 3.5% for this year.

site_title: GlobalTix gets S$3m in fresh funds from Tin Men Capital, SEEDS Capital
summary: GlobalTix, a Singapore-based tour and attractions ticketing platform, has received S$3 million in fresh funds from Tin Men Capital and SEEDS Capital. The investment will support the development of technological capabilities, such as contactless entry and capacity management, and deepen the firm's regional footprint. This marks the firm's second major funding round, following a S$12.5 million Series A round in 2018. GlobalTix has offices in Hong Kong, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines and is one of five booking platforms engaged by the Singapore Tourism Board to boost domestic tourism.

site_title: World military spending grows in 2020 despite pandemic
summary: Global military spending reached nearly US$2 trillion in 2020, increasing by 2.6% despite the Covid-19 pandemic's economic impact, according to a report from the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. The US$1,981 billion in spending represents a 4.4% decline in global gross domestic product. This defies expectations that military spending would decrease during the pandemic.

site_title: iFast unit enters business transfer agreement for transfer of Singapore mutual funds platform for S$3 million
summary: iFast Corporation has entered into a business transfer agreement with DWS Investments Singapore for the transfer of its Singapore mutual funds platform for S$3 million. The deal involves the transfer of seven authorised retail funds with assets under management of S$600 million. The transaction is expected to be completed on July 30, with no change to the funds' investment objectives or approaches. The move aims to improve operational efficiencies and lower costs for investors, with iFast to finance the deal through internal resources.

site_title: With red-carpet treatment, Singapore hotels may just nip through this crisis
summary: Singapore hotels are poised for recovery as the post-pandemic traveler seeks luxury, space, and high hygiene standards. With the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble expected to start on May 26, hotels are likely to outperform, especially serviced residences and luxury hotels. The city-state's handling of the pandemic and upcoming events, such as the World Economic Forum Special Annual Meeting 2021, will reassure leisure travelers. However, hotel occupancy and room rates may not return to pre-pandemic levels due to capacity limits and increased costs, with travelers opting for longer stays and more expensive accommodations.

site_title: Using AI to transform waste management solutions for the future
summary: A Singapore-based company, V8 Environmental, has implemented AI-powered smart robots to sort through waste for recyclables at a rate 12 times faster than human workers. The facility, which processes 350 tonnes of waste daily, has seen a 2-fold increase in recycling rates to 84%. The company, which has also adopted AI in waste management solutions, has retained all its staff despite automation, with the general manager crediting the company's founder for being willing to take on manual tasks and lead by example. The company's success is also attributed to support from Enterprise Singapore, which helped with digital transformation.

site_title: Price surge stokes en bloc hopes, but expectations gap a hurdle
summary: A price surge in Singapore's collective sales has sparked hopes for en-bloc deals, but a gap in expectations between buyers and sellers remains. Marketing consultants advise sellers to lower their price expectations due to rising resale condo prices and increased stamp duties. Developers are cautious due to thin profit margins and concerns about potential cooling measures. Experts suggest striking a balance between encouraging participation from unit owners and developers, with smaller sites potentially having a better chance of success. A pricing gap persists, hindering en-bloc deals.

site_title: CICT's Q1 net property income surges 66% post merger
summary: CICT, a Singaporean Reit, posted a 66% surge in net property income (NPI) for Q1 2021 to S$247.1 million, driven by its merger with CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) in October 2020. The Reit's gross revenue rose to S$334.8 million, with retail occupancy at 97.1% and office occupancy at 94.9%. CICT's portfolio weighted average lease expiry stood at 3.1 years, with a 5.3% increase in total new and renewal leases.

site_title: US-China relations: Still looking for the adults in the room
summary: The US-China relationship remains a pressing concern under President Joe Biden's administration. Despite a return to experienced foreign policy experts, the new administration's rhetoric on China sounds similar to that of former President Donald Trump. Biden's administration continues to pursue aggressive China policies, including unresolved trade disputes and a militarized approach. The administration's framing of China as a global hegemonic power is seen as overly simplistic and dismissive of China's Belt and Road Initiative as an economic policy rather than an anti-American strategy. The administration's handling of the Uighur crisis and climate change also raises concerns about strategic incoherence.

site_title: Can Ron DeSantis save the GOP?
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis is seen as a potential savior for the Republican Party, who could regain control of the House and Senate in 2022 and possibly even the presidency in 2024. The average loss for the party in possession of the White House in the first mid-term election is about 28 seats, which could benefit the Republicans. DeSantis has gained popularity for his handling of the pandemic, and his centrist positions on issues like the environment could appeal to voters. He also enjoys strong ties with former President Trump and could capitalize on the current divisions within the party to win the 2024 presidential election.

site_title: UN summit catalyses progress on global climate agenda
summary: The US-hosted climate summit, attended by President Joe Biden and 40 world leaders, marked a significant step forward in global climate diplomacy, with the US announcing plans to cut greenhouse emissions by at least 50% below 2005 levels by 2030. This move has sparked other large emitters to raise their climate ambitions, including Japan and Canada. The summit also saw China and the US collaborate on climate issues for the first time in partnership, with a focus on reducing emissions and financing low-carbon energy. The event has catalyzed progress on the global climate agenda, with key events leading up to the November UK-hosted COP26 conference.

site_title: Price surge stokes en bloc hopes, but expectations gap a hurdle
summary: Singapore property owners are optimistic about en bloc sales amid strong transaction volumes and prices, but developers are concerned about thinning margins and potential cooling measures. Consultants predict a mismatch in price expectations, which may lead to slow deals or failures. Despite this, interest from developers has grown, with over 15 seeking information on potential en-bloc launches, and more than 40 projects preparing to go on the market. Experts advise setting a reserve price that balances participation from unit owners and interest from developers, as the market faces uncertainty and risks of policy changes.

site_title: Tears, howls and blackouts at the train station
summary: The Oscars ceremony took place on Sunday, crowning Nomadland as Best Picture and experimenting with its traditional format to highlight diversity and honor established stars.

site_title: ISDN Q1 net profit soars 95.4% to S$6.1m
summary: ISDN Holdings reported a 95.4% increase in Q1 net profit to S$6.1 million, driven by a 23.4% rise in revenue to S$98.4 million. The company attributes its growth to market demand for industrial automation in Asia, post-Covid shifts in the region's industrial economy, and geopolitical tensions. ISDN expects to benefit from these trends, with plans to grow its technology capabilities, improve productivity, and advance its emerging business portfolio.

site_title: Thailand starts stricter Covid-19 shutdown, but experts say not enough
summary: Thailand has introduced stricter COVID-19 measures, including shutting parks, gyms, and day-care centers in Bangkok, and fining those who don't wear masks in public. However, experts say these measures are not enough to contain the spread of the virus, with over 57,500 infections and 148 deaths reported in just under 30 days. The government is under pressure to take more decisive measures, with an online petition calling for the resignation of the health minister gathering over 160,000 signatures. Thailand plans to procure more vaccines and consider additional restrictions later this week.

site_title: Thailand starts stricter Covid-19 shutdown
summary: Thailand has implemented stricter COVID-19 shutdown measures, including closing parks, gyms, cinemas, and day-care centers in Bangkok from April 26 to May 9, amid concerns of imported cases. The government also restricted travel from India. These restrictions come as the country faces a spike in infections, sparking criticism for not doing enough to contain the spread.

site_title: Mubadala eyes US$1b gas deal as UAE-Israel ties deepen
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment plans to buy a stake in Israel's Tamar offshore gas field for up to US$1.1 billion, the largest commercial agreement since the UAE and Israel normalized ties last year. The deal, signed with Delek Drilling, is part of Mubadala's due diligence. If finalized, it would be a significant milestone in strengthening economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: EU sues AstraZeneca over vaccine delivery shortfall
summary: The European Union has launched a lawsuit against AstraZeneca over coronavirus vaccine delivery shortfalls, alleging breaches of an advanced purchase agreement. The EU claims the company has not delivered the promised doses, with only 31 million doses out of 120 million expected in the first three months of this year. AstraZeneca denies the allegations, stating the contract only binds it to "best reasonable efforts." The lawsuit will begin in a Belgian court, with the EU seeking to ensure timely delivery of doses to European citizens.

site_title: Hollywood stars ditch hoodies, PJs for glamour
summary: Hollywood stars made a glamorous return to the red carpet at the Oscars, ditching casual attire for elaborate gowns and suits. Men such as Leslie Odom Jr., Daniel Kaluuya, and Colman Domingo wore stunning tuxedos, while actresses like Carey Mulligan, Andra Day, and Viola Davis stunned in gold and white gowns. Despite a trend towards neutral colors, some actresses, like Halle Berry and Angela Bassett, opted for bold colors, showcasing the glamour of Hollywood's return to fashion events after the pandemic.

site_title: IP protection, supply chain resilience key to Singapore's appeal: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's government has highlighted the country's IP protection and supply chain resilience as key factors attracting multinational corporations like 3M. The company has invested over S$1 billion and grown its staff to 1,600, producing 2.5 billion N95 respirators this year, tripling global production from the previous year. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing praised Singapore's strong intellectual property protection and open trade policy, saying these factors draw companies to locate in the country.

site_title: Digital RMB is no threat to dominance of US dollar
summary: The US dollar's dominance as the world's currency is unlikely to be threatened by the digital renminbi, according to a recent article. The digital renminbi's global role remains small, with a share of just above 2% in global payments and 4% in global foreign exchange transactions. China's financial system is weak, and the renminbi's convertibility is limited by capital account restrictions. The US should focus on maintaining a healthy economy, promoting openness, and multilateralism to ensure the US dollar's vibrant global role is maintained, rather than trying to protect it from the digital renminbi.

site_title: Darco receives originating summons issued by the High Court
summary: DARCO Water Technologies has been served with an originating summons by the High Court, filed by a group of 10 shareholders. The shareholders, holding 16.1% stakes, allege breaches of director's duties and fiduciary duties by non-executive deputy chairman Wang Zhi and Pek Thiam Keong. They claim the duo breached duties in consultancy payments, water-treatment asset transfers, and a waste-to-energy project. DARCO is seeking legal advice on the summons and derivative action.

site_title: Will Sevak's latest change of name and leadership spice up investors' returns?
summary: Sevak Ltd, a Catalist-listed company majority owned by founder Bhupendra Kumar Modi, is set to vote on a proposed name change to "Digilife Technologies Limited" to reflect its digitalisation strategy. The company has undergone four name changes in the past decade, sparking concerns among investors about the necessity of such frequent changes. Despite a shrinking topline and operating loss, the proposed name change lacks a well-articulated business direction, raising questions about the company's stability and continuity.

site_title: Low uptake of old IP scheme spells valuable lessons for Singapore
summary: Singapore's Intellectual Property Financing Scheme (IPFS) from 2014-2018 disbursed only S$12 million, highlighting the need for an ecosystem to accurately value intangible assets. The government has launched a new IP blueprint, Singapore IP Strategy (SIPS) 2030, to build up the ecosystem for IP and IA services. The blueprint aims to establish guidelines, grow valuation professionals, and introduce initiatives such as a valuation panel and online marketplace. It also seeks to develop nationally recognized IP standards and certification programs, with the goal of making IP financing more accessible to asset-light tech startups and SMEs.

images.alt_text: Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Indranee Rajah unveiled SIPS 2030 on April 26, 2021.

site_title: US core capital goods orders rise less than expected
summary: US core capital goods orders increased 0.9% in March, less than the 1.5% expected, but still indicative of accelerating economic growth due to government aid and improved public health. This follows a 0.8% decline in February due to cold temperatures. The data suggests the economy may have grown in the first quarter, despite initial expectations of a slowdown.

site_title: Credit Suisse investors face more losses in Greensill funds
summary: Credit Suisse investors may face a further US$190 million loss due to a 7% discount on notes from a US$2.8 billion loan book linked to troubled borrowers such as Katerra and GFG Alliance. The bank hired an advisory firm to assess the creditworthiness of the borrowers after Greensill filed for insolvency in March. Credit Suisse has already returned US$4.8 billion to investors, but the valuation on the US$2.3 billion notes linked to Katerra and GFG remains uncertain. The final payout for investors will depend on the validity of insurance coverage for the debts.

site_title: Philippines records more than one million coronavirus cases
summary: The Philippines has exceeded one million coronavirus cases, with 8,929 new infections reported on Monday, bringing the total to over 1 million cases and 16,853 fatalities. The country has the second-highest number of cases and casualties in Southeast Asia, behind Indonesia.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 defends request for Olympic nurses as virus spikes
summary: Tokyo Olympics organisers defended their request for 500 nurses, amid accusations of diverting medical resources. The request was made to address concerns about the spread of COVID-19 at the Games, which are set to take place in July. Organiser Toshiro Muto said discussions are ongoing and that the aim is to "come up with a feasible way of securing" the required nurse resources without compromising local healthcare services. The decision has sparked criticism on social media, with many calling for the Games to be cancelled or postponed.

site_title: Coastal Oil CFO pleads guilty to defrauding 8 banks using forged invoices
summary: Coastal Oil's CFO, Tay Peck Gek, pleaded guilty to defrauding 8 banks, including 7 in Hong Kong, using forged invoices to secure US$320 million in loans. The scheme, which began in 2016, involved fake sales contracts and tax invoices to obtain bank credit. Ong Ah Huat, a CFO, was charged with 58 offences and pleaded guilty to 15, facing a potential 9-year imprisonment. The remaining charges will be taken into consideration for sentencing. The scheme helped keep Coastal Oil afloat until its liquidation in December 2018.

site_title: Wealthy Indians flee by private jet as virus infections spiral
summary: Wealthy Indians are fleeing the country by private jet due to the surge in coronavirus infections, with hospital bed and drug shortages reported. Many are booking flights to destinations in Europe, the Middle East, and the Indian Ocean, including the Maldives. The move is partly driven by overseas nations imposing travel restrictions from India. A one-way private jet flight from New Delhi to Dubai costs around $20,000, while economy-class tickets have increased 10 times in price, with one-way trips costing $1,300. This exodus highlights the desperation of those trying to escape the crisis.

site_title: Givaudan and Bühler launch centre to develop plant-based protein alternatives
summary: Givaudan and Bühler have launched a Protein Innovation Centre in Singapore to develop plant-based protein alternatives. The centre, located in Woodlands, will provide businesses with expertise, networks, and technology to create authentic plant-based protein products. Minister of State Alvin Tan welcomed the collaboration, citing Singapore's focus on technology and meat alternatives for food security. The centre aims to create an eco-system for start-ups and food businesses, with the goal of producing up to 40 kg of plant proteins an hour, and is already in discussion with over five start-ups.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has announced temporary flexibility for construction firms to recruit workers from China, with quicker payouts under a cost-sharing arrangement. This move aims to boost construction projects amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Eligible public sector construction contracts will receive an additional 49-day extension, and construction firms will have more flexibility in hiring Chinese workers.

site_title: Leader Environmental Tech terminates proposed placement, mulls rights issue instead
summary: Leader Environmental Technologies (LET) has terminated its proposed placement of up to 352.9 million new shares at S$0.17 each, citing a substantial discount to the placement price and conditions precedent. Instead, the company is considering a possible rights issue of up to 663.5 million new shares at S$0.10 each, raising S$66.3 million. The proposed rights issue would be based on a one-share-for-two-share ratio, with chairman Lin Yucheng guaranteeing his entitlements. The company plans to announce the details at its annual general meeting on April 30, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Johnson denies saying 'let the bodies pile high'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson denied saying he would rather see thousands of bodies pile high than order a third Covid-19 lockdown, according to a report by The Daily Mail. Johnson faced criticism for his handling of the pandemic, with Labour Party leader Keir Starmer calling for an explanation if the remark was true. Johnson had imposed a third lockdown in January, despite criticism it could have been avoided. The denial comes amid a series of allegations against Johnson, including questions over the financing of his official apartment's renovation.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q3 revenue down 0.6% year-on-year
summary: Starhill Global Reit (SGReit) reported a 0.6% year-on-year dip in revenue to S$46.4 million for its Q3 FY21. Net property income (NPI) rose 0.6% to S$35.4 million, mainly due to lower rental assistance and operating expenses. The Reit's Singapore portfolio contributed 63.2% of total revenue, while its Australia portfolio contributed 24.5%. Occupancy rates remained stable at 97% for its retail portfolio. SGReit's average debt maturity extended to 3.1 years as it refinanced debt and entered into new facilities. The Reit remains cautious on the pandemic's impact, but expects the rollout of vaccines to be positive for global recovery.

site_title: Cheung Woh Technologies posts S$3.09m loss for H2 2021
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies posted a S$3.09 million loss for the half year ended Feb 28, 2021, with revenue shrinking 43.3% to S$13.4 million due to declines in HDD and PMS components segments. The company expects a challenging business environment due to global trade friction and the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a special final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per ordinary share, the company's loss per share was 1.04 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore ranked safest place to be in Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Singapore has taken the top spot in Bloomberg's Covid Resilience Ranking, surpassing New Zealand due to its strict border controls and quarantine program, which brought locally transmitted cases to near zero. The city-state has also administered enough vaccines to cover about 20% of its population, ahead of other virus eliminators like New Zealand, Australia, and Taiwan. Singapore is set to open a two-way travel bubble with Hong Kong on May 26 and has proposed a travel bubble with Taiwan and mutual recognition of vaccination certificates.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open ahead of big tech earnings
summary: Wall Street's three main indexes opened higher on Monday ahead of big tech earnings. The Dow Jones rose 0.74 points to 34,044.23, while the S&P 500 gained 4.86 points to 4,185.03, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 35.57 points to 14,052.38. The gains come as investors await first-quarter results from major tech companies later this week.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's three main indexes opened slightly higher on Monday, ahead of first-quarter results from big technology companies later this week.

site_title: India caps terms for founder-CEOs in blow to richest banker
summary: The Reserve Bank of India has capped the terms for founder-CEOs at 12 years, or 15 years with regulator discretion. This move affects Uday Kotak, CEO of Kotak Mahindra Bank, who has been in the role since 2003. Lenders have until October 1 to comply with the new rules, allowing Kotak to complete his current term. The move is seen as a blow to Kotak, who is the world's wealthiest banker with a net worth of $14.2 billion.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India has restricted how long a bank's founder can stay on as chief executive officer, a move that will come as a blow to the world's wealthiest banker.

site_title: IP protection and supply chain resilience are key to Singapore's attractiveness: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized that Singapore's ability to protect intellectual property and ensure supply chain resilience are key factors in attracting multinational companies. During his visit to 3M Singapore, Chan noted the country's ability to remain open and connected despite the pandemic, allowing for the export of essential products and medical supplies. Singapore's robust intellectual property regime, extensive free trade agreements, and skilled workforce also contribute to its competitiveness.

site_title: SGX-ST to delist China Sky Chemical Fibre Co
summary: Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) will delist China Sky Chemical Fibre Company due to its failure to submit a proposal for trading resumption by the deadline. The company had received an eight-month extension but missed milestones set by its subsidiary, iWave, due to the Covid-19 pandemic and Super Typhoon Rolly. China Sky's shares remain suspended, and the company had previously missed a deadline in August 2016. SGX-ST granted a one-month deadline for China Sky to submit an exit offer proposal.

site_title: MAS exploring links for cheaper, faster cross-border payments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is exploring links for cheaper, faster cross-border payments, with a focus on connecting payment systems in Southeast Asia. A tie-up between Singapore's PayNow and Thailand's PromptPay is set to go live "very soon", allowing users to send money instantly across the two countries. The MAS is also working with the Bank for International Settlements' (BIS) Innovation Hub Centre to improve cross-border payments and is exploring multilateral connections with other countries, including India.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q1 FY21 net profit up 6.5% year on year
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singapore supermarket operator, reported a 6.5% year-on-year increase in its Q1 FY21 net profit to S$30.9 million. Revenue also rose 2.7% to S$337.5 million, primarily driven by growth in new stores opened in FY2020, which contributed entirely to the revenue increase.

site_title: Korean firms bag contracts to design and build Pasir Ris interchange station and Cross Island Line tunnels
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$980 million contract to a joint venture between Daewoo Engineering & Construction and Dongah Geological Engineering to design and build the Pasir Ris interchange station and Cross Island Line tunnels in Singapore. The two Korean firms have established track records in providing design-and-build construction services for rail stations and tunnels locally and abroad. The project is part of Phase 1 of the Cross Island Line, with the interchange station and tunnels to be completed alongside addition and alteration works to the existing Pasir Ris station.

site_title: Construction firms to get flexibility for workers from China, quicker payouts: BCA
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) has announced three measures to support the construction industry in Singapore, amid the tight labor situation and rising costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Starting May 7, a temporary scheme will allow Chinese workers to obtain skills certification in Singapore, while government agencies will grant a 49-day extension of time to eligible construction contracts. Additionally, the public sector will provide quicker payouts for non-manpower-related costs under cost-sharing arrangements.

site_title: Poland fines Portuguese firm for misleading 'patriotic' Polish shoppers
summary: Poland's consumer watchdog fined Portuguese retail group Jeronimo Martins over 60 million zlotys (S$21 million) for labelling imported fruit and vegetables as grown in Poland, misleading "patriotic" shoppers. The regulator found that in 27.8% of inspected stores, products were incorrectly labelled, causing systemic and long-lasting violations. Jeronimo Martins has appealed the decision, citing concerns about the evidence gathered by the regulator. The fine aims to support Poland's economy during the coronavirus crisis by encouraging consumers to buy local products.

site_title: CEI Limited buy-out offer turns unconditional, closes
summary: CEI Limited's voluntary conditional buy-out offer has turned unconditional and closed, with 92.12% of shares accepted by AEM Holdings. The offeror will now exercise its right to compulsory acquisition of remaining shares and delist the company from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver in opening deals
summary: European stock markets opened with a hesitant start, with London's FTSE 100 dipping 0.2% to 6,926.18 points, while Paris's CAC 40 fell 0.2% to 6,248.84. Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.2% to 15,302.37. The decline follows gains in most Asian markets, which rose on Monday following a strong end to last week on Wall Street, ahead of the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy meeting.

site_title: China's plan to restrict hog transport will reshape two trillion yuan pork industry
summary: China is implementing a plan to restrict the transport of live hogs to control the spread of African swine fever, reshaping the 2 trillion yuan pork industry. The country will be divided into five regions, and live pigs will not be allowed across boundaries, affecting regional price differences. The controls are expected to push down pork prices in producing areas and increase costs in demand centers. This may lead to companies opening more pig farms closer to customers, and the cold-chain industry expanding.

site_title: Investors split on dollar outlook, clashing over pace of US recovery
summary: US investors are divided on the dollar's outlook as the world recovers from the pandemic, with some predicting a weakening dollar and others expecting it to strengthen. JPMorgan Asset Management and T. Rowe Price foresee the dollar weakening due to US economic exceptionalism fading, while PineBridge Investments expects it to rise due to US Treasury yields and inflation. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index has slipped 2% this month, and the Federal Reserve's policy assessment could lend weight to bearish views.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.36% on Monday, driven by bargain-hunting as investors focus on corporate results. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 29,126.23, while the Topix index gained 0.17%. The market recovered from early losses amid a virus state of emergency in Japan, with shares in Japan Airlines and Honda rising 4.58% and 1.76%, respectively, after reports of new partnerships. The Tokyo market is expected to remain range-bound as investors digest earnings.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower in muted holiday trade
summary: Australian shares fell 0.21% to 7,045.6 points on Anzac Day holiday, with lower trading volumes. Investors awaited US earnings season cues, which include tech giants Apple and Microsoft. Gold stocks plummeted 2.1%, while technology stocks dropped 0.7%. Miners, however, edged 0.53% higher, driven by Chinese steel futures and iron ore price hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index is now under pressure ahead of the big week of US earnings reports.

site_title: Telecom Italia's Olivetti buys 7.5m shares in Seco IPO
summary: Telecom Italia's Olivetti acquired 7.5 million shares in Seco's initial public offering (IPO), representing 7% of the company's final capital. Seco, a developer of embedded microcomputers and 'internet of things' solutions, is selling up to 37.8 million shares in the offer, set to run until April 30. The IPO is expected to start trading on the Milan Stock Exchange on May 5.

site_title: One community infection, one dorm resident among 45 new Covid-19 cases
summary: Singapore reported 45 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 61,051. The cases included one community infection and one dorm resident, while 43 were imported cases. The number of community cases has increased to 10 in the past week, with three unlinked cases. 60,647 patients have recovered, and 94 are currently hospitalized, with one in critical condition. Globally, the virus has infected over 146 million people and killed 3.1 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 15.04 points to 1,623.47 on Monday, driven by a gain of 577 to 560 gainers to losers. Volume reached 8.129 billion lots worth RM5.590 billion.

site_title: US private equity firm bets on boom in UK science labs
summary: US private equity firm Harrison Street Real Estate Capital is betting on the UK's bio-tech industry by acquiring the country's largest science incubator and combining it with a portfolio of science parks. The venture, valued at £120 million, will manage a 2.6 million square foot portfolio. This deal follows the trend of international investors pouring into the UK's science park market, driven by increased government funding for the sector. Harrison Street has invested heavily in science facilities in the US, and this acquisition aims to replicate that success in the UK.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on recovery hopes; eyes on corporate earnings, Fed
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.99% to a third consecutive gain, driven by optimism about a global economic recovery. The Kospi index ended at 3,217.53, with chip giant Samsung Electronics and battery makers LG Chem and Samsung SDI among the top gainers. Foreign investors purchased $351.92 million worth of shares, and the Bank of Korea is set to release its first quarter GDP data on Tuesday.

site_title: Deals of the week: StashAway buys back stock options, Halodoc secures Astra funding
summary: StashAway, a digital wealth management platform, announced it will buy back up to S$4 million in employee stock options, aiming to attract talent and demonstrate financial success. Meanwhile, Halodoc secured Astra funding. These South-east Asian tech deals made headlines in the past week, highlighting the growing importance of startup funding and innovation in the region.

site_title: Top Glove resolves all 11 International Labour Organization's Force Labour Indicators
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove manufacturer, has resolved all 11 International Labour Organization (ILO) indicators of forced labour, verified by independent consultant Impactt Limited. The resolution addresses issues such as abuse of vulnerability, restriction of movement, and physical and sexual violence. This achievement marks a significant step towards eliminating forced labour in Top Glove's operations. The company's efforts aim to ensure a safe and fair working environment for its employees.

site_title: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi charged with forging bank documents while under probe
summary: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi, 34, was charged with forging bank documents related to his probe into a suspected $1 billion financial fraud. He faces charges of cheating and fraudulent trading, with possible jail terms of up to 10 years and fines. Ng, former managing director of commodities trader Envy Global Trading and director of Envy Asset Management, is currently out on bail of $1.5 million. He also faces charges of swindling $48 million from Envysion Wealth Management and its CEO, and two charges of operating firms for fraudulent purposes.

site_title: India's coronavirus crisis deepens as countries promise aid
summary: India's coronavirus crisis deepens as the country records a record peak of 352,991 new infections, with overcrowded hospitals in Delhi and elsewhere struggling to cope with the surge. The government has urged citizens to get vaccinated and exercise caution, while countries including Britain, Germany, and the US have pledged to send urgent medical aid. India's death toll has risen to 195,123, with health experts estimating the actual number to be higher. The crisis has also led to criticism of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's handling of the situation, with many questioning the decision to hold rallies despite the severe outbreak.

site_title: STI closes higher on strong factory output numbers
summary: Singapore shares ended in positive territory on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.34% to 3,204.90, driven by strong factory output figures. The index beat expectations, with electronics leading the gain, and is expected to be sustained due to low base and global recovery. Other regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Seoul's Kospi rising, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.43% to 28,952.83. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.95% to 3,441.17, while the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.75% to 2,281.30. The decline came as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Analysts quadruple Singapore's Q1 growth estimate to 0.9% as factories maintain steam
summary: Singapore's factory sector showed a strong performance in March, with output increasing by 7.6% year-on-year, driven by demand for semiconductors and chemicals. This has led analysts to quadruple the country's Q1 growth estimate to 0.9%, more than four times the official estimate of 0.2%. The electronics and precision engineering clusters were particularly strong, with semiconductor growth supported by demand from cloud services and 5G markets. The chemicals industry also saw a 9.5% expansion in March, with petrochemicals rebounding from a year-ago low base.

site_title: Total confirms suspension of work on Mozambique gas project
summary: French energy giant Total suspends work on a $20 billion gas project in northern Mozambique due to the latest jihadist assault on a nearby town. The company is withdrawing personnel from the Afungi site and declaring a "force majeure" situation beyond its control. This move follows previous security concerns and escalating instability in the region. Total's decision aims to ensure the safety of its employees and protect the project's interests.

site_title: Nestle is in talks to acquire Nature's Bounty owner
summary: Nestle SA is in talks to acquire Bountiful Co, the owner of Nature's Bounty, potentially valuing the company at over $6 billion. The acquisition would expand Nestle's presence in the supplements and vitamins segment, following its successful entry into the market under CEO Mark Schneider. Schneider has been buying larger brands to gain pricing power and appeal to health-conscious consumers. The deal could preempt Bountiful's planned initial public offering, which was valued at over $6 billion.

site_title: Trade, factories to fuel Asean-6 economic recovery; retail sales a drag: report
summary: Trade and manufacturing are driving the economic recovery in the Asean-6 region, with industrial production expected to increase from the second quarter onwards, according to Oxford Economics. The region's economy contracted by 1.5% in Q1 2021, a pickup from the 3% decline in Q4 2020. Retail sales are a drag on most of the region, except for Singapore and Vietnam, where wholesale and retail trade expansions are occurring. Economists are cautiously optimistic about the outlook for Singapore and Vietnam, while warning of downside risks for Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines due to worsening Covid outbreaks.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Why young working adults need to start a financial plan now (Ep 94)
summary: Young working adults are advised to establish a financial plan as soon as possible, rather than waiting until they have a significant amount to invest. This is according to Chris Lim, digital editor at The Business Times, and Deepak Khanna, head of wealth products and journeys at HSBC, in episode 94 of BT Money Hacks. Khanna emphasizes the importance of having a plan in place to manage finances effectively and make informed investment decisions. By starting early, young adults can set themselves up for long-term financial stability and success.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises target price for ARA Logos, sees stronger growth prospects
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has increased its target price for ARA Logos Logistics Trust to S$0.814, citing 8.2% year-on-year revenue growth and a 35.7% year-on-year DPU gain in Q1 2021. The trust's occupancy rate has improved to 99.1% from 98.5% last year, supporting its forecast for 2021 to 2023. CGS-CIMB believes the trust's diversified portfolio and strong growth prospects make it an "add" call, with a 7% dividend yield.

site_title: Credit Suisse investors oppose risk chairman's Gottschling re-election
summary: Credit Suisse shareholders, holding over 15% of the stock, oppose re-election of risk committee chairman Andreas Gottschling amid the bank's significant losses, including at least $4.7 billion from Archegos and Greensill. Investors, including David Herro and the Ethos Foundation, want Gottschling removed due to his role in the failed investments. Norway's oil fund also plans to vote against his re-election, with Herro calling for his resignation. The bank's shareholders meeting is scheduled for April 30.

site_title: OCBC appoints new CEO of OCBC Wing Hang Bank
summary: OCBC Wing Hang Bank has appointed Ivy Au-Yeung as its new CEO, effective May 20, succeeding Na Wu Beng. Au-Yeung, 58, brings over 30 years of experience in corporate and commercial banking, having previously held roles at an Australian bank and OCBC Wing Hang Bank. Her appointment makes her the first female CEO at the bank and adds to the bank's female representation in its management team. The move comes as OCBC aims to grow its retail banking business in the Greater China region, a key market for the bank.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as gold stocks offset gains in miners, banks
summary: Australian shares were flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.13% at 7,052.20. Gains in banks and miners offset losses in gold miners and technology stocks. Heavyweight miners rose 0.5% due to iron ore price gains, while banks rose 0.8% to their highest since February. The lockdown in Western Australia's Perth weighed on sentiment, with top losers including JB Hi-Fi and Silver Lake Resources.

site_title: Bitcoin bounces strongly after hitting lowest since early March
summary: Bitcoin rallied strongly on Monday, rebounding from a low of $47,079, as investors took advantage of the lowest levels in seven weeks to buy back in. The cryptocurrency rose 9.6% to $52,747, with some analysts seeing the drop as a great buying opportunity. Despite a cautionary note from JPMorgan Chase, Bitcoin is on track for its biggest gain since February 8, with some cryptocurrency-linked stocks also rising.

site_title: Thai premier says more curbs planned to control virus flare-up
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha announced plans to implement fresh control measures to contain the country's biggest wave of coronavirus outbreak. The measures, to be considered by the Center for Covid-19 Situation Administration, include stricter curbs on businesses and movements in Bangkok, following a surge in cases linked to entertainment venues. Thailand reported its biggest one-day jump in new infections and record fatalities, with a total case count of 57,508. Authorities have already closed dozens of businesses in Bangkok for two weeks, with shortened hours for malls and convenience stores.

site_title: NTUC, STB launch initiative for workforce, business transformation in tourism industry
summary: NTUC and the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) have launched the Tourism Sector Capability Development Roadmap to transform the tourism industry in Singapore. The initiative aims to deepen cross-sector partnerships and address post-pandemic challenges. The roadmap outlines key areas, including upskilling workers, leveraging technology, and creating seamless visitor experiences. Business leaders, union leaders, and trade associations have worked together to identify challenges and enablers, with a focus on safe, standardised, and positive travel experiences for visitors. The collaboration reflects the need for cross-sector collaboration to address pandemic-related challenges.

site_title: Indonesia infrastructure tipped to rebound strongly from Covid-19 trough
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure sector is expected to rebound strongly from the COVID-19 trough, with Fitch Solutions projecting year-on-year growth of 8.7% in 2021, followed by an average annual expansion of 6.8% from 2022 to 2030. Strong government support, including loan guarantees and public funding, is driving the growth, with road and power projects expected to be key drivers. The government's infrastructure development plans and easing of restrictions on foreign investors are also expected to boost the sector, with foreign funds and state-backed agencies potentially investing in Indonesia's infrastructure projects.

site_title: Singapore factory output expands 7.6% in March as electronics boom continues
summary: Singapore's factory output expanded 7.6% in March, driven by a 33.7% growth in the electronics industry, with semiconductors leading the charge. The biomedical cluster, however, declined 6.6% amid lower output of biological products. Industrial production added 14.9% when excluding biomedical contributions, and the first three months of 2021 saw a 10.7% growth in manufacturing performance.

images.alt_text: The latest increase was a slowdown from the 16.5 per cent surge in February, but still beat the median estimate of 4.7 per cent in a private-sector Bloomberg poll.

site_title: Canadian government to intervene to end potential Montreal port strike
summary: The Canadian government will intervene to end a potential strike at the Port of Montreal, where 1,125 longshore workers are threatening to walk off the job due to changes to their work schedule. The strike, which could start on Monday, has raised concerns about the impact on Canada's economy, which is still recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic. Labour Minister Filomena Tassi has filed notice for legislation to resume operations if a strike occurs, and mediation talks are set for Monday. The last strike at the port lasted 19 days in August 2020.

site_title: Why Indonesia makes for a solid investment: Fidelity
summary: Indonesia emerges as a solid investment opportunity due to its strong demographic advantages, pro-reform government, and structural growth trends. The country's approach to COVID-19, avoiding strict lockdowns, helped mitigate the economic downturn. Indonesia's rising middle class and under-penetrated goods and services sectors drive growth potential, particularly in financial services, healthcare, home improvement, and digital economy. The government's focus on sustainability, including clean energy and electric vehicles, also presents opportunities for investors. With a large population, rich resource base, and strong demographic advantage, Indonesia is expected to contribute to global growth, making it an attractive universe for disciplined long-term investors.

site_title: China's biggest IPO this year looks to be in renewable energy
summary: China Three Gorges Renewables Group Co., the renewable energy unit of state-owned China Three Gorges Corp, is set to secure the country's largest IPO this year, raising up to 8.57 billion shares in Shanghai. The company, the world's largest hydropower company and China's largest clean-energy firm, plans to use the funds for offshore wind power projects and liquidity replenishment. The listing comes as China aims to reach peak carbon emissions by 2030 and carbon-neutrality by 2060, with renewable energy demand on the rise amid new solar projects and collaboration agreements with major wind-turbine makers.

site_title: Chinese firms are listing in the US at a record-breaking pace
summary: Chinese firms are listing in the US at a record-breaking pace, raising $6.6 billion through initial public offerings (IPOs) this year, an eightfold increase from the same period in 2020. Despite tensions between the two economies and the risk of delisting, companies like RLX Technology and Tuya Inc. are going ahead with listings. The growth in US IPOs is driven by factors such as greater liquidity, a broader investor base, and the cachet associated with a US listing.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies are listing in the US at the fastest pace ever, brushing off tensions between the world's two biggest economies and the continued risk of being kicked off American exchanges.

site_title: Singapore consortium cedes running of Chinatown Heritage Centre to STB
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has taken over the management of the Chinatown Heritage Centre from a local consortium, ending their contract due to the impact of Covid-19 and travel restrictions. The museum, which was closed for renovation, will remain closed until further notice. STB plans to review the centre's operating model and announce future plans in due course. The Chinatown Heritage Centre, opened in 2002, had undergone a revamp in 2014 and was previously operated by a consortium of tourism players.

images.alt_text: The Chinatown Heritage Centre has been closed since September last year for renovation and enhancement works, will stay closed until further notice instead of reopening this month.

site_title: Philips sees hit from product safety fault
summary: Dutch firm Philips anticipates a potential hit of up to 250 million euros from a possible safety risk in some sleep and respiratory care products. The company has identified a quality issue with sound-dampening foam in certain devices that could degrade under certain conditions. Philips has taken a 250 million euro provision and is initiating precautionary actions to address the issue. Despite this, the company's first quarter profits rose 2.6% to 40 million euros, driven by increased sales of healthcare products.

site_title: Fashion designer Alber Elbaz dies of Covid-19 aged 59
summary: Fashion designer Alber Elbaz has died at 59 after a three-week battle with Covid-19. Elbaz, who transformed Lanvin into an industry darling, was fired from the French fashion house in 2015. He went on to form partnerships and collaborated with brands like H&M before joining Richemont in 2019. Elbaz's designs, known for their playful edge, earned him fans among Hollywood stars and critics alike, who praised his inclusive vision of fashion and his ability to redefine the industry.

site_title: ExxonMobil investor says its climate strategy an 'existential' risk: report
summary: ExxonMobil's climate strategy is deemed an "existential business risk" by activist hedge fund Engine No. 1, citing the company's lack of a plan to adapt to the energy transition. ExxonMobil plans to continue pumping oil and investing in new projects, despite criticism over its approach to renewable energy. The hedge fund claims the company's total emissions will increase by 2025, and its strategy is causing "value destruction." This criticism comes as world leaders meet to discuss climate targets and the US oil giant is set to report its first-quarter results.

site_title: Temasek invests US$120m in India's UpGrad
summary: Temasek Holdings has invested US$120 million in edtech major UpGrad Education, the company's first external funding round. UpGrad, which offers over 100 courses to learners in more than 50 countries, plans to use the capital to strengthen its team, scale global operations, and expand its graduate and postgraduate degree portfolio in India. UpGrad aims to achieve US$2 billion in revenue by 2026 and is currently at an annual revenue run rate of US$165 million. The investment will help the company pursue merger and acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Saudi state miner Maaden names third CEO in 13 months
summary: Saudi state miner Maaden has appointed its third CEO in 13 months, following the departure of Mosaed Al Ohali for personal reasons. Abdulaziz Al Harbi, a senior vice president, will act as CEO until further notice. The stock rose 2.1% after the announcement, valuing the company at almost $20 billion. Al Ohali had aimed to reduce debt and keep a cash cushion, but the company made a slightly lower-than-expected profit in the first quarter.

site_title: South Korea's first Oscar-winning actress
summary: Youn Yuh-jung, a 74-year-old South Korean actress, has become the country's first Oscar-winning actress. She won the Best Supporting Actress award for her role in the film "Minari", a family drama about Korean immigrants in the US. This win marks the second consecutive year a Korean-language film has won the Best Picture award, following "Parasite"'s historic win in 2020. Youn's career has spanned over 50 years, with a string of notable performances and a recent Screen Actors Guild award.

images.alt_text: Septuagenarian Youn Yuh-jung, South Korea's first Oscar-winning actress, has spent decades portraying nonconformist characters, from a vicious heiress to an ageing prostitute, challenging social norms in both career and life.

site_title: Business class opens to masses as affordable Covid refuge
summary: Business class, once an exclusive haven for the wealthy, is now being invaded by masses of travelers seeking to minimize COVID-19 risk. With a record number of air miles accumulated during the pandemic, leisure travelers are splurging on premium seats for their first trips back. This unexpected boon is a welcome relief for airlines, which are forecast to lose $174 billion by the end of 2021. As vaccinations roll out, free-spending vacationers are emerging as a new market for carriers to exploit and recover revenue. Airlines are capitalizing on this trend to claw back lost revenue.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open nearly flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened nearly flat on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index off 0.1% and the Topix index up 0.4%. Investors assessed the impact of Japan's virus state of emergency while embracing Wall Street rallies.

site_title: Japan ruling party loses seats in blow for Suga before election
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) lost seats in three by-elections, a blow to Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga before a general election. The opposition won all three by-elections, which included replacing lawmakers due to graft charges and a lawmaker's death from Covid-19. Despite the losses, the LDP-led coalition maintained its majority in parliament. Suga faces a party leadership poll in September and must call a general election by October, which could weaken his support amid scandals and the pandemic.

site_title: Philippine central bank says to continue supporting economy amid pandemic
summary: The Philippine central bank, led by Governor Benjamin Diokno, will continue supporting the economy amid the ongoing pandemic. Despite a record 9.6% economic slump in 2020, the central bank believes the impact of the Covid-19 crisis will be transitory. The bank's support aims to mitigate the effects of the pandemic and maintain the economy's fundamental soundness.

site_title: Australia's Westpac expects first-half profit hit of A$28m
summary: Westpac Banking Corp expects its first-half cash earnings to be A$282 million lower due to provisions for customer remediation, write-downs, and costs associated with recent deals. The bank anticipates a profit hit of A$28 million. Westpac will report its first-half results on May 3.

site_title: Higher success rate for property auctions in Q1 as investors chase yields: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank reports a 3.5% success rate for property auctions in Q1 2021 in Singapore, surpassing pre-Covid levels in 2019. The improved success rate is attributed to investors seeking yields in a low interest-rate climate. Auction properties garnered interest from opportunistic retail investors, with a 76.3% increase in retail listings and a 28% decrease in industrial listings. The consultancy predicts a 5% success rate for the rest of 2021, driven by strengthened buyer demand for unique properties and limited supply.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks start week higher; earnings, Fed meeting eyed
summary: South Korean stocks opened higher on Monday, rising 0.4% to 3,198.15, ahead of a big earnings week and the US Federal Reserve meeting. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Key earnings announcements include POSCO, Samsung SDI, LG Display, and LG Chem. Investors are watching for clues on the global economy's recovery, with foreigners buying 36.8 billion won worth of shares. The won has lost 2.6% against the dollar this year, and money and debt markets showed a slight increase in treasury bond yields.

site_title: China to launch month-long effort in May to boost consumption
summary: China plans a month-long promotional campaign in May to boost domestic consumption, following a 34.2% year-on-year surge in retail sales in March. The effort, part of President Xi Jinping's "dual circulation" economic strategy, aims to reduce dependence on foreign markets. Activities include a consumer goods expo in Hainan province, car shows in Shanghai, and sales promotions on e-commerce platforms, targeting "good quality brands" in food, travel, and cultural products. The campaign is set to kick off on May 1, coinciding with the Labour Day holiday.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sees over 800b riyals in savings from energy reforms plan: finance minister
summary: Saudi Arabia aims to save over $200 billion over the next decade by replacing liquid fuel with gas and renewable energy sources, according to Finance Minister Mohammed al-Jadaan. The move is part of the kingdom's ambitious reforms program to modernize its economy and reduce dependence on oil revenues. The plan, which will displace at least 1 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, is expected to save the government 800 billion riyals (S$283.2 billion) over 10 years, which can be used for investment.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble to start on May 26: MOT
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong's air travel bubble is set to start on May 26, allowing travellers to move between the cities without quarantine, as long as the Covid-19 situation remains steady and under control. To qualify, travellers must have remained in either city for the last 14 days and download Hong Kong's LeaveHomeSafe app before departure. The bubble can be suspended if the seven-day moving average of unlinked community cases increases to more than five, and can resume only when the situation stabilizes.

site_title: Gold ticks up as dollar stays on back foot
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,779.36 per ounce, boosted by a soft US dollar ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. Palladium held below a record peak, while silver rose 0.2% to $26.04 per ounce. Investors sought safer assets amid concerns over COVID-19 cases, pouring $16.4 billion into global bond funds. Gold production in Zimbabwe fell 30% to 3.98 tonnes in the first quarter, while India's physical gold demand faltered due to COVID-19 restrictions.

site_title: Japan's services prices rebound but outlook clouded by new Covid-19 curb
summary: Japan's services prices rose 0.7% in March, the first increase in six months, driven by a base effect from last year's decline and increased demand for television and internet advertisements. However, the third state of emergency to combat a resurgence of new Covid-19 infections clouds the outlook, with expected store closures likely to hurt consumption. This moderation in the economy's recovery and weak wage growth pose challenges for the Bank of Japan's inflation target of 2%. Japan's core consumer prices fell for the eighth straight month in March.

site_title: Qatar Petroleum plans US$10b bond sale for gas expansion
summary: Qatar Petroleum plans to issue up to $10 billion in bonds to fund its massive North Field gas expansion project, which aims to increase annual output capacity by over 50% to 126 million tons by 2027. The project, valued at $29 billion, will cement Qatar's status as the world's largest liquefied natural gas exporter. The bonds will be issued in tranches of $7 billion to $10 billion and have maturities of 5, 10, and 30 years. This would be one of the largest corporate deals of the year from emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Qatar Petroleum plans to issue up to US$10 billion of bonds as soon as this quarter to fund a massive natural-gas project, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Building supply chain agility
summary: A global semiconductor chip shortage has highlighted the need for agile supply chains to prevent similar crises in the future. Experts recommend investing in technologies for real-time visibility, maximizing equipment effectiveness, and adopting event-driven digital twins. Diversifying manufacturing locations and supplier mixes, and having end-to-end visibility across the ecosystem, can also help mitigate risks. Governments and companies must work together to provide fiscal support and increase capacity and inventory to mitigate future disruptions. Leveraging advanced technologies, such as predictive modeling and data-driven decision-making, can also enable proactive management of supply chain risks.

site_title: Singapore launches 10-year blueprint to cement IP hub status
summary: Singapore has launched the 10-year Singapore IP Strategy (SIPS) 2030 to strengthen its position as an intellectual property hub. The blueprint includes an improved filing system, national standards, and an online marketplace, IP Grow, to facilitate access to IP services. The initiatives aim to create a vibrant and innovative economy, foster cross-border innovation, and establish Singapore as a regional IP dispute resolution hub. The strategy is part of Singapore's efforts to capitalize on the growing demand for IP globally, with IP filing numbers increasing by over 20% in the past five years.
