site_title: Pandemic-constrained Oscars feature more oratory, less music, comedy
summary: The 93rd Academy Awards ceremony, held on April 25, 2021, was marked by a significant departure from traditional televised Oscar presentations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The event featured lengthy oratory speeches from winners, with no live orchestra or musical performances, and a pre-recorded presentation of the five Oscar-nominated best original songs. The ceremony, held in a ballroom decorated in a quasi-cabaret style, was attended by a few hundred nominees and presenters, with some joining remotely. The show's focus on storytelling and personal anecdotes was seen as a departure from the usual entertainment-focused format, with mixed reactions from critics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with slight gains, following a strong finish on Wall Street the previous week. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.1% to 29,106.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.3% to 3,484.11. Investors are watching a meeting of Federal Reserve policymakers, but the gains were not attributed to any specific news.

site_title: Hatten Land to pay China Construction Yangtze River RM1.5m
summary: Hatten Land has agreed to pay RM1.5 million to China Construction Yangtze River Sdn Bhd after an adjudicator ruled in favor of the contractor. The payment includes RM1.4 million for contract works and RM150,000 for adjudication costs. The decision resolves a dispute over a construction contract valued at RM818.2 million, and Hatten Land has stated that the payment will not significantly impact its financial performance. The company's shares rose 10% after the announcement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.7 points or 0.2% to 1,611.2 at Monday's open, driven by a gain of 367 stocks to 254 losers. Volume traded was 992.4 million lots worth RM516.7 million.

site_title: UK lawmakers call for PM Johnson to publish Big Pharma lobbying messages
summary: UK lawmakers have called for Prime Minister Boris Johnson to publish all communications with pharmaceutical companies to determine if private lobbying influenced the UK's opposition to a Covid-19 vaccine intellectual property waiver. The waiver, opposed by US companies like Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson, would temporarily waive IP rights for developing countries to produce vaccines. A cross-party group of lawmakers and patient advocacy groups signed a statement, citing the UK's "utterly indefensible" stance, while the government claims it prioritizes transparency but needs confidentiality in its communications.

site_title: US administers 228.7m doses of Covid-19 vaccines: CDC
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that as of Sunday, the country had administered 228.7 million Covid-19 vaccine doses, with 140 million receiving at least one dose and 94.8 million fully vaccinated. Johnson & Johnson's vaccine was cleared to resume use after a 10-day pause, and 7.8 million doses were administered in long-term care facilities.

site_title: Stone Point, GIC near US$3b deal for financial services provider Ascensus
summary: US$3 billion deal nears completion for Ascensus, a retirement and savings account provider, as Stone Point Capital and GIC close in on the acquisition. The deal is backed by strong interest from potential buyers and could be announced as early as this week. Ascensus, previously owned by Genstar Capital and Aquiline Capital Partners, had considered an initial public offering but opted for a sale instead. The acquisition is part of the growing trend of investors snapping up retirement-services providers due to technological innovation and an aging population.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust to divest Kidman Park property in Australia for A$41.5m
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has agreed to sell its Kidman Park property in Australia for A$41.5 million, about 3.8% above its valuation of A$40 million. The sale is part of the trust's strategy to build a more resilient portfolio by divesting "lower-performing" properties. Net proceeds from the sale will be approximately A$40.5 million, which may be used to fund new acquisitions, repay debt, and work capital.

site_title: StashAway to buy back up to S$4m in employee options with upcoming fundraise
summary: StashAway, a wealth management platform, plans to buy back up to S$4 million in employee stock options with its upcoming US$25 million Series D funding round led by Sequoia Capital India. The fundraise, pending regulatory approval, will provide liquidity for employees and allow the startup to expand its engineering team in Singapore and abroad. With the fresh capital, StashAway will have a total paid-up capital of S$84.04 million, following its achievement of crossing US$1 billion in assets under management.

site_title: CICT posts 66.6% rise in Q1 net property income to S$247.1m
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) reported a 66.6% rise in Q1 net property income to S$247.1 million, driven by higher integrated development performance and income from office assets. Gross revenue rose 63.9% year-over-year to S$334.8 million. As of March 31, 2021, CICT's committed portfolio occupancy stood at 95.9%, with retail and office occupancy rates at 97.1% and 94.9%, respectively. The trust's average term to maturity has been extended to 4.4 years, and its upcoming integrated development at Raffles Place has achieved a 50% committed occupancy.

site_title: 'Nomadland' wins best picture at Oscars, Hopkins wins over Chadwick Boseman
summary: "Nomadland" won the Best Picture Oscar, while Anthony Hopkins took home the Best Actor award for his role in "The Father." Chloe Zhao became the first Asian woman to win Best Director for "Nomadland," and 15 women won a record 17 Oscars, including Frances McDormand, who won her third Oscar. The ceremony marked a return to Hollywood glamour after the pandemic shutdown and highlighted the industry's efforts to promote diversity and inclusion.

images.alt_text: In a major upset, Britain's Anthony Hopkins won the best actor trophy for his role as a man battling dementia in "The Father."

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, ARA Logos, Ascendas Reit, Aspen, Hongkong Land, Sheng Siong
summary: Several Singaporean companies saw significant developments that may impact trading of their securities. CIC recorded a 66.6% rise in net property income to S$247.1 million in the first quarter, driven by improved integrated development performance. ARA Logos divested Kidman Park in Australia for A$41.5 million. Ascendas Reit reported a 3% positive rental reversion and proposed the sale of a warehouse to Hafary for S$16 million. Meanwhile, Aspen withdrew an announcement about a US$210 million gloves supply order from Honeywell, and Sheng Siong announced it would continue to pay out 70% of its net profit as dividends.

site_title: India asks Twitter to take down some tweets critical of its Covid-19 handling
summary: India's government asked Twitter to remove dozens of tweets critical of its Covid-19 handling, citing the Information Technology Act, 2000. The platform withheld some of the tweets after the request, stating it reviews content under both Twitter's rules and local law. The move comes as India struggles with a world-record number of Covid-19 cases, with criticism mounting over the government's handling of the crisis. Twitter notified affected account holders and withheld access to the content in India, but did not remove it globally.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Monday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,189.14 at the Monday open, with 71.5 million securities changing hands. Yoma Strategic led the day with a 7% gain, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 1.4%. Jardine Matheson was the top loser, falling 2.3%. On Wall Street, stocks rose, with the S&P 500 advancing 1.1% and the Nasdaq Composite gaining 1.4%. European stocks declined, marking their first weekly loss in eight, amid a surge in global coronavirus cases.

site_title: Oil edges lower near US$62 with investors assessing demand outlook
summary: Oil prices edged lower near US$62 a barrel as investors assessed demand outlook ahead of a key OPEC+ meeting. The market faces near-term headwinds from a Covid-19 flare-up in India, which could impact the Opec+ alliance's supply plans. Despite this, global benchmark Brent is firming in a bullish backwardation structure, suggesting little concern about fresh supply. The Opec+ meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, and the prospect of more crude flows from Iran remains uncertain, adding to market volatility.

images.alt_text: Oil was steady at the open of trading in Asia as investors assessed the outlook for demand ahead of a key Opec+ meeting later this week.

site_title: Canadian dollar adds to winning streak, bolstered by yield gap
summary: The Canadian dollar strengthened against the US dollar for the fourth consecutive week, reaching 1.2475 to the greenback. The currency's gains were bolstered by the Bank of Canada's hawkish shift, which signaled a potential interest rate hike and reduced bond purchases. The yield gap between Canada and the US also contributed to the currency's strength. Canadian factory sales rose 3.5% in March, adding to evidence of economic recovery, while the US dollar fell against a basket of currencies and oil prices rose 1.2%.

site_title: UK fintech Currencycloud hiring for new Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore
summary: Currencycloud, a London-based fintech startup, has named Singapore as its Asia-Pacific headquarters and plans to hire over 50 staff members. The company will occupy a new office in Raffles Quay, providing on-the-ground support for existing customers in the region. Currencycloud is expanding its presence to improve services for customers in South-east Asia, Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan, and is applying for a major payment institution licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: EU will let vaccinated Americans visit this summer: official
summary: The European Union will allow vaccinated Americans to visit over the summer, with the European Commission recommending a switch in policy due to the US's rapid vaccination pace and advanced talks with EU officials. The move, announced by EU President Ursula von der Leyen, will enable trans-Atlantic leisure travel to resume, with all 27 EU member states accepting vaccinated travelers with EMA-approved vaccines. Individual member states may still impose stricter limits, but countries like Greece and Spain welcome the opportunity to reopen to American tourists, which could bring a financial boost.

site_title: Myanmar activists slam Asean concensus, vow to continue protests
summary: Myanmar's pro-democracy activists have criticized an agreement reached by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) with the country's junta chief, Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, to end the nation's violent post-coup crisis. The agreement, reached in Jakarta, Indonesia, calls for an end to violence, constructive dialogue, and a special envoy to facilitate talks. However, activists vow to continue protests, citing the junta's lack of commitment to releasing political prisoners and restraining security forces. The Myanmar National Unity Government welcomed the consensus but emphasized the need for "firm action" to restore democracy.

site_title: For China's property developers, Hong Kong is becoming Shenzhen's backyard
summary: Chinese property developers are increasingly targeting Hong Kong's border districts, viewing them as a more affordable alternative to Shenzhen, a neighboring boomtown. This shift is seen as a turning point, with buyers from Shenzhen considering Hong Kong as its "backyard." Despite Hong Kong's red-hot property market, the city's international economic prestige has come under pressure due to pro-democracy protests and national security laws.

site_title: NFL and Clubhouse partner on 2021 NFL draft programming lineup
summary: The National Football League (NFL) and social media app Clubhouse are partnering for the 2021 NFL Draft, offering an exclusive programming lineup. Fans can join NFL rooms to follow the draft live, listen to discussions, and ask questions. This partnership marks the NFL's second collaboration with an emerging platform, following previous partnerships with Snapchat and TikTok. Clubhouse's popularity has surged since billionaires Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg appeared on the platform, with 10 million weekly active users.

site_title: In London, rail-side gardening blossoms in a time of the pandemic
summary: A community-led project in London, Energy Garden, has been transforming train stations into eco-friendly gardens, providing a haven for wildlife and promoting sustainability. Since its inception in 2011, the project has grown, with 34 solar-powered sites created along train platforms, and now has over 300 volunteers. The gardens not only reduce carbon emissions but also serve as a community space, fostering social connections and environmental awareness. The project's success aims to address the climate change challenge and inspire others to take action.

site_title: UK economy set to grow faster than the US this year: Goldman
summary: Britain's economy is projected to grow 7.8% this year, surpassing the US, according to Goldman Sachs. This forecast comes after the UK's vaccination program has accelerated the country's recovery from the Covid-19 crisis. The UK's gross domestic product growth is expected to outpace the US, with Goldman Sachs' previous forecast for US growth being 6.8% in 2021. The UK's economy shrunk by nearly 10% last year, while the US economy shrank by an estimated 3.5%. The Bank of England Deputy Governor has also predicted "very rapid growth" over the next couple of quarters.

site_title: Investors betting against green are going against powerful governments
summary: Investors betting against green stocks are facing increased regulatory pressure from powerful governments. Major economies, including the US, Canada, Japan, and the UK, have pledged significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, paving the way for green investments and bonds. The European Union has also introduced new legislation to drive sustainable financing, with a focus on renewable energy and low-emission cars. As a result, companies not positioned for the transition to a lower-carbon economy risk being penalized, while those in the green sector are expected to benefit from the increased investment.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has also introduced more detailed and mandatory reporting requirements on sustainability, for some 50,000 companies on the continent.

site_title: Thai central bank likely to slash GDP forecasts after new virus outbreak
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to lower its GDP growth forecasts due to a rapidly spreading third wave of Covid-19 infections, driven by the highly transmissible B117 variant. The new outbreak has caused over 26,000 cases and 46 deaths, potentially impacting the tourism-reliant nation's efforts to reopen to foreign visitors. The central bank may reduce its forecasts for 3% GDP growth this year and 4.7% next year, and may take six quarters to return to pre-pandemic levels, with the tourism sector expected to be severely affected.

site_title: Foreign investors looking beyond Java for Indonesian fortunes
summary: Foreign investors, particularly those from Singapore, have begun investing heavily in provinces outside of Java, Indonesia, despite the Covid-19 pandemic. In 2020, they poured $80 billion into base metal and non-machine equipment manufacturing plants, creating nearly 1.16 million jobs, with 55% going to regions outside Java. The Omnibus Law, which has attracted foreign direct investment, has opened up new sectors to foreign investors and created tax incentives and tax holidays. The government aims to boost labor productivity to attract more investments and compete with Vietnam and the Philippines, while also addressing fiscal deficits and strengthening the rupiah.

site_title: Mapletree S-Reits grow and diversify
summary: Mapletree Investment Pte Ltd, a leading Singapore-based real estate development and investment group, has grown and diversified its portfolio. Its four listed S-Reits, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Mapletree Commercial Trust, and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, have a combined market capitalization exceeding S$25 billion. The S-Reits have seen revenue and profit growth, with Mapletree Logistics Trust's distribution per unit increasing 2.3% year-on-year. The group's assets under management have also grown significantly, with its third-party managed assets under a cluster of four listed S-Reits increasing over five times in the last decade.

site_title: Greensill: Politicians, financiers linked to scandal
summary: Former British Prime Minister David Cameron is at the center of a scandal surrounding the collapse of Greensill Capital, a firm he privately lobbied for state support despite its opaque business model. Lex Greensill, the firm's founder, obtained inside access to Downing Street during Cameron's tenure and has been linked to other high-profile figures, including Indian-British billionaire Sanjeev Gupta and major banks such as Credit Suisse and SoftBank. The collapse has sparked concerns about thousands of steel-sector jobs and has raised questions about the role of politicians and financiers in the scandal.

site_title: US racing aid to India; Singapore flies medical supplies there
summary: India set a new global record for Covid-19 infections with 349,691 cases in 24 hours, prompting a surge in aid from the US and Singapore. The US is racing to send aid, while Singapore is partnering with Air India and Amazon India News to airlift medical supplies, including oxygen concentrators and ventilator machines. India's hospitals are turning away patients due to a shortage of medical oxygen and beds, with the death toll rising by 10 times in the last month. The US has faced criticism for its export controls on vaccine raw materials, but Secretary of State Anthony Blinken has promised to rapidly deploy additional support to the people of India.

site_title: Draghi says deal reached with EU on Italy's recovery plan
summary: Italy has reached a deal with the European Commission on its recovery plan, Prime Minister Mario Draghi announced to his Cabinet. The plan, valued at over 220 billion euros, aims to revive the country's coronavirus-battered economy. The deal, reached after days of intense talks, includes investments in ecological transition, digitalization, infrastructure, education, and social inclusion. The plan's structural reforms focus on public administration, justice, and tax systems, with the government predicting a 3.6 percentage point increase in GDP by 2026. The plan will be submitted to Brussels by the end of April.

site_title: Economic recovery, low interest rates set tone for gold's performance
summary: Gold's performance in 2020 was driven by low interest rates and the need for investors to hedge against economic and financial risk amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The metal reached a historical high of $2,067.15 per ounce in August 2020 and finished the year up 25%. Despite declining consumption demand in key markets like India and China, investment demand remained strong. The outlook for gold remains uncertain, with concerns about inflation and the potential for a prolonged low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hongkong Land opened its first wholly-owned commercial development project, Kidzplorer, in Chongqing, as part of a $33 million investment to integrate edutainment with lifestyle retailing. The project is part of the company's five-year expansion plan across the Chinese mainland. Meanwhile, OKP Holdings denied being banned from or penalized for its involvement in a 2017 viaduct collapse accident.

site_title: Big Oil sees cash rolling in, but investors won't get it yet
summary: Big Oil companies, such as Exxon Mobil, Total SE, Chevron Corp, and Royal Dutch Shell, are generating spare cash after crude prices recovered from the pandemic. However, investors are unlikely to receive dividends as the companies will use the funds to ease debt. The industry's first quarter results are expected to show a significant improvement in profit and cash flow, with free cash flow projected to rebound to $80 billion for the five supermajors this year. However, investors are still concerned about the companies' ability to deliver sustainable cash flow and returns, with BP and Shell facing pressure to resume buybacks and other peers focusing on debt reduction.

site_title: Forty new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 40 new COVID-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 61,006. Among the cases, 10 were permanent residents and six were foreign domestic workers. Three were symptomatic, and there were no community cases. The number of unlinked cases in the community decreased to three, while 33 patients were discharged, bringing the total recovered to 60,647.

site_title: World's industrial comeback drives metals to multi-year highs
summary: Industrial metals such as copper, aluminum, and iron ore have reached multi-year highs as the world's large economies recover from the pandemic, driving demand for cars, electronics, and infrastructure. The US and China's commitment to greener policies and infrastructure packages are fueling gains, with copper reaching a 10-year high at $9,551.50 a tonne. However, concerns about reduced stimulus in China and global resurgence in the coronavirus may still impact metal demand.

site_title: Singapore unicorn helps clients access IP data with snap of finger
summary: Singaporean startup PatSnap, founded by Jeffrey Tiong, has joined the unicorn club after raising a US$300 million Series E funding round. The company provides an intellectual property platform that helps clients access patent data, drawing global giants like NASA, Disney, and Tesla. PatSnap's platform simplifies complex patent information, making it searchable and digestible. With over 10,000 clients in 40 countries, the startup earns by charging subscription fees, typically ranging from US$20,000 to US$1 million per year. PatSnap plans to expand into new verticals and geographies, aiming for a 50-60% year-on-year growth in its topline.

site_title: China firms are listing in the US at a record-breaking pace
summary: Chinese companies are listing in the US at a record-breaking pace, raising $6.6 billion in initial public offerings (IPOs) so far this year, an eight-fold increase from the same period in 2020. Despite tensions between the US and China, firms are not deterred, with many seeking US listings for their greater liquidity and investor base. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has implemented a law requiring accounting firms to review the financial audits of overseas companies, but Chinese firms continue to list in the US, with some planning secondary listings in Hong Kong to hedge against delisting risk.

site_title: The smart way to grow your money
summary: Singaporeans face financial uncertainty due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with less than half of millennials able to sustain themselves for six months if they lose their jobs. Financial planning is crucial to prepare for sunset years, with OCBC's Financial Wellness Index 2020 showing 42% of millennials unaware of the best way to grow their money. Experts recommend three pillars: savings, investment, and insurance, starting with tracking expenses and setting aside emergency cash. Investing regularly in quality assets over time can also help, with a focus on discipline and patience rather than quick gains.

site_title: Thomson Medical delivers in focus on women, children healthcare
summary: Thomson Medical Group (TMG) is focusing on growing its market share in women's and children's healthcare despite Singapore's declining birth rate. The group delivered close to 8,000 babies last year, accounting for 20.7% of total births. To address unmet needs, TMG is venturing into new areas, such as specialized learning centers for children with developmental delay and in vitro fertilization (IVF). The group has also expanded its pediatrics business and launched new initiatives like Thomson X, a platform for technology-enabled growth. TMG posted a net profit of S$8.1 million for the first half of 2020, driven by government grants and grants for its technology roadmap.

site_title: One-North Eden 85% sold
summary: One-North Eden, a luxury condominium in Singapore, has sold 85% of its units in a virtual launch, with 140 out of 165 apartments sold as of Sunday, April 25, 2021. The selling price ranges from S$1,800 to S$2,250 per square foot. Foreigners and permanent residents made up 20% of the buyers, while the rest were purchased by Singaporeans. The project's smart home technology and facial recognition system were key selling points.

site_title: London's crowded housing moves up on political agenda
summary: London's crowded housing crisis has become a major political issue, with candidates vying for mayor promising solutions to address the city's 8% overcrowded housing rate. The crisis has been exacerbated by the pandemic, with 3.7 million people in England living in overcrowded homes, and London Mayor Sadiq Khan pledging to deliver 10,000 new council homes a year. His Conservative challenger, Shaun Bailey, promises to build 100,000 homes under a shared-ownership program, with prices starting at £100,000. The issue is linked to the spread of Covid-19, with research showing that overcrowding increases the risk of infection and mortality.

site_title: Will bullish sentiment on cryptocurrencies continue?
summary: Bullish sentiment on cryptocurrencies is expected to continue, driven by increased interest from banks and institutions. Bitcoin's price surged from US$29,000 to an all-time-high of US$65,000 in mid-April 2021. However, recent news and rumors have negatively impacted the market, with the US Treasury allegedly planning to accuse financial institutions of using cryptocurrencies for money laundering, causing a significant decline in Bitcoin's price. The current price is trading in a range between US$53,800 and US$57,500, with a potential for a fourth lower high to be formed below US$58,000.

site_title: Maybank Momentum Grant is the gift that goes on giving
summary: Maybank has launched the Momentum Grant, Singapore's first interest-free recyclable grant for small charities. The grant, worth S$360,000, is repayable and aims to uplift and transform charities. Three non-profit organizations, Limitless, Engineering Good, and The Greenhouse Community Services, received the grants. Recipients will also receive masterclasses, mentorship programs, and a Maybank Community Package. The grant's repayable nature allows returned funds to be circulated to help more charities in the future.

site_title: Trade finance platforms pivot as banks take risk-off mode
summary: Trade finance platforms are adapting to banks taking a risk-off mode in the industry, driven by a US$3.4 trillion financing gap in global trade. Fintechs like PrivEx, CCRManager, and Tradeteq are pivoting to digitize loan distribution and re-distribute trade finance among financial institutions. These platforms aim to facilitate trade, reduce costs, and increase efficiency, with some partnering with 112 banks across 35 countries. Despite challenges, these platforms are exploring new opportunities, such as tokenizing trade finance instruments to open up to smaller institutional investors.

site_title: Mewah chairman, CEO raise deemed interest
summary: Mewah International's chairman and CEO, Cheo Tong Choon, and executive director Michelle Cheo Hui Ning, have raised their interest in the company's shares following a recent acquisition by TC Stone Ltd. The acquisition, worth S$273,156, has increased Dr. Cheo's stake from 47.98% to 48.03%. Mewah's share price has gained 24.2% to 41.0 cents in the 2021 year to April 22. The company's balance sheet and cash flows remain strong, with a net debt to equity ratio of 0.34 in 2020.

site_title: Online retail boom gets reality check
summary: Singapore's online retail sales have tapered off from a peak of 24.9% in May 2020 to 10.1% as of February 2021, despite being higher than the pre-pandemic proportion of 6.7% in December 2019. The growth is slower than the global forecast of 19.5% for 2021. Retailers face challenges such as high operational readiness costs, platform fees, and digital marketing expenses, which may make e-commerce less profitable than brick-and-mortar retail. The stagnating growth is also attributed to the focus on essential spending and cannibalisation from cross-border e-commerce.

site_title: US ends pause on Johnson & Johnson's vaccine after concern about clots
summary: The US health agencies lifted the pause on Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine after reviewing 15 cases of blood clots among 8 million doses administered. The FDA and CDC determined the vaccine is safe and effective, with a low risk of developing the rare blood-clot syndrome. The agencies will continue to investigate, but health officials say the vaccine remains an option, particularly for women under 50. Pharmacies and hospitals are gearing up to resume administering the vaccine, with nearly 10 million doses ready to be used across the US.

site_title: Spinning the Rolodex no longer cuts it for archaic loan sales
summary: Singapore-based fintech PrivEx aims to disrupt the US$3.25 trillion global secondary loans market by launching an online exchange to facilitate the trading of corporate loans among financial institutions. Licensed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, PrivEx uses data analytics and algorithms to improve price discovery and liquidity, cutting processing time from 19 man-hours to under 15 minutes. The platform, set to launch in the third quarter, will list various corporate loans and offer its services for free initially, with fees to be introduced later.

site_title: US home sales are surging. When will the music stop?
summary: US home sales are surging, with median sale prices reaching a 16% increase from last year, but experts warn that this trend may not last. Rising mortgage rates and tight inventory are expected to moderate demand, with some analysts predicting a 10% drop in home sales in the fourth quarter of 2021. Despite this, cities like New York are experiencing a turnaround, with sales increasing and prices stabilizing. The market is expected to follow regular economic cycles, with a shift away from investment buyers and a potential increase in demand for suburbs.

site_title: Computer chip shortage may leave car industry idling
summary: A global semiconductor shortage is affecting the car industry, with carmakers forced to idle production lines due to delayed deliveries. The shortage, caused by a surge in demand for electronic devices during the pandemic and supply chain issues, may last throughout the year, impacting production volumes of up to 100,000 vehicles. Companies like Toyota, Volkswagen, and Stellantis have already paused production, and some predict the shortage will continue into 2023, with no immediate improvement expected.

images.alt_text: Japan's government and local carmakers are lining up to offer support to Renesas Electronics (above), a key chip manufacturer, after a factory fire in March this year that could worsen a global semiconductor shortage affecting car firms.

site_title: OKP not aware of a ban on government projects post-viaduct mishap
summary: OKP Holdings, a mainboard-listed firm, claims it is unaware of a ban on government projects following a 2017 viaduct collapse accident. The company stated this in response to shareholder questions ahead of its annual general meeting. Despite the incident, OKP Holdings has secured "quite small" public sector contracts and has not participated in the North South Corridor project since then. The company is seeking clarification on the alleged ban.

site_title: Hongkong Land rolls out edutainment at lifestyle retailing across mainland China
summary: Hongkong Land, a Singapore-based property firm, has launched Kidzplorer, an edutainment play-centre at its Chongqing development, marking its first wholly-owned commercial project in south-west China. The $33 million investment over five years aims to integrate edutainment with lifestyle retailing in other cities. Kidzplorer features a 9-zone play area, a Steam classroom, and a family café, catering to parents with children. This marks a breakthrough in providing family-friendly amenities, elevating the value of Hongkong Land's portfolio in the Chinese mainland and region.

site_title: Germany faces lockdown until June as curbs fail to reduce cases
summary: Germany's coronavirus infection rate has risen despite stricter restrictions, prompting Finance Minister Olaf Scholz to urge the federal government to outline a plan to ease curbs by the end of May. Chancellor Angela Merkel called on Germans to stick to tougher rules in areas with high infection rates. The country's seven-day average of cases per 100,000 people reached 166, and schools will close if cases exceed 165 per 100,000 residents. The government aims to provide clear opening steps for the summer, allowing restaurants to adjust reopening plans and citizens to plan holidays.

images.alt_text: Mr Scholz: "We need a timetable on how to get back to normal life, but it must be a plan that won't have to be revoked after just a few days."

site_title: Myanmar Airways flight arrives in Jakarta ahead of Asean summit
summary: A Myanmar Airways International plane arrived in Jakarta ahead of the Asean summit, which focuses on the crisis in Myanmar. The flight, MMA001, is expected to bring Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, the junta chief behind the February coup, although his presence has not been confirmed. The summit aims to address the crisis and its humanitarian impact, which has led to widespread protests and human rights abuses in the country. The event is being held by the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean).

site_title: Manufacturing hurdles, not IP, slowing Covid jabs rollout: industry
summary: Industry representatives warn that removing intellectual property protections from Covid-19 vaccines or pressuring companies into technology sharing won't speed up production and could slow it down. Despite calls for IP waivers, vaccine manufacturers say the main hurdles are resolving trade barriers and export restrictions, as well as ensuring equipment and expertise to meet stringent quality and safety standards. A global shortage of vaccine components and ingredients is also hindering production, and some manufacturers fear that sharing technology with less-equipped producers could jeopardize progress and delay production.

site_title: Inflation could be the next big risk for investors
summary: Singapore's inflation rate rose 1.3% year-on-year in March, higher than February's 0.7% and January's 0.2%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects inflation to average between 0-1% in 2021. Similar inflationary pressures are seen in the US, where headline CPI rose 2.6% year-on-year in March. Analysts warn that the recent acceleration in inflation may not be transitory, with some predicting inflation could reach 3-4% by mid-2022. Energy stocks and Reits may outperform in a high inflation environment, while technology stocks may underperform due to their cash flows being concentrated in the future.

site_title: Hong Kong-Singapore air travel bubble to start on May 26: sources
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore will announce the start of their highly anticipated two-way air travel bubble on May 26, with flights initially operating quarantine-free between the financial hubs. The agreement, which was delayed due to virus flareups in Hong Kong, will be increased by June 26 if no further outbreaks occur. The resumption of the bubble is expected to unleash pent-up demand for travel, with Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways operating flights under the agreement.

site_title: Hong Kong-Singapore air travel bubble to start on May 26: sources
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore will announce a start to their two-way air travel bubble on May 26, allowing people to travel quarantine-free between the financial hubs. The agreement, delayed multiple times due to virus flareups in Hong Kong, will initially have limited flights, with the number increasing by June 26 if there are no further outbreaks. The resumption of the bubble is seen as a boost to the travel industry, particularly for airlines such as Singapore Airlines and Cathay Pacific Airways, which have been heavily impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Germany pulls virus 'emergency brake' but not all on board
summary: Germany has implemented tougher nationwide COVID-19 measures, including night curfews and school closures, after passing a disputed law to slow infections. The law, dubbed the "emergency brake," applies to regions with high incidence rates, with 8 states exceeding the 165 per 100,000 threshold. The move has sparked protests and criticism, with some parties vowing to take legal action. The new restrictions will affect areas with high infection rates, including major cities like Munich, which may impact the upcoming Euro 2020 football championship.

site_title: EU Athletes concerned by IOC decision to maintain ban on protests
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has maintained its ban on protests during the Tokyo Olympics, sparking concern from the European elite athletes' body, EU Athletes. The decision, which forbids demonstrations or political propaganda, was made after a review of Rule 50, which was deemed incompatible with human rights. EU Athletes criticized the consultation process, claiming it excluded thousands of athletes, and called for the IOC to amend the rule to allow peaceful demonstrations. The Tokyo Olympics begin on July 23, with athletes and stakeholders pushing for a change in the rule.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange's latest report shows that the tanker and dry bulk market has reached rate levels equivalent to last year's highs. Key highlights include:

- Capesize market reached $34,762, with Transatlantic C8 reaching $37,450.
- Fronthaul C16 rates rose to $19,200, with owners demanding premiums for coal routes.
- Panamax rates eased after an FFA sell-off, with EC South America round trips ranging from $26,750 to $23,600.
- Ultramax/Supramax rates were positive, with strong demand in the Asian arena.
- Suezmax and Aframax markets steadied, with some improvements in Northern Europe.
- Charterers dominated the market, exploiting negative sentiment and driving down rates in some segments.
- The market for 280,000mt Middle East to US Gulf trip remained flat at WS19.
- The 30,000mt clean cross Med trade saw higher rates in West Med loaders, while East Med and Black Sea saw slightly higher rates.

site_title: Commercial logic remains for new European league: 'Soccernomics' author
summary: Stefan Szymanski, author of "Soccernomics," says the demand for a European Super League will not disappear despite the UK's review of English football. The 12 elite European clubs' failed attempt to create a closed league has sparked pressure to increase regular matches and address financial issues caused by the pandemic. Szymanski believes mandating fan representation on club boards is a more viable option, but warns that driving out foreign owners could lead to capital flight and long-term consequences. He advocates for a revised European competition that prioritizes sport over the pyramid system.

site_title: Raffles Education receives requisition from Oei Hong Leong to remove Chew Hua Seng from board
summary: Raffles Education Corp has received a requisition from Oei Hong Leong to remove founder Chew Hua Seng from the board, citing improper actions in a share placement and China subsidiaries' operations. The request, made by Oei Hong Leong's firm Hong Leong Art Museum, which owns over 10% of Raffles Education, alleges Chew's unfitness as a director. The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to consider the resolution. This is not the first time allegations have been made, with earlier claims in 2017 and 2020. Raffles Education is seeking legal advice.

site_title: Malaysian PM's approval rating 'stable' amid vaccine rollout
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's approval rating remains stable at 67% in April, according to a Merdeka Center survey. Seventy percent of voters are satisfied with the government's handling of the pandemic, with strong support from the Malay electorate. Despite stressed personal financial conditions and a perception of a struggling economy, the prime minister's rating remains strong. The survey was conducted before a recent spike in COVID-19 cases and ahead of an election that Muhyiddin plans to call once the pandemic is under control.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's approval rating remained stable in the latest survey, with a majority of people polled "satisfied" with the government's handling of the pandemic, according to research house Merdeka Center.

site_title: DBS rolls out new package to set consumers on the path of sustainable living
summary: DBS has launched its DBS Green Solutions package to encourage consumers to adopt sustainable living practices. The package includes a green renovation loan, rebates for switching to green utilities, a green car loan, and rewards for eco-friendly purchases. Customers who take the green renovation loan can receive a preferential rate of 2.68% per annum, while those who install green energy infrastructure can receive rebates of up to S$100. The move aims to reduce DBS's environmental footprint and provide sustainable living solutions, as the company recognizes the urgent need to address climate change.

site_title: Gold erases gains as US data refuels recovery optimism
summary: Gold prices fell amid rising bond yields and strong US economic data, fueling optimism of a global recovery. New-home sales rebounded in March, and output at manufacturers and service providers reached a record high in April. The yield on benchmark 10-year Treasuries is expected to gain for the first time in four days, making gold less attractive. Despite a proposed tax hike by President Biden, investors are not shifting to gold due to limited overlap between stock and gold traders, and instead opting for fixed-income investments.

site_title: Arizona GOP-led election audit by Cyber Ninjas probed by judge
summary: An Arizona judge, Superior Court Judge Christopher Coury, has ordered Cyber Ninjas Inc., the group leading the audit of Maricopa County's 2020 general election results, to disclose internal procedures. The audit, led by Cyber Ninjas CEO Doug Logan, a supporter of the "Stop the Steal" movement, is being challenged by the Arizona Democratic Party, which claims the audit is being conducted by "unqualified and completely unhinged actors." The judge's order comes after the party sued to halt the process, citing concerns over the audit's legitimacy and procedures.

site_title: Perth in three-day lockdown as Australia quarantine tested
summary: Perth, Australia entered a 3-day lockdown after a returned overseas traveler tested positive for Covid-19, despite completing hotel quarantine. Over 2 million people are affected, with authorities racing to contact and test those potentially exposed. The lockdown aims to limit community spread, with New Zealand halting flights from Western Australia. The incident raises concerns about Australia's quarantine system, with the Labor opposition calling for a faster vaccine rollout to mitigate risks. Authorities have asked the federal government to reduce overseas traveler arrivals to ease pressure.

images.alt_text: Australia's fourth-biggest city entered a three-day lockdown on Saturday to prevent the spread of Covid-19 after a returned overseas traveler who'd completed hotel quarantine tested positive for the virus.

site_title: Aspen retracts announcements on Honeywell gloves order
summary: Aspen has withdrawn its US$210 million gloves supply order from Honeywell after the American company failed to sign the agreement by the effective date. The order was for nitrile medical-grade examination gloves, with Aspen set to manufacture and supply the gloves on an original equipment manufacturing basis. The announcement was made after Aspen's subsidiary received written instructions from Honeywell to issue an invoice for the first payment, but the agreement was not signed. Aspen shares had declined 2.13% after the retraction of earlier announcements.

site_title: Dollar falls as yields languish, euro gets extra late-day lift
summary: The US dollar fell 0.5% to 90.8080 against major currencies on Friday, marking a level not seen since early March, as US yields languished. The euro rose 0.7% to US$1.2098, driven by a better-than-expected European purchasing managers' index and a report of 21% new home sales in the US. The dollar index is expected to face downward pressure from the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy review next week.

site_title: India's urban affluent hit by new virus wave after dodging first
summary: India's new wave of Covid-19 infections is disproportionately affecting the urban affluent, with over 600,000 households in sealed buildings in Mumbai and only 164,000 slum households in containment zones. The affluent cities of Mumbai and Pune account for nearly 30% of Maharashtra's active cases. This is partly due to the initial lockdown, which isolated wealthier Indians from the virus, while poorer communities were more severely affected. The spread of the virus among the affluent poses a risk to India's growth, which is heavily reliant on private consumption, and has led to increased pessimism among consumers and calls for government support.

site_title: SoftBank SPAC said to be in talks for Vision Fund-backed Mapbox
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund-backed Mapbox is in talks to go public via a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) overseen by SoftBank Group Corp. The talks are at a valuation of up to $2 billion, with several SPACs involved. Mapbox, which provides mapping tools for companies like Instacart and Snap, aims to challenge Google Maps in the car navigation market. The company has already announced deals with General Motors and BMW, and is expected to reach $100 million in revenue this year. A deal has not been finalized, with negotiations ongoing.

site_title: Diamond stash worth billions sold off after demand roars back
summary: The diamond industry has rapidly sold off its massive stockpile of uncut gems, worth billions of dollars, after demand surged during the pandemic. Top producers De Beers and Alrosa PJSC have seen their inventories dwindle by 60% and 40% respectively, with De Beers selling 13.5 million carats in the first quarter. The industry's rapid turnaround has allowed it to raise prices, with De Beers selling over $1.6 billion in rough gems in its first three sales of 2021. However, risks remain, including potential shortages and a new coronavirus wave in India, which could impact local production.

site_title: The new Cabinet
summary: Singapore has announced a cabinet reshuffle, although no specific details are provided. DPM Gan is set to visit the US for trade talks, aiming to boost bilateral relations. The government has also launched initiatives to support sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, and to aid tariff-hit businesses. Additionally, a centre will be established to advance sustainable aviation, and workers are advised to future-proof their careers.

site_title: More Procurri shareholders come out against Novo Tellus' partial offer
summary: Novo Tellus' partial offer for Procurri Corporation has faced opposition from more shareholders, collectively owning around 8.8% of the company's shares. Key shareholders, including Koh Swee Yong and DeClout, have expressed intention to vote against the offer at 36.5 Singapore cents per share. The offer, launched to acquire 27.9% of Procurri's shares, now appears unlikely to secure necessary shareholder approvals, with more than half of existing shareholders voting against it.

site_title: Q1 retail rent slides in central region; fall expected to moderate further
summary: Singapore's central region retail rents slid 4.4% quarter-on-quarter in Q1, moderating from a 5.2% decline in the prior quarter. Analysts expect further decline as vaccinations ease safe distancing measures and border curbs.

site_title: Singapore core and headline inflation up again in March
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 0.5% in March, its second consecutive month of positive growth, driven by rising energy and petrol prices, surging COE premiums, and foreign worker shortages. Headline inflation was 1.3%, exceeding economists' expectations. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their forecast ranges of 0-1% for core inflation and 0.5-1.5% for headline inflation, with business cost pressures expected to remain contained.

site_title: Hope fades for Indonesian missing submarine as US assists search
summary: Indonesia's search for a missing submarine has faded as hopes dwindle for the 53 crew, expected to run out of oxygen early Saturday. The US is deploying a P-8 Poseidon aircraft to assist the search and rescue operation, with Australia also sending a sonar-equipped warship and helicopter. The submarine, KRI Nanggala-402, lost contact while conducting a torpedo drill in the Bali Sea, with officials investigating if it lost power during a dive. An oil spill was spotted near the last location, but the submarine's remains have yet to be found.

site_title: Europe: Stocks log first weekly drop in eight, Allfunds jumps in debut
summary: European stocks fell for the first time in eight weeks, with the Stoxx 600 slipping 0.2% and on track for a 0.8% weekly drop. The decline was driven by a surge in global coronavirus cases and concerns over US President Joe Biden's plan to raise income taxes. Defensive sectors like healthcare and consumer goods were hit hard, while commodity prices lifted miners. Despite this, about 67% of Stoxx 600 companies have reported strong earnings, and shares in some firms like Allfunds and Tod's rose on the day.

site_title: Free apps: To allow or not to allow? That is the question
summary: A free app may be tempting, but it may also come with a cost of personal data. According to Pixalate's Q3 2020 Mobile Ad Supply: App Safety Report, 70% of apps on the Google Play Store request access to "dangerous permissions" such as precise location, camera, and microphone. Experts warn consumers to be cautious when providing personal data and to read app permissions carefully. If data is compromised, users may have limited recourse, and may need to contact the app developer, financial institutions, or seek legal action.

site_title: Gan Kim Yong to lead MTI, Tan See Leng to helm MOM
summary: Singapore's Cabinet is undergoing a reshuffle, with Gan Kim Yong taking over as Minister for Trade and Industry from Chan Chun Sing, and Tan See Leng moving to head the Ministry of Manpower. The changes take effect on May 15, with Gan overseeing economic recovery from Covid-19 and Tan focusing on worker welfare and job growth. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described Gan as "well-suited" for the role, citing his experience in the private sector and as Health Minister. The moves aim to broaden experience and support businesses in the next phase of recovery and growth.

site_title: Tripartism 2.0 - moving from collaboration to co-creation
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a "company-centric" approach in Singapore's Tripartism 2.0, moving away from an "agency-centric" one. This involves working with companies to understand their unique needs and providing support accordingly. Employers must also transform their operations and reskill workers. The government will refresh industry transformation maps and focus on job redesign, reskilling, and predictive maintenance to equip workers for future challenges.

images.alt_text: Tripartism 2.0 is about moving from collaboration to co-creation said Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat on Friday, during a dialogue at the Singapore National Employers Federation's (SNEF) 40th anniversary event.

site_title: Wall Street starts to see weakness emerge in Bitcoin charts
summary: Bitcoin's recent rally appears to be weakening, with its relative strength index not confirming recent highs and its upward momentum fading. Technical analysts, including Tallbacken Capital Advisors' Michael Purves and JPMorgan Chase & Co strategists, are warning of a potential downturn, citing the coin's failure to break above $60,000 and the collapse of momentum signals. If Bitcoin fails to recover, it could test the $50,000 level, with institutional buyers likely playing a key role in determining the coin's direction.

site_title: Are private equity fund managers up to the job when it comes to predictable, persistent performance?
summary: Private equity fund managers' ability to deliver predictable, persistent performance is disputed due to inconsistent returns and underperformance in many funds. Factors contributing to this include the sector's high cyclical nature and lack of persistence in performance, as past results do not guarantee future outcomes. Over-intermediation, commoditization, and limited diversity among PE professionals also hinder the industry's ability to adapt to changing market conditions, leading to poor risk/return management techniques and inconsistent delivery of top-quartile results.

site_title: Corn, soy extend multi-year highs on tightening global supplies
summary: US corn and soybean futures closed firm on Friday, reaching multi-year highs due to tightening domestic and global supplies. Dryness in Brazil and a US cold spell raised doubts about 2021 corn crops, while Chinese demand for soybeans drove prices up. Futures markets were choppy, with nearby contracts leading the way ahead of the delivery period for Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) May futures. Prices ended modestly higher, with July corn settling up 1 cent at $6.32-1/2 per bushel and July soybeans up 1-3/4 cents at $15.16 a bushel.

images.alt_text: US corn and soybean futures closed firm on Friday after rocketing to multi-year highs this week on tightening domestic and global supplies, traders said.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust's Q1 DPU up 35.7% to 1.353 Singapore cents
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust reported a 35.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.353 Singapore cents for Q1 2021, with gross revenue rising 8.2% to S$31.1 million. The trust attributed the growth to new leases and a strengthening Australian dollar. Distributable income rose 59.3% to S$17.3 million. ARA Logos is optimistic about industrial and logistics transactions, citing Australia's resilient industrial sector and Singapore's strategic location.

site_title: Singapore's contractors association sourcing workers from countries other than India
summary: The Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) has announced plans to source manpower from countries other than India, following the restriction of non-Singaporean residents from India. This move aims to mitigate the impact of the restrictions on construction projects, which could lead to further delays. The association's decision comes as the global construction industry faces challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic and changing labor market dynamics.

images.alt_text: Following the immediate restriction of entry for non-Singaporean residents from India, the Singapore Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) said that it is working progressively to source for manpower from countries other than India.

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile week on positive note
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, ending a volatile week on a positive note, driven by strong new home sales data. New home sales surged 20.7% in March, reaching a 15-year high and surpassing pre-winter storm declines. This data helped offset market weakness, particularly after Thursday's decline due to reports of a potential capital gains tax hike.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks rose Friday to finish a volatile week on a positive note following strong new home sales data.

site_title: Singapore, regional bourses buck Wall St decline
summary: Singapore's regional bourses bucked the decline of Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.2% to 3,194.04. Locally, shares of Top Glove, Medtecs, Riverstone, and UG Healthcare rose 4.8% on average, taking their monthly gain to 21.8%. A major Cabinet reshuffle was announced, with Lawrence Wong becoming Singapore's next Finance Minister. The reshuffle aims to strengthen cohesion among ministers and prepare for a state of emergency in Japan amid a Covid-19 resurgence.

site_title: Japan declares 'short and powerful' emergency in Tokyo, elsewhere
summary: Japan has declared a "short and powerful" state of emergency in Tokyo, Osaka, and two other prefectures from April 25 to May 11 to combat a resurgent coronavirus pandemic. The measures include closing restaurants, bars, and karaoke parlours serving alcohol, and holding big sporting events without spectators. Schools will remain open, and companies are asked to allow people to work from home. The state of emergency affects nearly a quarter of Japan's population and coincides with the "Golden Week" holidays, dealing a blow to the tourism and services industries.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SP Group has agreed to provide Goldbell Group's commercial fleet with electric vehicle charging solutions. Sabana Reit reported a 3.1% positive rental reversion in Q1. OIO Holdings acquired staking provider Moonstake for S$7.1 million. AEM Holdings is set to delist contract manufacturer CEI from the Singapore Exchange due to losing the required free float.

site_title: There's a name for the blah you're feeling: it's called languishing
summary: Languishing, a sense of stagnation and emptiness, is a neglected middle child of mental health characterized by dull motivation, disrupted focus, and reduced productivity. It may be the dominant emotion of 2021, triggered by the emotional long-haul of the pandemic. Named by sociologist Corey Keyes, languishing is the void between depression and flourishing, and may be more common than major depression. Strategies to manage languishing include naming it, finding flow, setting boundaries, and focusing on small goals, to help individuals reclaim their sense of meaning, mastery, and connection.

images.alt_text: Languishing dulls your motivation, disrupts your ability to focus, and triples the odds that you'll cut back on work. It appears to be more common than major depression - and in some ways it may be a bigger risk factor for mental illness.

site_title: France and Singapore: towards achieving sustainable mobility
summary: France and Singapore are collaborating on sustainable mobility, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote digitalization in the transport sector. Both countries have set ambitious targets to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and 2030, respectively. France and Singapore are also exploring the use of advanced technologies, such as artificial intelligence and sustainable fuels, to reduce carbon emissions from air and maritime travel. The two countries have established partnerships to share experiences and expertise in sustainable transport, with a focus on promoting digital and smart infrastructure.

site_title: Welcome to the YOLO economy
summary: The US workforce is experiencing a shift, with many workers, particularly millennials, quitting stable jobs to pursue post-pandemic adventures. This phenomenon, dubbed the "YOLO economy," is characterized by a growing number of people taking risks and pursuing passion projects, driven by rising vaccination rates, a recovering job market, and increased financial cushions. The trend is fueled by a sense of disillusionment with traditional white-collar careers and a desire for work-life balance. Employers are responding with increased offers of raises, time off, and lifestyle allowances to retain employees, but many are choosing to leave the workforce altogether.

site_title: Gold approaches US$1,800 while palladium breaks record to near US$2,900
summary: Gold prices are nearing the US$1,800 an ounce psychological level, driven by a retreat in bond yields and a retreat in the dollar index. Palladium, meanwhile, has surged to a record high of US$2,894, with prices climbing over 17% this year due to rising demand for catalytic converters in emerging economies. The metal has been in a production deficit for 10 years, with supply concerns fueled by issues at Russian mines. The US Federal Open Market Committee meeting next week is expected to strike a more optimistic tone on the economic outlook, but chairman Jerome Powell is likely to emphasize that any policy changes are still some way off.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's Q1 occupancy slips to 90.6%; it achieves positive 3% rental reversion
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 3% positive rental reversion in Q1 lease renewals, but occupancy fell to 90.6% due to non-renewals at two properties in Singapore. Occupancy declined across various markets, including Australia, where it fell to 94.9% from 97.3% in the year-ago period. The Reit completed S$1.2 billion worth of acquisitions and secured S$251.2 million for future developments. Demand in Singapore is expected to remain subdued amid global uncertainties, with the Reit prioritizing a "stronger and profitable portfolio" for the long term.

site_title: Singapore may push envelope as CBDCs gain currency
summary: Singapore may soon launch a commercial multi-currency payment system for digital currencies, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The move comes as interest in central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) grows, with China aiming to be the first major central bank to issue a CBDC. MAS is sharing its experience from the successful Project Ubin, which explored cross-border payments using blockchain and CBDCs, to advance the development of multi-CBDCs.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 7.4% rise in Q1 DPU to 3.57 cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit posted a 7.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.57 cents for its Q1 2021, driven by a 1% increase in net property income to S$28 million. Gross revenue grew 0.4% to S$30 million, with lower property expenses contributing to the increase. The Reit's distributable income rose 7.4% year-on-year to S$21.6 million, excluding one-off Covid-19 relief measures retained in Q1 2020.

site_title: The unusual celebrity of Stephen Hawking
summary: Stephen Hawking, a renowned physicist, was the best-known figure in science from the mid-1980s until his death in 2018. Charles Seife's biography, "Hawking Hawking," provides a full-fledged account of Hawking's life, debunking the misconception that it's a provocative exposé. Hawking was born in 1942 and developed symptoms of ALS at 21, which worsened over time. Despite physical challenges, he continued to produce groundbreaking work, including his theory of Hawking radiation. The book offers a nuanced portrayal of Hawking's life, challenging the idealized image of a transcendent scientist and highlighting the complexities of his personal life and celebrity.

site_title: Sheng Siong to maintain 70% dividend payout ratio; expects 'elevated demand' to taper post pandemic
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, will maintain a 70% dividend payout ratio, with a proposed final dividend of three Singapore cents per share. The company's net profit jumped 84.9% in the fourth quarter, driven by increased demand amid the pandemic. However, CEO Lim Hock Chee expects the "elevated demand" to taper post-pandemic, leading to a decrease in net profit margin to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Singapore private home prices rise in Q1 on strong demand
summary: Singapore private home prices rose 3.3% quarter-over-quarter in Q1 2021, exceeding the 2.1% growth in Q4 2020, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. This is stronger than initial estimates, which suggested a 2.9% gain. The increase is attributed to strong demand in the market, surpassing expectations.

images.alt_text: Partly fuelling the overall price increase was a 6.7 per cent jump for landed properties in the January-March period this year, which more than reversed the 1.6 per cent drop in October-December last year.

site_title: Shoemaker Tod's shares surge as LVMH raises its stake to 10%
summary: Tod's shares surged 16% as LVMH raised its stake to 10% following the French luxury fashion house's purchase of a 6.8% stake from Tod's CEO Diego Della Valle for 74 million euros. The move may prompt speculation of a potential takeover, but Tod's CEO still owns 64% of the company. The Italian shoemaker has struggled with declining revenue and a reliance on European markets. LVMH's acquisition strengthens its partnership with Tod's, which is still in need of a turnaround.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust H1 DPU jumps 28%; it aims to focus on larger malls
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 28.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 5.996 Singapore cents for its first half-year ended March 31, driven by the enlarged retail portfolio post-acquisition of AsiaRetail Fund. The trust aims to focus on larger malls, citing a shift in performance of smaller assets, particularly those without strong residential catchment areas. Gross revenue rose 73.8% to S$173.6 million, and net property income grew 73.8% to S$125.7 million.

site_title: Good cholesterol: facts and fallacy
summary: Recent studies have challenged the long-held notion that raising high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels can reduce the risk of heart disease. Despite elevated HDL levels in some studies, major trials have failed to demonstrate significant benefits on heart complications. In fact, increased HDL removal from cholesterol-laden cells may paradoxically increase heart attack and stroke risk. As a result, physicians are advised to focus on lowering low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol instead of relying on HDL-raising therapies, and to be cautious about the potential benefits of HDL elevation.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas raises US$3b from bond offering
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas raised US$3 billion from a bond offering, exceeding initial expectations by 2.46 times. The 40-year bond tranche was the largest ever issued by a South-east Asian issuer. Petronas aims to refinance debt and use the funds for other corporate purposes. This move comes after the company posted its third consecutive quarterly loss due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which reduced fuel demand. The offering includes US$1.25 billion of 10.75-year and US$1.75 billion of 40-year conventional notes.

site_title: Understanding Integrated Shield changes
summary: Integrated Shield plan changes have sparked debate over rising medical expenses and the need for mitigating financial risk. Policyholders must review their riders to ensure alignment with healthcare expectations and affordability, as full riders will no longer be sold to new buyers. Existing policyholders with full riders must convert to partial riders by policy renewal. A review of riders is crucial to determine the best option, considering factors such as panel doctors, premium costs, and deductibles.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans and Permanent Residents have MediShield Life, which covers large medical bills if they stay either in a B2/C ward of a government/restructured hospital.

site_title: Half of Singapore's ministries to see leadership changes in Cabinet reshuffle effective May 15
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a major Cabinet reshuffle effective May 15, with 7 out of 15 ministries, including finance, trade, and industry, manpower, and health, set to see leadership changes. This is considered a more extensive reshuffle than usual for an early term of government. The new leaders were not announced, but the move is seen as a significant change in the government's leadership structure.

images.alt_text: Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong

site_title: HDB Q1 resale prices up for 4th straight quarter; volume eases
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) reported a 3% increase in the resale price index for Q1 2021, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of price rises. The market sentiment was lifted by the global rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and anticipated economic recovery. Despite a decrease in volume, the resale market remained robust, with prices rising for the fourth quarter in a row.

site_title: Baidu's Jidu Auto to invest 50b yuan in 'robot' smart cars
summary: Jidu Auto, a venture between Baidu and Geely, plans to invest 50 billion yuan (S$10.2 billion) in producing smart cars over the next five years. The company aims to launch its first electric vehicle in three years, targeting young customers with a "robot-like" design. Jidu plans to release new models every one or one-and-a-half years, hire 2,500-3,000 employees, and sell cars directly to customers without dealerships. The investment is part of tech companies' efforts to develop smart cars after Tesla's success in commercializing electric vehicles.

site_title: New Finance Minister Lawrence Wong not likely to rock fiscal-policy boat: observers
summary: Singapore's new Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, who starts his job on May 15, is not expected to significantly loosen the national purse-strings, according to observers. Wong, who previously held the post from 2016, is expected to follow Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's path and maintain fiscal policies unless the pandemic worsens. Wong has expressed a commitment to building on Heng's work while finding ways to finance spending needs sustainably, but the impact of the pandemic and US-China tensions pose challenges to his tenure.

site_title: Super League debacle outshines Mourinho's ouster
summary: The European Super League, a proposed multi-billion-dollar tournament featuring 12 top clubs, collapsed after just 48 hours due to widespread criticism and backlash from fans, players, and other clubs. The plan, which aimed to start in August, was met with outrage after being bypassed by fans who had been barred from stadiums due to the pandemic. The collapse leaves the future of the tournament in tatters, with UEFA considering potential action against the defectors. Meanwhile, Jose Mourinho was sacked by Tottenham Hotspur just days before the Carabao Cup final, marking the fifth time he has been fired as a manager.

site_title: Singapore office rents up 3.3% in Q1 2021
summary: Singapore's office rental market showed a 3.3% quarterly increase in Q1 2021, with average monthly gross effective rents for Grade A CBD office space reaching S$9.78 per square foot. Analysts predict the market may bottom out this year before recovering in 2022, driven by vaccination efforts and economic growth. Despite a 2.7% contraction in office prices in the Central Region, Fringe Area prices rose 5.8% and Central Area prices fell 4%. Net absorption was negative, with a 9,000 sq m decrease in office space, but analysts expect vacancy rates to stabilize and rents to recover in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Singapore PM to attend Asean meeting on Myanmar in Jakarta
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend the Asean meeting in Jakarta on Saturday to discuss the situation in Myanmar, which has affected regional peace and stability. He will be accompanied by the minister for foreign affairs, Vivian Balakrishnan. The Asean leaders will not prioritize Myanmar's election, according to Malaysia.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up amid earnings deluge
summary: US stocks rose early Friday, driven by strong earnings reports, including Intel and Mattel. Despite a strong week of earnings, stocks have been under pressure due to concerns over lofty valuations and rising coronavirus cases. Analysts also cited rising tensions over US tariffs. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, despite tariff threats.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q1 occupancy falls to 90.6%, rental reversion at 3%
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 3% rental reversion in Q1, with a portfolio occupancy of 90.6%, down from 91.7% in the previous quarter. Occupancy in Singapore fell to 86.9% due to non-renewals at two buildings. The decline was attributed to the non-renewals at the TÜV SÜD PSB Building and 138 Depot Road.

site_title: Myanmar troops fire warning shots at boat carrying Thai border officials
summary: Myanmar's military fired warning shots at a Thai border patrol boat near Tha Ta Fung in Mae Hong Son province, amid heightened tensions since the junta seized power nearly three months ago. The incident occurred in a region where thousands of ethnic Karen have fled military air strikes and are sheltering in the jungle on the Myanmar side. Thailand had previously prevented most from entering its territory, with tens of thousands remaining in the jungle.

site_title: Sheng Siong to continue with 70% dividend payout ratio; expects demand to taper post pandemic
summary: Sheng Siong, a supermarket operator, will continue to pay out about 70% of its net profit as dividends, unless operational reasons or major capital expenditures require it. The company expects demand to taper post-pandemic, which may impact its net profit margin, but sees opportunities for growth through innovation and adapting to changing market conditions. Sheng Siong reported an 84.9% jump in net profit for the fourth quarter, with a proposed final dividend of three Singapore cents per share.

site_title: China's demand for luxury goods gets own cargo route
summary: China's luxury goods demand is driving Alibaba's logistics arm, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, to launch direct cargo flights between Singapore and Hainan Island, a move to bolster supply for Chinese shoppers. The first flight will carry duty-free cosmetics and aims to establish a weekly schedule of seven return flights. Cainiao plans to expand routes to other destinations, including Japan and South Korea, as luxury spending in China is expected to continue growing, with Bain & Co. predicting a 48% market growth last year and China on track to claim the biggest share of the luxury goods market by 2025.

site_title: Strong, cohesive leadership must emerge from Cabinet rejig
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has made significant changes to his Cabinet, just nine months after the previous reshuffle. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat has stepped aside as the Prime Minister-in-waiting, and the changes are seen as a clear message that the focus is on keeping Singapore safe amid the pandemic and managing the economic onslaught. The changes aim to put the 4G leadership through the paces of working together cohesively, with Lawrence Wong taking over the Ministry of Finance and Chan Chun Sing moving to the Education Ministry, among other appointments.

site_title: Asean leaders and Myanmar junta chief to attend summit in Jakarta
summary: A summit of Asean leaders, including Myanmar's junta chief, is set to take place in Jakarta, marking the first concerted international effort to ease the crisis in Myanmar following the military coup. Senior General Min Aung Hlaing is expected to attend the meeting, which aims to discuss the situation and prevent further escalation. Analysts say the summit could be the most consequential in Asean's 54-year history, with potential outcomes including a humanitarian mission and a plan for dialogue between the junta and its opponents.

site_title: Singapore to meet emission targets through innovation: PM Lee
summary: Singapore aims to achieve its climate targets through innovation, despite its limited resources. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to quadruple solar energy production by 2025, utilizing the world's largest floating solar energy system, which can offset 33,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide annually. The country is also using technology to adapt to rising urban temperatures, with initiatives such as climate-responsive urban design and special cooling paint on buildings. Singapore's goal is to halve emissions from its 2030 peak by 2050 and achieve net-zero emissions by the second half of the century.

site_title: JPMorgan admits it misjudged backing European Super League
summary: JPMorgan has admitted it misjudged its support for the European Super League, a breakaway soccer competition that collapsed due to widespread protests from fans and politicians. The bank provided a $4.2 billion grant to founding clubs, but eight of the 12 member clubs walked away amid pressure. JPMorgan faced criticism for its role in financing the competition, with fans calling for a boycott of the bank. The bank's corporate sustainability rating was also downgraded by Standard Ethics over its involvement. JPMorgan's boss Jamie Dimon had previously emphasized the need for companies to prioritize workers and communities alongside shareholders.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan said on Friday it regretted supporting soccer clubs in launching a breakaway European Super League after the plan collapsed earlier this week due to a storm of protest from fans and politicians.

site_title: Honda aiming for 100% electric vehicles by 2040
summary: Honda aims to have 100% of its sales comprised of electric and fuel cell vehicles by 2040, as part of its efforts to meet climate goals. The company has set a target of 40% electric vehicle sales by 2030 and 80% by 2035, with a $61.53 billion investment in R&D to achieve the goal. This announcement comes as Japan aims to cut emissions 46% by 2030, surpassing its previous goal of 26% reduction by 2030. The move is in line with international efforts to address climate change and achieve carbon neutrality.

site_title: Bitcoin sinks below US$50,000 as cryptos stumble over Biden tax plans
summary: Bitcoin plummeted below US$50,000, falling 5% to US$48,8867, amid concerns over US President Joe Biden's plan to nearly double capital gains taxes to 39.6% for those earning over US$1 million. Other cryptocurrencies, such as Ether and XRP, also declined by 7%. Investors are booking profits, prompting a sell-off in risk assets. However, some traders and analysts believe the declines are temporary, and bitcoin's long-term prospects remain bullish, with prices potentially increasing again once the current consolidation period ends.

site_title: US new home sales surge 20.7% in March
summary: US new home sales surged 20.7% in March, exceeding expectations and reaching an annualized rate of over 1 million single-family homes, the highest since August 2006. This marked a significant rebound from February's drop caused by winter storms. The median sales price fell to $330,800, its lowest since August 2020. However, economists warn that declining mortgage applications may signal a cooling of the hot housing market.
