images.alt_text: Sales of new homes accelerated last month across most of the United States, jumping 20.7 per cent and more than recovering from the drop caused by winter storms in February.

site_title: US manufacturing activity accelerates in early April
summary: US factory activity accelerated in early April, with IHS Markit's flash US manufacturing PMI rising to 60.6, the highest since 2007. This followed a 59.1 reading in March, exceeding economists' forecasts of 60.5. The increase indicates growth in manufacturing, which accounts for 11.9% of the US economy. The boom in domestic demand, driven by the reopening economy, is leading to supply chain issues as manufacturers struggle to source raw materials and inputs.

images.alt_text: US factory activity powered ahead in early April, but manufacturers increasingly struggled to source raw materials and other inputs as a reopening economy leads to a boom in domestic demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the week higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index up 1.12% to 29,078.75, marking a 0.9% weekly gain. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, ending the week 2.21% and 0.45% higher, respectively. The gains came despite US pressure on high earners and a report on potential tax increases.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q1 DPU rises 16.2% to 2.045 Singapore cents on stronger operational performance
summary: Suntec Reit's first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) rose 16.2% to 2.045 Singapore cents, driven by stronger operational performances, particularly from its office and retail portfolios. The Reit's gross revenue edged up 0.2% and net property income rose 10.2%. The distribution will be paid on May 28, following a record date on May 3. CEO Chong Kee Hiong attributes the strong performance to the resilience of its office portfolio in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: Baidu and Geely plan 50b yuan smart car push
summary: Baidu and Geely's joint venture, Jidu Auto, plans to spend 50 billion yuan (S$10.22 billion) on developing smart car technology over the next five years. The company aims to hire 2,500 to 3,000 staff, including 500 software engineers, and will unveil its branding in the third quarter of 2021. Jidu plans to launch an electric vehicle within three years, designed to appeal to a young clientele, with new models released annually or every 18 months. The move is seen as a significant investment in China's electric vehicle market, with Baidu's autonomous-driving platform, Apollo, expected to give Geely a technology edge.

site_title: Credit Suisse legal woes grow with fresh Greensill complaint
summary: Credit Suisse's legal woes are growing following the collapse of Greensill Capital. Zurich prosecutors received a complaint against "persons unknown" related to the matter, which is currently being evaluated. The complaint is a significant development in Credit Suisse's ongoing issues, as the bank faces scrutiny over its dealings with Greensill. The Zurich Prosecutor's office declined to identify the complainant, citing the use of "persons unknown" in Swiss lawsuits. A formal probe is pending, adding to Credit Suisse's mounting legal challenges.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a Cabinet reshuffle, with Lawrence Wong relinquishing his education portfolio to take over as Minister for Finance. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) may soon launch a commercial multi-currency payment system for digital currencies. Singapore's private home prices rose 3.3% in Q1, while core inflation remained positive in March. The government will refresh industry transformation maps to meet new needs brought by the Covid-19 pandemic. Stocks ended the week in the black, with the STI up 0.2%.

images.alt_text: "Most of the 4G ministers have already accumulated experience in a wide range of portfolios. This round of Cabinet changes will allow them to gain new experience and exposure," said Mr Lee.

site_title: MOF, MTI among 7 key ministries to see changes in Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has announced a Cabinet reshuffle, with 7 key ministries to see changes. Lawrence Wong will take over as Minister for Finance, replacing Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. Gan Kim Yong will become Minister for Trade and Industry, while Ong Ye Kung will replace Gan as Health Minister. Chan Chun Sing will take over as Minister for Education. Other changes include S Iswaran becoming Minister for Transport, Josephine Teo taking over Communications and Information, and Tan See Leng becoming Minister for Manpower. The changes will take effect from May 15.

site_title: Singapore's contractors association sourcing workers from countries other than India
summary: Singapore's Contractors Association Ltd (SCAL) is working to source workers from countries other than India due to the restriction of entry for non-Singaporean residents from India. This move comes as the industry faces a dire labour crunch situation since the Covid-19 pandemic. The restriction is expected to negatively impact construction timelines, causing further delays. The tightening measures will also adversely affect the inflow of construction workers, exacerbating the existing labour shortage in the industry.

site_title: Brokers' Take: DBS upgrades Keppel to 'buy', raises target price
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded Keppel to "buy" and raised its target price to S$6.20, citing encouraging Q1 operating results, a major FPSO contract, and accelerating clean-energy transition into renewables and EVs. Analysts note improvements across segments, with revenue growing 70% and divestment gains totaling approximately S$100 million. The research house also expects Keppel to double its orderbook to S$6 billion with the FPSO contract.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday at 1,608.43, with a 0.70-point gain. The index saw 6.549 billion lots traded worth RM4.189 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 574 to 478.

site_title: Japan declares 'short, powerful' emergency in Tokyo, elsewhere
summary: Japan has declared a "short and powerful" state of emergency in Tokyo, Osaka, and two other prefectures from April 25 to May 11 to combat a resurgent coronavirus pandemic. Restaurants, bars, and karaoke parlours serving alcohol will be required to close, while big sporting events will be held without spectators. The restrictions will also include closing department stores, cinemas, and commercial facilities over 1,000 square meters, and asking companies to allow remote work. The measures aim to limit people's movement and slow the spread of the virus ahead of the Olympics.

site_title: Australia's Perth to enter snap lockdown after second Covid-19 case
summary: Western Australia's capital Perth and the neighbouring Peel region will enter a three-day lockdown from midnight on Friday after two people tested positive for Covid-19, marking the first cases of community transmission in Australia in a week. The lockdown will close most public spaces, including pubs, restaurants, and cinemas, but some sporting events will proceed with mandatory masks. The move comes as Australia has seen a recent spike in cases and has tightened its border controls to prevent further spread.

site_title: Eurozone economy picks up as manufacturing booms
summary: The eurozone economy experienced a manufacturing boom, leading to a strong growth in business activity in April, according to a key survey. The PMI index rose to 53.7 points, the fastest pace since July last year, despite coronavirus restrictions. The manufacturing sector expanded at a record rate, driven by pent-up spending, restocking, and investment. The service sector, however, remained hard hit by lockdown measures, but showed a marginal uptick in some countries. The growth marks a second consecutive month of expansion in business activity after four months of decline.

site_title: After blazing US stock rally, some warn of tougher market ahead
summary: Wall Street's rally has reached fresh records this year, but some prominent analysts are warning of a potential pause or decline in stock returns. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank, and BofA Global Research have expressed concerns about a possible headwind in the market due to expected slower US growth. These predictions have investors weighing whether to lock in gains or continue investing, with some forecasting a 10% pullback in the S&P 500 by year-end.

site_title: Indonesia to restrict foreign travellers from India over Covid-19 variant
summary: Indonesia has decided to restrict foreign travelers from India for 14 days to prevent the spread of Covid-19 variants. The decision comes after a chartered flight from Chennai carrying 129 people, including 12 who tested positive for Covid-19, arrived in Indonesia. Foreigners who have visited India in the past 14 days will not be issued visas, while those arriving from India will be allowed to enter but must follow stricter health protocols and quarantine. This measure aims to curb the spread of the virus in Indonesia, which has seen over 1.62 million cases and 44,000 deaths.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap four-week winning run, gold stocks lose shine
summary: Australian shares ended the day 0.08% higher, snapping a four-week winning streak, but recorded their first weekly loss in five. The S&P/ASX 200 closed at 7,060.70 points. US stocks declined overnight due to reports of a possible capital gains tax hike. Rising coronavirus cases in major economies dented hopes of a global economic rebound, affecting Australian equities. Gold stocks fell 0.4%, with Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources losing 0.9% and 1% respectively.

site_title: India reports world's highest infection tally for second day
summary: India reported a record 332,730 new coronavirus infections and 2,263 deaths on April 23, surpassing the US daily tally for the first time. The surge has overwhelmed the country's healthcare system, with many hospitals running out of oxygen and ICU beds. The government has met with state officials to discuss the crisis, while experts criticize the government for lifting restrictions too soon and not doing enough to vaccinate the population. The country's vaccination campaign has only reached a tiny fraction of its population, with less than 1.5% vaccinated.

site_title: Google, Amazon spent millions lobbying while facing bipartisan scrutiny
summary: Google and Amazon spent millions on lobbying in the first quarter of 2021, amid heightened scrutiny from Democrats and Republicans over alleged anticompetitive practices. Google increased lobbying by 49% to $2.7 million, while Amazon boosted its spending by 11% to $4.8 million, a company record. The increased lobbying comes as technology giants face antitrust complaints and bipartisan calls for sweeping reforms, with lawmakers like Senator Amy Klobuchar introducing legislation to punish companies for anticompetitive behavior.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip in early trade
summary: European stock markets declined in early trading on Friday, ending the week on a downbeat note. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.4% to 6,912.55 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices retreated 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. The decline followed a subdued performance in Asia. The week's losses were largely attributed to uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of virus state of emergency
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.57% lower on Friday, ahead of Japan's new virus state of emergency for the capital and other areas. The Nikkei 225 index fell 167.54 points to 29,020.63, while the Topix index slipped 7.52 points to 1,914.98. The move follows recent concerns over the country's COVID-19 situation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log first weekly loss in five
summary: South Korean stocks logged their first weekly loss in five, falling 0.39% as investors considered domestic coronavirus spikes and US capital tax increases. The Kospi rose 8.58 points to 3,186.10, with technology giant Samsung Electronics up 0.49% and LG Chem up 0.34%. Foreigners were net sellers of 26.4 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi has risen 10.88% so far this year, but the US tax hike issue was short-lived as it faces hurdles before implementation.

site_title: Two community infections among 39 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: There were 39 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, bringing the total to 60,943. Two cases were community infections, and one was from migrant workers' dormitories. The remaining 36 cases were imported, including 16 permanent residents and six foreign domestic workers. The Ministry of Health reported no hospitalizations.

site_title: Singapore stocks end the week in the black; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's main index, the STI, rose 0.2% to close at 3,198.42, ending the week in positive territory. Regional indices also followed suit, with the Kospi up 0.27% and the Hang Seng index advancing 1.12%. In contrast, Japan's Nikkei 225 Index fell 0.57% due to a state of emergency amid a Covid-19 resurgence. The gains were largely driven by market resilience despite US capital gain tax proposals and new Trump threats.

site_title: Duterte's daughter stays top in poll on Philippine president candidates
summary: Davao city mayor Sara Duterte-Carpio, the daughter of Philippine leader Rodrigo Duterte, has topped the latest opinion poll on preferred presidential candidates with 27% of the vote. Despite her father's public opposition and her own denial of running, the poll shows she remains the front-runner. Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr. is in second place, followed by Senator Grace Poe, Manila city mayor Francisco "Isko Moreno", and global boxing icon Senator Manny Pacquiao. The election is over a year away, and analysts note that the outcome could change significantly before the May 9 polls.

site_title: Frantic hunt for Indonesian submarine as rescuers hone in on signal
summary: Indonesia's search for a missing submarine with 53 crew members intensified as rescuers narrowed in on a signal from an unidentified object, with just hours to go before the vessel's oxygen reserves ran out. The US and Australia joined the search, and ships equipped with tracking equipment were deployed to locate the KRI Nanggala 402. Concerns over possible fuel-tank damage and the risk of carbon dioxide buildup from damaged equipment raised fears of a deadly disaster, with hopes of finding the crew alive fading fast.

site_title: Tan See Leng becomes Manpower Minister in Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Tan See Leng, 56, will become Manpower Minister in Singapore's Cabinet reshuffle, effective May 15. He will take on the full range of responsibilities from current Minister Josephine Teo, who moves to the Ministry of Communications and Information. This change aims to connect the work of the economic ministries, particularly on restructuring the economy and workforce. Tan See Leng, a healthcare industry veteran and Second Minister for Manpower and Trade, has led efforts to tackle Covid-19 in migrant worker dorms.

site_title: Gan Kim Yong to become Minister for Trade and Industry; Chan Chun Sing goes to MOE
summary: Singapore's Cabinet has announced a reshuffle, with Gan Kim Yong becoming Minister for Trade and Industry, replacing Chan Chun Sing, who will move to the Ministry of Education. Gan, who has been Health Minister since 2011, will oversee economic recovery and growth. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Gan's experience in handling the Covid-19 pandemic and his suitability for the trade ministry role. The changes take effect on May 15.

images.alt_text: Health Minister for Gan Kim Yong will become Minister for Trade and Industry with effect from May 15.
Chan Chun Sing becomes Minister for Education in the new Cabinet line-up announced on Friday.

site_title: US CDC probes new death, hospitalisation after J&J vaccine shots: officials
summary: The US CDC is investigating two incidents: the death of an Oregon woman and hospitalization of another in Texas, both after receiving Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine. Advisers are set to meet to consider whether to resume J&J injections, while senior health officials prepare for a potential green light. Officials emphasize that reported incidents do not necessarily mean they were caused by the vaccine.

site_title: Lawrence Wong to take over as Finance Minister, will let go of education portfolio
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will step down as Finance Minister on May 15, with Lawrence Wong taking over the role. Wong, who will relinquish his Education portfolio, has experience as Second Minister since 2016 and is seen as a natural fit for the job. The change is expected to bring continuity to the PAP administration's track record with foreign investors, but may also pose challenges due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and geopolitical uncertainties.

site_title: Luxury giant LVMH boosts stake in Italian shoemaker Tod's to 10%
summary: LVMH, the luxury French fashion house, has increased its stake in Italian shoemaker Tod's to 10% after CEO Diego Della Valle sold 6.8% of his shares to the company. The move may fuel speculation of a potential takeover. Tod's shares rose over 20% after appointing Chiara Ferragni as a director, aiming to revamp the brand and attract younger customers. The acquisition comes as LVMH gains market share in the wake of the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia's March CPI rises 1.7% y-o-y, higher than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.7% in March, exceeding the 1.4% forecast by economists. The increase was driven by higher prices for transportation, food, and non-alcoholic beverages. Housing and utilities, as well as clothing and footwear, saw subdued price growth. This marks the first time inflation has grown in a year since February, when it rose 0.1%. The data suggests Malaysia's inflation is on the rise, potentially impacting the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Australia man contracts Covid-19 after finishing two-week quarantine
summary: A man in Australia tested positive for Covid-19 after completing a two-week hotel quarantine in Perth, raising concerns about community transmission. Genomic sequencing is underway to identify the source. All passengers on a flight from Perth to Melbourne have been asked to self-isolate after the infected person traveled to Melbourne. Australia's hotel quarantine system has helped keep Covid-19 numbers low, but the country is tightening border controls and investigating cases of travelers contracting the virus from infected guests.

site_title: Phillip Capital Management names ESG head, looks to boost ethical portfolio offerings
summary: Phillip Capital Management appoints Stephen Beng as its first head of ESG strategy, aiming to boost ethical portfolio offerings. The move follows a surge in ESG-related fund trading activities, with assets under management crossing S$500 million. The firm plans to introduce ESG-focused portfolios, starting with wrapping the UK-based ethical portfolios and bringing them to accredited investors in Singapore. CEO Linus Lim emphasizes the need for investor education and greater ESG standardization in the region.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle for direction after US tax hike reports
summary: Asian markets struggled for direction on Friday after US tax hike reports, with 10-year US Treasury yields and the greenback affected. The news sent jitters through digital currency markets, with Bitcoin dipping below $50,000. Despite losses in Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney, Hong Kong saw gains, and Shanghai and Seoul posted modest gains. Analysts expect any tax plan to be short-lived, with oil benchmarks seeing a slight rise after a two-day slump.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit by US capital tax doubling plan
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined due to US President Joe Biden's plan to nearly double capital gains tax on wealthy Americans, spooking investors and driving them to safe-haven assets. The Australian dollar fell to a one-week low of US$0.7693, while the New Zealand dollar dropped to US$0.7151, its lowest level since April 19. The moves reflect reduced risk appetite and increased demand for US dollars, Japanese yen, and Treasuries.

site_title: Tesla releases data logs of China car crash after viral protest
summary: Tesla has released the data logs of a car crash in China, which occurred after a woman staged a viral protest claiming the vehicle's brakes had failed. The data shows the car was traveling at 118.5 km/h before impact and slowed to 48.5 km/h after the brakes were applied, with the driver braking over 40 times in the half-hour before the crash. The incident has sparked a dispute between Tesla and the woman, with the company releasing the data logs after a market regulator ordered it to do so.

site_title: Financial firms say they all want to be sustainable, but ask how they compare with peers: study
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore express a desire to be sustainable, but lack clarity on how they compare to peers. A study by SGX RegCo, NUS Business School, and KPMG Singapore found that 14 key financial institutions surveyed want to harmonize reporting standards for environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) performance. The report emphasizes the need for continued efforts to standardize reporting globally and locally, with one key recommendation being the establishment of a standard calculation method for ESG performance.

site_title: Gold set for third straight weekly gain as US yields, dollar pull back
summary: Gold prices rose for a third straight week, driven by a softer US dollar, falling Treasury yields, and a dip in equities. Spot gold increased 0.2% to $1,787.11 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.4%. The dollar index fell 0.1% against its rivals, making gold cheaper for other currency holders. US President Joe Biden's proposal to hike capital gains tax also encouraged investors to buy gold.

site_title: Transformation roadmaps will be refreshed to meet new needs: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's government will refresh its industry transformation maps (ITMs) to meet the accelerated changes brought by Covid-19. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced this at the 40th anniversary event of the Singapore National Employers Federation, stating that ITM 2025 will be complemented by the Emerging Stronger Taskforce. The government aims to transform the economy, reskill workers, and train students, with a focus on redesigning jobs and upskilling workers to adapt to the post-Covid-19 world.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB, DBS, UOBKH start coverage on Aztech Global on expected IoT growth
summary: Brokerages CGS-CIMB, DBS, and UOBKH have initiated coverage on Aztech Global with "buy" or "add" ratings and target prices of S$1.91, S$1.85, and S$1.86, respectively. The companies expect Aztech to benefit from the growing IoT market, with Frost & Sullivan predicting a 20.8% CAGR to reach US$425.2 billion by 2023. Aztech's average net margins are already above industry average, and the brokerages forecast significant revenue growth and profit expansion for the company.

site_title: Singapore may push envelope as CBDCs gain currency
summary: Singapore may soon launch a commercial multi-currency payment system for digital currencies, following the success of its Project Ubin. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is contributing its learnings from Project Ubin to design and develop new models for cross-border settlements. MAS is partnering with the BIS Innovation Hub and central banking community on Project Dunbar, which aims to create a regional multi-currency settlement platform. The project's initial focus will be on defining the digital currency stack and layers, with the goal of making cross-border payments cheaper, faster, and safer.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust says strategy will focus on larger malls
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) plans to focus on larger malls as part of its portfolio management strategy, according to its CEO Richard Ng. The trust has announced plans to divest YewTee Point and has seen a 28.4% increase in distribution per unit and 73.8% growth in gross revenue for the first half of FY21. Despite shopper traffic being "slightly lagging", tenant sales have recovered to near pre-Covid-19 levels. FCT's new code of conduct for leasing retail premises aims to consolidate and adapt its portfolio.

site_title: Bank of Japan will set guidelines when time comes to sell ETFs, says Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the bank will establish guidelines for selling exchange-traded funds (ETFs) when inflation approaches its 2% target. This decision aims to avoid losses and stabilize financial markets. Kuroda emphasized that it's premature to discuss an early exit from ultra-loose monetary policy, but the bank will consider various options, including selling ETFs to households. The BOJ's massive holdings of ETFs have raised concerns about market distortion and asset loading. A policy-setting meeting will deliberate on the timing and means of selling ETFs.

site_title: Singapore's core, headline inflation continue to rise in March
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 0.5% in March, up from 0.2% in February, while headline inflation increased to 1.3%, exceeding economists' expectations of 0.4% and 1.2%. The increase was driven by rising energy and petrol prices, as well as surging COE premiums. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their forecast ranges of 0-1% for core inflation and 0.5-1.5% for headline inflation. Despite concerns about inflation risks, experts expect benign inflation risks for the rest of the year due to slow wage growth and contained business cost pressures.

site_title: SP Group to make EV charging network available to Goldbell's commercial fleet
summary: SP Group has agreed to provide Goldbell Group's commercial fleet with its electric vehicle (EV) charging solutions, including installing EV charging infrastructure on Goldbell's premises. The partnership will also extend SP Group's charging points to BlueSG users once Goldbell completes its acquisition of the EV-sharing company, valued between S$20 million and S$25 million. The deal is expected to be completed by August this year.

site_title: HDB resale prices climb for 4th consecutive quarter; volume dips
summary: HDB resale prices rose 8.1% year-on-year to 142.2, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of increases, driven by Covid-19 vaccine optimism and a supply-demand imbalance. Despite a 0.8% dip in resale volume, prices rose in 22 of 26 HDB towns, with median resale prices reaching S$910,000 in central areas. The number of approved rental HDB flat applications increased 26% year-on-year, while BTO flats will be launched in August with a completion period likely to remain long due to construction delays.

images.alt_text: Prices of HDB resale flats rose for the fourth consecutive quarter even as fewer flats changed hands.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust DPU up 35.7% to 1.353 S cents for Q1
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust reported a 35.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.353 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by the commencement of new leases and a strengthening Australian dollar. Gross revenue rose 8.2% to S$31.1 million, while net property income increased 8.7% to S$23.9 million. The trust expects industrial and logistics transactions to continue growing in 2021, driven by demand for warehouse space.

site_title: Xi's next target in tech crackdown is China's vast reams of data
summary: China is cracking down on its tech giants, aiming to control massive data holdings as part of a broader plan to transform its economy. President Xi Jinping's crackdown on platforms like Alibaba and Tencent comes after a record $2.8 billion fine was imposed on Alibaba for market dominance. China is pouring money into digital infrastructure and drafting new laws on data usage, with the goal of positioning itself as a leader in the global economy. The government is exploring ways to get companies to share key data, with some analysts suggesting nationalizing data or becoming co-investors.

images.alt_text: As President Xi Jinping targets China's massive tech giants, the big question now is how he'll get them to share key data as part of a sweeping plan to transform the world's second-biggest economy.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts Q1 DPU of 1.22 pence, slightly above forecast
summary: Elite Commercial Reit posted a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.22 pence, slightly above forecast, with £4.5 million in income available for distribution. Revenue rose 15.1% to £6.6 million, driven by £864,000 from newly acquired properties. The Reit's portfolio now has 155 properties, all fully occupied. CEO Shaldine Wang aims to maintain stable income flow through diversification and yield-accretive acquisitions, with units trading 0.8% higher at 67 pence.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher after US tax hike reports
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.15% in morning trade on Friday, driven by reports of a potential US tax hike on high earners. The Hang Seng Index opened at 28,798.45, while mainland Chinese stocks were little moved. The US stock market had closed at record highs earlier in the week but edged down amid tariff threats. Despite this, Asian markets seemed to brush off the news, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.07 points, or 0.07%, to 1,606.66. Losers beat gainers 211 to 180, and volume reached 352.79 million lots worth RM211.67 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares unchanged as miners, energy stocks offset gains in banks
summary: Australian shares were largely unchanged on Friday, ending a four-week winning streak, as miners and energy firms offset gains in banks and healthcare companies. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,053.90, down 0.2% for the week. Miners BHP and Rio Tinto fell 1.8%, while energy firms shed 0.6%. Financial stocks edged higher, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank gaining 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Delta plans to buy 25 Airbus planes amid expected travel rebound
summary: Delta Air Lines announced plans to buy 25 Airbus A321neo aircraft and accelerate deliveries of three other planes, citing an expected rebound in travel demand as Covid-19 ebbs. The deal, worth billions, aims to address Delta's carbon footprint and increase efficiency, with new planes to be delivered in 2022. The move follows a quarterly loss for Delta, but the carrier expects to return to profitability later this year as travel demand rises.

site_title: Japan's factory activity improves in April but more virus measures loom
summary: Japan's factory activity expanded at its fastest pace in over three years in April, with the manufacturing sector showing significant growth. The au Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing PMI rose to 53.3, surpassing the 50.0 threshold for the third consecutive month. However, the service sector contracted for a 15th month, with expected coronavirus emergency measures looming. The country's economy is likely to face challenges from the surge in Covid-19 cases and new emergency curbs.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices extend falls, cellphone bill cuts to weigh ahead
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.1% in March, the eighth consecutive month, due to cellphone fee cuts and a rebound in gasoline costs. Analysts expect further drops ahead, putting pressure on the central bank to maintain stimulus. The government's plan to declare a third state of emergency may also weigh on inflation. Cellphone fee cuts are expected to push down the core index by up to 0.6% points, potentially hampering the BOJ's efforts to boost inflation. Japan's economy is expected to contract in January-March and rebound modestly in the current quarter.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas raises US$3b from bond offering
summary: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas raised US$3 billion from a bond offering to refinance debt and for other corporate purposes, exceeding the initial offer size by 2.46 times. The 40-year bond tranche was the largest ever by a Southeast Asian issuer. Petronas has been impacted by the coronavirus pandemic, posting its third quarterly loss in a row, and the offering aims to support the company's debt management. The bonds were priced at 92.5 basis points over the 10-year US Treasury yield for the 10.75-year note and 115 basis points over the 30-year US Treasury for the 40-year note.

site_title: Hollywood set for pandemic-era Oscars, with 'Nomadland' out front
summary: The 93rd Academy Awards, held at Los Angeles' Union Station, will feature a transformed ceremony due to the pandemic, with a large footprint and social distancing measures. "Nomadland" is expected to dominate the night, with director Chloe Zhao a "total lock" for best director and the film likely to win best picture. Netflix is expected to win the most prizes, including best documentary for "My Octopus Teacher." The ceremony will be pared back, with a strict guest list and reduced red carpet, but will feature a unique aesthetic and movie-like production.

site_title: Singapore retail rents decline in Q1, vacancy eases to 8.5%: URA
summary: Singapore's retail rents declined 4.4% in Q1, moderating from a 5.2% drop in the prior quarter. The central region saw a 18.4% decline since 2020, while the suburban segment remained resilient. Vaccination rollout and Phase 3 re-opening supported occupier demand, easing the retail rental decline. The island-wide vacancy rate eased to 8.5% in Q1, with retail prices and rents in the fringe area performing better than the central area. Analysts expect further moderation in retail rents as more employees return to work and footfall in the CBD increases.

site_title: Japan says to seek 'short, powerful' state of emergency for Tokyo, elsewhere
summary: Japan's government is seeking a "short and powerful" state of emergency for Tokyo, Osaka, and two other prefectures from April 25 to May 11 to combat a resurgent pandemic ahead of the Olympics. The measures include closing restaurants, bars, and karaoke parlours, canceling big sporting events, and limiting people's movement. Department stores and companies are also asked to close and allow work-from-home. The state of emergency aims to limit the spread of the pandemic and avoid an explosive outbreak, with the goal of limiting the movement of people and staying home.

site_title: Sabana Reit reports higher occupancy rates, positive rental reversions
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 3.1% positive rental reversion in the first quarter, with portfolio occupancy reaching 79% at the end of March, up from 76.5% at year-end 2020. The Reit manager also noted that 57% of expiring leases have been renewed or replaced with new ones. Despite the positive news, Sabana Reit's units fell 1.1% or 0.5 cents to 43 cents. The Reit manager is still searching for two independent directors to replace outgoing board members.

site_title: Japan rolls out vaccine slowly, despite looming Olympics
summary: Japan has fully vaccinated less than 1% of its population three months before hosting the Olympics, due to a slow rollout driven by caution and bureaucratic hurdles. Olympic organisers and local officials stress that vaccines are not a prerequisite for the Games, and participants will not be required to be inoculated. The slow rollout weighs on public opinion, highlighting concerns about Japan's preparedness for the event.

site_title: Japan PM's push for higher minimum wage faces uphill battle amid pandemic
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's plan to raise the minimum wage to 1,000 yen (S$12.30) an hour faces opposition from small and midsize firms worried about their survival during the COVID-19 pandemic, and from lawmakers in his ruling party concerned of a potential backlash. Smaller firms, which employ seven out of ten workers in Japan, have lobbied to scrap the plans, citing the timing as bad. The government aims to boost competitiveness and spur inflation, but policymakers acknowledge the potential economic impact.

site_title: Third Procurri shareholder comes out against Novo Tellus' partial offer
summary: Novo Tellus' partial offer for Procurri Corporation has received opposition from three substantial shareholders, including Koh Swee Yong, who owns 5.9% of Procurri's shares. DeClout and ICH Gemini also intend to vote against the offer. The offer aims to acquire an additional 27.9% of Procurri's shares, but needs more than 35.7% of independent shareholders to vote in favour. With three shareholders opposing the offer, a total of 31% of Procurri shareholders are now voting against the offer, leaving the outcome uncertain.

site_title: Netflix dominates cultural conversation from Mumbai to Rio
summary: Netflix dominates global cultural conversation, with its original series such as "The Queen's Gambit," "Cobra Kai," and "Money Heist" earning fans worldwide. The platform's ability to create pop culture moments, like "Tiger King," has been proven, and it continues to churn out hit shows, focusing on emerging markets and diverse viewpoints. With its vast subscriber base of 207 million, Netflix has a competitive advantage in the streaming universe, using data to understand viewership patterns and shape content decisions.

site_title: Rents of Singapore office space rise in Q1, vacancy rate ticks upwards: URA
summary: Singapore's office rental market showed a 3.3% quarter-on-quarter increase in Q1 2021, reversing a 3.5% contraction in Q4 2020. The average monthly gross effective rent for Grade A CBD office space rose to S$9.78 per square foot, while prices in the fringe area increased 5.8% and those in the central area fell 4%. Despite a 2.7% contraction in central region prices, the island-wide vacancy rate edged up to 11.9% due to falling net absorption. Analysts project the office rental market will bottom out this year before recovering in 2022.

site_title: Intel PC chip sales rise, but profit forecast falls short on manufacturing costs
summary: Intel Corp raised its annual sales outlook on booming demand for personal computers, but its second-quarter profit forecast fell short of analyst expectations due to manufacturing costs. The company reported $10.6 billion in PC chip sales in the first quarter, beating analyst estimates. However, Intel's profit forecast was below expectations, with the company investing heavily in new manufacturing technologies. Despite this, Intel's CEO, Patrick Gelsinger, expressed confidence in the company's ability to gain market share and beat its guidance for the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Biden tax hike reports
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday after US reports of considering a tax hike on the wealthy led to a Wall Street downturn. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.12% and the Topix index declined 0.70%. The decline followed a previous day's record-breaking close on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday after Wall Street tumbled following reports the US administration is considering a tax hike on the wealthy.

site_title: Singapore private home prices rise 3.3% in Q1 on 'extremely strong' demand
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 3.3% in Q1 2021, the largest quarterly increase since Q2 2018, driven by strong demand from both domestic and foreign buyers. The uptrend has lasted four consecutive quarters, with landed properties seeing a 6.7% jump and non-landed homes increasing by 2.5%. Resale volumes rose 6.4%, and rents of private homes gained 2.2% quarter-over-quarter. Analysts predict prices could increase by up to 5% this year, with a focus on luxury and city-fringe projects.

images.alt_text: Non-landed private homes became 2.5 per cent pricier in the first quarter this year, a tad slower than the 3 per cent rise in the fourth quarter last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Top Glove, Procurri, Procurri, AEM, Suntec Reit
summary: Keppel Corporation posted a 1.7% revenue increase to S$1.89 billion for its first quarter. Top Glove plans to sell 793.5 million new shares to raise HK$7.94 billion (S$1.36 billion). Procurri Corporation received a letter opposing Novo Tellus' offer, and AEM Holdings acquired 26.6% of a South Korean company for US$3.8 million. Suntec Reit increased its Q1 distribution by 16.2% to 2.045 Singapore cents, while iFast Corporation posted a record net profit of S$8.8 million.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit posts 7.4% rise in Q1 DPU to 3.57 S cents
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 7.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.57 Singapore cents for its Q1 2021, driven by higher rent contributions from a nursing home and increased rent from Singapore properties. Gross revenue and net property income grew 0.4% and 1% respectively, while distributable income increased 7.4% to S$21.6 million. The Reit's gearing levels remained stable at 37.8% and its interest coverage ratio stood at 20.9 times, with 85% of interest rate exposure hedged.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower in tandem with Wall Street; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% in early trade on Friday, following Wall Street's decline, amid reports of a potential steep increase in capital gain taxes on wealthy individuals. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 11.69 points to 3,176.09. Losers outnumbered gainers 74 to 48, with 58.3 million securities worth S$62.7 million changing hands.

site_title: Airlines hope for speedy fix to latest Boeing 737 MAX issue
summary: US regulators are working with Boeing to address an electrical problem affecting over 100 737 MAX planes, grounding them temporarily. The issue, described as an electrical bonding and grounding problem, has not significantly impacted airlines due to low travel volume. Airlines, including Southwest and American, expressed hope for a speedy resolution, with Southwest CEO Gary Kelly stating that the problem needs to be fixed quickly to avoid any consequences. The FAA aims to issue an airworthiness directive in a matter of weeks to resolve the issue.

site_title: Oil steady as Libya output decline offsets risks to Asian demand
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Thursday, with Brent futures rising 8 cents to $65.40 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 8 cents to $61.43 a barrel. Libya's oil production fell to about 1 million barrels per day due to budgetary issues, offsetting concerns over rising energy demand in India and Japan. However, analysts expect Iran to provide additional oil supply if a nuclear deal is reached, potentially impacting global production.

site_title: Facebook wants users' responses to improve feeds
summary: Facebook plans to prioritize posts based on user feedback, asking users if messages are "worth their time" to improve its News Feed ranking process. The move aims to address concerns over the platform's opaque algorithms, which critics say may prioritize sensational or divisive content. Facebook has been de-emphasizing political content and giving users more control over their feeds, following an internal review of its handling of the January 6 Capitol riot. The company will incorporate user feedback into its algorithm to provide a more complete picture of valuable content.

site_title: ECB keeps policy unchanged, sees scope for rebound
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept interest rates unchanged as expected, maintaining copious stimulus to support the euro area economy through its recession. ECB President Christine Lagarde expects a firm rebound in economic activity this year as Covid-19 infections decline and vaccination rates increase. The bank will review its massive bond purchases in June, potentially slowing purchases and allowing borrowing costs to rise, but will be data-dependent in its decision.

site_title: Going Green
summary: On Earth Day, Singapore's businesses are making a commitment to sustainability. Local companies like Forest & Whale, Crunch Cutlery, and Gin Lee Make are working on reducing waste and promoting eco-friendly practices. Forest & Whale's Reuse Lab project uses compostable and edible materials for food packaging, while Crunch Cutlery offers edible cutlery alternatives. Gin Lee Make uses sustainable materials and production methods to minimize waste. Meanwhile, Lion Brewery Co offsets its carbon impact by reforestation and partners with Green Steps Group to monitor tree growth. Other companies, such as aquama and Sigi Skin, are also adopting sustainable practices, including using biodegradable cleaning solutions and waterless skincare products.

site_title: Myanmar summit a test for Asean's credibility: Thailand
summary: A weekend summit on the Myanmar coup crisis will test Asean's credibility and unity as leaders and foreign ministers from the 10-country Association of Southeast Asian Nations gather in Jakarta on Saturday. At least 739 people have been killed, and 250,000 displaced, since the military coup ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi in February. The summit comes amid escalating death toll and international condemnation, with China urging a "soft landing" for the country. Asean countries face pressure to deliver concrete outcomes and may consider expelling Myanmar from the bloc if the situation doesn't improve.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on worries over tax hike proposal
summary: US stocks plummeted 0.9% on Thursday, closing at 33,815.90, after reports emerged that the Biden administration is planning to propose a significant increase in capital gains taxes on wealthy individuals. The proposed tax rate would rise from 20% to 39.6% for those earning over $1 million. Despite strong corporate earnings and low unemployment claims, the market was spooked by the tax hike reports, which analysts said could lead to a long process on Capitol Hill.

site_title: US sends aircraft to aid in Indonesia submarine search
summary: The US military will send airborne teams to aid Indonesia in searching for a missing submarine, KRI Nanggala 402, with 53 sailors on board. The submarine disappeared during exercises off the coast of Bali on Wednesday. The US Defence Department expressed "deep sadness" over the incident and offered support to the Indonesian sailors and their families.

site_title: Stronger operational performance boosts Suntec Reit Q1 DPU by 16.2% to 2.045 S cents
summary: Suntec Reit's Q1 DPU increased by 16.2% to 2.045 Singapore cents, driven by stronger operational performance. Gross revenue rose 0.2% to S$87.1 million, and net property income increased 10.2% to S$59.5 million. Occupancy rates for its Singapore and retail portfolios were 96.1% and 91.5%, respectively. The Reit manager expects office portfolio revenue to remain stable, while retail portfolio revenue is expected to recover to 80% of 2019 levels by year-end.

site_title: India logs record new infections as Europe hopes peak may be over
summary: India has recorded a record 315,000 new coronavirus cases, the highest daily total since the pandemic began, attributed to a "double mutant" variant and super-spreader events. European countries, including the UK and UAE, have imposed travel restrictions on India due to concerns over the variant. Meanwhile, some European nations, such as France, are easing restrictions and hoping the peak of the third wave has passed. Vaccination programs are picking up speed, with Germany set to open vaccinations to all adults in June and Germany and Russia in talks to buy 30 million doses of the Sputnik V vaccine.

site_title: UK reports 32 deaths from clots after AstraZeneca jabs
summary: The UK's medicines regulator reported 168 people have suffered rare blood clots after taking the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine, resulting in 32 deaths. The cases, up to April 14, represent a rise in deaths and cases compared to the previous period. The regulator stated that the benefits of the vaccine outweigh the risks in the majority of people, but the UK government has offered an alternative vaccine to those under 30 due to concerns over blood clots.

images.alt_text: A total of 168 people have suffered rare blood clots after taking the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine in Britain, and 32 have died, the UK's medicines regulator said Thursday.

site_title: Manhattan retail rents extend slide, showing Covid's full impact
summary: Manhattan retail rents continued to decline in the first quarter, with Soho experiencing a 20% drop to $279 per square foot. Luxury retailers' recent leases failed to fill vacant space, with 30% of Soho's retail space available. Other areas, like Lower Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, saw rents decline over 15%. The pandemic's impact is evident, with ongoing social distancing measures and a lack of tourists and office workers hindering sales. Landlords are adjusting rents downward to spur leasing.

site_title: Tesla can be fooled into unmanned driving: report
summary: A report by Consumer Reports found that Tesla's Autopilot system can be easily tricked into driving without a person behind the wheel, posing extreme danger on public roads. Democratic Senators Richard Blumenthal and Ed Markey have urged US auto safety regulators to investigate a recent fatal crash involving a Tesla with no one in the driver's seat. The incident has raised concerns about the safety of Tesla's autonomous driving technology.

site_title: Canada bans passenger flights from India, Pakistan for 30 days
summary: Canada has suspended all passenger flights from India and Pakistan for 30 days due to increased Covid-19 cases detected in travelers from these countries. The measure, announced by Transportation Minister Omar Alghabra, will not apply to cargo flights, ensuring the continued shipment of essential goods. The decision comes as India reports a single-day high of over 300,000 new cases, while Canada has seen a high percentage of positive tests linked to flights from India, accounting for 50% of all positive cases at the border.

images.alt_text: Canada suspended all passenger flights from India and Pakistan on Thursday for 30 days, Transportation Minister Omar Alghabra announced, citing increased Covid-19 cases detected in travelers arriving from these countries.

site_title: Citi veteran on the art of building a relationship
summary: Citi Private Bank chairman Lee Lung-Nien, a 30-year veteran, emphasizes the importance of building relationships over pushing products in private banking. He believes that a banker's ability to engage with people from various backgrounds is crucial, and that technical skills alone are not enough. Lee, who has diverse interests outside of banking, stresses the value of face-to-face interactions and a personal touch. He is now focusing on deepening existing relationships and bringing in new clients, with plans to grow Citi's private bank portfolio by 2025 and triple its assets under management (AUM) in the same period.

images.alt_text: CITI on Monday announced that Lee Lung Nien will head its private banking business in South Asia, in addition to his existing role as chairman of the private bank for the region.

site_title: Europe: Solid earnings boost stocks as ECB stands pat
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Thursday, led by strong earnings from companies like Nestle, SAP, and Pernod Ricard, and boosted by a positive outlook on economic recovery. The European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged, setting the stage for a potential rate hike in June. Despite global market concerns, European stocks have seen strong gains this year, driven by vaccination efforts and stimulus programs. The Stoxx 600 index extended its gains for a second day, reaching near-record highs.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU up 14.8% to 0.8 cent in Q1
summary: ESR-Reit reported a core distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.8 Singapore cent for Q1, a 14.8% increase from the previous year. Gross revenue rose 4.4% to S$60.3 million, driven by lower property expenses and higher net property income. The company's rental collection rate was 97.5% of total receivables, and 32 leasing transactions were recorded in the quarter. Despite the pandemic's impact, ESR-Reit's Q1 was characterized by increased leasing momentum and strong rental collections.

site_title: Cosy comfort in the time of the pandemic
summary: Bottega Veneta's Spring/Summer 2021 collection, "Salon 01," embodies the theme of domestic comfort and luxury amidst the pandemic. Creative director Daniel Lee presents a minimalist, logo-free aesthetic with 50 looks featuring tailored knits, handcraft, and clean shapes. The collection revisits early 1990s silhouettes, such as tank tops and dresses, in a modern, unencumbered way. Emphasizing quality over gimmicks, the collection features roomy, utilitarian pieces in fabrics reminiscent of home furnishings, with a focus on comfort and cohesion.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust FY21 DPU down 13.3% to 6.175 cents
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 13.3% decrease in distribution per unit (DPU) for FY21 to 6.175 Singapore cents, due to the Covid-19 pandemic and lower rental rates. Despite this, net property income rose 5.2% and gross revenue increased 10.4%. The trust amended its distribution policy to make distributions on a half-yearly basis, starting from H1 FY21. MNACT's assets under management stood at S$7.9 billion, with a total portfolio occupancy of 97%. The trust expects low consumption demand to continue to weigh on retail sales, but growth in the Seoul office market is expected.

site_title: When supply chains snap ...
summary: A recent crisis, such as the pandemic, can severely impact small economies like Singapore's, threatening access to essential imports like food and medicines. To increase self-reliance and resilience, Singapore can explore solutions, including enhancing its Integrated Plan insurance and promoting domestic industries. Experts also warn of the need for consumers to understand the implications of recent changes to IP insurance, which could impact income and medical expenses. Meanwhile, the article highlights various lifestyle and business topics, including food, finance, and sustainability initiatives.

site_title: Questions raised in China over Tesla's safety and service
summary: Tesla faces backlash in China over safety and service concerns after a customer's protest at the Shanghai Auto Show, where a woman claimed her brakes malfunctioned nearly killing her. The company initially sparked anger with an uncompromising statement, prompting state news agency Xinhua to call for an investigation. Tesla later apologized and pledged to cooperate with the investigation, as China's market watchdog agency launches an inquiry into the complaint. The incident raises concerns for foreign manufacturers operating in China, where the government encourages sustainable energy use and the country has become the world's largest EV market.

site_title: Worsening outbreak a setback for India-UK Roadmap 2030
summary: India's surge in Covid-19 cases has set back its efforts to realize the India-UK Roadmap 2030, a project aimed at re-energizing trade and investment between the two countries. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson cancelled his visit to India, and instead, the two leaders will meet virtually to discuss plans. The UK has also invited Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to be an observer at the G7 summit in June. The surge in cases has raised concerns about the effectiveness of UK vaccines against the "double mutant" variant spreading in India, and the UK has placed India on the "red list" with quarantine restrictions.

site_title: The Coconut Club gets a new owner and fresh direction
summary: The Coconut Club, a famous nasi lemak eatery, has a new owner and fresh direction under The Lo & Behold Group. The restaurant, founded by late owner Lee Eng Su, will continue to serve its signature dish with attention to detail, using high-quality ingredients sourced from Malaysia and a family-owned plantation. The new owner, Wee Teng Wen, is committed to carrying on Lee Eng Su's legacy, including his hiring practices that supported marginalized communities. The refreshed menu will be launched in May, and the restaurant will also explore expanding its retail business and community outreach initiatives.

site_title: What three economists taught us about currency regimes
summary: Three influential economists, Richard Cooper, Robert Mundell, and John Williamson, contributed to the debate on optimal currency arrangements. Cooper advocated for fixed exchange rates, Mundell for a common European currency, and Williamson proposed intermediate exchange-rate regimes, such as the crawling peg and target zone. Their ideas, though influential, were not universally adopted, and the current freely floating exchange rate system suits most large countries better. The passing of these economists leaves a legacy of powerful ideas that continue to shape global economic policies.

site_title: US financial regulators in hot seat as Biden ramps up climate agenda
summary: US President Joe Biden is ramping up his climate agenda, putting pressure on the country's financial regulators to catch up with Europe's climate risk assessments. The White House is expected to issue an executive order requiring the systemic risk watchdog to assess climate change risks to financial companies and markets. This could lead to a more integrated approach to climate risk oversight in the financial sector. The move aims to align US regulations with those in Europe, which have been incorporating climate risks into their oversight for several years.

site_title: Can multilateral cooperation coexist with great power rivalry?
summary: The US is re-engaging with the world under President Joe Biden's administration, proposing initiatives to promote global multilateralism. The US Treasury Secretary has called for a new $650 billion special drawing rights (SDR) issuance to boost global liquidity and support developing countries. A second proposal involves taxing multinational corporations on their sales worldwide and setting a global minimum corporate tax rate of 21%. The Biden administration is also hosting a virtual climate summit with world leaders, including China's President Xi Jinping, to address global net-zero emissions by 2050 and climate change. However, the success of these initiatives depends on China's cooperation, which remains uncertain due to rising bilateral tensions.

site_title: China warns of 'serious harm' to relations as Australia scraps Belt and Road Initiative deal
summary: China has warned of "serious harm" to relations with Australia after Canberra scrapped a Belt and Road Initiative deal with Victoria state, citing concerns over propaganda and foreign policy consistency. The decision, made by Defence Minister Peter Dutton, comes amid strained relations between the two countries, including spats over the coronavirus pandemic and Huawei. China has already imposed tariffs on Australian industries, and Beijing has threatened retaliatory actions. The move is seen as a significant blow to China's global infrastructure push.

site_title: Credit Suisse moves to boost capital ahead of a further Archegos hit
summary: Credit Suisse is raising over $2 billion through bond issuance to boost its capital base ahead of a potential hit from the collapse of US investment fund Archegos. The move is expected to increase the bank's core capital level to around 13% and mitigate losses of around 600 million Swiss francs in the April-June quarter. The bank's CEO, Thomas Gottstein, stated that the bond placement will strengthen the bank's balance sheet and enable it to support its core franchise.

site_title: Yes, working from home makes you more productive: study
summary: A new study found that remote work boosts productivity in the US economy by 5% due to savings in commuting time. The study, which polled over 30,000 US workers, also found that 20% of full workdays will be carried out from home after the pandemic, compared to 5% before. The shift to remote work is expected to have lasting economic gains, with higher-income employees benefiting the most.

site_title: Three ethical questions to ask before hiring a CEO
summary: A global economist recommends that boards of directors ask three key ethical questions when hiring a CEO: (1) Will you attest to your past behavior to provide an opportunity to declare any significant issues, (2) How would you navigate a specific moral dilemma, and (3) What is the worst thing you have ever done to another human being. These questions aim to assess a candidate's moral and ethical behavior, rather than just their business track record, as corporations increasingly prioritize ethics and morality in choosing CEOs.

site_title: The most sustainable whiskies you can buy now
summary: Sustainable whiskey production is gaining traction, with top brands such as Buffalo Trace, Johnnie Walker, and Blinking Owl incorporating eco-friendly practices into their operations. These initiatives include reducing carbon footprints, harnessing wastewater heat, and utilizing locally sourced and organic grains. Some notable examples of sustainable whiskey include Marble Distilling Co.'s Hoover's Rvenge Ragged Mountain rye, Bowmore's 25 Year Old single malt, and Blinking Owl's 100% state-grown bourbon. As consumers increasingly demand more environmentally responsible products, the whiskey industry is responding with innovative and impactful sustainable practices.

site_title: Mandatory use of TraceTogether at malls, workplaces, schools to start on June 1
summary: Singapore will make digital check-ins for contact tracing mandatory at high-footfall places starting June 1, using either the TraceTogether app or token. This includes shopping malls, workplaces, schools, and dine-in food and beverage outlets, replacing the existing SafeEntry system. The move follows high adoption rates of the TraceTogether app, with over 90% of the population using it or having collected a token. Existing SafeEntry check-ins at individual retail outlets will be removed, increasing convenience for patrons.

site_title: Need a meeting room? At some banks, you can now use the CEO's corner office
summary: Standard Chartered is transforming its 881 senior staff offices worldwide into meeting rooms by the end of 2021, shifting towards permanent hybrid working. CEO Bill Winters has cleared out his London office, and the bank is also reevaluating its real-estate needs. This move follows similar announcements from other banking executives, such as HSBC's CEO Noel Quinn, who plans to turn his London office into a meeting space. The bank aims to improve flexibility, collaboration, and space efficiency in its operations.

site_title: Doing right by the customer in the digital age
summary: The phrase "the customer is always right" remains relevant in the digital age, emphasizing the importance of listening to customers and providing personalized experiences. As businesses shift to digital-first models, they must evolve to cater to customers' needs, leveraging technology to deliver seamless conversational experiences. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital transformation, with 91% of new digital service consumers in Singapore planning to continue this behavior post-pandemic. To stay competitive, businesses must prioritize technological adoption and invest in data-driven insights to create personalized experiences, ultimately doing right by the customer.

site_title: Trudeau likely to be only just getting started on housing tweaks
summary: Canada's banking regulator is tightening qualification rules for uninsured mortgages, reducing the size of mortgages eligible by about 4%. The move aims to curb the country's pandemic housing boom and prevent a housing bubble. The regulator's stress test rate will climb to 5.25% on June 1. The Canadian government is expected to take further steps to cool the market, with Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland watching the regulator's move closely. Experts say more needs to be done to address the issue of low interest rates and high demand for housing.

site_title: The eternal and the ephemeral
summary: Two museum exhibitions, "Life In Edo | Russel Wong In Kyoto" at the Asian Civilisations Museum and "Wikicliki: Collecting Habits on an Earth Filled with Smartphones" at the Singapore Art Museum, explore vastly different concepts of art and beauty. The former features centuries-old Japanese prints and photographs of geishas, while the latter delves into contemporary art influenced by technology and the internet. The exhibitions challenge traditional notions of beauty and art, with the latter questioning the need for physical spaces to experience art.

site_title: India records world's biggest single-day rise in Covid cases
summary: India records the world's highest daily tally of 314,835 Covid-19 infections, surpassing the US record of 297,430 new cases in January. The country's healthcare system is in crisis, with most hospitals full and oxygen running out, leading to a collapse of the healthcare system. India's total cases have reached 15.93 million, with 184,657 deaths, and the government has launched a vaccination drive, but only a fraction of the population has been vaccinated. China has offered to help, while experts blame complacency, mixing, and mass gatherings for the surge in cases.

site_title: iFast Q1 net profit rises to record S$8.82m on revenue growth
summary: iFast Corporation, a wealth management platform, reported a record net profit of S$8.82 million in Q1 2021, a 2.5 times increase from the previous year. Revenue grew 51.4% to S$28.5 million, with assets under administration reaching a new record of S$16.1 billion. The company expects to increase its dividend per share in 2021. Its B2C and B2B revenue also saw significant growth, with increases of 90.1% and 30.7% respectively.

site_title: 2021 Kia Stinger review: Content is king
summary: The 2021 Kia Stinger has undergone a mid-life revamp, retaining its core characteristics of being a beautifully-sorted driver's car with lovely feelsome steering and composure around corners. The car now boasts an 8-inch touchscreen, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity, and a suite of driver aids, such as cameras and adaptive cruise control. While minor cosmetic changes were made, the Stinger's performance and interior refinement remain its strongest points. However, the car's sound system and highway tire rumble are notable oversights, and a more powerful V6 version is expected to be released in the future.

images.alt_text: With little to fiddle with, Kia's engineers seem to have improved the Stinger by adding bells and whistles.

site_title: UK commercial-property loan defaults surge 44%
summary: UK commercial-property loan defaults surged 44% to 4.6% in 2021, the highest since the 2008 global financial crisis. This rise was driven by the pandemic's impact on retail and hospitality owners, leading to a 23% decrease in new lending and increased borrowing costs. The temporary ban on evictions has also contributed to the increase in under-performing loans. Experts predict that real estate lending will become more expensive and require further capital for borrowers over the next two to five years.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as earnings roll in; jobless claims fall
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened flat on Thursday as investors assessed earnings from US airlines and AT&T. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.08%, the S&P 500 opened lower by 0.07%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.02%. US jobless claims fell, with fewer Americans filing fresh claims last week.

site_title: Mapletree explores US$1b student housing Reit IPO in Singapore
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based property developer and manager, is exploring a US$1 billion student housing real estate investment trust (Reit) IPO in Singapore. Talks with advisers are ongoing, with a potential listing as soon as next year. This would be the country's largest Reit listing since 2013 and add to the US$5.6 billion of property trust IPOs in Singapore over the last five years. Mapletree owns four Singapore-listed Reits and six private equity real estate funds, with a portfolio ranging from residential to data centers across 13 markets.

site_title: AEM unit acquires 26.6% of South Korean firm for US$3.8m
summary: AEM Holdings acquired 26.59% of South Korean company Ateco Inc for US$3.8 million. The investment gives AEM rights to acquire further shares, totaling up to 65% of Ateco's outstanding share capital. The deal is expected to have no material impact on AEM's financials and will allow both companies to collaborate on joint development efforts for semiconductor devices. AEM CEO Chandran Nair stated that the investment provides access to the South Korean market and enables the companies to stay ahead in the industry.

site_title: How will partial offer for Procurri play out?
summary: Procurri's partial offer by Novo Tellus faces a hurdle as two shareholders, ICH Gemini Asia Growth Fund and Declout, have indicated they will vote against the offer. Despite this, the offer can still go through if other investors tender their shares. If dissenting shareholders mount a counter offer, it could thicken the plot. Novo Tellus has refused to revise the offer price of S$0.365 per share unless a competitive situation arises. Procurri's management has agreed to tender half its shares, but the offer still requires 22% acceptance from independent shareholders.

site_title: Insurer Chubb 'disappointed' as Hartford rebuffs more buyout offers
summary: Chubb, a property and casualty insurer, expressed disappointment after Hartford Financial Services Group rejected two buyout offers, valued at nearly US$25 billion. Hartford declined the offers of US$67 and US$70 per share, maintaining its disciplined approach to acquisitions despite the potential mega-merger. The rejections come as the industry faces claims from companies affected by the coronavirus crisis, with Chubb's CEO warning of a possible record loss.

site_title: Singapore firms in India brace themselves for further lockdowns
summary: Singapore firms with businesses in India are bracing themselves for further lockdowns amid India's record-breaking new Covid-19 cases. Companies like Khaitan International, Fortrec Chemicals & Petroleum, and Modern Montessori International are taking precautions to reduce exposure and protect employees' health and safety. India's prime minister has urged states to impose lockdowns only as a last resort, but stretched medical resources are leading to concerns about the country's ability to cope with the surge.

site_title: US existing home sales drop to seven-month low
summary: US existing home sales dropped 3.7% to a seven-month low of 6.01 million units in March, the lowest level since August 2020, due to a shortage of properties and boosting prices for first-time buyers. Home resales increased 12.3% year-over-year, while the median existing house price surged 17.2% to a record high of $329,100. Economists attribute the drop to a mismatch between supply and demand, rather than speculation, and expect increased Covid-19 vaccinations to lead to more homeowners putting houses on the market.

site_title: Casual izakaya and oysters at Kakiin
summary: Kakiin Oyster Bar, a Japanese dive in Orchard Plaza, offers excellent space planning and cooking despite gruff service. The two female chefs work efficiently, preparing extensive izakaya fare like sautéed oysters and grilled steak. The boss man is a skilled oyster shucker and server, adding flashes of geniality to the evening. Oysters are the specialty, with various types and preparation options available. While some dishes, like the crab croquette and steamed clams, are hit-or-miss, the garlic oyster fried rice and grilled oysters are highlights. Overall, Kakiin Oyster Bar is a satisfying, if not aesthetically pleasing, dining experience.

site_title: Boy, 11, among two locally transmitted cases of Covid-19
summary: An 11-year-old boy and a 32-year-old migrant worker were the two locally transmitted cases of Covid-19 reported in Singapore on April 22, 2021. The boy, an Indian national, was a student at Dimensions International College and was quarantined after developing a fever. The migrant worker, a Bangladeshi national, was a construction supervisor who had received both doses of the Covid-19 vaccine but tested positive in the dormitories. The Ministry of Health emphasized the importance of continued safe management measures and testing to mitigate spread and keep community transmission low.

site_title: Mercedes EQS: The S$500,000 flagship EV for younger buyers
summary: Mercedes-Benz's EQS, a flagship electric vehicle, has been launched as an electric companion to the S-Class. The EQS can travel up to 770km on a full charge and has a compatible 200kW fast charger that can gain 300km of range in 15 minutes. Estimated to cost at least S$500,000, it will arrive in Singapore early next year. The EQS boasts a 108kW-hour battery, aerodynamic design, and a Hyperscreen display. Mercedes aims to attract younger, more progressive buyers who value sustainability and technology.

site_title: Airlines see signs of continued recovery
summary: Airlines report improved financial results, with Southwest Airlines earning $116 million in the first quarter, marking the company's first annual profit in 50 years. American Airlines lost nearly $1.3 billion, but industry executives believe the worst is behind them due to rising vaccinations and decreasing Covid-19 hospitalizations. Steady weekly improvements in domestic leisure bookings have also boosted confidence, with many airlines expecting a summer travel surge.

site_title: If EVs don't make sense in Singapore yet, Nissan's e-Power system might
summary: Nissan's e-Power system, a petrol-electric hybrid technology, may be gaining traction in Singapore as a transitional step towards electric vehicles (EVs). The system, which uses only electric power for propulsion, has been adopted by Nissan in the country, with the Nissan Kicks e-Power and other e-Power models available. This technology is seen as a more affordable and accessible alternative to full EVs, with lithium-ion batteries being a major cost factor. Nissan's e-Power bet has paid off, with 81% of its sales now made up of electrified cars, and the technology is gaining popularity among consumers, with some owners expressing interest in owning an EV once public charging infrastructure becomes more widespread.

site_title: HSBC pivot stokes tension between its Hong Kong, London bankers
summary: HSBC is relocating senior executives from its London headquarters to Hong Kong as part of a pivot to Asia. The move aims to demonstrate the bank's commitment to its historic turnaround plan, which focuses on the Asian market. However, some staff are concerned about added bureaucracy and blurred reporting lines, while others see the shift as a positive step towards more local decision-making. The relocation of key executives, including the global heads of investment banking and commercial banking, may lead to friction with regional chief Peter Wong, who has expressed unhappiness about the costs of the relocations.

site_title: Euro gains ahead of ECB meeting; dollar languishes
summary: The euro has gained ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting, trading at US$1.2033, up 0.1% on the day. Analysts expect the ECB to maintain its current monetary policy, but a positive economic outlook or hints of tapering bond purchases could send the euro higher. The dollar has languished, trading near a seven-week low against major currencies, as fading US Treasury yield gains reduced its interest rate advantage. The ECB meeting sets the stage for a decision on bond purchases in June.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall to new one-year low
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped to a fresh one-year low of 547,000, indicating subsiding layoffs and strong job growth in April. However, the labor market recovery is far from complete, with 17.4 million people collecting unemployment checks in early April. Economists attribute the high number of jobless people to a lack of suitable job openings, rather than unemployed workers refusing jobs. The low claims figure follows a second straight week below the 700,000 level since March 2020.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to delist Coinbase from Xetra, Frankfurt trade
summary: Deutsche Boerse has announced it will delist Coinbase shares from its Xetra trading system and Frankfurt stock exchange due to incorrect data. The US cryptocurrency exchange mistakenly used a wrong reference code, known as a LEI code, during trading. Coinbase claims to be working to resolve the "administrative error" and has not experienced any interruptions to trading. The delisting will remain in effect until further notice, requiring Coinbase to apply for an LEI to resume trading.

site_title: Metro Bank targets US$3b in consumer finance
summary: Metro Bank aims to expand its consumer finance lending to US$2.78 billion, a tenfold increase, as part of a strategy to reverse a sharp downturn in fortunes. The move into riskier lending could help the loss-making bank return to profit and revive its stock, which has fallen 97% since a major accounting error in 2019. The expansion will include unsecured lending, overdrafts, credit cards, and personal car loans, and is seen as a way to boost profits in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Singapore to help firms after borders shut to India workers
summary: Singapore is closing its borders to all non-residents who were recently in India, effective Friday, due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. The move is expected to worsen a foreign manpower crunch in labor-intensive sectors, including construction, process, and marine industries. The government is working on extra support measures for these sectors, but industry players are concerned about productivity losses and upward pressure on wages. The ban applies to all long-term pass holders and short-term visitors who were in India in the last two weeks, and those deemed to hail from "higher-risk countries or regions" must serve out a 21-day stay-home notice order.

site_title: AEM unit acquires 26.6% of South Korean firm for US$3.8m
summary: AEM Holdings acquired 26.59% of South Korean firm Ateco Inc for approximately US$3.8 million through its wholly-owned subsidiary AEM Singapore. This investment gives AEM rights to acquire further shares, potentially reaching up to 65% of Ateco's total outstanding share capital. Ateco designs memory test handler solutions, and the deal aims to facilitate joint development efforts and access to the South Korean market, according to CEO Chandran Nair. The transaction is expected to have minimal impact on AEM's financials.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
