summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 11.15 points to 1,607.73. The market saw 545 gainers compared to 534 losers, with a total volume of 7.900 billion lots worth RM4.984 billion.

site_title: Further delays in housing projects due to Covid-19 measures on migrant workers
summary: Singapore's construction and housing projects are facing further delays due to the government's decision to ban long-term pass holders and short-term visitors from India from entering the country, effective April 23. The move is aimed at preventing the spread of Covid-19 and is expected to impact the construction, marine and process (CMP) sectors, particularly those reliant on workers from India. The government is reviewing additional support measures for local small and medium-sized enterprises and contractors affected by the new restrictions.

site_title: Talk of phasing out ECB emergency bond buys is premature, says Lagarde
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has denied discussing the phasing out of its emergency bond purchase program, citing it as "premature." ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that any changes to the program's pace are "data-dependent" and not tied to a specific time frame. The ECB continues to purchase bonds at a significantly higher pace than previously expected, with no indication of slowing down the program. This decision comes after some analysts had questioned the ECB's commitment to supporting the euro zone economy.

site_title: IMF chief urges G20 to adopt carbon price floor to reach climate goals
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva urged the G20 to adopt an international carbon price floor to combat climate change. The current average global carbon price of $2 a ton needs to reach $75 a ton by 2030 to reduce emissions in line with the Paris climate accord. A floor price could cover up to 80% of global emissions, avoiding less efficient border carbon adjustments and unlocking trillions of dollars in private investments. Georgieva also emphasized the need for green taxonomy and reporting of climate-related financial risks, as well as support for developing countries.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust FY21 DPU down 13.3% to 6.175 Singapore cts
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) posted a 13.3% decline in DPU to 6.175 Singapore cents for FY21, due to lower rental rates at its Hong Kong and Beijing malls, as well as higher rental reliefs granted to retail tenants. Despite this, gross revenue and net property income rose 10.4% and 5.2% respectively, driven by acquisitions in Japan and South Korea. The trust has amended its distribution policy to make payments on a half-yearly basis, starting from H1 FY21.

site_title: Singapore's appeal to tech investors grows with global shift to remote work
summary: Singapore's appeal to tech investors is growing as the global shift to remote work continues. Strong government support, ease of doing business, political stability, and proximity to the Asean region are key pull factors. The city-state's tech ecosystem is well-positioned to take advantage of this shift, with several initiatives in place to foster collaboration and innovation. Venture capital investors are drawn to Singapore's stability and intellectual property protection, and the government is actively promoting the city as a center for innovation and entrepreneurship. With the pandemic accelerating the shift to online deal-making, Singapore has an even better chance of becoming a global startup hub.

images.alt_text: Skilled and entrepreneurial people, particularly those who want to be in the tech scene, are no longer limited to a particular city or region. Singapore's tech ecosystem is thus "in a good position in terms of mindset to take advantage of this", says Tan Yinglan, managing partner of Insignia Ventures Partners.

site_title: EU looks to sue AstraZeneca over delivery shortfall
summary: The European Commission is considering legal action against AstraZeneca for underdelivering Covid-19 vaccine doses to the EU, with 31 million doses received out of 120 million promised. The EU wants member states to back the lawsuit, but not all are in agreement. AstraZeneca has warned it will deliver 70 million doses this year, but public confidence has been damaged by a rare blood clot link. The EU is increasingly relying on the BioNTech/Pfizer vaccine, and a lawsuit could take months to resolve.

site_title: ECB keeps pouring in cheap money as virus woes persist
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its massive pandemic-fighting stimulus package, keeping interest rates at historic lows and its 1.85 trillion euro pandemic emergency bond purchasing programme intact until March 2022. The goal is to encourage spending and investment, driving up growth and inflation. The ECB also emphasized its readiness to adjust its instruments if necessary. This move follows a top German court's approval of the European Union's 750-billion-euro recovery fund, providing a boost to efforts to stimulate the eurozone economy.

site_title: ARA Logos Logistics Trust to divest Upper Changi property for S$16.7m
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has agreed to divest ALOG Changi DistriCentre 2 for S$16.7 million to PGI Holdings. The sale is approximately 7.7% above CBRE's valuation of S$15.5 million. The proceeds will improve financial flexibility and enhance the portfolio, with an estimated divestment gain of S$800,000. The proposed divestment is expected to complete in the second quarter and is not expected to impact net asset value or net property income for 2021.

site_title: 2021 Mercedes S-Class review: A good luxe charm
summary: The 2021 Mercedes S-Class is a luxurious car that offers a blend of physical and digital qualities. It features a spacious cabin, comfortable ride, and advanced infotainment system. The S 450L 4Matic model, currently available in Singapore, boasts a powerful 3.0-liter straight-six engine and mild hybrid technology, making it a capable motorcar. With a starting price of S$523,888, the S-Class is a premium vehicle that offers a unique blend of comfort, technology, and performance.

images.alt_text: The new S-Class doesn't actually look like a huge car. If anything, it seems to disguise its size, hiding it under smooth surfaces and understated lines, with slender lamps at each end to aid the illusion.

site_title: Prosus, Tencent invest US$80m in European online broker BUX
summary: Prosus and Tencent Holdings have invested US$80 million in European online-trading group BUX, expanding its zero-commission investment platform and hiring more staff to adapt it for different European markets. The investment will also enable the company to make investing more affordable and accessible for younger generations. BUX plans to use the funding to further develop its platform, following a similar investment round by Austrian unicorn Bitpanda that raised US$170 million last month. The investment marks a significant foothold for the internet giants in the growing European online-trading sector.

site_title: Top Glove to sell 793.5m new shares
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove manufacturer, plans to sell 793.5 million new shares, raising HK$7.94 billion (S$1.36 billion). The company will use 60% of the proceeds for production expansion and data-driven manufacturing, 10% for research and development, and 10% for software upgrades and IT acquisition. The remaining amount will be allocated towards environmental, social, and corporate governance initiatives, investment opportunities, and working capital. Top Glove shares closed at S$1.80, 2.3% higher.

site_title: Fabchem China proposes S$25m reverse takeover of Singapore interior fit-out firm
summary: Fabchem China has proposed a S$25 million reverse takeover of Singapore-based interior fit-out company Lincotrade & Associates, with Fabchem issuing 113.6 million new shares to Lincotrade's directors. The deal will result in Fabchem owning up to 68.2% of the enlarged issued share capital. The acquisition is aimed at meeting Singapore Exchange requirements for a new listing on Catalist, and Fabchem expects to become a cash company after disposing of its Shandong Yinguang Technology stake.

site_title: Singapore to block all non-resident entry, transit from India 'until further notice' from Friday night
summary: Singapore is blocking all non-resident entry and transit from India "until further notice" starting Friday night due to a fresh Covid-19 outbreak at a foreign laborer dormitory. The ban applies to those who have been in India in the last two weeks, including long-term pass holders and short-term visitors. Those who have recently been in India must serve a 21-day Stay-Home Notice order at dedicated facilities. The move comes amid concerns that recovered Covid-19 cases could be re-infected, especially among migrant workers from India.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q1 profit and revenue up slightly
summary: Keppel Corp reported a revenue of S$1.89 billion for its Q1 FY21, a 1.72% increase from the previous year. The company attributed the growth to higher contributions from urban development and asset management segments, offset by lower revenues from energy and environment. Net profit for Q1 FY21 was "slightly higher" than the previous year, at S$160 million.

site_title: More support for construction, process, marine firms in light of freeze on arriving workers from India
summary: The Singapore government is providing additional support to construction, process, and marine firms affected by the freeze on migrant workers arriving from India due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Minister of Education Lawrence Wong announced the measures, which will help local small and medium-sized enterprises and contractors impacted by the restriction. The support will be reviewed and announced when ready, with a focus on helping the construction, marine, and process sectors, which are expected to face further delays in projects. The government is also working with trade associations and industry leaders to support firms through this period.

site_title: Healthtech startup Halodoc raises US$80m in funding led by Astra unit
summary: Healthtech startup Halodoc has raised US$80 million in Series C funding led by Astra Digital Internasional. Other investors include Temasek, Telkomsel, Novo Holdings, and existing investors. The funds will be used to expand Halodoc's presence in Indonesia's healthcare verticals. Founded in 2016, Halodoc provides a digital healthcare platform with live consultations, lab tests, and medication delivery. The startup aims to improve healthcare access for Indonesians, with a goal of 20,000 licensed doctors and 4,000 pharmacies.

site_title: iFast Q1 net profit rises to record S$8.8m on revenue growth
summary: iFast Corporation posted a record net profit of S$8.82 million in Q1 2021, a 2.5 times increase from the year-ago period. Net revenue rose 51.4% to S$28.5 million, while gross revenue increased 43.8%. The company's assets under administration reached a new record of S$16.1 billion, with record net inflows of S$1.28 billion. The directors declared an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share, with earnings growing to 3.22 cents. The group expects to increase its dividend per share in 2021.

site_title: Lasseters expects Malaysia hotel to generate revenue after planned soft opening in July
summary: Lasseters International's property and hospitality development business in Malaysia, the Mercure hotel, has received its Certificate of Practical Completion and is set for a soft opening in July, subject to market conditions and travel restrictions. The hotel is expected to generate revenue from then on, despite the group's casino and spa businesses in Australia accounting for almost 100% of its revenue. Lasseters is negotiating several proposals for property development projects in Malaysia and plans to allocate 40-60% of its working capital for potential investments in property development.

site_title: Indonesia's end-March fiscal deficit at 0.82% of GDP
summary: Indonesia reported a budget deficit of 144.2 trillion rupiah (S$13.1 billion) at the end of March, or 0.82% of GDP, due to shrinking tax revenues and rising spending to support economic recovery. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati described the recovery trend as "very convincing" and maintained the 2021 economic growth forecast at 4.5% to 5.3%.

site_title: Singapore corruption-related reports fall to lowest in 5 years, says CPIB
summary: Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) reported a five-year low in corruption-related reports in 2020, with 239 cases, down from 350 in 2019. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the CPIB maintained its low corruption level and achieved a high clearance rate of 87%, with 129 individuals prosecuted and a 97% conviction rate. The bureau attributed the decrease to curtailed economic activities and the "circuit breaker" period. Singapore's anti-corruption efforts remain well-regarded internationally, ranking third in the 2020 Corruption Perceptions Index.

site_title: US deepens emissions target at climate summit, goal called 'game changing'
summary: The US has pledged to cut its greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030, a goal considered "game changing" by British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. This targets a 50-52% reduction from 2005 levels and aims to spur other countries to raise their ambition. The US, the world's second-largest emitter, seeks to reclaim global leadership in combating climate change after former President Donald Trump withdrew the US from international emissions-cutting efforts. The goal is part of President Joe Biden's broader plan to decarbonize the US economy entirely by 2050.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration on Thursday pledged at a US climate summit attended by world leaders to slash US greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030, a target it hopes will spur other big countries to raise their ambition to combat global warming.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore industrial space rents and prices increased in Q1, with the market likely to remain stable for 2021 due to low supply and growing demand. A shareholder voted against Novo Tellus' partial offer, while Mapletree is exploring a US$1 billion student housing Reit IPO. Razer launched a US$50 million sustainability fund, and corporate earnings saw a 14.8% increase for ESR-Reit. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 1.04% higher at 3,187.78, rebounding from losses. Corruption-related reports in Singapore fell to a five-year low.

site_title: Tokyo Olympic torch staffer becomes event's first Covid-19 infection
summary: A Tokyo Olympic torch staffer has become the first participant to be diagnosed with Covid-19, sparking concerns about the event's safety amid a fourth wave of infections in Japan. The officer, a 30-year-old police officer, tested positive after working on the relay in Kagawa prefecture. Despite wearing a mask and having no contact with runners, the man contracted the virus, leading to public worries about the event's impact on the country's health crisis. The Olympics are set to start in 92 days, with the Japanese government expected to declare a state of emergency in major cities.

site_title: Singapore stocks bounce back from losses; STI up 1.04%
summary: Singapore stocks bounced back from losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.04% to 3,187.78. ComfortDelGro emerged as the top performer, gaining 2.29% to S$1.79, after announcing a partnership with Lazada. Mapletree Investments is exploring listing a student housing Reit in Singapore, which could raise US$1 billion. Jardine Matheson Holdings and Singtel were the biggest decliners, while Asian markets also rebounded, with the Nikkei 225 Index snapping its two-day losing streak.

site_title: BlackRock, Tudor Group back cybersecurity startup Deep Instinct
summary: BlackRock is leading a $100 million investment round for cybersecurity startup Deep Instinct, with Tudor Group and other investors also participating. The funds will be used for sales and marketing in North America, Europe, and Japan, with Deep Instinct aiming to reach $100 million in revenue by next year. The company's endpoint protection software uses deep-learning techniques to predict and prevent malware and ransomware attacks. Existing investors Coatue Management, Millennium, and Unbound also took part in the round, with BlackRock's William Abecassis joining the company's board.

images.alt_text: BlackRock is leading a US$100 million investment round for Deep Instinct, a cybersecurity software startup.

site_title: Singtel, Wilmar, SP Group and Razer in green finance push on Earth Day
summary: Singaporean companies Singtel, Wilmar, and SP Group announced their commitment to green financing projects on Earth Day. These loans aim to support clean and sustainable sectors, aligned with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standards. The move is part of a global push towards green finance, coinciding with the global observance of Earth Day.

site_title: Volvo sees more risk from 'unstable' chip supply chain
summary: Volvo Group warns of potential further disruption from the semiconductor shortage, which has already forced the truckmaker to idle plants. The company, citing an unstable chip supply chain, may see production stoppages spread to other parts of its business. Despite a significant increase in order intake for trucks, Volvo's operating profit jumped 66% in the first quarter, but the company maintains its readiness to increase production when possible. The global shortage, exacerbated by bad weather and a fire at a Japanese chip plant, has disrupted vehicle manufacturers worldwide.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to 28,755.34. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.23%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange rose 0.48%. The recovery on Wall Street, which had experienced a two-day slump, contributed to the Hong Kong market's gains.

site_title: Hong Kongers, Singaporeans most pessimistic about their health: study
summary: A study by the Economist Intelligence Unit found that Hong Kong and Singapore residents have the lowest optimism about their current and future health, with scores of 46.5 and 47.3, respectively. In contrast, Indian residents were the most optimistic, scoring 59 out of 100. Despite having effective public and private healthcare systems, residents in these countries are pessimistic due to their knowledge of chronic diseases and life expectancy. The study also found that digital health technologies are popular, but users need improvement, and awareness of wellness and disease connections is growing.

site_title: Migrant workers from Westlite Woodlands dorm moved to quarantine facility
summary: Hundreds of migrant workers from Westlite Woodlands dormitory were transferred to a quarantine facility after 11 more Covid-19 cases were detected at the dorm on Wednesday. The workers were taken to a 240-room hotel listed as temporarily closed, Quality Hotel Marlow at Balestier Road. The transfer came after a 35-year-old Bangladeshi worker tested positive for the virus despite receiving both doses of the Covid-19 vaccine. Certis Cisco personnel supervised the movement of workers, who brought some belongings, to the buses.

site_title: 'Pervasive racism' meant UK's Black and Asian troops not commemorated
summary: A UK report has found that "pervasive racism" may have led to the under- or non-commemoration of up to 350,000 Black and Asian service personnel who died fighting for Britain during World War One. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission has apologized and will act to correct the issue, acknowledging the wrongs of the past. The investigation revealed entrenched prejudices and colonial attitudes that resulted in inadequate commemoration, with many casualties being from African and Middle Eastern backgrounds.

site_title: Japan ups greenhouse gases reduction goal from 26% to 46%
summary: Japan has raised its greenhouse gas reduction goal to 46% by 2030, up from 26%, in response to US pressure and domestic criticism. The new target, set by Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, aims to cut emissions compared to 2013 levels. The move is seen as a step towards achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, in line with some other countries. The US, under President Joe Biden, has been seeking to restore credibility on combating global warming after former President Donald Trump undermined international consensus on reducing emissions.

site_title: Climate activists shatter 19 windows at HSBC HQ in London
summary: Climate activists from the Extinction Rebellion group shattered 19 windows at HSBC's London headquarters as part of a protest against the bank's financing of climate change. Despite HSBC's pledge to achieve net zero by 2050, the group claims the bank continues to finance coal power and has no plan to cancel contracts with fossil fuel-linked clients. The activists, who also pasted stickers on the broken windows, were arrested and are facing potential prison time, citing the struggle of the Suffragettes as a historical example of using direct action to fight for a cause.

images.alt_text: Climate activists shattered 19 windows at HSBC's headquarters in London's Canary Wharf on Thursday as part of a protest against the financing of what the group says is devastating climate change that threatens the planet.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound, virus worries weigh
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.18% on Thursday, rebounding from a 1.52% drop the previous day, amid a global equities rebound. The Kospi benchmark closed at 3,177.52, driven by gains from technology giant Samsung Electronics and battery maker LG Chem. However, investor sentiment was weighed down by concerns over rising Covid-19 cases in Asia and Latin America, which could hinder the global economic recovery.

site_title: Covid tragedy spills onto social media in India
summary: India is grappling with a record-breaking surge in COVID-19 cases, with 2,104 new deaths and 314,835 fresh cases reported on Thursday. The nation's hospitals and crematoriums are overwhelmed, prompting frantic social media appeals for help, including ICU beds, oxygen, and medical supplies. The crisis has forced restrictions on movement in major cities, and the government is struggling to cope with the shortage of crematoriums. Amid the desperation, many are turning to social media to rally support and provide aid, with strangers volunteering to bring supplies and food to patients' doorsteps.

images.alt_text: These days, social media posts in India are no longer about cheeky photos, funny memes or political jokes.

site_title: Strong Asia growth powers Hermes sales in Q1
summary: Hermes reports a 44% surge in sales in the first quarter, driven by strong growth in Asia, where revenues nearly doubled due to eased Covid-19 restrictions. The French luxury group's revenues reached 2.08 billion euros, beating analyst expectations. Sales in Asia excluding Japan surged 94%, with significant growth in China. The company's strong performance adds to signs of a luxury goods sector comeback, despite concerns about a possible resurgence of the virus in Japan.

site_title: 17 workers at Westlite Woodlands dorm test positive for Covid-19
summary: Seventeen workers at Westlite Woodlands dormitory in Singapore have tested positive for COVID-19, following a 35-year-old Bangladeshi national who was confirmed to have the virus on Monday. The cases are being investigated as potential re-infections. Meanwhile, 24 new cases were confirmed, bringing Singapore's total to 60,904, with one community case and one new case from migrant workers' dormitories.

site_title: Razer launches US$50m sustainability fund
summary: Razer has launched a US$50 million sustainability fund, the Razer Green Fund, to invest in startups focused on environmental and sustainability issues. The fund will invest in seed and Series A funding rounds globally, with a focus on renewable energy, carbon issues, and plastics management. The company aims to achieve 100% renewable energy in its global offices by 2025 and 100% carbon neutrality by 2030, with recent investments in sustainable consumer products and initiatives to reduce its environmental footprint.

site_title: Thai economy may lose US$3.2b a month after new virus outbreak
summary: Thailand's economy may lose $3.19 billion a month due to a third Covid-19 wave and a highly contagious variant, affecting the service sector. The outbreak could reduce workers by 149,000 a month, cutting gross domestic product (GDP) by 1.2-1.8%. If economic stimulus measures are implemented, the economy may grow 1.2-1.6% this year, down from the current forecast of 2.8% growth. Household debt levels may rise to 92% of GDP, with the debt already at 89.3% of GDP at the end of 2020.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best day in two weeks as gold stocks shine
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8% to 7,055.40, its best day in two weeks, driven by a rebound in global equities and gains in gold and healthcare stocks. The tech-heavy Nasdaq added 1.2% in the US, while Asia-Pacific shares rose 0.3%. Gold stocks surged 2.7%, with Newcrest Mining and Chalice Mining gaining 2.3% and 8.1%, respectively. Healthcare stocks also rose 1.7%, led by CSL's 1.8% gain. AGL Energy fell 2.9% after its CEO resigned.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend gains on upbeat Nestle, Volvo earnings
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, extending gains for a second session, driven by strong earnings reports from Nestle and Volvo. Nestle reported its strongest quarterly sales growth in 10 years, while Volvo beat market expectations for core earnings. However, Credit Suisse fell 5.7% after posting a significant pre-tax loss. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index is nearing record highs ahead of the European Central Bank's policy decision.

images.alt_text: European stocks moved towards record highs on Thursday after stumbling earlier in the week, as a set of strong earnings reports brightened sentiment ahead of the European Central Bank's policy decision.

site_title: Gold nears US$1,800 level as US dollar, yields retreat
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-month high, approaching the $1,800 threshold, as the US dollar faltered with easing Treasury yields. Spot gold was steady at $1,793.32 per ounce, while palladium gained 0.1% to $2,877.12 an ounce due to tight market conditions. Market participants await the European Central Bank meeting and US Federal Reserve policy meeting. The decline in US Treasury yields reduced the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, contributing to gold's rise.

site_title: German MPs quiz Merkel, ministers over Wirecard scandal
summary: German lawmakers are grilling top ministers and Chancellor Angela Merkel over the Wirecard scandal, which involved 1.9 billion euros in missing funds and led to the company's bankruptcy. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz and Economy Minister Peter Altmaier are facing criticism for their roles in ignoring early warning signs of the scandal. Merkel will also be questioned for promoting Wirecard on a trip to China in 2019, raising questions about her office's oversight. The investigation aims to uncover the political and regulatory failings that allowed the scandal to go unnoticed for years.

images.alt_text: German lawmakers probing the collapse of payments firm Wirecard are this week grilling top ministers and even Chancellor Angela Merkel as a parliamentary inquiry into the massive fraud reaches a dramatic climax.

site_title: India records world's biggest single-day rise in coronavirus cases
summary: India reported a record 314,835 new daily COVID-19 cases, surpassing the US one-day rise of 297,430. The country's total cases reached 15.93 million, with 184,657 deaths. Hospitals across northern and western India are facing a severe shortage of medical oxygen and beds, with over two-thirds of hospitals having no vacant beds. Experts attribute the surge to new variants, particularly the "double mutant" strain. India's vaccination drive has been slow, with only a fraction of the population having received shots, and authorities have announced that vaccines will be available to anyone over 18 from May 1.

site_title: Singapore industrial space rents, prices up in Q1; likely to remain stable for 2021
summary: Singapore's industrial space rents and prices are expected to remain stable in Q1 2021, with a 0.6% increase in rentals and a 0.9% increase in prices, according to data released by JTC. Despite a low supply of new industrial space, with only 131,000 sq m completed in Q1, demand is expected to increase as the economy recovers further in 2021. Experts predict that prices and rents may remain stable, with some segments experiencing growth, such as multiple-user factories, which saw a 0.5% increase in occupancy rates.

site_title: UK commercial-property loan defaults surge 44% on lockdown hit
summary: UK commercial-property loan defaults surged 44% to 4.6% in 2021, the highest since the global financial crisis, due to the pandemic's impact on borrowers with business properties. Defaults on underperforming loans rose to 8.6% of all outstanding loans. The lockdowns led to a 23% drop in new lending and higher borrowing costs, with loan margins reaching record highs. Experts predict that real estate lending will become more expensive and require further capital for borrowers over the next two to five years.

site_title: Hyundai Q1 profit triples to highest in four years as luxury car demand booms
summary: Hyundai Motor reported its highest quarterly profit in four years, tripling to 1.3 trillion won (S$1.54 billion) in the first quarter, driven by strong demand for luxury sports-utility vehicles and premium Genesis cars. Revenue rose 8.2% to 27.4 trillion won. However, the company faces a global semiconductor shortage, which may derail its growth momentum, and has already paused production three times to conserve chip inventory. Shares rose 2% on the news, making Hyundai the third-best performer among large Asian automakers this year.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to close pilot bases in Canada, Australia, New Zealand: SCMP
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways plans to close its pilot bases in Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, according to an internal memo. This move, along with reviewing European and US bases, may impact hundreds of jobs. The airline has already closed overseas cabin crew bases and regional airline Cathay Dragon during the pandemic, resulting in over 5,900 job losses. The decision aims to conserve cash.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares jump after two-day declines, chip stocks advance
summary: Japanese shares jumped 2.38% to close at 29,188.17, with the Nikkei average gaining the most in over seven weeks, following a two-day decline. Chip-related shares advanced, with Tokyo Electron, Advantest, and Shin-Etsu Chemical rising 4.58%, 4.2%, and 3.45% respectively. Nidec, a precision motor manufacturer, was the top gainer among the top 30 core Topix names. The underperformers were Nintendo and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, which fell 0.26% and 0.16% respectively.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound after Wall Street rally
summary: Asia markets rebounded after a Wall Street rally, with Tokyo's Nikkei up over 2% despite an escalating coronavirus outbreak ahead of the Olympics. Hong Kong and Sydney also rose, while Shanghai fell 0.1%. Analysts expect further growth in US stocks, citing strong corporate results and a post-pandemic American economy. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, are expected to provide further guidance on interest rate forecasts. Oil futures stumbled, but gold prices rose due to softer oil prices and lower US yields.

site_title: Credit Suisse sees 600m Swiss franc Q2 hit from Archegos
summary: Credit Suisse expects a 600 million-franc (S$869.3 million) second-quarter hit from Archegos Capital Management's collapse, adding to the bank's losses after a US$4.8 billion blow from the US hedge fund's collapse. The bank posted a lower-than-expected loss of 252 million francs for the first quarter, but faces a capital increase of 1.9 billion francs and regulatory enforcement proceedings. The collapse has left Credit Suisse with a total potential loss of US$8.7 billion, according to JPMorgan analysts.

site_title: Tokyo Motor Show cancelled due to pandemic
summary: The Tokyo Motor Show has been cancelled for the first time in its history due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The biennial car show, scheduled for autumn, was cancelled by the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association (JAMA). The last Tokyo Motor Show in 2019 drew around 1.3 million attendees, and the cancellation marks a significant change for the industry.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust up 2.8% on news of ARA's potential stake purchase in trustee-manager
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's units rose 2.8% to 74.5 cents after ARA Asset Management, a global real assets fund manager, signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding to acquire a 5% stake in the trust and a 50% stake in its trustee-manager. This strategic partnership aims to bring international investors and best practices to the underloved Chinese-sponsored Reit sector, allowing the trust sponsor to focus on operating and improving assets.

site_title: Coffee, dairy help Nestle post strongest quarter in a decade
summary: Nestle posted its strongest quarterly sales growth in 10 years, driven by increased demand for coffee, dairy, and petcare products. The company's organic sales rose 7.7% in the first quarter, beating forecasts and surpassing its peer Danone. Nestle's sales growth was driven by emerging markets and e-commerce, with petcare, powdered and liquid beverages, and dairy experiencing significant increases. The company confirms its guidance for the year and expects sustained mid-single-digit organic growth.

site_title: Asean Blockchain Consortium formed to drive cross-border collaboration
summary: The Asean Blockchain Consortium (ABC) was formed to drive cross-border collaboration and promote blockchain technology in South-east Asia and Australia. Participating organisations, including Blockchain Association Singapore, inked a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to foster blockchain education and adoption. The ABC aims to engage with regulators to ensure legal compliance and raise awareness about blockchain. This collaboration is expected to support the growth of the industry in a healthy and sustainable pace, with ample room for innovation, according to BAS co-chairman Chia Hock Lai.

images.alt_text: Organised by Blockchain Association Singapore, the participating associations inked a memorandum of understanding at a virtual event.

site_title: Australia: Miners and banks push shares higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,033.2, driven by gains in the mining and banking sectors, despite energy stocks declining 2% due to a drop in crude prices. Technology stocks led the gains, with companies like Nuix and Megaport advancing 1.9% and 1.3%, respectively. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.36% to 12,579.9, rebounding from two consecutive days of losses.

site_title: Nasa extracts breathable oxygen from thin Martian air
summary: NASA's Perseverance rover has successfully extracted breathable oxygen from the Martian atmosphere using an experimental device called Moxie. The device, which works through electrolysis, produced about 5 grams of oxygen, equivalent to 10 minutes' worth of breathing for an astronaut. This feat marks the first experimental extraction of a natural resource from another planet's environment for direct human use. The oxygen will be crucial for future human missions to Mars, where astronauts will require a sustainable source of breathable air and rocket fuel.

site_title: Mapletree explores US$1b student housing Reit IPO in Singapore
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based property developer and manager, is exploring a US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) for a student housing real estate investment trust (Reit) in Singapore. The IPO could take place as soon as next year, adding to the country's growing list of property trust IPOs. Mapletree owns four Singapore-listed Reits and has a significant portfolio of student accommodation assets in Asia, Europe, and the US, with a total value of approximately S$3.6 billion. The company is in preliminary discussions with advisers on the offering plan.

site_title: Hong Kong arrests six in HK$2.5b money laundering case
summary: Hong Kong authorities arrested six individuals suspected of money laundering involving HK$2.5 billion (S$427.5 million) through opening 60 personal accounts at various banks. The suspects, aged 23 to 50, were involved in over 2,600 transactions from January 2018 to February 2020. This case follows recent high-profile arrests, including 12 for "ramp and dump" stock scams and money laundering, and bank staff allegedly involved in HK$6.3 billion of dirty money flows.

site_title: Electricity retailer Geneco appoints new CEO
summary: Geneco, a Singapore electricity retailer, has appointed Lim Han Kwang as its new CEO, replacing Low Boon Tong. Lim has over 18 years of experience in the Singapore electricity and gas market, previously holding roles at YTL PowerSeraya and Sembcorp Power. Under Lim's leadership, Geneco aims to accelerate its green ambition and drive a steady energy transition towards sustainable energy solutions.

site_title: Greensill creditors vote for Australian liquidation, probes of directors to follow
summary: Creditors of Greensill Capital Pty, the Australian parent of the collapsed British supply chain financier, voted to liquidate the company, with 26 creditors owed A$4.6 billion voting in favor of liquidation. The decision triggers further investigations into the conduct of its directors. Prosecutors in Germany have raided the offices and homes of Greensill bankers, including officials suspected of possible wrongdoing, amid a criminal complaint filed by German regulator BaFin over an audit that found Greensill Bank could not provide evidence of receivables on its balance sheet.

site_title: Search for missing Indonesian submarine enters second day as neighbours offer help
summary: An Indonesian submarine, KRI Nanggala-402, with 53 crew on board, went missing during a torpedo drill north of Bali on Wednesday. A search operation entered its second day after finding an oil slick near the submarine's dive location. Neighboring countries Australia, Singapore, and India offered assistance, with Australia pledging to help in any way possible. The submarine's diesel-powered design limits its depth to 250-500 meters, and the navy believes a blackout may have occurred, leading to the loss of control.

site_title: Samsung boss on trial over 'manipulated' takeover deal
summary: Samsung's jailed vice-chairman Lee Jae Yong went on trial over allegedly manipulating a 2015 takeover deal involving subsidiaries Samsung C&T and Cheil Industries. Lee is accused of stock manipulation, breach of trust, and other offenses, which critics say aimed to consolidate his grip on the conglomerate ahead of his father's death. Lee is already serving a two-and-a-half year prison sentence for bribery and other offenses. The trial raises concerns about the dominance of family-controlled chaebols in South Korea's economy, with experts warning that it threatens the system of conglomerate control.

site_title: Credit Suisse had more than US$20b exposure to Archegos investments: WSJ
summary: Credit Suisse had over $20 billion in exposure to Archegos Capital Management, a fund that collapsed in March, before the bank was able to liquidate its positions. The bank's systems were not fully implemented to monitor the fund's growth, and its top executives were only aware of the exposure in the days leading up to the collapse. This exposure contributed to a $4.7 billion first-quarter charge for the bank. The collapse of Archegos follows a similar exposure to Greensill Capital, leading to significant losses and leadership changes at the bank.

site_title: Tencent, Sequoia invest in data startup at US$200m valuation
summary: WakeData, a Chinese enterprise data services provider, has raised US$25 million from investors led by Tencent Holdings and Sequoia China at a post-money valuation of US$200 million. The company, which provides data management toolkits, aims to double its revenue to at least 250 million yuan (S$51.2 million) this year and turn profitable in 2022. Founded in 2018, WakeData will use the funding to expand its operations and support its clients, including property developer Country Garden and retailer Watsons, in their digitalization efforts.

images.alt_text: WakeData, a Chinese enterprise data services provider, has raised US$25 million from investors led by Tencent Holdings and Sequoia China at a post-money valuation of US$200 million.

site_title: Another Procurri shareholder to vote against Novo Tellus' partial offer
summary: Procurri, a tech company, received a letter from shareholder ICH Gemini Asia Growth Fund stating its intention to vote against Novo Tellus' partial offer of 36.5 Singapore cents per share. This is the second shareholder to oppose the offer, following Declout's decision last week. The offer aims to acquire 27.9% of Procurri's shares, with Novo Tellus holding 19.5% and a concert party holding 9.2%. The outcome of the offer depends on more than half of independent shareholders voting in favor, which currently stands at 25.1% against.

site_title: Mandatory use of TraceTogether at malls, workplaces, schools to start on June 1
summary: Singapore will require the use of TraceTogether at high-traffic areas starting June 1, replacing SafeEntry for shopping malls, workplaces, schools, and other locations. Over 90% of the population has downloaded the TraceTogether app or collected the token. Existing SafeEntry check-ins at individual retail outlets will be removed, and other modes of check-in will be discontinued. The move aims to increase convenience for patrons while maintaining contact tracing capabilities.

site_title: Malaysia taps oil-backed trust fund to pay for vaccines
summary: Malaysia's government has enacted a new emergency law allowing it to use oil and gas contributions to pay for vaccine procurement. The law, enacted in January, grants the government access to the RM17.4 billion national trust fund, previously used for infrastructure and development. The move aims to boost the country's Covid-19 vaccination programme, which has been criticized for its slow rollout. As of Tuesday, 757,547 people have been fully vaccinated, while around 462,000 more are awaiting their second shots, with the government aiming to inoculate 80% of the 32 million population by December.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong said to delay travel bubble announcement
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have postponed an announcement on an air travel bubble between the two financial hubs for the second time in five months. The cancellation was initiated by the Singapore side, but no reason was provided. A new date for the announcement has not been set. The air travel bubble, expected to facilitate travel between the two cities, was expected to be announced on Thursday but was instead called off.

site_title: US offers business tax credits for Covid-19 vaccinations
summary: The US government is offering tax credits to businesses that provide employees with time off to receive a Covid-19 vaccine or recover from its side effects. The credits, worth up to $11,000 per employee, are available to companies with fewer than 500 employees and will be paid for by the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan. The program aims to encourage employees to get vaccinated and is part of President Biden's efforts to end the pandemic and accelerate the economy's recovery.

site_title: China blasts Australia's decision to cancel Belt and Road deal
summary: China has strongly criticized Australia's decision to cancel agreements between the Belt and Road Initiative and the Victoria state government, calling it an "unreasonable and provocative move" that will further damage bilateral relations. The cancellation comes after Australia's federal government scrapped memorandums of understanding and framework agreements signed between Victoria and China's National Development and Reform Commission, citing concerns over foreign policy and adverse relations. China has retaliated with crippling tariffs on Australian barley and wine, while blocking coal shipments, and has indicated there will be no immediate thaw in ties between Beijing and Canberra.

site_title: Hong Kong: Markets rise at open
summary: Hong Kong markets rose at the open on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.33% or 95.06 points to 28,716.98, following a two-day slump on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained ground, rising 0.29% and 0.38%, respectively. The recovery in Asian markets comes as US stocks rebounded from record lows amid tariff threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.45 points, or 0.15%, to 1,599.03 on Thursday, driven by 412.17 million lots worth RM168.15 million. Gainers outpaced losers 267 to 172.

site_title: Air pollution costs Indian businesses US$95b a year: study
summary: India's air pollution costs businesses around $95 billion annually, equivalent to 3% of the country's GDP, due to premature deaths, absenteeism, and reduced consumer spending. The pollution causes nearly 1.7 million premature deaths in 2019, resulting in lost working years valued at $44 billion. The effects of pollution also lead to 1.4 billion sick days, $6 billion in lost revenue, and decreased productivity, costing businesses up to $24 billion.

site_title: Offer for Penguin closes; offeror, concert parties to hold 80.05% stake
summary: The offer for Penguin International closed with total acceptances of 63.2% and the offeror, along with its concert parties, will own 80.05% of the company, or 176.2 million shares. The offeror, led by Jeffrey Hing, made an offer at S$0.65 per share. Prior to the closing, the offeror and its concert parties held 21.7% of Penguin, acquiring an additional 16.8% on the open market. As a result, shares of Penguin rose 3.1% to S$0.67.

site_title: Singapore's Altara joins US$12.6m Series A round of US software startup
summary: Singapore-based venture firm Altara Ventures has joined a $12.6 million Series A round for US software startup FreeAgent. Altara Ventures led the round, alongside existing investors Pelion Venture Partners and BlueRun Ventures. FreeAgent offers a cloud platform for managing customer-facing work and views itself as an alternative to Salesforce. The funding will be used to deepen product development and go-to-market activities. Altara Ventures' general partner, Dave Ng, expressed excitement about partnering with FreeAgent's co-founder and CEO, Dave Stephens, citing his track record of success in the industry.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU up 14.8% to 0.8 S cent for Q1
summary: ESR-Reit posted a core distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.8 Singapore cent for Q1, up 14.8% from the previous year. Gross revenue rose 4.4% to S$60.3 million, while net property income grew 7.6% to S$44.1 million. Total income available for distribution increased 17.1% to S$28.7 million. The company's rental collection rate was 97.5% and occupancy rate was 90.8%. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, the portfolio showed increased leasing momentum and strong rental collections, with 32 leasing transactions for 317,000 square feet of space.

site_title: Outflows continue at Australian wealth manager AMP as reputation damage bites
summary: Australian wealth manager AMP saw A$1.5 billion in net outflows at its Australian wealth management business in the first quarter, with shares hitting a one-year low due to reputation damage. The company continues to lose clients despite efforts to repair its image. AMP Capital, its asset management arm, also saw net outflows of A$2.9 billion, including A$1.3 billion from external clients. AMP's assets under management decreased 1.7% to A$186.5 billion, and shares dropped 3.9% to A$1.12.

site_title: Malaysia issues US$800m sustainability sukuk, world's first by a sovereign
summary: Malaysia has issued US$800 million worth of 10-year trust certificates, billed as the world's first sovereign US dollar sustainability sukuk. The 30-year trust certificates, totaling US$500 million, were also issued. The proceeds will be used for green projects aligned with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals Agenda. The issuance resulted in the lowest ever yield and spread for a US-dollar sukuk by Malaysia, with the 10-year and 30-year trust certificates priced at 2.070% and 3.075% respectively.

site_title: MailOnline sues Google for search result 'manipulation'
summary: Associated Newspapers, the UK owner of MailOnline, filed a lawsuit in a New York court against Google, alleging the tech giant manipulates search results by downgrading its stories. The complaint claims Google reduced MailOnline's search traffic by 50% since the start of the year due to the website's use of client-side header bidding, which increases competition for ad space. Google denies the claims, stating they are "meritless" and that its dominance in the market is due to its ad revenue model, not search results manipulation.

site_title: New Zealand to introduce new rules for setting lending restrictions
summary: New Zealand plans to introduce new lending rules that grant the finance minister more authority to restrict loans, allowing the central bank to decide the best instrument to use. The Reserve Bank will have full discretion to apply restrictions, and a new deposit guarantee scheme will protect up to NZ$100,000 per depositor in banks. The move aims to strengthen the country's financial system and provide more support for banks during times of economic uncertainty.

site_title: Olam, Mondelez to develop a sustainable commercial cocoa farm in Indonesia
summary: Olam International and Mondelez International have partnered to develop a sustainable commercial cocoa farm in Indonesia, with a 50% stake in AztecAgri for $10.8 million. The 2,000-hectare farm on Seram Island will be the world's largest sustainable cocoa farm, featuring cocoa, shade trees, and forest to promote biodiversity and carbon capture. The farm will utilize smart technology and sensors to optimize land usage and farming practices. The project aims to test a modernized cocoa farming model that can be replicated across the region.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, Keppel Reit, Sembmarine, Penguin, Procurri, Olam
summary: Several Singapore stocks saw notable developments, including Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) posting a 5.5% increase in DPU, Ascendas India Trust rising 5% in net property income, and ESR-Reit announcing a 14.8% rise in core DPU. Keppel Reit reported a 22% increase in distributable income. Meanwhile, Sembcorp Marine partnered with Shell to trial hydrogen fuel cells, and Olam International entered a joint venture with Mondelez International to develop a sustainable cocoa farm.

site_title: Roche's Q1 Covid-19 test business offsets slumping drug division
summary: Roche's first-quarter sales were 14.9 billion Swiss francs, driven by a 55% increase in diagnostics sales from Covid-19 tests, which offset a 9% decline in the company's main drug business. The strong Swiss franc and negative impact of the pandemic on the drug division contributed to the revenue decline. Despite this, Roche still expects low- to mid-single-digit sales growth for the year at constant exchange rates.

site_title: US to join effort to curb climate-warming emissions from shipping
summary: The US will join an international effort to achieve net zero emissions from shipping by 2050, as announced by climate envoy John Kerry. The US will work with Saudi Arabia to deploy technologies to rapidly reduce the sector's emissions, which emit 1 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide annually. The move aims to address European and British pressure to address shipping emissions in the US's forthcoming climate plan under the 2015 Paris agreement.

images.alt_text: The United States will join an international effort to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 in the global shipping industry, climate envoy John Kerry announced ahead of a summit of world leaders President Joe Biden will host this week.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,172.68 at 9:02am, following Wall Street's gains. Sembcorp Marine shares led the gains, rising 2.4% to 21 cents. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also traded higher, with DBS up 1%, UOB up 0.7%, and OCBC up 1.3%. This follows Wall Street's gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.9%, S&P 500 up 0.7%, and Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.2%.

site_title: London trails Europe on green bonds: lawmakers
summary: The UK lags behind European nations in issuing green bonds, with the first sovereign green bond planned for this summer. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak's initiative mirrors policies in France and Germany, which have issued green bonds since 2017 and 2020, respectively. Lawmakers express concerns over the higher cost of green bonds, which may be more expensive than traditional state bonds. The UK's net-zero carbon emissions goal by 2050 is a key focus, with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson hosting COP26 in Glasgow in November.

site_title: Oil prices drop 2% on US crude build, Covid-19 surge in India
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Wednesday, falling to their lowest in a week, due to a surprise build in US crude inventories and concerns over surging Covid-19 cases in India. US crude inventories rose to 493 million barrels, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell to $61.35 per barrel. The surge in Covid-19 cases in India, the world's third-largest oil user, is expected to drive down fuel demand, further contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: UK fintech Currencycloud on hiring drive for new Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore
summary: Currencycloud, a UK-based fintech startup, has named Singapore as its Asia-Pacific headquarters and plans to hire over 50 staff in the next year. The company will occupy a new office in Raffles Quay, providing on-the-ground support for existing customers in the region. Currencycloud is also applying for a major payment institution licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, with Rohit Narang, a co-founder of Trusting Social, appointed as managing director for the region. This move aims to expand the company's services in South-east Asia, Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan.

site_title: Secret selfie? UK spy agency MI5 to join Instagram
summary: Britain's domestic intelligence service, MI5, is set to open an official Instagram account, @mi5official, to bust myths and reveal archive material. The account aims to engage with users, host Q&As with serving intelligence officers, and promote career opportunities. With over one billion users, MI5 plans to utilize the platform to increase transparency and humanize the spy agency. This move marks the latest step by UK spy agencies to come out of the shadows, following similar efforts by MI6 and GCHQ.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.34% or 381.75 points to 28,890.30, while the Topix index advanced 1.18% or 22.29 points to 1,910.47. The market sentiment was supported by recovery hopes.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending rallies on Wall Street where recovery hopes supported market sentiment.

site_title: Biden to end Trump-era California emissions battle: report
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to announce an end to a Trump-era California emissions battle, reversing a decision made by his predecessor Donald Trump to repeal California's federal exemption to set stricter vehicle emission standards. California had challenged the decision in court, with more than 20 other states joining the challenge. The Biden administration's move is seen as a step to break with Trump's environmental policies and allow California to set its own standards, potentially leading to more ambitious US commitments on climate change. The announcement is set to coincide with Biden's virtual Earth Day summit.

site_title: 11 more Covid cases detected at Westlite Woodlands dormitory
summary: 11 more Covid-19 cases have been detected at Westlite Woodlands dormitory in Singapore, including 10 who have recovered. The cases were confirmed after 568 pre-emptive tests were conducted on Tuesday, following a 35-year-old Bangladeshi worker who tested positive despite receiving both Covid-19 vaccine doses. Plans are underway to move hundreds of workers to a quarantine facility. The Ministry of Manpower and Ministry of Health have taken swift public health actions, including isolating and quarantining close contacts and conducting tests on all residents.

site_title: Canada judge adjourns Huawei executive's extradition hearing to August
summary: A Canadian judge has adjourned Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou's extradition hearing until August, granting her team time to review newly obtained HSBC documents. The delay, requested by Meng, upends the scheduled resumption of the British Columbia Supreme Court proceedings, which were set to last three weeks. Meng is accused of misrepresenting to HSBC links between Huawei and a company that sold telecoms equipment to Iran in violation of US sanctions. The adjournment will come as little relief to families of two Canadians jailed in China for "trumped-up" espionage charges, further straining Canada-China relations.

site_title: US police under scrutiny after new fatal shooting of Black suspect
summary: African-American father Andrew Brown, 40, was fatally shot by a police deputy in Elizabeth City, North Carolina, while attempting to flee. The incident occurred amid concerns over law enforcement shootings, following recent high-profile cases, including the conviction of Derek Chauvin for George Floyd's murder. Pasquotank County Sheriff Tommy Wooten has pledged transparency in the investigation, with the North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation handling the case.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back after two days of losses
summary: US stocks rebounded from two days of losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.9% to 34,137.31, the S&P 500 advancing 0.7% to 4,173.44, and the Nasdaq Composite Index surging 1.2% to 13,950.22. The recovery was driven by gains in industrial, oil, and financial companies, despite a 7.4% drop in Netflix due to lower-than-expected earnings. Other companies like Intuitive Surgical and CSX also saw significant gains, as investors took the drop as a cue to buy.

site_title: Yellen lays out 'bold' climate agenda for US economy, markets
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has outlined a "bold" climate agenda for the US economy, pledging to use all tools to tackle climate change and achieve net-zero emissions. Yellen emphasized the need for international cooperation and urged financial institutions to seize the opportunity presented by tackling climate change. She warned that failure to act could undermine economic growth, and called for greater disclosures of climate-related risks among companies. The Biden administration is set to unveil a target to cut emissions by 50% by 2030 at a climate summit on Thursday.

site_title: Two Vietnamese billionaires set to make a splash in US IPO markets
summary: Vietnamese billionaires Pham Nhat Vuong and Trinh Van Quyet are set to make a splash in the US IPO market, with Vingroup's VinFast unit aiming to raise $2 billion and Bamboo Airways seeking $200 million. The move comes as the US IPO market continues to boom, with over 100 listings in the first quarter of 2021. The two companies are expected to capitalize on the trend of digital transformation and the growth of venture capital markets. If successful, VinFast's IPO could be the biggest ever by a Vietnamese company, while Bamboo Airways aims to establish itself as a major player in the global aviation industry.

site_title: Complaints grow in China against Tesla autos
summary: Tesla faces backlash in China over a viral incident at the Shanghai Auto Show where a woman claimed her brakes failed, nearly killing her. The woman was jailed for 5 days, but her message sparked widespread concern. China's market watchdog agency and consumer protection agency issued statements, instructing Tesla to fulfill its quality and safety responsibilities. Tesla responded, saying it would address any issues, but also warned against "unreasonable customer demands." This comes as Chinese firms, including Huawei and Xiaomi, enter the electric vehicle market, with the Chinese government aiming for new-energy vehicles to comprise 25% of car sales by 2025.

images.alt_text: Electric carmaker Tesla is facing a backlash in China just as local competitors seek to challenge the US-based company's share of the Asian giant's market.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound on strong earnings, M&A speculation boosts Hugo Boss
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings and speculation about mergers and acquisitions, particularly in the healthcare and semiconductor sectors. Hugo Boss surged 6.7% amid takeover interest, while healthcare stocks like Roche and ASML jumped 3% and 4.1% respectively. The Stoxx 600 index is on track for a record 61% earnings growth in the first quarter, outperforming corporate America. Despite concerns about stretched valuations and inflation, markets remain optimistic ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday.

site_title: US dollar, yen rise as global outlook sours
summary: The US dollar rose on Wednesday, driven by a decline in global stock markets due to a resurgence of Covid-19 cases in countries such as India and Japan. The greenback's safe-haven appeal and softer US Treasury yields also contributed to its rise, with the dollar index up 0.11% at 91.321. The euro weakened 0.25% to US$1.2000, while the Australian dollar lost 0.4% to US$0.7717. The US dollar's rise is seen as a response to a soursing global outlook, with investors betting on a slower economic recovery.

site_title: Young investors need to watch leverage
summary: Singapore property investors, especially young ones, should be cautious when using leverage due to rising healthcare costs, tech disruptions, and stricter immigration rules. Experts advise keeping loan-to-value ratios below 50-60% and building up wealth through CPF savings before entering the market. They also stress the importance of diversification, considering sector and country concentration risks, and being clear about expectations on capital appreciation and rental returns.

site_title: Europe's rebel football league dead in water amid fans' fury
summary: The European Super League, a proposed breakaway football league, has collapsed just days after its launch due to opposition from fans, authorities, and politicians. Six English clubs, including Manchester United and Chelsea, withdrew from the project, followed by Atletico Madrid and Inter Milan. The league's collapse is seen as a victory for governing body UEFA and national leagues, which are pushing ahead with plans for a revamped Champions League. The project's architects, led by Juventus chairman Andrea Agnelli, have abandoned the plan, citing the need to "reshape the project" amid fan fury.

site_title: Big global banks burnishing Asia wealth strategy from Singapore vantage point
summary: Global banks are shifting their focus to Singapore as a key node for offshore wealth flows, with Citi doubling down on the city-state's potential. Singapore is the third-largest hub for cross-border wealth, with total bookings exceeding $1 trillion in 2019. Large banks are relying on institutional referrals and their globality to attract wealthy clients, and some have formed partnerships with local peers to tap into onshore markets. Despite regulations and know-your-customer requirements, the trend is expected to continue as banks seek to capture a share of the growing global wealth, particularly from Asia.

images.alt_text: A 2020 global wealth report by Boston Consulting Group found that Singapore is the third-largest hub for cross-border wealth, with total bookings in 2019 exceeding US$1 trillion.

site_title: Foxconn mostly abandons US$10b Wisconsin project touted by Trump
summary: Foxconn is drastically scaling back its US$10 billion factory project in Wisconsin, reducing investment to US$672 million and cutting new jobs to 1,454 from 13,000. The company's original plan, touted by former US President Donald Trump, was to build a 20-million-square-foot manufacturing campus for flat-panel display screens. However, the project faced opposition and concerns over supplier availability and water rights. The revised deal, announced on Tuesday, will save Wisconsin taxpayers US$2.77 billion and maintain accountability measures for job creation.

site_title: Apple targeted in US$50m ransomware hack of supplier Quanta
summary: Apple was targeted in a $50 million ransomware hack by the Russian group REvil, which claimed to have stolen blueprints for the company's latest products. The attack occurred on the same day as Apple's product launch, and the group published schematics for a new laptop, including internal designs from March 2021. REvil is demanding a ransom payment by May 1 and will continue to post stolen data unless the payment is made. Quanta, Apple's supplier, acknowledged the attack but did not disclose the extent of the data stolen.

site_title: Netflix's dominance slows as rivals gain
summary: Netflix's subscriber growth slowed in Q1 2021, with 4 million new customers, below its forecast of 6 million. The company reported 207.6 million total paying subscribers, but its share of viewers' attention has been cut by competitors like Disney+, HBO Max, and AppleTV+. Netflix's global demand for original programs, such as Bridgerton, has dropped relative to newcomers. Despite this, the company remains profitable, with $1.7 billion in profit and a $5 billion stock buyback plan.

site_title: Myanmar junta chief to attend Asean summit: report
summary: Myanmar's junta chief, General Min Aung Hlaing, is set to attend the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, despite international condemnation. The summit, scheduled for Saturday, will be the junta's first since the coup on February 1. Critics have called for the junta's leader to be excluded from the meeting, citing human rights abuses and the killing of hundreds of protesters. Myanmar's National Unity Government, which includes ousted politicians and pro-democracy activists, has also called for the junta to be excluded, citing the need for Asean to hear from the legitimate authority in Myanmar.

site_title: Offerors for Singapore Reinsurance, Procurri declare final prices
summary: Singapore Reinsurance Corp and Procurri Corporation have declared final prices for their respective offers. Singapore Reinsurance's offer price from Fairfax Asia of 35.35 Singapore cents remains unchanged, and the offer is unconditional after receiving 132.6 million shares representing 51.23% of the company's voting rights. Procurri's offer price of 36.5 Singapore cents from Novo Tellus is also final, except in a competitive situation, and has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by the company's independent financial adviser.

site_title: 22 Covid patients die in India after oxygen supply disrupted
summary: A 30-minute oxygen supply leak from a tanker outside a hospital in Nashik, India, killed 22 Covid-19 patients. The leak cut off oxygen to over 60 critically ill patients, but the supply was restored within half an hour. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi condemned the incident, and the state's chief minister ordered an inquiry. This tragedy comes as India battles severe shortages of medical supplies during its second wave of coronavirus infections.

site_title: European Super League failed to see that love of the game powers football
summary: The European Super League, a proposed breakaway football tournament, has been abandoned after 12 top-tier European clubs withdrew in response to fan protests and criticism from governing bodies. The league's failure represents a battle over the sport's soul, highlighting the importance of understanding fan sentiment and the human element in decision-making. The collapse serves as a reminder that economics is a human science, and neglecting this can lead to disastrous consequences, as seen in the backlash against the European Super League.

site_title: Thai tycoon's US$17b bid for telecom giants draws sceptics
summary: Thai tycoon Sarath Ratanavadi's US$17 billion bid to acquire control of telecom giants Intouch Holdings and Advanced Info Service has drawn skepticism from analysts. Gulf Energy Development's added debt is expected to be substantial, with net debt nearly doubling to 120 billion baht last year. Analysts question the cost-benefit ratio, citing a lack of clear synergy between energy and telecommunications, and the potential for marginal value addition. Despite optimism over the post-pandemic era and potential for digital transformation, investors remain cautious about the proposal.

site_title: Take bold steps to redesign work, thrive in new normal
summary: The Singapore government has announced measures to support organizations in shifting from responding to Covid-19 to thriving in the pandemic. These measures include extending the Jobs and Skills Package to support local workers and introducing the Emerging Technology Programme to help businesses digitize and access global markets. The government is encouraging organizations to think outside the box and make fundamental changes to their work, workforce, and workplace. A survey found that 61% of business executives globally are considering re-architecting work, and 80% of Singapore respondents plan to reimagine work in the next 1-3 years.

site_title: Reduce, reuse, recycle: Meet business people who do it
summary: Today marks Earth Day, highlighting the importance of reducing, reusing, and recycling. BTLifestyle shines a spotlight on local entrepreneurs who have incorporated eco-friendly policies into their work, such as making compostable packaging and sustainable apparel. New technology plays a key role in developing products for a sustainable lifestyle. The article also features an exhibition on Japanese beauty and reviews a popular nasi lemak eatery undergoing a major revamp.

site_title: Post failed merger, Sabana sets sights on asset revamps, disposals
summary: Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit, after aborting its merger with ESR-Reit, plans to divest non-performing assets and upgrade others to improve resilience and growth. The REIT has completed NTP+, a food and beverage-focused mall, and is upgrading its industrial park. The move aims to boost its portfolio valuation and improve its growth trajectory despite constraints.

site_title: Landed property deals reap tidy profits in Q1 2021
summary: In Q1 2021, landed properties dominated the top profit-making deals in Singapore, with record-breaking sales, including a freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) at Nassim Road sold for S$128.8 million. Non-landed properties, however, did not fare well, with many units purchased during the 2007 market peak or sold due to unfavorable circumstances. The proportion of loss-making transactions edged up to 14.6% in Q1 2021, lower than 16.8% in 2020. Experts attribute the improved market to economic growth and labor market stabilization.

site_title: Pot of gold at end of Singapore property rainbow? Not a sure thing anymore
summary: Singapore's long-term capital appreciation in private homes and real estate investment trusts (Reits) may not be repeated, say observers. The attractive past performance is attributed to the maturity of the market and cooling measures. OCBC Investment Research shows that prices of private homes and Reits outperformed the general stock market over five periods, but the outlook is uncertain for commercial and retail Reits. Experts predict that private home prices will grow in tandem with nominal GDP, while Reits in the logistics and industrial trusts segment may benefit from a benign environment.

site_title: China should not rush to use digital yuan across borders
summary: China's former central bank governor Zhou Xiaochuan advises against rushing the use of digital yuan for cross-border payments due to regulatory obstacles and foreign concerns. The digital yuan, primarily for domestic retail payments, faces issues such as money laundering and terrorist funding restrictions. Zhou notes that the yuan's global status will depend on China's economy, currency stability, and convertibility. Foreign concerns about the digital yuan potentially threatening the global financial system are downplayed, with Zhou stating that China's goal is not to replace the US dollar.

site_title: Strengthening consumer confidence boosts March retail sales in Australia
summary: Australia's retail sales exceeded expectations in March with a 1.4% increase, driven by soaring house prices and a surge in employment boosting consumer confidence and spending. Sales rose 2.3% from March last year, with household consumption fueled by record-low borrowing costs and government welfare payments. Despite a 0.1% decline in sales values in the first quarter, consumer spending growth is expected to remain strong this year, driven by a recovery in jobs and low interest rates.

site_title: Citi, UBS among 40 banks to join Carney's climate action pledge
summary: More than 40 global banks, including Citi and UBS, have signed the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, pledging to cut pollution from their portfolios and reach net-zero emissions by 2050. Led by former Bank of England governor Mark Carney, the alliance brings together 160 companies responsible for $70 trillion in assets. Banks have agreed to align emissions with net-zero pathways, set 2030 targets, and focus on polluting sectors. The move comes ahead of the US President Joe Biden's global climate summit and is seen as a step towards supporting the Paris Agreement's goal to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: It's vital for all to work together to beat the heat
summary: Singapore is experiencing rising temperatures, with an annual mean temperature increase from 26.9°C to 28.0°C from 1980 to 2020. The World Economic Forum's Special Annual Meeting 2021 in Singapore will address climate change and its social and economic impacts. Rising heat and humidity levels pose significant challenges, affecting livelihoods, infrastructure, and the economy. Climate change mitigation and adaptation are essential for a sustainable future, and government and business leaders are urged to take action on Earth Day.

site_title: Tesla says sorry as disquiet in China climbs after protest
summary: Tesla has apologized to Chinese consumers after a woman's car brakes failed at the Shanghai Auto Show, causing her to nearly die. The incident led to criticism from government entities, including China's state-run Xinhua news agency and the Communist Party's discipline commission, over Tesla's consumer service attitude. The company has received backlash in China, where it has enjoyed government support and perks, and faces increasing competition from local EV players such as Nio and Xpeng. Tesla's deliveries in China have been record-breaking, but the company's reputation is under scrutiny.

site_title: Australia cancels China's Belt and Road deal with Victoria state
summary: Australia has cancelled agreements between China's Belt and Road Initiative and the Victoria state government, citing concerns over foreign policy and relations. The decision, made by Foreign Minister Marise Payne, comes under laws passed in December allowing the federal government to block agreements with overseas governments. The move worsens ties between the two nations, which have been strained since Australia called for an independent probe into the coronavirus origins. China has responded with trade reprisals, including crippling tariffs on Australian barley and wine.

site_title: Stable rents expected for single- and multiple-user factory space this year
summary: Singapore's factory space rents are expected to remain stable this year due to new supply and uneven manufacturing sector growth. The National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies (IREUS) forecasts 885,000 sq m of single-user factory space and 1.14 million sq m of multiple-user and single-user factory space to be added to the market. The government may regulate supply to keep industrial rents stable, and manufacturers can seize opportunities to expand their footprint ahead of a potential recovery.

site_title: Australia cancels Victoria's Belt and Road deals with China
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Marise Payne has cancelled two deals with China, including two agreements struck by Victoria state in 2018 and 2019, as part of a new process allowing her to review foreign deals by states and universities. The decision comes amid a diplomatic spat with China, which has imposed trade sanctions on Australian exports. The cancellation follows a federal parliament grant of veto power over foreign deals by states, a move that has been denied to be aimed at China. Four deals, including the cancelled agreements, have been notified to Payne.

site_title: When companies share their space for social causes
summary: Kim Choo Kueh Chang, a Singaporean Peranakan food and collectibles store, partnered with Collaborate for Good to support local frontliners during the pandemic. The store loaned its space for donations of face masks and sanitizers, and also hired staff with high-functioning autism or special needs as community guides or kitchen staff. This initiative aligns with the company's corporate social responsibility framework. Similar partnerships have been established with WeWork Singapore, Suntec Singapore, and Preschool Market, demonstrating the potential for businesses to support social causes while promoting sustainability.

images.alt_text: Besides loaning its space to do good, Kim Choo Kueh Chang has been impacting its local community by hiring and training staff with high-functioning autism or special needs as community guides or kitchen staff.

site_title: Hotels get lean and mean with machines and job redesign
summary: Singapore's hotel sector has weathered the pandemic downturn better than expected, with hotels adopting technology and job redesign to reduce reliance on foreign workers. The industry has seen a 9,300 job loss in the accommodation workforce, compared to 9,000 in aviation, 10,000 in retail, and 15,400 in food and beverage. To mitigate job losses, the government has launched the Job Redesign Reskilling (JRR) programme, which has helped cushion the impact and moderate job losses.
