summary: Macrotech Developers Ltd, India's biggest homebuilder, made its market debut with a 13% drop in shares amid high Covid-19 cases. The IPO, valued at 25 billion rupees, is the third-largest this year and aims to reduce debt by 15 billion rupees. Despite a strong overall performance by India's newest stocks, the benchmark S&P BSE Sensex gauge fell 2.6% due to rising infections. The company plans to sell assets to reduce net debt to 127 billion rupees from 184 billion rupees.

site_title: Singtel reviewing strategic options for its Thai units following bid for them
summary: Singtel is reviewing strategic options for its Thai units, Advanced Info Service (AIS) and Intouch Holdings, after a bid from Thai-listed power producer Gulf Energy Development. The offer, valued at an 11% premium, may not be enough to persuade Singtel to sell, with analysts citing the firm's long-term outlook for the businesses and the relatively low premium. Analysts expect Singtel to maintain its interest in AIS unless offered a higher price, with some speculating that the offer could boost Singtel's share price temporarily.

site_title: UK home prices hit new peak in buying frenzy on tax break, low interest rates
summary: UK home prices reached a record high in April, with the average cost rising 2.1% to £327,797, driven by a tax break and low interest rates. The surge is attributed to a "buying frenzy" as buyers seek to move out of cities following the pandemic, with almost a quarter of sales being for properties on the market less than a week. The trend is expected to remain robust for the rest of 2021, but may lose some steam as government support unwinds.

site_title: Orocobre buys Galaxy to form world's 5th-largest lithium company
summary: Orocobre Ltd and Galaxy Resources have formed the world's fifth-largest lithium company through a $4 billion tie-up, creating Australia's largest lithium pure play. The deal will produce over 130,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent and grant the merged company a strong balance sheet. Orocobre CEO Martin Perez de Solay will take the top job, while Galaxy CEO Simon Hay will be president of international business. The deal, expected to complete in August, has the unanimous support of the Galaxy board and will see Orocobre shareholders own 54.2% of the combined entity.

site_title: E-commerce giants bulk up on logistics, but it's not endgame for 3rd-party players
summary: E-commerce giants in South-east Asia are expanding their in-house logistics capabilities, potentially disrupting the third-party logistics (3PL) industry. Marketplaces such as Shopee, Lazada, and Amazon are investing in warehouses and logistics fleets, giving them more control over supply chains and pricing power. This trend may lead to consolidation among 3PLs, with some predicting a mid-to-long-term disruption. However, 3PLs are adapting, with some companies focusing on efficiency gains and strategic partnerships to stay competitive.

site_title: What's next for Jack Ma's Ant Group after China orders revamp?
summary: China has ordered a restructuring plan for Jack Ma's Ant Group, the fintech conglomerate, which will see the group become a financial holdings company. Ant needs to raise 13.4-20.1 billion yuan (S$2.7-4.1 billion) to meet minimum capital adequacy ratio requirements, but it's unclear how it will raise capital. The restructuring may also lead to founder Ma's stake and control being divested. Ant's payment business and valuation are expected to change as part of the plan, with some investors optimistic that the company will not be valued cheaply.

site_title: Expectations of commodities supercycle could be misplaced
summary: A commodities "boom" fueled by unprecedented fiscal and monetary impulses may not be on the cusp of a supercycle, experts say. The current rally is driven by liquidity and inflation-hedging appetite, rather than structural demand changes. A growing China shift to a consumption-based economy and the limited impact of the green revolution on metals like copper and nickel also cast doubt on a supercycle. As the Covid-19 story continues, markets should remain vigilant for a potential correction. The current upswing is more of a cyclical recovery than a multi-year bull run.

site_title: Singa to fund Deep Tunnel Sewerage System
summary: Singapore is funding a S$10 billion Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS), a 100km underground conveyance system for treating used water, scheduled for completion by 2025. The project, which will free up space on land, is one of the nationally significant infrastructure projects to be funded through borrowing under the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (Singa). The government will spread the cost over many years, with each generation bearing part of it, and the project is expected to last for at least 50 years.

site_title: Godzilla vs Kong tops North American box office for third straight weekend
summary: Godzilla vs Kong topped the North American box office for its third consecutive weekend, adding $7.7 million in ticket sales and boosting its total to $80.5 million. The film is the first to cross the $100 million mark since the pandemic began, with Warner Bros' entire 2021 slate following a similar release pattern due to the impaired marketplace. Other holdover titles, such as Nobody and The Unholy, also performed well, while Disney's Raya and the Last Dragon and Tom and Jerry rounded out the top five.

site_title: Road back to Iran nuclear deal is paved with obstacles
summary: US President Joe Biden has decided to revoke the 2018 decision to withdraw from the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, aiming to restore the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPA) and relax international sanctions. However, this move faces significant opposition from powerful forces at home and abroad, including 43 Republican and Democratic Senators, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who demand Iran agree to stricter nuclear and missile restrictions. Diplomatic efforts, led by President Biden's special envoy to Iran, Robert Malley, are underway in Vienna, but a gradual process of lifting sanctions in exchange for Iranian concessions is seen as a possible solution.

site_title: Families reunite as Australia-New Zealand travel bubble begins after almost 400 days of border closure
summary: Australia and New Zealand launched a quarantine-free travel bubble, ending a 400-day border closure. Emotional reunions took place at airports as families were reunited after almost two years apart. The move aims to boost tourism and economic ties between the two countries. The travel bubble is a significant step towards normalizing relations between the two nations, which were severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Asian drivers warming up more to EVs, but there's still a way to go
summary: Singapore aims to register only cleaner-energy cars in nine years as part of its national sustainability movement, The Green Plan. However, a Deloitte survey found that Singaporean drivers are still leaning towards internal combustion engine vehicles, with 64% preferring petrol/diesel engines. Only 44% of Singaporean consumers said they would choose more fuel-efficient options, with concerns about battery electric vehicles (BEVs) including lack of charging infrastructure, safety concerns, and cost/price premium. The survey suggests that government support for electric vehicles is crucial in encouraging their uptake in the region.

site_title: Making a difference, one word at a time
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) has launched a volunteer reading programme to help "reluctant readers" from underprivileged students, with over 120 pupils benefiting since its inception in 2015. The programme, which takes a hiatus during the pandemic, has been a success, with bank employees finding it beneficial to their job satisfaction. The initiative promotes social interaction skills and reading habits among students, and has become one of the bank's most successful employee-volunteering programmes.

site_title: From private equity to grocery business
summary: Joe Stevens, a former Standard Chartered banker, runs Little Farms, a gourmet grocery store in Singapore, focusing on natural and organic produce. He faces challenges such as technology adoption and financial issues among employees. Despite recording losses, the business has grown its customer base and revenue over the past five years. Stevens plans to expand the company, introducing healthy ready-to-eat meals and enhancing its e-commerce experience. He expects the trend towards healthier eating to accelerate in Singapore and Asia, with opportunities for growth in the region.

site_title: Credit Suisse serves investors gruel as Wall Street feasts on deals
summary: Credit Suisse faces an anticipated pre-tax loss of nearly US$1 billion for the first quarter due to the collapse of Archegos and Greensill Capital. The bank's investment bank and asset management division are under scrutiny, with investors seeking clarity on the future. CEO Thomas Gottstein has announced that incoming chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio will undertake a strategic review, and the bank has slashed costs through bonus cuts. Credit Suisse's share price has fallen 15% this year, and shareholders are facing a reduced dividend and halted share buybacks.

site_title: By plane or raft, parcel delivery startups going places in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asian parcel delivery startups are expanding aggressively, with companies like Indonesian courier J&T Express and Singapore's Ninja Van launching their own cargo aircraft and investing heavily in infrastructure. J&T Express added a Boeing 737-300 aircraft for next-day delivery, while Ninja Van expanded its network of pick-up and drop-off points, and hired over 34,000 employees. The move is seen as a sign of how third-party logistics startups are growing in the region, with experts predicting further innovation in last-mile logistics, including flexible delivery options and payment methods.

site_title: Herman Miller to buy Knoll for US$1.8b in workplace bet
summary: Herman Miller agreed to acquire rival office-furniture company Knoll for $1.8 billion. The deal aims to capitalize on workplace renovations and restructurings as the pandemic eases. The combined company expects $100 million in annual cost savings within two years. Herman Miller CEO Andi Owen will lead the merged entity, with Knoll Chairman and CEO Andrew Cogan stepping down. The acquisition is expected to generate growth through the transformation of home and office spaces as work continues to be split between the two.

site_title: Coronavirus: co-existence or eradication?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has reached a critical point, with a global infection count of over 150 million and a death toll of over three million. Experts argue that attempting to eradicate the disease is unrealistic due to its widespread presence and the potential for variants to emerge. However, the author challenges this view, citing the potential for herd immunity through widespread vaccination and the need to address the virus's proven mutability. The author concludes that seeking eradication of COVID-19 is now a more realistic policy, requiring coordinated efforts from wealthy countries to implement vaccination programs, isolation, and treatment in vulnerable areas.

site_title: Malacca unveils plan to draw RM100b to new economic zone as tourism falters
summary: Malacca, Malaysia has unveiled a 15-year plan to develop a coastal economic zone, the Melaka Waterfront Economic Zone (M-WEZ), to boost investment and diversify the local economy, which relies heavily on tourism. The RM100 billion project aims to create 20,000 new jobs annually and attract high-impact investments. The zone will span 33km of coastal and reclaimed land, with a focus on the maritime sector, and is expected to be completed by 2035. The project is seen as a "game changer" for the state, which has faced a slump in tourism income due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: BMW's China joint venture to start production in 2023
summary: BMW's China joint venture with Great Wall Motor Co is set to start production in 2023, with the goal of having electric vehicles make up one-quarter of its sales in the country. Construction of a manufacturing plant is "well under way," and production of two Mini EVs for China and global markets will start in 2023. China remains the world's largest electric vehicle market, with BMW CEO Jochen Goller remaining optimistic about the long-term outlook for the country's car market despite intense competition.

site_title: Investing in health will have pay-offs in the economy
summary: Investing in health can have significant pay-offs for the economy, particularly in Asian economies where poor health reduces GDP by 14% each year. Research by McKinsey Global Institute found that implementing known health interventions could reduce Asia's disease burden by 40% over 20 years, boosting Singapore's GDP by $38 billion in 2040, a 7% increase. A healthier workforce would lead to lower healthcare costs, increased productivity, and more socially and economically active individuals, ultimately contributing to a higher return on investment.

site_title: MPA honours SMF chairman Sohmen-Pao, 10 companies for maritime contributions
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) honored 10 companies and Singapore Maritime Foundation chairman Andreas Sohmen-Pao for their maritime contributions at the biennial Singapore International Maritime Awards. The recipients included bunker suppliers, ship owners, and research and development technology firms, with a focus on sustainability and decarbonization. Sembcorp Marine received the Sustainability Award and BW Group won the Singapore Registry of Ships Green Ship Owner Award, recognizing efforts to reduce carbon emissions in the Port of Singapore and promote energy-efficient ship designs.

site_title: Top European clubs to launch breakaway Super League
summary: Twelve top European football clubs, including six Premier League teams, announced the launch of a breakaway European Super League, sparking accusations of greed and cynicism. The ESL aims to create a midweek competition with guaranteed qualification for its 15 founding members, who will receive substantial solidarity payments. However, UEFA and national football authorities threatened to bar the clubs from their national competitions and the Champions League, and FIFA expressed disapproval, calling for calm dialogue.

images.alt_text: Liverpool's German manager Jurgen Klopp raising the trophy after winning the Uefa Champions League final against Tottenham Hotspur in June 2019.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has entered a non-binding term sheet with Temasek for a joint venture, Hydrogen Energy, to utilize Nanofilm's advanced materials in hydrogen energy systems. The joint venture aims to apply Nanofilm's surface solutions to fuel cell and electrolyser systems. This partnership aims to tap into the growing hydrogen energy economy.

site_title: Citi to step up China investment banking, trading as it exits retail business there
summary: Citi is expanding its investment banking and trading operations in China after exiting retail banking in the country. The bank plans to apply for securities and futures brokering licenses within two months, aiming to launch the businesses in 12-18 months. A CEO will be named soon, and 50 initial hires will be made, with plans to grow to around 100 staff. This move follows foreign banks' aggressive expansion plans in China, seeking to double or triple their staffing in the $54 trillion financial market.

site_title: What SMEs can learn from their larger counterparts amid Covid-19
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can learn valuable lessons from larger counterparts amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Key takeaways include: planning for multiple scenarios, investing in technology to improve efficiency and cash flow management, surrounding themselves with the right expertise, and understanding their value in the market. Having a strong plan in place that can be adapted to changing circumstances is crucial for SMEs to navigate economic uncertainty. By adopting these strategies, SMEs can set themselves up for success and be better equipped to handle future challenges.

site_title: How a legendary New York hotel became a battleground
summary: The Chelsea Hotel in New York, a legendary residence hotel, has been stuck in endless construction since 2011, preventing it from operating as a boutique hotel. Despite multiple developers attempting to revamp the property, it remains suspended. The hotel's owners struggle to spin the project into an upscale hotel, and the site has become a character in its own right, with ongoing drilling and construction. The hotel's past as a bohemian hub is still remembered, but its current state is marked by stagnation and uncertainty.

site_title: EU sanctions 10 Myanmar junta officials, two firms
summary: The EU has imposed sanctions on 10 Myanmar junta officials and two conglomerates, the Myanmar Economic Corporation (MEC) and Myanmar Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL), due to the coup and violent crackdown on protesters. The measures, set to take effect, aim to increase pressure on the military regime to negotiate. The sanctions follow previous EU sanctions on junta chief Min Aung Hlaing and 10 other senior officials. The EU's actions are part of efforts by Western powers to target the military's key moneymakers and bring an end to the violence in Myanmar.

site_title: Microsoft to invest US$1b in Malaysia to set up data centres
summary: Microsoft plans to invest US$1 billion in Malaysia over five years, part of a new partnership with government agencies and local companies. The investment will establish a data-centre region, enabling the government and businesses to transform their operations. Additionally, Microsoft will assist up to a million Malaysians in acquiring digital skills by 2023. This investment comes after Malaysia's decline in foreign direct investments (FDI) by 68% last year, and is seen as a boost to the country's efforts to attract more FDI.

site_title: Why the world needs new generation of 'green' accords
summary: The world needs a new generation of 'green' accords to address the growing environmental crisis, with governments recognizing the need for broader, more effective international agreements. Traditional short-term priorities often override environmental commitments, and lack of enforcement mechanisms hinder progress. To overcome this, governments must engage with national lawmakers to create durable domestic laws, increase transparency, and strengthen national governance structures. This approach has already led to successful climate legislation in countries like South Korea and Mexico, and could deliver game-changing results if scaled up.

site_title: Leveraging current momentum to go green post-Covid-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a temporary reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, but the world still needs to take drastic measures to address climate change. The United Nations estimates that over 110 countries have committed to carbon neutrality, but many are not on track to meet the Paris Agreement goals. In response, Singapore has unveiled its Green Plan 2030, aiming to become the world's greenest country by doubling down on sustainability efforts. The plan includes targets to reduce emissions, increase renewable energy, and promote eco-friendly transportation. With the momentum from the pandemic, countries are expected to raise their carbon emission targets at the upcoming Climate Change Conference (COP26).

site_title: Non-stop cremations cast doubt on India's counting of Covid dead
summary: India's non-stop cremations during the Covid-19 pandemic have raised concerns about the accuracy of the country's death toll. Crematoriums in major cities have reported far higher numbers of cremations than official Covid-19 death tolls, with some cremating over 100 bodies a day under Covid protocols. Experts say this discrepancy may be due to underreporting, with many deaths not being medically certified, particularly in rural areas. The discrepancy is not unique to India, but the testimony of workers and academic research suggest deaths in India are being underreported compared to other countries.

site_title: Econ Healthcare relists on Catalist with first-day premium of 3.6% to its IPO price
summary: Econ Healthcare, a Singapore-based private nursing home operator, relisted on the Catalist board with a first-day premium of 3.6% to its IPO price of S$0.28, ending at S$0.29. The company received applications for 86.9 times the number of shares available, with net proceeds planned for expansion and upgrading existing facilities. Econ Healthcare aims to capitalize on growing demand for quality eldercare services in Singapore, Malaysia, and China, driven by affluent and aging populations.

site_title: Xi's Boao Forum speech to focus on risks and challenges the world is facing
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will address the Boao Forum, focusing on global risks and challenges, and his country's solutions. The forum, attended by Chinese officials and business leaders, discusses topics like digital currencies, carbon neutrality, and post-pandemic economics. China's top financial watchdog is monitoring hedge fund inflows to ensure financial stability as the country opens its capital markets. The event aims to attract foreign capital and showcases China's economic outlook.

site_title: Zoom launches US$100m fund to invest in apps using its technology
summary: Zoom has launched a $100 million fund to invest in startup software companies that build apps using its video conferencing technology. The fund will provide investments of $250,000 to $2.5 million to companies creating "Zoom Apps" that add new features to Zoom's platform. The investments will focus on early-stage developers and aim to encourage the creation of new functions, such as digital whiteboards and telemedicine apps, to enhance Zoom's cloud-based video systems.

site_title: 'Dulux dog' breed faces extinction in Britain
summary: The Old English Sheepdog, a British dog breed known for its shaggy coat, has been listed as vulnerable to extinction by the Kennel Club due to declining popularity. The breed's numbers have dropped significantly since its peak in the late 1970s, with just 227 puppy registrations recorded in 2020. This move marks the first time the breed has been listed as vulnerable to extinction by the club. The decline is attributed to a decrease in popularity over the years.

site_title: Britain to add India to Covid-19 travel red-list
summary: Britain has added India to its travel "red-list" due to 103 cases of a coronavirus variant first identified in the country. Non-UK and Irish residents will not be allowed to enter the UK if they've been in India in the past 10 days, while UK residents will need to complete 10-day hotel quarantine upon arrival. The rules take effect at 4 am local time on Friday.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors look to earnings for recovery cues
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Monday, retreating from record levels as investors awaited the first-quarter earnings season for corporate recovery cues from the Covid-19 pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 18.3 points, or 0.05%, and the S&P 500 dropped 5.7 points, or 0.14%. Investors looked for hints on corporate recovery, despite US President Trump's tariff threats.

site_title: Webster Financial to buy Sterling in US$5.14b acquisition
summary: Webster Financial agreed to purchase Sterling Bancorp in an all-stock transaction valued at US$5.14 billion. Sterling investors will receive 0.463 shares of Webster for each of their shares, valuing Sterling shares at US$26.56. The deal is part of US regional banks' efforts to combine in response to low interest rates and technological competition. After completion, the bank will have US$63 billion in assets and US$52 billion in deposits, with its headquarters in Stamford, Connecticut.

site_title: Genting Malaysia bets big on SkyWorlds
summary: Genting Malaysia's $800 million SkyWorlds theme park is set to open in mid-2021, despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Experts believe the leisure sector will recover within six months to a year after Malaysia's vaccination targets are met. The park's opening is expected to draw traffic to Resorts World Genting's casino, potentially boosting earnings. While some analysts predict the park may not turn a profit, others see it as a catalyst for Genting Malaysia's recovery and a way to funnel visitors onto casino floors, which could offset losses.

images.alt_text: A pandemic is a strange time to launch a mega-attraction, what with the closed international borders and curbs on domestic leisure activities.

site_title: China's Ant explores ways for Jack Ma to exit as Beijing piles on pressure
summary: China's Ant Group is exploring options for founder Jack Ma to divest his stake and give up control, potentially clearing the way for the company to revive its plans to go public. The move comes after Beijing's scrutiny of the business, with regulators signaling that divestment could help draw a line under the pressure. This could pave the way for Ant to revive its IPO plans, which stalled after Ma's speech.

images.alt_text: Beijing has since late last year unleashed a series of investigations and new regulations that have not only reined in Mr Ma's empire but also swept across the country's technology sector.

site_title: Pacific Ocean storm intensifies into year's first super typhoon
summary: A powerful storm, Surigae, intensified into the year's first super typhoon in the Pacific Ocean, affecting the eastern Philippines. The storm killed one man, triggered flooding, and forced over 100,000 evacuations. With winds reaching 195 km/h and a diameter of 500 km, Surigae is not expected to hit land but highlights a potentially busy storm season. Experts say the 2021 typhoon season is expected to be at least average, possibly above average, due to global warming.

site_title: Coca-Cola tops sales expectations amid vaccine-led reopening
summary: Coca-Cola's first-quarter sales exceeded expectations, driven by early signs of recovery in demand, particularly in areas with higher vaccination rates. Organic revenue climbed 6% in the quarter, topping analyst estimates. The company plans to sell a portion of its Coca-Cola Beverages Africa bottling business through an initial public offering, which could value the business at around $6 billion. Despite commodity inflation pressures, Coca-Cola is "well-hedged" to withstand costs and expects to maintain its forecast for organic sales and earnings growth.

site_title: Libra Group seeks to extend moratoria
summary: Libra Group, a Catalist-listed company, has applied to the High Court for an extension of its existing moratorium, set to expire on April 30, in order to further discuss a potential investor and engage with creditors. The company has received a term sheet from a new investor and plans to seek their involvement during the moratorium period. Trading in Libra's shares has been suspended due to its inability to continue as a going concern.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Asia-Pacific ex-Japan's share of global M&A falls to 14% in first quarter
summary: Asia-Pacific excluding Japan's share of global M&A fell to 14% in the first quarter, with North America capturing 54.4% of the market share. However, analysts predict a comeback in the second quarter as the global Covid vaccination campaign resumes and many Asian markets return from the Chinese New Year break. Meanwhile, other news includes Vietnam's reaction to a US tariff announcement, Malaysia's industrial production rising 0.3%, and a potential rebound for GoTo shares after a US$2.2 billion sell-off.

site_title: Fuelled by China, auto supplier Faurecia sees robust Q2 growth
summary: Faurecia, a French car parts maker, reported robust Q2 growth driven by surging sales in China, which jumped 88% from the previous year. The company beat market expectations with 8.9% organic sales growth on a reported basis. Despite low car production, finance chief Michel Favre expects a dynamic pace to restart once semiconductors become available. Faurecia confirmed its financial targets and predicted strong organic sales growth, setting a high benchmark for peers.

site_title: UK intervenes in Nvidia's takeover of Arm Holdings on national security grounds
summary: The UK has intervened in Nvidia's $40 billion takeover of Arm Holdings on national security grounds. Digital Secretary Oliver Dowden issued an intervention notice, requesting a report from the UK's independent competition authority to assess the implications of the deal. The UK concerns that the takeover could lead to a loss of control over a vital supplier to multiple silicon chip makers, potentially generating a single player dominating the market.

site_title: Greens name Annalena Baerbock as candidate to succeed Merkel
summary: Germany's Green party has named Annalena Baerbock, 40, as their candidate to succeed Chancellor Angela Merkel. This move throws a challenge to the conservative party, which has been divided over Merkel's succession. Baerbock, a former trampolining competitor and trained lawyer, has surged in popularity in recent months, criticizing the government for not prioritizing children during the pandemic and proposing her own policies. The Greens now have a genuine chance of becoming the biggest party and taking the chancellery, which could mark a new chapter for the party and the country.

site_title: Nanofilm seeks opportunities in hydrogen with Temasek joint venture
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has entered into a non-binding term sheet with Temasek to form a joint venture, Sydrogen Energy, to apply its advanced materials surface solutions to hydrogen energy components. The venture aims to bring about a "tipping point" in the mass commercial adoption of the proprietary technology, focusing on fuel cell applications. Nanofilm will hold a majority stake in the joint venture, with the goal of overcoming cost and durability issues in fuel cells and electrolysers, and accelerating the adoption of hydrogen energy.

site_title: India locks down capital to battle coronavirus outbreak
summary: India has locked down its capital New Delhi for a week to control a raging coronavirus outbreak, with hospitals running out of beds and the government re-imposing restrictions. The city of 20 million has seen a record high of 273,810 infections, the fifth consecutive day of over 200,000 cases. The lockdown comes as India has the world's second-highest caseload with over 15 million known infections. The move follows similar measures in other parts of India, and the UK has cancelled Prime Minister Boris Johnson's visit due to the surge.

site_title: J&J Covid-19 vaccine manufacturing halted at US plant
summary: US Food and Drug Administration halts production of Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine at a US manufacturing plant in Baltimore due to an error that led to millions of doses being ruined. The halt was requested by the FDA on April 16, pending completion of an inspection. Johnson & Johnson will work with the FDA and the plant's owner, Emergent BioSolutions, to address any findings.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.09 points to 1,600.29. Losers outnumbered gainers 739 to 397, with a total trading volume of 7.468 billion lots worth RM4.102 billion.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q1 operational cash flow up 15.6%
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 15.6% increase in operational cash flow for the first quarter, driven by strong performance from infrastructure asset Ixom and the acquisition of Philippine Coastal Storage & Pipeline Corporation. Operational cash flows reached S$66.5 million, up from S$57.5 million in the same period last year. Ixom's cash flows benefited from a strong Australian dollar, while the Philippine Coastal acquisition is expected to drive long-term sustainable returns. KIT's units closed S$0.54, down 1.8% on the day.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore plans to establish a global maritime decarbonisation centre to coordinate and drive solutions. Sembcorp will terminate a utilities services agreement with Eastman Chemical Singapore. Singtel is reviewing strategic options for its stakes in associates. Frasers Property secured a $300m sustainability-linked loan in Australia. A Singapore cybersecurity firm launched the world's first AI-embedded solid-state drive. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to close at 3,209.72.

site_title: Hoe Leong Corp pursues voluntary liquidation of three vessel units
summary: Hoe Leong Corp has placed three subsidiaries under creditors' voluntary liquidation, following the disposal of vessels. The subsidiaries, Arkstar Offshore, Arkstar Voyager, and Arkstar Unicorn, have ceased their vessel-chartering business. The company expects to gain S$1 million from the deconsolidation, to be recognized for the 2021 financial year. Abuthahir Abdul Gafoor and Yessica Budiman have been appointed liquidators. Trading of Hoe Leong's shares has been suspended since September 2019.

site_title: Gojek co-CEO to head app giant GoTo after merger with Tokopedia
summary: Gojek co-CEO Andre Soelistyo will head the newly formed Indonesian app giant GoTo after a merger with Tokopedia. The holding company, GoTo, will have 58% ownership by Gojek's shareholders and the remaining 42% by Tokopedia's owners. Patrick Cao will retain his title as president of the new entity. The merger aims to create a combined entity, combining Gojek's transport and delivery services with Tokopedia's e-commerce platform.

site_title: Phase 2 of underground 'highway' for used water to be financed through borrowing
summary: Singapore is financing the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) Phase 2, a 100km-long underground water conveyance system, through borrowing under the newly introduced Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (Singa). The S$10 billion project aims to free up land by moving facilities for treating used water underground. The government will borrow up to S$90 billion to pay for infrastructure that lasts for at least 50 years, spreading the cost over multiple generations. The project, expected to be completed by 2025, will reduce land usage and improve water resilience.

site_title: Abercrombie & Fitch to close sole Singapore outlet in May
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch is closing its sole Singapore outlet in Knightsbridge Mall on May 2, without giving a reason. The Singapore flagship store, which opened in 2011, employed about 800 people and occupied 21,000 square feet. This closure follows the company's announcement to close several flagship stores globally last November.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin the week in the black; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.25% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,209.72. Sembcorp Industries led gains, advancing 9.79%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding followed closely. However, Thai Beverage slumped 3.36% after the deferment of its subsidiary BeerCo's listing. Aviation counters Singapore Airlines and Sats also declined. Markets in Asia and Europe also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 1.49% and the Nikkei 225 closing flat.

site_title: Basement-level KTV unit at The Adelphi up for sale via expression of interest
summary: A 999-year leasehold strata retail unit at The Adelphi in Singapore is up for sale via expression of interest. The 4,090 sq ft unit, approved for KTV use, is fully leased and located next to an escalator for high visibility. The unit's sale price is expected to be in the range of S$2,685 to S$3,573 per square foot, similar to recent sales of basement units at The Adelphi. The sale will close on May 18, with no buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty applied. Foreigners are eligible to purchase.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: How to ride the next phase of the bull market (Ep 6)
summary: Singapore's bull market is expected to continue, with key takeaways from the BT Mark To Market podcast. Controlling shareholders are buying back companies cheaply, and many Singapore stocks are trading below their book values. This has been a catalyst for local stocks, particularly through value unlocking. To ride the bull market, investors should look for stocks that have potential for growth beyond mere value unlocking, and consider consulting a financial adviser before making any investment decisions.

site_title: New Zealand says it will set China policy, not Five Eyes
summary: New Zealand's Foreign Minister Nanaia Mahuta announced the country will set its own policy for dealing with China, distancing itself from the US-led Five Eyes intelligence alliance. Mahuta stated New Zealand prefers multilateral opportunities to express its interests rather than relying on the Five Eyes. The move comes after New Zealand recently sealed a free trade agreement with China and amid growing tensions with Australia, a key Five Eyes partner.

site_title: Deals of the week: Bukalapak gets more GIC funds; EDBI backs cancer biotech
summary: Bukalapak raised US$234 million led by Microsoft, GIC, and Emtek, with plans to list in Indonesia and potentially merge with a US SPAC. Biotech startup Immunoscape secured US$14 million co-led by EDBI, to scale operations and improve immune-profiling technology. Genesis Alternative Ventures closed a US$80 million debt fund, while Vietnamese electric motorbike startup Dat Bike raised US$2.6 million. These deals highlight investments in Southeast Asian tech startups, with a focus on growth, innovation, and expansion.

site_title: Europe: Shares at record high on auto stocks boost
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% on Monday, extending its record-setting rally, as optimism about a solid earnings season offset rising Covid-19 cases. Auto stocks led gains, while miners and travel stocks also rose. Danske Bank fell 1.7% after CEO Chris Vogelzang resigned amid money laundering allegations. ABN Amro rose 3.3% after reaching a 480-million-euro settlement with prosecutors.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembcorp hits 10-month high amid positive HSBC, Credit Suisse ratings
summary: Sembcorp Industries shares hit a 10-month high, reaching an intraday high of S$2.08, after HSBC upgraded its call to "buy" and initiated coverage on the stock with "outperform". Credit Suisse also initiated coverage with "outperform" and a target price of S$2.40. The upgrades are attributed to Sembcorp's energy division valuation and expected renewables ambitions. The company is set to announce its investor day in May, with analysts expecting a rebound in return on equity.

site_title: Manager at two restaurants is sole local Covid-19 case
summary: A 44-year-old manager at two Singapore restaurants, tested positive for Covid-19 on April 16, becoming the sole community case. He is asymptomatic and a household contact of an earlier reported case. His wife, an accountant, also tested positive on April 16. Epidemiological investigations are ongoing, and all contacts, including co-workers, are isolated and quarantined. This brings Singapore's total Covid-19 cases to 60,851, with 19 imported cases reported on Monday.

site_title: Fire-hit chipmaker Renesas plans full capacity
summary: Japanese chipmaker Renesas Electronics plans to restore full capacity at a plant hit by a fire by May, with production expected to reach 30% of previous capacity by the end of this week. The company has received help from foreign suppliers and domestic support, and is committed to achieving 100% capacity in May. Renesas is a key supplier of automotive semiconductors, and the news comes as car makers face semiconductor supply problems due to increased demand. The Japanese government and some customers, including Toyota, have offered assistance in the recovery effort.

site_title: China's births may fall below 10 million annually in next five years: expert
summary: China's birth rate may fall below 10 million annually in the next five years if the government doesn't abolish its two-child policy, according to an expert. The country's population may also decline, with a recent 15% drop in births to 10.035 million in 2020. The falling birth rate and rapidly aging population will test China's ability to care for its elderly. The country's one-child policy was abolished in 2016, but rising costs and economic uncertainties have discouraged couples from having more children. A census is expected to reveal further demographic changes.

site_title: ECB finds top eurozone banks underreport risk
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) found that eurozone banks significantly underreported their risky assets by 275 billion euros, or 12%, using their own models. This led to a 70 basis point decrease in the ratio of capital to risky assets between 2018 and 2021. The ECB's review, which included 65 large banks, identified areas for further improvement, including ensuring probability of default assumptions are conservative and adapting borrower rating methods. Banks are working to correct deficiencies and fully comply with ECB requirements.

images.alt_text: Large euro zone banks have been underreporting their risky assets by 275 billion euros(S$440.2 billion) by using their own models to quantify potential losses, the European Central Bank said on Monday.

site_title: Danske Bank CEO quits after being named a suspect in ABN Amro probe
summary: Danske Bank CEO Chris Vogelzang resigned after being named a suspect in a Dutch investigation into ABN Amro's money-laundering regulations. Vogelzang, who led Danske Bank since 2019, stated that being a suspect did not imply he would be charged. The Dutch bank ABN Amro reached a $574 million settlement with prosecutors over money-laundering allegations. Vogelzang's resignation comes as Danske Bank is being investigated by authorities in Denmark, the US, Estonia, and France. Carsten Egeriis will take over as CEO, effective immediately.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher as healthcare, industrial firms rebound
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.5% to 29,106.15 on Monday, led by a rebound in healthcare and industrial firms. The Hang Seng healthcare index and industrials index added 3.1% and 2.2%, respectively, following China's solid economic growth in the first quarter. Despite gains, big tech names faltered due to lingering regulatory concerns.

site_title: HSBC Asia Technology M&A head Choy to join Midea as CFO
summary: HSBC Asia Technology M&A head Jeremy Choy is joining Chinese home appliances giant Midea Group Co as its chief financial officer, based at Foshan, China. Midea is seeking to diversify into technology-driven areas such as smart living and the Internet-of-Things. Choy will replace Helmut Zodl, who left earlier this year to become the CFO of General Electric's health care business. This move is part of Midea's efforts to expand its business beyond traditional home appliances.

site_title: India bans oxygen to most industries to meet hospitals' demand
summary: India has banned oxygen supply to most industries to meet the rising demand from hospitals due to a surge in coronavirus infections. The nation reported a record 273,810 new infections, with Maharashtra, the epicentre of the new wave, requesting authorities to airlift oxygen cylinders. Industries producing oxygen as a byproduct have been bottling the gas for hospitals, with Indian Railways transporting it via special tankers. This move aims to address the critical shortage and alleviate pressure on hospitals.

images.alt_text: India has barred the supply of oxygen to many industries to meet rising demand from hospitals which are under pressure from a surge in coronavirus infections in the country.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks mixed, barely up for sixth session ahead of tech, auto earnings
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.01% to 3,198.84, driven by optimism over upcoming corporate earnings, particularly from chipmakers amid chip shortages, and preliminary April exports. However, the benchmark Kospi has risen just 11.32% so far this year, with the won weakening 2.8% against the dollar. Foreigners sold 299.8 billion won worth of shares, and the Kospi's 10-year yield fell to 1.982%.

site_title: Taiwan dollar gains as US hints at currency valuation pressure
summary: Taiwan's dollar rose to its highest in a month, surpassing Asian peers, after the US Treasury hinted at greater pressure to allow the currency to appreciate. The dollar rose 0.5% to 28.196 against the greenback, its strongest since March 16. The Treasury report considered Taiwan's currency undervalued by up to 21% and urged the central bank to limit FX intervention to exceptional circumstances, despite not labeling Taiwan a currency manipulator. The report's emphasis on Taiwan's structural undervaluation and strong exports is expected to support the dollar's appreciation.

site_title: China to bring solar and wind power generation to 11% of total electricity use in 2021
summary: China aims to increase solar and wind power generation to 11% of total electricity use by 2021, up from 9.7% in 2020. The National Energy Administration (NEA) has set a goal to boost non-fossil fuels to 25% of primary energy consumption by 2030, with solar and wind power reaching 16.5% by 2025. The government has urged developers to accelerate construction and local governments to grant approvals for new projects, aiming to ensure the long-term development of renewables. The draft plan will be open for public consultation until April 25.

site_title: Much hype with expectations must be managed for Malaysia-US relations: ISEAS
summary: Malaysia and the US are seeking to expand their partnership, but managing expectations is crucial due to competing priorities and persistent gaps on multiple fronts, according to ISEAS-Yusok Ishak Institute. Despite the Biden administration's perceived credibility and promises of collaboration, the think-tank warns of constraints on collaboration due to domestic priorities, the US-China rivalry, and recurring problems on governance and economic issues. The two countries must navigate these challenges to achieve meaningful cooperation on public health and maritime issues.

site_title: Gojek Co-CEO to head app giant after merger with Tokopedia
summary: Gojek co-CEO Andre Soelistyo will lead the newly formed Indonesian app giant GoTo after a merger with e-commerce company Tokopedia. The merged company aims for a valuation of up to $40 billion. GoTo will have three business units: ride-hailing provider Gojek, e-commerce arm Tokopedia, and payments and financial services under DKAB. The deal, valued at $2.2 billion, is expected to be completed this summer. Soelistyo, 37, has overseen Gojek's diversification into consumer services and has led over $5 billion of fundraising from investors.

site_title: Japan's hard-hit regions may slide back to Covid-19 state of emergency
summary: Japan is considering reinstating states of emergency in hard-hit regions due to a recent surge in Covid-19 cases. Osaka and Tokyo, among other prefectures, have reported record cases and are calling for stronger measures to control the spread. The measures, which include shorter business hours and teleworking, have been deemed ineffective so far. The Tokyo Olympic Games, set to start in July, are also at risk as the new wave of infections complicates preparations. Authorities are urging swift consideration of the requests for a state of emergency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index inching up 0.01% and the Topix index slipping 0.22%. Concerns over the spread of coronavirus variants offset gains in the tech sector. The benchmark indexes closed at 29,685.37 and 1,956.56, respectively.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH raises InnoTek target price on China's shift towards EVs
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has raised its target price for InnoTek to S$1.20 from S$0.82, maintaining a "buy" call. The brokerage attributes this move to China's shift towards electric vehicles, with expected sales to increase 80% year-over-year to 2 million units in 2021, benefiting InnoTek's precision metal components division, which generates over 30% of its annual revenue from China.

site_title: Week-long lockdown in New Delhi as virus cases soar
summary: New Delhi, India, has imposed a week-long lockdown starting Monday due to a surge in Covid-19 cases, with 273,810 infections reported on Monday, a record high. The city's health system is at a "tipping point" with hospitals running out of beds and oxygen supplies. Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said the lockdown will slow the pandemic but improve healthcare. The lockdown affects 20 million people and will last until next Monday, with businesses and essential services only allowed to operate.

site_title: "Vaccine passport" likely on the travel horizon for Singapore
summary: Singapore is likely to introduce a "vaccine passport" for international travel, building on its National Covid-19 Immunisation Programme. The digital passport would provide proof of vaccination and Covid-19 test results, allowing the country to accelerate plans to restart international flights. Singapore is testing the IATA Travel Pass, a digital ID system that displays Covid-19 testing results, and is exploring a digital "immunity passport" that combines identity and health information. The move aims to revive international travel, which has been essential for social and business purposes, and to establish trust between Singapore and the rest of the world.

site_title: Singapore to set up a global maritime decarbonisation centre: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore plans to establish a global maritime decarbonisation centre, driven by the International Advisory Panel on Maritime Decarbonisation, to coordinate and catalyse maritime decarbonisation solutions. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will announce the centre's details later this week. Additionally, the MPA will launch a public consultation exercise to develop the Maritime Singapore Decarbonisation Blueprint 2050 by the end of 2021. The centre aims to reduce vessel idle times and carbon emissions, and will also explore in-shoring, digitalisation, and talent development to improve the maritime industry's sustainability and resilience.

site_title: Case appoints Lee Siow Hwee as new executive director
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (Case) has appointed Lee Siow Hwee as its new executive director, effective April 1, 2021. She will succeed Loy York Jiun, who returned to the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC). Lee previously served in the People's Association for 18 years, holding various appointments, including deputy general manager of a CDC and constituency director.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars hit by weakness in oil, commodities
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Monday, tracking losses in oil and copper amid rising Covid-19 infections globally. The Australian dollar recovered to around flat at US$0.7735, while the New Zealand dollar eased 0.12% to US$0.7142, hitting a four-day low. Traders remain bullish on both currencies in the long term, citing a weaker US dollar and the kiwi's cheapening in Q1. The reopening of the Australian-New Zealand border also supports the kiwi.

site_title: Singtel to review strategic options for its stakes in associates
summary: Singtel is reviewing strategic options for its stakes in associates Intouch Holdings and Advanced Info Service, following a conditional voluntary offer by Gulf Energy Development to buy all of Intouch Holdings' securities at 65 baht each. If successful, Gulf Energy will also tender for Advanced Info's shares at 122.86 baht each, with a minimum of 50% ownership required. The move aims to ensure shareholders benefit from the intrinsic value of the businesses.

site_title: Microsoft to invest US$1b in Malaysia to set up data centres: Malaysian PM
summary: Microsoft to invest $1 billion in Malaysia over 5 years to set up data centers and provide cloud services as part of the Bersama Malaysia initiative, aiming to attract foreign direct investments. The investment will enable the government and businesses to "transform" their operations, with a focus on digital skills development for up to 1 million Malaysians by 2023. This move comes after a 68% decline in foreign direct investments in Malaysia last year, with total investments expected to reach $3.87 billion to $4.84 billion over 5 years.

site_title: Singapore cybersecurity firm launches world's first AI-embedded solid-state drive
summary: Singapore cybersecurity firm Flexxon launched the world's first AI-embedded solid-state drive (SSD) called X-PHY, providing enhanced data security against remote and physical attacks. The device features temperature sensors and alerts users via email in case of an incursion, and can automatically wipe data if compromised. The product is currently in trials with government agencies and plans to be available to businesses by September this year, with mass consumer market production expected by early 2022. The innovation aims to increase security and safety for end-users and has been hailed as a "breakthrough" by Singapore's Minister for Foreign Affairs.

site_title: Asia: Equities higher on US recovery hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by hopes for a US economic recovery, with the Dow and S&P finishing at new peaks and posting their fourth consecutive weekly gains. Investors are optimistic about accelerated US pandemic containment efforts, while a wary eye is kept on new Covid-19 variants. Hong Kong and Shanghai rose over 1%, while Tokyo and Sydney also increased, despite concerns over a slow-moving vaccination program in Japan.

site_title: Gold firms as softer US dollar, yields lift appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,777.33 per ounce, reaching a seven-week peak, driven by a weaker US dollar and lower US Treasury yields. The dollar index is near a one-month low, making gold less expensive for other currency holders. Lower bond yields also reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-bearing gold. The outlook for gold is positive in the short term, with sentiment in equities remaining upbeat due to accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Crypto-rich investors snap up virtual real estate
summary: Crypto-rich investors are snapping up virtual real estate, with prices skyrocketing in blockchain-based online environments. NFTs have become a new type of virtual asset, with ownership verified by blockchain, and are being used to buy land, buildings, avatars, and even names. Investors like Metakovan and Anand Venkateswaran are buying up NFTs, with some plots of virtual land selling for hundreds of thousands of dollars. Atari plans to launch its own blockchain-based virtual world, and some virtual worlds are attracting interest from musicians and companies, with potential for hundreds of thousands of attendees.

site_title: BMW aiming for quarter of China sales to be electric vehicles by 2025
summary: BMW aims to have 25% of its China sales as electric vehicles by 2025, up from 4% last year. The company plans to offer 12 electric models in China by 2023 and has a joint venture with Great Wall Motor to produce electric Mini models globally. BMW expects half of its global sales to be fully-electric models by 2030, with production expansion in China under consideration.

site_title: Toyota unveils new EV, joins Volkswagen's bet on electric future
summary: Toyota unveiled its first electric SUV, the "bZ4X," at the 2021 Shanghai Auto Show, joining Volkswagen's electric vehicle push. The vehicle features a new "e-TNGA" platform, a solar-powered battery recharging system, and is set to be produced in Japan and China, with global sales by mid-2022. By 2025, Toyota plans to introduce 15 electric vehicles, including 7 "bZ" series models, and expand its electrified models to around 70. This move accelerates Toyota's shift towards electrification, following major automakers' pivot towards electric vehicles.

site_title: Oil falls amid surging coronavirus infections in India, other countries
summary: Oil prices fell amid rising coronavirus cases in India and other countries, with Brent crude down 43 cents to $66.34 a barrel and US oil down 42 cents to $62.71 a barrel. The surge in infections, particularly in India, which reported 261,500 new cases, has led to concerns of stronger measures and a hit to economic activity. This has triggered profit-taking, with oil prices down 0.6% and 0.7% respectively. Experts warn of a potential fourth wave of infections in Japan, which could further impact business.

site_title: Surging German Greens to name candidate for Merkel's crown
summary: Germany's opposition Greens party will announce their candidate to succeed Angela Merkel on Monday, challenging the chancellor's conservatives in the September general election. The party has chosen between two co-presidents, Annalena Baerbock and Robert Habeck, both of whom have shown strong discipline and popularity among party members. The Greens' environmentalist platform has resonated with younger Germans, and Baerbock's reputation as a methodical and science-based leader may give her an edge over Habeck, who has faced criticism for past faux pas.

site_title: China's Ant explores ways for Jack Ma to exit as Beijing piles pressure: sources
summary: China's Ant Group is exploring options for founder Jack Ma to divest his stake in the financial technology giant, potentially allowing him to exit the company and giving way to Beijing's scrutiny. Regulators have signaled that a divestment could help Ant move forward with plans to go public. Ma has been under pressure since criticizing regulators in a speech last year, and his exit could help clear the way for the company's revival. However, any move would require Beijing's approval, and Ant has denied that a divestment is under consideration.

site_title: Hugs, tears as Australia-New Zealand travel bubble opens
summary: Australia and New Zealand have opened a quarantine-free travel bubble, allowing families separated by the pandemic to reunite. The first flights took off on Monday, with most passengers being returning New Zealanders. The arrangement is a significant step forward for the two countries, which have successfully contained the virus. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern hailed the success as a key factor in the travel bubble, and passengers expressed excitement and relief at being able to reunite with loved ones. The move is seen as a major milestone in the countries' efforts to return to normalcy.

site_title: Singaporeans' headline inflation expectations continue upwards: poll
summary: Singapore's headline inflation expectations have continued to rise, reaching 2.7% in March, according to the latest survey by DBS and the Singapore Management University. This marks an upward trend from December's 2.2% and September's 1.9%. The survey attributed the increase to global cues of recovery and normalization, as well as the roll-out of various vaccines. Despite this, inflation expectations remain lower than the historical average, with 3.3% for the first quarter of 2012 to 2020.

site_title: India's Razorpay raises US$160m from investors including GIC
summary: Razorpay, an Indian digital payments startup, has raised US$160 million from investors including GIC and Sequoia India, tripling its valuation to US$3 billion. The funds will be used to expand into banking and lending, make acquisitions, and add services in South-east Asia. The company has seen 300% growth in volume and revenues, processing US$40 billion annualized payments volume. Razorpay competes with startups like BillDesk and PayU, and its valuation surge follows a record-breaking year for Indian startups, with six turning unicorns in just a few days.

site_title: Australia's latest resources boom is driving a surge in IPOs
summary: Australia is experiencing a surge in initial public offerings (IPOs) in the resources sector, driven by a commodities supercycle and the nation's strong mining industry. Over the past 12 months, the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) recorded 42 mining-related IPOs, surpassing Toronto and London. This boom is expected to continue as Australia's resources earnings are set to reach an all-time high this financial year, driven by rapid growth in lithium production and a global economic recovery. The ASX's "secret sauce" for attracting resources capital includes its single-board structure and best-in-class reporting system, making it an attractive destination for mining companies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.83 points, or 0.24%, to 1,604.55 on Monday, with losers beating gainers 270 to 200. Volume was 407.05 million lots worth RM200.94 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.32% to 29,587.44, and the Topix index slipping 0.29% to 1,955.26. Investors sought new cues amid sustained optimism about US economic growth, despite sustained tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,204.83, thanks to a strong start from local banks and gains from Sembcorp Marine and Thai Beverage Public Co. The Dow and S&P 500 also reached record highs on Friday, while European shares ended at a record high.

site_title: Australia's Orocobre buys Galaxy to make world's fifth-largest lithium company
summary: Australia's Orocobre Ltd has acquired Galaxy Resources under a scheme of arrangement for A$4 billion, creating the world's fifth-largest lithium miner. The deal, worth A$1.78 billion in shares, will result in Orocobre becoming Australia's largest lithium pure play. The merged company aims to produce over 130,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent, with significant expansion plans in Argentina. Analysts praise the deal for its synergies and global diversity, positioning the company as a major global player in the lithium market.

site_title: Hot stock: ThaiBev falls 4.7% after delaying spin-off listing
summary: ThaiBev shares fell 4.7% on Monday after the company delayed the proposed spin-off listing of its subsidiary BeerCo on the Singapore Exchange, citing unfavorable market conditions. The shares dropped as much as five Singapore cents to 69.5 cents, closing at 71 cents. BeerCo, which produces beer brands including Chang and Bia Saigon, will delay the listing "for the time being" after consulting with financial advisers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong equities remained flat on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.03% to 28,960.13. Despite new record highs on Wall Street, investors were cautious due to US economic growth optimism being tempered by tariff threats. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also fell slightly.

site_title: Australia: Shares boosted by banks and miners, energy stocks weigh
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.2% to 7,079.00, driven by gains from banks and miners, with Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals up 1.7% and 1.3%, respectively. Energy stocks, however, fell 1% to their lowest since March 19. The move was boosted by a travel bubble between Australia and New Zealand, as well as positive corporate earnings and US economic data.

site_title: Frasers Property bags A$300m sustainability-linked loan in Australia
summary: Frasers Property Limited has secured a $300 million, five-year sustainability-linked loan in Australia. The loan, backed by the Australian government-owned Clean Energy Finance Corporation, will support the deployment of clean energy technologies in two industrial projects, reducing embodied carbon and operating emissions. The loan comes with a reducing pricing structure and interest cost reduction from the second year onwards, provided that Frasers Property maintains a four-star rating or above in the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark. This marks Frasers Property's 15th green and sustainability-linked financing since 2018.

site_title: Shares of Econ Healthcare close 3.6% higher than its IPO price on Catalist relisting
summary: Econ Healthcare shares closed 3.6% higher than its IPO price of S$0.28 on Catalist relisting, ending at S$0.29. The company has expanded its services into China with the establishment of Chongqing Nursing Home, expected to commence operations in 2021. Econ Healthcare sees growth opportunities in Singapore, Malaysia, and China, driven by affluent and aging populations. The company received 86.9 times the number of shares available in its IPO and raised S$43.8 million from investors.

site_title: Trip.com Group shares open up 4.85% in Hong Kong debut
summary: Trip.com Group, a China-headquartered travel and accommodation booking business, made its Hong Kong debut with shares opening at HK$281 apiece, 4.85% higher than the secondary listing offer price of HK$268. The company raised US$1.09 billion. Domestic tourism in China has improved, with 102 million trips made during the recent Qingming holiday, equivalent to 94.5% of 2019 levels. Co-founder James Liang attributed the improved domestic trips to lower international flight margins.

site_title: Bahamas tops China in ranking of central bank digital currencies
summary: The Bahamas has taken the top spot in a ranking of central bank digital currencies, followed by Cambodia, according to a report by PwC. China ranks third, with its retail digital currency project still in the test phase. Only 23% of retail projects have reached implementation stage, while nearly 70% of wholesale projects are running pilot programs. The report highlights the importance of financial inclusion in emerging economies, where retail digital currencies are more active.

site_title: Facebook to announce new audio products on Monday: Recode
summary: Facebook will announce new audio products on Monday, including an audio version of its video-conferencing product Rooms and a Clubhouse-like product. The company will also launch a product allowing users to record brief voice messages and post them in their newsfeeds, as well as a podcast discovery product connected to Spotify. These new products aim to expand Facebook's presence in social audio, a space dominated by Clubhouse, which has 10 million weekly active users. The announcement comes after Facebook started public testing of its Hotline app earlier this month.

site_title: Asking prices for UK houses hit new high after tax cut extended: Rightmove
summary: Asking prices for UK homes hit a record high after Finance Minister Rishi Sunak extended a tax cut for homebuyers, according to Rightmove. Prices rose 2.1% in five weeks, with the average price of £327,797, and homes sold in record-fast time. The tax break, which includes a mortgage guarantee scheme, fueled a mini-boom in the housing market. However, Rightmove notes that some of the "froth" may come off later in the year as economic conditions worsen. Despite this, the website expects activity to remain robust for the rest of 2021.

site_title: Airports get busy as Australia-New Zealand quarantine-free travel begins
summary: Australia and New Zealand have begun quarantine-free travel, allowing Australian residents to fly to New Zealand for the first time in over a year. Hundreds of passengers crowded Australian airports on the first day, with Qantas adding 16 return flights daily. The move aims to drive economic recovery and reunite families and friends. Both countries' leaders warned of potential disruptions and ongoing Covid-19 outbreak risks. The quarantine-free travel system will be reviewed and may be extended to other Pacific countries when safe.

site_title: Deutsche Bank builds global emerging market FX trading engine in Singapore
summary: Deutsche Bank is relocating its global emerging-market FX trading engine from London to Singapore, aiming to shave fractions of seconds from order execution times. The move is driven by the growing importance of the Chinese yuan and the need to locate servers closer to customers amid high-frequency trading. Singapore, the third-largest FX hub globally, is competing with Hong Kong for yuan trading volumes. The upgrade is part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to boost technical capability and capitalize on the region's growing liquidity center status.

site_title: China's green car credit scheme turns up heat on carbon-emitters
summary: China has tightened its green car credit scheme, increasing pressure on automakers to develop electric or fuel-efficient vehicles. The policy shift aims to wean the industry off decade-long subsidies, with regulators putting more teeth on tradable credits to offset penalties on carbon-intensive models. Global automakers, including Volkswagen, Tesla, and General Motors, are struggling to comply, with some buying credits from rivals or expanding their electric lineups. The move is expected to encourage Chinese EV startups and consolidate China's lead in electric vehicles.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts offered A$3b to buy out James Packer
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts has accepted a A$3 billion offer from US private equity firm Oaktree Capital to buy out James Packer's 37% stake in the casino operator. The move comes after Packer indicated he was open to selling his stake as part of a A$8 billion takeover bid by Blackstone Group. The Crown Board will assess the Oaktree proposal and a deal is expected to scale back Packer's influence over the company. The New South Wales state gaming regulator recently reached a deal with Packer's private company, Consolidated Press Holdings, to reduce his influence.

site_title: Citi lasers in on Singapore as it exits 13 retail markets
summary: Citi is exiting 13 consumer markets, including China and India, and is focusing on four key markets: Singapore, Hong Kong, London, and the UAE. Singapore is expected to become one of four wealth hubs for the bank, with plans to hire up to 1,500 staff and triple assets under management (AUM) by 2025. Citi aims to capture rising flows within Asia by investing in tech infrastructure and integrating its wealth platforms. The bank's global consumer banking unit will focus on Singapore, Hong Kong, London, and the UAE, with a goal of growing and bumping up mass affluent clients into private banking tiers.

site_title: Deal elusive in conservatives' battle for Merkel's crown
summary: Conservative leaders Armin Laschet and Markus Soeder failed to reach a deal by their self-imposed deadline, deepening the crisis in Angela Merkel's CDU-CSU alliance just months before elections. Laschet, Merkel's preferred choice, has 15% support, while Soeder, who has gained popularity, has 44% backing as the most qualified chancellor candidate. The infighting has drained energy, as Germany struggles with the pandemic, and has led to calls for emergency meetings to decide who to support.

site_title: E-commerce competition set to rise with Coupang said to be entering Singapore
summary: Coupang, South Korea's e-commerce giant, is set to enter Singapore's market, marking its first overseas expansion in 11 years. The company has been recruiting hundreds of employees in Singapore, including senior executives, to optimize its digital logistics business. This move is expected to increase competition in the e-commerce market, where key players include Shopee, Lazada, and Amazon. Coupang's expansion could pave the way for the company to enter the larger South-east Asia market, which has a population of over 650 million.

site_title: Hong Kong bans flights from India, Pakistan and the Philippines for two weeks
summary: Hong Kong suspends flights from India, Pakistan, and the Philippines for two weeks due to the detection of the N501Y mutant Covid-19 strain. The decision affects airlines such as Cathay Pacific and Cebu Pacific, and comes as the city reports 30 new cases, 29 of which were imported. Hong Kong has only vaccinated around 9% of its 7.5 million residents, prompting the government to expand its vaccine scheme to include those aged 16-29. The ban aims to curb the spread of the virus in the city.

site_title: Tesla with 'no driver' in deadly Texas crash: report
summary: Two men were killed in a Tesla crash in Texas on Saturday, with police almost 99.9% certain that the vehicle had no one behind the wheel. The car was traveling at high speed when it crashed into a tree and burst into flames. One victim was in the front passenger seat and the other in the rear seat. Tesla's driver assistance systems were not engaged at the time of the crash, and it's unclear if the driver-side airbag deployed. The incident raises questions about the safety of Tesla's vehicles when left unattended.

site_title: Historic oil glut amassed during Covid-19 pandemic almost cleared
summary: The historic oil glut that formed during the COVID-19 pandemic has nearly cleared, with only 20% of surplus oil remaining in storage tanks of developed economies as of February. The International Energy Agency reports that commercial oil inventories across the OECD are back to their five-year average, and Opec+ is reviving some halted supplies. The re-balancing is propping up international crude prices near $67 a barrel, benefiting producers but increasing concerns for motorists and governments wary of inflation.

site_title: Clubhouse closes new round of financing
summary: Clubhouse, a live audio app, has closed a new funding round led by Andreessen Horowitz, valuing the company at $4 billion. The social media sensation, which allows users to listen to live audio-only chats, has struggled to scale up due to high demand, with servers overwhelmed by users. The funding round comes after the company grew faster than expected after its January capital raising. Clubhouse aims to establish itself as the standard-bearer for digital audio, with celebrity appearances and long conversations contributing to its popularity.

images.alt_text: Clubhouse has closed a new funding round as the wildly popular live audio app struggles to scale up in response to demand, the company said Sunday.

site_title: Japan virus surge raises worries over new Tokyo emergency
summary: Tokyo's governor, Yuriko Koike, has instructed officials to consider declaring another state of emergency due to a surge in COVID-19 infections, which have reached the highest level in over two months. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is under pressure to take measures to contain the spread, as a new survey shows broad opposition to hosting the delayed 2020 Summer Olympics. The Olympics, scheduled for July, have already been delayed a year, and 73% of respondents surveyed said they were against the event being held as planned.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's governor opened the door to declaring another virus emergency as infections surge, adding to the challenges facing an Olympics that's less than 100 days away.

site_title: Volvo to provide cars for Didi's self-driving test fleet
summary: Volvo Cars has signed an agreement to provide hundreds of its XC90 SUVs to Didi Chuxing's self-driving test fleet. The cars will be equipped with backup steering and braking systems to be integrated with Didi's Gemini self-driving hardware platform. This partnership will allow Volvo to gain real-world experience and test its vehicles in a real-world environment. Didi is working towards an initial public offering with a valuation of at least $100 billion, while Volvo aims to become the partner of choice for self-driving fleets globally.

images.alt_text: Swedish carmaker Volvo Cars said on Monday it has signed an agreement to provide cars to the autonomous driving technology unit of China's top ride-hailing firm, Didi Chuxing, for its self-driving test fleet.

site_title: Major Sembcorp customer to terminate utilities services agreement
summary: Sembcorp Industries received a notice from major customer Eastman Chemical Singapore to terminate its utilities services agreement, following Eastman's exit from its manufacturing site operations on Jurong Island. The agreement, in place since 1999, contributed 5% to Sembcorp's FY2020 net profit. This move is part of Sembcorp's diversification efforts, with the company also facing challenges from expiring natural gas contracts in Singapore and power purchase agreements in Vietnam.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Keppel, Frasers Property, ThaiBev, SIIC Environment, Econ Healthcare
summary: Sembcorp Industries lost 2% on Monday after receiving notice from Eastman Chemical Singapore to terminate its utilities services agreement. Keppel Corporation is in advanced discussions with Petrobras for a contract to build a floating production storage and offloading vessel for the Buzios field off Brazil. Frasers Property Limited secured a $300 million sustainability-linked loan to deploy clean energy technologies in Australian projects. ThaiBev deferred the proposed spin-off and listing of its subsidiary BeerCo due to uncertain market conditions. SIIC Environment signed water treatment projects in China, while Econ Healthcare received 86.9 times more applications for its IPO than available shares.

site_title: Vaccine passport: A valid proof
summary: Experts weigh the pros and cons of requiring proof of COVID-19 vaccination for international travel, citing concerns of vaccine inequity and the need for standardized data governance. While some advocate for vaccination as a key risk mitigant, others argue that it may widen the divide between high-income and low-income countries. A balanced approach, including testing and quarantine, is seen as a more practical solution, with digital tools like the IATA Travel Pass being proposed as a way to facilitate safe travel. Ultimately, a nuanced balance between public health and economic concerns is needed to restart international travel.

site_title: US dollar at four-week low on retreating Treasury yields
summary: The US dollar fell to a four-week low against a basket of currencies due to a sharp drop in US Treasury yields. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield dipped to a one-month low of 1.528%, causing investors to buy into the Federal Reserve's accommodative policy stance. Market participants expect dollar weakness to persist, with some predicting the 10-year Treasuries won't move significantly over the coming quarter. This sets the backdrop for dollar weakness continuing in the current quarter, according to economists.

site_title: Growing calls for more oxygen, beds as India Covid-19 crisis deepens
summary: India is grappling with a worsening Covid-19 crisis, adding a record 261,500 new cases, with one-in-six people testing positive. The country has 14.8 million cases, the second most in the world. To address the shortage of beds, hospitals will convert some wards into Covid-19 facilities, and special trains will transport oxygen tankers to needy states.
