This comes after Crown lost its license to operate a casino in Sydney due to concerns over Packer's influence on the company, which is a key requirement for a US$6.2 billion buyout offer from Blackstone Group. The deal aims to reduce Packer's influence and allow Crown to maintain its casino license.

site_title: Opponents of Myanmar military rule hold 'silent strike'
summary: Myanmar's opposition to the military rule observed a "silent strike" on Friday, with many citizens staying home to mourn over 700 killed in protests. The silent strike followed a black-clad march in several cities, as protesters continue to show opposition to the return of military rule. Protest leader Ei Thinzar Maung called for the silent strike, as security forces step up their suppression of the protests.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as record China data fails to impress
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday as record Chinese economic growth figures of 18.3% in the first quarter failed to impress investors. The data, which was the highest since records began three decades ago, was tempered by its weak comparison figure from last year and came in slightly below forecasts. Despite this, a sharper-than-expected increase in retail sales provided hope for the country's consumers. The mixed response to Chinese data followed a surge in US stocks earlier in the week, driven by reports on US consumer spending and jobless claims.

site_title: Australia considers staggered reopening of borders
summary: Australia is considering a staggered reopening of its international borders, with fully vaccinated residents allowed to travel abroad first. The country aims to prioritize Australians who are vaccinated, with a focus on business and personal emergencies. A "travel bubble" between Australia and New Zealand is set to open on Monday. Any further easing of travel restrictions will depend on the pace of Australia's vaccination rollout, which has missed initial targets.

images.alt_text: Australia will consider a staggered reopening of its international borders to allow residents who are fully vaccinated against Covid-19 to travel abroad first, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Thursday.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars set for strong weekly gains as US dollar sags
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are expected to gain ground this week, driven by the US Federal Reserve's promise of easy monetary policy settings. The Aussie is up 1.5% for its second consecutive weekly rise, near Thursday's three-week high of US$0.7761. The Australian dollar is facing key chart resistance around US$0.7849. Global risk appetite is bolstering the currencies as the US dollar sags, providing a boost to the Australian and New Zealand dollars.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars eased off highs on Friday but were on track for solid weekly takings as global risk appetite was bolstered by the promise of easy monetary policy settings by the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Analysts upgrade Singapore export, growth forecasts on robust March trade data
summary: Analysts have upgraded Singapore's export and growth forecasts after non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 12.1% year-on-year in March, beating expectations. Nomura economists predict NODX growth will remain robust in Q2, with the global semiconductor supply crunch driving the recent success. Electronics exports grew 24.4% and non-electronics exports increased by 9.4%, with petrochemicals and pharmaceuticals contributing to the gains. This is expected to boost Singapore's GDP recovery, with analysts now projecting 2-6% year-on-year growth for 2021.

site_title: ST Engineering enters Australia rail market with Queensland's Cross River Rail contract win
summary: ST Engineering has secured a contract to provide 96 sets of platform screen doors for four new underground stations on Queensland's Cross River Rail, marking its first entry into the Australian rail market. The global technology group aims to "improve connectivity and quality of life for communities in South East Queensland." This contract win comes as ST Engineering expands its presence in the metro business, with Head of Smart Mobility Chew Men Leong expressing excitement about the opportunity.

site_title: Music and massage: Malaysian farmers attempt to grow prized Japanese muskmelons
summary: Malaysian farmers have successfully grown Japanese muskmelons, one of the world's most expensive fruits, using a unique combination of nutrients, massage, and classical music. The farmers at Mono Premium Melon rub the melons with a soft cloth to enhance flavor and play music to stimulate growth. After over a decade of experimentation, the company's director says the melons are "almost like an artpiece." This breakthrough could lead to increased production and availability of the prized fruit.

site_title: South Korea's Moon replaces PM, Cabinet ministers after election defeat
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in replaced Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun and six Cabinet ministers after the party's devastating local election defeats. Moon named Kim Boo-kyum, a former interior minister, as the new prime minister and nominated new ministers for various portfolios. The appointments are subject to parliamentary confirmation hearings, but lawmakers lack the power to block them if the president proceeds with formal appointment. The move aims to revive Moon's party and implement his policy agenda.

site_title: China Construction Bank issues three ESG-themed bonds; one to list on SGX
summary: China Construction Bank has issued three ESG-themed bonds, totaling US$2.4 billion, with one to be listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The bonds, issued on April 15, 2021, include a two billion yuan "Transition Bond" priced at 2.85% and will be listed on SGX and Hong Kong Stock Exchange on April 22. This marks the first ESG-themed bond issued through CCB's Singapore branch, which will be mainboard-listed. The issuance is part of the bank's efforts to raise funds and support environmental, social, and governance initiatives.

site_title: Traditional IPOs outperform SPACs as blank-cheque frenzy cools
summary: Traditional initial public offerings (IPOs) have outperformed special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) this year, with regular IPOs gaining 36% compared to SPACs' 1.2% average gain. The cooling investor sentiment toward SPACs signals a decrease in competition for attractive assets, potentially benefiting European markets. Meanwhile, some successful IPOs, such as crypto exchange Coinbase and online courses provider Coursera, have seen significant gains.

images.alt_text: Special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) may have become the hottest must-have for business tycoons, celebrities and even athletes, but old-school initial public offerings (IPOs) have quietly outperformed them this year.

site_title: Australia finds Google misled customers over data collection: regulator
summary: Australia's federal court ruled that Google misled customers about collecting personal location data through Android mobile devices. The court found that Google wrongly claimed it could only collect data from the location history setting, which was actually enabled by default. Users were also not informed that turning off location history but leaving other settings on would allow data collection. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will seek penalties, but no amount was specified. Google has disputed the findings and is reviewing its options, including a possible appeal.

site_title: DBS to exit thermal coal lending by 2039
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, announced it will phase out thermal coal lending by 2039, becoming the first Singapore bank to do so. The bank will stop financing customers who derive more than half of their revenue from thermal coal from January 2026. DBS will disclose its thermal coal exposure in its annual Sustainability Report and focus on renewable energy projects, increasing its exposure to S$4.2 billion in 2020. This move follows similar commitments from other banks worldwide to cut thermal coal financing.

site_title: China's CPE reaches first-close of US$3b new private equity fund: source
summary: China's CITIC Private Equity (CPE) has reached a first-close of its new US$3 billion private equity fund, with US$1.8 billion in commitments from existing investors, including Singaporean state investors GIC and Temasek. The firm aims to complete the fundraising by year-end and will start deploying capital once the first-close is completed. This fundraising comes as Asia-focused private equity firms tap into markets with liquidity and investors seek better returns in a low interest rate environment.

site_title: Kuroda says no need to change Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that there is no need to change the central bank's 2% inflation target, citing its stability in medium- to long-term currency moves. Kuroda expressed confidence that achieving the target is still possible, despite time being required.

site_title: China's Q1 GDP grows at record pace as recovery speeds up
summary: China's Q1 GDP surged 18.3% in the first quarter, the strongest since 1992, as the economy recovered from a 6.8% slump in 2020. Strong demand at home and abroad, along with government support for smaller firms, drove the growth. While the quarterly growth slowed to 0.6%, the overall increase is a positive sign for China's economic recovery, which is expected to grow 8.6% this year, beating the government's target. Policymakers are now focusing on cooling credit growth to contain debt and financial risks.

images.alt_text: China's economic recovery quickened sharply in the first quarter from a coronavirus-induced slump earlier last year, propelled by stronger demand at home and abroad and continued government support for smaller firms.

site_title: China's new home prices quicken in March
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.5% in March, accelerating from a 0.4% gain in February, according to Reuters calculations. On a year-on-year basis, prices grew 4.6%, compared to 4.3% in February. Authorities have implemented measures to curb speculation, including greater scrutiny on fund flows and fixed price references for secondary market financing. This marks the latest effort to slow China's rapidly rising home prices, which have been a concern for the government.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.47% at 29,780.79, and the Topix index advancing 0.19% to 1,962.91. The gains followed rallies on Wall Street, where high-tech shares led the gains ahead of a US-Japan summit later in the day.

site_title: Cooking with class
summary: Sub-Zero and Wolf has launched "The Lab by BakedByWolf," a community kitchen workshop offering cooking and baking masterclasses in a stylishly understated space. The initiative provides a non-intimidating introduction to high-end kitchen appliances and technology, while also serving as a test kitchen for the brand's online bakery. Monthly classes are already scheduled, led by chefs such as Eric Low and Nicholas Koh, and offer a bonding activity for friends, a platform for corporate events, and a space for learning local and Japanese cuisine.

site_title: Theme parks, vaccinations and basketball: California gets back to normal
summary: California has largely returned to normal after a year of pandemic restrictions, with theme parks like Universal Studios Hollywood reopening and basketball fans allowed back to stadiums. Vaccinations are now available to all Californians over 16, with half of the eligible population receiving at least one dose. The state has experienced a sharp decline in Covid-19 cases and deaths, and restrictions are set to be lifted by mid-June.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose at the open on Friday, following a record performance on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.12% to 28,827.17, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.24% to 3,407.19. Investors await Chinese economic growth data release later in the day, amid US tariff threats and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Apple announces US$200m forestry fund to reduce carbon
summary: Apple has announced a $200 million fund, the Restore Fund, to invest in commercial forestry projects, aiming to remove 1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide annually. The fund, launched in partnership with Conservation International and Goldman Sachs, aligns with Apple's goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2030. By removing carbon from the atmosphere, the fund seeks to drive broader change and encourage investment in carbon removal globally, utilizing nature as a tool to mitigate climate change.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai, others to be sentenced for illegal assembly
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai and nine pro-democracy activists, including prominent figures Martin Lee and Margaret Ng, are expected to be sentenced for participating in unauthorized assemblies during 2019 anti-government protests. Lai, who has been in jail since December, faces up to five years in prison. The verdict comes amid Beijing's tightening grip on Hong Kong, which has imposed a national security law punishing dissent with up to life in prison. The sentencing marks a significant development in the ongoing crackdown on pro-democracy activists.

site_title: US: Stocks charge to new records on strong bank profits, retail sales
summary: US stocks reached new records on Thursday, driven by strong bank profits, retail sales, and a low unemployment rate. Retail sales surged 9.8% in March, while jobless claims fell to 576,000, the lowest since the pandemic began. The Dow and S&P 500 closed at fresh records, with Citigroup and Bank of America reporting at least a doubling of quarterly profits. European equities also rose, despite weaker growth expectations in Germany.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.33 points, or 0.21%, to 1,604.92. Losers beat gainers 220 to 202, and volume reached 293.43 million lots worth RM142.78 million.

site_title: Zuckerberg urged to nix kids' version of Instagram
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has been urged to scrap plans for a pre-teen version of Instagram due to concerns over the platform's impact on children's privacy and well-being. Campaigns and advocacy groups from around the world argued that Instagram "exploits young people's fear of missing out and desire for peer approval," and presents challenges to adolescents' privacy and well-being. Despite Instagram's efforts to prevent underage children from creating accounts and blocking adults from contacting young users they don't know, critics remain skeptical, citing Facebook's long track record of exploiting young people.

site_title: China's digital yuan won't topple US dollar: BOJ official
summary: A senior Bank of Japan official downplayed concerns that China's digital yuan could threaten the US dollar's position as the world's main reserve currency. Kazushige Kamiyama stated that the dollar's status won't change easily and may even strengthen further if the US adopts digitalization. The People's Bank of China has rolled out a trial for its digital yuan, but no single digital currency is likely to conquer the world, according to Kamiyama, citing the need for improved settlement systems. The BOJ is studying digital currencies and participating in group studies with major central banks.

site_title: Delta reports another loss but sees jump in leisure travel
summary: Delta Air Lines reported a quarterly loss of $1.2 billion, but expects a return to profitability in the September quarter. The airline attributed the loss to the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenues down 60% at $4.2 billion. However, leisure travel bookings have recovered to 85% of 2019 levels, and Delta plans to resume booking middle seats in May. The company sees a path to returning to profitability and may start hiring additional pilots or flight attendants by the end of the year if the industry recovery accelerates.

site_title: Biden to meet with South Korea's President Moon in May: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden is scheduled to meet with South Korea's President Moon Jae-in in Washington in the second half of May, according to the White House. This visit will be the first face-to-face bilateral meeting between the two leaders. The meeting aims to highlight the iron-clad US-South Korea alliance, following Biden's meeting with Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga. The exact date is still being finalized.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher after positive non-oil export figures on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Friday, driven by a 12.1% year-on-year surge in non-oil domestic exports, beating analysts' estimates of a 2.6% rise. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,188.07.

site_title: Pfizer CEO: Vaccine third dose 'likely' needed within 12 months
summary: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla stated that a third dose of the company's Covid-19 vaccine is "likely" to be needed within 12 months of being fully vaccinated, with annual revaccinations potentially required. Researchers are unsure how long vaccines provide protection against the coronavirus, and variants will play a key role in determining the need for booster shots. This comes as the US President's Covid-19 response team head, David Kessler, warned of the potential need for booster shots to combat emerging variants.

site_title: Europe: Earnings, metal rally spur stocks to record high
summary: European stocks closed at a record high on Thursday, driven by a rally in commodity prices and upbeat earnings reports, despite concerns about the pace of Covid-19 vaccinations. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5%, with miners jumping 1.5% and travel & leisure stocks closing up 0.1%. European stocks have recovered all pandemic-induced losses, but lag US counterparts due to vaccine roll-out issues. Analysts expect a 50% earnings rebound in the first quarter, with companies like ABB and Publicis reporting positive results.

site_title: Sinopharm to inject 30b yuan in vaccine assets into unit Tiantan Biological: sources
summary: Sinopharm plans to invest 30 billion yuan (S$6.14 billion) in unit Tiantan Biological Products Corp, a Shanghai-listed company, to speed up its vaccine business on the public market. The investment will be used to inject six vaccine-focused biological products developers, including makers of two Covid-19 vaccines. This move comes as China aims to develop more homegrown Covid-19 vaccines to challenge Western rivals, with President Xi Jinping pledging China's vaccines for the global public good.

site_title: City of London calls for 'paradigm shift' in tech at banks
summary: The City of London is calling for a "paradigm shift" in the use of technology at banks to reduce compliance costs and make the financial district more globally competitive. The report recommends increasing the use of "RegTech" to streamline processes, such as reporting data to regulators and detecting crime. This shift aims to make the City of London more competitive with other financial hubs.

site_title: Oil edges up to fresh four-week highs as demand outlook improves
summary: Oil prices rose to fresh four-week highs on Thursday, with Brent futures reaching US$66.94 a barrel and US WTI crude settling at US$63.46, driven by positive US economic data and higher demand forecasts from the IEA and Opec. US retail sales rebounded more than expected, boosting hopes of a broader economic rebound, while a weaker US dollar also contributed to the price gains. Supply discipline and rebounding economies are expected to support oil prices, although Opec's plans to ease production cuts starting next month may cap gains.

site_title: Brexit hit to Britain worse than expected, says study
summary: A study by New Financial found that over 400 financial firms in Britain have relocated over $1.87 trillion in assets and 7,400 jobs to EU hubs due to Brexit, exceeding initial estimates. The study predicts more pain to come and that the UK's financial services industry will be chipped away, potentially reducing the country's £26 billion annual trade surplus with the EU. Dublin emerged as the biggest beneficiary, followed by Paris and Luxembourg, with Frankfurt expected to be the long-term winner in terms of assets.

site_title: Democrats unveil bid to expand US Supreme Court, restore 'balance'
summary: US Democrats unveiled a bill to expand the Supreme Court from nine to 13 justices, seeking to restore a balance and address concerns about the court's conservative majority. The proposal, which would allow President Joe Biden to fill the four new seats, is unlikely to pass due to Republican opposition. The move is seen as an effort to pressure Biden to reform the court, with liberals citing recent decisions that have gutted civil rights and voting rights protections.

site_title: Investors concerned about DBS Trustee's decisions on EHT
summary: Investors in Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) are concerned about DBS Trustee's decisions, citing breaches of the Securities and Futures Act and a "depressed market environment" as reasons for selling assets. DBS Trustee, which took over as the trustee of EHT after its original manager was removed, is unlikely to have the operational capabilities to carry out all Reit manager duties. Observers suggest that Reit trustees do not have the "overarching powers" to oversee retail investors or Reit managers, leading to calls for regulators to modify the rules for Reit trustees to give them more suitable powers and discretion.

site_title: Thailand reports fourth record daily rise in Covid-19 cases this week
summary: Thailand reported a record 1,543 new Covid-19 infections on Thursday, the fourth record rise this week, amid a third wave of infections. Authorities have urged people to limit travel and begin working from home, with shopping malls closing early and banking branches limiting customer numbers. The country's healthcare system is under strain, with 8,973 patients being treated. Thailand has vaccinated less than 0.4% of its population, trailing neighboring countries, and is awaiting locally produced AstraZeneca shots expected to start being delivered in June.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore Airlines, Hong Lai Huat, Datapulse Technology
summary: Singapore Airlines will stop carrying transit passengers from Singapore to Hong Kong until further notice due to new regulatory requirements. Hong Lai Huat Group's shares fell 1.1% after the company stated a lockdown in Cambodia may impact property sales.

images.alt_text: SIA said on Thursday that it and Scoot will stop carrying transit passengers from Singapore to Hong Kong until further notice, due to new regulatory requirements in the city.

site_title: Bezos says Amazon needs better 'vision' for workers
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has stated that the company needs a better "vision" for its workers, following the defeat of an effort to create the company's first labor union. Bezos aims to make Amazon "Earth's best employer and Earth's safest place to work" with a new goal. Despite the company's accomplishments, Bezos acknowledges the need for improvement in employee success.

site_title: Moody's mulls upgrade of Grab's B3 ratings; S&P holds steady
summary: Credit ratings agency Moody's has placed Grab's B3 credit ratings under review for an upgrade, citing the potential elimination of redemption risk from the company's upcoming US$39.6 billion listing. In contrast, S&P Global Ratings maintains a "B-" credit rating for Grab, expecting the company to remain loss-making over the next two years. The merger with Altimeter Growth Corp is expected to raise about US$4.5 billion in cash proceeds, eliminating redemption risk and providing additional funds for expansion.

site_title: One Hyde Park penthouse for sale at £175m
summary: A penthouse at London's One Hyde Park project is being sold for £175 million, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. The 18,000 sq ft property, split over two levels, features five bedrooms, a private spa and gym, and two terraces. The sale comes after a surge in demand for London's luxury homes, with some speculating the market may be bottoming out after tax increases. The sale could be the second mega deal at One Hyde Park this year, following a deal to purchase an unfurnished penthouse for £110 million.

site_title: L'Oreal sales recover from pandemic
summary: L'Oreal's quarterly sales exceeded pre-pandemic levels for the first time, reaching 7.6 billion euros (S$12.14 billion) in January-March. This represents a 5.4% rise from the same period last year, with sales driven by Asia, particularly China, and online sales. Despite a flat final quarter of 2020, the company remained profitable, posting net earnings of 3.6 billion for 2020. CEO Jean-Paul Agon attributed the recovery to the beauty market continuing to recover, with consumer products still suffering due to a lacklustre makeup category.

site_title: Mercedes enters new era with its flagship EQS sedan going electric
summary: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled its new flagship EQS sedan, marking a significant shift towards electric vehicles. The EQS boasts a market-leading driving range and luxurious interior, rivaling the S-Class in terms of luxury and performance. Analysts praise the EQS for its exceptional comfort, handling, technology, and material quality, setting new benchmarks in the EV space. However, the car's price point is expected to be higher than comparable S-Class models, potentially affecting sales volumes. Mercedes aims to prove its engineering prowess in the electric age, where expertise in battery technology and software is key.

site_title: Ex-VP Pence receives pacemaker to fix 'slow heart rate'
summary: Former US Vice President Mike Pence has received a pacemaker to treat a slow heart rate after experiencing symptoms over the past two weeks. The procedure, performed at Inova Fairfax Medical Campus in Virginia, was successful, and he is expected to fully recover and return to normal activity in the coming days. Pence, 61, is believed to be considering a potential White House run.

site_title: Singapore exports blow past forecast, jumping 12.1% on low base, chip crunch in March
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) surged 12.1% year-over-year in March, beating a median estimate of 2.6% by private analysts. This marks the fourth consecutive month of growth, driven by a low base for electronics. The expansion outpaced expectations, with growth in non-electronics shipments also contributing to the increase.

site_title: Oil hits one-month highs as IEA, Opec raise forecasts
summary: Oil prices rose to a one-month high due to increased demand forecasts from the International Energy Agency (IEA) and the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec). Brent crude increased by 16 cents to $66.74 a barrel, driven by major economies recovering from the pandemic.

site_title: Germany's top court throws out Berlin's rent freeze
summary: Germany's Federal Constitutional Court has ruled that Berlin cannot impose a five-year rent freeze and restrictions on landlords due to national legislation covering rent regulation. The court stated that Germany's civil code, which regulates the relationship between landlords and tenants, pre-empts local rules, rendering Berlin's efforts to control prices ineffective.

site_title: Spicy sojourn at Huda
summary: Huda Restaurant in Singapore's Chinatown offers a unique culinary experience with its Beijing-inspired cuisine, specializing in small lobsters (crayfish or yabbies) cooked in various styles, including spicy mala and garlic. The no-frills eatery boasts vibrant Chinese regional cooking, with dishes like Sichuan-style boiled fish and preserved century egg. While some items on the menu are hit-or-miss, the restaurant's hearty and pleasant cooking, combined with its Haidilao-style hospitality, make it an enjoyable discovery for adventurous diners. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: Coinbase sell-off after trading debut dents bitcoin price
summary: Coinbase's direct listing sparked a frenzy in demand for cryptocurrencies, with Bitcoin reaching an all-time high. However, the exchange's 14% tumble on its debut dented the market, with Bitcoin falling to $63,160. Despite this, the industry's growth and mainstream acceptance are expected to continue, with Coinbase's valuation reaching $86 billion. The listing's legitimacy has brought increased attention from investors and regulators, and the industry's volatility remains a concern.

site_title: The future of work for bankers, post pandemic
summary: The pandemic may have permanently changed the way bankers work, with many finance professionals now tethered to their homes and relying on video calls instead of business travel. This shift in work habits could reshape workforce planning, office space, and organizational culture for banks. The pandemic also highlighted issues in the financial industry, such as over-leveraged investments and scams, and the need for greater transparency and regulation. As a result, bankers and investors must adapt to a new normal and prioritize due diligence and responsible investing.

site_title: With earnings soaring, Wall Street banks see economic boom ahead
summary: Wall Street banks are optimistic about the US economy's recovery, with Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo reporting strong quarterly earnings. The banks attribute their success to consumer spending, driven by stimulus money, and supportive policies from the Federal Reserve. Despite some cautionary signs, such as ongoing COVID-19 cases and vaccination challenges, the banks' earnings suggest a "dramatic V-like pickup" in the economy. The banks have reduced their pandemic-era reserves and reported robust revenues across multiple lines of business, including investing, lending, and trading.

images.alt_text: Goldman reported a doubling of revenue to US$17.7 billion, from US$8.7 billion, thanks to double-digit percentage gains in investment banking, money management and markets.

site_title: TSMC sees chip shortage lasting into 2022
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, expects the global chip shortage to last into 2022 despite efforts to increase productivity and keep pricing reasonable. The company is expanding capacity, hiring thousands of employees, and constructing new facilities to alleviate the shortage. CEO C. C. Wei stated that TSMC is doing "all it can" to address the issue, but tight supplies are likely to continue into next year.

site_title: HK's Shun Tak to launch debut Singapore residential project
summary: Shun Tak Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed conglomerate, is set to launch its maiden Singapore residential project, Park Nova, in District 10. The 54-unit super-luxury freehold development features units ranging from 1,432 sq ft to 5,899 sq ft. Analysts expect the project to attract wealthy buyers, particularly from North Asia, due to Shun Tak's network and the improved property market sentiment. Prices are expected to range from S$4,200 to S$5,000 psf, with the project's completion anticipated in 2023.

site_title: Malaysia's Covid-19 infection rate climbs as Ramadan begins
summary: Malaysia's COVID-19 cases have surged to 2,000 for the first time since March 5, with the reproduction number reaching 1.14, indicating the virus is spreading rapidly. The government has urged visitors to bazaars to follow protocols, but concerns remain about the spread of the virus due to low vaccination rates and the decision to allow bazaars to remain open during Ramadan. The government plans to rely on targeted curbs and has not ruled out imposing a movement control order if necessary.

site_title: Pay cuts for heads of Singapore property firms
summary: Singapore property firm City Developments (CDL) saw its executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng's remuneration drop 82% to S$1.63 million in 2020, amid the company's first full-year loss since the 1970s, recording a net loss of S$1.92 billion. This significant decline is attributed to the company's reversal from a S$564.6 million profit in 2019.

site_title: Building Singaporeans' trust in financial-sector representatives
summary: A study published in the Journal of the Economics of Ageing found that older Singaporeans' trust in financial advisers significantly affects their financial decisions. The study, conducted in 2018-2019, surveyed 6,000 older Singapore residents aged 50 and above, revealing that trust in insurance agents was 8.4% higher for those with life insurance coverage, while trust in bank financial advisers was 4.1% lower. The research suggests that increasing trust in financial advisers could help address the insurance inadequacy problem, with experts recommending improvements in financial literacy, licensing examinations, and ethics for financial advisers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group's property division sales may be affected by a 14-day lockdown in Cambodia's Phnom Penh and Kandal provinces, starting Thursday. The company's offices will be closed and employees will work from home. GuocoLand's wholly-owned subsidiary, GuocoLand (China), has agreed to dispose of its 100% interest in Beijing Jiang Sheng Property Development for 3 million yuan (S$0.6 million). GuocoLand shares closed unchanged at S$1.71.

site_title: Various ways to raise revenue for long-term needs being studied
summary: The Singapore government is studying various ways to raise revenue to meet long-term fiscal needs, including increasing the GST rate, raising the top marginal personal income tax rate, and implementing an "automation tax." The government aims to support low- and middle-income households with enhanced GST Vouchers and a GST Assurance Package. The decision on revenue measures will take into account the state of the economy and spending needs, with the goal of maintaining a competitive economy and building a fair and just society.

site_title: London new home sales plummet in Q1
summary: London new-home sales plummeted 39% to 3,703 in Q1, the lowest level in nearly nine years, due to a lack of interest from landlords and buyers for central properties. The housing market is in flux, with suburban houses valued for space and greenery and apartment prices falling. The number of new homes starting construction hit its lowest level since 2011. Overseas buyers acquired 210 new homes, less than half the number in the same period last year. The decline may be a sign that urban life's popularity won't return to post-pandemic London.

site_title: Grooming younger agents paying off at ERA
summary: ERA Realty's move to groom young agents appears to be paying off, with the average age of its top five performers under 40 and average income of S$3.12 million. This marks a significant shift from previous years, where top agents were older. The company's focus on nurturing younger talent may be a key factor in its success.

site_title: Xi Jinping to join European climate summit; John Kerry in China for talks on environment
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will join a virtual climate summit with France and Germany, marking his first major international climate engagement. US envoy John Kerry visited Shanghai for meetings with Chinese officials, aiming to boost support for the US drive to address environmental challenges. Kerry's visit comes after the US and China agreed to cooperate on climate change issues. The climate summit and Kerry's visit highlight growing international pressure on China to take action on climate change.

site_title: US economy gains momentum as consumer confidence grows: Fed
summary: The US economy gained momentum in the spring, driven by growing consumer confidence, increased Covid-19 vaccinations, and strong fiscal support. Economic activity improved in the labor market as more people returned to work. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated the economy is on track for stronger growth and hiring in the coming months. The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report highlighted these positive trends, indicating a boost in economic activity between late February and early April.

site_title: New private home sales double in March as buyers snap up luxe condos
summary: Singapore developers sold 1,296 new private homes in March, a double increase from February. Luxury condos were in high demand, especially in the core central region (CCR), where half of the upcoming projects are slated to launch. This surge in luxury sales is expected to test demand for Singapore's prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Ant revamp spells lessons for S-E Asian fintechs
summary: China's central bank announces Ant Group's restructuring as a financial holding company, severing links between e-wallet AliPay and other businesses. This move comes after a record fine of 18.2 billion yuan (S$3.7 billion) on Alibaba following an anti-monopoly investigation. Industry observers stress the need for South-east Asian fintechs and regulators to engage early and address risks in cross-selling financial products, citing Ant Group's forced restructuring as a lesson. Regulators and fintechs must address potential risks and collaborate to avoid similar consequences.

site_title: Citi to exit consumer business in 13 markets
summary: Citi trounced Q1 profit estimates, driven by an economic recovery outlook. As part of a strategic review, the bank will exit its consumer businesses in 13 Asian and EMEA markets. New CEO Jane Fraser is overseeing the review.

site_title: Japan will do utmost to stop Covid spread before Olympics, says PM Suga
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga vowed to prevent the spread of coronavirus ahead of the Olympics, stating that the government would do "everything possible" to prevent infections. However, a ruling party official, Toshihiro Nikai, suggested that cancellation of the event was an option, citing the potential for the Olympics to spread infection. Japan is currently experiencing a fourth wave of coronavirus infections, with new cases in Tokyo reaching 729 on Thursday. Despite these concerns, the Tokyo Olympic organising committee remains committed to hosting the Games this summer, with plans to incorporate social distancing measures and restrictions.

site_title: The darker side of organisational life
summary: The British royal household, exemplified by the experiences of Princess Diana, Sarah Ferguson, and Meghan Markle, reflects broader social issues of exclusion and social inequality. These patterns are rooted in deeply held, unconscious assumptions that define the organisational culture, leading to rejection and marginalization of outsiders. To address these issues, organisations must confront their "unthought known" - primitive, unconscious thoughts and feelings that are swept under the rug. Conflict and "madness" can provide insights into underlying issues, and embracing change can lead to transformation, but requires tolerance and a willingness to confront anxiety and threats of change.

site_title: US retail sales climb most since May 2020
summary: US retail sales surged 9.8% in March, the largest gain in 10 months, driven by business reopenings, increased hiring, and stimulus checks. This rebound follows a 2.7% decline in February. Retail categories, including restaurants, apparel, and furniture outlets, experienced significant sales gains, with e-commerce sales also rebounding. The report suggests a strengthening job market and economy, but warns that federal stimulus payments may have a temporary impact and that consumer spending may shift towards travel and services in the long term.

site_title: Dell spins off 81% stake in VMware to pay down debt
summary: Dell is spinning off 81% of its stake in VMware, a cloud computing software maker, to pay down debt. The move is expected to be tax-free and will help Dell reduce its long-term debt of $41.62 billion. VMware will distribute a special cash dividend of $11.5 billion to $12 billion to its shareholders, including Dell, which will receive $9.3 billion to $9.7 billion. The spinoff is expected to help VMware secure an investment-grade credit rating and potentially form partnerships with major cloud computing providers.

site_title: Prince Philip's death shines spotlight on future of UK
summary: Prince Philip's death highlights the uncertain future of the UK monarchy and the country itself, as Queen Elizabeth II reaches 95 years old next week. Despite past troubles, the Royal Family has largely recovered, with Prince William and Prince Harry contributing to its popularity. However, Prince Harry's departure from the family may impact his popularity. The Queen's and Prince Philip's longevity and the Royal Family's efforts to modernize have shifted public perception, with polls showing Prince William and Kate as the most popular members, followed by Prince Harry.

site_title: US dollar hits four-week low as yields pull back
summary: The US dollar hit a four-week low against major currencies due to Treasury yields pulling back from a surge last month. Investors believe the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates low, supporting the dollar's decline. The Russian rouble also dropped 1% to $0.76 as the US announced plans to impose sanctions on Russia for alleged election interference and cyber activity.

site_title: Asian investors need to prep for EU's new ESG challenge
summary: The European Union's Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR) has been implemented, requiring financial institutions to standardize sustainability disclosures and prevent "greenwashing". The regulation affects non-EU financial market participants, including those in Asia, who need to prepare for the new standards, which will impact their sustainability reporting and disclosure practices.

site_title: Over 100m Internet-linked devices at risk, Singapore's CSA urges firms to patch systems
summary: Singapore's Cyber Security Agency has issued an alert over new vulnerabilities in over 100 million Internet-connected devices, including medical equipment and industrial control systems. The Singapore Computer Emergency Response Team (SingCert) advises administrators to apply the patch immediately. Organisations in healthcare and government sectors are most affected, but it's unclear how many devices in Singapore are impacted. The alert follows a global discovery of vulnerabilities in various devices, prompting administrators to take action to prevent potential cyber threats.

site_title: Building, marine, process sectors still struggling to get entry for workers
summary: Singapore's construction, marine, and process sectors struggle to get entry approvals for foreign workers, particularly those from India and Bangladesh, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Employers face an uphill battle to get approvals, with some having submitted applications repeatedly for months. The government adjusts entry approvals dynamically, depending on the global COVID-19 situation and risk levels of countries. The lack of certainty on when workers can come in makes it difficult for employers to plan ahead, leading to delays and impact on projects and planning.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.97 points to 1,608.25. The market saw 6.492 billion lots traded worth RM4.738 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 801 to 323.

site_title: Indonesia's exports and imports grow more than expected in March
summary: Indonesia's exports surged 30.47% in March to $18.35 billion, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher commodity prices and rebounding global demand. Imports also grew 25.73% to $16.79 billion, the strongest growth since July 2018. The trade surplus narrowed to $1.56 billion, below expectations. The statistics bureau attributed the growth to improving manufacturing activity, investment, and purchases of raw materials and capital goods ahead of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.

site_title: Crunchy Indian snack adds bite to multi-million-dollar feminist success story
summary: Lijjat Papad, a multi-million-dollar Indian snack cooperative founded by seven women in 1959, has become a symbol of feminist success. The business employs 45,000 women across India, offering them a job for life and financial independence. With annual sales of over 6,000 rupees in 1959, the cooperative has grown to become a household name, expanding into other categories and even producing a Bollywood film about its story. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Lijjat has maintained its commitment to women's empowerment, with staff receiving modest salary hikes and no layoffs.

images.alt_text: Women arranging rolled papads for delivery at one of Lijjat Papad's branches in Mumbai. The cooperative employs 45,000 women across India, offering them a job for life as "co-owners" of the enterprise.

site_title: Elite bottles of wine so exclusive, you can't just buy them
summary: Exclusive wine bottles are only available to members of clubs or by visiting the winery, with some requiring a personal connection or "good vibes." Ovid winemaker Austin Peterson offers one-off experiments like 2019 Experiment No W69, a California white wine, for $95, while other rare bottles include 2018 Experiment No R98 and 2016 Variazioni di Rosso dell'Ornellaia. Other exclusive wines include Ridge Vineyards' Advanced Tasting Programme, Chateau Montelena's historic vintages, and SGC Wines' Bordeaux cuvées available only to members of its Le Cercle club, with some requiring a hefty annual fee.

images.alt_text: Think of exclusive wines as rewards for intrepid loyalists and wine adventurers willing to go beyond retail.

site_title: Bank of America profit more than doubles on reserve release boost
summary: Bank of America reported a 124% increase in first-quarter profit, exceeding estimates, as it released US$2.7 billion from coronavirus loan loss reserves. The bank's net income rose to US$7.56 billion, or 86 cents per share. Despite a 12% fall in consumer banking revenue, credit costs improved, and analysts expect an accelerating economic recovery. The bank's chairman, Brian Moynihan, attributed the boost to the White House's pandemic relief package and increased vaccinations.

site_title: UK restaurant bookings and job adverts rebound as lockdown eases
summary: The UK's economy is showing signs of recovery as lockdown measures ease, with restaurant table bookings jumping to 79% of pre-pandemic levels and online job adverts recovering to pre-pandemic levels. Non-essential shops reopened in England, and British banks are preparing to increase mortgage lending. The Bank of England and International Monetary Fund expect Britain's economy to grow rapidly this year, but a slower recovery is anticipated, with output likely to take until 2022 to return to pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Restaurant table bookings on April 12 jumped to 79% of their level on the same day in 2019, figures sourced from reservations company OpenTable show.

site_title: The three 'E's of management style
summary: A former colleague's leadership style, exemplified by the "three 'E's" of management - Encouraging, Empowering, and Enduring - transformed a small business into a $825 million company. This approach, which prioritizes the well-being and support of employees, is a model for effective leadership. The article highlights the importance of emotional intelligence and generosity of spirit in management, citing the former colleague's selfless dedication to a cause despite his own health struggles. This approach can lead to better employee outcomes and business success.

site_title: Avis soars as high car-rental demand meets supply shortages
summary: Avis Budget Group's stock reached a record high as the company benefits from increased car-rental demand and supply shortages. The company's shares rose 1.9% to $77.24, more than doubling so far this year. Industry-wide inventory tightness and a global semiconductor shortage are limiting the ability of car rental companies to restock their fleets, leading to higher prices. Avis and rivals Hertz and Enterprise are cautiously adding cars back to their fleets, but at a slower pace due to production pauses and prioritizing sales to higher-margin buyers.

site_title: SGX raps three former executive directors of Datapulse Technology
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded three former executive directors of Datapulse Technology for breaching a mainboard listing rule. The directors, Ng Cheow Chye, Ng Cheow Leng, and Si Yok Fong @ Chin Yok Fong, failed to disclose material information about the company's disposal of a property at 15A Tai Seng Drive in 2017. The information included the National Environment Agency's (NEA) rejection of the company's proposed use of a Toa Payoh property for manufacturing activities. The directors resigned in December 2017 and have since appealed the decision, but it will not be heard by the SGX.

site_title: HSBC Singapore moves into new digs with hybrid model
summary: HSBC Singapore has moved to its new headquarters at Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) after over 140 years at the original Collyer Quay site. The move, originally planned for 2021, was delayed due to the global pandemic. The bank is adopting a hybrid model, marking a change in its operations.

images.alt_text: HSBC's newly upgraded offices at MBFC and split site at Mapletree Business City can now house 65 per cent of staff abiding by the one-metre safe distancing rule.

site_title: US private equity landlord seeking to evict renters despite ban: report
summary: A US private equity firm, Pretium Partners LLC, is seeking to evict thousands of cash-strapped tenants despite a federal moratorium on evictions. Firms Progress Residential and Front Yard Residential Corp have filed nearly 500 eviction actions, with a disproportionate number in majority Black areas. The companies claim they comply with the CDC eviction moratorium and work with residents to avoid eviction, but will proceed if rent is not paid. The CDC recently extended the pandemic eviction moratorium to June 30.

site_title: Shippers navigate choppy waters amid high operational costs
summary: Global shipping shippers face increased wait times and rising operational costs amid the COVID-19 pandemic and Suez Canal disruptions. The daily average of vessels staying at the Singapore port for more than two days decreased to 49 per day in March, but shippers must navigate higher operating costs, including a 5-10% increase in manning costs and 3-5% increase in dry-docking spend. Insurance premiums have also risen, with hull and machinery cover costs increasing by 3-5%. Despite some costs unwinding, shippers expect trading conditions to remain "challenging" due to ongoing COVID-19-induced trade uncertainties.

site_title: EU-UK trade deal passes key vote in European Parliament
summary: The European Parliament has approved a key vote in favor of the EU-UK trade deal, with 108 votes in favor, one against, and four abstentions. The deal has been provisionally applied since January, but lawmakers are demanding further reassurances on the Northern Ireland protocol, which has led to tensions and violence in the region. The UK Parliament has ratified the deal, but European lawmakers must vote on ratification by April 30th, with some warning of economic chaos if the deal is not ratified. A meeting between EU and UK officials is scheduled to discuss the protocol dispute.

site_title: Blockchain accelerator Tribe gets strategic backing from Korean VC firm
summary: Blockchain accelerator Tribe Accelerator secured strategic investment from Korea Investment Partners (KIP), a South Korean VC firm, and other investors, including Mandiri Investment Management Singapore and early Twitter, Coinbase, and Square investor Greg Kidd. Tribe aims to grow its accelerator and educational institute, expand into new markets, and support promising blockchain startups. The program has already seen participating startups collectively raise US$70 million, with notable partners including Pfizer, HSBC, and Infineon Technologies.

site_title: Tembusu Partners invests US$1m in e-sports company RSG
summary: Singapore-based e-sports startup RSG secured US$1 million in seed funding from Tembusu Partners' FrontSight Capital Fund. The investment will support RSG's teams competing in games like Mobile Legends and PUBG. This marks the first of up to 10 planned investments in South-east Asian e-sports teams and companies, with growth in the sector expected to reach 24% annually from 2018 to 2023, according to market research firm Newzoo.

site_title: Biden imposes sanctions on Russia, restricts buying new debt
summary: The Biden administration imposed new sanctions on Russia, including restrictions on buying new sovereign debt, in response to alleged misconduct related to the SolarWinds hack and election interference. The sanctions target 32 entities and individuals, six Russian companies, and expel 10 Russian diplomats. US financial institutions will also be barred from participating in new debt issued by the Russian central bank, Finance Ministry, and sovereign wealth fund, effective June 14.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration imposed a raft of new sanctions on Russia, including long-feared restrictions on buying new sovereign debt, in retaliation for alleged misconduct related to the SolarWinds hack and efforts to disrupt the US election.

site_title: ERA Realty eyes 40% increase in revenue amid boom in property transactions
summary: ERA Realty Network aims to achieve a 40% increase in revenue to S$550 million by early next year, in line with its 40th anniversary. The company's goal for this year is S$450 million, with incentives for its 8,000 agents, including a Tesla Model 3 electric car and a penthouse unit worth S$2 million for reaching the target. ERA's ambition relies on strong home sales without government cooling measures and recruitment of more agents, as the top real estate agency, PropNex, has over 9,200 agents.

site_title: Citigroup profit triples on reserve release, to exit some consumer units
summary: Citigroup's first-quarter profit tripled to $13.1 billion, exceeding market estimates, due to the release of pandemic-era loan loss reserves. The bank plans to exit consumer units in Australia, China, and India to focus on higher-returning opportunities in wealth management and institutional businesses in Asia. CEO Jane Fraser aims to transform Citigroup into a competitively profitable organization.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in March with 1,296 new sales, double February's 645. Buyers focused on high-end condos after the Chinese New Year break. Naiise, a Singapore-based retailer, went into liquidation after founder Dennis Tay exhausted his savings and borrowed heavily from banks. Moody's placed Grab's B3 corporate family rating under review for an upgrade. Singapore's ageing population pushed for new private eldercare facility models, while Genesis Alternative Ventures closed a US$80m debt fund and Singapore Medical Group dropped a potential share transaction. The STI rebounded 5.38 points, or 0.17%, to 3,184.77.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore sold 1,296 new private homes in March, double that of February's 645, with buyers targeting high-end condos after a break during Chinese New Year.

site_title: Global officials urge rich countries to donate excess Covid-19 vaccine doses, money
summary: Global officials are urging rich countries to donate excess Covid-19 vaccine doses and funds to the Covax initiative, which aims to supply low- and middle-income countries. The Covax program has shipped over 38 million doses to 111 countries, but global supply is tight, and many countries have ordered more vaccines than they need. Officials are calling for an additional $2 billion by June to support the program, which is also seeking donations of excess vaccine doses to get the global economy back on track.

site_title: US factory output rises in March, shaking off winter weakness
summary: US factory output rose 2.7% in March, the largest increase in eight months, following a 3.7% decline in February due to severe winter storms. Total industrial production increased 1.4% after a 2.6% decrease in February. The stronger-than-expected reading was attributed to improving business confidence and government aid, but was tempered by ongoing challenges such as semiconductor shortages and shipping issues. Factory capacity remains below pre-pandemic levels, and total industrial production is now just 3% below its February 2020 level.

site_title: Thermo to buy PPD for US$17.4b as health deals soar
summary: Thermo Fisher Scientific agreed to acquire PPD, a clinical and research services provider, for $17.4 billion. The deal, valued at $47.50 per share, represents a 24% premium to PPD's closing price. This acquisition follows a surge in healthcare dealmaking, with over $160 billion in transactions this year, driven by the need for new Covid-19 drugs and vaccines. The deal will assume $3.5 billion of PPD's debt and is part of a growing trend in the industry.

site_title: Hong Kong widens Covid-19 vaccine scheme to under 30s
summary: Hong Kong authorities have expanded its COVID-19 vaccine scheme to include residents aged 16-29, aiming to boost vaccination rates. The city has seen a relatively slow take-up, with only 8% of its 7.5 million residents vaccinated. The expansion, announced three days after loosening restrictions for fully vaccinated residents, comes amid dwindling confidence in China's Sinovac vaccine and fears of adverse reactions. Around 632,000 people have received their first dose, with the BioNTech vaccine seeing greater demand. The move aims to increase the total eligible population to 6.5 million.

site_title: US retail sales climb most since May 2020 in broad advance
summary: US retail sales surged 9.8% in March, the largest gain since May 2020, driven by business reopenings, hiring, and stimulus checks. The rebound in sales, especially in retail categories hit hard by the pandemic, is expected to continue as Covid-19 vaccinations and easing restrictions gain pace. All 13 retail categories posted sales gains, with receipts at restaurants and apparel retailers rising 13.4% and 18.3%, respectively. The strong sales figures signal a strengthening job market and economy, but may also indicate a shift towards travel and services over merchandise spending.

site_title: New US jobless claims plunge to 576,000, lowest since pandemic
summary: US jobless claims dropped to 576,000, the lowest level since the pandemic, according to government data. This is a significant decrease from the previous week, with a drop of nearly 200,000 claims. Despite this, a separate program for freelance workers and others not normally eligible for aid brought the total to over 700,000. The data is seen as a positive sign for the US economy's rebound, with analysts noting that the reopening and rehiring have begun with "gusto."

site_title: Myanmar security forces arrest prominent leader of anti-coup campaign
summary: Myanmar security forces arrested prominent leader Wai Moe Naing, 25, of the anti-coup campaign after ramming his motorbike during a rally in Monywa, about 700 km north of Yangon. Wai Moe Naing, a Muslim and high-profile leader of opposition to the coup, was detained along with Myo Aye, director of the Solidarity Trade Union of Myanmar. The arrest comes amid ongoing protests and strikes against the military rule, which ousted an elected government led by Nobel peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow hit record highs on upbeat earnings, strong retail sales
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow Jones indexes hit record highs on Thursday, driven by upbeat earnings reports and strong March retail sales. The Dow Jones rose 57.64 points, or 0.17%, to 33,788.53, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 15.10 points, or 0.37%, at 4,139.76. This rebound bolsters hopes for a broader economic recovery, despite ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat property and real estate sales to be affected by Cambodia lockdown
summary: Hong Lai Huat Group's property and real estate division sales are expected to be affected by a 14-day lockdown in Cambodia's Phnom Penh and Kandal Province, starting April 15. The group's offices in Cambodia will shut and employees will work from home. Hong Lai Huat shares fell 1.1% due to the announcement. The company's agriculture division will continue to operate normally.

site_title: Muted trading; medical stocks rally on rising global Covid-19 case count
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 5.38 points, or 0.17%, to 3,184.77 on Thursday, driven by gains in medical stocks. The rally came amid rising global Covid-19 case counts, with new cases exceeding 800,000 per day. Medical equipment suppliers and glove makers led the gains, while Singapore Airlines fell 2.91% despite news of a potential air travel bubble with Hong Kong. Muted trading was observed across Asia, with the Nikkei 225 and Shanghai Composite Index also experiencing declines.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Thursday, following a soft lead from Wall Street and concerns about tight liquidity in Chinese financial markets. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.37%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.52% and 0.54%, respectively. The declines were attributed to global market uncertainty and US tariff threats.

site_title: UK job ads and restaurant bookings rebound as lockdown eases
summary: The UK economy is showing signs of recovery as lockdown measures ease, with English diners rushing back to restaurants and online job adverts reaching pre-pandemic levels. Restaurant table bookings jumped to 79% of 2019 levels, and online job adverts recovered on April 8. The Bank of England expects Britain's economy to grow rapidly this year, but a slower recovery is expected compared to the US and Japan. Around 5.7 million employees remain on furlough, and economists predict a slower return to pre-pandemic levels by 2022.

site_title: SGX raps ex-executive directors of Datapulse Technology for breaching rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded three former executive directors of Datapulse Technology for breaching a mainboard listing rule. Ng Cheow Chye, Ng Cheow Leng, and Si Yok Fong @ Chin Yok Fong failed to disclose material information about the rejection of a property acquisition by the National Environment Agency (NEA) in September 2017. The LDC found that the NEA rejections were necessary for shareholders to make an informed decision on the disposal of the company's property. The trio has filed a notice of appeal, but SGX has declined to hear it, citing lack of grounds for appeal.

site_title: Genesis Alternative Ventures closes US$80m debt fund anchored by Sassoon family
summary: Genesis Alternative Ventures, a Singapore-based firm, has closed its US$80 million debt fund, exceeding its initial target of US$70 million. The fund is anchored by Sassoon Investment Corp, a family office affiliated with The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf. Other investors include Aozora Bank, Korea Development Bank, and Silverhorn Group. This marks Genesis Alternative Ventures' first fund and solidifies its position in the alternative investment space.

site_title: China gives green light to nuclear units to cut carbon, sources say
summary: China's state council approved the construction of five nuclear power units with a total installed capacity of 4.9 GW, roughly 10% of the country's total, to meet its climate goals and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The projects, developed by China National Nuclear Corp, include four regular nuclear units and a small, 125-MW module reactor demonstration project. Construction is expected to start later this year and be completed by 2026, with China aiming to have installed or under construction 200 GW of nuclear capacity by 2035.

site_title: Cathie Wood's Ark buys US$246m of Coinbase shares, sells some in Tesla
summary: Cathie Wood's investment firm, Ark, purchased $246 million worth of Coinbase shares on its Nasdaq debut, adding to its flagship fund. Meanwhile, they sold $178 million worth of Tesla shares, maintaining their largest investment by weightage. The move comes after Wood predicted Tesla's share price could reach $3,000 by 2025. The ARK Innovation fund's assets under management rose to nearly $22 billion, up from $1.86 billion in 2019.

site_title: German constitutional court strikes down Berlin rent cap
summary: Germany's Constitutional Court struck down a rent cap law in Berlin, ruling the city government lacks authority to enact such rules. The law, which forced landlords to cut rents for over 300,000 tenants and freeze them for five years, was deemed invalid. Shares in property companies with assets in Berlin rose following the verdict. The decision reverses a policy implemented in November 2020, affecting thousands of tenants and potentially impacting the city's housing market.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy imports Singapore's first carbon neutral LNG cargo
summary: Pavilion Energy, owned by Singapore's Temasek Holdings, has imported Singapore's first carbon neutral liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo. The company offsets the emissions by "retiring" high-quality carbon credits from projects in Peru and China. Pavilion Energy signed long-term contracts with Chevron and Qatar Petroleum Trading to include greenhouse gas emissions statements, and is working with partners to develop a methodology for calculating emissions. This move marks a significant step towards Singapore's goal of becoming a carbon neutral LNG supplier.

site_title: Shell plays down risk of stranded oil and gas reserves
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has stated that 75% of its oil and gas reserves will be produced by 2030, with 3% produced after 2040, playing down the risk of "stranded assets" due to the shift to renewable energy. The company aims to cut its emissions to net zero by 2050 and has set out plans for hydrogen, biofuels, and carbon-sucking technologies. However, critics argue that the use of carbon offsets will allow oil and gas reserves to be drained, and the company's plans do not deliver enough absolute emission reductions to achieve the Paris goals.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS initiates coverage on GHY Culture & Media with 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on GHY Culture & Media Holding with a "buy" recommendation and a S$1 target price, citing the company's strong network, healthy content production pipeline, and flexible revenue models. The research team expects a 40% growth in FY2021 and FY2022 revenue due to partnerships with top TV networks and streaming platforms. A projected 46% earnings growth in FY2021F and 39% in FY2022F is also anticipated, driven by the lifting of lockdowns and increased demand for concerts.

site_title: TSMC books 19% Q1 profit growth; says chip shortage likely last into 2022
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) reported a 19.4% rise in first-quarter profit, beating market expectations, driven by strong chip demand amid the global shift to home working. The company expects the chip shortage for its auto clients to be greatly reduced from the next quarter. TSMC plans to invest $100 billion over the next three years to increase capacity and is expanding its capacity to alleviate the shortage. The company's shares have risen 16% so far this year, driven by the growth opportunities in the advanced chip market.

site_title: Moody's places Grab B3 ratings under review for upgrade
summary: Moody's has placed Grab's B3 credit ratings under review ahead of its proposed $39.6 billion listing via a merger with a US SPAC. The review includes Grab's corporate family rating and senior secured term loan. Moody's changed its outlook from "stable" to "ratings under review" due to Grab's expected loss-making status over the next two years, as maintained by S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: 16 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 16 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notice. The total number of cases rose to 60,735. There were no community cases and no cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The majority of new cases were work permit holders arriving from various countries, with no reported asymptomatic cases. The number of new cases in the community remained stable, with 25 cases discharged on Thursday, leaving 57 patients in hospital.

site_title: China will assess food safety threats posed by Fukushima water release: ministry
summary: China plans to assess potential food safety threats from Japan's release of contaminated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea. The release, expected to start in about two years, has drawn opposition from China, South Korea, and Taiwan. China's commerce ministry will evaluate the impact on related food and agricultural products and their trade.

site_title: Singapore's ageing population presses for new way to build private eldercare facilities
summary: Singapore's government tender for a 30-year leasehold site for a proposed dementia care village along Gibraltar Crescent in Sembawang drew only one bid, valued at S$15 million, which was deemed too low. The bid price may indicate the difficulty of paying full upfront land price for a project relying on long-term revenue. Experts suggest this may be a sign that a new approach to building private eldercare facilities is needed to address Singapore's ageing population.

site_title: KKR-backed AppLovin raises US$2b in US IPO at over US$28b valuation
summary: AppLovin, a mobile app and gaming company backed by KKR & Co, raised US$2 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) at a price of US$80 per share, valuing the company at US$28.64 billion. The IPO marks the latest player in the mobile gaming industry to list itself on the stock market, amid surging demand for video games during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Vietnam could export 4% of world's electronics by 2025, but logistical bottlenecks a potential constraint
summary: Vietnam is projected to export around 4% of the world's electronics by 2025, driven by its growing manufacturing sector, according to Oxford Economics. The country experienced a 2.9% GDP growth in 2020, outperforming other economies globally. Its share in global goods exports increased to 1.6% in 2020, up from 1.4% in 2019 and 0.5% in 2010. However, logistical bottlenecks could pose a constraint to its export growth.

site_title: Singapore property investment to recover to pre-Covid levels in coming quarters: Colliers
summary: Singapore property sales are expected to recover to pre-Covid levels in the coming quarters, according to Colliers. Total property investment volume reached S$3.8 billion in Q1 2021, with commercial and industrial segments driving growth. Commercial volumes jumped 337% qoq and 43.8% yoy, while industrial sales gained 140.6% qoq. Residential investment sales, excluding government land sales, grew 12.9% qoq and 154% yoy. Colliers expects private land sales via en bloc and collective sales to recover in 2021.

site_title: SIA, Scoot to stop flying transit passengers from Singapore to HK
summary: Singapore Airlines and Scoot will stop flying transit passengers from Singapore to Hong Kong until further notice due to new regulatory requirements in Hong Kong. The move affects flights starting on Saturday for Singapore Airlines and April 30 for Scoot. Passengers originating from Hong Kong can still transfer through Changi Airport. The suspension comes after two Covid-19 cases were detected on a Scoot flight from Singapore to Hong Kong, and a similar ban was imposed on Singapore Airlines two weeks earlier.

images.alt_text: Budget carrier Scoot passenger flights departing from Singapore will not be allowed to land in Hong Kong for two weeks starting Friday, after two Covid-19 cases were detected on a Scoot flight on Sunday.

site_title: Deliveroo's orders more than doubled in first quarter
summary: Deliveroo reported a 114% year-on-year increase in group orders to 71 million and a 130% year-on-year increase in gross transaction value to £1.65 billion in the first quarter. The company attributed the growth to strong demand in the UK and Ireland, driven by record new customer growth and sustained demand from existing customers.

site_title: Europe: Earnings, metal rally spur record high for stocks
summary: European stocks hit a record high on Thursday, driven by a rally in commodity prices and positive earnings reports. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3%, with miners and travel stocks leading the gain. UK's FTSE 100 outperformed, while Swiss company ABB raised its sales outlook and French advertising group Publicis returned to organic growth. However, Britain's Deliveroo slipped 1.5% despite strong quarterly orders.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on Kakao boost, recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.38% to 3,194.33, led by Kakao's 18.7% surge after a 5-for-1 stock split. Foreigners bought 265.8 billion won worth of shares, while the won inched down to 1,117.6 per dollar. The benchmark Kospi index closed up 11.95 points, with chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix also rising, while LG Chem fell. The Bank of Korea kept interest rates steady and sounded upbeat on growth and expected inflation to accelerate.

site_title: Naiise goes into liquidation; founder to file for bankruptcy
summary: Naiise, a Singaporean retailer, has gone into liquidation after closing its last store due to years of late payments to vendors. Founder Dennis Tay will file for personal bankruptcy, citing exhaustion of savings and heavy bank loans. Naiise, which started in 2013, owes vendors sums ranging from hundreds to five-digit figures. Tay apologized to employees, marketplace sellers, and those owed money, attributing the business's demise to his own failures. The company's financial struggles also led to a fine of S$8,000 for late CPF contributions.

site_title: 80% of Singapore investors believe in ESG, but only a quarter take action: survey
summary: A survey by HSBC found that 80% of Singapore investors believe in ESG (environmental, social, and governance) principles, but only 25% incorporate these factors into their investments. Lack of suitable products and limited investor knowledge are major barriers to sustainable investing in Singapore. Investors cited a lack of knowledge on ESG investing, concerns about financial losses, and limited product options as major hurdles. Despite this, 46% of investors believe their portfolios will comprise 100% sustainable investments in the next 3-5 years, driving demand for tailored ESG products.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 14-month closing high as jobs data cements recovery view
summary: Australian shares reached a 14-month high, closing 0.5% higher at 7,058.6, driven by strong employment data that cemented confidence in the economy's recovery. Unemployment dropped to a one-year low, and the number of people in work surpassed its pre-pandemic peak. Mining and energy stocks led the rebound, with BHP and Rio Tinto jumping 2.9% and 3% respectively, while Whitehaven Coal fell 16.8%. Energy stocks also rose, with Ampol climbing 6.4% after reporting a profit, while gold stocks tumbled 2.36%.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes nearly unchanged as tech shares cap gains
summary: Japanese shares closed slightly higher on Thursday, led by cyclical firms and banks, while technology stocks capped gains. The Nikkei rose 0.07% to 29,642.69, and the broader Topix gained 0.54% to 1,962.78. Shipping firms, such as Nippon Yusen and Mitsui OSK Lines, advanced, while chip-related firms Tokyo Electron and Advantest fell after an analyst cut their investment ratings. Financial shares rose after Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo reported bumper profits.

site_title: US dollar at three-week low as Fed's dovish message sinks in
summary: The US dollar reached a three-week low against a basket of currencies as investors reacted to the Federal Reserve's dovish message, which has led to a decline in US bond yields. The dollar index fell to 91.571, while the euro traded near its highest level in four weeks. Reassurances from Fed officials that interest rates will remain low have stabilized US bonds, and investors are giving the Fed the benefit of the doubt, despite concerns about potential future rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The dollar nursed losses on Thursday, holding near a three-week low against a basket of currencies as US bond yields pulled back from last month's surge with investors buying the Federal Reserve's arguments that interest rates can stay low.

site_title: US envoy assures Taiwan relations are 'stronger than ever'
summary: US envoy Christopher Dodd stated during a visit to Taiwan that relations between the US and Taiwan are "stronger than ever". This comes as Taiwan faces increasingly hostile moves by China. The US delegation, led by former senator Dodd, former deputy secretaries of state Richard Armitage and James Steinberg, met with Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen, affirming the US partnership with Taiwan. The visit comes amid rising tensions between the US and China over Taiwan.

site_title: Japan ruling party official says cancelling Olympics is an option: Kyodo
summary: A senior Japanese ruling party official, Toshihiro Nikai, has stated that cancelling this year's Olympics is an option if the coronavirus crisis worsens, with rising cases in Tokyo and Osaka. The Games are set to begin on July 23, but polls indicate little support in Japan for holding the Games during a pandemic. The official's comments, made in a television interview, have sparked a trend on Twitter with over 20,000 tweets using the hashtag "#CancelOlympics".

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday's session down
summary: Hong Kong shares began Thursday's session down, following a soft lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.10% to 28,872.82, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21% to 3,409.61. The decline marks a two-day loss, after the markets experienced gains on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia's exports and imports grow more than expected in March
summary: Indonesia's exports and imports grew more than expected in March, with merchandise exports rising 30.47% to US$18.35 billion due to higher commodity prices and rebounding global demand. Imports also increased, supported by improving domestic manufacturing activity. The growth was driven by rising shipments of oil, natural gas, palm oil, steel, and coal, as well as elevated commodity prices and demand from top trade partners like China and the US.

site_title: Asean IPOs fall in Q1 amid record-breaking global IPO market
summary: ASEAN saw 23 IPOs raising US$2.4 billion in Q1 2021, down from 32 listings in the same period last year. Thailand's exchanges raised US$1.6 billion, while Indonesia led in deal numbers with 12 IPOs.
