The first quarter is typically a muted period for IPOs in Asean, with companies gearing up for capital market activities. This decline marks a departure from the record-breaking global IPO market.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda warns of lingering Covid-19 pain on economy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that Japan's economy is likely to experience a modest recovery due to lingering caution over the coronavirus pandemic. The economy is expected to improve thanks to a rebound in global demand and the government's fiscal spending, but record Covid-19 cases in Osaka will likely continue to impact growth. Kuroda's comments come as Japan confronts a resurgence in infections and targeted lockdown measures are enforced in the western region.

site_title: Philippines lifts nine-year-old moratorium on new mining projects
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has lifted a nine-year moratorium on new mining projects, allowing the government to enter into agreements for new mining projects and review existing contracts for possible renegotiation. This move aims to boost state revenues. The executive order, signed on April 14, 2021, was made public by the presidential palace. The decision is seen as a significant shift in the country's mining policies, following years of delays and controversy surrounding the industry.

site_title: New Singapore private home sales soar in March; buyers zoom in on posh condos
summary: Singapore private home sales surged in March with 1,296 units sold, doubling February's 645. Buyers targeted high-end condos, with 546 units sold in the core central region, an eight-year high. Developers launched 959 units for sale in March, up from 167 in February. The number of transactions in the core central region made up 42.1% of new sales, with rest of central region and outside central region sales making up 29.9% and 27.9%, respectively.

site_title: Biden, Suga to send signal to assertive China at US-Japan summit
summary: US President Joe Biden and Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga will meet to highlight Tokyo's central role in countering an increasingly assertive China. The summit will emphasize regional defense and human rights concerns, with Biden seeking Japan's support in the face of China's rising maritime activities and human rights abuses in Xinjiang. The meeting comes ahead of a general election in Japan and may set the tone for future cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Gold gains on weaker dollar; retail sales, jobless data eyed
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,738.96 per ounce, boosted by a weaker US dollar. Investors await US jobless claims and March retail sales data. The dollar held near a three-week low, with US bond yields leveling off. A weaker dollar increases gold's appeal as a safe-haven metal.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars break higher, data speaks of strong Q1
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged to three-week highs as upbeat data showed the Australian economy grew strongly in Q1, with 70,700 jobs added and unemployment at a one-year low. The Aussie jumped 1% to US$0.7718, while the kiwi dollar rose 1.2% to US$0.7145. Strong economic data also led to gains against the yen and euro. The Reserve Bank of Australia and New Zealand reiterated their commitment to patient monetary policies, with no interest rate hikes expected until late next year and early 2023, respectively.

site_title: Australia's March jobs jump 70,700, unemployment drops to 5.6%
summary: Australia's job market saw a significant boost in March, with 70,700 new jobs created, exceeding forecasts by double. Unemployment dropped to 5.6%, its lowest level in a year, and the number of employed surpassed pre-pandemic levels. This marks a remarkable recovery from the 7.5% unemployment rate in July last year. The strong job market data is seen as a positive indicator for the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Australian job creation again far outstripped expectations in March as unemployment dropped to a one-year low and the total number of employed passed its pre-pandemic peak.

site_title: Can Biden's new infrastructure plan rival China's Belt and Road Initiative?
summary: The US, under President Biden, is considering a new infrastructure plan to rival China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), which has become the global leader in infrastructure development. The BRI, launched in 2013, has attracted 138 nations with investments of over $690 billion. The US aims to unite allies and partners to counter China's influence, proposing a similar initiative to promote high-quality and environmentally sustainable infrastructure development. However, the US faces challenges in convincing the global community that it can provide a superior alternative, given its own infrastructure deficits and declining investments in developing nations.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders struggle to build on rally
summary: Asia markets experienced a mixed performance on Thursday as investors struggled to build on recent rallies, amid concerns that valuations may have run too high. The Dow managed a gain, while other major indexes were underwhelming. The Chinese central bank's efforts to control debt issuance and pull back on stimulus measures also weighed on markets. Despite this, some analysts noted that investors remain optimistic about the region's recovery, with stocks still trading at elevated levels.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Bukit Sembawang, Sinarmas Land, Boustead Projects
summary: Jardine Matheson completed its 15% stake acquisition in Jardine Strategic Holdings, with the latter delisting from the Singapore Exchange, London Stock Exchange, and Bermuda Stock Exchange. Bukit Sembawang put The Atelier's public launch on hold due to health and safety concerns. Sinarmas Land sold a London property for £72 million. Boustead Projects agreed to a settlement with Veolia ES Singapore Industrial for a net sum of S$4.9 million.

site_title: Grab's planned IPO will erase its 2023 refinancing risk: S&P
summary: Grab's planned initial public offering (IPO) will eliminate its 2023 refinancing risk, according to S&P Global Ratings. The IPO's estimated $4.5 billion cash proceeds will convert the company's convertible redeemable preference shares into equity, reducing its 2023 maturity wall. S&P maintains its "B-" rating, expecting Grab to implement growth strategies to achieve higher profitability and positive free operating cash flow by 2023. Despite this, the agency notes Grab will likely remain loss-making over the next two years due to a currency mismatch between its debt and operating cash flows.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.07% at 29,640.66, and the Topix index up 0.42%. The gains came after a mixed close on Wall Street, amid concerns over Japan's expanding virus infections. The moves were largely driven by cautious trade, with investors brushing off recent Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% in early trade on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,186.99 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 79 to 29, with P5 Capital and Ntegrator International seeing significant gains. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also traded higher. In contrast, Wall Street stocks mostly fell amid concerns over excessive equity valuations, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 1.0% and the S&P 500 down 0.4%.

site_title: Beijing's top official in Hong Kong warns foreign powers not to interfere
summary: Beijing's top official in Hong Kong, Luo Huining, warned foreign powers against interfering in the city, threatening countermeasures. This comes amid escalating tensions between Hong Kong and Western governments, who have condemned Beijing's imposition of a national security law in June. The law has been criticized as an attempt to suppress dissent in the former British colony.

site_title: Jardine Strategic acquisition completed; shares to delist from three exchanges
summary: Jardine Strategic Holdings has completed its acquisition by Jardine Matheson Holdings, with the conglomerate acquiring a 15% stake. The acquisition was approved by shareholders at a special general meeting and led to the company's shares being delisted from three exchanges: the Financial Conduct Authority's Official List, the London Stock Exchange, and the Bermuda Stock Exchange. The shares were expected to be suspended from trading on the Singapore Exchange mainboard on Tuesday, with the delisting taking effect on April 15.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group's potential share transaction with third party to be dropped
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) announced it will not pursue a potential share transaction with a third party, citing a lack of progress in preliminary discussions. The move comes after significant price movements and trading volume in the shares, prompting a query from its sponsor CIMB Bank Singapore. SMG remains open to exploring avenues to improve shareholder value, but will focus on other initiatives. As of Thursday, SMG shares were trading at 31 Singapore cents, down 3.5 cents or 10.1% from the previous day.

site_title: Qantas boosts domestic capacity outlook as travel demand improves
summary: Qantas Airways has boosted its domestic capacity outlook, forecasting it will reach 90% of pre-pandemic levels in the current quarter and 107% by the next financial year. The airline's CEO, Alan Joyce, attributed the positive signs to sustained recovery and strong travel demand. Qantas had previously forecast 80% pre-pandemic levels, allowing it to stop burning cash. International flights are expected to resume on October 31, pending Australia's vaccination rollout.

site_title: Gallant Venture files notice of three straight years of losses
summary: Gallant Venture, a Singapore-listed developer and master planner, reported three consecutive years of pre-tax losses as of its audited full-year consolidated accounts. The company's net loss widened to S$59.1 million in FY2020, from S$52.4 million the previous year. Its resort segment was largely impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak. Gallant Venture still meets the financial entry criteria, with a six-month average daily market capitalisation of S$709.8 million, and no dividend was declared for FY2020.

site_title: GameStop leads 'meme stocks' higher, snaps seven-day losing streak
summary: GameStop shares rose 18% on Wednesday, snapping a seven-day losing streak, to close at US$166.53. The move followed a late-Tuesday announcement that the company would pay back US$216 million in debt early, boosting optimism among supporters. Analysts say the debt repayment eliminates bankruptcy risk, but Wedbush Securities still has a "Sell" rating on the stock. The stock has surged over 780% this year, fueled by a short squeeze in January.

site_title: Instagram dabbles with letting people hide 'likes'
summary: Instagram is testing the option to hide "like" counts on posts, allowing users to decide whether to see or hide the counts. The experiment aims to ease pressure from seeking approval from others and potentially reduce the impact on mental health. Some users found the feature beneficial, while others still want to see like counts to track popularity. If successful, the feature could be made permanent and extended to Facebook, which owns Instagram. Experts say the insatiable quest for "likes" can be addictive and have devastating effects, particularly for younger people.

site_title: Almost half of Shopify's top executives to depart company: CEO
summary: Shopify's CEO, Tobi Lutke, announced that three top executives will leave the company in the coming months, including the chief talent officer, chief legal officer, and chief technology officer. The departures follow the departure of the chief product officer in September. Despite this, Lutke expressed confidence in the company's leadership bench and stated that the departures were unanimous for the best of the company. Shopify shares fell 5.1% after the announcement, citing concerns about slowing revenue growth.

site_title: Nato allies agree to start Afghan pullout by May 1
summary: NATO allies agreed to start withdrawing their forces from Afghanistan by May 1, following the US announcement to pull its troops out by September. The withdrawal will be orderly and coordinated, with the goal of completing the US and Resolute Support Mission forces within a few months. The decision comes amid a growing consensus in Washington that little more can be achieved in Afghanistan, and despite stalled peace efforts between the Taliban and the Afghan government.

site_title: BNPL firm Zip to raise A$400m for expansion
summary: Zip Co, an Australian buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) firm, plans to raise A$400 million through senior unsecured convertible notes to fund growth and expansion. The funds will support core and international growth opportunities, including expansion into Canada and South-east Asia. The company reported record quarterly earnings and increased transaction volume by over 100% in the March quarter. Zip also made a soft launch in Canada and acquired a strategic stake in Philippine firm TendoPay. The additional capital will help the company compete with larger rivals like Afterpay.

site_title: mm2 Asia raises nearly S$54.7m from rights issue
summary: mm2 Asia raised nearly S$54.7 million from its rights issue priced at 4.7 Singapore cents per share, a 60.8% discount from the previous closing price of 12 Singapore cents per share. The issue was announced on February 3.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.74 points, or 0.05%, to 1,599.02. Volume was 250.49 million lots worth RM150.52 million. Gainers beat losers 212 to 154.

site_title: Twitch star hits a high with month-long live stream
summary: Twitch star Ludwig Ahgren set a new record for subscribers with over 283,000 during a month-long live stream. The record-breaking stunt, which began in mid-March, surpassed that of popular streamer Tyler "Ninja" Blevins. Ahgren promised to donate a portion of each $5 monthly subscription to charities, including The Humane Society and St. Jude's. The stream, which was initially intended to last 31 days, ended on Tuesday. Ahgren's achievement solidified his position as the third most popular streamer on Twitch, with 2.65 million followers.

site_title: Former star of US show 'The Bachelor' says he's gay
summary: Former Bachelor contestant Colton Underwood revealed on Good Morning America that he is gay, having come to terms with his sexuality earlier this year. Underwood, 29, expressed regret for accepting the role of Bachelor and acknowledged that female contestants may have felt misled. He initially struggled with his identity, experiencing suicidal thoughts, but has since taken control of his life. Underwood's revelation marks a significant shift in his public persona, following his appearance on The Bachelor in 2018 and The Bachelorette in 2018.

site_title: Federal Reserve sees more optimism among US business, activity accelerating
summary: US businesses are feeling more optimistic as vaccinations against Covid-19 become common, with economic activity accelerating moderately in recent weeks. The Federal Reserve's survey of business conditions found that consumer spending strengthened, manufacturing activity expanded further, and half of the districts reported robust growth. However, supply chain disruptions and price increases, particularly in the manufacturing and construction sectors, are causing complications. Most districts reported modest to moderate increases in headcounts, with the strongest gains in manufacturing, construction, and leisure and hospitality.

site_title: Malaysia builder rally hots up as pump-priming signs appear
summary: Malaysian builders are seeing a surge in contract wins and mega infrastructure projects, leading to a rally in the industry. Kerjaya Prospek Group, one of the country's largest contractors, won its first job of 2021, boosting its shares to a 20-month high. This trend is expected to continue with more projects in the pipeline, indicating a revival in the construction sector. The positive news has raised hopes for the country's economy.

site_title: China must halve power sector emissions by 2030 to meet climate goals: study
summary: China must halve its carbon dioxide emissions from coal-fired power plants by 2030 to meet its goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2060, according to a study. The country needs to shut, retrofit, or reserve around 364 gigawatts of coal-fired power by 2030, which is approximately a third of its current total. This move could save China $1.6 trillion and improve its international reputation. Experts recommend China halt new coal plant approvals to meet climate goals, but the country's 2021-2025 five-year plan aims to promote the "clean and efficient use of coal".

site_title: Luxury retailers use social media, virtual showrooms to woo customers
summary: Luxury retailers are adapting to the pandemic by leveraging social media, virtual showrooms, and online sales to connect with customers. Brands such as Moncler, Hermes, and LVMH are using video streaming and WhatsApp to showcase their products, with sales assistants acting as personal shoppers to pamper VIP customers. Online revenues have doubled to 20% of sales, with analysts predicting a 25% rise by 2023. This shift is expected to continue, with sales assistants being trained to build relationships with customers and provide personalized service.

site_title: US CEOs sign statement against 'discriminatory' voting laws
summary: Hundreds of US CEOs, companies, and billionaires signed a statement opposing discriminatory voting laws, including those in Georgia. The legislation, enacted after the state's Republican governor signed a measure imposing voter ID requirements and limiting voting hours, has sparked public criticism and boycotts from corporations and sports bodies. The statement emphasizes the importance of equal voting opportunities for all eligible voters.

site_title: China's Q1 growth hits record 18.7%: analysts' poll
summary: China's economy grew at a record 18.7% in Q1, rebounding from a historic Covid-19 contraction, driven by exports and domestic demand. This is the only major economy to grow last year. Analysts' poll forecasts China's GDP growth to slow in the future, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Spanish-language TV giants team up to take on Netflix
summary: Spanish-language TV giants Televisa and Univision are joining forces to create a new company, Televisa-Univision, which will be the largest Spanish-language media group in the world. The deal, backed by SoftBank and Google, aims to compete with Netflix and Amazon by launching a global streaming platform in early 2022. Televisa will contribute its content assets and receive $4.8 billion in cash and Univision shares, while Univision will receive most of the remaining assets. The new company is expected to have estimated combined sales of around $4.0 billion and cater to the 600 million Spanish speakers worldwide.

site_title: Edinburgh festivals will go ahead, onsite and online
summary: The Edinburgh International Festival will proceed with in-person and online performances from August 7-29, despite the ongoing pandemic. The festival's director, Fergus Linehan, confirmed that events will be staged in specially designed pavilions to ensure social distancing. The festival's programme will be released in June, and many performances will be streamed for free for international audiences. The festival aims to return to live performance, with a focus on smaller, innovative works, and hopes to provide confidence to other events to press ahead with plans.

site_title: Oil climbs nearly 5% on signs of increasing crude demand
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 5% on Wednesday, driven by a report from the International Energy Agency predicting global demand and supply rebalancing in the second half of the year. US crude inventories fell by 5.9 million barrels, exceeding forecasts, and petrol supplies rose to 8.9 million barrels per day, the highest since August. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries also raised its global demand forecast by 70,000 bpd. Analysts attribute the gains to signs of a strong economic recovery in China and the US, and the ongoing vaccination efforts in the US.

site_title: Open the windows to curb Covid spread: experts
summary: Experts say opening windows and ventilating spaces should be a key measure to prevent Covid-19 spread. Despite mounting evidence, the role of airborne transmission is often overlooked, with crowded, poorly ventilated indoor spaces being a high-risk area. The virus primarily spreads through inhalation at close range, not contact with surfaces or at long range. The World Health Organization has encouraged better ventilation in buildings, and experts emphasize the importance of added emphasis on ventilation due to the long airborne lifespan of tiny particles.

site_title: Toshiba CEO exit gives better governance a chance
summary: Toshiba's CEO, Nobuaki Kurumatani, resigned after a series of controversies, including accounting scandals and a US nuclear business collapse. His ties to buyout bidder CVC Capital Partners raised concerns. Toshiba now has a chance to improve corporate governance. An independent investigation into the affair was approved by shareholders, and the company is reviewing a $20 billion bid from CVC. Toshiba's new chairman, Satoshi Tsunakawa, must ensure a robust and open process for reviewing the bid, and a good deal for shareholders.

site_title: Europe: SAP, LVMH earnings nudge stocks higher; German shares lag
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings from SAP and LVMH, while German shares lagged due to a cut in 2021 GDP forecast. LVMH reached record highs, spurring gains in luxury stocks. SAP's cloud sales rose, boosting its 2021 revenue outlook. Despite a decline in euro zone industrial output, economists remain upbeat about the bloc's prospects as it reopens later in the year.

site_title: Thai stocks enjoying boost on links to medicinal drugs
summary: Thailand has granted 1,649 licenses for cannabis use since January, boosting stocks of companies involved in the medicinal drug industry. The Thai Food and Drug Administration has approved licenses for growing, possession, research, extraction, and production of cannabis. However, some local securities companies are losing interest due to concerns over the lack of clear business plans and profitability. The SET is concerned but allows listed companies to disclose their plans, as long as they comply with Thai laws.

site_title: All eyes on what course new OCBC chief will set
summary: OCBC's new CEO, Helen Wong, starts her top role today, having been plucked from HSBC. She will inherit a franchise with strong fundamentals and capital levels, and is expected to push the lender to its next stage of growth amid a recovering global economy. With geopolitical tensions and digital bank entrants to watch out for, Wong will have to navigate challenges such as navigating Hong Kong uncertainties and articulating the bank's digitalisation strategy. Her expertise in Greater China and experience in investment and corporate banking will be crucial in driving OCBC's growth.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall amid valuation concerns
summary: US stocks fell amid concerns about excessive equity valuations, with the Nasdaq Composite Index sinking 1.0% to 13,857.84. Metal producers and oil companies, such as ExxonMobil, US Steel, and Freeport-McMoRan, rose, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell 0.2% and 0.4%, respectively. The Federal Reserve's survey highlighted supply chain snarls and increasing demand, but also rising optimism as COVID-19 vaccinations become common. Equity strategist warn that stocks are "priced to perfection" ahead of the earnings season.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average eked out a 0.2 per cent gain to 33,730.89, while the S&P 500 fell 0. 4 per cent to 4,124.66.

site_title: New local Covid-19 cluster reported, first since March 25
summary: A new local Covid-19 cluster has been reported in Singapore, linked to a 44-year-old Papua New Guinea national who arrived on March 25. The national tested negative multiple times before testing positive on April 12. Three other cases, also on the same flight, were identified as close contacts. The Ministry of Health has classified the case as locally transmitted, likely through exposure to coworkers. The cluster brings Singapore's total cases to 60,719, with 27 new cases reported, including 26 imported cases.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde says euro zone economy still on crutches
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that the euro zone economy is still relying on monetary and fiscal stimulus, likening it to a patient on two crutches. This marks a pushback against suggestions to dial back emergency bond purchases as soon as July. Lagarde emphasized that the ECB will not remove these crutches until the economy makes a full recovery.

site_title: EU lays out US$1t debt plan to fund recovery from Covid-19 pandemic
summary: The European Union has proposed a $1 trillion debt plan to fund its recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic over five years. The plan, called NextGenerationEU, aims to issue bonds and bills via a network of primary bank dealers by September. Almost a third of the funds will be in green bonds, and the EU will begin issuing debt via auction for the first time. The plan faces challenges, including ratification by EU member states and court challenges in Germany and Poland.

site_title: Singtel associate Bharti Airtel unveils new corporate structure to focus on digital
summary: Bharti Airtel, a joint-venture company of Singtel, has announced a new corporate structure to focus on digital, unlocking value for shareholders. The new structure will house all digital assets under Airtel Digital Limited, while telecom businesses will be under Airtel Limited. Airtel Payments Bank will remain separate, and infrastructure entities, international subsidiaries, and affiliates will remain unchanged. The new structure aims to provide agility, expertise, and operational rigour, serving customers brilliantly while unlocking value for shareholders.

site_title: Buyer from Fujian pays S$39.3m for Sentosa Cove villa
summary: A buyer from Fujian province purchased a sea-facing bungalow in Sentosa Cove for S$39.3 million, or nearly S$2,012 per square foot based on the 19,550 sq ft land area. This is the latest deal in a series of Chinese buyers acquiring Singapore property.

site_title: London penthouse offered for sale at US$241m
summary: A London penthouse at One Hyde Park is being offered for sale at US$241 million, according to entrepreneur Nick Candy. The 18,000-square-foot property has five bedrooms, a private spa and gym, and two wraparound terraces, and was refinanced with a loan from Credit Suisse Group in 2018. The sale could be a signal that London's luxury home market is recovering after tax increases. If sold, it would be the second mega deal at One Hyde Park this year, following a hedge fund boss's near deal to purchase an unfinished penthouse.

site_title: TikTok founder now ranked among world's richest
summary: TikTok founder Zhang Yiming's net worth has surpassed $60 billion, ranking him alongside Tencent's Pony Ma and bottled-water king Zhong Shanshan. Despite the challenges faced by ByteDance, including the Trump administration's pressure, the company has continued to grow, with revenue more than doubling last year. Zhang is known for his long-term approach to business, focusing on building an enduring global brand. As the Chinese government seeks to rein in powerful corporations, Zhang's wealth has become a significant concern.

site_title: Beijing signals end of China Big Tech's golden age
summary: Beijing has signaled the end of China's Big Tech's golden age, imposing record fines and overhaul orders on Alibaba Group and Ant Group. The country's government has asserted its authority, warning tech giants that "the red line of laws cannot be touched." Companies like Alibaba, Ant, and Tencent are expected to streamline non-core businesses, reduce influence, and seek sign-offs from Beijing. The move is a response to the industry's aggressive expansion and dominance, with regulators seeking to curb monopolies and promote competition.

site_title: Coronavirus variants don't have to be scary. Still, mask up
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic's variants, despite their frequent changes, are largely ineffective and pose little threat to public health. Of the 136 million sequenced virus cases, only a handful have been associated with significant changes, and vaccines remain effective against these variants. The US is experiencing a fourth wave of cases, primarily in Michigan, but vaccines can help mitigate this surge. Combining vaccination with mask-wearing and distancing is the fastest way to end the pandemic.

site_title: Korean startup building chip to save traders microseconds
summary: A South Korean startup, Rebellions Inc, is developing a microchip designed to speed up artificial intelligence in high-frequency trading by a few microseconds, aiming to cut precious milliseconds off reaction times. The chip, an application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC), could halve the microseconds needed to make orders. The company, backed by $6.68 million in investments, plans to have a prototype ready in the second half of 2021 and quadruple its workforce by 2023. The technology could also be applied to cloud services and autonomous driving.

site_title: Coinbase valued at US$83b in choppy Nasdaq debut
summary: Coinbase Global Inc, a cryptocurrency exchange, made its Nasdaq debut with a valuation of US$83 billion, swinging between US$112 billion and US$83 billion. The company's stock opened at US$381 per share, up 52.4% from its reference price. Founded in 2012, Coinbase boasts 56 million users and an estimated US$223 billion assets on its platform. The company's valuation has surged in line with bitcoin's gains this year, with revenue estimated to be over US$1.8 billion in the first quarter. Regulatory risks also loom, particularly with the increasing number of digital assets users.

site_title: Myanmar activists remember dead with red paint protests
summary: Myanmar activists held red paint protests on the second day of the traditional new year holiday, marking the blood of people killed in protests against the junta. The display aimed to shame the military, with people marching and holding signs calling for the release of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi. The protests, which began on Tuesday, have brought the economy to a standstill, with the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners reporting 710 protester deaths since the coup. The US and other Western countries have imposed limited sanctions, while the UN human rights office fears the military clampdown could escalate into a civil conflict.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents extend rise in March as rental volumes rebound: SRX
summary: Rental volumes for condominium units and HDB flats rose in March, with condo units surging 32.4% to an 8-month high and HDB flats increasing 41.2% to a 9-month high. Rents for condo units rose 0.8% and HDB rents increased 0.5% from February to March. Occupancy rates remain high, driven by a steady stream of Singapore permanent residents and long-term pass holders returning to the market, leading to higher rental demand and low supply.

site_title: Bernard Madoff, mastermind of giant Ponzi scheme, dies at 82
summary: Bernard Madoff, mastermind of the largest Ponzi scheme in history, died at 82. He was serving a 150-year term at the Butner Federal Correctional Complex in North Carolina after being convicted of fraud, money laundering, and other crimes. Madoff defrauded thousands of clients of over $19 billion, promising stellar returns that he actually paid from new investors. His death was confirmed by his attorney, Brandon Sample, who said Madoff had requested compassionate early release due to end-stage kidney disease.

site_title: In pursuit of lasting development
summary: The Papua New Guinea Sustainable Development Program (PNGSDP) is a non-profit company focused on sustainable development, poverty alleviation, and lasting benefits. Led by managing director John Wylie, the organization invests in four key areas: health, education, jobs creation through agribusinesses, and infrastructure. PNGSDP has a $1.6 billion fund and has reported a 12.1% return on investment last year. The organization aims to implement long-term projects, such as aerial health patrols and rural health centers, and has supported the country's Covid-19 response. PNGSDP's focus on creating livelihoods in the cash economy through agribusinesses has significant growth potential. The organization has a lean core team of 15 staff, 90% of whom are local women, and is committed to internal sustainability and succession planning.

site_title: 13 years after the GFC: Has anything really changed?
summary: The article examines whether 13 years have seen significant changes in the financial landscape since the 2008 Global Financial Crisis (GFC). Despite new consumer protection laws and reforms, financial institutions continue to offer high-risk, complex products to retail investors, such as cryptocurrencies and special purpose acquisition companies. Central banks' unlimited money printing has created a "risk off" market where investors underestimate risk, and the market's similarity to the 2008 era is concerning. The article concludes that despite efforts to reform, the financial system remains vulnerable to similar crises, and the old adage "the more things change, the more they stay the same" holds true.

site_title: Of politically exposed people and financial crime
summary: Financial institutions worldwide were fined a record US$10.6 billion in 2020 for financial crime violations, including anti-money laundering and know your customer regulations. Politically exposed persons (PEPs) require additional scrutiny due to money laundering and corruption concerns. However, categorizing PEPs can be challenging due to jurisdictional variances in definitions. Recent cases, such as the Luanda Leaks, have led to hefty fines for financial institutions with inadequate PEP management policies and processes. Regulators urge FIs to be more vigilant in identifying and managing PEPs to avoid costly fines.

images.alt_text: One of the most infamous financial crime stories in recent years is the 1MDB scandal, which implicated Goldman Sachs in a massive corruption scheme. Malaysian regulators issued two of the highest value enforcement actions in 2020 - a settlement with Goldman that included a US$2.5 billion penalty and the guaranteed return of US$1.4 billion in assets.

site_title: Last year's low base will lift GDP figures; but sequential numbers can add perspective
summary: Singapore's first-quarter GDP growth beat economists' consensus forecast, reaching 0.2% year-over-year, driven by the low base effect from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects full-year growth to exceed the 4-6% forecast range, barring global economic setbacks. Sequential figures for the second quarter may be more reliable, but the low base effect still applies, raising the possibility of better-than-expected growth in the second quarter. The central bank expects the ongoing recovery to be sustained by an upturn in external demand.

images.alt_text: Advance estimates released on Wednesday put first-quarter gross domestic product growth at 0.2 per cent year on year, well in excess of economists' consensus forecast of -0.5 per cent.

site_title: S-Reit mergers have mostly been value destructive
summary: Singapore's S-Reit mergers have largely failed to deliver promised benefits, with most acquirer's share prices and total returns disappointing over time. Only Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has outperformed, returning 18.5% in price performance and 51.7% in total returns since its merger. Unitholders have seen price declines and negative returns for most merged entities, with managers citing Covid-19 and operational pressures as factors. Experts argue that mergers should focus on delivering cost savings and synergies, with managers needing to provide more transparency on post-merger plans and targets.

site_title: Banking software firm Alkami valued at more than US$3b in US market debut
summary: Alkami Technology, a US banking software provider, made its US stock market debut, valuing the company at over $3 billion. Its shares surged 38% on the first day, opening at $41.26 and surpassing the initial public offering price of $30. The company raised $180 million in the IPO, with over 160 financial institutions using its cloud-based digital banking services. Alkami's platform aims to help smaller financial firms compete with large US banks, and it served 9.7 million users in 2020.

site_title: Better prospects for warehouses this year
summary: Warehouses in Singapore are expected to see better prospects this year, following a resilient performance in 2020. However, rents for certain segments, such as multiple-user factory space, may face pressure due to economic uncertainties. The performance across the industrial market is expected to vary, with some segments experiencing rent increases and others facing declines.

images.alt_text: Rents for warehouses and business parks eased slightly by 1.3% and 1.1% respectively in 2020, while rents for multiple-user factory space retreated by 1.8%.

site_title: MOH sets up multi-stakeholder panel to address health insurance issues
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has established a 12-member Multilateral Healthcare Insurance Committee (MHIC) to address health insurance issues. The panel brings together MOH, doctors, insurers, hospitals, and consumer representatives to enhance the current system. The appointment takes effect on April 27, and the committee's recommendations will be released when ready. This move aims to improve collaboration and address issues in the healthcare insurance sector.

site_title: Transitioning to a new work-from-anywhere reality
summary: The post-Covid-19 working world is shifting towards a "work-from-anywhere" reality, where work can be done anywhere and for anyone. With eased Covid-19 workplace measurement rules, up to 75% of a company's workforce can return to the office, but many employers plan to maintain flexible work arrangements. Technological advancements and the need for remote work during the pandemic have made this new paradigm a necessary consideration for companies. As a result, the traditional 9-to-5 work model is becoming increasingly obsolete, and individuals can now work for anyone, regardless of location.

site_title: Biotech startup Immunoscape raises US$14m in funding
summary: Biotech startup Immunoscape has raised US$14 million in funding, valuing it at US$37.9 million, to scale operations in Singapore and the US and improve its immune-profiling technology. The funding, led by EDBI and existing investors, will be used to expand the team, build a San Diego laboratory, and increase its capacity for in-house research and development. Immunoscape aims to develop targeted cancer treatments using its platform, which assesses a person's immune health.

site_title: The rites of Spring
summary: Singapore's rising music stars, Jasmine Sokko, Yung Raja, and Iman Fandi, are featured in BTLuxe's luxury lifestyle edition, celebrating their music, fashion, and personal creative journeys. The issue also covers Watches & Wonders 2021, where top watch brands unveiled their novelties, and showcases new menus at Como Dempsey, including recipes for hobby chefs. The article concludes with a focus on luxury lifestyle and the start of Spring.

site_title: US dollar down as 'mean reversion' trade widens
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-month low due to strong demand for US bonds at a recent auction, which reduced Treasury yields and narrowed the interest rate advantage the dollar held over other major currencies. The rate differential between US and German benchmark 10-year yields narrowed to 193 basis points, down from over 200 bps at the start of the month. This trend is seen as a 'mean reversion' trade, where the dollar's value is expected to revert to its historical average.

site_title: Grab US listing: Anthony Tan's super vote and 4 notable details
summary: Grab, a nine-year-old ride-hailing company, is set to list on the US markets through a $39.6 billion merger with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). CEO Anthony Tan will control 60.4% of voting power due to a dual-class structure, granting him disproportionate voting rights. The company faces risks including corruption investigations and regulatory challenges related to gig worker classification. Grab reported a net loss of $2.7 billion in FY2020, but expects its deliveries business to drive adjusted net revenue growth. The company's valuation appears more bullish than peers, with analysts warning it may be over-ambitious.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat as big banks kick off earnings season
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Wednesday, April 14, 2021, as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan kicked off the first-quarter corporate earnings season, amidst a swift global economic recovery. The Dow Jones fell 8.32 points, while the S&P 500 opened lower and the Nasdaq Composite gained 7.98 points. This marked a mixed start to the earnings season, which is expected to provide insight into the US economy's performance.

site_title: Gojek and Tokopedia said to be finalising US$18b merger to form 'Goto'
summary: Indonesian internet companies Gojek and Tokopedia are reportedly finalizing a $18 billion merger to form 'Goto', with plans to close the deal as early as this month. The combined business will be led by four senior executives, including co-CEOs from both companies. This comes after a potential merger between Gojek and Singapore-based Grab ended, and follows Grab's own plans to go public in the US. The merger has been in the works since the beginning of this year.

site_title: Wells Fargo profit beats estimates as bank frees reserve funds
summary: Wells Fargo reported a first-quarter profit of $4.74 billion, beating Wall Street estimates, as the bank reduced its reserve funds by $1.6 billion. The lender's overhead ratio increased to 77% due to rising costs, but pre-provision profit fell 13% to $4.07 billion. Wells Fargo's CEO Charlie Scharf aims to overhaul the bank, avoiding material restructuring charges, as the bank stabilizes costs tied to its sales practices scandal. The bank's profit rose from $653 million a year earlier, largely due to a large provision for potential loan losses during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore dollar tipped to strengthen even as MAS waits to tighten monetary policy
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has left the door open for policy normalization at its next review in October, despite economic growth picking up. Analysts expect the Singapore dollar to appreciate, with some predicting a stronger half-yearly trend in the policy band. The MAS has not ruled out tightening policy, but core inflation is expected to stay low, keeping an accommodative policy stance. The MAS' stance and global price pressures are expected to fuel further upward pressure on the S$NEER, with some analysts predicting a 0.5% appreciation in the policy band if core inflation accelerates unexpectedly.

site_title: Insolvencies in Singapore to rise 3% from pre-Covid 2019 - among world's lowest
summary: Singapore's insolvencies are projected to rise 3% this year compared to pre-Covid 2019, ranking among the lowest globally, according to Atradius senior economist Theo Smid. This represents an increase of only 3% from the end of 2021 to 2019, indicating a relatively stable economic situation. The low increase suggests that Singapore's unprecedented support measures have helped mitigate the impact of the pandemic on businesses.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans to raise US$200m in US IPO
summary: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans to raise up to $200 million in a US IPO, aiming for a market capitalization of up to $4 billion. The airline, owned by FLC Group, plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange and increase its fleet to 40 aircraft by the end of the year. It aims to launch flights to new destinations, including the US, Australia, and the UK, if the COVID-19 pandemic improves. Bamboo Airways targets a 25% rise in pretax profit to $28.9 million this year.

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit jumps on record global dealmaking
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 5,800% increase in first-quarter profit to $6.7 billion, beating analyst expectations of $10.22 per share. The bank capitalized on record global dealmaking activity, with a 102% surge in total revenue to $17.7 billion. This was driven by fees from private firms merging with listed shell companies and a 47% increase in the global markets unit's performance. The bank's losses from the Archegos fire sale were deemed immaterial.

site_title: Connecting enterprises to opportunities in a post-pandemic world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated digital transformation among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, forcing them to rethink their direction and adapt to a hybrid work environment. To stay ahead, SMEs must prioritize digital solutions, cybersecurity, and customer-centric approaches. Key areas to focus on include maintaining productivity and engagement in hybrid work environments, adopting cloud-based services, and scaling operations through digital channels. SMEs should also upgrade their technology, partner with trusted providers, and invest in cybersecurity measures to lower the risk of exposure to cyber threats.

site_title: Ponzi schemer Bernie Madoff dead in prison
summary: Bernie Madoff, the mastermind behind the largest financial scam in history, died in prison at 82, according to US media. Madoff was sentenced to 150 years in prison in 2009 for running a pyramid-style scheme that defrauded tens of thousands worldwide, with estimated losses ranging from $25 billion to $63 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Economists have revised their 2021 GDP forecast upwards due to Singapore's better-than-expected Q1 data. Grab's merger with Anthony Tan will grant him 60.4% voting power. The Singapore dollar is expected to strengthen despite the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) holding off on tightening monetary policy. Swiss private bank Bank J. Safra Sarasin has been fined S$1m for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing rule breaches. The Atelier condo project's public launch has been put on hold due to caveats lodged for four units, and a substantial shareholder is voting against a partial offer for Procurri.

site_title: Sinarmas Land sells London property for £72m
summary: Sinarmas Land has sold a London property, Unlimited House, for £72 million (S$131.8 million). The 44,116 sq ft Grade-A office space and 2,928 sq ft residential block were sold on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis. The disposal resulted in a gain of approximately £15.6 million, increasing net tangible assets per share. The proceeds will be used for repayment of bank loan, working capital, or future acquisitions.

site_title: Europe powers express 'grave concern' over Iran enrichment move
summary: European powers, including Britain, France, and Germany, expressed "grave concern" over Iran's decision to boost uranium enrichment to 60% in response to an alleged Israeli attack on a nuclear facility. The move brings Iran closer to the 90% purity threshold for military use, increasing its potential "breakout time" to build an atomic bomb. Talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal have resumed in Vienna, with the aim of finding a rapid diplomatic solution, but Iran's recent actions are seen as "contrary to the constructive spirit and good faith of these discussions".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.57 points to 1,598.28, closing higher on Wednesday. The market saw a trading volume of 5.911 billion lots worth RM2.991 billion. Despite 510 losers, the number of gainers was 502.

site_title: US import prices increase solidly, seen temporarily boosting inflation
summary: US import prices rose 1.2% in March, driven by higher costs for petroleum products and tight supply chains, with the year-on-year increase reaching 6.9%, the largest rise since January 2012. Economists expect the inflation to be temporary, with supply chains adapting and becoming more efficient. Import prices excluding fuel and food jumped 0.8% last month, with prices for imported capital goods soaring 1.8% and agricultural exports increasing 2.4% due to higher prices for meat and soybeans.

images.alt_text: US import prices increased more than expected in March, lifted by higher costs for petroleum products and tight supply chains, the latest sign of inflation heating up as the economy reopens.

site_title: Noise pollution poses long-term risk to trees: study
summary: A study published in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B found that noise pollution poses a long-term risk to tree populations and plant diversity, even after the sources of excess noise are removed. Researchers in the US observed a 75% decline in pinyon pine seedlings in noisy sites compared to quiet ones. After removing noise sources, the seedlings failed to recover, suggesting that the impact of noise pollution persists even after the noise is gone. This long-term effect highlights the need to consider noise pollution in planning decisions and mitigate measures.

images.alt_text: Noise pollution poses a long-term risk to tree populations and plant diversity that may persist even after the sources of excess noise are removed, according to research published on Wednesday.

site_title: Thailand reports daily record of more than 1,300 new coronavirus cases
summary: Thailand reported a daily record of 1,335 new coronavirus cases, the largest rise since the start of the pandemic, amid a new wave of infections. The spike comes as Thais celebrate the Songkran new year holidays, prompting authorities to urge people to work from home and reduce gatherings. The country's total caseload is now at 35,910, with 7,491 patients currently being treated. Authorities are concerned about the strain on the healthcare system and are working to vaccinate the population, with plans to inoculate half of the adult population by the end of the year.

site_title: EU regulators set July 27 deadline for Aon, Willis deal
summary: EU antitrust regulators have set a July 27 deadline for their decision on Aon's $30 billion bid for Willis Towers Watson. Aon has offered to sell assets in five European nations to address competition concerns, including Willis Re, German retirement benefits, and insurance broking activities in France, Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands. The EU is seeking feedback from rivals and customers before deciding whether to demand more concessions or clear/block the deal.

site_title: Swiss private bank fined S$1m for breaching anti-money laundering, counter-terrorism financing rules
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) fined S$1 million Swiss private bank Bank J. Safra Sarasin (BJS) for serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing rules. The bank failed to properly document client relationships and transactions, and relied on customers' representations without corroborating them. The MAS directed BJS to appoint an independent party to validate its remediation measures, highlighting the importance of vigilance in guarding against illicit wealth and the need for strong oversight of controls to prevent money laundering and terrorism financing.

site_title: MOH sets up multi-stakeholder panel to address health insurance issues
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has established a 12-member Multilateral Healthcare Insurance Committee (MHIC) to address health insurance issues. The committee, comprising healthcare providers, payors, and consumer representatives, will work collaboratively to enhance Singapore's healthcare insurance system, ensuring quality and cost-effective care. The panel will provide recommendations on accessibility, transparency, and claims pre-authorisation processes. The MOH will work with the committee to strike a balance between preserving patient choice and providing sustainable care.

site_title: Boustead Projects unit to pay Veolia S$4.9m to settle contractual matter
summary: Boustead Projects' wholly-owned subsidiary Boustead Projects E&C (BP E&C) has agreed to pay Veolia ES Singapore Industrial S$4.9 million to settle a contractual matter related to a 2017 contract for a Singapore hazardous waste-treatment facility. The payment is part of an amicable settlement, following a letter of demand from Veolia for S$17.8 million last September.

site_title: JPMorgan Asia Pacific vice-chair El-Omari retires after 29 years
summary: Mac El-Omari, vice-chairman of investment banking for Asia Pacific at JPMorgan Chase & Co, is retiring after nearly 29 years with the bank. He will remain with the company for a few months to facilitate the transition and will leave in the summer. El-Omari expressed his gratitude to JPMorgan, calling it "integral part of my life" and stating that the team is "family" to him.

images.alt_text: Mac El-Omari, vice-chairman of investment banking for Asia Pacific at JPMorgan Chase & Co, is retiring from the bank after serving nearly three decades.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong 'finalising details' of air travel bubble, hope to announce plans soon
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are finalizing details for an air travel bubble, with plans to restart all forms of travel between the two cities without quarantine. The bubble was initially set for November last year but was postponed due to a spike in Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong. With the coronavirus situation in Hong Kong improving, talks have progressed, and Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam expects an early indication of agreement. Vaccination will be mandatory for travelers from Hong Kong heading to Singapore.

site_title: JPMorgan profit surges on huge trading, investment banking boost
summary: JPMorgan reported a substantial increase in first-quarter earnings, with net income rising to $14.3 billion, or $4.50 per share, driven by a surge in trading and investment banking activities. This beat analyst expectations of $3.10 per share. The bank's strong performance is attributed to favourable comparisons to the previous year, when it built reserves against loan defaults due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan reported substantially higher first-quarter earnings on Wednesday, as the largest US bank released more reserves and was aided by a blowout quarter from its trading desks and soaring investment banking fees.

site_title: Grab to give Anthony Tan 60.4% voting power; posted US$10.4b accumulated loss
summary: Grab's merger with Altimeter Growth Corp has granted CEO Anthony Tan 60.4% voting power, mirroring "super voting" shares seen in US tech companies. Post-merger, Tan will own 2.2% of the company, with a 45-vote Class B share for each Class B ordinary share. Grab has recorded a US$10.4 billion accumulated loss as of 2020, with a net loss of US$2.7 billion in 2020. The dual-class structure may raise concerns among retail investors, following criticism of excessive founder control in tech companies like Facebook.

site_title: Europe's vaccine rollout hit by doubts over J&J, AstraZeneca shots
summary: Europe's COVID-19 vaccine rollout is facing challenges due to concerns over blood clotting from Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca shots. The US FDA recommended pausing use of Johnson & Johnson's vaccine after six women under 50 developed rare blood clots, prompting European authorities to suspend or restrict its deployment. This move comes as Denmark has dropped AstraZeneca's vaccine due to similar blood clotting risks. The European Medicines Agency is set to issue guidance on the issue.

site_title: South Korean, Malaysian bonds get massive foreign inflows in March
summary: Foreign investors bought a net $7.4 billion worth of Asian bonds in March, with South Korean bonds receiving a record $8.1 billion inflow. This is the 10th consecutive month of foreign inflows into Asian bonds. Malaysian bonds also drew in $1.4 billion, while Indonesian and Indian bonds saw outflows. Despite rising US bond yields, South Korean bonds have been attracting heavy inflows due to the country's strong current account position and lower yields. The outlook for foreign inflows is uncertain due to expected US rate hikes and regional economic growth slowdowns.

site_title: Economists raise 2021 GDP forecast on better-than-expected Q1 data
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to perform better than initially forecast, following a 0.2% growth in Q1, reversing the 2.4% contraction in Q4. This is the first expansion since the Covid-19 pandemic began. Economists are revising their full-year growth forecast, with some predicting a better-than-expected performance. The positive Q1 data was a surprise to private-sector economists, who had anticipated a 0.5% contraction.

site_title: Sri Lanka bans 11 Muslim groups ahead of Easter attacks anniversary
summary: Sri Lanka has banned 11 Muslim groups, including the Islamic State and Al-Qaeda, ahead of the second anniversary of the Easter Sunday suicide bombings that killed 279 people. The ban, under the Prevention of Terrorism Act, carries a maximum 20-year prison sentence. The move comes amid threats from Roman Catholics to protest the government's failure to act against those responsible for the attacks. The government has denied direct links to the bombings and has instead focused on banning similar Islamic groups.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.42% to 28,900.83. This follows a record-breaking close on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, up 0.60% and 1.41% respectively. The gains are attributed to the release of corporate earnings and attention from traders.

site_title: Ex-Halcyon Agri co-founder named CEO of fund manager set up by former StanChart Singapore chief
summary: Robert Meyer, co-founder and former CEO of Halcyon Agri, has been appointed as the new CEO of Caber Partners, a Singapore-based fund manager. Meyer took a 19.9% stake in Caber through an early-stage venture capital firm he set up in 2009. He aims to develop capital allocation strategies that expose investors to Asean opportunities, with plans to announce its inaugural fund soon. Meyer replaces outgoing CEO Ray Ferguson, who will remain as non-executive chairman.

site_title: UK productivity rose in 2020 as lockdown hit lower-paid jobs
summary: UK productivity rose 0.4% in 2020 despite a 10% fall in total production due to the COVID-19 pandemic, mainly affecting lower-paid jobs. This contrasts with the 2008-09 economic downturn, where productivity declined steadily. The Office for National Statistics attributed the difference to the types of jobs impacted, with lower-paid roles bearing the brunt of lockdown measures.

images.alt_text: British workers' average hourly output rose by 0.4 per cent last year, despite a fall of nearly 10 per cent in total production due to the coronavirus pandemic, as lower-paid jobs bore the brunt of Covid lockdown measures.

site_title: Geely's Lotus Cars mulls raising US$1b to expand into China EV market
summary: Zhejiang Geely Holding Group is considering raising approximately $1 billion to help Lotus Cars, a British sports car manufacturer, expand into the electric vehicle market in China. The funds would value Lotus's EV operations at around $5 billion. Geely is also exploring an initial public offering (IPO) of Lotus Cars, which could value the entire business at over $15 billion. This move comes as investor interest in electric vehicles continues to surge, with more than $180 billion raised globally through SPAC IPOs in the past 12 months.

site_title: Kerry to visit Shanghai for climate talks in first China trip by Biden official
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry is set to visit Shanghai for climate talks in his first China trip by a Biden administration official. Kerry will meet with China's climate envoy and discuss cooperation on climate change despite high tensions between the two countries. The trip comes ahead of President Joe Biden's virtual climate summit, where China's President Xi Jinping is expected to attend. Kerry hopes to find areas of common ground with China on climate change, with Beijing promising to peak its carbon emissions by 2030.

site_title: Europeans want digital euro to be private, safe and cheap: ECB survey
summary: Europeans favor a digital euro that is private, safe, and cheap, with 43% prioritizing privacy, according to an ECB survey. Respondents also value usability across the euro area, absence of additional costs, and offline use. The digital euro would give holders a direct claim on the ECB, potentially altering bank runs and financial sector business models. Half of respondents support a cap on digital euro ownership, and two-thirds want it offered by private intermediaries, with a quarter preferring a "smart card" or phone app. The digital euro's design is still in its early stages, with a launch expected in four of five years.

images.alt_text: Euro zone citizens expect the European Central Bank's proposed digital euro to be private, safe and cheap, an ECB survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: One community infection among 27 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 27 new Covid-19 cases, with one community infection and 26 imported cases. The total cases now stand at 60,719, with 30 deaths from complications. The remaining 15 who tested positive died of other causes. Globally, the virus has infected over 137 million people, with 2.95 million deaths.

images.alt_text: There were 27 new coronavirus cases confirmed as at Wednesday noon, taking Singapore's total to 60,719.

site_title: Philippines files new diplomatic protests over Chinese boats in disputed waters
summary: The Philippines has filed new diplomatic protests against China over its presence of over 240 boats in the South China Sea, specifically in the disputed Whitsun Reef. The Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs accused China of undertaking illegal fishing and posing a threat to navigation and marine resources. The protests come after Manila summoned Chinese Ambassador Huang Xilian to press for the withdrawal of Chinese vessels. The Philippines has long been concerned about China's maritime assertiveness, and the situation has put President Rodrigo Duterte in a difficult spot.

site_title: Schwab errs with US$1.2m account transfer, customer buys house with 'windfall'
summary: Charles Schwab accidentally sent $1.2 million to a woman's Fidelity account in Louisiana, instead of the $82.56 she had requested. The funds were transferred in February and were used to buy a house and a car, with the owner, Kelyn Spadoni, arrested on fraud and theft charges. Schwab is cooperating with authorities to resolve the issue. Experts say that recipients of cash wired in error are typically required to return it, and that Spadoni's actions constitute theft.

site_title: Bitcoin touches US$64,000 high as traders eye Coinbase listing
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$64,207 on April 13, 2021, as traders anticipated Coinbase's listing on the Nasdaq. The listing, valued at about US$100 billion, is seen as a sign of growing acceptance of cryptocurrencies by traditional investors. Analysts expect the rally to continue, with some predicting a move to US$10,000. The listing also boosted other digital coins, such as Binance Coin, and follows announcements from companies like Tesla and Goldman Sachs to offer crypto investments.

site_title: UAE partners with Japan's iSpace to send rover to the moon in 2022
summary: The UAE has partnered with Japan's iSpace to send a rover to the moon in 2022, as part of the UAE's efforts to diversify its economy through space exploration. This move follows the UAE's successful launch of its first interplanetary probe, which entered Mars' orbit in February. The partnership aims to develop the UAE's scientific and technological capabilities, reducing its reliance on oil.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 13-month high on gold, tech boost
summary: Australian shares reached a 13-month high on Wednesday, closing 0.7% higher at 7,023.1 points, driven by gains in gold stocks and technology firms. New Zealand's benchmark also hit a near two-month high after the central bank left interest rates at a record low. Asia's equity markets largely ignored US inflation data, which showed consumer prices were not rising wildly.

site_title: Japan's Kagome stops tomato paste imports from China's Xinjiang region
summary: Japan's Kagome, the country's largest tomato paste manufacturer, has halted imports from China's Xinjiang region due to concerns over forced labor. The decision comes amid a growing human rights issue and Western companies' boycotts in China. Although Xinjiang tomato paste accounts for only 1% of Kagome's production, the company considers factors like cost and sustainability when sourcing raw materials. This move is seen as a response to Western governments' warnings and China's denials of alleged abuses against Muslim Uighurs in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit near three-month closing high
summary: South Korean stocks rose to a near three-month closing high on Wednesday, driven by foreign investor buying and a weak dollar. The Kospi index ended 13.30 points higher at 3,182.38, its highest close since January 25. The won jumped most in over two months, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Despite concerns over rising Covid-19 infections, foreign investors net bought 104.6 billion won worth of shares, offsetting worries. The US consumer price index rose 0.6%, but Treasury bond yields eased.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents extend rise in March as rental volumes rebound: SRX
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental markets rebounded in March, with condo rentals surging 32.4% to an eight-month high and HDB rentals rising 41.2% to a nine-month high. Rents increased 0.8% for condos and 0.5% for HDBs, with condo rents up 2.4% from last year and HDB rents up 3.4%. Experts attribute the rise to a steady stream of Singapore permanent residents returning to the market, driving higher demand and low supply.

site_title: The Atelier condo shelves public launch; caveats lodged for four units
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates has put The Atelier condo's public launch on hold, instead conducting private viewings for the 120-unit project. Four units were sold in March, with prices ranging from S$2,743 to S$3,040 per square foot. The decision was made due to health and safety concerns amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The development is expected to be completed in Q1 2024 and will offer large, flexible spaces for work, study, and play.

site_title: Report on Capitol Hill riot criticises police preparation, response
summary: The US Capitol Police report criticized the preparation and response to the January 6 riot, citing inadequate intelligence gathering and refusal to use aggressive crowd control tactics. Despite receiving intelligence warnings of potential violence by Trump supporters, officers were instructed not to use stun grenades and other tools. The report found that officers did not prepare properly, with shields not stored under the right temperature and some locked on a bus. A congressional hearing on the report is scheduled for Thursday.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as earnings come into focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday as investors focused on earnings season, despite concerns over US inflation and vaccine-related issues. Most markets, including Hong Kong and Shanghai, jumped more than 1% in early trade, while Tokyo and Singapore dipped. Analysts expect earnings growth to outweigh concerns about supply chain shortages and rising commodity prices, with the global economy recovering and businesses reopening. The S&P 500 closed at a record, and Bitcoin held above $63,000 ahead of a Coinbase cryptocurrency exchange debut.

site_title: Europe: SAP, LVMH earnings nudge stocks higher
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat earnings from SAP and LVMH, offsetting concerns over the Covid-19 vaccination programme. SAP increased 2.6% after raising its 2021 revenue outlook, while LVMH rose on the back of strong sales. The Stoxx 600 index ended the day at 7.07am GMT, with technology and personal goods sectors among the top gainers.

site_title: South Korea aims to fight Japan's Fukushima decision in world tribunal
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in ordered officials to explore referring Japan's plan to release over 1 million tonnes of contaminated water from its Fukushima nuclear plant to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. The decision, set to start in about two years, sparked strong protests from fisheries and environmental groups. Moon expressed concerns about the decision, citing the country's geographical proximity and shared sea boundaries with Japan. South Korea summoned Tokyo's ambassador in Seoul and convened an emergency meeting to craft its response to the move.

site_title: Nomura tightens hedge fund financing after Archegos collapse
summary: Nomura Holdings is tightening financing for hedge fund clients following the Archegos Capital Management collapse, which may cost the Japanese brokerage an estimated $2 billion. The restrictions are part of a review of Nomura's prime brokerage, potentially leading to a scaling back of the business. Leverage for some clients is being tightened, with previously granted exceptions to margin financing limits being reconsidered. The move is a response to the Archegos fiasco, which highlighted the risks of prime brokerage services.

site_title: Tesla data collected in China is kept in China, exec says
summary: Tesla's data collected from electric cars in China is stored in China, according to the company's vice-president Tao Lin. This comes after reports that China's military banned Teslas from its facilities. Lin stated that Tesla must abide China's laws and regulations, and Chinese data is "very well protected" and stored domestically.

site_title: With 100 days to go, Tokyo scrambles to stage pandemic Olympics
summary: Tokyo is facing significant challenges 100 days before the 2020 Olympics, with the COVID-19 pandemic affecting athlete safety, spectator numbers, and ticket sales. The resurgent coronavirus in countries like India and Brazil is a major headache for the organisers. Despite initial assurances of reliability and security, the pandemic has raised concerns about the event's feasibility, leaving uncertainty about the future of the Olympics.

site_title: Archegos ripples through banks' lucrative hedge fund units
summary: Archegos Capital Management's collapse has led to a re-evaluation of prime brokerage services, with lenders Nomura Holdings and Credit Suisse Group significantly curtailing their financing for hedge funds and family offices. The firms have taken steps to curb leverage and require more collateral, potentially reducing profitability for some trades. European regulators are examining risks and European Central Bank executive Isabel Schnabel has called for better regulation to address systemic risks. This may lead to changes in the lucrative prime brokerage industry, which is a cornerstone of global banking.

images.alt_text: The collapse of Archegos Capital Management, an investment firm that few even on Wall Street had heard of until it imploded last month, is changing a lucrative, decades-old part of global banking.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.05% to 28,796.55 at open, following a record-breaking close on Wall Street, with US inflation concerns seemingly having little impact on traders. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index inched up 0.05%. The rally comes amid a global stock market rally, with other major markets including Singapore and Europe also experiencing gains.

site_title: Europe: Shares pause near record highs
summary: European shares hovered near record highs on Tuesday, influenced by China's robust exports and import growth. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1%, driven by gains in luxury and technology stocks. Despite US inflation data, the Federal Reserve's accommodative policy stance remains intact, soothing markets. The Stoxx 600 has surged to record highs this month, lagging the US S&P 500 due to a slow vaccination rollout. Attention shifts to the start of the first-quarter corporate earnings season, with major US banks and European companies set to report earnings.

site_title: Toshiba shares surge on imminent CEO resignation, bidding war expectations
summary: Toshiba shares surged 8% on Wednesday following reports of CEO Nobuaki Kurumatani's imminent resignation amid controversy over a US$20 billion buyout bid from CVC Capital Partners. The bid could shield Kurumatani and other managers from pressure from activist shareholders. Rival suitors, including KKR & Co and Brookfield Asset Management, are also considering offers, potentially upending CVC's plans. The board meeting on Wednesday will discuss management issues, but the reports of Kurumatani's resignation were not based on company announcements.

site_title: Bukalapak raises US$234m in funding round led by Microsoft, GIC, Emtek: document
summary: Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak raised US$234 million in a funding round led by Microsoft, GIC, and Emtek. The 11-year-old startup, valued at over US$2.5 billion, is planning to list in Indonesia before eyeing a merger with a US-based SPAC. Bukalapak faces competition from ride-hailing and payments company Gojek and e-commerce rival Tokopedia, which are close to finalizing a merger ahead of a potential dual listing. The funding round comes amid interest from global investors in the fast-growing South-east Asian technology sector.

site_title: Qantas expects all of its Airbus A380 superjumbos to fly again
summary: Qantas expects to reactivate all 12 of its Airbus A380 superjumbos, citing confidence in global air travel demand recovery. CEO Alan Joyce stated that once demand is there, the A380s will be viable again. The airline grounded the planes in June, citing a three-year period where they would be useless. Despite international travel collapse during the pandemic, Qantas plans to restart almost all overseas routes by the end of October, with Emirates' fleet expected to return next year. The airline remains optimistic about a rebound in passenger traffic, with vaccinations in major markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.36 points, or 0.02%, to 1,597.35. Volume was 278.29 million lots worth RM104.95 million. Gainers beat losers 241 to 138.

site_title: Taiwan chip firms will adhere to US rules blacklisting China supercomputing entities
summary: Taiwan's chip companies have pledged to adhere to US rules blacklisting Chinese supercomputing entities, following the US Commerce Department's addition of seven Chinese entities to an economic blacklist. The entities were linked to China's military modernization efforts and weapons of mass destruction programs. This move comes after a Taipei-based chipmaker halted orders from one of the entities. Companies listed on the US Entity List must apply for licenses from the Commerce Department, which face tough scrutiny. Taiwan's chip firms will need to comply with these regulations to continue doing business with US suppliers.

images.alt_text: Taiwan said on Wednesday its chip companies will adhere to US rules after Washington added seven Chinese supercomputing entities last week to an economic blacklist and after a Taipei-based chipmaker halted orders from one of the entities named.

site_title: Oil rises after robust China data but J&J vaccine pause weighs
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday after strong Chinese import data, with Brent crude oil futures up 39 cents to $63.67 a barrel and US crude oil futures up 48 cents to $60.18 a barrel. However, concerns over pauses on the Johnson & Johnson vaccine and its impact on economic recovery and oil demand growth capped the rally. Analysts await clear demand data and direction on US inventories to break out of the current trading range.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as tech stocks track Wall Street higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.27% to 6,995.9, tracking a US tech rally, while miners advanced due to robust commodity prices. The S&P 500 closed at a record high and the Nasdaq composite jumped, despite concerns over the US inflation and halted Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine rollout.

site_title: China ramps up communication with US firms to improve ties
summary: China is taking steps to improve relations with US investors, with officials from the National Development and Reform Commission meeting with representatives from companies such as Tesla and Qualcomm. The meetings aim to strengthen economic ties and grow exchanges between the two nations, with Ning Jizhe, vice-chairman of the NDRC, stating that a "community of shared interests" has formed between business circles in China and the US. This move comes amid heightened economic tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei index down 0.21% at 29,688.76 and the Topix index down 0.41% at 1,950.50. The decline follows a mixed close on Wall Street amid concerns over rising virus infections in Japan.

site_title: Gold edges higher as dollar dwindles after US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,747.49 per ounce after US inflation data showed a bigger-than-expected rise, boosting its appeal as a hedge against inflation. The US dollar fell to three-week lows, making gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. The US economy is expected to expand by 5-6% this year, but the Federal Reserve will not withdraw its funding just yet. The European Central Bank also discussed its tolerance for overshooting its inflation target.

site_title: Singapore GDP grows 0.2% in Q1; first turnaround since Covid-19 pandemic started
summary: Singapore's economy grew 0.2% in the first quarter, its first expansion since the Covid-19 pandemic began, reversing a 2.4% contraction in the previous quarter.
