The growth was driven by the manufacturing sector, which rose 7.5%, while the construction sector declined 20.2%. Economists raised their forecasts, with Barclays' Brian Tan expecting a 7.5% growth rate and OCBC's Selena Ling anticipating a 15% rebound in Q2. The expansion is seen as a positive sign, but base effects are expected to fade, leading to a more modest growth rate in the second half of the year.

site_title: China saw record 18.7% growth in first quarter: AFP survey
summary: China's economy experienced a record 18.7% growth in the first quarter, according to an AFP survey of 15 economists. The rebound was driven by exports and domestic demand, following a historic contraction caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. This growth rate surpasses the only other major economy to expand last year, marking China's swift recovery from lockdowns and virus control measures.

images.alt_text: China's economy grew at a record pace during the first quarter as it rebounded from a historic contraction caused by Covid-19, and boosted by exports and domestic demand, an AFP poll of analysts found.

site_title: 'Violent' ducks? Hong Kong clothing brand cartoons rile China
summary: Hong Kong clothing brand Chickeeduck is struggling after its cartoon ducks were seized in China for "advocating violence". The brand's owner, Herbert Chow, had informed that a shipment of 10,000 items had been seized, impacting the brand's preparations for the Chinese New Year shopping season. Authorities in China cited the avian characters as promoting violence, despite the brand's cute and harmless designs. Chow is now seeking alternative production methods to avoid further disruptions.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Wednesday; STI down 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks fell marginally, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 0.02% to 3,187.23, following a mixed close on Wall Street and unchanged monetary policy by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Despite Q1 GDP growth of 0.2%, local banks were mixed, with DBS down 0.4%, UOB up 0.04%, and OCBC down 0.3%. Global shares, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, finished mostly higher, with European shares hovering near all-time highs.

site_title: France says EU push for tougher emissions rules goes too far: Le Figaro
summary: France's finance minister Bruno Le Maire expressed concerns that proposed Euro 7 emission standards, which aim to reduce pollutants from cars, go too far and threaten the country's automotive industry. The EU's CLOVE consortium recommends tightening emission limits starting from 2025, but Le Maire believes the standards are not suitable for France. Industry associations, such as Germany's VDA, also expressed concerns about the proposals' technological feasibility. The EU's proposals are expected to be released later this year, and France plans to work with the EU to find a more balanced approach.

site_title: BT Explains: Banks in Singapore rejig physical space for a pandemic, and more
summary: Singapore banks are rethinking their physical real estate in response to the pandemic. DBS is expected to shed office space, following other banks in the industry. This shift has implications for the banking sector and office rentals. Meanwhile, OCBC has announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: mm2 Asia raises nearly S$54.7m from rights issue
summary: mm2 Asia raised nearly S$54.7 million from a rights issue priced at 4.7 Singapore cents per share, a 60.8% discount from its previous closing price. The majority of net proceeds will be used to reduce existing liabilities. The company's executive chairman, Melvin Ang, contributed an additional S$14.9 million to the issue. Shares of mm2 Asia fell 0.3 Singapore cent or 4.9% to 5.8 cents after the close of the issue.

site_title: EU Parliament nears UK trade deal vote
summary: The European Parliament is set to take key committee votes towards ratifying the EU-UK trade deal this week, despite concerns over the UK's potential breach of the divorce agreement. The UK parliament has ratified the deal, but EU lawmakers are seeking assurances that Britain will honor its commitments. Without ratification by April 30th, the trade deal would cease to apply, leaving the UK and EU with no arrangements on trade. The EU has launched a legal process against Britain's unilateral change to the agreement, which includes delaying food checks on Northern Ireland until October.

site_title: AI startup SambaNova raises US$676m from investors including Temasek, GIC
summary: SambaNova Systems, a US-based AI startup, has raised US$676 million in funding led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2, valuing the company at US$5 billion. Temasek and GIC also invested for the first time. Other investors include BlackRock, Intel Capital, GV, and Walden International. The funding round brings SambaNova's total funding to over US$1 billion. The investment will support the company's hardware and software used to run artificial intelligence applications.

site_title: Employers prioritise skills over education, experience: LinkedIn report
summary: Employers in Singapore prioritize skills over education and experience, according to a LinkedIn report. 39% of companies look for technical skills, while 31% seek transferable skills, with only 8% and 12% placing emphasis on education and work experience. To fill skills gaps, 60% of companies may hire from outside their industries, with 65% using existing employees to leverage insider perspectives. HR plays a significant role in employee training and development, and its influence on business strategies has increased post-Covid-19, with 57% and 90% of companies indicating this, respectively.

images.alt_text: Employers seek to hire those with communication skills, problem-solving skills and strategic thinking over those with traditional qualifiers, professional networking platform LinkedIn said in a report.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment jumps to 11-year high in April
summary: Australian consumer sentiment reached an 11-year high in April, jumping 6.2% to 118.8, driven by strong family finances and optimism on the economy. Despite concerns over the vaccine rollout, consumers proved resilient, with measures of family finances and future economic prospects increasing. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index showed optimists outnumbering pessimists, and the outlook for the economy over the next 12 months rose 10.3%. The housing market remained a hot topic, with house price expectations surging 2.7% but making housing less affordable.

site_title: MAS keeps monetary policy unchanged, raises headline inflation forecast to 0.5-1.5%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) kept monetary policy unchanged, maintaining a neutral stance, as core inflation is expected to stay low this year. The MAS raised its forecast for all-items inflation to 0.5-1.5% and held core inflation steady at 0-1%. The decision was in line with analyst expectations and is seen as supportive of a stronger Singapore dollar. The MAS cited higher-than-expected private transport and accommodation costs, but noted that surplus oil production capacity should cap further price increases.

site_title: Toshiba CEO to resign as buyout offer stirs turmoil: media
summary: Toshiba's president, Nobuaki Kurumatani, is set to resign amid turmoil sparked by a buyout offer from private equity firm CVC Capital Partners. The proposed $20 billion deal is seen as too small by some Toshiba board members, who are also exploring other offers from KKR and Brookfield Asset Management. Kurumatani's resignation comes as Toshiba faces challenges in improving governance after past scandals and restructuring efforts. He will be replaced by chairman Satoshi Tsunakawa, who will discuss the appointment of representative executive officers at a board meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth returns to royal duties four days after her husband's death: PA
summary: Queen Elizabeth returned to royal duties four days after Prince Philip's death, hosting a ceremony marking the retirement of the Earl Peel as Lord Chamberlain. This event comes as Philip's funeral is scheduled for Saturday, with the 99-year-old monarch having reigned alongside him for 69 years.

site_title: Credit Suisse offers big blocks of Discovery, iQIYI shares related to Archegos: sources
summary: Credit Suisse has offered large blocks of shares in Discovery Inc and iQIYI Inc, related to its Archegos Capital unwind, after regular trading ended on Tuesday. The bank put 19 million Discovery class A shares and 35 million iQIYI shares on the market, with pricing ranges of $38.40-$39.60 for Discovery and $15.85-$16.35 for iQIYI. This move comes after Credit Suisse took a $4.7 billion hit from dealings with Archegos Capital, prompting leadership changes in its investment bank and risk divisions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LHN, Livingstone Health, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Yongnam
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Four companies saw new developments that may impact trading: LHN Group acquired 8 flats for S$16.8 million, increasing its shares by 1.6%. Livingstone Health announced expansion plans, boosting its shares by 20.9%. Frasers Hospitality Trust redeemed S$100 million securities, potentially leading to an uptick in distributions. Yongnam Holdings proposed a S$7.9 million placement to raise funds for working capital, with shares closing at 8.3 Singapore cents. These developments may influence trading for these companies, and investors should monitor their shares closely. The companies' shares ended the day with varying price movements.

site_title: US intelligence report says North Korea could resume nuclear tests this year
summary: US intelligence experts warn that North Korea may resume nuclear tests this year to force the Biden administration to enter into dialogue. The report suggests that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un views nuclear weapons as a deterrent against foreign intervention and aims to gain international acceptance. Meanwhile, Iran announces plans to enrich uranium up to 60% purity, bringing it closer to producing a nuclear device. The report also notes that Iran may consider options if it doesn't receive sanctions relief, including designing and building a new reactor.

site_title: Covid patients with sedentary habits more likely to die: study
summary: A study of nearly 50,000 Covid-19 patients found that those with sedentary habits for at least two years before the pandemic were more likely to be hospitalized, require intensive care, and die from the virus. Physical inactivity was the second-highest risk factor for severe Covid disease, after advanced age and a history of organ transplant.

site_title: SolarWinds says dealing with hack fallout cost at least US$18m
summary: SolarWinds Corp reported costs of at least $18 million to investigate and remediate the fallout from a cyber breach in the first quarter of 2021, caused by Russian hackers. The breach affected US government and private companies by compromising a widely used network management tool, SolarWinds Orion. The company has hired CrowdStrike Holdings and KPMG to aid in the investigation. SolarWinds expects significant legal and professional services expenses in future periods, and its shares gained 2.1% in Tuesday trading.

images.alt_text: Texas-based SolarWinds Corp said the sprawling breach stemming from the compromise of its flagship software product has cost the company at least US$18 million in the first three months of 2021.

site_title: Kerry to talk climate on first trip by Biden official to China
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry is set to visit China this week, marking the first trip by a Biden administration official to the country. Kerry aims to find areas of cooperation despite strained relations, particularly on issues like intellectual property and human rights. His trip precedes President Biden's virtual climate summit, where China's President Xi Jinping is also invited. Kerry hopes to work with China to address the climate crisis, noting that the country's emissions will peak by 2030.

site_title: Moderna Covid vaccine efficacy falls slightly to 90% in US trial
summary: Moderna's Covid vaccine efficacy has decreased to 90% in a US trial, a slight drop from 94.1% previously reported. The new figure is based on 900 adjudicated cases of Covid, down from 185 cases in the earlier report. The company attributes the decrease to the emergence of new variants, but is working on variant-specific boosters that have shown increased immune responses in mice studies. Moderna has delivered 132 million doses globally, including 117 million to the US, and remains on track to deliver 300 million doses by the end of July.

site_title: Police seek arrest of Italian middleman in Vatican property deal
summary: Italian magistrates have issued an arrest warrant for Gianluigi Torzi, a financial broker, on suspicion of fraudulent billing practices and tax fraud in a Vatican property deal. Torzi, who is currently in Britain, is also suspected of money laundering. The warrant, part of "Operation Broking Bad," alleges Torzi issued fake bills to the Vatican for 15 million euros for work never carried out. The Vatican has previously charged Torzi with extortion, embezzlement, and money laundering related to the London property transaction.

site_title: Biden to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan by September 11
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan by September 11, the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, marking the end of America's longest war. The decision delays a Trump-era agreement by around five months, amid concerns about a potential Taleban victory. The withdrawal will begin in May, and the US will maintain a limited presence to guard installations. A Turkish-led international peace conference will take place in April, but the outcome is uncertain, with many observers believing the Taleban may have already won.

site_title: Nvidia, Volvo Cars hasten data-processing power race
summary: Nvidia and Volvo Cars are partnering to use Nvidia's high-powered chips for more autonomous driving functions in future vehicles, starting next year. Volvo will equip its new XC90 model with Nvidia's Drive Orin system, which offers more processing power than current chips. This move follows Tesla's lead in software-driven features and functional capability. Nvidia's automotive business has seen a significant growth in orders, with a pipeline of billions of dollars. Other automakers, including Faraday Future and Daimler, are also adopting similar approaches to catch up with Tesla's autonomous driving capabilities.

site_title: Japan's greenhouse gas emissions fall to record low
summary: Japan's greenhouse gas emissions fell to a record low of 1.21 billion metric tonnes of CO2 equivalent in the year ended March 2020, a 2.9% decline from the previous year. This marks six consecutive years of emissions cuts, driven by increased use of renewable energy and lower electricity demand from manufacturing. The country aims to cut emissions by 26% to 1.04 billion tonnes by 2030 and is considering raising its target in light of its goal to become carbon neutral by 2050.

site_title: Coinbase brings cryptocurrencies to Wall Street
summary: Coinbase, a US-based cryptocurrency exchange, has made history by becoming the first company dedicated to cryptocurrency to list on the Nasdaq stock exchange. The company's direct listing, valued at $65.3 billion, makes it the largest new entrant to the US stock market since Uber in 2019. With nearly 115 million shares available, Coinbase's valuation is largely dependent on the price of bitcoin, which has surged in recent months, with the company's revenue increasing almost tenfold to $1.8 billion in the first quarter. However, concerns remain about the sustainability of the market and potential government regulation.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly shrug off J&J vaccine problem
summary: US stocks finished a volatile session mostly higher, despite concerns over rising inflation and the halt to Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine due to blood clot fears. The S&P 500 reached a fresh record, while the Nasdaq jumped over 1%, while the Dow pulled back 0.2%. Analysts say the J&J issue may slow vaccination momentum but the other two vaccines are still effective. Energy prices surged, leading the charge in consumer price inflation, which rose 2.6% in the 12 months through March.

site_title: Oil prices climb on robust China data, Middle East tension
summary: Oil prices rose 0.6% to $63.65 a barrel for Brent crude and 0.5% to $60.02 a barrel for US crude, driven by China's robust export growth and Middle East tensions. China's import growth surged 21% in March, while US crude stockpiles were expected to drop for a third straight week. Yemen's Houthi movement fired missiles at Saudi oil sites, but price gains were capped by slow vaccination rates in Europe and anticipated Iranian oil supply.

site_title: Egypt 'seizes' megaship over nearly US$1b Suez claim
summary: Egypt has seized the megaship MV Ever Given, which blocked the Suez Canal for nearly a week, until its owners pay US$900 million in compensation. The Japanese-owned vessel was stuck in a sandstorm on March 23, causing an estimated US$9.6 billion in cargo delays. The canal's closure resulted in losses of US$12-15 million per day for Egypt. The ship was freed on March 29 and is now in unobstructive anchorage in Bitter Lake, pending payment of the compensation.

images.alt_text: The megaship which blocked Egypt's Suez Canal and crippled world trade for nearly a week has been "seized" on court orders until the vessel's owners pay US$900 million, canal authorities said on Tuesday.

site_title: Grab's US$39.6b SPAC deal comes with bells and whistles
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing and food delivery company, is set to go public via a US$39.6 billion merger with Altimeter Growth, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). The deal includes a three-year lockup period and a backstop of up to $500 million to provide certainty for Grab's cash raise. Grab expects to raise $4.5 billion in cash proceeds, with a projected net adjusted revenue of $4.5 billion by 2023. The proposed transaction has been approved by both companies' boards and is expected to close in July 2021, subject to shareholder approvals.

images.alt_text: Grab is set to go public at a US$39.6 billion valuation via an upcoming merger with Altimeter Growth, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). This is set to be the largest-ever SPAC merger.

site_title: How long will the great reflation trade last?
summary: Analysts expect the global economy to expand by 6% or more this year, driven by rising growth expectations and concerns about inflation. The reflation trade in global bond markets is expected to continue, with central banks responding to rising rates. However, factors such as a potential slowdown in the vaccine campaign and concerns about the medium-term outlook may stall or reverse the rise in rates, and the medium-term outlook for the global economy remains moderate at best.

site_title: Twitter to open first Africa office to tap fast-growing markets
summary: Twitter to open its first African office in Ghana, aiming to tap into the continent's growing markets. The move comes as Africa's internet penetration rate of 39% lags behind the global average. Twitter trails Facebook, which has offices in Johannesburg and plans to open a second in Lagos. Ghana's President Nana Akufo-Addo welcomed the move, calling it crucial for the development of the country's tech sector. The office is seen as a key step for Twitter to expand its presence in Africa, a region with significant growth potential.

site_title: Hong Kong to outlaw campaigning for election boycotts
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced plans to outlaw campaigning for election boycotts, with a maximum penalty of three years in jail. The move is part of China's efforts to tighten control over the city, following the imposition of a national security law and the vetting of candidates for loyalty. The new laws will regulate acts that manipulate or damage the election, and ban open incitement to boycott or cast blank votes. Critics say the move will eviscerate the last vestiges of Hong Kong's political opposition, with the city's legislature set to expand to 90 seats, but with only 20 directly elected.

site_title: DBS Research notes 'compelling case' for privatisation of Frasers Hospitality Trust
summary: DBS Research notes Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) as a "compelling case" for privatisation due to its current discount to net asset value and low trading liquidity. The trust's decision to redeem its S$100 million perpetual securities may lead to an uptick in distributions if managers repay with debt, potentially increasing the gearing ratio to 42%. DBS estimates privatisation will cost less than S$500 million, offering control of 4,000 room keys and landmark hotels. The research team projects a one-per-cent accretion to its FY2021 distribution forecast.

site_title: Jack Ma's fortune jumps US$2.3b after record Alibaba fine
summary: China has fined Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., a record antitrust fine, resulting in Jack Ma's fortune increasing by US$2.3 billion to US$52.1 billion. Alibaba's American depositary receipts jumped 9.3% in New York, the largest jump in almost four years. The fine was seen as a positive for investors, who breathed a sigh of relief.

site_title: US consumer prices increase in March by most since 2012
summary: US consumer prices increased 0.6% in March, the largest rise since 2012, driven by a 0.6% gain in petrol costs. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.3% for the first time in seven months, fueled by rising rents and auto insurance. Year-over-year changes are distorted by the base effect, but the data adds to concerns about budding inflationary pressures, with some analysts predicting sustained upward movement in inflation.

site_title: Sale of Fullerton Health draws eight non-binding bids in 1st round: sources
summary: Fullerton Health Corp, a Singapore-based healthcare solutions firm, has received eight non-binding bids in the first round of its sale process, according to sources. The firm, majority owned by SIN Capital Group, is facing liquidity strain and valuation concerns due to its complicated capital structure and the sustainability of its growth story. The sale process is currently "midway," with potential investors meeting the management team for a deeper dive. RRJ Capital, a Hong Kong-based private equity firm, may have significant sway in the sale process due to its existing relationship with Fullerton Health and its chairman, Richard Ong, who sits on the board.

site_title: The ecstasy of Yayoi Kusama's speckles
summary: The New York Botanical Garden has hosted an exhibition, "Kusama: Cosmic Nature," featuring 92-year-old artist Yayoi Kusama's works, including her signature polka dots and infinity mirrors, set amidst the garden's flowering cherry trees. The three-year-exhibition includes various sculptures, installations, and special gallery exhibits, offering a unique chance to experience Kusama's art in a more subdued atmosphere. The show's focus on pairing nature and artifice creates a striking psychological interplay, highlighting the artist's themes of wistful yearning and ecstasy.

site_title: High-end condo sales surge as March new home purchases double
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in March, with 1,293 new sales recorded, doubling February's 645. The recovery in the economy and low interest rates are cited as reasons for the surge. Luxury flats, particularly those above $5 million, are in high demand. The increase in sales is attributed to buyers returning from the Chinese New Year break and concerns over new cooling measures. Official monthly data is set to be released on April 15.

site_title: Tackling the big issues to thrive, post-Covid
summary: The Singapore Maritime Week (SMW) is set to take place, focusing on resilience, digitalisation, decarbonisation, and talent development in the post-Covid-19 environment. The event aims to explore solutions for the shipping industry to thrive, with a "Covid passport" for easy crew travel being a key task. The week will feature 19 events, including a keynote speech by MISC Berhad President and CEO Yee Yang Chien, and a discussion on digitalisation and decarbonisation. The event is seen as crucial for the industry to adapt to the new normal and achieve sustainable growth.

site_title: Demand for soap, snacks boosts Givaudan's first quarter
summary: Givaudan, a Swiss fragrance and flavor maker, reported a 7.7% increase in like-for-like sales in the first quarter, driven by strong demand for household items like soap and snacks, particularly in emerging markets. The company's fragrance and beauty business rose 9.9% and its taste and wellbeing unit increased 5.8%. Despite uncertainties from the COVID-19 pandemic, Givaudan's CEO remains optimistic for 2021, citing a strong start and attractive growth profile.

site_title: Trip.com to price Hong Kong secondary listing at HK$268 a share
summary: Trip.com Group is set to raise HK$8.5 billion after pricing its Hong Kong secondary listing at HK$268 per share, a 2% discount to its Nasdaq closing price. The company is offering 31.6 million shares, with retail investors able to buy up to HK$333 per share. The secondary listing aims to hedge against US exchange delisting risks and attract Asia-based investors. The shares are due to start trading in Hong Kong on April 19.

site_title: Revamp of Ant dents investor appetite for IPO revival
summary: China's regulator-imposed revamp of Ant Group, transforming the fintech into a financial holding company, appears to have lowered investor appetite for its planned initial public offering (IPO). The overhaul, which comes after a record US$2.75 billion antitrust penalty against Alibaba Group, is expected to limit Ant's profitability and valuation. Investors now value Ant around US$200 billion, down from its previous valuation of US$315 billion. The revamp may also increase capital requirements, dampening Ant's return on equity and asset potential.

site_title: Are financial markets prepared for the 'reopening trade' in Asia?
summary: Financial markets in Asia are not fully prepared for the "reopening trade" as household spending on discretionary services declined sharply during the Covid-19 pandemic, resulting in pent-up demand. This surge in demand could lead to higher prices, with inflation rates potentially rising 10-30% in some countries, like India, which saw a 6.7% increase in discretionary services. Bond markets signal a lack of preparedness, with limited rises in yields, and a rotation out of growth stocks to value stocks is expected once household spending picks up, potentially leading to volatile portfolio flows and currency performance.

site_title: Delayed gratification and a barbell portfolio
summary: A personal finance article discusses the concept of delayed gratification, applying it to physical and financial health. The idea is to prioritize tasks, such as exercise and moderation, before indulging in leisure activities. A related article highlights the growing importance of dollar asset diversification in Asia, with Asia expected to both drive and gain from this trend. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, while a shift away from dollar-denominated assets is also underway.

site_title: Dyson to hire 250 more engineers, scientists in Singapore over five years
summary: Dyson plans to hire 250 more engineers and scientists in Singapore over five years, doubling its existing teams, as part of its £2.75 billion global investment in future technology. The move will support its ambitions to develop high-performing technology products with increasing intelligence. Dyson will also expand into its new global headquarters at St James Power Station, increasing its engineering footprint in Singapore more than two-fold.

site_title: Nvidia nips at Intel's heels with new chip
summary: Nvidia unveiled its first server microprocessors, targeting Intel's most lucrative market with a chip for complex computing work. The move is seen as a challenge to Intel, with Nvidia's shares jumping 6% and Intel's falling 4%. Nvidia's first-quarter revenue is tracking above forecast. The new chip is pitched at data center owners to utilize AI for intricate computing tasks, further solidifying Nvidia's push into the market.

images.alt_text: Nvidia Corp's server microprocessor extends a push into Intel Corp's most lucrative market. Intel's shares fell about 4 per cent and Nvidia's jumped on the news.

site_title: Palm tracks rival soya oil higher; but gains curbed by inventory, output rise
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rose 0.68% to RM3,675 a tonne after three sessions of losses, tracking higher soya oil prices. However, gains were capped by higher-than-expected inventories and production, which are expected to outstrip demand, leading to higher ending stocks. April production is forecast to grow 11% and exports to rise 18% due to the Eid festival and potential stockpiling in China and India.

site_title: Blockchain firm ConsenSys raises US$65m from JP Morgan, others
summary: Blockchain firm ConsenSys has raised US$65 million from major banks and financial services firms including JP Morgan, Mastercard, and UBS Group to fund its growth and global expansion. The funding comes as finance firms explore greater use of cryptocurrencies for investment and payment purposes. ConsenSys acquired JPMorgan's Quorum blockchain unit in August last year and has clients including Microsoft, Amazon, and Ernst and Young. The company is also building Central Bank Digital Currencies for six central banks, and its protocols group is expanding its presence.

site_title: Blackstone tweaks conditions for US$6b Australia Crown Resorts buyout
summary: Blackstone Group Inc has modified the conditions for its proposed US$6 billion buyout of Crown Resorts Ltd, requiring the Australian casino operator not to lose further state licences before the deal is approved. Crown faces quasi-judicial inquiries in Victoria and Western Australia due to alleged links to organised crime. The US firm expects to receive state approvals by Q3 2021, with the Victorian and WA inquiries due to deliver their recommendations in August and November, respectively. The deal valuation has been set at A$8 billion.

site_title: America needs to empower workers again
summary: The US labor movement has declined significantly since the 1980s, with union membership plummeting from around a quarter of the workforce to less than 10%. Despite this, union advocates argue that the decline was largely driven by politics, not economics. Technological progress and globalization have not led to a decline in union influence, and many countries with strong unions, such as Denmark and Canada, remain highly unionized. The US needs a union revival to address spiraling inequality and restore workers' bargaining power. A strong labor movement can also counterbalance corporate influence and provide a counterweight to big money in politics.

site_title: UN fears Myanmar heading towards Syria-style 'full-blown conflict'
summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet, warned that Myanmar is heading towards a full-blown conflict like Syria, citing a campaign of repression and slaughter of its people by the military. At least 710 civilians, including 50 children, have been killed since the military seized power from Aung San Suu Kyi on February 1. The military has responded with air strikes and retaliated against ethnic rebel groups, raising fears of a broader civil conflict. The UN urges countries to take immediate and decisive action to stop the violence and prevent crimes against humanity.

site_title: Getting disclosure and spirit of executive pay right
summary: Genting Singapore's annual general meeting will be held virtually, allowing shareholders to ask questions "live". The company, owner of Resorts World Sentosa, saw revenue and profit fall sharply in 2020, but highlighted its support for Singapore's Covid-19 efforts. Executive chairman Lim Kok Thay's remuneration package drew attention, with a total remuneration of S$21.25-21.5 million in 2020. The company explained that a large part of Lim's pay relates to an accrued contingent bonus, which has not been paid. The issue of executive pay and disclosure is highlighted as a key concern, with some questioning the rationale behind the large pay package.

site_title: Women & wealth: for richer or poorer
summary: Women's financial literacy and inclusion are crucial for building economic resilience, particularly in developing nations affected by the pandemic. Financial inclusion aims to provide women with access to financial products and services, enabling them to manage their finances and make informed decisions. Empowering women economically involves having access to income and assets, control of economic gains, and the power to make decisions. Studies show strong links between empowering women and positive outcomes, such as better nutrition, family planning, and investments in education and healthcare. Improving financial literacy and demystifying financial planning can help change attitudes towards wealth management.

site_title: The pandemic-driven rise of data centres
summary: The pandemic has led to a data centre boom in Asean, driven by the shift to digitalisation, e-commerce, gaming, and video streaming. As a result, demand for high-performance computing infrastructure has surged, fuelling growth in the sector. The pandemic has also accelerated the adoption of emerging technologies such as IoT, AI, and data analytics, further driving the need for data centres. The region's ability to sustain this growth in the years to come remains uncertain, posing challenges for the sector's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jardine Strategic to be delisted from Singapore Exchange, following acquisition by Jardine Matheson. Oceanus Group to exit SGX watch-list after submitting application. Zheneng Jinjiang Environment's pre-conditional mandatory cash offer lapsed due to unsatisfied pre-conditions. Ascendas India Trust secured a five-year S$100 million unsecured sustainability-linked loan facility.

site_title: Malaysia's Muhyiddin to visit Singapore in May for talks with PM Lee
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will visit Singapore on May 4 to meet with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, discussing border reopening and other issues. Malaysian Foreign Minister Hishammuddin Hussein confirmed the meeting, stating it was previously agreed upon during a visit by Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan in March. The two countries aim to recognize each other's vaccine certificates for cross-border travel and restore limited travel for other groups of travelers.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will visit Singapore on May 4 to meet Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. They are expected to discuss the reopening of the border, among other things, Malaysian newspaper The Star reported.

site_title: Greenback edges up before US inflation data release
summary: The US dollar edged higher against a basket of currencies, moving away from recent three-week lows, before US inflation data release. The dollar-yen pair was down 0.2% at 109.150. The 10-year US Treasury yield rose to 1.6677%, still below the March 30 high of 1.7760%. Markets await the release of US consumer price index (CPI) data for March, which is expected to show a rise in inflation.

site_title: Biden proposes summit with Putin amid tensions over Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden proposed a summit meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin amid growing tensions over Ukraine, where thousands of combat-ready troops have been amassed. Biden stressed the US commitment to Ukraine's territorial integrity and voiced concern about a Russian military build-up in Crimea and on Ukraine's borders. The proposed summit aims to discuss the full range of issues facing the US and Russia, with a third country hosting the meeting in the coming months.

site_title: Swiss watch expo switches to Shanghai after virtual debut
summary: The Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (Watches and Wonders) has switched to a physical event in Shanghai after a virtual debut, due to the coronavirus crisis. The event, which typically takes place in Geneva, featured 19 brands, including Chanel, Rolex, and Cartier, showcasing new products. The virtual version allowed for online learning and engagement, but organizers predict that online and offline events will continue to coexist. The event is seen as a step towards the industry's recovery from the pandemic, which hit Switzerland's luxury watch sector hard.

images.alt_text: In 2020, Swiss watch exports fell by 21.8 per cent to 17 billion Swiss francs. China became the biggest export market for Swiss watches in 2020.

site_title: China warns 34 tech firms to curb excess in review
summary: China has ordered 34 internet corporations to curb excess anti-competitive practices within a month. The move signals Beijing's ongoing scrutiny of powerful firms, including Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. Shares in Tencent Holdings Ltd and Meituan extended losses after the State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) emphasized its commitment to eradicating information and market dominance abuses. The stern statement follows a probe into Alibaba, indicating Beijing's determination to address anti-competitive practices in the tech industry.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's IHC adds stake in top UAE builder with new deal
summary: Abu Dhabi's International Holding Co (IHC) has acquired a 45% stake in Alpha Dhabi Holding, becoming a major shareholder in Aldar Properties PJSC. The deal expands IHC's investment vertical and diversifies its portfolio. IHC's market capitalization is now over $43 billion, making it the second-largest in the UAE. The company's shares have surged over 110% this year. IHC's CEO, Syed Basar Shueb, sees the acquisition as a strategic move to increase scale and diversify investments.

site_title: Hedge fund manager's Manhattan penthouse sells after 74% price cut
summary: Hedge fund manager Steve Cohen's 9,000-square-foot Manhattan penthouse at 151 East 58th Street has sold after a 74% price cut. The 51st and 52nd floor duplex was initially listed for $115 million in 2013 but was reduced to $29.5 million before finding a buyer. The sale marks the end of an eight-year journey, with Cohen paying $24 million for the apartment in 2005. The final sale price has not been disclosed, but the deal is considered a sign of buyers returning to Manhattan's luxury apartment market amid deep discounts.

images.alt_text: The sale marks the end of a journey that began in 2013 when Steve Cohen, founder of Point72 Asset Management and owner of the New York Mets, listed the unit for US$115 million.

site_title: US: S&P 500 muted after strong inflation data
summary: The S&P 500 opened flat on Tuesday, despite strong inflation data, with consumer prices increasing by the most in over 8-1/2 years in March. Johnson & Johnson's stock fell as federal health agencies recommended pausing its Covid-19 vaccine use. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.07%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.38%.

site_title: Private club Straits Clan gets new owner
summary: The Straits Clan, a private club in Singapore, has been acquired by The Mandala Group, a hospitality player with luxury properties overseas. The deal marks The Mandala Group's focus on members' clubs as part of its growth strategy, with plans to explore further clubs in Singapore and Asia. The club will be rebranded Mandala Club and undergo renovations, with a 50% increase in headcount expected within the next 12 months. Financial records show Straits Clan has moved into full profitability since last November.

site_title: British retailers achieve higher spending in March
summary: British retailers reported higher spending in March, with total sales 8.3% higher than in March 2019 and 13.9% higher than in March 2020. The increase is attributed to increased grocery purchases due to consumers spending more time at home. Non-essential stores are expected to reopen in April, which may lead to a turn-around in sales growth, with some retailers, such as Primark, already seeing long queues of shoppers.

site_title: Air Canada gets C$5.9b lifeline from Ottawa
summary: Air Canada has reached a deal with the Canadian government for a C$5.9 billion aid package, the largest individual coronavirus-related loan, amid criticism from the airline industry about the Trudeau government's slow response. The agreement includes a ban on share buybacks and dividends, capping executive compensation at C$1 million, and preserving jobs. Air Canada will also proceed with planned aircraft purchases. The deal aims to support the airline's liquidity and maintain a competitive sector, with the government purchasing a 14.2% stake in the airline.

site_title: JD Sports to resume dividends, plans to ramp up warehouse space post-Brexit
summary: JD Sports, UK's largest sportswear retailer, forecasts profit growth this year and resumes dividend payments after beating analysts' profit forecast for the year ended Jan 2021. The company plans to ramp up warehouse space to fulfill online orders and minimize disruptions from Brexit, with a new warehouse in Dublin and e-fulfillment partnerships in the UK and Europe. JD Sports expects adjusted pre-tax profit of £475-£500 million for the year through January 2022.

site_title: SPAC boom in the US faces new SEC threat with accounting crackdown
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is cracking down on accounting rules for special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), potentially disrupting filings for new SPACs. The SEC is questioning whether warrants issued to early investors should be considered equity instruments or liabilities. The move could impact hundreds of SPAC filings and affect public companies that have already merged with targets, requiring them to restate financial results. The SEC urges accountants and lawyers to review statements and correct material errors, potentially spelling a massive nuisance for the industry.

site_title: A Paris Opera ballet etoile on being young, gifted and successful
summary: Paris Opera Ballet star Hugo Marchand, 27, has written a memoir "Danser" about his experiences as a young dancer, tackling self-acceptance, politics, and the pressures of the competitive ballet world. Marchand describes the grueling training and competitiveness of the Paris Opera Ballet school and company, and shares his struggles with self-doubt and stage fright. He also touches on the recent report on diversity and racism within the company, and his ambitions to dance with New York City Ballet and explore other artistic disciplines. Marchand's book offers a candid look at the highs and lows of a young dancer's career.

site_title: Livingstone Health maps expansion plans
summary: Livingstone Health, a Singapore-based multidisciplinary specialist healthcare group, is taking a cautious approach to expansion. The company, which listed on the Singapore Exchange just two months ago, is focusing on boosting its offerings and increasing its range of services, including primary and tertiary healthcare. Livingstone plans to expand its primary care footprint organically or through acquisitions and grow its medical talent pool to double from current levels. The group has also signed a memorandum of understanding with a Hong Kong-listed company to evaluate project collaboration opportunities in integrated healthcare infrastructure projects in South-east Asia and South Asia.

site_title: So you want to become a long-term investor
summary: Long-term investing is crucial for success, as holding a stock for the long term is more important than just buying it. Simply purchasing shares does not guarantee profits, and failing to hold them for the long term can result in missing out on their full potential. Most investors focus on what stock to buy, but neglect the importance of holding the stock for the long term, which can lead to missed opportunities and financial losses.

site_title: Judging a company by its name
summary: A study using machine learning and sentiment analysis found that grandiose names of companies are not a reliable indicator of future success. Instead, companies with shorter and easier-to-pronounce names, patriotic names, and names with greater fluency tend to have more positive outcomes. The study also found that grandiose names are associated with more regulatory actions and lower abnormal returns, but this does not necessarily mean investors should avoid companies with such names. The findings have implications for the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning in assessing company performance and identifying potential risks.

site_title: United Airlines unveils bid to fund sustainable aviation fuel use
summary: United Airlines has partnered with global companies, including Nike and Siemens, in the 'Eco-Skies Alliance' to fund the use of 3.4 million gallons of low-carbon, sustainable aviation fuel derived from trash this year. The partnership triples United's annual sustainable fuel usage and aims to create a market for sustainable aviation fuels. The airline's goal is to cut net emissions by 100% by 2050, and this initiative is seen as a step towards achieving this target.

site_title: One US patient died, another critical after J&J vaccine
summary: A US patient died and another is in critical condition after receiving the Johnson & Johnson Covid vaccine due to blood clotting complications. Six women aged 18-48 developed a rare form of brain blood clotting with low blood platelets between 6-13 days after vaccination. The incident has raised concerns over the safety of the vaccine.

site_title: Natural capital: the coming market disruption you haven't heard about
summary: A new report by Cambridge University professor Partha Dasgupta highlights the "natural capital" market disruption, emphasizing the need to acknowledge that human economies and activities depend on the natural world. The report notes that current ecological footprint exceeds the biosphere's regenerative rate, leading to "impact inequality." Dasgupta suggests that private investment in natural capital is limited, with only 0.1% of global GDP devoted to it, while governments spend billions on activities harming biodiversity. The report proposes various actions and policies to balance supply and demand, including biodiversity-related taxes, payments for ecosystem services, and green bonds, to mitigate the impact of human activities on the environment.

site_title: US calls for pause of J&J shot due to blood clotting
summary: US health officials have called for a pause in using Johnson & Johnson's single-dose Covid-19 vaccine due to six women developing a rare and severe form of blood clotting. The CDC and FDA recommended the pause out of caution, citing the need for healthcare providers to be aware of the potential for these adverse events. Over 6.8 million doses of the J&J vaccine have been administered in the US, and the Biden administration has sought to accelerate vaccinations amid concerns about new variants.

site_title: Singapore's Fave eyes India breakthrough with US$45m sale to unicorn Pine Labs
summary: Fave, a fintech platform, has been acquired by Indian merchant commerce company Pine Labs in a US$45 million cash-and-stock deal. Fave will continue to operate with its current leadership structure and expand its presence in the Indian market later this year. The company plans to hire over 100 new employees and introduce Buy Now Pay Later services in Singapore. Pine Labs, with a strong presence in India's BNPL market, will help Fave tap into the Indian consumer rewards market.

site_title: Committee looking into doctor panel dispute has tough job to satisfy all
summary: A committee has been formed to investigate the dispute between the Singapore Medical Association (SMA) and the Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore over the restrictions on doctors in Integrated Shield Plans (IPs). The SMA objects to the limited composition and size of approved doctor panels, which disadvantage non-panel doctors, while the LIA argues that these measures are necessary to curb rising healthcare costs and prevent a significant increase in future premiums. The committee will need to find a solution that balances the interests of all stakeholders, with the goal of arresting healthcare cost escalation and avoiding escalating premiums.

site_title: US consumer prices increased in March by most since 2012
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.6% in March, the largest increase since 2012, driven by a 0.6% jump in gasoline costs. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, increased 0.3% for the first time in seven months. Year-over-year changes are distorted by the pandemic's base effect, but the data fuels concerns about inflation, with some analysts predicting a sustained upward movement. The Federal Reserve has warned that any meaningful price increase will likely be temporary.

site_title: UN fears Myanmar heading towards Syria-style 'full-blown conflict'
summary: The UN rights chief warns that Myanmar is heading towards a massive conflict like Syria's due to a military crackdown on dissent, resulting in at least 710 civilian deaths and widespread displacement. The military's "campaign of repression and slaughter" has been met with retaliatory attacks from ethnic armed rebel groups, raising fears of a broader civil conflict. UN High Commissioner Michelle Bachelet urges countries to take decisive action to stop the violence and calls for concerted pressure on the military to halt grave human rights violations and possible crimes against humanity.

site_title: WHO, agencies urge countries to suspend sale of live wild mammals at markets
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) and international agencies have urged countries to suspend the sale of live wild mammals at food markets, citing they may be the source of over 70% of emerging infectious diseases in humans. This guidance comes after a WHO-led mission to Wuhan, China, investigating the origin of the Sars-CoV-2 virus. The move aims to ensure the global food system is safe and sustainable, reducing the risk of zoonoses.

images.alt_text: International agencies including the World Health Organization urged countries on Tuesday to suspend the sale of live wild mammals in food markets, warning they may be the source of more than 70 per cent of emerging infectious diseases in humans.

site_title: American Airlines defers 37 Boeing deliveries for as long as three years
summary: American Airlines has delayed deliveries of 37 Boeing aircraft for up to three years due to the ongoing pandemic. The carrier will postpone 18 737 MAX jets and 14 787-8 planes, with some conversions to 787-9 models also delayed. This move is expected to result in a deeper loss than analysts projected, with a first-quarter adjusted loss of $4.29 to $4.41 per share. Revenue is expected to decline 62% from 2019 levels, as international and business demand remains stagnant.

site_title: Stolen ancient Roman statue found in Brussels antiques shop
summary: An ancient Roman statue, "Togatus," worth around $119,000, was recovered in Brussels after being stolen in 2011 from a villa in Rome. Two off-duty police officers spotted the 1st-century marble piece in an antiques shop and confirmed its authenticity through police files. Belgian authorities assisted in its confiscation and shipment back to Italy in February. An Italian art dealer, operating under a false name, was charged with possession of stolen goods and exporting the statue illegally. The statue was recovered after a follow-up investigation.

site_title: Sotheby's, Phillips latest to join NFT craze
summary: Traditional auction houses Sotheby's and Phillips have launched NFT auctions, following Christie's record-breaking sale of a digital artwork for $69.3 million in March. The phenomenon is becoming more mainstream, with daily NFT transactions exceeding $10 million. Sotheby's is selling NFT works by digital artist Pak, while Phillips is auctioning off an artwork that will generate new digital objects. The move is seen as a way for auction houses to capitalize on the growing NFT market, which is attracting a younger audience of collectors.

images.alt_text: A person looking at a piece by Hoxxoh during a preview on March 25 at the grand opening of Superchief Gallery NFT, a physical space dedicated exclusively to NFT artwork in New York.

site_title: Austria health minister quits over Covid crisis 'overwork'
summary: Austria's health minister, Rudolf Anschober, has resigned due to overwork and exhaustion while managing the country's COVID-19 crisis. Anschober, 60, served since last year and had been a key figure in keeping the pandemic under control. He warned the pandemic is still ongoing and urged caution. Anschober cited circulation problems and had been absent from work since last week. This is his second time taking a break from politics due to burnout, with a three-month leave in 2012.

site_title: Tinder appoints ex-Pizza Hut CMO amid push for Gen Z users
summary: Tinder appoints George Felix, former CMO of Pizza Hut, as its new CMO to attract Gen Z users amid pandemic-induced restrictions. Felix will focus on engaging and recruiting younger users, as a recent study showed nearly half of Gen Z users had video chats with matches during the pandemic. With the company's majority market share in the US dating-app market, Tinder aims to maintain growth as cities reopen and in-person socializing returns. Felix replaces outgoing CMO Jenny Campbell, who left in November to join Kate Spade & Co.

site_title: Telkom Indonesia unit Mitratel weighs US$1b IPO
summary: PT Dayamitra Telekomunikasi, also known as Mitratel, a unit of state-owned PT Telkom Indonesia, is considering a potential initial public offering (IPO) in Jakarta that could raise approximately US$1 billion. This would be Indonesia's largest first-time share sale in over a decade. Mitratel manages over 16,000 telecommunication towers and has asked for proposals on the potential offering. The IPO plan is reportedly underway, with preparations expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condo resale volumes in Singapore reached a 10-year high in March with 1,662 units resold, more than double the number in the same period last year. Fave, a fintech platform, secured a US$45 million sale to an Indian merchant commerce company, aiming to expand in India's consumer rewards market. Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will visit Singapore on May 4 to discuss border reopening. Temasek and BlackRock formed a US$600 million decarbonization investment partnership, while LHN inked S$16.8 million sale and purchase agreements for eight Beach Road flats.

site_title: Six steps to transforming your business successfully
summary: A six-step guide to transforming a business successfully is outlined, emphasizing the importance of shared purpose, balancing change and operations, and adapting to change. The steps include: 1) avoiding imitation of others, 2) prioritizing value creation over transformation, 3) ensuring balanced leadership, 4) embracing productive failure, 5) focusing on technological foundations, and 6) being selective in responding to feedback. Successful transformation requires a company's unique "DNA" and a willingness to continuously analyze and adapt to changing circumstances.

site_title: Egypt 'seizes' megaship over nearly US$1b Suez claim
summary: Egypt has seized the Japanese-owned megaship "Ever Given" over a nearly $1 billion claim for damages due to its blockage of the Suez Canal in March. The vessel, operated by Taiwanese company Shoei Kisen Kaisha, was stuck in a sandstorm for nearly a week, causing estimated $9.6 billion in lost cargo. The ship's owners must pay $900 million in compensation, as ordered by an Egyptian court, or face the vessel being kept in unobstructive anchorage until the payment is made.

site_title: Demand for soap, snacks boost Givaudan's first quarter
summary: Swiss fragrance and flavour maker Givaudan reported a 7.7% increase in like-for-like sales for the first quarter, driven by strong demand for soap and snacks in emerging markets. The company's fragrance and beauty business rose 9.9%, while its taste and wellbeing unit increased 5.8%. Sales linked to out-of-home consumption were down, but less than last year as restrictions were lifted. Givaudan remains optimistic for 2021 despite uncertainties, and confirmed its target for 4-5% like-for-like organic sales growth per year.

site_title: Credit Suisse to make US$1.7b supply chain fund payment
summary: Credit Suisse is making a US$1.7 billion payment to investors in its frozen Greensill supply-chain finance funds, bringing total repayments to about half the money owed. The bank has repaid about US$4.8 billion and plans to give a further update on future disbursements by the end of the month. Credit Suisse is in dialogue with administrators and creditors to recover money for investors, with potential for recovery but uncertainty on the amounts to be distributed.

site_title: Grab to go public in the US at US$39.6b valuation
summary: Grab is set to go public in the US via a merger with Altimeter Growth, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), valuing the group at approximately US$39.6 billion. The deal is expected to raise US$4.5 billion in cash proceeds, with Grab's total addressable market projected to grow from US$52 billion in 2020 to US$180 billion by 2025. The combined company will be listed on Nasdaq under the symbol "GRAB."

site_title: German government seeks law change to take back pandemic control from states
summary: Germany's federal government is seeking a law change to take control of pandemic measures from states, citing rising infections in several regions. The proposed "emergency brake" would introduce nationwide lockdowns, curfews, and restrictions on gatherings and businesses if infection rates exceed 100 per 100,000 residents for three consecutive days. The change, which must be approved by parliament, aims to prevent the health system from becoming overwhelmed. Chancellor Angela Merkel's government believes tougher measures are needed to combat the pandemic, particularly with the more transmissible variant spreading rapidly.

site_title: Indonesia may benefit more from China's economic recovery than the US's: report
summary: Indonesia is expected to benefit more from China's economic recovery than the US's, according to a report by UOB. China has invested heavily in a diversity of sectors in Indonesia, while the US has concentrated its foreign direct investment in the mining sector. Indonesia's exports to China grew 15.6% in 2020, compared to 4.6% to the US. China's recovery could lead to a boost in foreign direct investment and exports, particularly in sectors such as natural products and iron and steel, which are in high demand from China.

site_title: Hong Kong vaccine bookings double after Lam offers benefits
summary: Bookings for coronavirus vaccinations in Hong Kong doubled after Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced benefits for the vaccinated, including easing social-distancing rules and "vaccine bubbles" for restaurants and bars. Around 13,500 people booked Pfizer vaccinations and 3,300 signed up for Sinovac vaccinations, with the government aiming to promote vaccination to encourage more of the population to get shots. Despite a slow vaccination rate, with only 8% of the population vaccinated, the government plans to continue easing restrictions for the inoculated while maintaining restrictions for the unvaccinated.

site_title: FHT could reap benefits if managers repay 4.45% perps with debt: DBS report
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) may see a potential uptick in distributions if its managers repay the 4.45% perpetual securities with debt, according to a DBS Group Research report. This would lead to an estimated 1% accretion to its FY2021 distribution forecast. The decision to redeem outstanding securities may also increase gearing to 42% and reduce financing costs, but could limit future perpetual issuances. Despite this, DBS maintains its view that FHT offers "compelling value" at its current price of S$0.55 per unit.

site_title: IMF offers rosier view on Asia, warns of Fed fallout on markets
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has offered a more optimistic view of Asia's economic outlook, citing a rebound from last year's pandemic slump. However, the IMF warns that a faster-than-expected rise in US interest rates could disrupt markets, potentially triggering capital outflows from the region. The IMF also notes that a slowdown in China's GDP growth and ongoing challenges in vaccine rollout and virus resurgence pose key downside risks.

site_title: People can now choose which Covid-19 jab to take
summary: Singapore now allows individuals to choose which Covid-19 vaccine to receive, with the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines available at different vaccination centers. The Moderna vaccine is administered at 11 centers, while the Pfizer vaccine is available at 27 centers. Individuals must select the same vaccination center for both doses. Both vaccines have similar efficacy rates and side effects, with the Pfizer vaccine requiring two 30-microgram doses taken three weeks apart.

images.alt_text: People who want to choose which Covid-19 vaccine to take can now refer to the Ministry of Health's (MOH's) website, where the full list of vaccination centres and vaccines has now been made available.

site_title: MyTeksi to US$40b: How Grab evolved over the years
summary: Grab, a Southeast Asian ride-hailing giant, is set to list on the US public market through a merger with special purpose acquisition company Altimeter Growth, valuing the company at approximately $39.6 billion. Founded in 2012 by Anthony Tan and Tan Hooi Ling, Grab expanded rapidly, diversifying its services to include food delivery, fintech, and parcel delivery. The company has faced intense competition from rival Uber and Gojek, but has maintained its lead in the region. Grab's IPO is expected to be a major milestone for the startup landscape in Southeast Asia, with analysts expecting the company to tap the funds to continue competing aggressively.

images.alt_text: Anthony Tan, co-founder and chief executive of Grab, in the company's early days.

site_title: Livingstone Health maps expansion plans
summary: Livingstone Health Holdings, a multidisciplinary specialist healthcare group, is mapping out expansion plans following a reverse takeover (RTO) in April 2021. The group aims to increase its range of services and number of clinics and medical practitioners. It plans to expand its primary care footprint organically or through acquisitions, grow its pool of doctors, and branch into allied health services. Livingstone also signed a memorandum of understanding with Hong Kong-listed China Machinery Engineering Corporation to evaluate project collaboration opportunities in integrated healthcare infrastructure projects in South-east Asia and South Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.71 points to 1,597.71. The decline followed a broader market trend, with the US stocks also edging down from records amid tariff threats. Losers outnumbered gainers 740 to 328, with a total of 6.346 billion lots traded worth RM3.054 billion.

site_title: Yongnam proposes placement of 104.5m new shares at 7.6 Singapore cents each
summary: Yongnam Holdings proposes issuing up to 104.5 million new shares at 7.6 Singapore cents each to raise up to S$7.9 million, primarily for general working capital. The placement represents a 9.9% discount to the previous market price and will account for 16.7% of the enlarged share capital. The company's board views the placement as beneficial for meeting project expenses and strengthening its financial position. Net asset value per share is expected to decrease to 23.35 cents from 26.59 cents.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.15% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 28,497.25. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.48% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.06%. The gains come ahead of the release of US inflation data later in the day, which investors are closely monitoring.

site_title: European MNC Schneider Electric and EDB set up new venture in Singapore
summary: Singapore-headquartered NaviX Solutions, a new venture between European multinational company Schneider Electric and the Economic Development Board (EDB), was unveiled on April 13, 2021. The company aims to help companies manage critical power assets, creating approximately 100 new jobs in customer service, technical support, finance, and other areas. NaviX Solutions will initially launch in phases, addressing critical challenges in the evolving digital economy. The venture is expected to leverage Schneider Electric's competitive advantages in energy management, customer networks, and global scale.

site_title: 14 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 14 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 60,692. The cases were detected on arrival and placed on stay-home notice. There were no community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The number of new cases in the community remains stable at two cases per week, and 60,342 patients have fully recovered.

site_title: UK police hunt for thieves who stole world's biggest rabbit
summary: British police are searching for thieves who stole Darius, the world's largest rabbit, from his owner's garden in central England. The 4ft 3-inch-long Continental Giant rabbit was recognized by Guinness World Records in 2010. His owner, Annette Edwards, offered a £1,000 reward for his safe return, as Darius is too old to breed and was retiring from public appearances. This is not the first tragedy for Edwards, as her three-foot-long son Simon died in 2010 during a cross-Atlantic flight.

site_title: Europe: Shares pause near record high with eyes on US inflation data
summary: European shares hovered near record highs on Tuesday, driven by strong export data from China and optimism around a swift global economic recovery. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.1% as German exports grew at a robust pace, while investor attention turned to US inflation data due later in the day. The focus will be on US consumer price data, expected to show a 0.5% increase in March, amid rising bond yields.

site_title: Top Glove's billionaire founder buys stake in education firm
summary: Lim Wee Chai, billionaire founder of Top Glove, has emerged as a minority shareholder in Malaysian private education firm Minda Global. He bought the shares in a recent placement, holding less than 5% of the company. This investment is separate from Top Glove Group, with shares surging as much as 50% to 18 sen. Lim expressed his passion for education, stating it's essential for people, organizations, and nations to advance.

site_title: Australia reports second AstraZeneca blood clot case, vaccine rollout steady
summary: Australia reported its second case of a blood clot after receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine, but vaccination cancellations remain steady. The country abandoned its goal of vaccinating all 26 million population by year-end due to rare cases in Europe. Authorities recommended Pfizer's vaccine for those under 50, and no plans are to add Johnson & Johnson's vaccine. Despite setbacks, the economy is expected to recover faster, with Treasurer Josh Frydenberg saying the virus suppression has boosted household and business confidence.

site_title: CDL, IOI's South Beach complex snags S$1.22b green loan
summary: Singapore's CDL and IOI Properties Group have secured a S$1.22 billion green loan from a consortium of lenders, marking one of the city-state's largest green loans. The five-year loan will refinance South Beach, an integrated office, residential, hotel, and retail development. This brings the total sustainable financing for CDL to over S$2.5 billion, demonstrating the developer's "strong sustainability track record." The refinancing aligns with CDL's sustainable finance framework, highlighting its commitment to environmentally friendly projects.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat ahead of US inflation data
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, closing 0.04% higher at 6,976.9 points, as investors awaited US inflation data before making further bets. Energy and mining firms, including BHP and Rio Tinto, declined, while tech stocks like Afterpay and Zip Co rose. The market is in a holding pattern, with low trading turnover, and the next 24-48 hours will be crucial in determining the market's direction.

site_title: China warns online platform companies to halt anti-competitive practices
summary: China's market regulator warned nearly 34 internet companies, including Tencent and ByteDance, to halt anti-competitive practices such as forcing vendors to use their platforms exclusively. The warning comes after a record $2.75 billion fine was imposed on e-commerce giant Alibaba. The regulator ordered companies to conduct self-inspections within a month, with severe punishment for non-compliance. The warning aims to guide companies in their work and correct their practices according to the law, despite a "positive" development in the platform economy in China.

site_title: China says release of Fukushima water 'extremely irresponsible'
summary: China has criticized Japan's plan to release over 1 million tonnes of treated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the ocean, calling it "extremely irresponsible" and a threat to public health and international safety. The water has been stored for years and will be diluted, but concerns from neighboring countries and fishing communities have prompted China to express its disapproval. China considers the ocean a "common property of mankind" and is closely following the developments, reserving the right to make further responses.

site_title: Condo resale volumes in Singapore hit 10-year high; prices up 0.1% in March: SRX
summary: Condo resale volumes in Singapore reached a 10-year high in March with 1,662 units resold, exceeding double the number from the same period last year. Prices rose 0.1% for the eighth consecutive month, with a 4.2% year-on-year increase. The lack of new home supply, particularly in suburban areas, is attributed to the limited mega launches. Analysts expect demand for resale homes to remain robust, driven by the vaccination programme's impact on market confidence.

site_title: Britain's JD Sports reinstates dividend as online boom lifts forecast
summary: Britain's JD Sports has reinstated its dividend after a strong online performance during the pandemic, with forecasted higher profit for the current financial year. The company expects headline profit before tax to range from £475 million to £500 million. JD Sports has also signed a letter of intent with Clipper Logistics for e-fulfilment and warehousing, and plans to open a warehouse in Dublin to fulfill online orders in Ireland. The decision comes after the company raised £464 million in equity in February and embarked on several acquisitions in the US and Europe.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound ahead of earnings season
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded 0.72% on Tuesday, closing at 29,751.61, driven by buying on dips after falls on the previous session. Investors await growth outlooks from the upcoming corporate earnings season. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 212.88 points, while the Topix index added 3.96 points.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit near three-month closing high on tech boost, foreign buying
summary: South Korean stocks reached a nearly three-month high on Tuesday, closing 1.07% higher at 3,169.08, driven by tech heavyweights and foreign buying. Chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose, while battery makers LG Chem and Samsung SDI surged. Foreigners were net buyers of 444.9 billion won worth of shares. The Bank of Korea is expected to keep interest rates low due to signs of economic recovery, despite concerns over domestic Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Airlines could use new EU Covid pass this summer: official
summary: A senior EU official suggests that airlines could use the new EU Covid certificate to verify vaccination, testing, or recovery status before allowing passengers on summer holidays. The certificate would be valid until the World Health Organisation declares the pandemic over. The EU aims to provide a tool for trust and confidence in travel, allowing for free movement. This move comes as the EU seeks to restart its travel sector, which has been ravaged by the pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong officials approve election overhaul
summary: Hong Kong officials have approved a Bill to implement China's plan to overhaul the city's elections, limiting the influence of the pro-democracy opposition. The changes, approved by the Executive Council, will redraw the electoral map and make it a crime to advocate for blank ballots. A "review committee" will also vet candidates to ensure loyalty to the Communist Party. The moves are part of China's broader plan to increase control over Hong Kong, following an order from China's top legislative body. The changes are expected to be tabled in the Legislative Council on Wednesday.

site_title: STI breaks five-day losing streak to gain 0.4%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) broke a five-day losing streak, gaining 0.44% to close at 3,187.9 points on Tuesday. The best performer was Sembcorp Industries, adding 2.67% after a positive report on its renewable-energy segment. Genting Singapore declined 1.62% due to a Moody's report on its earnings. The region finished mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.72%, while China's Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.48%. Investors are looking ahead to the US earnings season and Treasury auctions.

site_title: Indonesia keeps Sinovac, says best shot is one that's available
summary: Indonesia plans to continue using Sinovac and AstraZeneca vaccines to combat COVID-19, despite concerns about their efficacy rates. The World Health Organization has endorsed the vaccines as safe and effective, with Indonesia aiming to inoculate over 180 million people within a year. Research shows the Sinovac vaccine has an efficacy rate of just above 50%, while Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have delivered protection rates of over 90%. Indonesia will wait for China's response on vaccine mixing and monitor the vaccines, prioritizing the available option.

site_title: Australian government sells A$14b in new 2032 bond
summary: The Australian government successfully sold A$14 billion of a new 2032 bond, priced at a yield to maturity of 1.9%. The 1.75% Treasury Bond drew A$48 billion in bids, with Commonwealth Bank, Deutsche Bank, UBS, and Westpac acting as joint-lead managers.

site_title: China's revamp of Ant dents investor appetite for IPO revival
summary: China's regulatory-imposed revamp of Ant Group, transforming the fintech into a financial holding company, has dented investor appetite for its planned IPO. The overhaul follows a record US$2.75 billion antitrust penalty on affiliate Alibaba Group Holding. Investors expect lower profitability and valuation for Ant, with some valuing it at US$200 billion, down from a touted US$315 billion last year. The revamp is seen as removing uncertainty and relief for Alibaba, but may limit Ant's growth prospects.

site_title: China's export growth misses forecasts despite strong demand
summary: China's exports rose 30.6% in dollar terms in March, exceeding economists' forecasts, while imports surged 38.1%. The trade surplus reached $13.8 billion for the month. Despite slower growth from February's record, export momentum remained strong due to vaccine rollouts and global growth recovery. China's commerce ministry aims for stable foreign trade development this year.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to discuss border reopening during Muhyiddin's May 4 visit
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is set to visit Singapore on May 4 to discuss the reopening of the border with Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The visit comes after Malaysian Foreign Minister Hishammuddin Hussein confirmed that the matter is on the agenda, despite Johor's desire to reopen the border within two months. The appointment of a Malaysian High Commissioner to Singapore remains under process due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Jack Ma's fortune jumps US$2b after record Alibaba fine
summary: China imposed a record antitrust fine of $2.8 billion on Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., a move that increased Jack Ma's fortune by $2.3 billion to $52.1 billion. The fine, based on 4% of 2019 domestic sales, is less severe than feared and won't require a radical overhaul of Alibaba's e-commerce strategy. Alibaba shares rose 9.3% in New York, and the company expressed gratitude and respect for government regulation. The fine follows a campaign against monopolies, which has seen Jack Ma's fortune decline since last year.

site_title: StanChart offers new tool to project impact of job loss, property buys on household finances
summary: Standard Chartered has launched a free online financial planning tool called the Standard Chartered Goals Planner, in partnership with fintech BetterTradeOff. The tool allows users to plan and track their financial goals, including property purchases, early retirement, and funding education, while simulating the impact of real-life events such as job loss or illness. The platform aims to empower clients to take control of their finances and close the financial literacy gap, with the goal of providing improved accessibility to financial products and advice.

site_title: Brokers' take: Jefferies upgrades SGX to a 'buy' with S$11.30 target price
summary: Jefferies upgraded Singapore Exchange (SGX) to a "buy" rating with a target price of S$11.30, up from S$10.50. Analyst Krishna Guha cited robust volumes, growing product offerings, and upcoming index changes as key growth levers. The firm raised growth estimates by 11% and 4% for FY21 and FY22, respectively. However, a potential launch of MSCI China futures by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange is a near-term risk. As of Tuesday, SGX shares were trading 1.5% higher at S$10.11.

site_title: Hong Kong retailer stocks jump after city eases travel rules
summary: Hong Kong retailers saw significant jumps in stock prices after the government announced plans to relax travel restrictions, potentially reviving the tourism sector. The city's economy has been impacted by the pandemic, with visitor arrivals down 97% in February compared to the same month last year.
