The relaxation of travel restrictions, including exempting non-resident visitors from quarantine starting May, has boosted optimism among investors and businesses. Key stocks, such as Sa Sa International Holdings and AIA Group, surged by up to 9.9% and 4.3% respectively, as the government's move is seen as a step towards reopening the city.

site_title: Nissan-backed startup WeRide gets California permit to test driverless vehicles
summary: WeRide, backed by Nissan, Renault, and Mitsubishi, received a California permit to test two passenger vehicles without a safety driver. The startup is also testing its driverless vehicle in China's Guangzhou. This permit allows WeRide to join other companies like Waymo, AutoX, and Cruise in testing autonomous vehicles without a human driver. The move is part of the growing investment in autonomous driving, aiming to take an early lead in the future of mobility.

site_title: GM marketing spend will return to normal levels post pandemic
summary: General Motors' marketing and promotional spending is expected to return to normal levels after the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the company's top marketing officer, Deborah Wahl. The pandemic caused a significant drop in GM's advertising and promotional spending, with a reduction of $1 billion to $2.7 billion in 2020. As the industry recovers, dealers are citing higher prices for new and used cars due to shrinking inventories and a "whole new attitude" from consumers. GM plans to engage with online influencers, launch vehicles in a more entertaining way, and offer personalized communications to change its spending approach.

site_title: Grab to announce merger with US SPAC, to be valued at nearly US$40b: sources
summary: Grab Holdings, South-east Asia's largest ride-hailing and food delivery firm, is set to announce a merger with US-based Altimeter, valued at nearly US$40 billion. The deal includes a US$4 billion private investment from Asian and global investors, and will lead to a public listing. Grab's net revenue surged 70% last year, and the company expects its food delivery business to break even by end-2021. The merger is a big win for Grab's early backers, including SoftBank Group Corp and Didi Chuxing.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up ahead of US inflation, earnings
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday ahead of the US inflation and earnings season, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul gaining more than 1%. The US producer price inflation data last week gave investors a taste of what to expect over the next few months, with concerns about reopening and potential interest rate hikes. Despite worries, investors remain upbeat about the outlook, citing pent-up demand, vaccination progress, and supportive fiscal and monetary policies. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields reached one-year highs, but the smooth sale of government bonds on Monday soothed some concerns.

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus up 5% following application to exit SGX watch-list
summary: Oceanus Group shares rose 5% following its application to exit the SGX watch-list. The seafood supplier has been on the list since 2015 and has received four extensions. To be removed, Oceanus must record consolidated pre-tax profit and have an average daily market cap of S$40 million or more over the last six months. The company's shares reached an intraday high of 4.4 Singapore cents, with 87.7 million shares traded at the midday break.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts bonuses following Archegos loss
summary: Credit Suisse has cut bonuses for its staff by hundreds of millions of dollars following a US$4.7 billion loss from the collapse of hedge fund Archegos Capital. The bank's pre-tax income for the first quarter is expected to be around US$3.7 billion, with a significant portion attributed to staff bonus reductions and one-off items. The exact magnitude of the bonus cuts will be revealed in the company's quarterly results next week. This move comes after the bank was also exposed to the collapse of Greensill Capital earlier in the year.

site_title: China central bank adviser urges against credit contraction: report
summary: China's central bank adviser, Wang Yiming, advises against credit contraction while maintaining control over inflation expectations. The move comes as the central bank balances economic support with debt risks. New bank loans in China rose in March, but broad credit growth slowed. Wang also urges contingency planning for possible US Federal Reserve policy changes, citing uncertainty and the need to "leave enough space" to deal with new uncertainties. This warning comes as China's economy quickly regains momentum and investors closely watch the central bank's actions.

site_title: India's Adani Ports removed from S&P index due to links with Myanmar military
summary: S&P Dow Jones Indices removed India's Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd from its sustainability index due to the firm's business ties with Myanmar's military, accused of human rights abuses following a coup in February. Adani Ports is building a $290 million port in Yangon on land leased from a military-backed firm. The move comes after human rights groups reported the subsidiary would pay millions of dollars in rent to the military-controlled firm. The port developer did not comment on the decision.

site_title: British variant of Covid-19 not as severe as feared: The Lancet
summary: A new study published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases found that the British variant of Covid-19, B.1.1.7, does not cause more severe disease in hospitalized patients compared to other variants. The study analyzed 496 patients and found no difference in risks of severe disease, death, or clinical outcomes. Additionally, a separate study found that vaccines are likely effective against the British variant, with no apparent increase in reinfection rate. The variant is approximately 40-70% more transmissible than previously dominant variants.

site_title: Australia's IGO to exit gold operations to focus on lithium, nickel
summary: IGO Ltd is exiting its gold operations by selling its 30% stake in the Tropicana mine to Regis Resources Ltd for A$903 million. The sale allows IGO to focus on its nickel and lithium ventures. Proceeds from the stake sale will be used to fund IGO's investment in Australian lithium assets. IGO CEO Peter Bradford stated that the mine is no longer aligned with the company's focus on clean energy commodities. Regis plans to raise up to A$650 million in equities to fund the acquisition, which is seen as paying a premium for the stake.

site_title: UK economy grew in February as firms prepared for lockdown easing
summary: The UK economy grew by 0.4% in February, exceeding economists' expectations, as companies prepared for the lifting of a third coronavirus lockdown. The growth was driven by a partial recovery in trade with the European Union, with exports rising 47% and imports up 7%. The economy shrank by 2.2% in January, less severe than initially estimated, and has shrunk by almost 10% last year due to the pandemic. A fast rollout of Covid-19 vaccines has raised hopes for a bounce-back this year and in 2022.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says weak yen promises to benefit Japan's economy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that a weak yen benefits Japan's economy by inflating the value of overseas profits and increasing the value of yen-denominated assets. A weak yen may not boost export volumes as much as in the past due to manufacturers producing goods locally for overseas sales. Kuroda emphasized that equilibrium currency rates are desirable, and the BOJ will combat sharp yen rises with monetary easing if necessary. The dollar is currently above the 100-yen mark, which is considered the BOJ's threshold.

site_title: EU's Investment Bank poised to deploy blockchain for bond sale
summary: The European Investment Bank plans to use blockchain technology for its upcoming bond sale, marking a potential boost for the digital-ledger technology in the EU's debt market. Goldman Sachs, Banco Santander, and Societe Generale will explore a digital bond in euros, which will be registered and settled using blockchain. This move follows European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde's suggestion to launch a digital currency by the end of the decade. Several issuers globally have experimented with blockchain-based issuance, but its use in debt markets remains far from mainstream.

site_title: Australia shelves plans to buy J&J's one-dose Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Australia has shelved plans to purchase Johnson & Johnson's one-dose Covid-19 vaccine due to concerns over rare blood clots. The country, which aims to vaccinate its 26 million population by the end of the year, has instead doubled its Pfizer order to 40 million shots. This decision comes after authorities recommended under-50s not receive the AstraZeneca vaccine amid its own review of the vaccine's safety. Australia's vaccination program, heavily reliant on AstraZeneca, is now moving away from adenovirus vaccines under review.

site_title: Nvidia, Volvo Cars accelerate auto industry's data-processing power race
summary: Nvidia and Volvo Cars have partnered to accelerate the auto industry's data-processing power, with Volvo set to use Nvidia's new high-powered chips to enable more autonomous driving functions in its future vehicles starting next year. This move marks a significant shift towards digital processing power over horsepower, with Volvo and other automakers competing with Tesla, the world's most valuable automaker. Nvidia's revenue from its automotive business is expected to grow into the billions of dollars, following a similar deal with electric vehicle startup Faraday Future.

site_title: Ethiopian Jews' long wait for life in Israel
summary: The article discusses the long wait of Ethiopian Jews for life in Israel, as thousands are buried in a cemetery in northern Ethiopia due to insurmountable hurdles in immigrating to Israel. The cemetery, where many Ethiopian Jews are buried, has grown to an unprecedented size, with hopes that Israel will take responsibility before all of them die there. The situation highlights the difficulties faced by Ethiopian Jews in obtaining Israeli citizenship and relocating to the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Tuesday, down 0.69 points or 0.04% to 1,607.73. Volume reached 376.03 million lots worth RM161.47 million. Losers edged out gainers 233 to 203.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened slightly higher on Tuesday, up 0.07% or 2.33 points to 3,176.26, as Wall Street retreated from record levels ahead of earnings reports and economic data. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 54, with Oceanus rising 7.5% and Jiutian Chemical slipping 1%. Local banks were mixed, while Tokyo stocks opened higher, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.2%.

site_title: Australian business conditions surge to record in March: survey
summary: Australian business confidence reached a record high in March, jumping 8 points to +25, according to the National Australia Bank's index. Firms reported sharply increased sales, profits, and employment, indicating a rapid recovery from the pandemic recession. The survey's confidence measure eased 3 points to +15, still showing a relatively upbeat outlook. This surge in business confidence is a positive sign for the country's economic recovery.

site_title: LHN inks S$16.8m sale and purchase agreements for eight Beach Road flats
summary: LHN Limited has signed binding sale-and-purchase agreements to acquire eight flats in Beach Road, Singapore, for S$16.8 million. The units, located at 75 Beach Road, will be used for various purposes, including the new headquarters of the company and commercial spaces for its co-working and co-living business. The purchases were made through LHN's subsidiaries and will be funded by internal funds, bank borrowings, and deposits. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand the company's portfolio and diversify its revenue stream.

site_title: Blackstone adds conditions for Crown Resorts buyout
summary: Blackstone has set conditions for its proposed buyout of Crown Resorts, including that the company not lose further state licenses. Crown already faces Royal Commission inquiries in Western Australia and Victoria due to its Sydney casino license being deemed unfit. Blackstone offered A$11.85 per share for Crown shares not already owned, valuing the company at A$8.02 billion. The conditions come as Crown faces ongoing regulatory challenges, including inquiries in multiple states.

site_title: Takeaways from the government's C$5.9b aid package for Air Canada
summary: The Canadian government has announced a C$5.9 billion aid package for Air Canada, providing up to C$5.9 billion in funds through a loan program launched during the pandemic. The package includes a C$500 million share buyback and a C$1.5 billion secured revolving credit facility. The government will purchase Air Canada shares at a 14.2% discount, and the credit facility is secured against certain airline assets. The move aims to support the country's largest airline during the pandemic.

site_title: China tells Ant Group it will be regulated like a bank
summary: China has ordered Ant Group Co to become a financial holding company subject to stricter regulations, similar to those of a bank. The move comes after the central bank halted Ant's record IPO last year, citing a changed regulatory environment. Ant must rectify its business in five areas, including eliminating unfair competition and improving corporate governance. The overhaul aims to curb the "reckless" push of technology firms into finance and address monopolies online. The measures are expected to drastically reduce Ant's valuation, potentially leaving it with less than $144 billion in value.

site_title: UK retailers report higher spending in March -BRC
summary: British high street retailers reported higher spending in March, with total sales 8.3% higher than in March 2019 and 13.9% higher than in March 2020. The increase in spending was largely driven by grocery purchases as consumers spent more time at home. However, some retailers, such as discount clothing chain Primark, saw long queues of shoppers after non-essential stores reopened in England on Monday. The higher spending may be short-lived, as some analysts expect a turn-around in April.

site_title: US SPAC boom faces new SEC threat with accounting crackdown
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is cracking down on the accounting rules for blank-cheque companies, specifically warrants issued to early investors. The SEC may not consider warrants as equity instruments but as liabilities for accounting purposes, which could disrupt filings for new special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs). This move threatens hundreds of pending SPAC filings and could require public companies to restate their financial results. The SEC aims to ensure investors are fully informed of potential risks associated with blank-cheque companies.

site_title: LA's famous Cinerama Dome movie theater among coronavirus casualties
summary: Los Angeles' iconic Cinerama Dome movie theater, a historic landmark and popular venue for movie premieres, is closing permanently due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Pacific Theatres group, which owns the theater, announced its closure on April 12, 2021, citing a lack of viable options for reopening. The closure also affects 15 other ArcLight and Pacific Theatres locations. The theater's closure marks a significant loss for the film industry, with many celebrities expressing dismay and calling for alternative solutions to save the iconic venue.

site_title: Vietnamese electric motorbike startup raises US$2.6m in pre-Series A round
summary: Dat Bike, a Vietnamese electric motorbike startup, has raised US$2.6 million in a pre-Series A round led by Jungle Ventures to drive adoption of green transportation in South-east Asia. The funds will be allocated to research and development, customer-facing operations, and scaling the team. The company aims to become a local motorcycle brand in the region, leveraging product and engineering innovations to develop a sustainable supply chain. CEO Son Nguyen plans to achieve these innovations within the next two to three years, paving the way for expansion into the larger South-east Asian market.

site_title: StanChart nabs UBS veteran Raymond Ang as global private and priority banking head
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Raymond Ang, a 25-year veteran of consumer and private banking, as global head of private and priority banking. Ang will report to Judy Hsu and is based in Singapore. He previously held senior positions at UBS, The Carlyle Group, DBS, and Citi. Ang's appointment is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to take effect later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, adding 0.37% to 28,557.84, following two days of losses. The positive move was driven by news that Hong Kong's leaders may start relaxing pandemic containment measures, boosting the local economy. In contrast, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.05% and 0.13%, respectively.

site_title: Aspen Glove inks two-year US$210m supply agreement with Honeywell
summary: ASPEN Glove, a subsidiary of Aspen (Group) Holdings, has entered into a two-year master supply agreement with Honeywell worth US$210 million. Aspen Glove will manufacture and supply nitrile medical-grade examination gloves to Honeywell for the US market, with upfront payments of US$20 million by May 2021. The deal will allow Aspen Glove to expand its facility and increase production capacity to 7.2 billion gloves per annum by the fourth quarter of 2021, generating a cumulative sales value of US$310 million in gloves.

site_title: Temasek and BlackRock form US$600m decarbonisation investment partnership
summary: Temasek and BlackRock have formed a US$600 million decarbonisation investment partnership, Decarbonization Partners, to accelerate global efforts to achieve a net zero economy by 2050. The partnership will deploy private capital in early-stage growth companies focusing on renewable and mobility technologies, and companies driving decarbonisation in building and manufacturing sectors. The funds will be staffed by Temasek and BlackRock employees, with a dedicated team to source and undertake investments. The partnership aims to leverage expertise in sourcing and underwriting private investments, and create sustainable value for stakeholders over the long term.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.22% and the Topix index increasing 0.16%. Investors bought on dips ahead of corporate earnings season, driving the gains. The benchmark indices closed at 29,604.44 and 1,957.62, respectively.

site_title: Investors dump commodities as supercycle call meets scepticism
summary: Investors are reducing their bullish bets on commodities, citing concerns over the economic reopening and inflation. Net bullish positions on commodities have decreased for six weeks, with oil being the most affected. The commodity supercycle, predicted by major investment banks, is being questioned due to rising Treasury yields, a stronger dollar, and worries about China tightening liquidity. Despite calls for commodities to continue their price rebound, investors are trimming their positions amid logistical bottlenecks and supply concerns, raising questions about the sustainability of the supercycle.

site_title: New Zealand introduces climate change law for financial firms in world first
summary: New Zealand has become the first country to introduce a climate change law for financial firms, requiring banks, insurers, and investment managers to report the impacts of climate change on their business. The law, expected to be passed this week, will require financial firms with assets over NZ$1 billion to disclose climate-related risks and opportunities. The first reports will be made by companies in 2023, and the goal is to bring climate risks and resilience into financial decision-making, with a focus on achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Stocks to watch: JMH, ST Engg, Aspen, Sinarmas Land, Tee International
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) approved its acquisition of Jardine Strategic, effective April 14. ST Engineering's contract win with Oshkosh Defense boosted its shares. Aspen entered a two-year master supply agreement with Honeywell, valued at US$210 million. Sinarmas Land and Mitbana jointly developed a transport complex in Greater Jakarta. Tee International reported a wider net loss for the third quarter. Shares of Yongnam Holdings halted trading pending announcements.

site_title: Swiss watch expo switches to Shanghai after virtual debut
summary: The Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie, a prestigious watch fair, has switched from a virtual debut to a physical event in Shanghai, marking the first time the event has taken place outside of Geneva. The fair was initially cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic but returned online this year. With Europe battling a third wave of the pandemic, the physical event will take place in Shanghai, replacing Geneva's usual location.

site_title: Oil rises on US vaccine rollout, Middle East tension
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by optimism over the US vaccine rollout and a missile attack on Saudi oil sites by Yemen's Houthi movement. Brent crude rose 33 cents to $63.28 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate rose 38 cents to $59.70 a barrel. Despite the upward momentum, global vaccination rates remain uneven, with the US at 22% and Europe at around 6%. The US economy is expected to grow, but faces risks of reopening too quickly and sparking a Covid-19 resurgence.

site_title: US: Stocks slip as market awaits key data, earnings
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, edging down from records ahead of key economic data and earnings reports. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2% to close at 33,745.40, while the S&P 500 slipped less than 0.1% to 4,127.99. Analysts are uncertain about market momentum, citing concerns about whether expected economic recovery is already priced in. Earnings reports from JPMorgan Chase and other large banks are expected to be strong, but investors remain cautious.

site_title: Biden meets with CEOs on semiconductor shortage, says US must invest
summary: US President Joe Biden met virtually with CEOs to address the semiconductor shortage, calling for the US to invest in its own infrastructure to prevent future supply crises. The meeting comes as the shortage has affected US auto manufacturing and personal electronics, potentially leading to higher prices. Biden emphasized the need for the US to lead in semiconductor production, stating that the country must not wait like China and other countries. The summit is part of Biden's efforts to build support for his $2 trillion infrastructure bill, which includes $50 billion for semiconductor manufacturing and research.

site_title: Digital tools helping SMEs to handle supply-chain chaos
summary: Digital tools are helping Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) manage supply chain disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Companies like HEC Electrical & Construction and Haulio are adopting digital platforms to streamline operations, reduce paperwork, and improve efficiency. These tools enable real-time tracking, notification, and collaboration, reducing costs and improving supply chain visibility. Trames, a local startup, has launched a simplified digital-platform solution for SMEs, aiming to make digitalization a necessity for industry growth and competitiveness.

site_title: US prices will heat up but won't overheat: White House economists
summary: US White House economists predict US prices will rise in the coming months due to pent-up consumer demand and supply constraints, but the increases are expected to be temporary. The economy's reopening and the pandemic's ongoing impact are driving inflation, which is expected to peak in the next several months. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell agrees that the issues will be transitory, and the impact should fade over time as the economy recovers. The expected price spikes are expected to be measured, with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) forecast to rise 0.5% in the latest month.

site_title: Intel to supply self-driving systems for delivery trucks
summary: Intel is supplying self-driving systems to Silicon Valley startup Udelv, which plans to deploy a fleet of autonomous delivery vehicles by 2028. The companies aim to produce over 35,000 driverless "Transporters" by 2028. The partnership combines Intel's Mobileye Drive system with Udelv's automated delivery vehicles, which combine self-driving technology with robotics for unloading cargo. This move comes as companies like Amazon, Google, and Tesla invest in autonomous driving technology for deliveries, which are seen as a key area for adoption.

images.alt_text: Intel on Monday said it is supplying self-driving systems to Silicon Valley startup Udelv, which plans to have a fleet of autonomous delivery vehicles in action within two years.

site_title: Auction houses Sotheby's, Phillips latest to join NFT craze
summary: Traditional auction houses Sotheby's and Phillips have launched NFT auctions, joining Christie's in the trend that has seen over $10 million in NFT transactions daily. The phenomenon, sparked by Christie's record-breaking $69.3 million sale of a digital artwork, is now becoming more mainstream with digital artists and collectors gaining credibility. Sotheby's is holding a three-day sale featuring digital artist Pak's work, while Phillips is selling a unique piece by Canadian artist Mad Dog Jones, which will generate new artworks with limited NFTs.

site_title: US posts record deficit through March on pandemic spending
summary: The US government posted a record deficit of $1.7 trillion through March, a 130% surge due to pandemic stimulus spending. This represents a $1 billion increase from the same period in the prior fiscal year. The fiscal year-to-date deficit is attributed to the effects of the pandemic, which started showing up at the end of March 2021, and the recently approved $1.9 trillion rescue package. The deficit for March alone surged 454% to $541 billion.

site_title: UK launches inquiry into lobbying scandal involving ex-PM
summary: The UK government has launched an inquiry into a lobbying scandal involving former Prime Minister David Cameron, who lobbied ministers to secure funding for the collapsed finance firm Greensill. The inquiry, led by senior lawyer Nigel Boardman, will examine how contracts were secured and how business representatives engaged with government. Cameron, who became a paid advisor to Greensill after leaving government in 2016, personally lobbied finance minister Rishi Sunak to persuade the government to let the company access emergency financing. The inquiry aims to ensure government transparency and verify if good value was secured for taxpayers' money.

site_title: Higher shipping costs are here to stay, sparking price increases
summary: Higher shipping costs are expected to remain a challenge for businesses, with contract rates for container freight increasing 25-50% over the past year. The cost of shipping a 40-foot container from Asia to the US West Coast and European ports has reached record highs, with rates ranging from $2,500 to $3,000. This is forcing companies to pass on the extra costs to consumers, with some retailers and manufacturers reporting significant price hikes. The Federal Reserve is also taking note, with officials warning of potential inflationary pressures due to supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: UK hits key vaccine target just as pubs, shops and salons reopen
summary: The UK has hit its target of offering a first dose of the coronavirus vaccine to all over-50s by mid-April, with over 32 million people receiving the jab. As restrictions ease, pubs, shops, and salons reopened, with many people celebrating the end of lockdown. Prime Minister Boris Johnson hailed the milestone as a "major step forward in our roadmap to freedom," with efforts now focusing on delivering second doses and offering all adults an initial shot by August.

site_title: Swiss financial watchdog grills Credit Suisse on Greensill risks
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator FINMA questioned Credit Suisse about risks in its dealings with Greensill Capital months before the bank was forced to close $10 billion of funds linked to the now-insolvent finance firm. FINMA head Mark Branson discussed the risks with outgoing Credit Suisse chairman and CEO Thomas Gottstein. The bank had previously shut $10 billion of supply chain finance funds after Greensill lost credit insurance coverage. Credit Suisse has since suspended fund managers and changed its asset management unit head, citing huge losses from exposure to Archegos Capital Management.

site_title: Yes to raising GST rate, but later; other alternatives exist
summary: A Singaporean writer responds to an article advocating for a 9% GST rate, suggesting that the current 7% rate is already sufficient and that increasing it may disproportionately affect lower-income households. The writer argues that GST is not a neutral tax when viewed in context, as it shifts the economic burden from businesses to consumers. They propose alternative measures to restore public finances, such as an excess-profits tax on high-income earners, a higher corporate tax rate, or an "automation tax" on businesses. The writer advocates for a more targeted approach to taxation to avoid burdening the lower-income population.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip from record highs as focus shifts to earnings
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% from record highs on Monday as investors booked profits ahead of the quarterly earnings season. Technology, travel, and leisure, and commodity stocks led declines. In contrast, French utility companies Veolia and Suez surged 9.7% and 7.7% after agreeing on a merger deal worth nearly 13 billion euros. The Stoxx 600 index closed at a record high on Friday, but slipped back to its previous level.

site_title: Promising economic data in Q1 boosts business confidence of a recovery
summary: Singapore's economic performance in Q1 shows encouraging clues of a nascent recovery from its worst recession on record. Business confidence levels have reached the highest level since the Covid-19 pandemic, reflecting optimism. This comes after promising economic data, indicating that dark clouds are receding.

site_title: A has-been power in decline? China should not bet against the US
summary: The US and China are experiencing growing tensions, with some US politicians and lawmakers viewing China as a main challenge to US global supremacy and liberal-democratic values. However, critics argue that viewing China as an enemy could be a self-fulfilling prophecy, and that the US should instead adopt more effective and less dangerous ways to manage competition. The Chinese government's "wolf warrior diplomacy" and nationalist policies may be misinterpreting the US's current challenges, including economic downturn and cultural turmoil, and may lead to further escalation. The US has historically shown resilience and ability to regenerate itself, despite facing significant challenges in the past.

site_title: Singapore Silver Bullion vault to house 15,000 tonnes of silver
summary: Singapore is set to become a major silver storage hub with the construction of a 15,000-tonne silver vault, the largest in the world, expected to be completed in the first half of 2022. The vault's opening is seen as a positive factor for silver, which is expected to outperform gold this year due to its crucial role in energy transition, particularly in solar panels. Analysts forecast high demand growth for silver over the next few years, driven by retail interest, cheap valuations, and its use in industrial applications.

site_title: US women's football team to appeal over equal pay as working conditions approved
summary: A US federal judge approved a settlement between the US women's football team and the US Soccer Federation, granting equal working conditions such as flights, hotels, and venue selection. The team had been seeking over $66 million in damages due to pay inequality. The US women's team plans to appeal the court's equal pay decision and will take the case to a federal appeals court, with a spokesman stating that equal pay is the next step needed to grow women's football.

images.alt_text: The United States women's football team vowed to press on with an appeal in their equal pay lawsuit on Monday after a federal judge in Los Angeles formally approved a deal with the US Soccer Federation over working conditions.

site_title: Godzilla vs Kong becomes top-grossing movie in pandemic
summary: Godzilla vs Kong became the highest-grossing movie in North America since the start of the pandemic, earning $69.5 million in its second weekend. This surpasses previous pandemic-era blockbusters, including Tenet, Croods: A New Age, and Wonder Woman 1984. The film's success boosts the economic case for reopening 45% of North American theatres still shut, but the industry faces other hurdles. The film's hybrid release on HBO Max also highlights the need for studios to return to a state of confidence in putting big-budget movies in theatres.

site_title: UK revises foreign takeover bill to reduce burden on companies
summary: The UK is revising its proposed National Security and Investment law to ease the burden on foreign companies seeking to buy stakes in British assets. The amendment requires prospective overseas buyers to notify the government if they're seeking a 25% stake, up from 15% in the existing draft bill. This change aims to strike a balance between protecting British assets and deterring foreign investment, as the government seeks to steer the economy out of recession. The bill will overhaul existing rules and impose set time-frames for scrutiny.

site_title: Tears, cheers and golf shares rise as Matsuyama's Masters victory thrills Japan
summary: Hideki Matsuyama became the first Japanese man to win a major golf title, capturing the Masters with a one-stroke victory. The 29-year-old golfer finished on 10-under par after a final-round 73. His historic win thrilled Japanese fans, with broadcasters and commentators choked up in tears. Shares in golf-related companies rose on the Tokyo stock market, and Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga hailed the win as a bright spot during the pandemic, saying it encouraged and excited people across Japan.

site_title: Singapore corporates need to get serious about sustainability
summary: Singapore corporates are being urged to prioritize sustainability, with over 2,000 investors globally committing to the Principles for Responsible Investing. The push comes as companies face pressure to balance profitability with sustainability efforts, with 99% of companies meeting or exceeding financial return expectations since inception. Despite some progress, there is still a long road ahead for Singapore companies to incorporate environmental and social metrics into their executive performance scorecards and long-term incentive plans, with only 5% of companies currently doing so.

site_title: Japan begins Covid-19 shots for over 65s
summary: Japan began Covid-19 vaccinations for people aged 65 and above, using Pfizer's vaccine, with 2,810 doses initially allocated to Tokyo. The country's elderly population of 36 million is expected to receive two doses, but shots for the general population are unlikely until late summer or winter. Japan's vaccination pace is expected to be slow, potentially leading to a fourth wave of infection, driven by virulent mutant strains. The country's rapidly aging population of 126 million is also a concern.

site_title: The Biden bulldozer may have to slow down
summary: US President Joe Biden's ambitious spending and tax-hike plans may face significant hurdles in Congress. The $2.3 trillion American Jobs Plan, which includes infrastructure investments and social programs, is unlikely to pass with a simple majority. Conservative Democratic Senator Joe Manchin's insistence on bipartisan support has raised doubts about the bill's prospects. The administration is exploring options, including splitting the bill into smaller packages, to gain support from Republicans and moderate Democrats. Passing at least some of the economic programs this year could provide President Biden with momentum, but it will depend on various factors, including the pandemic's progress and the economy's growth.

site_title: Tencent-backed Waterdrop faces pushback on IPO
summary: Chinese online insurance technology firm Waterdrop, backed by Tencent, is facing pushback from domestic regulators on its planned US IPO due to concerns over its business model being seen as risky. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has questioned Waterdrop's business risks, slowing down the IPO process, and has told its founder that it would not suggest going public at this point. Waterdrop denies any opposition from Chinese regulators and is now looking to list in the second quarter, despite not needing Chinese regulatory approval.

site_title: All eyes on Grab's financials ahead of US$34b SPAC deal
summary: Grab is set to unveil a US$34 billion SPAC merger, which could provide clarity on the company's financial health and growth prospects. Industry observers will closely watch unit economics of Grab's core ride-hailing and food-delivery businesses, and expect the company to use the funds to compete aggressively while potentially streamlining its multiple verticals. Grab's valuation is considered "fair" compared to peers like Meituan and Uber, and the company's ability to defend its territory against rivals and new entrants will be key to its success.

site_title: Million dollars for a coveted HDB unit not an aberration
summary: Million-dollar HDB transactions are on the rise, with 53 such flats sold in the first three months of 2021. These unique, larger flats, such as executive maisonettes and DBSS units, command premium pricing due to their differentiated layouts and features. Despite concerns over land lease decay, buyers are using pricey public flats as homes, and some may opt for prime HDB resale units due to financial constraints or a desire for flexibility. As Singapore's population ages, downgrading from private to HDB units may become more common, driving demand for these luxury flats.

site_title: 15,000 traineeships and company attachment opportunities in pipeline
summary: Singapore's government-funded traineeship and company attachment opportunities, the SGUnited Traineeships and SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programmes, are expected to continue despite a gradual labor market recovery. As of February, 9,500 people have participated in the programmes, with 160 trainees completing the programme and 200 finding full-time jobs. Interest from organizations to host trainees or mid-career individuals remains strong, with 85% of host organizations planning to convert suitable trainees to regular employees.

site_title: Digital transformation is not just about technology
summary: The logistics industry must strategically invest in digitalization to keep up with the e-commerce boom. Digital transformation is not just about technology, but about responding to future challenges and disruptions. Key trends include the rise of omni-channel retail, the importance of real-time visibility in warehouses, and the use of artificial intelligence to handle inventory control and predict consumer habits. Automation can improve logistics efficiency, and technologies like drones and autonomous vehicles are being explored. The industry must also be prepared for cross-border retail and supply chain disruptions, which can be mitigated through advanced supply chain analytics and AI.

site_title: 2,500 on-site attendees expected at upcoming trade show
summary: Singapore's largest trade show since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Architecture & Building Services (ABS) 2021, will take place from June 30 to July 2 at the Marina Bay Sands Expo & Convention Centre. The event will welcome 2,500 on-site participants and 5,000 online visitors, exempting fully-vaccinated attendees from pre-event Covid-19 testing. The hybrid event will test new formats and processes, paving the way for larger business events to take place.

site_title: Post-Covid era of hybrid work beckons in UK
summary: The UK is expected to adopt a hybrid or flexible workweek as COVID-19 restrictions ease in June. Surveys indicate a high demand for this arrangement, with many workers seeking a balance between home and office work. UK businesses are planning to implement this model, allowing employees to split their time between the two. This shift is expected to bring benefits such as increased productivity and work-life balance, although details on implementation and timing are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: World's priciest painting may be a Leonardo after all
summary: The world's most expensive painting, the Salvator Mundi, may be a Leonardo da Vinci work after all, contradicting a French documentary. Experts at the Louvre and analysis unit C2RMF concluded the painting is a work by da Vinci, contrary to the documentary's claims. The painting was bought by the Saudi royal family in 2017 for $450 million, with initial exhibition plans at the Louvre scrapped due to security concerns. The Louvre and C2RMF have confirmed the painting's authenticity, with some experts stating it was damaged and restored, but remains a da Vinci work.

site_title: Companies should look global to seize growth opportunities: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of companies taking a global perspective to fuel growth. Ascent Solutions, an Internet of Things company, exemplifies this approach by expanding its capabilities to provide end-to-end services, including tracking and tracing technology for cargo internationally. The company's innovative technologies and international presence are expected to provide transparency and trust in trade financing, while also offering solutions for preventive maintenance in Singapore's public housing.

site_title: Thailand considers visa rule changes to lure expats, long-term tourists
summary: Thailand is considering changes to its visa rules to attract more expats and long-term tourists, aiming to boost investment and tourism revenue as the pandemic eases. The government plans to relax regulations on immigration, visa applications, and work permits for foreign experts, and offer inducements such as corporate income-tax cuts and incentives for retirees. The goal is to attract one million retirees, who could contribute up to 1.2 trillion baht to the Thai economy annually.

site_title: Japfa set to feast on pork shortage, higher prices amid African swine fever outbreak
summary: African swine fever has led to a global pork supply deficit, driving up lean hog futures by 55% since the beginning of the year. The shortage is expected to persist in 2021 as China's pork production recovers slowly from the outbreak. Singapore-listed agri-food company Japfa is optimistic about its swine operations in Vietnam, which could benefit from the shortage. Japfa expects to expand its operations in Vietnam and potentially enter other markets, citing the country's high pork consumption and shift towards industrialized producers.

site_title: Alibaba shrugs off US$2.75b antitrust fine, shares rally
summary: Alibaba Group Holdings Ltd received a record $2.75 billion antitrust fine from China's State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) for abusing market dominance. Despite the penalty, Alibaba's CEO, Daniel Zhang, expressed confidence in the government's overall support of the company, stating it will not impact the firm's business model. The fine is part of a broader crackdown on technology conglomerates, and Alibaba's shares rose 9% in Hong Kong trade as the uncertainty was alleviated.

site_title: Will UIC's 4G leader change more than its name?
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) is seeking shareholder approval to change its name to Singapore Land Group, citing strong historical brand equity within real estate circles. The proposed name change comes as the company undergoes leadership changes, with Jonathan Eu, the new COO, taking over operations and performance. Eu has expressed his views on refreshing UIC's portfolio of "Grade-A location, but Grade-B quality" assets, which has already begun with the upgrade of the Singapore Land Tower. The company faces challenges in rejuvenating its large portfolio of commercial properties and addressing its limited free float, with only 12.6% of shares in public hands.

site_title: Korean 'webtoons' firm eyes 20t won value from US IPO
summary: Kakao Entertainment, a South Korean webtoons firm, is considering a US initial public offering (IPO) valued at over 20 trillion won ($23.8 billion), doubling its current worth. The company's CEO, Lee Jinsoo, cites Coupang's successful IPO as a potential path, and plans to prepare for an IPO a year from now. Kakao Entertainment aims to expand globally, leveraging the popularity of Korean culture and its existing webtoon and manga sales.

site_title: Flipkart partners Adani Group to build new warehouse
summary: Flipkart has partnered with Adani Group to build a 534,000-square-foot fulfilment centre in Mumbai, which will store 10 million units of inventory and be operational by the third quarter of 2022. The centre will be leased to Flipkart and will be one of the largest logistics hubs in India. Flipkart will also develop a third data centre at the AdaniConnecX facility in Chennai to keep its data within India. The partnership is seen as a significant move to battle Amazon for a bigger slice of India's growing e-commerce market, estimated to reach $200 billion by 2026.

site_title: Didi Chuxing filing confidentially for big US IPO: sources
summary: Beijing-based Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing company, has filed confidentially with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise billions of dollars. Meanwhile, Grab Holdings, a South-east Asian ride-hailing startup, aims to announce a merger with a blank-cheque company in the US valued at over $34 billion. Both companies are capitalizing on a rebound in tech stocks and a surge in demand for ride services in Asia. The listings could pave the way for some of the largest tech debuts globally this year.

site_title: Microsoft to buy artificial intelligence firm Nuance for US$19.7b
summary: Microsoft to acquire Nuance for $19.7 billion, bolstering its healthcare offerings. Nuance's technology is used in medical records and employed in over three-quarters of US hospitals. The deal doubles Microsoft's potential healthcare market to nearly $500 billion. Microsoft's earnings jumped 33% in the latest quarter, driven by cloud computing and personal computing. The acquisition is part of Microsoft's industry-specific cloud strategy, with CEO Satya Nadella stating "AI is technology's most important priority, and healthcare is its most urgent application."

site_title: ICG subsidiary acquires cement-related assets in Kazakhstan
summary: ICG's subsidiary Sharcem has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire cement-related assets in Kazakhstan for around 7.07 billion Kazakhstan tenge (S$22.1 million). The assets include seven land plots and facilities for a cement plant, which will increase ICG's annual cement production capacity by one million tonnes to four million tonnes. The acquisition is expected to be completed by May 31, 2021, and is conditional upon the transfer of assets and removal of liens. This move aims to establish a stronger foothold in Central Asia, where cement demand remains strong.

site_title: Emboldened Putin stirs up global landscape with Xi
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a new law that could keep him in power until 2036, potentially alongside Chinese President Xi Jinping. This move has emboldened Russia's foreign policy, with Putin building up an estimated 25,000 troops at the Ukraine border, sparking concerns among the West. The US and Germany have urged Putin to roll back the military presence, while the US has put its forces in Europe on high alert. Putin's long-term ambitions include restoring Russia's geopolitical prominence and fostering economic ties with China, with potential implications for global economics and geopolitics.

site_title: HSBC bans customers from buying bitcoin-backer MicroStrategy shares
summary: HSBC has banned customers from buying or transferring MicroStrategy shares, citing a "virtual currency product" and a lack of appetite for direct exposure to virtual currencies. The ban applies to HSBC InvestDirect clients in certain countries, including Canada and Britain, and does not affect existing holdings or outgoing transfers. This move comes as large financial firms, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, are exploring investments in cryptocurrencies. MicroStrategy, a US business software firm, owns billions of dollars in bitcoin and has been a prominent supporter of the cryptocurrency.

site_title: Tanglewood back this summer, with Beethoven and Yo-Yo Ma
summary: The Boston Symphony Orchestra's Tanglewood summer season will take place with limited crowds and distancing requirements, featuring a focus on Beethoven's music and appearances by guest artists such as Yo-Yo Ma. The six-week season will include eight orchestral programs, including a Beethoven opener and a tribute to John Williams on his 90th birthday. Performances will last 80 minutes without intermissions and take place in the Koussevitzky Music Shed. The season comes as the performing arts scene begins to reopen after a year of pandemic-related closures, with the orchestra estimating losses of over $50 million in revenue.

images.alt_text: The Tanglewood lawn is a favourite spot for picnicking. Besides Yo-Yo Ma, other familiar guests include Joshua Bell, Anne-Sophie Mutter, Lisa Batiashvili, Emanuel Ax, Daniil Trifonov and Jean-Yves Thibaudet.

The Tanglewood lawn is a favourite spot for picnicking. Besides Yo-Yo Ma (above), other familiar guests include Joshua Bell, Anne-Sophie Mutter, Lisa Batiashvili, Emanuel Ax, Daniil Trifonov and Jean-Yves Thibaudet.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jardine Matheson's acquisition of Jardine Strategic will proceed as planned after shareholders approved the deal at a special general meeting. The acquisition, effective April 14, aims to simplify the parent company structure of the group. International Cement Group (ICG) has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire cement-related assets in Kazakhstan for US$22.1 million. Tee International reported a widened net loss to S$6.4 million for its third quarter, mainly due to a major project completion and COVID-19 slowdown.

site_title: Massive fire guts historic Saint Petersburg factory
summary: A massive fire engulfed a historic factory in Saint Petersburg, Russia, on April 12, 2021, forcing the evacuation of 40 people and claiming the life of one firefighter. Two others were hospitalized. The blaze occurred in the Nevskaya Manufaktura building, a former imperial capital landmark. The fire sent clouds of black smoke over the city, but no injuries were reported among the evacuated residents.

site_title: US dollar drops as traders await inflation data
summary: The US dollar fell to a three-week low as traders awaited inflation and retail sales data. The euro climbed above US$1.19, while the British pound rebounded from a two-month low. This comes as the US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi hit with new criminal charge
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been charged with a fresh criminal offense under the natural disaster management law, adding to the six existing charges against her. The 75-year-old Nobel laureate has been under house arrest since February 1, as the military deposed her government. The junta's crackdown on dissent has resulted in over 700 civilian deaths and 3,000 arrests in the past 70 days, with protests continuing despite the brutality. The international community has condemned the violence and called for restraint, but diplomatic efforts have been hindered by disagreements over sanctions.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower; earnings, data in focus
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Monday, retreating from record levels ahead of the start of the earnings season and a key inflation report. The Dow Jones fell 25.54 points, or 0.08%, to 33,775.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 opening 4.09 points lower, or 0.10%, at 4,124.71. Investors are gearing up for the earnings season and a potential inflation report that may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Big fight brewing in NY over what to do with possibly polluted area
summary: A contentious development plan for New York City's Gowanus Canal is sparking opposition from residents and activists. The proposed $17 billion project, backed by Mayor Bill de Blasio's administration, aims to transform the Superfund site into a mixed-use neighborhood with 8,000 housing units, parks, and shops. However, critics argue that the plan will erase the neighborhood's identity, displace low-income families, and fail to adequately address environmental concerns, including toxic pollutants and coal tar pooling. A lawsuit has stalled the project, with some residents fearing the area's flood-prone status and others questioning the plan's safety and inclusivity.

site_title: Uber, PayPal, Walgreens launch US$11m vaccine rides fund
summary: Uber, PayPal, and Walgreens launched a US$11 million fund to provide free ride-hail trips to US Covid-19 vaccination sites for those who lack transportation. The Vaccine Access Fund, managed by Local Initiatives Support Corporation, aims to address healthcare equity and vaccine access in low-income and Black communities. Consumers can support the effort by donating through PayPal or the Uber app, with the companies seeking additional corporate donors. This initiative builds upon the Biden-Harris administration's efforts to expand vaccine access and utilizes innovative tools from the companies involved.

site_title: STI ends in the red along with region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 10.61 points or 0.33% to 3,173.93 on Monday, following regional declines. The biggest loser was Sembcorp Industries, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the best performer. Asian equity markets are off to a "wobbling start" to the week, driven by concerns over China's antitrust fine on Alibaba and rising Covid-19 case counts in India and Thailand.

site_title: Deals of the week: Trax attracts Softbank; Flash Coffee hot on Asia-Pacific
summary: Trax, a retail analytics firm, secured US$640 million in Series E funding led by Softbank Vision Fund 2 and BlackRock Inc. to scale its business and drive growth. Flash Coffee, a coffee chain backed by Rocket Internet, raised US$15 million for expansion in 10 Asia-Pacific markets, planning to open 300 additional stores by the end of the year. Deeptech startup Atomionics raised S$2.5 million to develop quantum sensors, while Glints secured US$22.5 million in Series C funding to build its talent-recruitment platform.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Reit to dispose of hotel for US$18m
summary: Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-REIT) has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement for the sale of the Crowne Plaza Dallas Near Galleria-Addison hotel in Texas for US$18 million. The 428-room hotel is located near downtown Dallas and Dallas Fort-Worth International Airport. The transaction marks one of 18 hotels in EH-REIT's portfolio that will be disposed of. The sale is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: England reopens with pints pulled, shopping sprees and hair cuts
summary: England has reopened after three months of lockdown, with people flocking to retailers, pubs, and hairdressers to resume spending and socializing. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the reopening as a "major step" towards freedom, but urged people to behave responsibly amid the ongoing coronavirus threat. Hundreds of thousands of businesses have been closed since the lockdown, with estimated losses of £27 billion in sales and 67,000 retail jobs shed in 2020. Non-essential stores will reopen in Wales on Monday, while pubs and restaurants will initially serve outdoors, with indoor service to resume on May 17.

site_title: Jardine Strategic acquisition to go ahead; resolution passed at special general meeting
summary: Jardine Strategic's acquisition by Jardine Matheson is set to proceed, despite some shareholders voting against the deal. The acquisition, announced in March, aims to simplify the parent company structure of the group. A majority of shares voted against the resolution were held by investors who were not shareholders at the time of the announcement. The deal is expected to become effective on April 14.

site_title: London wins 'super prime' property hot spot: survey
summary: London has become the most popular city for ultra-luxurious residential property purchases, surpassing Hong Kong and New York, according to a Knight Frank survey. In 2020, London's super-prime property sales reached US$3.7 billion, up from US$3.2 billion in Hong Kong. Despite Brexit and Covid, London's luxury real estate market continued to thrive, with the combined value of super-prime properties sold in the city climbing in 2020.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.83 points lower on Monday at 1,608.42. Losers outpaced gainers 667 to 411, with a total volume of 5.827 billion lots worth RM3.351 billion.

site_title: Taiwan reports largest incursion yet by Chinese air force
summary: Taiwan reported its largest incursion yet by Chinese air force on Monday, with 25 aircraft, including fighters and nuclear-capable bombers, entering its air defence identification zone. This comes after the US State Department issued new guidelines to deepen ties with Taipei, and amid repeated missions by China's air force near the self-ruled island. The Chinese government has not commented on the incident. The US move is seen as a boost to Taiwan's international support amid China's growing assertiveness in the region.

site_title: 70% of Japanese want Tokyo Games cancelled or delayed
summary: A Kyodo News poll found that 70% of Japanese people want the Tokyo Olympics to be cancelled or delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic. Only 24.5% support the event going ahead as scheduled. The poll also showed 39.2% wanting the Games scrapped and 32.8% favouring another delay. The survey was conducted just over 100 days ahead of the planned start of the Games, amid a fourth wave of Covid-19 infections driven by virulent mutant strains.

site_title: Tee International's Q3 net loss widens to S$6.4 million
summary: Tee International reported a widened Q3 net loss of S$6.4 million, up from S$4.1 million last year, due to a 50% decline in revenue to S$46.7 million. The company attributed the decline to the completion of a major project and COVID-19-related slowdown. Gross loss was S$2.1 million, primarily from its engineering and construction segment, but environmental business and rental income remained stable.

site_title: Veolia, Suez agree US$15b utilities merger after bitter spat
summary: Veolia and Suez, French waste and water management companies, have agreed to a $15.44 billion merger after months of negotiations. The deal values Suez at 20.50 euros per share and will see the companies combine to better compete with emerging global challengers and innovate in environmental services and recycling. As part of the agreement, some Suez assets will be spun off into a new entity with 7 billion euros in revenue to ease antitrust concerns. The deal was brokered by former Suez chairman Gerard Mestrallet and Veolia CEO Antoine Frerot.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Monday, following a heavy sell-off across Asia, as investors await the start of the earnings season. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.86% to 28,453.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.09% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 2.13%. The losses followed a record close on Wall Street.

site_title: Ant to be financial holding firm in overhaul forced by China
summary: China has ordered Ant Group to become a financial holding company, subject to stricter regulations, as part of an overhaul following the firm's halted initial public offering last year. The central bank directed Ant to rectify five areas, including eliminating unfair competition, managing liquidity risks, and improving corporate governance. The measures are expected to drastically reduce Ant's valuation, potentially cutting its value by half. Ant has agreed to cut off improper links between its payments and financial products, and to apply for a company license for personal credit reporting. The overhaul creates a definitive supervision framework for the largest fintech player in China.

site_title: Fitch raises outlook for Australia's 'Big Four' banks as economy rebounds
summary: Fitch Ratings upgraded its outlook for Australia's "Big Four" banks to "stable" from "negative", citing the country's economic rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic. The economy grew faster-than-expected in the final quarter of 2020 and is expected to expand 4.7% in 2021, driven by monetary and fiscal stimulus. The banks' financial profiles are expected to remain stable over the next two years, but risks remain until the vaccination programme is completed. Fitch affirmed the banks' A+ ratings.

site_title: 60% of Asean companies say they are not transitioning to net zero fast enough: survey
summary: Sixty percent of Asean companies believe they are not transitioning to net zero carbon emissions quickly enough, surpassing the global average of 55%. The survey found that 60% of Asean executives require high investment to transition, and 73% cite a lack of investor support as the biggest barrier. Only 20% of Asean companies expect to make progress between 2030-2040, with 53% planning to make progress between 2040-2050. The Covid-19 pandemic has delayed their transition, but 90% of respondents believe cost savings from sustainable practices can make it more financially attractive to speed up the transition.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How to plug financial knowledge gaps (Ep 93)
summary: HSBC's head of wealth products, Deepak Khanna, discusses financial knowledge gaps in a recent podcast episode. The top 3 gaps include: 1) mismatch between financial product maturity and personal goals, 2) insufficient risk assessment, and 3) reliance on broad asset classes without diversification. Khanna emphasizes the importance of building a multi-asset portfolio and understanding sustainable investments. The episode aims to provide useful financial tips for investors, especially those with larger portfolios. The podcast is available on HSBC's FinFit index and financial coaching tools, and is intended for general information only in Singapore.

site_title: 25 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 25 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 60,678. The cases include one locally-transmitted case in a migrant worker's dormitory, which was the first since February 28. The Ministry of Health noted that the case was a reminder that vaccinated individuals can still get infected. 60,320 patients have recovered, and 58 remain in hospital, with 230 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Japan wholesale prices rise for first time in more than a year
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 1% in March for the first time in over a year, driven by a 29% spike in non-ferrous metals and 9.8% rise in oil products and coal. The increase follows a 0.6% fall in February and exceeds a median market forecast. Analysts expect the impact on consumer inflation to be modest, citing soft wage growth and slow vaccine rollouts. The Bank of Japan will scrutinize the data in its quarterly review, amid concerns about the potential for a brief uptick in prices to trigger a withdrawal of stimulus.

site_title: Prince Harry back in the UK for Prince Philip's funeral
summary: Prince Harry returned to the UK on Sunday from Los Angeles to attend Prince Philip's funeral, which will be held at Windsor Castle on Saturday. Due to coronavirus guidelines, Prince Harry will quarantine before attending the ceremony. The Duchess of Sussex, who is pregnant, will not attend due to doctor's advice. Prince Philip, the Queen's husband and Prince Harry's grandfather, died at Windsor Castle on Friday at 99. The royal family will hold a private funeral, with Prince Charles and other family members participating in a procession behind the coffin.

site_title: Late payment charges on HDB mortgage, public rental payments further suspended
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for National Development Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim announced a six-month extension of late payment charge suspension for HDB mortgage and public rental arrears, from April 12 to September 30. The move aims to support households facing financial difficulties due to the economic impact of COVID-19. The suspension is part of the government's targeted support to households in need, following previous extensions in October last year. Over 5,200 households have taken financial assistance measures, including deferred or reduced repayment schemes and rent reductions.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 50% to S$38.7b in March
summary: SGX's total market turnover value reached S$38.75 billion in March, a 50% increase from February. Investor optimism drove global markets, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.3% month-over-month. Equity fundraisings and bond listings reached S$50.8 billion and S$516 million, respectively, in March, the highest amounts since February 2020. Derivatives traded volume increased 31% to 23.2 million contracts, while ETF turnover rose 34% to S$1.6 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall as Yaskawa leads tech sell-off after earnings view disappoints
summary: Japanese shares fell 0.77% to close at 29,538.73, led by a 7.11% drop in Yaskawa Electric after its earnings fell short of expectations, prompting a sell-off in other tech stocks. Other technology firms, including Nitto Denko and Shin-Etsu Chemical, also declined. Despite a 6.21% gain in Toshiba after a takeover bid, the Nikkei average has been in a holding pattern since hitting a 30-and-a-half-year high in mid-February.

site_title: Clemens Philippi joins MSIG Asia as chief operating officer
summary: MSIG Asia appoints Clemens Philippi as chief operating officer (COO), effective Monday. Philippi, previously CEO for Asean at Euler Hermes, will collaborate with senior leadership to drive profitable growth in the financial and insurance market. This appointment follows the recent hiring of chief risk officer William Song. The move aims to drive business and operational synergies in Asia amid challenging market conditions. Philippi will join MSIG Asia's executive committee, further solidifying the company's commitment to sustainable growth in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise on gains in battery makers, strong US recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.12% to 3,135.59 on Monday, led by battery makers LG Chem and SK Innovation, which surged 0.62% and 11.97% respectively after resolving a dispute. The US economy is seen as an "inflection point" for growth, according to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. However, investors remain cautious ahead of US earnings and inflation data. Exports jumped 24.8% in the April 1-10 period, and the won fell 0.33% against the dollar.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Sanofi plans to invest 400 million euros in a Singapore facility to manufacture vaccines, enabling the production of innovative vaccines on a massive scale for Asia and quickly responding to future pandemic risks.

site_title: DiaSorin to buy Covid-19 test-maker Luminex for US$1.8b
summary: DiaSorin, an Italian diagnostics company, agreed to acquire Luminex Corp, a US-based maker of Covid-19 testing kits, for approximately $1.8 billion. The all-cash transaction will give DiaSorin a greater foothold in the US market and a bigger presence in North America, where the company accounts for about 37% of its sales. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter and is subject to shareholder approval. DiaSorin's CEO Carlo Rosa said the acquisition fits with the company's strategy to grow its positioning in molecular diagnostics.

site_title: South Korea's regulator to probe Hyundai execs for alleged insider trading
summary: South Korea's Financial Services Commission (FSC) is set to investigate Hyundai Motor executives for alleged insider trading. The probe follows allegations of undisclosed information regarding Hyundai's talks with Apple on autonomous vehicle development. The investigation, which may take up to six months, is a result of a review of Hyundai executives' stock trades. The FSC will lead the investigation, which aims to determine if any insider trading occurred.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ease from record high ahead of earnings season
summary: European stocks eased 0.1% from all-time highs as investors held off on big bets ahead of earnings season. Concerns over surging Covid-19 cases globally and US earnings justifying sky-high valuations contributed to the decline. British retailers set to reopen from a strict winter lockdown also impacted the market. Despite this, mining and healthcare shares supported the Stoxx 600 index.

site_title: Tears, cheers and shares rise as Matsuyama victory thrills Japan
summary: Hideki Matsuyama, a 29-year-old Japanese golfer, won the Masters title, becoming the first Japanese man to capture a major golf title. His one-stroke victory was met with tears and cheers in Japan, with shares in golf-related companies rising on the Tokyo stock market. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga hailed the win as a bright spot during the pandemic, and Matsuyama's victory marked a historic moment for Japanese golf, with many praising his achievement as a source of hope for the country.

site_title: India sees job losses as curbs return to check new virus wave
summary: India is experiencing job losses due to a fresh round of provincial lockdowns to curb the rising virus infections. Unemployment rose to 8.6% for the week ending April 11, from 6.7% two weeks ago, with severe impacts in urban areas nearing 10%. The country is facing an escalating health crisis, with record-breaking cases and hospital overloads, prompting further restrictions. This resurgence of COVID-19 worsens the job outlook, with prolonged night curfews potentially leading to another bout of reverse migration and sustained job creation challenges.

site_title: Korean 'webtoons' firm eyes 20t won valuation from US IPO
summary: Korean webtoon firm Kakao Entertainment is considering a US initial public offering (IPO) with a potential valuation of over 20 trillion won (S$23.85 billion), double its current worth. The company, which owns popular webtoons, is planning to spend 1 trillion won this year to acquire assets overseas or at home. Kakao Entertainment aims to expand globally, leveraging the growing popularity of Korean culture, and is already available in over five languages. A US IPO would be the latest in a string of Korean startups exploring listings, following Coupang's blockbuster listing in March.

site_title: Thailand considers visa rule overhaul to lure investment, tourists
summary: Thailand's government considers overhauling its visa rules to attract more investment and tourists. The plan, proposed by a task force led by Chayotid Kridakorn, aims to make it easier for expats and long-term tourists to stay in the country. Proposed changes include relaxing work permit requirements and corporate income-tax cuts. The goal is to boost the economy, which contracted by its largest margin in over two decades last year, and attract 1 million retirees to contribute $51 billion annually. The framework is set to be proposed to the government's economic panel within a month.

site_title: 9,500 people have taken on SGUnited traineeships, attachments so far: MOM
summary: About 9,500 people have taken up government-funded traineeships and attachment programs in Singapore, with 160 having completed the program. Of those who completed the program, about 60% found full-time employment, while 200 individuals secured jobs during the program. The majority of trainees, 85%, were converted to regular employees by their host organizations. Despite the positive outcomes, nearly half of those who received attachments or offers turned them down, citing other opportunities.

site_title: Huawei CFO and HSBC reach agreement in Hong Kong case seeking documents
summary: HSBC and Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou reached an agreement in a Hong Kong court case, with HSBC agreeing to produce documents related to the Chinese tech giant. Meng, accused of misleading banks into handling transactions violating American trade sanctions, sought records from HSBC. The agreement was revealed at a Hong Kong court hearing and involves "document production." The Canadian extradition hearings on Meng's request are expected to continue until May, with potential appeals extending the process.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip after government scraps vaccination targets
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.3% to 6,974 on Monday, closing lower for the second straight session, after the federal government scrapped its Covid-19 vaccination targets. The decision followed a shift in stance on AstraZeneca's vaccine. Travel stocks, such as Webjet and Qantas, fell 2% each, while miners and gold stocks declined, with BHP Group and Newcrest losing 1.3% and 2.6% respectively. Healthcare stocks outperformed, with CSL and ResMed rising 0.9% and 1.8%.

site_title: Nobel economist warns against wealth tax to pay for pandemic
summary: Nobel Prize-winning economist Angus Deaton warns against introducing a wealth tax to pay off pandemic debts, citing its potential to become permanent and create incentives for the wealthy to avoid it. Deaton recommends instead focusing on addressing social inequalities through targeted policies, rather than relying on a one-time wealth tax. He also cautions against cuts to social services, warning that austerity measures have exacerbated existing economic disparities in the UK.

site_title: Wealthy Japanese flying private in greater numbers, ANA says
summary: Wealthy Japanese individuals are increasingly turning to private jets due to the ongoing pandemic, with ANA Holdings Inc expecting 1 billion yen in sales for its private jet charter business in the 2022 fiscal year. Inquiries for private charters have risen 30% to about 20 per month, driven by business people flying to Japan and those stuck overseas seeking to return home. Japan's small market size is offset by the country's efficient domestic transport system, while the number of wealthy households has reached 1.3 million, with net financial assets reaching 333 trillion yen.

site_title: Harley-Davidson nominates Ford CEO Farley to join its board
summary: Harley-Davidson has nominated Ford CEO Jim Farley to join its board, in a move aimed at revitalizing the struggling motorcycle maker and preparing it for an electric future. Farley, a car racing enthusiast and owner of classic Harley-Davidsons, has nearly doubled Ford's electrification spending to $22 billion. Harley-Davidson CEO Jochen Zeitz is seeking to transform his company by embracing electrification, a strategy he previously championed during his tenure as a board member. The nomination was disclosed in an April 9 letter to shareholders, ahead of a May 20 annual shareholders meeting.

site_title: Philippines eases movement curbs in Manila region
summary: The Philippines has relaxed movement curbs in the Manila region and four neighboring provinces, moving to a modified enhanced community quarantine until the end of April. The national capital and surrounding provinces will allow more businesses to operate, with restrictions on gatherings and nighttime curfews eased. The move comes as hospitals added 3,156 beds for Covid-19 patients and the country struggles with the most active coronavirus cases in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Sanofi plans to invest 400m euros to manufacture vaccines in Singapore
summary: Sanofi plans to invest 400 million euros over five years to establish a new vaccine production site in Singapore, valued at S$639 million. The facility, in partnership with the Singapore Economic Development Board, will produce innovative vaccines on a massive scale for Asia, create up to 200 local jobs, and be carbon-neutral. It will complement Sanofi's existing manufacturing capacities in Europe and North America, mainly supplying the Asian region. The project is currently in its design phase, with construction expected to begin in Q3 2021 and completion in Q1 2026.

site_title: Companies are selling their real estate at the fastest pace ever
summary: Companies in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa sold record amounts of real estate in 2020, totaling 27 billion euros (S$43 billion). This is the fastest pace of corporate property sales ever, driven by companies seeking to shore up their balance sheets during the pandemic. Office properties accounted for nearly a third of sales, with volumes jumping 10% from the previous year. The shift to home working and lockdowns led to a reevaluation of business needs, prompting companies to reconsider their real estate holdings.

site_title: Staff-served buffet lines in Singapore allowed to resume
summary: Staff-served buffet lines in Singapore are allowed to resume starting April 12, 2021, following the suspension due to the Covid-19 pandemic. However, self-service buffets remain suspended, and certain events such as weddings and corporate gatherings are still prohibited. The permitted staff-served buffets must adhere to specific rules, including limited capacity and the presence of a representative to ensure compliance with safe-management measures. This development brings "some hope" to food caterers whose revenue declined by 70-80% since the pandemic began.

site_title: Pan Ocean Co signs long-term time charter contract with Shell worth around US$55m
summary: Pan Ocean Co has signed a long-term time charter contract with Shell NA LNG worth around US$55 million. The contract, starting May 2023, includes an 8-year duration with two extension options. The estimated total sales for the transaction was US$55 million.
