The deal was completed in a heavily-subscribed placement involving sovereign wealth funds, hedge funds, and major investors, with Prosus committing not to reduce its remaining stake further for three years.

site_title: Hin Leong founder OK Lim's court hearing on additional charges postponed
summary: A Singapore court hearing for OK Lim, founder of collapsed oil trading firm Hin Leong Trading, has been postponed until April 29. Lim was expected to face additional forgery-related charges, but the session was adjourned due to his respiratory health issue. He was previously charged with two counts of abetment of forgery last year.

images.alt_text: A Singapore court session where the founder of collapsed oil trading firm Hin Leong Trading, Lim Oon Kuin, was to face additional charges has been postponed until April 29, according to court proceedings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.16% on Thursday, driven by an Asia-wide advance following a record lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 29,008.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.08%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The gains were despite US President Trump's new tariff threats.

site_title: Grab to launch US$275m fund for social and environmental programmes
summary: Grab is launching a US$275 million fund, the GrabForGood Fund, to support social and environmental programs in South-east Asia. The fund will be seeded with US$50 million in cash and US$200 million in expected Grab shares value. The initial allocation includes US$20 million for Covid-19 vaccine subsidies and will support programs in education, financial support, and environmental issues. An advisory board will oversee the fund's distribution, providing representation for Grab partners and the broader community.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat will step down as leader of the fourth-generation ministers and relinquish the Finance portfolio due to his age and health. Excess JSS payouts amounting to S$370 million were mistakenly made to 5,400 businesses in October. UOB successfully issued US$1.5 billion in sustainability bonds, a first for Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.29% for the third consecutive session.

site_title: Norway wealth fund could allocate up to US$80b to outside firms
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund is planning to allocate up to $80 billion to external asset managers, increasing its allocation to 6% from 5%, as it aims to diversify its portfolio and manage equities in emerging markets. The fund's CEO, Nicolai Tangen, notes that the current market is at risk due to low interest rates and potential inflation, and the fund is preparing for potential volatility by stepping up research on negative selection and training portfolio managers to deal with extreme stress.

site_title: Investors, foreign leaders can still expect coherence and stability despite succession setback: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing has reassured foreign investors that the country's coherence and stability will remain despite Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat's withdrawal from the line of political succession. Chan emphasized the continuity of plans, policies, and processes, while Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stressed the unchanged national leadership team. Lee noted that the quality of leadership produced by Singapore's system will be the key factor in maintaining stability and investor confidence. A new Finance Minister will be named in two weeks, following a Cabinet reshuffle.

site_title: Tiger Global backs bots startup Gupshup at US$1.4b value
summary: Tiger Global has invested $100 million in messaging bots startup Gupshup at a $1.4 billion valuation, the startup's first major funding since 2011. Gupshup, co-founded by Beerud Sheth, helps companies develop customer-relations chatbots on websites or services like WhatsApp. The investment is part of a growing trend of private investments in Indian startups, with over $2 billion in funding secured this year, creating at least five new unicorns. Gupshup plans to use the funding to build out its service globally, with annual revenue exceeding $150 million in 2020.

site_title: Singapore shares down for third straight session; STI loses 0.29%
summary: Singapore shares fell for a third consecutive session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 0.29% or 9.36 points to 3,186.40. Asian markets are cautious ahead of Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's speech. The decline follows a 5-day rally and comes as US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Meet the ex-BMW designer shaping Kia's future
summary: Kia has appointed a new design chief, Karim Habib, who previously worked at BMW, to shape the brand's future. Habib, a Lebanese-born mechanical engineer, has been tasked with creating Kia's "design language," dubbed "Opposites United," which takes inspiration from nature and humanity. Kia's first new electric car, the EV6, showcases this design language and boasts Porsche-rivalling acceleration. The EV6 is expected to arrive in Singapore next year and is part of Kia's plan to roll out seven new pure-electric cars by 2027. Habib aims to create original, inventive, and exciting electric vehicles that improve the lives of customers.

site_title: Singapore bank chiefs see opportunities arising from China, geopolitics
summary: Singaporean bank chiefs see opportunities emerging due to the current global geopolitical situation, particularly with China's rise. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) chairman, Wee Ee Cheong, and outgoing OCBC chairman Samuel Tsien, emphasized the need for Singapore to capitalize on its role as a hub for supply chain financing and attract talent. With China emerging stronger, Singapore is expected to benefit from the relocation of factory plants and the Asean-China corridor. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) also highlighted the importance of building digital foundational infrastructure to support the financial industry.

site_title: Apple to argue it faces competition in video game market in Epic lawsuit
summary: Apple plans to argue that it faces competition in the video game market in its defense against antitrust allegations by Epic Games. The company will claim that consumers have multiple choices for video game transactions, including purchasing virtual tokens on other platforms and using them on iPhones without fees. This stance contrasts with Epic's argument that Apple has monopoly power over the market for software developers due to its control over app installation and fees. The case will be heard by US District Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers in May.

site_title: 21 new coronavirus cases reported, all imported
summary: There were 21 new coronavirus cases reported in Singapore, all of which are imported cases who had been placed on stay-home notices (SHN) on arrival. The total number of cases now stands at 60,575. No community cases were reported, and none originated from migrant workers' dormitories. The 21 cases were previously identified as close contacts of a community case, but a serological test result has confirmed that the individual was infected in the past.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat no longer Singapore's next PM; to relinquish Finance portfolio at Cabinet reshuffle
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat is stepping down as Finance Minister due to his age and health concerns, citing a desire for a "sufficiently long runway" to lead Singapore beyond the Covid-19 crisis. He will relinquish his portfolio and remain First Assistant Secretary-General of the ruling PAP. A Cabinet reshuffle is set to take place in two weeks, with a new Finance Minister to be appointed. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong accepted Heng's decision, describing it as selfless, and will remain in office until a new successor is chosen by the 4G team.

site_title: London Stock Exchange investigating Refinitiv data outage
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) is investigating a data outage on its Refinitiv market data unit, Eikon, which began at 8:30am GMT on Thursday. The outage disrupted access to market prices for subscribers, including those relying on data for trading currencies and other assets. LSEG apologized for the disruption and is working to resolve the issue. This is the second outage at Refinitiv since LSEG's US$27 billion purchase of the company in January, with analysts warning of heavier-than-expected integration costs.

site_title: S$370m in excess JSS payouts mistakenly made to 5,400 businesses in Oct
summary: The Singapore government has acknowledged that S$370 million in excess Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts were mistakenly made to 5,400 businesses in October, resulting from incorrect reopening dates being assigned to firms. The error also affected 360 businesses with S$1.2 million in excess foreign worker levy waivers and rebates. Affected businesses have agreed to return S$200 million of the excess payouts, with the remaining amounts to be recovered through deductions from future JSS payouts or cash repayment.

site_title: Australia-based fintech company Finder buys GoBear's brand
summary: Australia-based fintech company Finder has acquired the brand, trademark, and digital assets of GoBear, including its social media channels in seven markets. GoBear, a financial services firm, had announced its closure in January 2021 due to funding issues. The GoBear brand will continue to operate through social media and email channels, with its website content integrated into finder.com. Finder has seven offices globally and will utilize the acquired digital assets to expand its services.

site_title: Manhattan renters scoop up lingering units in discount frenzy
summary: Manhattan renters are snapping up long-lingering apartment units with average discounts of 6.8% off the original list price, the second-highest markdowns since the pandemic began. Apartment contracts jumped 89% in March to 4,986, with units spending an average of 100 days on the market. Despite an uptick in demand, clearing the inventory of empty apartments remains a challenge, with 19,633 empty units seeking tenants at the end of March. Rents are stabilizing, with median rent up 4.6% from February, but still 14% less than last March.

site_title: 2,500 on-site participants expected for major trade show at Marina Bay Sands
summary: Singapore's largest trade show since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, Architecture & Building Services (ABS) 2021, will welcome 2,500 on-site participants and 5,000 online visitors from June 30 to July 2. The event, held at Marina Bay Sands Expo & Convention Centre, will exempt fully-vaccinated local attendees from pre-event Covid-19 testing and implement safe-management measures, including social distancing ambassadors and limited capacity. The event aims to test new formats and processes for larger meetings, incentives, conferences, and exhibitions, paving the way for larger business events to take place.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close up on US recovery hopes; virus surge caps gains
summary: South Korean shares closed up for a sixth consecutive session, driven by optimism over the US Federal Reserve's commitment to supportive policy. The Kospi rose 0.19% to 3,143.26, despite a surge in local coronavirus cases. The benchmark bond yield fell, while the Korean won weakened. Foreigners were net buyers of 107.5 billion won worth of shares, and the Kospi has risen 9.39% this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.07% or 21.81 points at 29,708.98. The Topix index slipped 0.79% or 15.57 points to close at 1,951.86. Investors sidestepped active trading due to a lack of fresh clues, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Inflation worries keep gold steady after Fed maintains stance
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,737.89 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve maintained its stance on keeping interest rates low for a longer period, citing a commitment to supporting the economy until its recovery is more secure. This move countered concerns about potential higher inflation.

site_title: Indonesia turns to China to help plug vaccine shortage after AstraZeneca delays
summary: Indonesia is in talks with China to receive an additional 90-100 million Covid-19 vaccine doses to address a shortage after AstraZeneca delays. The country had initially agreed to receive 50 million doses, but now plans to receive only 20 million doses in 2021. Indonesia aims to reach herd immunity with 181.5 million people vaccinated within a year. The country has already received 56 million doses from China's Sinovac Biotech and is also negotiating with AstraZeneca to reschedule its shipments.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is in talks with China on getting as many as 100 million Covid-19 vaccine doses to plug a gap in deliveries after delays in the arrivals of AstraZeneca shots, Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin said on Wednesday.

site_title: Myanmar crisis sounds death knell for garment industry, jobs and hope
summary: Myanmar's garment industry is facing a severe crisis, with thousands of jobs at risk due to the ongoing military coup and resulting economic downturn. The sector, which accounts for a third of the country's exports, has seen a significant decline in orders, with 800 workers at one factory, owned by Li Dongliang, on the verge of being laid off. The industry's struggles are emblematic of the broader economic challenges facing Myanmar, which employs 700,000 low-income workers and relies heavily on foreign investment. The situation is further complicated by US tariffs and other global economic pressures.

site_title: Uniqlo operator Fast Retailing raises profit outlook
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, has raised its profit outlook for the 2020/21 fiscal year, expecting a 70.7% increase in operating profit to 255 billion yen (S$3.12 billion). The company attributes the stronger rebound to solid performance in East Asian countries less affected by virus lockdowns. In the first six months of the financial year, Fast Retailing logged a 0.5% dip in revenue year-on-year, but operating profit rose 22.9% from the previous year. The company plans to continue opening new stores, with 2,337 Uniqlo stores worldwide by the end of August.

site_title: Thai consumer spending may fall 100b baht on new Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Thailand's consumer spending may drop up to 100 billion baht (S$4.26 billion) if a new Covid-19 outbreak lasts for two months, potentially sinking the economy in the current quarter. Consumer confidence fell to 48.5 in March, and a new wave of infections has raised concerns about the economy's growth, which could shrink in the second quarter instead of growing 1-2 per cent as forecast. The outbreak's impact is expected to be felt for at least three months before consumer spending picks up if the Covid situation eases quickly.

site_title: Europe: Stocks scale all-time highs with miners in the lead
summary: European stocks reached record highs, driven by gains in miners, automakers, and retailers, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.5% to its highest level since the pandemic. The US Federal Reserve pledged to keep monetary policy loose, boosting investor optimism. Despite news of vaccine restrictions, investors focused on economic recovery and the world's largest-ever block trade by Prosus, which rose 1.6% after selling 2% of China's Tencent Holdings for $14.7 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend rally on iron ore, Wall Street strength
summary: Australia's shares rose for a fifth consecutive day, driven by iron ore prices and Wall Street strength. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.4% to 6,953.2 points, with heavyweight mining stocks like Fortescue Metals Group and BHP Group up 2.4% and 1.8% respectively. The S&P 500 and Dow also closed higher, with the US Federal Reserve reiterating its accommodative stance until the economic rebound is more secure.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB initiates 'buy' on AIMS APAC Reit with S$1.55 target price
summary: RHB has initiated a "buy" rating on AIMS APAC Reit (AAReit) with a target price of S$1.55. The broker cites AAReit's high-quality industrial assets in Singapore and Australia, strong logistics-focused portfolio, and potential for acquisition-led growth. Analysts expect a 9% increase in distribution per unit by end FY2022, driven by occupancy improvements and accretive acquisitions. AAReit's small size and established track record of extracting value from existing assets are also highlighted as key strengths.

site_title: Despite stumbling blocks, ACTS moving at steady clip
summary: The Asean Customs Transit System (ACTS) has made significant progress since its launch in November 2020, with several initial live pilot operations and growing interest from traders in Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. Despite challenges, stakeholders are optimistic about the system's potential to enhance regional cooperation, trade efficiency, and environmental sustainability. Key benefits include improved logistics timelines, reduced regulatory bottlenecks, and increased adoption of green logistics. The ACTS is expected to expand to Brunei, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with a focus on multimodal consignments and reduced costs for trucking operations.

site_title: Reddit-fuelled penny stock's 6,400% rally reversing in Sydney
summary: IOUpay, a fintech firm, has seen its stock price plummet 40% since mid-February after a 6,400% rally fueled by a Reddit-fueled retail trading frenzy. Analysts predict further declines due to intensified competition from larger rival Afterpay in South-east Asia. IOUpay's newly launched buy-now-pay-later services face increased competition, and retail investors may sell out, leading to a subdued price for an extended period. Despite this, IOUpay remains Asia's top-performing interactive media and services stock over the past year.

site_title: China begins construction of its fifth rocket launch site
summary: China has begun construction on its fifth rocket launch site in Ningbo city, eastern Zhejiang province, as part of a plan to increase space infrastructure and support the growing demand for commercial missions. The site, valued at 20 billion yuan, is expected to launch 100 missions per year, comparable to Cape Canaveral in Florida. China aims to build massive constellations of commercial satellites and currently plans to launch over 1,000 low-Earth orbit satellites in coming years, with the Long March-5 rocket capable of transporting 60 satellites at a time.

site_title: Tesla scouts for showroom space in India, hires executive for lobbying: sources
summary: Tesla is scouting for locations to open showrooms in India's New Delhi, Mumbai, and Bengaluru, with plans to import and sell the Model 3 sedan by mid-2021. The company has hired executive Manuj Khurana to lead its lobbying and business efforts, and is searching for commercial properties as large as 20,000-30,000 square feet. Despite challenges such as limited charging infrastructure and high taxes, India's growing affluent market and government incentives make it an attractive target for Tesla.

site_title: DBS enhances digital investment advisory tool for retail investors
summary: DBS has launched an enhanced digital investment advisory tool for retail investors, providing personalized product recommendations based on risk profiles, investment preferences, and financial situations. The tool, NAV Planner, aims to help investors overcome inertia and make better investment decisions. The new version offers specific product recommendations, including collective investment schemes, insurance solutions, and robo-advisory portfolios. DBS has observed a positive response to the tool, with guided users investing an average of S$7,500 per year, compared to S$3,000 for non-guided users.

site_title: Axiata, Telenor in advanced talks to merge Malaysian operations
summary: Axiata Group and Telenor ASA are in advanced talks to merge their Malaysian mobile operations, Celcom Axiata Berhad and Digi.Com. The proposed deal would have the companies equal ownership of 33.1% each, with Malaysian institutional investors owning at least 51.1% of the shares. As part of the transaction, Axiata would receive newly issued shares in Digi and US$400 million in cash. The merged company, Celcom Digi, aims to be a leading telecommunications service provider in Malaysia with estimated proforma revenue of RM12.4 billion.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up after Wall Street record
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Thursday, driven by optimism over the US economy's strong recovery, despite some volatility. The S&P 500 hit a record on Wall Street, with investors betting on blockbuster growth. US President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan, worth $2.25 trillion, is expected to pass with a simple majority in the Senate, despite potential tax rises. Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen pushes for a global corporate tax to finance recovery efforts. Markets were broadly up, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul leading gains, while Tokyo and Singapore fell.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday morning with losses, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.25% to 28,604.12. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, easing 0.35% and 0.40% respectively. The losses come as investors prepare for the corporate earnings season, which is expected to begin soon.

site_title: New Zealand suspends entry for travellers from India due to high Covid-19 cases
summary: New Zealand has suspended entry for all travellers from India for about two weeks due to a high number of positive coronavirus cases arriving from the South Asian country. The suspension, starting April 11 and ending April 28, follows 23 new positive cases, 17 from India. The move aims to assess risk management measures before resuming travel. This is not a country-specific risk assessment, but rather a response to the increasing number of cases globally. New Zealand has virtually eliminated the virus within its borders and reported no community transmission for about 40 days.

site_title: Jokowi doubles Indonesia's wealth fund goal to US$200b
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has set a goal to double the country's wealth fund to $200 billion in the next two to three years, aiming to fund its push for a resource-driven economy to rise up the value chain. The fund, known as the Indonesia Investment Authority, has received pledges from investors in the UAE, Japan, the US, and Canada, growing to $20 billion in six months. The fund will support long-term development and Indonesia's goal to move beyond relying on raw resources, with a focus on infrastructure, technology, and renewable energy.

site_title: UK firms step up hiring as lockdown nears end
summary: British companies sharply increased hiring and offered higher pay in March as they regained confidence in economic recovery and prepared for easing Covid-19 restrictions. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation reported the fastest rate of permanent staff hiring in six years, with spending on temporary staff rising the most since 2017. Retail and hospitality remained the weakest sectors, while demand was strongest for nurses, IT workers, and certain blue-collar and finance roles. This growth comes ahead of the UK's economic forecast, which expects unemployment to rise to 6.5% later this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly lower on Thursday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 0.09 points to 3,195.67. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 56, with Jiutian Chemical falling 4.4% and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding trading flat. Local banks DBS and OCBC were mixed, while UOB rose 0.2%. The decline follows mixed trading on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average edged up, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%.

site_title: World's priciest painting not a full da Vinci, claims documentary
summary: A French documentary has questioned the authenticity of the Salvator Mundi, the world's most expensive painting sold at a 2017 Christies auction for $450 million. The documentary suggests the painting is not a full work by Leonardo da Vinci, sparking a diplomatic dispute between France and Saudi Arabia, the painting's owner, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The authenticity of the painting has been a topic of debate for years, with some experts questioning the provenance of the artwork.

site_title: HDB resale prices rise for 9th straight month in March
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.8% in March, marking the ninth consecutive month of increase, driven by delays in Build-to-Order flats, rising private property prices, and improving market sentiment. Year-over-year, prices rose 9.5% from March 2020, nearing their all-time highs, with March prices 4.9% lower than their peak in April 2013.

site_title: JPMorgan chief predicts a boom for US economy
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon predicts the US economy will boom, driven by excess savings, deficit spending, and vaccinations, potentially lasting into 2023. However, he warns that high stock valuations may not justify the rising US debt, and inflation could lead to aggressive interest rate hikes, potentially causing a recession. Dimon also argues that banks are playing a smaller role in the financial system due to competition from fintech companies and big tech firms, and that tougher regulation of big banks may not be worth it.

images.alt_text: The annual letter to shareholders by JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon was published early Wednesday. The letter, which is widely read on Wall Street, is not just an overview of the bank's business but also covers Mr Dimon's thoughts on everything from leadership lessons to public policy prescriptions.

site_title: Crushing poll defeats for South Korea's ruling party
summary: South Korea's ruling Democratic Party suffered crushing defeats in local elections, with conservative opposition candidates winning mayoral seats in Seoul and Busan. The People Power Party's Oh Se Hoon won Seoul by 57.5% to 39.2%, and the conservative candidate in Busan by 62.7% to 34.4%. The results are seen as a significant barometer of public opinion ahead of the 2022 presidential election, which may further erode the Democratic Party's struggling ratings. The party's approval ratings have plummeted to 32%, with 58% disapproving of Moon Jae-in's job performance.

site_title: Over 50% of APAC companies likely to issue social bonds in the next year: survey
summary: Over 50% of Asia-Pacific companies are expected to issue social bonds in the next year, with employee welfare as a top priority, according to a survey by ING. Companies in APAC and North America are more likely to issue social bonds than their European counterparts. The survey also found that 80% of companies across each region expect new government sustainability policies to intensify action on improving access to healthcare. Despite short-term momentum on social issues, investors prioritize more ambitious environmental targets over externally-focused social targets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.42% and the Topix index 0.45%. Investors sidestepped active trading due to a lack of fresh clues. The mixed close on Wall Street also contributed to the downward trend.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare receives letter of demand for S$10.7m
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare received a letter of demand for S$10.7 million from Value Monetization III, following a favorable court judgment in a suit against Crest entities. The company had received nearly S$13.1 million from the entities, which included a S$12.6 million judgment debt, and had previously won a court case in which it was determined that Crest entities were jointly and severally liable. OUELH's shares were trading flat after the announcement, with the company advising its legal counsel to refute VM III's demand.

site_title: States back in the pilot's seat after Europe airline bailouts
summary: Air France-KLM, along with several European airlines, has received billions of euros in government aid to cope with the pandemic. The latest bailout, worth 4 billion euros, will see the French government re-emerge as the airline's largest shareholder, holding up to 30% stake. This trend is expected to continue, with other airlines such as Deutsche Lufthansa, Alitalia, SAS, and TAP Air Portugal receiving similar aid. The EU has attached strict conditions to the aid, but some airlines, like Ryanair, have criticized the move, arguing it distorts the market and creates an unfair advantage.

images.alt_text: Air France-KLM and other airlines including Germany's Deutsche Lufthansa AG and Alitalia SpA will see a bigger state presence following aid to cope with one of the industry's worst crises.

site_title: Ex-VP Pence to pen memoir ahead of 2024 race: publisher
summary: Mike Pence, a conservative Republican, has signed a two-book deal worth at least $3 million with Simon & Schuster to write an autobiography about his time as US Vice President in the Trump administration. The memoir, set to be published in 2023, will cover his faith and public service, including his time as a congressman, governor of Indiana, and Vice President. Pence's deal comes ahead of a potential 2024 presidential run, as he is widely believed to be considering a candidacy.

site_title: Uber dangles higher pay to lure US drivers back, but warns it will not last
summary: Uber is offering higher pay to US drivers as trip demand temporarily outstrips driver supply, but warned the increase won't last. The company invested $250 million to boost driver earnings and offers payment guarantees. Drivers in top-25 markets are earning an average of $36 per hour, with some seeing median hourly earnings 25-75% higher than pre-pandemic levels. The increase comes as more US states lift lockdown restrictions and vaccination rates increase, but ride-hail drivers have been slow to return due to safety concerns and sluggish demand.

site_title: Lendlease appoints new Asia chief executive based in Singapore
summary: Lendlease appoints Justin Gabbani as its Asia chief executive, effective June 1, based in Singapore, replacing Tony Lombardo. Gabbani, who was Lendlease's CFO for Asia, will oversee significant opportunities across the region. Outgoing group CEO Steve McCann will retire from the board on May 31 after a 16-year career with the group. Deborah Yates has also been appointed as the company's chief people officer, starting July 1.

site_title: The ulti-mutt pet? Chinese tech company develops robo-dogs
summary: A Chinese tech company, Weilan, has developed the AlphaDog, a robotic response to the growing demand for pets and technology. The high-tech hound uses sensors and AI technology to "hear" and "see" its environment, and can be taken for walks. It moves at a speed of almost 15 kmh and can predict friction and adjust its stride frequency. The robot's creators plan to add features such as barking and human voices for conversations, and are exploring applications for the visually impaired. Over 1,800 AlphaDogs have sold in the first month, with a hefty price tag of 16,000 yuan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.85 points, or 0.12%, to 1,602.44. Volume reached 437.24 million lots worth RM212.59 million. Gainers outpaced losers 232 to 188. This follows a broader Asia-Pacific market trend, where traders are bracing for US-EU trade talks and US tariff threats, but still managing to edge towards fresh records.

site_title: Twitch to boot users for transgressions elsewhere
summary: Twitch, a live video streaming service, announced it will ban users for abusive or violent behavior in the real world or on other online platforms. The service will suspend users for up to an indefinite period for severe offenses, including violent extremism, hate group membership, and threats of mass violence. The decision aims to protect the Twitch community from safety risks. Users who have committed past offenses and have undergone rehabilitation may be spared a ban if they complete a trusted rehabilitation process.

site_title: Manhattan's Watson Hotel sells for US$175m as market thaws
summary: Manhattan's 600-room Watson Hotel has been sold for $175 million to Yellowstone Real Estate Investments, marking one of the largest lodging transactions since the COVID-19 pandemic. The sale price tops the $150 million paid for the Surrey Hotel and comes as the US market shows signs of recovery, with accelerating vaccination campaigns and expected increases in leisure and corporate travel. Yellowstone plans to evaluate potential redevelopment options for the property, which has been viewed as a potential site for offices or apartments.

site_title: Tax break extension revives UK housing market boom: RICS
summary: The UK housing market has revived after the extension of a tax break for property purchases, according to a survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. The monthly gauge of house prices rose to +59 in March from +52 in February. This marks a rebound from fading activity before the planned expiry of the temporary cut to property purchase tax, known as stamp duty, at the end of March. The extension of the tax break is expected to boost demand for housing.

site_title: Global value chains still here, but region must integrate
summary: Asean+3 region remains highly attractive for global value chains, with the region's middle class expanding and labor up-skilling to the digital economy. Despite supply chain reshuffling anticipated, firms are not moving as quickly as expected, with key factors including relationships with suppliers, costs of switching locations, and government incentives. The importance of Asean integration was emphasized, with experts calling for the region to get its act together and comply with economic agreements. Globalization is seen as a means to tackle vulnerabilities of global value chains, and digitalization is highlighted as a necessity for firms to improve risk management and reduce logistical bottlenecks.

site_title: IMF chief worried about middle-income countries, urges expanded definition of 'vulnerable'
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva expressed concerns about middle-income countries hit hard by the pandemic, urging the expansion of a broader definition of 'vulnerable' countries. The IMF's current lending limits to only the poorest countries are seen as inadequate. The G-20 finance officials backed a $650 billion expansion of the IMF's emergency reserves, which richer members can loan to help poor countries. Georgieva plans to discuss a potential expansion of concessional financing terms to middle-income countries and a broader definition of 'vulnerability' beyond income levels.

site_title: UOB sells US$1.5b in sustainability bonds in a Singapore first
summary: UOB priced a dual tranche of sustainability bonds, raising US$1.5 billion in its first sustainability bond offering from Singapore. The bonds, priced at 1.25% and 2% per annum, were oversubscribed with a final orderbook of US$2.75 billion. Sustainability-focused investors contributed 60% to the final orderbook, marking a significant participation from investors in the Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the US. This is the first dual tranche senior and Tier 2 instrument in sustainability format globally from a bank issuer.

images.alt_text: UOB has priced a dual tranche of senior notes at 1.25 per cent and Tier 2 subordinated notes at 2 per cent per annum. The bank raised US$1.5 billion, with a final orderbook of US$2.75 billion.

site_title: Press freedom in Macau's gambling hub under spotlight as China ramps up scrutiny
summary: Macau's Portuguese and English media, particularly the public broadcaster TDM, have faced scrutiny from China's authorities, with the introduction of new editorial rules requiring journalists to promote "patriotism, respect and love" for mainland China. At least six journalists have resigned since the rules were announced, amid concerns over press freedom and censorship. The move is seen as a response to the government's increasing control over Hong Kong's media, and reflects Beijing's growing pressure on Macau to conform to its "one country, two systems" policy.

site_title: Why world faces greater political risk in post-crisis era
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank's annual Spring meetings coincide with a complex, "multi-speed" global recovery from the pandemic, with economic fortunes diverging due to differential vaccine rates. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warns of increased macroeconomic instability, polarisation, and social unrest, echoing the aftermath of the 2007-08 international financial crisis. She calls for governments to invest in fiscal and monetary stimulus to mitigate the downturn, which could have been three times worse without it. The IMF estimates that $3 trillion in reforms could help emerging markets, while faster progress in ending the health crisis could add $9 trillion to global GDP by 2025.

site_title: Westpac sued over consumer credit insurance sales
summary: Australia's corporate regulator has filed a civil lawsuit against Westpac Banking Corp, alleging the lender sold consumer credit insurance to customers who had not agreed to buy it. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) conducted a review of 11 banks from 2018 to 2019, finding high-pressure selling methods and policies sold to ineligible customers. This is part of a broader investigation into consumer credit insurance sales.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's subsidiary CES Capital Holdings sold shophouses for nearly S$10.7 million. Creative Technology plans to reduce its share capital by US$217.7 million to write off accumulated losses and restructure finances. HC Surgical Specialists' appeal to sue its CEO was dismissed by the Court of Appeal, with the court finding that the woman had a vendetta and lacked good faith.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pause near record high, UK outperforms
summary: European stocks closed near record highs, edging 0.1% lower, while UK equities outperformed due to a weaker pound. Healthcare shares fell 0.8%, while exporter-heavy FTSE 100 gained 0.9%. Economists expect strong global recovery driven by vaccines and stimulus measures, with profits for Stoxx 600 companies expected to jump 47.4% in Q1.

site_title: Biden willing to negotiate on corporate taxes, but 'sick and tired' of non-payers
summary: President Joe Biden is open to negotiating corporate tax rates for his $2 trillion infrastructure plan, but emphasizes the need for companies to pay a significant share of the bill. The plan would increase the corporate tax rate to 28% from 21%, with additional levies on overseas earnings and a new minimum tax on profits. Despite opposition from Republicans and corporations, Biden argues that the US must invest in infrastructure to maintain its global leadership and avoid falling behind China.

images.alt_text: While Malaysia, like many other countries in South-east Asia and elsewhere, are enthusiastic that "America is back" - primarily because the Biden administration is perceived to be more credible and promises more room for collaboration on key issues - the think-tank warned that collaboration between the two countries is likely to be constrained by competing priorities and persistent gaps on multiple fronts.

site_title: Myanmar security forces kill 15 protesters; junta leader says opposition aims to 'destroy' country
summary: Myanmar security forces killed at least 15 protesters on Wednesday, with dozens wounded, in the latest crackdown on opposition to the ruling military junta. Senior General Min Aung Hlaing said the civil disobedience movement aims to "destroy" the country, but a London-based research group claims the military is losing control. The violence has resulted in the deaths of at least 600 civilians since the coup on February 1, with nationwide protests and strikes persisting. The military is now focusing its crackdown on rural areas, and Western sanctions are unlikely to succeed in restoring democracy.

site_title: Singtel unit prices S$1b subordinated perps at 3.3%
summary: Singtel announced the pricing of its S$1 billion subordinated perpetual securities, attracting S$2.1 billion in demand from investors. The bonds will have an initial rate of 3.3% per annum, with a step-up of 25 basis points in 2031 and 75 basis points in 2051. The deal, led by DBS, HSBC, OCBC, and Standard Chartered, marks the first time such a structure has been used in the SGD bond market, with Singtel's order book closed after receiving interest from a wide range of high-quality investors.

images.alt_text: Singtel on Thursday announced that its wholly-owned subsidiary Singtel Group Treasury had priced S$1 billion of subordinated perpetual securities on April 7.

site_title: Federal Reserve members see US inflation under control, but more express concern
summary: US Federal Reserve members view inflation as stable, but some express concern it may increase due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on supply and demand. The Fed's benchmark lending rate remains at zero, and the economy's recovery is considered incomplete. Despite a faster-than-expected rebound, labour force participation remains low, and concerns about workers' health and childcare responsibilities persist. The Fed warns that the path ahead is uncertain, with the pandemic posing significant risks to the outlook.

site_title: Oil up on global economic recovery, but hefty US fuel stocks weigh
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures settling at $63.16 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $59.77 a barrel, both up 0.7%. The gains were capped by rising petrol inventories and concerns about new coronavirus outbreaks weakening fuel demand. The Federal Reserve's minutes and the International Monetary Fund's forecast of 6% global growth also supported prices. However, rising Covid-19 cases in the Americas and potential increases in global crude supplies from Iran also weighed on the market.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Singtel, Chip Eng Seng, HC Surgical, OUELH, Creative Tech
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies saw notable developments on Thursday. UOB priced its sustainability bond, raising US$1.5 billion. Singtel priced S$1 billion of subordinated perpetual securities, with an oversubscription of S$2.1 billion. Chip Eng Seng sold shophouses for nearly S$24.2 million. HC Surgical's appeal to sue its CEO was dismissed by the Court of Appeal. OUELH received a letter of demand for S$10.7 million and Creative Technology announced plans to reduce its share capital to write off accumulated losses. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Growing interest in Raffles Medical as market factors in recovery
summary: Raffles Medical Group's shares reached a new 52-week high of S$1.19 on April 7, 2021, as market sentiment factors in a recovery in its operations and revenue. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal of RHB upgraded the company to a "buy" from "neutral" with a target price of S$1.29, expecting recurring net profit to grow 25% annually in 2021 and 2022. Jaiswal forecasts breakeven in earnings before interest and taxes for the group's China hospitals within 3-4 years.

site_title: Policyholders must come first in insurer-vs-doctor Shield debate
summary: The use of Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) medical panels has sparked a debate between insurers and doctors over the balance between fees and patient options. Stakeholders are urged to work together to raise transparency and efficiency, benefiting consumers. Greater transparency would allow insurers to provide policyholders with better information on doctors' quality and track records, and access to pricing mechanisms and claims processing times. A comprehensive app could facilitate patient choice and confidence in finding the right doctor. Full transparency would require cooperation from all parties, including doctors, pharmaceuticals, and regulators.

site_title: SoHo Advisors launching event to match US-listed SPACs with Asia-Pacific targets
summary: SoHo Advisors, a Singapore-based fintech investment bank, is launching a virtual event to connect US-listed special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) with target companies in the Asia-Pacific. The event, scheduled for May 4, will connect 10 regional targets with 10 US-listed SPAC sponsors, with at least $200 million each. The event aims to accelerate the SPAC conversation and help regional top private companies evaluate the viability of a SPAC process.

site_title: Mural art designs to recognise work of maritime personnel
summary: Senior Minister Chee Hong Tat unveiled two murals at PSA and Jurong Port in Singapore to thank seafarers, port workers, and other frontline maritime personnel for their hard work during the Covid-19 pandemic. The murals, designed by local artist Jaxton Su, highlight the vital role of these personnel in ensuring international trade and supply flow remained uninterrupted. As part of the MaritimeSG initiative, a face mask design by Chee also promotes appreciation for the maritime community while supporting ocean waste removal. The murals and masks aim to show gratitude and support for the maritime community's efforts.

site_title: Will office assets continue to pique investor interest?
summary: The office market in Singapore has seen a slump in office prices in the Central Area, outpacing the decline in rents, likely due to pandemic-linked uncertainties. The National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies reported a 10.8% year-on-year drop in office prices, compared to a 9% decline in rents. This shift may prompt companies to cut their physical footprint and turn to co-working spaces, while the pandemic has accelerated trends such as ghost kitchens and the green economy, potentially diverting interest away from traditional office assets.

site_title: Facebook does not plan to notify half billion users affected by data leak
summary: Facebook will not notify the 530 million users affected by a data leak, which occurred before 2019, due to concerns about the effectiveness of notifications and the lack of control over the issue. The data, including phone numbers and profile details, was obtained by "malicious actors" through a vulnerability in Facebook's contact syncing tool. Facebook claims the data does not include sensitive information, but experts warn it could be used for hacking or other abuses. The company has plugged the hole and is in contact with regulators, including Ireland's Data Protection Commission.

site_title: US: S&P 500 edges to record as Federal Reserve eyes inflation risk
summary: The S&P 500 edged to a record high on Wednesday, while the Nasdaq dipped, amid concerns over inflation. US President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan and calls for a global minimum corporate tax sparked market activity. Federal Reserve minutes showed most policy makers view inflation as stable, despite some concerns. Individual companies like JPMorgan Chase and Carnival rose after reporting strong quarterly performance, with Carnival seeing a 90% increase in cruise booking volumes.

site_title: Digitalisation of banks in Asean holds allure, but...
summary: Digital banking in ASEAN is gaining momentum, with Singapore leading the way in awarding licenses to four digital banks. However, regulatory challenges persist, particularly regarding interconnected activities across jurisdictions and the impact of Big Tech and fintechs on the market. Despite progress towards financial development, a significant portion of the population remains unbanked in countries such as Cambodia, Vietnam, and the Philippines. Regulators must balance the benefits of digital banking, including increased competition and financial inclusion, with the need for careful oversight to preserve market competition, data privacy, and financial stability.

site_title: World No. 1 Johnson eyes joining the US Masters elite list
summary: World No. 1 golfer Dustin Johnson is aiming to join the elite list of players who have won the US Masters in consecutive fashion, following his victory at the 2020 tournament. Johnson, who feels his game is in "pretty good shape," recently expressed satisfaction with the conditions at Augusta National Golf Club, where he will compete in the 2021 edition of the Major. Despite a recent disappointing finish at the Players Championship, Johnson remains confident and is not overly concerned about holding onto his title, saying it "doesn't really make a difference" to him.

site_title: MINDS clinic fills healthcare gaps for the intellectually disabled
summary: MINDS clinic in Singapore provides healthcare services to intellectually disabled individuals, filling gaps in specialist care. The clinic, funded by OCBC Bank, offers health screenings, medical consultations, and referrals to medical practitioners. Since its establishment in 2017, 750 beneficiaries have undergone health screenings, and the clinic has helped identify and address issues such as hypertension, diabetes, and vision impairment. The clinic's health passports, which detail beneficiaries' medical history and needs, have improved diagnosis and treatment outcomes. The clinic aims to provide person-centered, integrated healthcare management and future care planning for intellectually disabled individuals.

site_title: Fertile grounds in Asia for private equity investments in healthcare
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated changes in the healthcare sector in Asia, creating opportunities for private equity investments. Industry experts note that digital innovation and partnerships between pharmaceutical companies, healthcare systems, and insurance providers are key to addressing the pandemic's impact. The Asia-Pacific region saw a significant rise in healthcare private equity deals, with a 21% increase in global deals and a 156% increase in Asia-Pacific deals in 2020. Strong growth in the biopharma sector fueled much of the rise, with China accounting for over 60% of deals in the region.

site_title: Samsung, LG forecast 40% leap in Q1 operating profits
summary: South Korea's two largest electronics firms, Samsung and LG, forecast a 40% leap in Q1 operating profits, driven by a surge in demand for semiconductors and home appliances due to the COVID-19 work-from-home trend. Samsung Electronics expects 9.3 trillion won in operating profits, up 44.2% from last year, while LG Electronics forecasts a 39.2% increase to 1.5 trillion won. The companies' sales are expected to reach record highs, with Samsung's smartphone business leading the way.

site_title: Tiger Woods crash due to 'unsafe' driving speed up to 140 kmh: sheriff
summary: Tiger Woods was driving at nearly double the speed limit when he crashed in California in February, according to Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva. Woods's SUV was traveling up to 140 kmh before it crashed, leaving him with a shattered right leg. There were no signs of impairment or distracted driving, and investigators found no evidence of intoxication. Woods may have accidentally hit the accelerator while trying to press the brakes, but he does not recall the incident. He is recovering at home in Florida after undergoing hours of surgery.

site_title: Swiss watchmakers go digital to show off new products, revive sales
summary: Swiss luxury watchmakers are launching an all-digital Watches & Wonders event to showcase their latest products and revive sales hit by the coronavirus crisis. Despite being traditionally offline sellers, the success of online platforms for pre-owned watches has shown the possibility of selling luxury timepieces online. The event aims to capitalize on this trend and boost sales in the luxury watch market.

site_title: Restrictive terms, poor outcomes hobble voucher scheme for tourism sector
summary: The SingapoRediscovers Vouchers (SRV) scheme, a government initiative to boost local spending in the tourism sector, has been met with criticism due to restrictive terms and poor outcomes. Over 2 million eligible adults have not redeemed their vouchers, with many citing the need to top up cash for food and beverage expenses and bad experiences with participating merchants. Despite the low take-up, the Ministry of Trade and Industry has no plans to extend the deadline, citing a reasonable 25% redemption rate, which is expected to increase to 50% by the June school holidays.

site_title: GM plans to start making Silverado electric pick-up truck in 2022
summary: General Motors plans to start production of the Chevrolet Silverado electric pick-up truck at its Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant in late 2022, with the vehicle expected to go on sale in early 2023 as a 2024 model. The company's investment in electric vehicles is part of its projected spending of $9 billion to $10 billion this year, with the electric Silverado offering a range of over 640km on a full charge. The Detroit-Hamtramck plant is also expected to build other full-size electric trucks and sport utility vehicles, including the GMC Hummer electric sport utility vehicle.

site_title: Greenback holds near two-week lows
summary: The US dollar slipped near two-week lows on Wednesday, stabilizing US bond yields and awaiting the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes for market guidance. Despite a strong rally in the previous quarter, the dollar has softened due to decreasing bond yields and global risk appetite. The 10-year US Treasury yield is currently at 1.6579%, down from its peak in March. Market participants are waiting for the Fed meeting minutes, which may signal a potential 25 basis point hike in December 2022, and could impact the dollar's future path.

site_title: Maxwell House reserve price lowered to S$268m in second bid at collective sale
summary: Singapore's Maxwell House, a 13-storey commercial building, is up for collective sale with a new reserve price of S$268 million, down from S$295 million in its first launch. The 41,799 sq ft site is zoned for commercial use and has a 99-year leasehold tenure. The building's location near Tanjong Pagar and Chinatown is expected to be enhanced by the upcoming Maxwell Mass Rapid Transit station. A rezoning to a plot ratio of 5.6 and a GFA of 234,077 sq ft could result in a 30% uplift in plot ratio.

site_title: M&A, in the midst of a crisis, can be deployed to boost growth
summary: Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) can boost growth during economic crises, taking advantage of diminished valuations and low interest rates. Despite a decline in M&A activity in 2020, companies are now seeing a resurgence with more megadeals. A Harvard Business Review study found that companies that made significant acquisitions during a downturn outperformed those that did not. Examples include Heineken's acquisition of Scottish and Newcastle and Thomson's purchase of Reuters, which resulted in cost savings. Analysts see the recent megadeals, such as Salesforce's acquisition of Slack, as opportunities for growth rather than opportunistic purchases.

site_title: On the obscured ESG flows in Asia
summary: Deutsche Bank's Kamran Khan warns that ESG capital flowing into Asia may be underreported due to investments originating from one continent and being deployed in another. He cites his bank's 46 billion euros in sustainable financing and ESG investment, which appears too low due to many deals being booked in Europe and North America. Khan emphasizes the importance of establishing high standards of ESG transactions and setting benchmarks, rather than focusing on numerical volumes. He notes that Asia is likely a top recipient of ESG capital, particularly with multinational companies sourcing and selling to the region, and that governments in the Asia-Pacific are placing a higher priority on ESG and sustainability.

site_title: SGX's proposals on SPAC listings set tone for a more sustainable scheme
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a consultation on special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), proposing rules to improve the structure and reduce risks. The proposed rules include minimum market capitalization, limiting redemptions to dissenting shareholders, and minimum sponsor equity participation. These measures aim to encourage quality targets and long-term investors, promoting a more sustainable future for SPACs. The proposals follow growing scrutiny of SPACs in the US, where the Securities and Exchange Commission has warned investors against investing in SPACs with celebrity involvement.

site_title: Telemedicine firm WhiteCoat raises S$10.8m in venture funding
summary: Singapore-based telemedicine firm WhiteCoat has raised S$10.8 million in Series A funding led by the GEC-KIP Technology and Innovation fund. The investment aims to further its lead in the Singapore telemedicine space and bolster its expansion into South-east Asian markets. With the funding, WhiteCoat plans to enhance its full-stack proprietary telemedicine platform, expand its suite of remote healthcare services, and drive growth despite the COVID-19 health crisis, which has seen revenues rise eight times and the number of consultations surge seven times.

site_title: 'Millionaires tax' threat has some NY bankers, managers eyeing exits
summary: New York's proposed "millionaires tax" of up to 15.73% on top earners is prompting some bankers and fund managers to consider exits, with some already looking for apartments in Florida or planning to move their entire firms out of the city. The tax proposal, which aims to increase combined state and city taxes for those earning over $1 million, is seen as a significant incentive for wealthy individuals to relocate. Large financial companies have already begun moving staff out of New York, and some are exploring options to relocate their firms as well.

site_title: Will the cyclical recovery boom last?
summary: The global economy is experiencing a cyclical recovery boom, with indicators such as the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) PMI reaching historic highs in various countries. The US, Canada, the UK, and continental European countries have seen strong PMI figures, while South Korea's export data and Belgium's business-confidence survey also point to a robust economic expansion. However, the question remains whether this boom will last, as governments and central banks may start to tighten monetary and fiscal conditions, and financial markets remain unpredictable. The current recovery may benefit median households more than people think, but its sustainability depends on a complex combination of factors.

site_title: Tencent's top holder Prosus to sell up to US$14.6b stake
summary: Prosus NV, a major shareholder of Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings, plans to sell up to $14.6 billion worth of shares in the company, reducing its stake to nearly 29%. The sale, set at a discount to the last trading price, will boost Prosus's war chest for new e-commerce deals amid the coronavirus pandemic's surge in online demand. The move gives Prosus a larger war chest to potentially secure a mega deal, after missing out on two high-profile takeovers in the past year.

site_title: Masters venue Augusta is tricky, but there have been wonder shots
summary: US Masters is known for miraculous shots, with Tiger Woods' precision chip in 2005, Jon Rahm's shot off water in 2020, and Phil Mickelson's 189-meter shot through a 1.2-meter gap in 2010. This year's tournament features Bryson DeChambeau, who boasts unmatched power and distance, and Justin Thomas, who is committed to his goals and has a strong mental game. Other notable golfers include Brooks Koepka, Jordan Spieth, and Rory McIlroy. The Masters, with its unique Augusta course, is expected to produce more wonder shots, with 90-100 golfers competing in the prestigious tournament.

site_title: The roots of the EU's vaccine debacle
summary: The European Union's vaccine rollout has been marred by inefficiency, with less than 15% of the population receiving at least one dose, compared to 31% in the US and 45% in the UK. The EU's failure can be attributed to flawed negotiations with pharmaceutical companies, which included non-binding contracts and lack of penalties for missing deadlines. The EU's structure, with multiple actors involved in decision-making, has hindered accountability and nimble executive action, leading to prolonged vaccine shortages and high human and economic costs.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia shareholders may benefit from secondary listing of diesel engine unit
summary: Hong Leong Asia's shares have risen 20% this year, reaching a 52-week high, with analysts seeing potential for further gains. CGS-CIMB initiated coverage on the conglomerate, recommending an "add" call and a target price of S$1.18. The brokerage believes investors are undervaluing HLA's building materials segment while overpaying for its diesel engine business, which is listed in New York. A potential secondary listing of China Yuchai in Hong Kong or China could re-rate HLA, with a target price of S$1.33.

site_title: GIC-backed Trax secures US$640m in Series E funding led by Softbank Vision Fund 2 and BlackRock
summary: Trax, a retail analytics firm backed by Singapore's GIC, has secured US$640 million in Series E funding led by Softbank Vision Fund 2 and BlackRock. The round saw participation from new investors, including the Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System and Sony Innovation Fund. Trax will use the funds to invest in its team, extend market leadership, and drive growth. The company specializes in cloud technology and AI to help consumer-packaged goods companies and grocery retailers make data-driven decisions.

site_title: The Design Collective
summary: Seven top architects, known as the Dalvey Seven, collaborated on designing seven exclusive Good Class Bungalows in a massive plot in Dalvey Estate, Singapore. Each architect brought their unique design ethos to the project, showcasing their individual styles. Meanwhile, public artworks created by artists with a message of hope are scattered across Singapore, offering a respite from pandemic stress. The TAG Heuer Aquaracer watch brand has launched a new version, and the Clan Hotel now features the Asian fusion restaurant Qin by Tung Lok.

site_title: Yellen proposes wide-ranging corporate tax changes to pay for infrastructure
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen proposed a wide-ranging corporate tax hike plan to pay for President Joe Biden's infrastructure investment proposal, aiming to raise $2.5 trillion in new revenues over 15 years. The plan includes a 21% global minimum corporate tax rate and a 15% minimum tax on "booked" income, targeting big US companies that use complex tax strategies to reduce their federal tax liabilities. The plan aims to end tax breaks for the fossil fuel industry and introduce new clean energy tax incentives.

site_title: BOJ may deploy new tool to stimulate economy
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) may deploy a new tool, an "interest scheme to promote lending", to stimulate the economy. The scheme aims to offset the negative rate charge on banks and incentivize lending for specific sectors, such as green investment. The BOJ has been studying the idea internally for years and may use it as a future possibility to pump money to areas in need and respond to government pressure. The move underscores the BOJ's growing reliance on fiscal policy to spur growth in an economy hit by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Justin Thomas: I want to be somebody whom kids look up to
summary: Golf star Justin Thomas expresses his desire to be a role model for kids, stating that his relationship with Rolex has been a "tremendous" one, with the brand's emphasis on excellence resonating with him. Thomas, who has been sponsored by Rolex since 2013, has a deep appreciation for the brand's watches, including a Datejust and Cosmograph Daytona. He credits his love for golf to his father, a golf pro, and cites Tiger Woods as a major inspiration throughout his career. Thomas aims to establish a foundation to impact kids and become a positive ambassador for the sport.

site_title: Beijing is colour-coding buildings to indicate vaccination rates
summary: Beijing is colour-coding buildings in its financial district to indicate vaccination rates, aiming to accelerate the city's immunisation roll-out amid government pressure. Buildings with over 80% vaccinated workers display green signs, while yellow and red signs indicate lower vaccination rates. On-site immunisation drives have been organized, and officials face pressure to meet the government's goal of vaccinating 40% of the population by June.

images.alt_text: Beijing's financial district is leading the campaign to "green code" its buildings - putting up green circular signs that indicate more than 80% of those working in the building have been vaccinated.

site_title: Sole Covid-19 community case is foreign domestic worker
summary: A 40-year-old foreign domestic worker from Myanmar is Singapore's sole new community Covid-19 case, reported on April 7. She tested negative during her stay-home notice and had been identified as a close contact of another case during a flight to Singapore. After developing symptoms, she tested positive and was warded at a hospital. Her serological test result is positive, indicating a past infection, and public health actions are being taken as a precautionary measure. This marks a decrease in community cases, with only two new cases reported in the past week.

site_title: French winemakers set candles and straw ablaze to save vines from frost
summary: French winemakers in Chablis, Burgundy, and Bordeaux lit candles and burned straw to protect their vineyards from sharp spring frosts, with temperatures plummeting to -5 degree Celsius. The move aims to shield shoots from damage, but the forecast of more cold nights raises concerns of serious damage and lost production. Winemakers also used heaters, wind towers, and smokescreens to mitigate the damage, with some fearing the worst due to past experiences with severe cold snaps in April 2017 and 2019.

site_title: Parcel locker network: private or government-owned?
summary: Singapore's nationwide parcel locker network is set to be owned and operated by the government entity Pick Network, with 1,000 locker stations expected in HDB estates, transport nodes, and community centers by end-2021. The decision not to tender for a private-sector operator has raised questions about the impact on market competitiveness, with some industry watchers suggesting a public-private partnership could be more beneficial. The government's intention is to provide a neutral operator to ensure open and non-discriminatory access, while also deploying the network expeditiously to realise productivity gains.

site_title: Jordan king says palace crisis 'is over'
summary: Jordan's King Abdullah stated that the palace crisis, sparked by an alleged plot involving his half-brother Prince Hamzah, has been resolved. In an address, King Abdullah assured the nation that the "sedition has been nipped in the bud" and that the country's stability remains intact. The crisis, which was the worst in decades, was described by the king as "the most painful" for him personally.

site_title: Right time for tourism fund boost, as Singapore gears up for global rebound, say watchers
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board has set aside S$848.5 million, including a fresh S$68.5 million injection, to revive the tourism sector's fortunes. The fund aims to support quality tourism enterprises and capitalize on emerging trends such as wellness, sustainability, and technology. The board plans to increase its marketing efforts globally, with initiatives including the Tourism Technology Transformation Cube and a capability development roadmap. Industry experts believe the funding and strategy are timely, but also note that the private sector must be convinced of the sustainability and potential for returns.

site_title: UK to restrict AstraZeneca to over 30s on blood-clot link
summary: The UK's Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency has advised not using AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine on those under 30 due to a possible link with rare blood clots in the brain. Despite this, the agency and European Medicines Agency agree that the vaccine's benefits outweigh the risks. The warning comes amid increasing public wariness, with patients canceling appointments. The European Union's vaccination campaign may be threatened, but officials emphasize the vaccine's effectiveness in preventing severe disease and saving lives.

site_title: Warhol a lame copier? Judges who said so are sadly mistaken
summary: A federal appeals court in New York City ruled that Andy Warhol's use of Lynn Goldsmith's 1981 photo of Prince in his 1984 silk-screen was not "transformative" enough to be considered fair use under copyright law. The court's decision contradicts the landmark 1964 Brillo Boxes case, where Warhol's use of the boxes was deemed transformative and thus eligible for fair use. The ruling has sparked criticism from art critics and philosophers, who argue that the court's definition of transformation is too narrow and undermines the creative freedom of artists who use appropriation as a key technique.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on foreign buying for fifth straight session
summary: South Korean stocks rose for a fifth straight session on Wednesday, driven by strong foreign buying expectations of an economic recovery and stabilizing US bond yields. The Kospi index closed up 10.33 points, or 0.33%, at 3,137.41. Foreign investors purchased 318.7 billion won worth of shares on the main board, with the won strengthening and benchmark bond yields falling. Despite concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic, IMF forecasts global growth to reach 6% this year.

site_title: Airline leader blasts 'monopoly' fee hikes, citing Heathrow
summary: IATA's new head, Willie Walsh, vows "strong and aggressive" resistance to suppliers and airports, including Heathrow, attempting to cover pandemic losses by raising charges. Walsh criticizes airports like Heathrow for seeking to pass on costs, particularly for a third runway, and accuses them of acting as monopolies. He also downplays concerns over aircraft market consolidation, citing the benefits of sale-and-leaseback deals. Heathrow claims its charges have fallen by a quarter, despite increased customer satisfaction, and urges Walsh to work together to decarbonize global aviation.

site_title: Taiwan threatens to fight to the end as China sends more jets into defence zone
summary: China sent 15 aircraft, including 12 fighters, into Taiwan's air defense zone, prompting Taiwan's foreign minister to warn that it would fight to the end if attacked. Taiwan's air force intercepted and warned the Chinese away, while the US expressed concern about the risk of conflict and said its commitment to Taiwan is "rock solid." Taiwan plans to conduct military exercises to improve its defense capabilities, amid a stepped-up show of force by China.

site_title: Malaysia says South Korean and Japanese firms to invest RM16.05b
summary: Malaysia secured RM16.05 billion in potential investments from South Korean and Japanese firms, with South Korean companies committing RM7.3 billion and Japanese companies agreeing to invest RM8.75 billion. The investments include a RM1 billion glass fibre production plant from Nippon Electric Glass. The deals aim to boost foreign direct investment in Malaysia, which dropped 68% in 2020, with the country hoping to attract more investments this year.

site_title: US trade deficit widened to record US$71.1b in February
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a record $71.1 billion in February, surpassing the median estimate of $70.5 billion. Imports increased 0.7% to $258.3 billion, while exports fell 2.6% to $187.3 billion. The merchandise-trade deficit rose 3% to $88 billion, with the nation's surplus in services trade falling to $16.9 billion, the smallest since 2012. Severe winter weather and a global semiconductor shortage contributed to the increase in imports and decrease in exports.

site_title: Thailand braced for infections spike after detecting UK Covid-19 variant
summary: Thailand has detected at least 24 cases of the highly contagious UK Covid-19 variant B.1.1.7, with nearly 200 entertainment venues in Bangkok closed for two weeks. The variant is 1.7 times faster spreading than usual, and Thailand has seen a spike in infections, with 334 new cases reported on Wednesday. Thai authorities are preparing field hospitals in anticipation of a potential spike in infections, and the country is just a week away from a major holiday period.

site_title: Climate protesters break windows at Barclays London HQ, seven arrested
summary: Climate protesters from the Extinction Rebellion group broke windows at Barclays London HQ on April 7, 2021, using hammers and pasting "In Case of Climate Emergency Break Glass" on the building. Seven people were arrested. The action was part of the group's "Money Rebellion" against the capitalist system's role in climate change.

site_title: Several blasts reported in Myanmar's commercial capital; factory set alight
summary: A series of small blasts hit Myanmar's commercial capital Yangon, targeting government buildings, a military hospital, and a shopping mall. A Chinese-owned factory was set on fire, with no casualties reported. Activists also set fire to the Chinese flag in a neighbourhood. The blasts and fire were attributed to "handmade 'sound bombs' or fireworks" by the US Embassy. The incident occurred amidst the ongoing civil unrest and military crackdown in Myanmar, with at least 581 people killed and 3,500 arrested since the coup.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit to sell 2 shophouses in Tanjong Pagar for S$10.7m
summary: Chip Eng Seng's subsidiary CES Capital Holdings is selling two conservation shophouses in Tanjong Pagar for S$10.7 million and three shophouses in Geylang Road for S$13.5 million. The properties, acquired in 1988 and 1996, generate stable rental income but do not contribute significantly to the company's revenue and profitability. The disposals are part of the group's asset management strategy to divest non-strategic assets. The net proceeds will be used for working capital or to pursue opportunities with better upside potential.

site_title: Family businesses in Singapore lagging in digital transformation: poll
summary: A survey by PwC found that family businesses in Singapore lag behind globally in digital transformation, with only 29% confident in their digital capabilities. High costs, inadequate internal infrastructure, and skill shortages are cited as major concerns. Despite optimism about growth in 2022, sustainability remains a low priority, with only 25% of businesses focusing on green efforts. The survey also highlights concerns about succession planning, with only slightly more than a quarter having documented a plan.

site_title: G-20 to boost IMF war chest by US$650b amid pandemic: draft
summary: G-20 nations agreed to boost the International Monetary Fund's war chest by $650 billion to aid vulnerable countries affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The draft communique also recommitments to fighting protectionism and tackling climate change, and extends debt-servicing suspension for vulnerable countries until the end of 2021.

site_title: IMF says controlling virus can raise US$1t in tax revenue
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates that controlling the global pandemic through vaccination could generate over $1 trillion in additional tax revenue in advanced economies by 2025. The IMF recommends continuing to invest in healthcare systems and households until the pandemic is curbed globally, as vaccination will "more than pay for itself" in terms of public money invested. This comes as global public debt reached a record 97% of GDP in 2020, with countries announcing $16 trillion in fiscal actions in the past year.

site_title: Pegasus inks agreement with Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts to manage eco-resort in Vietnam
summary: PEGASUS Investment and Consultancy JSC and Banyan Tree Hotels and Resorts signed a hotel-management agreement for Dhawa Quy Nhon Vietnam, an eco-resort in Vietnam, with an estimated S$100 million investment. The resort, expected to open in 2023, will feature 240 rooms and sits on 10.5 hectares of land. The partnership highlights collaboration between two home-grown brands with overseas footprints, with both companies optimistic about Vietnam's tourism sector recovery post-COVID-19.

site_title: NEA to lower vehicle noise levels, tighten motorbike emissions from 2023
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) in Singapore will adopt new vehicle noise standards and tighten motorbike emissions from April 1, 2023. Motor vehicle noises will be limited to 68-77 decibels, and motorbikes to 68-77 decibels, lower than current Japanese and European standards. The agency will also tighten emission standards for motorcycles registered before July 1, 2003, with a one-year extension to June 30, 2028, for those meeting the new standards.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is pumping an additional S$68.5 million into its tourism fund to support the sector. The move comes as the country aims to provide targeted support to quality tourism enterprises. Meanwhile, Singapore's unemployment rates fell for the fourth straight month in February. The government is also investing in sports infrastructure, with the launch of a tender for the redevelopment of Ulu Pandan Road. Additionally, a poll found that family businesses in Singapore lag behind in digital transformation, with only 29% confident in their digital capabilities.

site_title: Flying-taxi SPAC accused of stealing aircraft technology
summary: Archer Aviation, a US$3.8 billion startup, is accused of stealing intellectual property from Wisk Aero, a joint venture of Boeing and Google co-founder Larry Page's Kitty Hawk, for its electric-powered flying taxi technology. Wisk claims thousands of files, including designs and secret information, were downloaded by former employees before they joined Archer. The complaint alleges Archer's rapid development of an eVTOL aircraft was facilitated by the stolen technology, and Wisk is seeking damages and an injunction to prevent further infringement.

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional trend, STI down 0.37%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.37% on Wednesday, closing at 3,195.76 points, as Wall Street retreated from all-time highs. This marked a pause from the previous record rally.
