In contrast, other Asian markets remained upbeat, with Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 0.12% and Seoul's Kospi increasing 0.33%. The decline was attributed to US market volatility amid tariff threats.

site_title: Certification programme launched to ensure safe resumption of Mice events in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Association of Convention and Exhibition Organisers and Suppliers (SACEOS) has launched the SG SafeEvents Certification programme to ensure safe resumption of MICE events in Singapore. The certification programme, based on the Technical Reference 84, covers hygiene benchmarks and safe-distancing best practices. About 700 SG SafeEvent Ambassadors have been trained to implement the standards, with the aim of having 1,000 ambassadors trained by mid-2021. The programme provides assurance that MICE and events companies have implemented necessary measures to minimise Covid-19 infection risk.

site_title: Serene Tiong's appeal over request to sue HC Surgical CEO dismissed
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore dismissed Serene Tiong's appeal against a previous High Court ruling, which found she lacked good faith in suing HC Surgical Specialists CEO Heah Sieu Min for alleged breach of director's duties. Tiong's case was deemed "wholly unmeritorious" and driven by revenge, with the court noting her history of conflict with Dr. Ong and her own financial interests. Tiong was ordered to pay costs of S$45,000 to the company and Dr. Heah.

site_title: Maxwell House reserve price lowered to S$268m in second collective sale tender
summary: Singapore's Maxwell House is up for sale via a second public tender with a reduced reserve price of S$268 million, lower than the initial S$295 million. The 13-storey commercial building sits on a 41,799 sq ft plot with views from all four sides and a 99-year leasehold tenure. The site is zoned for commercial use and is near the upcoming Maxwell MRT Station, expected to enhance connectivity. The URA previously advised on a potential mixed-use development with a 30% uplift in plot ratio, translating to a blended land rate of around S$1,565 per sq ft.

site_title: HSBC moves more than 1,200 UK staff to permanent home working
summary: HSBC is moving over 1,200 UK staff to permanent home working contracts, with around 70% of its 1,800 call centre staff opting for the change. The move, which is seen as a significant shift towards hybrid working, will see staff based in England, Wales, and Scotland working from home full-time. The bank has offered a £300 per year working from home top-up payment to cover additional expenses. While the union Unite is broadly supportive of the change as it is voluntary, it has warned other banks against forcing staff to stay at home if they do not want to, and highlighted the need for proper support to prevent wellbeing concerns.

images.alt_text: HSBC is moving more than 1,200 staff in Britain to permanent working from home contracts, in one of the strongest indications yet of how banks are locking in changes to employees' work patterns as a result of the pandemic to cut costs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.68 points to 1,600.59 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 6.303 billion lots worth RM3.619 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 590 to 440.

site_title: COEs end mostly higher, with certificate for bigger cars up by more than S$5,000
summary: COE certificates ended mostly higher at the latest tender, with cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp closing at S$45,600, and those above 1,600cc or 130bhp at S$52,309. Open COE, which often goes to bigger cars, finished at S$52,200. Commercial vehicle COE fell to S$36,134, while motorcycle premium rose to S$8,000. The increase is attributed to a wealthy consumer demand driven by bullish equity and property markets, and new emission penalties for bigger cars starting in July.

site_title: Deeptech startup Atomionics raises S$2.5m in seed funding to develop product
summary: Singapore-based deeptech startup Atomionics has secured S$2.5 million in seed funding to develop its quantum sensors that enable navigation without GPS. The funding, led by Wavemaker Partners, will be used to build the product and take it to market. The quantum sensors have various use cases, including detecting underground hydrocarbons, mineral reserves, and infrastructure, as well as navigating aircraft and submarines. The startup aims to create a universal positioning system that works everywhere, including underground, underwater, and in space, without relying on satellites or external signals.

site_title: Malaysian ex-PM Najib faces bankruptcy over tax bill
summary: Malaysian former Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing potential bankruptcy due to an outstanding tax bill of over US$400 million. He lost power in 2018 amidst a financial scandal involving the 1MDB fund, for which he was convicted and sentenced to 12 years in jail. Najib has denied any wrongdoing and claims the case is politically motivated. If declared bankrupt, he will lose his seat in Parliament and be barred from running in elections. Najib has begun an appeal against his conviction and has asked his lawyers to halt the bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Flash Coffee raises US$15m, plans 300 more stores in 2021
summary: Flash Coffee, a Rocket Internet-backed coffee chain, has raised US$15 million in Series A funding to expand its brand in 10 Asia-Pacific markets. The company plans to open 300 more stores by the end of 2021, with a focus on technology-driven "new retail" models. Flash Coffee aims to have a store every 500 meters in major Asian cities, with a regional HQ in Singapore and expanded tech hub in Jakarta.

site_title: Australia: Shares close at highest in over a year, extend gains for fourth session
summary: Australia's shares closed at their highest in over a year, rising 0.61% to 6,928 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, for the fourth consecutive session. The gains were driven by the energy and gold sectors, with gold stocks extending their gains for a third session. The central bank's decision to keep lending rates unchanged sparked uncertainty, with some analysts expressing concerns about inflation and economic direction. Tech stocks also continued their winning streak, with Afterpay adding 1.9%.

site_title: Shell flags likely fall in first-quarter fuel sales
summary: Royal Dutch Shell expects its fuel sales to fall or be steady for the first quarter, with refined oil product sales at 3.7-4.7 million barrels per day. Refinery utilisation rates are at 71-75% compared to a forecast of 73-81%. Shell's refining margins have improved to around $2.6 per barrel. The company also expects its liquefied natural gas production to be 7.8-8.4 million tonnes. Total upstream production is forecast to rise to 2.4-2.48 million barrel of oil equivalent.

site_title: Euro zone business activity returns to growth in March
summary: Euro zone business activity returned to growth in March, driven by a record expansion in the manufacturing sector. The services sector, coping with new lockdowns, showed resilience, with the Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 49.6. A composite PMI of 53.2 also indicated economic health, despite supply chain disruptions and renewed lockdowns. Factory activity growth reached its fastest pace in nearly 24 years, but inflation is unlikely to be sustained. Optimism about the year ahead improved, with the composite future output index reaching its highest since February 2018.

site_title: Jokowi supports central bank mandate to aid Indonesia's growth
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has expressed support for expanding Bank Indonesia's mandate to include economic growth and job creation, potentially risking the central bank's independence. The move comes as the country's economy is expected to grow 7% in the second quarter, following a recession in 2020. Widodo stated that Bank Indonesia will remain independent, but emphasized the need for financial-sector reform to ensure a swift response in times of crisis. This move has raised concerns among global investors, who may view it as a challenge to the central bank's independence.

site_title: US jobs progress still far short of Fed's 'substantial' tripwire
summary: The US job market showed a small improvement in March, adding nearly a million jobs, but still lags far behind the Federal Reserve's threshold for reining in its support. The unemployment rate remains 6%, and the employment-to-population ratio is 7 percentage points below its peak in 2000. The Fed's "substantial further progress" goal is considered unmet, and policymakers are cautious, citing the need for sustained higher growth and the COVID-19 pandemic's lasting impact on the labor market.

site_title: 85% of all ongoing BTO projects delayed; 43,000 households affected
summary: About 85% of ongoing Build-To-Order (BTO) projects in Singapore are delayed, affecting around 43,000 households. The Ministry of National Development attributed the delays to manpower shortages and supply chain disruptions due to the global Covid-19 situation. To expedite construction works, the Housing Board is considering allowing less noisy construction activities on Sundays and public holidays. The government is taking steps to ensure the safety and quality of construction, while also addressing the issue of construction delays for private residential and commercial projects.

images.alt_text: Less noisy construction activities at BTO sites may be allowed to be carried out on Sundays and public holidays to speed things up.

site_title: SLA and SportSG launch tender for 102 Ulu Pandan Road for sports use
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) and Sport Singapore (SportSG) have launched a tender for 102 Ulu Pandan Road, a 44,643 sqm state property. The site will be converted for sports use, meeting the needs of residents and the general public. This marks the first joint tender by SLA and SportSG, aiming to assess the response and potential for additional state property sites. The tender will evaluate bids based on a 60-40 quality-price ratio, with the quality component being a key consideration.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up on hopes for global recovery
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 0.12% to 29,730.79, driven by hopes for a global economic recovery. The broader Topix index also gained 0.67%. The market shifted its focus to corporate earnings, as investors await company reports. The gains come amid a global economic recovery outlook, shifting market focus from trade tensions to corporate performance.

site_title: Singapore Inc in a lockdown: 3 days, 10 quarantine halls, 960 beds and SIA blankets
summary: On April 7, 2021, Singapore's "circuit breaker" lockdown was in full swing, with Surbana Jurong CEO Wong Heang Fine leading the mobilization of Singapore Inc to convert 10 Expo halls into quarantine facilities. The project was completed in six hours beyond the expected deadline, with 960 beds installed, makeshift storage boxes and locks, and blankets sourced from Singapore Airlines. The lockdown lasted nearly two months, forcing non-essential businesses to shut down to curb the spread of Covid-19, and the city-state faced significant global supply chain instability.

site_title: Deliveroo shares rise as retail investors start trading stock
summary: Deliveroo Holdings shares rose 3.9% as retail investors began trading the company's shares, following its £1.5 billion IPO last week. Despite a 28% slump in shares since its debut, retail investors, including 70,000 customers who purchased £50 million worth of shares through a community offering, started buying shares. The company's dual-class share structure and gig-economy business model were criticized by some institutional funds. Hundreds of riders are expected to protest for better working conditions.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo Holdings, which collapsed in its London debut last week after a £1.5 billion (S$2.7 billion) initial public offering, gained as much as 3.9 per cent as retail investors began to trade the company's shares.

site_title: SoHo Advisors launching event to match 10 US SPACs with over US$2b with Asia-Pacific targets
summary: SoHo Advisors, a Singapore-based fintech investment bank, is launching a virtual event to connect US-listed special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) with target companies in the Asia-Pacific. The event, scheduled for May 4, aims to match 10 US SPACs with over $2 billion in capital with 10 regional targets, including leading unicorns in sectors like ride-sharing, e-commerce, and healthcare. The event is expected to accelerate the SPAC conversation and facilitate deals between US-listed SPACs and Asian companies.

site_title: Taiwan accuses Beijing of luring Paraguay with 'vaccine diplomacy'
summary: Taiwan accused China of using "vaccine diplomacy" to lure Paraguay into switching diplomatic recognition in exchange for coronavirus vaccines. China has been ramping up pressure on Taiwan since 2016, and has poached seven of Taiwan's official allies. Taiwan's foreign minister said China offered Paraguay millions of vaccine doses if it severed ties with Taiwan. Paraguay is one of only 15 countries that recognize Taipei over Beijing, and has reported a surge in coronavirus cases, prompting President Mario Abdo Benítez to seek more vaccines.

site_title: Osaka cancels Olympic torch run, declares Covid-19 medical emergency
summary: Osaka, Japan, has cancelled Olympic torch run events due to a medical emergency declared by the government amid record coronavirus infections, primarily among young people, 107 days before the Tokyo Olympics. The Osaka governor attributed the strain on the medical system to a more infectious virus variant.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, shedding 0.91% due to investors returning from a weekend holiday and turning profit-takers after a healthy rally at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index fell to 28,674.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: 'It's the tone': Palau president explains his China mistrust
summary: Palau President Surangel Whipps has reaffirmed his country's stance against China's pressure campaign, vowing not to be bullied into recognizing Taiwan as China's territory. Whipps, who leads one of the world's smallest nations, has emerged as the most vocally China-sceptical leader in the Pacific, citing Beijing's aggressive stance under President Xi Jinping. Despite China's efforts to isolate Taiwan, Whipps sees the island as a democracy and a key ally, and Palau will maintain its recognition of Taiwan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.56% to 20,101.40 points, following a rally from the end of last week. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, with gains of 0.45% and 0.08% respectively. The rally comes as investors return from a holiday break and despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: 'Ghostbusters', 'Jumanji' will headline water park in Thailand
summary: Sony Pictures Entertainment is developing a theme and water park, Columbia Pictures' Aquaverse, in Thailand with Amazon Falls. The 5.7-hectare park, opening in phases in October 2021, will feature attractions based on popular Sony characters such as Ghostbusters, Jumanji, and Hotel Transylvania. The park aims to capitalize on Thailand's post-Covid tourism rebound, with the country easing travel restrictions and aiming to regain its $60 billion tourism revenue from 2019.

site_title: Softbank-backed Kahoot is Asia-Pacific's latest edtech contender
summary: Kahoot, an online education startup backed by Softbank, is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region. The company aims to capture "substantial growth" in markets such as Japan, China, and Singapore through partnerships with regional entertainment and media players. Kahoot recently acquired language learning tool Drops and online whiteboard tool Whiteboard.fi, and has over 100 million players in the region. The company plans to tailor its content and create a localised interface to build momentum and gather interest in the region.

site_title: One community infection among 35 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 35 new COVID-19 cases, including one community case, bringing the total to 60,554. The community case was placed on a stay-home notice, along with 34 imported cases. No cases were reported from migrant workers' dormitories. The Ministry of Health also confirmed five permanent residents who returned from India and Malaysia, as well as 13 imported patients for work. With 25 cases discharged, 60,224 patients have recovered, and 48 remain in hospital, including one in intensive care.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record high, UK outperforms
summary: European stocks hovered near record highs on Wednesday, with the UK's FTSE 100 gaining 0.3% due to a weaker pound. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.2% after closing at an all-time high. Germany and France's DAX and CAC 40 indices remained flat. The UK's roll-out of Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine lifted the domestically focused midcap index.

site_title: Connectivity, digitalisation crucial to Asean+3 growth
summary: Asean+3 nations emphasize the importance of connectivity and digitalization in post-pandemic growth, citing the need for greater globalisation to tackle supply chain vulnerabilities. Minister Indranee Rajah and AMRO chief economist Khor Hoe Ee highlight the region's attractiveness for GVC investment, with digitalisation seen as crucial for improving risk management and reducing logistical bottlenecks. Policymakers stress the need for rethinking data security and human capital management policies to enhance resilience.

site_title: BitMEX ex-CEO Arther Hayes, a Singapore resident, surrenders to face US charges
summary: Former BitMEX CEO Arthur Hayes, a Singapore resident, has surrendered to US authorities to face charges of failing to prevent money laundering on the cryptocurrency exchange he co-founded. Hayes, along with co-founders Benjamin Delo and Samuel Reed, were accused of conspiring to skirt US laws requiring money-laundering controls. Hayes was released on a $10 million bond pending future court proceedings in New York, where the case is part of growing US scrutiny of cryptocurrency exchanges.

site_title: Crypto exchange Coinbase quarterly profit more than doubles 2020 total
summary: Coinbase, the largest US cryptocurrency exchange, reported a preliminary first-quarter profit of $730-800 million, more than doubling its 2020 total of $1.3 billion. The company generated $1.8 billion in revenue, surpassing 2020's annual total, and has 56 million verified users. Coinbase plans to go public through a direct listing on Nasdaq on April 14, with an expected debut valuation of around $90 billion. The company anticipates "meaningful growth" in 2021 revenue, particularly from its custody business, despite the volatility of token prices.

site_title: Gold dips as strong US data sparks economic recovery hopes
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,737.75 per ounce amid strong US data and increased economic recovery hopes. The US job market saw a two-year high in February, while the International Monetary Fund raised its global economic growth forecast to 6%. Central banks' dovish stance supports gold prices in the medium term, despite a slight profit-taking trend. Silver and palladium also fell 0.4%, while platinum rose 0.8%.

site_title: Singapore to pump extra S$68.5m into tourism fund to support sector: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore is increasing its Tourism Development Fund by S$68.5 million to support the tourism sector amid near-term headwinds. The fund, established in 2005, aims to grow tourism receipts and visitor arrivals. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for the sector to adapt to changing trends, including sustainability and technology. The Singapore Tourism Board will launch a Tourism Sector Capability Development Roadmap to address workforce demands from Covid-19. The government also plans to support innovative solutions and digital transformation in the tourism industry.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB initiates 'add' on Hong Leong Asia, expects 54% profit growth
summary: Research firm CGS-CIMB has initiated an "add" rating on Hong Leong Asia (HLA) with a target price of S$1.18, forecasting a 54% net profit growth in FY2021. HLA's diesel engine segment is expected to benefit from China's National VI engine standards, while its building materials segment is expected to recover as construction activities resume. The analyst notes that investors are currently paying for the diesel engine segment while getting the building materials segment for free, offering a potential value opportunity.

site_title: SocGen in talks with Amundi for 825m euro sale of asset management unit
summary: Societe Generale has entered into exclusive negotiations with Amundi to sell its 825 million euro Lyxor asset management unit. The sale is part of the bank's efforts to boost profits. The transaction is expected to be finalized by February 2022 and will have a positive impact on the group's CET1 ratio. Societe Generale will retain some Lyxor units, with Amundi acquiring the majority of the asset management activities for institutional clients in France and abroad.

images.alt_text: Societe Generale has entered into exclusive negotiations with asset manager Amundi to sell most of its Lyxor asset management unit, a 825 million euros (S$1.31 billion) transaction in line with the French bank's efforts to boost its profits.

site_title: US vaccine 'passports' advance despite growing controversy
summary: US states, led by New York, are moving forward with "vaccine passports" despite growing controversy and political divisions. The voluntary digital passes, such as New York's, verify vaccination status or recent negative test results. In contrast, Republican governors in Florida, Texas, and South Dakota have issued executive orders prohibiting government-mandated vaccine passports. The US government has stated it will not issue a federal mandate, but will provide guidance to ensure systems are not used unfairly. The development of digital certification is expected to continue, with Israel's "green pass" rollout and the Common Pass project gaining interest.

site_title: Singapore unemployment rates fall for fourth straight month in February
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate fell to 3% in February for the fourth straight month, with 96,800 residents and 85,900 citizens unemployed. The Manpower Minister, Josephine Teo, cautioned that further declines would be harder to achieve, citing the need for sustained hiring demand and employers to look beyond familiar candidates. Despite elevated rates, Teo noted "good progress with jobs growth," with 27,000 employers hiring 130,000 locals under the Jobs Growth Incentive.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as vaccine, data add to recovery hopes
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Wednesday, driven by vaccine and data releases that fueled hopes for a global recovery. US President Joe Biden announced that all adults would be eligible for a vaccine by April 19, while California's governor set a June deadline for reopening the state. Job openings surged to a two-year high in February, and the International Monetary Fund increased its 2021 growth forecast to 6.0%. Despite some losses, analysts expect gains to continue, citing low interest rates and investor demand for returns.

site_title: SME business sentiment hits highest reading since start of pandemic
summary: Business sentiment among Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has reached its highest reading since the start of the pandemic, with an overall index of 49.9 for the April to September period. The reading, derived from a survey of over 2,100 SMEs, indicates improving business sentiments across all six sectors, with significant gains in construction and engineering, and business services. The improvement is attributed to the gradual reopening of the economy, easing of business restrictions, and government budget measures.

site_title: What happens when women run the economy? We're about to find out
summary: Women now hold key economic positions in the US, with Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo, and trade czar Katherine Tai leading the administration's economic policy. The new $2.3 trillion spending plan includes $400 billion for the "care economy," supporting home- and community-based jobs, and aims to fix racial and rural-urban inequalities. Women leaders are bringing fresh perspectives to economic policy, emphasizing empathy and the impact of policies on vulnerable communities. The global recession has disproportionately affected women, accounting for 54% of overall job losses, and bringing them back to work could boost GDP in various countries.

site_title: Australia blames EU supply issues for slow vaccine roll-out
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison blamed EU supply issues for the country's slow vaccine rollout, citing restricted export controls and shortages of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine. Despite receiving only 700,000 doses of the vaccine, out of a contracted 3.8 million, Morrison assured EU officials that the government would encourage export licenses if they are granted. The country is now severely behind schedule, with only 850,000 shots administered by the end of March, prompting growing public frustration.

images.alt_text: Australia's prime minister on Wednesday blamed restricted vaccine supply from Europe for his country's halting coronavirus inoculation efforts, as he faced down growing public frustration over the sluggish rollout.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.22% and the Topix index up 0.41%. Despite falls on Wall Street and a strong yen against the dollar, the market was boosted by a lack of fresh market-moving events.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH upgrades CSE Global to 'buy' as oil prices rise
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has upgraded CSE Global to "buy" with a target price of S$0.68, citing the technology solutions provider's potential to leverage the recovering oil sector. Analyst John Cheong expects oil prices to rise due to Opec supply curbs and a potential demand recovery, supporting CSE Global's oil and gas segment. The analyst also remains positive on the group's infrastructure and mining segments, with raised earnings forecasts and a maintained full-year dividend of 2.75 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.49 points, or 0.47%, to 1,586.40. Trading volume reached 324.07 million lots worth RM153.13 million. Gainers outpaced losers 215 to 205.

site_title: Samsung Electronics forecasts 44.19% jump in Q1 operating profit
summary: Samsung Electronics forecasts a 44.19% jump in Q1 operating profit to 9.3 trillion won, driven by strong smartphone sales and the launch of its Galaxy S21 series. The company expects to produce 62 million smartphones, regaining its global market lead. Despite a potential loss of 400 billion won due to a factory shutdown in February, analysts say the company's mobile business will benefit from solid shipments and cost control, leading to a significant increase in operating profit.

site_title: Biden says he has not yet spoken to Federal Reserve chair
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that he has not spoken to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell since taking office, citing a deliberate effort to restore the central bank's independence. This move follows the Trump era, where the president frequently criticized Powell's decisions and urged policy changes. Biden emphasized the importance of the Fed's independence, which is traditionally retained in key duties like setting interest rates.

site_title: Part of Mapletree's first European office fund offered in digital tokens
summary: Mapletree Investments' European office fund, the Mapletree Europe Income Trust (MERIT), has been tokenized by digital securities platform iSTOX, allowing 50 accredited investors to invest in the fund. The tokenization reduces the minimum investment ticket and enables smaller investors to access private real estate funds. MERIT consists of seven Grade-A offices in regional cities with a total asset value of 1.2 billion euros. The fund aims for a 12% internal rate of return through yield and growth. Tokenization using blockchain technology aims to increase accessibility and efficiency in the investment process.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars carried higher by global growth tide
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are rising due to signs of a global economic acceleration. The Aussie reached a two-week high of US$0.7675, while the kiwi dollar reached US$0.7063, challenging resistance levels. The currency gains are driven by trade flows and commodity prices, with both currencies expected to continue their upward momentum.

site_title: Toshiba to get proposal to go private from CVC Capital: source
summary: Private equity firm CVC Capital Partners is set to propose taking Toshiba Corp private in a deal worth over 2 trillion yen (S$24.1 billion), aiming to save Toshiba's embattled CEO from scrutiny. The proposal comes amid a battle with activist shareholders. Toshiba's CEO, Nobuaki Kurumatani, confirmed receiving the proposal, stating they will discuss it at a board meeting on Wednesday. The deal could help Toshiba escape calls for greater transparency and better governance from large overseas shareholders.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Raffles Medical to 'buy', expects return to business as usual
summary: RHB has upgraded Raffles Medical to 'buy' from 'neutral' with a higher target price of S$1.29, expecting the private medical provider's business to return to normal in 2021 amid resumption of deferred appointments and elective surgeries. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal forecasts 25% annual growth in recurring net profit and expects the group to achieve Ebitda break-even in its China hospitals within 3-4 years. The company plans to raise debt to enhance return on equity and grow faster organically or inorganically.

site_title: A third of Covid-19 survivors suffer neurological or mental disorders: study
summary: A study analyzing 236,379 Covid-19 patients found that 34% developed neurological or psychiatric disorders within six months, with anxiety and mood disorders being the most common. Post-Covid cases of stroke and dementia were rarer but still significant, especially in those with severe Covid-19. The study suggests Covid-19 may lead to a wave of mental and neurological problems, and urgent research is needed to identify the biological or psychological mechanisms involved.

site_title: Japan PM Suga signals chance of calling snap election: Asahi
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga hinted at the possibility of calling a snap general election before his term ends in September, citing a chance to dissolve parliament before the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's leadership race. This comes amid speculation about a potential visit to the US later this month, which could prompt a dissolution of parliament. Suga has previously expressed caution over a snap election, focusing on containing the pandemic, but the possibility of an early election remains.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engg, Trendlines, iX Biopharma, 3Cnergy, Yinda Infocomm
summary: ST Engineering shares rose 0.5% after being selected to participate in the US Army's Cold Weather All-Terrain Vehicle prototype phase. Trendlines Group shares jumped 15.3% after receiving a non-binding letter of intent for an acquisition. iX Biopharma's product may be manufactured and distributed in China following an agreement with China Resources Pharmaceutical Commercial Group Co. 3Cnergy shares dropped 5% due to material uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern. Yinda Infocomm appointed a new CEO, while Boldtek shares rose 27.8% after a substantial shareholder notification.

site_title: Oil gains 1% on strong US, China economic data
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, recouping losses from the previous session, driven by strong economic data from China and the US. Brent crude rose to $62.74 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $59.33 a barrel. The increase was partly due to Opec+ agreeing to return 350,000 barrels per day in May and June, and partly due to easing of coronavirus restrictions in England. However, concerns over global demand and rising Covid-19 infections in India and Europe weighed on prices, with analysts warning that a strong demand recovery is still uncertain.

site_title: Australia-NZ 'travel bubble' to begin April 19 in pandemic milestone
summary: New Zealand and Australia will begin a quarantine-free travel bubble on April 19, allowing Australians to visit New Zealand without mandatory COVID-19 testing. The move marks a significant milestone in the pandemic response, with both countries effectively eradicating the virus. Airlines Qantas and Air New Zealand will increase flights to over 70% of pre-pandemic levels, and the travel bubble will enable sports competitions and events to proceed. The agreement is seen as a step towards normalcy, with Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison calling it the "first of many more steps" in recovery.

site_title: Facebook says hackers 'scraped' data of 533 million users in 2019 leak
summary: Facebook has confirmed that hackers "scraped" data of 533 million users in 2019, taking advantage of a feature to find friends using contact lists. The data, including phone numbers, birth dates, and email addresses, was shared at a hacker forum. Facebook says the data was obtained prior to September 2019, not through hacking, and did not include passwords or financial information. The company is urging users to check their privacy settings and tighten account security. This is not the first time Facebook has faced controversy over data leaks, following a 2016 scandal involving Cambridge Analytica.

images.alt_text: Facebook said Tuesday that hackers "scraped" personal data of some half-billion users back in 2019 by taking advantage of a feature designed to help people easily find friends using contact lists.

site_title: Digital and green strong avenues of growth for ASEAN and UK
summary: The UK's Integrated Review emphasizes digital and climate change opportunities in Southeast Asia, particularly for ASEAN member states. This shift could make the UK a viable source of investment for these regions. In other news, Vietnam reacts to the US tariff announcement, Malaysia's industrial production rises 0.3% in May, and foreign investors return to Vietnamese stocks. Additionally, a rate cut in Malaysia signals economic growth jitters, while Thailand's super-long bonds gain value due to tariffs and a political crisis. These developments highlight the complexities and challenges facing ASEAN and the UK in the post-Brexit era.

site_title: Major E3 video game show goes virtual - and free
summary: The Entertainment Software Association (ESA) announced that the Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3) will return as a free, virtual event in June, after being cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic. The event will take place from June 12-15 and will feature major game reveals and insider opportunities, with companies like Nintendo, Microsoft, and Ubisoft confirmed to participate. Sony, however, will not attend, citing a shift towards online events. The virtual E3 aims to be more inclusive and exciting for fans, while still showcasing the industry's best.

site_title: StashAway launches digital wealth advisory platform in Hong Kong
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based robo-adviser, has launched its digital wealth advisory platform in Hong Kong, licensed by the Securities and Futures Commission. Stephanie Leung, a seasoned wealth manager, will lead the expansion. The platform aims to make investing accessible to all, breaking traditional high-commission-based fees and minimum investment amounts. StashAway has clients from over 160 countries, managing over $1 billion in assets, and has consistently outperformed its benchmarks since its inception in 2017.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains as commodity-exposed firms shine
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to a fresh high since mid-February, driven by commodity-exposed stocks on firm crude and metals prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,920.2 points, with metals and mining stocks leading the gain. The International Monetary Fund raised its global economic growth forecast to 6% for this year. Strong economic data from China and the US lifted oil prices, while a retreating dollar and lower US Treasury yields boosted bullion, further lifting sentiment.

images.alt_text: Australian shares on Wednesday extended gains for a fourth session, driven by commodity-exposed stocks on firm crude and metals prices and as investors placed bets on improving prospects for a global economic recovery.

site_title: AstraZeneca UK vaccine trial in children paused: Oxford University
summary: AstraZeneca's UK vaccine trial for children has been paused while regulators assess its possible link to blood clots. The trial, led by Oxford University, was halted after reports of rare cases of thrombosis/thrombocytopaenia in adults in Norway and continental Europe. The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) and the European Medicines Agency (EMA) are reviewing the data. The pause follows controversy over the jab's efficacy and safety profile, including a failure to deliver promised doses to the European Union. The WHO will reveal its findings later this week.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back from records to end lower
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday, pulling back from records after the International Monetary Fund lifted its global growth forecast to 6.0% for this year. The US vaccination rollout accelerated, with California Governor Gavin Newsom announcing plans to fully reopen its economy by June 15. The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.3% to end at 33,430.24, while the S&P 500 declined 0.1% to 4,073.94. Individual stocks, such as General Motors, rose, while Phillips 66 fell 1.6% due to expected financial losses.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging up 0.1% to 3,211.85 points, driven by investor bets on a swift global economic recovery. Pharmaceutical company iX Biopharma rose 17.8% after trading 24 million shares, while gains outnumbered losses 80 to 38. The market saw 36.5 million securities worth S$68.6 million change hands by 9:02am.

site_title: Supporting a strong, inclusive, and sustainable recovery in Asean
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) must strengthen regional cooperation and improve domestic resource mobilization to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Regional cooperation can enhance regional financial safety nets, deepen trade, and build health security. Asean economies can reduce health vulnerabilities and lift regional health security by improving supply chains, reducing non-tariff barriers, and promoting paperless trade. Domestic resource mobilization can be achieved by strengthening tax systems, deepening local currency bond markets, and catalyzing green finance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supports Asean in forging a strong, inclusive, and sustainable recovery.

site_title: New small business coalition targets Amazon on antitrust
summary: A new coalition of small business groups, including the American Booksellers Association and National Grocers Association, has launched a campaign to enforce tougher US antitrust laws, specifically targeting Amazon. The coalition aims to "stop tech monopolies" by breaking up and regulating Amazon. The group's goal is to promote fair competition in the online market, and its campaign is seen as a response to Amazon's growing dominance in e-commerce.

images.alt_text: A new coalition of small business groups on Tuesday launched a campaign for tougher US antitrust enforcement, specifically calling for the breakup of online commerce titan Amazon.

site_title: Kim Kardashian is a billionaire: Forbes
summary: Kim Kardashian West has been named a billionaire by Forbes, with an estimated net worth of $1 billion. Her wealth comes from TV income, endorsement deals, and her lifestyle brands, including KKW Beauty and Skims. Kardashian's net worth jumped over $200 million since October, surpassing her sister Kylie Jenner's net worth. The 40-year-old's success follows a five-year journey, with Forbes initially reporting she made her first $51 million in 2016. Kardashian's business ventures have proven lucrative, with Skims estimated to be worth over $500 million.

site_title: Amazon backs Biden on tax hike, infrastructure plan
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos expressed support for President Joe Biden's proposal to increase the corporate tax rate to 28% to fund infrastructure improvements. Bezos stated that the investment will require concessions from all sides, but Amazon is willing to consider a rise in the corporate tax rate as part of a balanced solution. This comes after Biden singled out Amazon for avoiding income taxes, citing a 2019 study that found 91 Fortune 500 companies, including Amazon, pay no federal income tax. Amazon aims to maintain or enhance US competitiveness with the proposed infrastructure plan.

site_title: Over 2,000 RWS staff put skills to good use
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) volunteered as the managing agent for two community care facilities (CCFs) in Singapore, covering admission, housekeeping, and operations command centre duties. Over 2,000 RWS staff members put their skills to good use, providing care packs, activities, and emotional support to patients. The experience not only helped care for Covid-19 patients but also gained valuable knowledge and experience in infection control, enabling a smooth re-opening of RWS when the circuit breaker was lifted in June.

site_title: Mun Siong Engineering fined and barred from hiring new foreign workers until Dec 29
summary: Mun Siong Engineering, a Singapore-based company, has been fined S$15,000 by the Ministry of Manpower for breaching the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act. The company was found to have made an "inherent oversight" in submitting work pass applications for six foreign workers, relying on verbal representations instead of documentary proof. Mun Siong has assured MOM that it will exercise due care in future submissions and has paid the administrative fine. The company is barred from applying for new foreign workers until December 29.

site_title: S Korea property woes could turn tide against Moon in by-elections
summary: South Korean voters are turning against President Moon Jae-in's economic agenda due to soaring home prices and widening wealth inequality. Anger is fueling support for opposition candidates in crucial by-elections in Seoul and Busan, which may impact Moon's momentum. The global housing market's overheating is a contributing factor, with similar issues affecting countries like Australia and Canada. The by-elections, scheduled for this week, are expected to have significant implications for the country's politics.

site_title: Hmlet: a hard lesson in hubris
summary: Hmlet, a co-living operator, is reeling from a cash crunch and management exodus following rapid expansion. The company, which signed long-term leases and reconfigured apartments for short-term rentals, accumulated over 100 properties in six countries by 2021. However, weak demand in a highly competitive space has forced Hmlet to rethink its ambitions, drawing parallels with its US-listed, China-based peers who experienced similar falls from grace. The company's future remains uncertain as it seeks to address its financial and operational issues.

site_title: 'Even with money, you can't source for anything': Surbana Jurong CEO
summary: Surbana Jurong, a consultancy firm, transformed 10 Singapore Expo event halls into healthcare facilities within 7 days in March 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite financial constraints, the team faced significant challenges in sourcing materials and manpower. The project relied on the firm's extensive network and ingenuity to deliver beds, cabinets, and other essential items. The team worked with Singapore Port Authority and local companies to overcome logistical hurdles, ultimately completing the project ahead of schedule. The experience highlighted the importance of designing public facilities for multiple purposes to prepare for future pandemics or emergencies.

site_title: The case for a 9% GST
summary: Singapore's Second Minister for Finance, Indranee Rajah, supports a planned 2% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to boost government revenue. The government's cash surpluses from 2011 to 2019 do not justify reducing the planned increase, as it would compromise inter-generational equity. A 2% GST rise would generate an additional S$3.2 billion per year, making it the second-largest generator of tax revenue. GST is a stable source of government revenue, neutral in terms of foreign trade, and easy to administer. The increase would be mitigated by providing GST vouchers to lower-income individuals.

site_title: GameStop fiasco brings market's trust deficit into full relief
summary: The GameStop fiasco has highlighted the market's trust deficit, sparking debates on investing versus speculation versus gambling. The wild January ride has brought attention to the democratization of markets and the impact of technology on free and fast access to markets. Hearings are planned in the US Congress to address investor protection and market integrity. The CFA Institute is engaging with industry stakeholders to foster transparency and integrity in markets, raising concerns about a potential "investor class" that views investing as costly entertainment.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 closes at record high on global recovery optimism
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed at a record high on Tuesday, recovering all pandemic-driven losses, as investors bet on a speedy global economic recovery. The index rose 0.7% to 435.36 points, with economically sensitive sectors such as banking and automakers rebounding strongly. Euro zone unemployment remained unchanged at 8.3% in February, highlighting the impact of government policies. London stocks took cheer after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a possible next phase of economic reopening.

site_title: US dollar rebounds amid growing optimism
summary: The US dollar rebounded from a near two-week low on Tuesday due to growing optimism about the US economy. Despite a weak start to April, the dollar rebounded after investors consolidated positions following a sell-off overnight. A strong US jobs report and solid US services activity reading on Friday and Monday, respectively, contributed to the rebound. However, hedge funds continued to cut their long positions on the currency, indicating that the dollar's recovery may be short-lived.

site_title: Credit Suisse takes 4.4b Swiss franc hit on Archegos
summary: Credit Suisse has taken a 4.4 billion Swiss franc hit from its dealings with Archegos Capital Management, prompting the bank to overhaul its investment bank and risk division leadership. The bank expects a 900 million Swiss franc loss for the first quarter and has suspended share buyback plans and cut its dividend by two thirds. CEO Thomas Gottstein has vowed to learn from the losses, while the bank's board launches an investigation into the losses. The scandal is the second major blow to Credit Suisse in recent months, following the collapse of Greensill Capital.

site_title: 1970s-style inflation highly unlikely
summary: A recent economic stimulus has led to concerns about inflation, with 10-year US Treasury yields increasing by 80 basis points since the start of the year. However, experts believe that a 1970s-style inflation is highly unlikely, as the stimulus is expected to be short-term and not translate into a long-term acceleration in core inflation. The global economy is expected to grow strongly, with the US and China projected to grow 8% and 9% respectively, driven by pent-up demand and spending. Inflation is likely to trend back to pre-pandemic levels, but it will not reach the high levels seen in the 1970s.

site_title: US Treasury yields' climb seen getting boost from real rates
summary: US Treasury yields are expected to rise due to strong economic readings and real rates, signaling a shift from inflation concerns to growth expectations. Ten-year real yields are near a 4-year high, and some strategists forecast them to reach 2.3% in the second quarter. The Federal Reserve may begin discussions to wind down its asset purchases, potentially leading to a tapering of policy. Strong job creation figures and record growth in service industries have fueled bets on growth, overshadowing inflation concerns.

site_title: US push for minimum corporate tax globally may impact investment hubs
summary: The US proposal for a global minimum corporate tax rate of 21% may negatively impact investment hubs like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Switzerland. Analysts note that Singapore's appeal to multinational corporations goes beyond tax incentives, citing factors such as its pro-business environment and strategic location. While the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) supports a global minimum tax, the US' specific proposal faces uncertain international support, with some experts suggesting a more modest rate of 10-12.5% may be adopted instead.

site_title: Biden, Suga seek to sweeten ties
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to meet Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, marking the first face-to-face encounter between the two leaders. The meeting comes as Biden focuses on Asia-Pacific security, particularly tensions with China in the South China Sea. The issue is a top priority for Biden, who aims to maintain a "free and open" Asia-Pacific. The meeting follows a virtual Quad session last month, which included Australian, Indian, and Japanese prime ministers, to discuss security concerns in the region.

site_title: Youn Yuh-Jung never dreamt of acting, now she's an Oscar nominee for Minari
summary: Youn Yuh-Jung, a 73-year-old Korean actress, has been nominated for an Academy Award for her role as Soonja in the film Minari. This marks the first Oscar nomination for a Korean actress. Yuh-Jung's journey to acting began when she failed her college entrance exam and was persuaded to audition for a drama. She went on to have a 50-year career in Korean television and film, despite facing sexism and limited opportunities. Her performance in Minari, directed by Lee Isaac Chung, has earned her critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the SAG supporting actress award.

site_title: China's services sector recovery accelerates in March: survey
summary: China's services sector saw a significant acceleration in recovery in March, with the Caixin/Markit services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 54.3, the highest since December. Firms hired more workers and business optimism surged, despite inflationary pressures. Employment rose back into positive territory as businesses hired more workers than they laid off. Overall, analysts expect a strong rebound in China's full-year growth, driven by successful control of domestic Covid-19 transmissions. However, rising input costs and output prices pose challenges to sustained post-pandemic recovery.

site_title: Stronger US dollar and weaker KOSPI emerging
summary: The US dollar is gaining strength, while the KOSPI index is weakening, driven by a stronger US dollar and a weaker Korean currency. A bullish dollar outlook is predicted, with a potential upside target of $1.03 for the dollar index, but this target is considered low-probability and should be taken with caution. In contrast, the KOSPI index is showing a bearish down-sloping triangle pattern, with a downside target near 2600, but this target may not be reliable due to a lack of historical support levels.

site_title: iX Biopharma enters cooperation deal with China Resources Pharmaceutical Commercial Group
summary: iX Biopharma has entered a strategic cooperation agreement with China Resources Pharmaceutical Commercial Group, a move that could pave the way for its sublingual pharmaceutical and nutraceutical products to be manufactured and distributed in China. The agreement, which includes licensing or joint venture options, will be overseen by CRPCG, which will handle registration, manufacturing, distribution, and promotion. This follows the development of iX Biopharma's patented drug-delivery platform technology, WaferiX, which is useful for drug repurposing. The agreement aims to facilitate long-term cooperation and binding contracts between the parties.

site_title: Trendlines surges to 10-month high after letter of intent for portfolio company
summary: Trendlines Group shares surged to a 10-month high after receiving a non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of a portfolio company by an unnamed public corporation. The shares jumped 24.5% to 12.2 Singapore cents, with the company expecting a material positive impact on its net tangible assets per share and earnings per share if the deal is completed. The non-binding LOI comes after Trendlines announced plans for a dual primary listing on Israel's Tel-Aviv Stock Exchange, which could provide the company with access to two different equity markets.

site_title: Turning to the bond markets for clues
summary: Global equities rose last week due to strong performances in US and European markets. Stocks that benefit from lower rates tend to outperform, while those with high growth potential are more sensitive to changes in long-term yields. Value-oriented stocks, such as financials and economically-sensitive sectors, have lower duration characteristics and are less affected by yield changes. The yield curve suggests a moderate inflation outlook, but the 10s-30s term spread indicates a possible shift towards lower inflation. Investors should consider a style-agnostic approach, diversifying across the entire equity spectrum, and may benefit from value stocks, particularly in regions like Latin America.

site_title: At NCS, resourcefulness was needed to deploy tech solutions
summary: NCS, a Singaporean IT company, played a crucial role in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic by providing technical support and resources to the government's efforts. The company's healthcare sector lead, Jim Lim, led a team of 15 engineers who worked 9-10 hour shifts daily to deploy tech solutions, including Telehealth on Wheels kiosks, remote mobile device management, and robotic process automation. These solutions helped reduce labor efforts, risks of contamination, and infection. NCS also set up similar monitoring systems in worker dormitories, eldercare centers, and Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

site_title: Air France gets EU nod for 4b-euro aid
summary: The European Union has approved a €4 billion (US$4.7 billion) aid package for struggling Air France, the French flag carrier. The deal includes a 30% stake increase for the French state and the relinquishment of 18 daily slots at Paris' Orly airport. EU competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager said the agreement ensures fair prices and increased choice for European consumers. The aid follows Air France's €7.1 billion loss in 2020 due to the pandemic, with rival airline Ryanair criticizing the support as distorting competition.

site_title: Virtual AGMs on extended run but challenges remain
summary: Singapore's Law Ministry has extended the deadline for companies to hold online annual general meetings (AGMs) until revoked or amended. This comes as service providers are preparing to meet the increased demand for virtual AGMs, with some companies contracting 50 or more virtual AGMs this year. The virtual AGM concept has been met with mixed sentiments, but companies like NTT Cloud Communications, Hong Bao Media, and Motion Media Works are adapting their traditional businesses to accommodate the new format. The cost of running a virtual AGM varies, but extensive rehearsals and technical runs are necessary to ensure a smooth experience.

site_title: China asks banks to curtail loan growth for rest of the year
summary: China's central bank has asked major lenders to curtail loan growth for the rest of 2021 due to surge in bubble risks. The request was made in a meeting with the People's Bank of China on March 22, where banks were told to keep new advances at roughly the same level as last year. Some foreign banks were also urged to reduce lending through "window guidance." This move aims to mitigate potential risks and slow down the economy.

site_title: Asean's ability to digitalise is key to its recovery and growth trajectory
summary: Asean's ability to digitalize is crucial for its recovery and growth, as the Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of new technologies and reconfigured global value chains. Asean members, particularly Singapore, are strengthening digitalization efforts, diversifying export markets, and enhancing inclusivity to remain attractive locations for foreign investment. The region will need to keep up with the digital economy's core infrastructure and coordinate regional strategies to address potential shocks, with over 90% of new digital consumers expected to continue using online services. A shift towards resilience and sustainability is also expected, with economies that adapt quickly to digitalization emerging stronger.

site_title: Taiwanese family wants them all in S$293m Draycott deal
summary: The Tsai family, owners of Want Want China Holdings, has purchased the entire 20-unit Eden tower at 2 Draycott Park in Singapore for S$293 million in a three-tranche deal. The completed freehold luxe development is located in a prime area of Singapore.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AUDITORS for 3Cnergy, an investment-holding firm, have raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a material uncertainty. As of Dec 31, 2020, 3Cnergy's current liabilities exceeded its current assets by nearly S$18.9 million. The company incurred a net loss of S$7.04 million and significant net operating cash outflows in 2020.

site_title: Salvors help save the planet, not just the economy
summary: The International Salvage Union (ISU) emphasized the importance of environmental protection in its recent Associate Members' Day 2021. President Richard Janssen highlighted the growing public demand for zero tolerance on environmental damage and the role of salvors in preventing marine pollution. The ISU reported 191 operations involving 2.5 million tonnes of potential pollutants in 2020, with a focus on preventing bunker fuel leaks from ships in trouble. The organization's efforts help protect hard-won reputations and contribute to a changed world prioritizing environmental care.

site_title: Google wins major copyright case against Oracle
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled in favor of Google, overturning a lower court's decision that Google's inclusion of Oracle's software code in Android did not constitute fair use under US law. In a 6-2 decision, Justice Stephen Breyer wrote that allowing Oracle to enforce a copyright on its code would harm the public by limiting future creativity. Google was seeking a potentially massive damages verdict, with Oracle estimating damages of up to $30 billion, but the ruling spares the company from a massive payout.

site_title: Iron ore rush turns two SGX plays red hot
summary: Iron ore plays Fortress Minerals and Southern Alliance Mining on the Singapore Exchange have seen significant gains this year, with shares jumping 25% and 61% respectively. The surge is attributed to higher global prices for the ferrous commodity, driven by a booming recovery in China and tight supplies. Both companies expect to capitalize on the boom, with Fortress Minerals planning to boost production and Southern Alliance Mining expanding its product portfolio and exploring mergers and acquisitions. Despite potential supply balances, analysts expect revenue to rise for both companies.

site_title: EU denies blocking 3.1 million AstraZeneca shots to Australia
summary: The European Union denied blocking 3.1 million doses of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine from being shipped to Australia, contradicting an Australian government source's claim. The EU has rejected only one of 491 vaccine export requests since increasing transparency, but seven requests are currently being reviewed. The EU has been scrutinizing vaccine exports due to shortages, particularly in the EU. Australia's inoculation campaign is behind schedule, with only about 670,000 people vaccinated out of an initial target of 4 million by end-March.

site_title: Caregivers Alliance launches mental health awareness campaign
summary: CAREGIVERS Alliance Limited launched a "Walk for Mental Wellness" campaign to raise awareness about mental health and highlight caregiving challenges. The campaign, which started on April 6, 2021, aims to raise at least S$250,000 through a dollar-for-dollar matching from the government. The non-profit organisation seeks to support caregivers and individuals affected by mental health issues.

site_title: MUFG Bank to rebuild Tokyo headquarters for post-pandemic work
summary: MUFG Bank plans to rebuild its 40-year-old Tokyo headquarters, significantly reducing facility expenses by consolidating 19,000 workers currently spread across nine locations. The new building will be designed with post-pandemic work arrangements in mind, including remote work and satellite offices. The bank aims to complete detailed designs by March 2023. MUFG also plans to transfer compliance roles to India, including anti-money laundering projects, to reduce costs and pursue efficiency.

site_title: ST Engineering selected as partner to produce prototype vehicle for US Army
summary: ST Engineering has been selected by the US Army to produce prototypes of a Cold Weather All-Terrain Vehicle (CATV) for extreme cold weather conditions. The company, along with US-based Oshkosh Defense, will deliver two prototypes in the third quarter of 2021. The US Army plans to issue a follow-on production contract for up to 200 CATVs in 2022. The prototypes will be evaluated on payload, mobility, and other factors, and are derived from ST Engineering's Bronco 3 and Oshkosh's existing CATV designs.

site_title: Malaysia sends back over 300 containers of illicit plastic waste
summary: Malaysia has sent back over 300 containers of illicit plastic waste to their countries of origin since 2019, with 267 already returned and 81 more in the process. The move comes after Malaysia became a popular destination for unlicensed plastic waste following China's 2018 import ban. New UN rules under the Basel Convention aim to discourage the production of hard-to-recycle plastics and prevent rich countries from dumping trash in developing nations. Environment Minister Tuan Ibrahim Tuan Man vowed to take "strict action" against shipping companies or agents breaking Malaysia's environment laws.

site_title: FairPrice backs national efforts to help community
summary: NTUC FairPrice, a Singapore supermarket chain, demonstrated its resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic by fulfilling a massive order of household items within 48 hours. The company's efforts were part of the national response to set up community care facilities. Amidst the challenges, FairPrice prioritized its community support, showcasing its commitment to helping those in need during a difficult time.

images.alt_text: Mr Seah says: "Ensuring the availability and affordability of necessities has always been our priority and this commitment is even more crucial in times of crisis."

site_title: Suez Canal may expand southern channel, chairman says
summary: The Suez Canal Authority is considering expanding the southern section of the waterway where the container ship Ever Given became stranded in March. Chairman Osama Rabie stated that the authority is also looking into procuring cranes that can offload cargo at heights of up to 52 meters. The expansion plans aim to improve the service and prevent future grounding issues. Rabie estimated that the procedures would be completed within two to three days, and the canal will be able to handle ships of the Ever Given's size in the future.

site_title: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor a showcase of solid bilateral ties
summary: China and Pakistan's China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) has marked its 70th anniversary of diplomatic relations, with the two countries celebrating their solid bilateral ties. The CPEC has brought $25.4 billion in direct investment and created 75,000 jobs, despite being labeled as a "debt trap" by some analysts. China's Ambassador to Singapore, Hong Xiaoyong, argues that the CPEC's financing arrangements are manageable, with repayment mainly coming from operational revenue, and that third-party participation is welcome, particularly from Singapore. The partnership aims to promote social-economic development, industry, and agriculture in the region.

site_title: Fast food struggles to hire as demand soars, US economy roars
summary: Taco Bell and other fast-food chains are struggling to hire employees due to a surge in demand amid the US economic recovery. The company plans to hold spot interviews at nearly 2,000 locations on April 21 to recruit 5,000 new employees. To attract workers, Taco Bell is offering benefits such as four weeks of annual vacation, eight weeks of paid maternity leave, and four weeks of "baby bonding" time for general managers. The US restaurant industry is still short 1.2 million employees from pre-pandemic levels, and the labor market is described as "tight."

site_title: IMF in favour of global minimum corporate tax
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has expressed support for a global minimum corporate tax, with its chief economist Gita Gopinath stating that it's a "big concern" of the fund. This comes as US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen calls for G20 countries to adopt a global minimum corporate tax to end the "race to the bottom" on taxation. The IMF warns that tax avoidance and evasion are reducing government revenues, hindering social and economic spending. Finance ministers from G20 nations are set to meet to discuss the issue.

site_title: S-Reits' growth lies in foreign asset acquisitions: Aprea
summary: Singapore's S-Reit sector is expected to grow through foreign asset acquisitions rather than new listings, according to John Lim, chairman of the Asia Pacific Real Assets Association (Aprea). The sector needs more "S$10 billion to S$15 billion Reits" and policy adjustments to facilitate overseas acquisitions. With regional markets developing their own Reit regimes, cross-border listings may become less relevant, and the Asia-Pacific region is poised to become the global Reit epicentre with a market cap of over US$1 trillion by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Despite the absence of new S-Reit listings of late, John Lim, chairman of Aprea, is not worried.

site_title: IMF upgrades global growth outlook again as some Covid clouds begin to clear
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its global growth outlook, forecasting a 6% increase in worldwide output this year, the fastest pace since the 1970s. The US economy is expected to grow 6.4%, the fastest since the early 1980s, driving the upgrade. However, the outlook for other countries, such as Germany, France, and Japan, remains unchanged. The IMF warns that the recovery is uneven, with multispeed recoveries underway in different regions and income groups, and that uncertainties, including the pandemic and accommodative policies, could impact the forecast.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as IMF lifts outlook
summary: US stocks were flat early Tuesday as the IMF lifted its 2021 global growth forecast to 6.0% due to increasing coronavirus vaccinations. The Dow Jones dropped 0.1% to an all-time high, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index remained flat. Investors await the start of first-quarter earnings season, optimistic about a reopening economy. The IMF's revised forecast follows strong US hiring and industrial data.

site_title: US job openings increase solidly in February
summary: US job openings rose 268,000 to 7.4 million in February, exceeding expectations. Hiring also increased to 273,000 to 5.7 million, driven by strengthening domestic demand and additional fiscal stimulus. The Labor Department's JOLTS report follows the March jobs addition of 916,000, the most in seven months.

site_title: Man City post losses of £126m due to Covid-19 impact
summary: Manchester City reported a net loss of £126 million for the 2019-20 season due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on their finances. Revenue dropped 11% to £478.4 million, primarily caused by matchday and broadcasting revenues. The club expects to post profits in the 2020-21 season, with deferred revenues and subsiding pandemic impact. This is in contrast to Chelsea's profit and Arsenal's loss, with Manchester City's CEO stating that the 2019-20 accounts do not accurately represent the season's reality.

site_title: AGMs: virtual, but not unilateral, please
summary: In 2020, Singapore-listed companies held 744 virtual general meetings, with 682 being AGMs and 121 EGMs, but only 6 companies (1.2%) held virtual AGMs with a live Q&A session. The majority of companies failed to engage shareholders actively, resulting in passive meetings with limited interaction. Singapore regulators have issued updated guidance encouraging issuers to adopt enhanced digital tools, but making virtual meetings mandatory could be a step further. Electronic online voting is already common in many markets, and hybrid meetings combining virtual and physical elements may be the future.

site_title: WHO does not back vaccination passports for now
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) does not support requiring vaccination passports for travel due to uncertainty over vaccine effectiveness in preventing transmission and equity concerns. WHO spokeswoman Margaret Harris stated that the organization is not certain that vaccines prevent transmission and that there are concerns about discrimination against those who cannot receive the vaccine. The WHO is reviewing China's COVID-19 vaccines for possible emergency use listing around the end of April.

site_title: Building supply chain resilience to combat volatility
summary: Global manufacturers are shifting their supply chain strategies to prioritize flexibility and resilience over cost reduction, following the Covid-19 pandemic's disruption. In a survey of 200 global manufacturers, 45% plan to shift production closer to home markets, while 36% rank cost reduction as a top three goal, down from 63% in the past three years. Companies are rethinking their supply chain strategies to lower the risk of disruption, with automation reducing the cost of manufacturing and enabling companies to move supply chains closer to home without significant cost increases.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.33 points lower on Tuesday at 1,578.91, with a trading volume of 6.273 billion lots worth RM 3.227 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 650 to 382.

site_title: Taiwan imposes water rationing as drought worsens
summary: Taiwan has imposed water rationing on over one million households and businesses in its central regions due to a severe drought, the worst in 56 years. The state water company is cutting supplies in affected areas for two days a week, with restrictions including no shampoo treatments and car washes. The drought, combined with a global semiconductor shortage, poses a threat to Taiwan's microchip manufacturing sector, which powers major electronics. The government warns of "preparing for the worst" and prioritizing water supplies to essential facilities.

site_title: Etihad starts direct passenger flights to Israel
summary: Etihad Airways has launched direct commercial passenger flights from Abu Dhabi to Tel Aviv, Israel, marking the latest air link between the two countries. The inaugural flight was attended by UAE and Israeli officials, with Etihad offering two weekly flights due to Israel's green list status. The UAE and Israel have normalized ties, with both countries boasting fast Covid-19 vaccination programs. Other UAE and Israeli airlines have also launched direct flights, making the UAE a popular destination for Israeli tourists.

images.alt_text: Abu Dhabi state carrier Etihad Airways began direct commercial passenger flights from the United Arab Emirates capital to Tel Aviv in Israel - the latest direct air link between the two countries that established diplomatic relations last year.

site_title: STI ends flat despite Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore shares ended Tuesday nearly flat, closing at 3,207.63 points, down 0.07% or 2.11 points. Despite an overnight Wall Street rally, Asian markets adopted a cautious tone, with Seoul and Jakarta ending higher, while Tokyo and Kuala Lumpur fell. The Straits Times Index (STI) constituents, including Venture Corporation and Singapore Airlines, rose, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding declined. Analyst Jeffrey Halley attributed the mixed trading to Wall Street's inconsistent rally pattern, suggesting Asian markets need stronger rallies to buy into the recovery trade.

site_title: Auditors for 3Cnergy flag material uncertainty as liabilities exceed assets by S$18.9m
summary: AUDITORS for 3Cnergy, an investment-holding firm, have raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a significant gap between its liabilities and assets, exceeding S$18.9 million as of Dec 31, 2020. The company incurred a net loss of S$7.04 million and significant cash outflows. The auditors noted that the company relies on bank and shareholder support to pay debts, casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Axington now a cash company, faces risk of being delisted
summary: Axington Inc, a Catalist-listed company linked to the Bellagraph Nova saga, has become a cash company and faces the risk of delisting if it doesn't acquire a new business within a year. The company notified the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) of its cash company status due to lack of revenue-generating business. Axington has until August 30 to submit a resumption proposal, with a failure to do so resulting in delisting.

site_title: H&M to lay off more than 1,000 staff in Spain: union
summary: H&M is laying off over 1,000 staff in Spain, including those on furlough due to the pandemic, with 30 shops set to close. The move has been criticized by the Workers' Commission union, which calls the layoffs "absolutely disproportionate" and unjustified. The company's net profit tumbled tenfold in 2020, but online sales surged 40% during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Swedish fashion giant H&M is to lay off more than 1,000 staff in Spain who are currently on furlough due to the pandemic, the Workers' Commission (CCOO) union said Tuesday.

site_title: Chinese 'limited edition' sneakers soar after Xinjiang backlash
summary: Chinese limited edition sneakers have seen price surges among collectors and speculators amid a boycott of global brands that source from Xinjiang. Nike and Adidas faced backlash on Chinese social media over past comments on sourcing products from the region. Xinjiang authorities deny using coercive labor programs, but researchers and foreign lawmakers claim they do. The boycott has driven up demand for Chinese sneakers, despite 190% tariffs on US imports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SP Group is building South-east Asia's first large-scale underground substation in Labrador, serving nearby towns such as Alexandra, Clementi, and Keppel. The 230 kV substation will meet the electricity needs of these areas when operational.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits record high on global recovery optimism
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 index reached a record high of 436.16 points, up 0.9% on Tuesday, as investors bet on a speedy global economic recovery. The index has climbed over 60% from its virus-induced lows last year. The German DAX, France's CAC 40, and UK's FTSE 100 also notched gains, with Wall Street's main indices reaching all-time highs. The strong US labor market and services sector activity contributed to the rally despite rising coronavirus cases globally.

site_title: Old Mutual fund says South Africa needs gas as a transition fuel
summary: South Africa's Old Mutual fund backs natural gas as a transition fuel to help bridge the country's shift from coal power generation to renewables. The fund, which has invested $830 million in renewable energy, plans to consider funding companies producing 3,000 megawatts of electricity from gas. Gas is seen as a more dispatchable alternative to renewables, which depend on weather conditions. The move is expected to rile the country's renewable-energy lobby, but is in line with the stance of South Africa's biggest coal consumers.

site_title: Yinda Infocomm appoints new CEO 3 years after previous resigns
summary: Yinda Infocomm has appointed Pierre Prunier, 40, as executive director and CEO, replacing acting CEO Qian Zimin. Prunier was previously director and chief strategy officer at International Biometrics. He takes over three years after the previous CEO, Qian Zhongcheng, resigned in July 2018. The appointment was made following an exchange filing on Tuesday.

site_title: Russia warns Myanmar sanctions could spark 'full-blown civil conflict'
summary: Russia warns that sanctions against Myanmar's junta could lead to a "full-blown civil conflict," opposing such measures. The warning comes as international powers seek to pressure the military with sanctions over its coup in February, which ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi. Over 550 people have been killed in anti-coup unrest. The UN Security Council has expressed deep concern over the situation, while Russia has developed ties with the military junta, showcasing its equipment at a parade.

site_title: Investors build up residential property portfolio in Q1 2021
summary: Investors in Singapore boosted their residential property portfolios in Q1 2021, with overall investment sales reaching S$3.8 billion, a 26.7% year-on-year increase. The residential sector led the market, with a record-breaking sale of a Good Class Bungalow for S$128.8 million. Commercial and mixed development sales also grew, while industrial sales more than doubled to S$906.1 million. Outbound investment sales rose 45.6% to S$9.9 billion, driven by demand for logistic spaces.
