Despite a pick-up in sales activity, supply is expected to remain limited, leading to more partnerships and land purchases.

site_title: 24 new coronavirus cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 24 new imported coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 60,519. All cases were detected on arrival and placed on stay-home notices. There were no community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The number of new cases in the community has remained stable at two per week. With 12 patients discharged, 60,199 have fully recovered, and 46 remain hospitalized.

images.alt_text: There were 24 new coronavirus cases confirmed at noon on Tuesday (April 6), taking Singapore's total to 60,519.

site_title: Sceptical president invites Netanyahu to form next Israeli government
summary: Israel's President Reuven Rivlin has tasked Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with forming a new government after the country's fourth inconclusive election in two years. Netanyahu, who is facing corruption charges, has 28 days to assemble a coalition, with a possible two-week extension. The president expressed doubts about Netanyahu's prospects for success, stating that none of the candidates have a real chance of forming a government. Netanyahu has been trying to break the stalemate by urging allies to join him in a conservative government, but his trial entered its second day as he faces bribery, breach of trust, and fraud charges.

site_title: Yellen declares end to Trump's global retreat, eyes tax deal
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has declared an end to the "global retreat" of the Trump era, outlining a case for a harmonized corporate tax rate across major economies to restore global leadership and credibility. Yellen's proposal, part of the Biden administration's $2.25 trillion infrastructure plan, aims to level the playing field for multinational corporations and promote innovation and growth. The US is leading global efforts to develop a minimum corporate tax agreement, with 140 countries involved, but negotiations remain challenging, with disagreements over digital taxation.

site_title: Civil contracts worth S$526m awarded to build four MRT stations
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded two civil contracts worth S$526 million to build four new MRT stations as part of the Jurong Region Line (JRL) project. The stations, including Jurong Hill, Jurong Pier, Nanyang Gateway, and Nanyang Crescent, are expected to reduce travel time for commuters by up to 30 minutes. Construction is set to begin this quarter, with completion expected in 2029.

site_title: Australia central bank cautions about housing boom as rates held at record lows
summary: Australia's central bank left interest rates at a record low of 0.1% as the housing market boomed, with prices soaring at the fastest pace in three decades in March. The Reserve Bank of Australia will monitor trends in property debt, urging lenders to maintain standards. Rates are expected to remain at 0.1% until at least 2024, and analysts predict stricter macro-prudential rules to rein in risky lending behavior.

site_title: Digital Realty's third data centre offers blueprint for future data centres in Singapore
summary: Digital Realty officially opened its third data centre in Singapore, Digital Loyang II or SIN12, which sets a blueprint for sustainable and productive data centre construction. The 50 MW facility, built using design for manufacturing and assembly technology, achieved a 30% productivity improvement and features sustainable design elements, including indirect evaporative cooling systems and lithium-ion batteries. The data centre is part of Digital Realty's efforts to increase sustainability, with the company aiming to achieve 70% design for manufacturing and assembly adoption by 2025 or earlier.

site_title: ST Engineering selected as partner to produce prototype vehicle for US Army
summary: ST Engineering and Oshkosh Defense have been selected by the US Army to participate in the prototype phase for the Cold Weather All-Terrain Vehicle (CATV), a tracked vehicle designed for extreme cold weather conditions. The two companies will deliver two prototypes, a general-purpose vehicle and a cargo vehicle, in the third quarter of FY21. The US Army plans to issue a follow-on production contract for up to 200 CATVs in FY22, replacing the Small Unit Support Vehicles (SUSVs) in service since the 1980s.

site_title: EasyJet CEO criticises testing requirements in Britain's travel restart plan
summary: EasyJet CEO Johan Lundgren criticized Britain's travel restart plan, citing unnecessary Covid-19 testing requirements for low-risk destinations. He argued that such tests would add to costs and complexities, potentially excluding those who cannot afford them. Lundgren expressed optimism that travel to popular destinations like Spain and Greece could resume by July and August, despite the UK government's current May 17 reopening date. EasyJet continues to discuss re-opening travel with the government.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on foreign buying, US recovery hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.20% on Tuesday, driven by foreign buying and optimism over US economic recovery. The Kospi index closed at 3,120.83, recovering from early declines. The won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: Italy's 'Dying Town' seeks UNESCO heritage nod
summary: Italy has nominated Civita di Bagnoregio, a town known as "The Dying Town" due to landslides and erosion, for a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The town, perched on a spur of cliffs, has resisted decline for centuries and boasts unique geological features. With a fragile ecosystem, the town's mayor aims to promote resilience and slow down erosion. The nomination is expected to be decided by UNESCO in June 2022, and local residents hope the recognition will help the town recover after the pandemic.

site_title: Sarcos Robotics plans SPAC deal for US$1.3b value
summary: Sarcos Robotics plans a US$1.3 billion reverse merger with SPAC Rotor Acquisition Corp, valuing the combined entity at US$1.3 billion including debt. The deal includes a potential earnout of US$280 million based on post-merger performance. Sarcos, a robot maker, will receive US$500 million from the transaction, and has raised US$220 million in private investment. The company, led by CEO Ben Wolff, develops wearable robotic systems for industrial and military workers.

site_title: BP hits US$35b net debt target well ahead of schedule
summary: BP, a London-based energy group, has hit its US$35 billion net debt target in the first quarter of 2021, exceeding expectations and paving the way for share buybacks. The company generated US$4.7 billion from sale proceeds, driven by strong trading, price environment, and resilient operations. This achievement is a result of earlier-than-anticipated disposal proceeds and will allow BP to deliver on its promise of buying back shares. The company's shares rose 3% to 299 pence, up 16% this year.

site_title: Credit Suisse estimates Archegos fallout at US$4.7b; overhauls executive board
summary: Credit Suisse announced an estimated loss of 4.4 billion Swiss francs (US$4.7 billion) from its relationship with Archegos Capital Management, a private investment vehicle that collapsed due to debt-laden bets on media companies. The bank also suspended a share buyback program, cut its proposed dividend, and overhauled its executive board, including the departure of its chief risk officer and investment banking head. The bank dumped over US$2 billion worth of stock to end exposure to Archegos, and its share price has fallen by a quarter in the past month.

site_title: No award of tender for Plot 7 Jalan Papan industrial site: JTC
summary: The Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) announced that the tender for Plot 7 Jalan Papan industrial site will not be awarded due to the lowest bid being below the reserve price. The tender was launched on Dec 29, 2020, and closed on Feb 23, 2021, with only two bids received. Plot 7 was the last of three confirmed list sites under the 2020 industrial government land sales programme, which proceeded according to schedule regardless of demand.

site_title: Air New Zealand, Qantas to ramp up Australia-NZ flights as bubble opens
summary: Air New Zealand and Qantas Airways plan to increase flights between Australia and New Zealand to at least 70% of pre-pandemic levels once a two-way quarantine-free travel bubble opens on April 19. The airlines aim to reduce their cash burn as they rely on domestic markets for revenue. Before the pandemic, Australia was New Zealand's largest tourism market, accounting for around 20% of Air New Zealand's revenue. The increased flights will help the airlines recover from the pandemic's impact on their revenue.

site_title: China asks banks to curtail credit for rest of year
summary: China's central bank has asked major lenders to curb loan growth for the rest of 2021, citing surge in bubble risks. The request, made at a meeting in March, aims to keep new advances stable and reasonable, with some foreign banks also urged to rein in lending. This move follows a record 19.6 trillion yuan in credit issued in 2020, and aims to curb risks in the financial and real estate sectors while boosting bank profitability.

site_title: SP Group building South-east Asia's first large-scale underground substation
summary: SP Group is constructing South-east Asia's first large-scale underground substation in Labrador, Singapore, freeing up 3 hectares of land for a 34-storey commercial development. The 230 kV substation will serve nearby towns and the Greater Southern Waterfront, with completion scheduled for 2024. The project aims to optimize space, reduce the risk of damage, and support Singapore's urban renewal plans and SDG goals for sustainable energy access.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, shedding 1.30% or 392.62 points from the benchmark Nikkei 225 index. The decline followed a three-day winning streak, with profit-taking emerging after recent gains. Japan's household spending for February fell 6.6% from a year ago, and trading was thin, indicating players were waiting for fresh factors. Key stocks including SoftBank Group, Renesas Electronics, Nissan, and Toyota also fell, while Nintendo gained 0.58%. The Nikkei index is expected to remain range-bound around 30,000 points.

site_title: Singapore firms' payment performance improves in Q1: SCCB
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance improved marginally in Q1 2021, with 42.50% of payments made on time, up 1.21 percentage points from the previous quarter. Slow payments rose to 43.08%, while partial payments decreased marginally to 14.42%. The construction sector saw a dip in slow payments, but the retail and services sectors saw an increase. SCCB CEO Audrey Chia attributed the improvement to expected economic activity growth in the coming months, expecting further payment performance improvement.

site_title: Myanmar protesters paint Yangon red
summary: Myanmar protesters have marked the deaths of hundreds of people killed by troops with red paint on roads in Yangon, amid a nearly two-month-long crisis following the military coup on February 1. Over 570 people have been killed and 3,500 arrested, with security forces halting broadband internet and blocking mobile data services to hamper organization. Demonstrators have held marches, civil disobedience campaigns, and called for international intervention, with authorities issuing arrest warrants for celebrities and influencers. The crisis has sparked international outrage and raised concerns about the fate of detained leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: Australia: Tech, travel stocks lift shares to 1-1/2-month closing high
summary: Australia's shares ended at a 1-1/2 month high on Tuesday, driven by travel stocks after a travel bubble was announced between the country and New Zealand, while tech stocks jumped to their highest level in a month. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8% to 6,885.90 points, led by gains from Cleanaway Waste Management, Qantas Airways, and Afterpay. Tech stocks rose over 5% to their highest level since February 25, with the central bank keeping interest rates at an all-time low until at least 2024.

site_title: Legislation for alternative arrangements for meetings to extend beyond June 2021: MinLaw
summary: The Ministry of Law (MinLaw) has announced an extension of legislation allowing entities to hold meetings via electronic means beyond June 30, 2021. The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) (Alternative Arrangements for Meetings) (Meetings Orders) will continue to be in force until revoked or amended. MinLaw will give at least six months' notice before alternative arrangements cease to be available to provide certainty for entities. This move aims to cater to entities that have relied on the Meetings Orders for early preparations. The duration of the legislation will be determined by the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) (Control Order) Regulations 2020.

site_title: StashFin raises US$40m in Series B extension equity financing
summary: StashFin, a Singapore-based neobanking startup, has raised US$40 million in Series B extension equity financing from global investors. The funding will be used to pursue neobanking across South Asia, grow existing markets, and strengthen its customer platform for local languages. Existing investors, including Tencent Cloud Europe BV, also participated in the round. This latest funding follows "explosive growth" seen by StashFin over the last few years, according to Altara Ventures general partner Koh Boon Hwee.

site_title: Shell invests in sustainable aviation-fuel maker LanzaJet
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc has invested in sustainable-fuels technology company LanzaJet, adding to its expansion into clean energy. LanzaJet is building an "alcohol-to-jet" facility in Georgia with capacity to produce 10 million gallons of sustainable aviation fuel per year. The deal is part of Shell's efforts to create a broader range of technology pathways for sustainable aviation fuels, with CEO Anna Mascolo stating that SAF at pace and scale is critical for the industry. This investment follows recent purchases by Shell, positioning the oil giant for the energy transition.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell Plc has invested in sustainable-fuels technology company LanzaJet, adding to a string of deals positioning the oil giant for the energy transition.

site_title: FMCG growth to be reignited in Asia: NielsenIQ
summary: NielsenIQ Asia predicts FMCG growth to pick up and "normalise" in Asia this year, reversing a flat (-0.1%) growth in 2020. Despite a 40% decline in India in April 2020, the country's overall growth returned to 8% by the end of the year. The company identifies five key trends for growth: convenience, homebound services, alternative products, natural blends, and eco-friendliness. Asian consumers now prioritize value for money, safety, and hygiene when shopping, with online shopping also becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: Taiwan's Acer sees global chip shortage gradually easing
summary: Taiwan's Acer reports that a global chip shortage for mid-end consumer products is easing, with better supplies expected in the second half of the year. The shortage, initially concentrated in the auto industry, has spread to various consumer electronics. Acer's president, Andrew Hou, notes that suppliers have worked to address the issue, and sales in the Pan-Asia Pacific region are booming. The shortage stems from a combination of factors, including the pandemic and increased demand for electronic products, with the main issue being the lack of mid-range chips.

site_title: Gold hits over one-week high as dollar, yields slip
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to a one-week high of $1,735.30 per ounce, driven by a weaker dollar and declining US bond yields. The dollar hit a two-week low versus rival currencies, making gold cheaper for international buyers. Investors sought riskier assets amid strong US economic data and hopes of a swift recovery. Analysts predict gold could struggle to extend last week's recovery, with a break above $1,750 needed to continue its upward trend.

site_title: Jeep sales climbing in Japan as younger people warm to the brand
summary: Jeep sales in Japan are expected to increase 5% this year to over 15,000 units, driven by younger buyers drawn to the brand's rugged appearance and outdoor capabilities. The company has successfully adapted to the Japanese market with right-hand drive models and a strong social media presence. Jeep has retained a loyal customer base, with sales up 36% in March compared to the same period last year. Fiat Chrysler Japan plans to introduce new models, including the Grand Cherokee, Compass, and Gladiator, although chip availability may impact the schedule.

site_title: India food delivery firm Swiggy gets US$800m in funding
summary: Swiggy, an Indian food delivery firm, has secured US$800 million in funding from investors including Falcon Edge Capital LP and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. The funding round was heavily subscribed and will speed up growth in existing businesses and seed new ones. Swiggy's valuation is expected to reach nearly US$5 billion. The company competes with other food delivery startups, including Zomato and Amazon's India unit, and has driven a strong recovery in the food delivery business with a clear path to profitability.

site_title: Air France-KLM gets 4b euro rescue; France to raise stake
summary: Air France-KLM has received up to 4 billion euros in a rescue package, with the French government potentially increasing its stake to 30% as part of a recapitalization plan. The airline will receive 1 billion euros in fresh capital and convert a 3 billion-euro loan into hybrid instruments. In exchange, Air France will give up 18 daily slots at Orly airport. The deal aims to support the airline after being severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Baby stocks face shake-up in Japan as Suga turns to childcare
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is set to form a new "Children's Agency" to oversee childcare and education policies, amid the country's low fertility rate. The move has boosted shares in baby stocks, with Youji Corp's shares nearly doubling. The policy is expected to become a core feature of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's manifesto for a lower house election this year. Suga aims to strengthen policy for infants and children, with the goal of breaking down administrative silos and promoting Japan's future. The agency's establishment is seen as a key feature of Suga's administration.

site_title: KKR raises US$15b in Asia's biggest fund as buyout-backed deals rise
summary: KKR has raised US$15 billion for its fourth Asia-Pacific focused fund, the region's largest private equity fund. The fund will invest in opportunities from rising consumer spending, urbanization trends, and corporate carve-outs. This follows a 51% increase in private equity-backed deals in Asia to a record US$129 billion last year. KKR's fund will tap into the growing technology sector and received strong support from global investors, including Asia Pacific-based investors. The fund's hard cap was exceeded, exceeding initial target of US$12.5 billion.

site_title: Trendlines Group receives letter of intent for acquisition of portfolio company
summary: Trendlines Group announced a non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of a portfolio company by a public corporation. The acquisition is expected to positively impact the group's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the 2021 financial year. Trendlines Group's minimum share of the sale proceeds is estimated to be approximately S$19 million.

site_title: Apple chief Tim Cook talks of autonomous cars
summary: Apple chief Tim Cook expressed interest in autonomous cars during an interview with the New York Times. Cook stated that self-driving cars align with Apple's technology, but did not confirm plans for an Apple-branded autonomous vehicle. This revelation comes amidst rumors surrounding Apple's potential entry into the autonomous vehicle market. Cook's comments suggest Apple may explore the development of autonomous cars, but no specific timeline or details were provided.

site_title: Inquiry in France over 'clandestine' Covid-defying dinners
summary: A French investigation has been launched into alleged "clandestine" luxury dinners in Paris during the pandemic, with reports claiming politicians and government officials attended without following health rules. A hidden camera caught staff at a high-end restaurant in Paris not wearing masks, despite the country's lockdown. The investigation will assess if the dinners were organized in defiance of health rules and determine who were involved. Several government officials have denied attending such events, but the scandal has sparked public outrage and calls for accountability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Tuesday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.03% to 1,584.8 at Tuesday's open, with 769.6 million lots traded worth RM280.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 313 to 234.

site_title: Australia-NZ 'travel bubble' to begin April 19 in pandemic milestone
summary: New Zealand will allow quarantine-free visits by Australians starting April 19, creating a "travel bubble" between the two countries. This move comes after both nations have effectively eradicated COVID-19, with minor outbreaks attributed to leaked travelers. The decision marks a significant milestone in the pandemic, allowing for increased travel between the neighboring nations.

site_title: Six in 10 in Singapore open to Sora-based loans, products: poll
summary: More than 60% of Singaporeans are open to choosing Sora-based loans and products, citing the interest rate benchmark's stability and certainty. The survey, conducted by UOB, found that 70% would apply for Sora-pegged products within 6-12 months of their availability. Financial institutions will stop referencing the Swap Offer Rate (SOR) by April and the Singapore Interbank Offer Rate (Sibor) by September to shift to a Sora-centred interest rate market. UOB launched Singapore's first dual tranche Sora-SOFR corporate loan in September last year and Sora-based residential and commercial property loan solutions in December.

site_title: New IMF reserves could fund vaccinations for low, middle-income countries: report
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is considering a new allocation of $650 billion in Special Drawing Rights (SDR) to help countries cope with the pandemic and its economic fallout. This move could provide $44 billion to vaccinate 70% of the population in low- and middle-income countries by the end of 2022, at no added cost to rich countries. The allocation could also fund other measures to help poor and middle-income countries, such as debt service moratoriums and low- or no-interest loans.

images.alt_text: Moves to bolster the IMF's emergency reserves could provide the US$44 billion needed to vaccinate 70 per cent of the population in lower- and middle-income countries by the end of 2022, at no added cost to rich countries, a new Rockefeller Foundation report finds.

site_title: US pushing G20 for global minimum corporate tax: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is pushing for a global minimum corporate tax to stem government revenue erosion and promote a level playing field in taxation. The US is seeking a 21% minimum tax rate for multinationals, with the US corporate tax rate set to increase to 28%. The G20 finance ministers are expected to discuss the proposal during a virtual meeting on Wednesday. A global minimum tax agreement would complement ongoing OECD negotiations and give the US a stronger presence in international economic cooperation.

site_title: North Korea says it will skip Tokyo Olympics due to Covid-19
summary: North Korea has decided not to participate in the Tokyo Olympics due to the coronavirus, citing the need to protect its athletes amid the global health crisis. The decision was made by the country's Olympics committee on March 25. This move is a significant one, as it could make North Korea the first major country to skip the games because of the pandemic. The country has previously been cautious about participating in international events, having imposed strict measures to prevent the coronavirus from entering the country.

site_title: Migration in focus for US envoy's trip to Central America
summary: US President Joe Biden's special envoy, Ricardo Zuñiga, began a two-nation tour of Central America to address soaring migration. Zuñiga met with Guatemalan President Alejandro Giammattei on Monday, focusing on economic development, security, and immigration. The visit comes as the number of US-bound migrants has increased, with over 171,000 caught along the US-Mexico border in March, the highest monthly total in two decades. Zuñiga will also visit El Salvador later this week, with further talks planned in Washington on April 9.

site_title: OCBC Wealth Insights: Is Asia ex-Japan a risky investment proposition?
summary: OCBC Wealth Insights examines the market outlook for Asia ex-Japan, a region considered risky for investment. Mr. Vasu Menon, Executive Director of Investment Strategy at OCBC Bank, shares his insights. Key factors influencing the region's performance include economic growth, inflation, and monetary policies. Menon notes that while Asia ex-Japan is a high-growth region, its volatility and debt levels pose risks. A balanced approach is recommended, with a focus on quality companies and diversification. Menon cautions investors to stay vigilant and adapt to changing market conditions. The outlook remains positive but with a cautious tone.

site_title: Hot stock: Trendlines up 15.3% after letter of intent for portfolio company
summary: The Trendlines Group shares surged to an eight-month high after the company received a non-binding letter of intent for the acquisition of a portfolio company by a public corporation. The shares rose 15.3% to an intraday high of 11.3 Singapore cents. If a definitive agreement is signed, the deal is expected to positively impact Trendlines' net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2021. The minimum share of the sale proceeds to be received in cash is estimated to be about S$19 million, but there is no assurance the LOI will be executed.

site_title: Mark Cuban-backed Singapore NFT startup Mintable closes seed round
summary: Mintable, a Singapore-based non-fungible token (NFT) marketplace platform backed by billionaire investor Mark Cuban, has closed its undisclosed seed round. Investors participating in the round include prominent venture capital firms such as CRC Capital and Sound Ventures. Following the fundraise, Mintable aims to spearhead the mainstream adoption of NFTs in 2021.

site_title: Australia job ads jump to 12-year high in March: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements surged to a 12-year high in March, with a 7.4% growth from February, reaching 190,542. This increase suggests the labor market's recovery can withstand the removal of emergency support programs. ANZ economist Catherine Birch estimates that 100,000-150,000 people will lose employment, but expects net losses to be smaller due to growing labor demand. Unemployment has fallen to 5.8% and is expected to remain rapid in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Rise of the 'robo-plants', as scientists fuse nature with tech
summary: Scientists in Singapore have developed a high-tech system to communicate with plants using electrodes that detect the weak electrical pulses naturally emitted by vegetation. This technology, which includes a remote-controlled Venus flytrap, could be used to build "plant-based robots" that can pick up fragile objects and detect problems with crops at an early stage. The system can stimulate the flytrap's jaws to slam shut but cannot yet reopen them, and researchers believe it could be particularly useful in detecting diseases in crops facing threats from climate change.

site_title: US lawmakers push for removal of UK, EU whiskey tariffs
summary: US lawmakers, led by John Yarmuth and Andy Barr, have urged US Trade Representative Katherine Tai to remove 25% tariffs on American Whiskey imposed by the EU and UK in retaliation for US tariffs on steel and aluminum. The tariffs have led to a 37% decline in US whiskey exports to the EU and a 53% decline to the UK. The lawmakers warn that the tariffs will cause irreparable harm to US whiskey distillers, including craft distillers in every US state. They hope for a global solution to reduce excess production capacity and support the recovery of affected industries.

site_title: Starbucks to eliminate disposable cups in South Korea by 2025
summary: Starbucks plans to eliminate disposable cups in South Korea by 2025, as part of its "cup circularity" programme. The Seattle-based chain will launch reusable cups with a small deposit, refundable at contactless kiosks. This move follows South Korea's revised laws limiting plastic and disposable items, and comes as the company shifts away from sustainability efforts amid health concerns. Starbucks has over 1,500 stores in South Korea, its fifth-largest market, and aims to reduce its global refuse and carbon footprint.

site_title: South Korea property woes could turn tide against Moon in by-elections
summary: South Korea's soaring home prices and widening wealth inequality are fueling opposition support in by-elections, potentially turning the tide against President Moon Jae-in's economic agenda. The overheated housing market, a global phenomenon, is seen as a crucial factor in the elections, which could mark a turning point for Moon's plans to increase public employment and fiscal spending. Losing key cities like Seoul and Busan to opposition candidates could signal a decline in Moon's popularity, making it his last year in office.

site_title: Trump urges court to throw out congressional subpoena to Mazars
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is urging a federal judge to dismiss a Congressional subpoena for his financial records, calling it unconstitutional and unenforceable. Trump's lawyers argue that the subpoena is too broad and only seeks president-specific information. The subpoena was ordered by the House Oversight committee after the Supreme Court ruled that congressional subpoenas seeking the president's personal information must be "no broader than reasonably necessary". This is part of a complex series of legal battles centered on Trump's tax information, which he has refused to release.

site_title: Tharman warns home buyers about rising rates
summary: Singapore's government, led by Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) chairman and Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, is warning home buyers to exercise caution due to rising interest rates. The US long-term rates increase may boost debt servicing costs, potentially affecting a small percentage of households in the private property market. Despite this, MAS analysis suggests that the median household's mortgage servicing ratio remains manageable. Tharman advises buyers to assume interest rates will rise and be sure of their ability to service loans before making long-term financial commitments.

site_title: Private equity sees shale escape route by building cash flow
summary: Private equity firms, which heavily invested in shale oil and gas, are seeing a potential escape route by acquiring private companies with strong cash flow. Pioneer Natural Resources Co's $6.4 billion deal to buy DoublePoint Energy LLC is the largest acquisition of a closely held oil company since 2011. The strategy, which involves flipping private equity-backed explorers to giant public companies for quick profits, has collapsed due to debt-fuelled drillers contributing to a global crude glut. The deal is seen as a test of a healthy company with ample inventory pursuing an acquisition, and may pave the way for other private equity-backed companies to be acquired.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at Tuesday's open, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 9.74 points to 3,219.48, with Sembcorp Marine and Oceanus being the most actively traded counters. Local banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS also gained ground. The US stock market finished at fresh records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all reaching new highs, driven by signs of an accelerating US recovery and increasing Covid-19 vaccinations.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong and Thailand are closed on Tuesday for public holidays. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. Singapore stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Recruitment firm Glints raises US$22.5m led by Tokyo-listed Persol Holdings
summary: Glints, a Singapore-based recruitment firm, has raised US$22.5 million in a Series C round led by Tokyo-listed Persol Holdings. The funding will be used to build features and solutions on its talent platform, deepen its presence in Southeast Asia, and expand its product and engineering teams. The company has seen significant growth, with revenue more than doubling in 2020 and annual revenues growing at triple-digit percentages for the past three years. Glints' clients include major companies such as Gojek, Starbucks, and Mediacorp, and the platform has achieved a 28-day hiring average, significantly cheaper than industry standards.

site_title: World's biggest solar company joins the hydrogen game
summary: Longi Green Energy Technology Co, the world's largest solar company, has registered Xi'an Longi Hydrogen Technology Co in China, marking its entry into the hydrogen market. The company's billionaire founder and president, Li Zhenguo, serves as chairman. Longi plans to produce hydrogen through electrolysis of water powered by renewable energy, aiming to reduce costs and scale up production. This move is seen as a key step in reducing carbon emissions and meeting global climate change targets, with Li stating that his company will invest in research and development to achieve this goal.

site_title: Samurai dance teacher moves online as Tokyo Olympics bans foreign spectators
summary: A Japanese dance teacher, Koshiro Minamoto, who specializes in teaching Bugaku, a unique performance art combining samurai sword play and classical Japanese drama, is adapting his business to the Tokyo Olympics' ban on foreign spectators. Minamoto had prepared to welcome tourists with in-person classes but now holds online classes on Zoom, reaching students from Europe and the US. While the online experience lacks direct correction and hands-on techniques, Minamoto charges $85 for in-person and $18 for online classes. He acknowledges the shift but remains committed to sharing the arts of the samurai.

site_title: Audio app Clubhouse floats payment feature for creators
summary: Clubhouse, an audio-chat app, is launching a payment feature for creators, allowing users to send payments through the platform. The feature, initially available to a small test group, will hold a minor card processing fee. The move aims to monetize the platform, which saw significant growth after high-profile discussions between Elon Musk and Vlad Tenev. The feature will be rolled out to other users in waves, and Clubhouse will not receive any payment from it.

site_title: BlackRock breaks Wall Street ranks with planned racial audit
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, plans to conduct an independent racial audit of its operations following a shareholder request. This move comes after similar steps taken by companies like Airbnb and Facebook, but contrasts with peers like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, which have voted against proposals calling for audits. The audit aims to assess BlackRock's impact on racial inequities in the financial system and address the racial wealth gap. The review will be conducted by a third-party group and will start in 2022.

site_title: Oil falls more than 4% on rising Opec+ supply, Covid-19 spikes
summary: Oil prices fell 4% on Monday, with Brent crude settling at $62.15 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate at $58.65 a barrel, amid rising Opec+ supply and the threat of another severe Covid-19 wave. Opec+ agreed to increase production monthly from May to July, while Iran boosts supply. The strong economic rebound in the US is countered by these factors, indicating a bearish market outlook.

images.alt_text: Oil fell 4 per cent a barrel on Monday, as rising output from Opec+ and the threat of another severe Covid-19 wave countered signs of a strong economic rebound in the United States.

site_title: Dollar falls with most Treasury yields amid scepticism on Fed
summary: The US dollar slid against most major peers as the 5-year Treasury yield pulled back from a one-year high amid skepticism about the strength of US economic data. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dropped 0.4% to its lowest in two weeks. The reversal occurred despite a record high March ISM Services Index and gains for US stocks. The Federal Reserve's shift in interest rates is being questioned, leading to a decrease in Treasury yields.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares gain after Wall Street rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.3% in early trade on Tuesday, driven by Wall Street's rally to a record finish on optimism for US recovery. The Nikkei 225 index gained 94.75 points to 30,184.00, while the Topix index rose 0.04% to 1,984.32. The gains followed US stocks' record close, despite tariff threats.

site_title: Japan Airlines to retire 13 Boeing 777 planes after United incident
summary: Japan Airlines has retired 13 Boeing 777 planes with Pratt & Whitney engines a year earlier than planned due to concerns over metal fatigue. The move follows a US Federal Aviation Administration order to inspect the planes after a cracked fan blade was found on a United Airlines flight. The Japanese airline will use Airbus A350s on domestic routes and international planes for other domestic routes to maintain flight frequencies. This decision comes amid lower flying demand worldwide due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Japan Airlines (JAL) said it had retired its fleet of 13 Boeing 777s with Pratt & Whitney (P&W) engines a year earlier than planned, having suspended operations in February after an engine on a United Airlines plane shed debris.

site_title: Tesla's 'home run' quarter shows China, Europe bet paying off
summary: Tesla delivered 184,800 electric vehicles worldwide in Q1, exceeding analyst estimates of 169,850 and beating the fourth-quarter figure by 4,000 vehicles. This marks a strong start to the year for the company, with CEO Elon Musk counting on global growth to scale up production and sales. The results suggest Musk's bet on China and Europe is paying off, with the company's volume in these regions standing apart from most automakers facing electronic-chip constraints.

site_title: Singapore hedge fund targets billions for trade finance
summary: A Singapore hedge fund, TradeFlow Capital Management, has partnered with the International Chamber of Commerce to launch a new fund for small firms financing physical commodity trades. The fund aims to bridge a US$1.5 trillion gap in trade finance for small businesses, with a typical transaction size of US$200,000. TradeFlow has posted steady gains since its formation in 2018 and will be sold to Supply@ME Capital. The partnership will help ease access to trade finance for small businesses worldwide, representing 45 million companies across 100 countries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Trendlines, PropNex, Aspen, New Silkroutes, KSH, Straits Trading
summary: The Trendlines Group announced a non-binding letter of intent for a potential acquisition that could positively impact its net tangible assets and earnings per share. PropNex acquired a 70% stake in online marketplace Ovvy for S$1 million. Aspen Holdings received a 100% investment tax allowance grant from Malaysia's finance ministry, granting it an income tax exemption. New Silkroutes Group signed a non-binding agreement to design and develop a cloud-based AI platform. KSH Holdings clinched a S$171.8 million contract for a biomedical sciences development. The Straits Trading Company's shares rose after a subsidiary acquired JL Family Office's 10% stake in Straits Real Estate for S$105 million.

site_title: Fed should be 'deliberately patient' on policy, Mester says
summary: Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank President Loretta Mester stated that the US economic outlook is brightening, but the economy remains nearly 8.5 million jobs short of employment levels in February 2020. Mester advised the Fed to be "deliberately patient" in its approach to monetary policy, sticking to its easy monetary policy to support growth further. She expects higher inflation readings over coming months but believes price increases won't be sustained. The Fed aims to keep interest rates near zero until full employment and 2% inflation are reached.

site_title: Automakers want aid set aside for car-grade US chip production
summary: Automakers are urging Congress to set aside a portion of the $52 billion funding approved for the CHIPS for America Act to support vehicle-grade chip production. The industry projects a potential 1.3 million vehicle shortfall in the US this year due to the global semiconductor shortage. The Alliance for Automotive Innovation, representing major automakers, suggests using some of the funding to build new capacity for auto-grade chips and mitigate supply chain risks.

site_title: Credit Suisse starts unloading stocks linked to Archegos
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG started unloading stocks tied to Archegos Capital, a fund that imploded after heavily leveraged bets went wrong. The bank sold over $2 billion worth of ViacomCBS, Vipshop Holdings, and Farfetch shares, trading at significantly lower prices than before. Credit Suisse's losses could run into the billions of dollars, but the bank's CEO Thomas Gottstein is spared from removal. The move comes after rivals, including Nomura Holdings, also dumped Archegos-related shares to avoid losses.

site_title: Samudera Shipping riding the Covid-19 tide
summary: Samudera Shipping Line, a container shipping company, has seen its shares rise 26% this year, reaching a 52-week high of 31.5 Singapore cents, due to the surge in e-commerce sales and port congestion caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Analysts, including Lim & Tan, believe the company remains undervalued, with a target price of 49 cents and an upside potential of 55.5%. Samudera's healthy balance sheet and steady dividend payments also support its stock price, with some analysts predicting a significant increase in net profit to US$20 million in FY2021.

site_title: Gold steadies amid recovery optimism after US jobs report
summary: Gold prices steadied amid optimism over the US jobs report, which showed a 916,000 job increase in March, fueling growth expectations and boosting stocks. The report countered a weakening dollar, causing the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index to fall 0.3%. Despite this, gold prices remain bearish, with holdings in bullion-backed ETFs at a three-week low. The global economy's fast recovery is expected to make it difficult for gold to gain traction, according to economist Howie Lee.

site_title: Efforts taken to ramp up manpower supply for construction sector
summary: Singapore's construction sector is ramping up efforts to address manpower shortages, with 1,100 notifications for relief from Covid-19 measures received as of March 19, with 180 applying for assessor's determination. The government has extended the relief period until September 30, and is working with industry players to retain experienced workers and establish better upstream processes. Most developers are on track to meet delivery possession dates, but those struggling are encouraged to discuss mutually agreeable arrangements with purchasers.

site_title: Saudis hike oil prices for key Asia market in sign of confidence
summary: Saudi Arabia raised oil prices for key Asia market, signaling confidence in the region's economic recovery. The increase, expected to be between 20-50 US cents per barrel, follows the Opec+ cartel's agreement to boost daily crude production by over 2 million barrels from May to July. The move aims to stabilize prices after several months of Asia prices being above those for Europe and the US. Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman emphasized the need for caution until the global economic recovery is complete.

site_title: Pick Network not created to stifle competition in parcel locker sector, says Sim Ann
summary: Singapore's government-owned Pick Network, set to operate the country's parcel locker system, was not created to stifle competition, Senior Minister Sim Ann told Parliament. The network, which will have 1,000 locker stations, will complement existing locker offerings from private operators, not compete with them. The IMDA subsidiary aims to improve efficiency and provide open access to the network. Some MPs raised concerns about potential dominance and market consolidation, but Sim Ann emphasized the need for a neutral operator to ensure open access.

site_title: Japanese luxury hot spring resorts operator eyeing US locations
summary: Hoshino Resorts, a 107-year-old Japanese luxury hot spring resort operator, plans to open its first facility on the US mainland in 3-5 years. CEO Yoshiharu Hoshino aims to bring traditional Japanese hot spring resorts to North America, citing the existing culture of visiting hot springs for relaxation. The company has scouted locations, including Saratoga Springs, and will seek a partner to build a new facility. This move is expected to attract Americans seeking a unique cultural experience, and Hoshino Resorts plans to resume its search once COVID-19 curbs ease.

site_title: China tests Biden with South China Sea tactic that misled Obama
summary: China has deployed hundreds of fishing boats to a disputed reef in the South China Sea, prompting the Philippines to issue daily diplomatic protests. The move is seen as a test of US President Joe Biden's commitment to deter Chinese assertiveness in the region. Beijing claims the boats are taking shelter from the wind, but the US describes it as a "maritime militia" tactic. The Philippines is limited in its options, with President Rodrigo Duterte's administration seeking to balance its ties with China while maintaining its alliance with the US. China's actions are raising concerns about its intentions and the potential for escalation.

site_title: Phuket in mass vaccination drive ahead of rest of Thailand
summary: Thailand's resort island of Phuket is launching a mass vaccination drive ahead of the rest of the country, aiming to inoculate at least 460,000 people by July 1. The move prioritizes tourism, which accounts for 11-12% of the country's GDP, and is seen as a key step towards reopening to vaccinated overseas visitors without quarantine requirements. The goal is to build immunity for 70-80% of the island's population, allowing tourists to visit freely without posing a risk to the rest of Thailand.

site_title: Is America's longest military engagement finally over?
summary: The US war in Afghanistan, launched by President George W Bush in 2001, has become the longest military engagement in American history. Despite promises from Democratic and Republican presidents to end the conflict, US troops have remained in the country for over two decades, with President Joe Biden acknowledging that it's unlikely the US will leave Afghanistan in 2022. The war has expanded into a series of US military interventions in the Middle East, and the US continues to station around 50,000 soldiers in the region. The US has largely lost the war, and negotiations with the Taliban aim to provide a cover for an "honourable" American exit without a humiliating defeat.

site_title: Singa infrastructure bonds seen soon, with strict safeguards
summary: The Singapore government plans to issue infrastructure bonds, known as Singa, to fund major public projects. The bonds will be issued under a strict framework that includes legislative safeguards to ensure proceeds are used responsibly and sustainably. To qualify, projects must be owned and controlled by the government, cost at least S$4 billion, and be available for use for at least 50 years. The government has set a gross borrowing limit of S$90 billion over 15 years and an annual interest threshold of S$5 billion. The first issuance is expected in the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: Vaccination bookings to begin in June for those under 45: Janil Puthucheary
summary: Singapore residents under 45 are likely to be invited to book their Covid-19 vaccinations starting in June, according to Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary. The country aims to complete its national vaccination program by the end of the year, with 1.52 million vaccine doses administered and 1.05 million people receiving at least one dose. Supplies are limited due to high global demand, and authorities will evaluate high-risk individuals, including religious workers. The Health Ministry plans to conduct further studies to monitor vaccine efficacy.

images.alt_text: As at April 3, about 1.52 million Covid-19 vaccine doses have been administered in Singapore.

site_title: SAG Awards go to The Trial of the Chicago 7, Chadwick Boseman, Viola Davis
summary: The Trial of the Chicago 7 won the SAG Award for best cast in a motion picture, following a decade of films that took the award and went on to win the Oscar for best picture. Chadwick Boseman won best-actor for Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, while Viola Davis won best-actress for the same film. Daniel Kaluuya won supporting-actor for Judas and the Black Messiah. These wins could give The Trial of the Chicago 7 momentum for the Oscars.

site_title: LG Electronics to exit smartphone market
summary: LG Electronics to exit smartphone market after nearly six years of losses totaling $4.5 billion. The move will allow the company to focus on growth areas, leaving its 10% share in North America vulnerable to Samsung Electronics and Apple. LG will be the first major smartphone brand to completely withdraw from the market, relinquishing its No. 3 position in the US.

site_title: SoftBank mints new unicorn in Indian social commerce app
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund 2 led a $300 million funding round for Bengaluru-based social commerce startup Meesho Inc, valuing the company at $2.1 billion. Existing investors Prosus Ventures and Facebook participated in the round, which will be used to strengthen Meesho's talent pool. The platform, which serves over 13 million individual entrepreneurs, aims to expand e-commerce to smaller cities and towns. The investment adds to the growing number of Indian unicorns and follows SoftBank's confidence in the transformative potential of artificial intelligence.

site_title: S$3.9m lab for TCM research
summary: A*Star has opened a new laboratory, valued at S$3.9m, in collaboration with ChemoPower Technology to investigate the chemical composition of traditional medicinal herbs used in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). The laboratory aims to aid scientists in understanding the quality and authenticity of TCM products.

site_title: Can we prevent the global fire next time?
summary: The article discusses whether the global economy can prevent a similar crisis like the 2008 financial meltdown. Despite policymakers' efforts to stabilize the global economy during the COVID-19 pandemic, there are four reasons to believe progress may be slower and more difficult. These include the ongoing crisis in many countries, differing national responses to the pandemic, the high cost of healthcare, and the limited access to global health data. The article concludes that preventing future crises will require sustained global cooperation and investment in public health infrastructure.

site_title: Chip shortage putting the brakes on Singapore car dealers, part makers
summary: A global semiconductor shortage is affecting car manufacturers and dealers worldwide, including those in Singapore. Major car makers such as Ford, Nissan, and Volkswagen have paused or cut production due to the shortage, which has also impacted orders for Singapore-based car component manufacturers. The shortage, caused by increased demand for consumer electronics during the pandemic, is expected to worsen until early 2022, with some manufacturers prioritizing production of best-selling models over less popular ones.

site_title: Logistics bottlenecks still an issue for coffee players, but local companies slightly more insulated
summary: The Suez Canal blockage, caused by the Ever Given, is expected to delay the easing of shipping supply constraints in the second quarter of 2021, affecting the coffee industry. Local companies such as Bacha Coffee and Joe & Dough have few concerns about supplies due to their diversified sourcing and stockpiling strategies. Food Empire Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, may face minimal impact from the blockage, with analyst Jarick Seet predicting temporary higher freight costs and potential delays in shipments.

site_title: URA extends Jalan Anak Bukit site's tender deadline to June 29
summary: The tender for a 3.22-hectare site along Jalan Anak Bukit in Singapore has been extended to June 29, 2021, due to a new requirement for a centralised cooling system to serve a future mixed-use integrated transport hub. The site, which can yield about 845 private homes, was initially set to close on March 30, 2021. The extended deadline aims to give developers more time to consider their proposals in line with the Singapore Green Plan 2030 objectives.

site_title: Shopee to help SMEs upskill via SkillsFuture Queen Bee programme
summary: Shopee has partnered SkillsFuture Singapore to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) upskill their operations and expand into e-commerce through the SkillsFuture Queen Bee programme. As part of the partnership, Shopee will support 30 SME sellers with a skills manager and create a skills support ecosystem to help them excel in e-commerce. The programme aims to equip entrepreneurs and SMEs with the relevant skills and capabilities to accelerate their digital transformation.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway marketing yen bonds
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is marketing a multi-tranche yen bond deal, offering notes for a four-part deal that may price on Thursday. The proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, targeting a 5-year bond at 17-20 basis points over mid-swaps, equivalent to a 0.2% coupon. Berkshire Hathaway sold 430 billion yen in its inaugural deal in 2019, and plans to hold its Japanese trading house investments for the long term, potentially increasing its holding to 9.9%. The company also plans to refinance $1 billion of maturing notes.

site_title: Goldman axes short-dollar call as US yields spoil bet
summary: Goldman Sachs has closed its short-dollar position, joining other investors in ending bearish bets on the US currency after surging Treasury yields triggered a rebound. The recommendation was made nearly six months ago and would have netted a 5% gain, but the trade has been "roughly flat" since the start of the year. The firm still expects currencies to appreciate versus the dollar over the coming quarters, but sees opportunities to short the US currency potentially re-emerging if Europe's pandemic situation improves.

site_title: Sabana Reit's response to Quarz, Black Crane reflects box-ticking culture that pervades market
summary: Sabana Reit's manager responded to demands from minority investors, Quarz and Black Crane, to bear the cost of a failed merger with ESR-Reit. The manager claimed that minority investors should pay for the deal, citing due process and regulations. However, critics argue that the manager failed to address minority investors' concerns and actively recommended the merger despite opposition. The manager's response reflects a "box-ticking" culture that prioritizes corporate interests over minority investors' needs. A more proactive and independent approach could have resulted in a better outcome for unitholders.

site_title: Rebuilding trust in independent directors
summary: Singapore's corporate governance framework has strengthened the proportion of independent directors, but the appointment and election process remains a major contributor to the lack of true independence. The country's hybrid approach to determining independence, which relies on the practice guidance of the latest Code, is less prescriptive compared to other Asian markets. Implementing cumulative voting for directors, allowing minority shareholders to appoint IDs, and making the criteria for determining independence more prescriptive could enhance the independence of IDs. Robust enforcement against directors for breaches of duties is also crucial in building trust in IDs.

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs replacing risk chief in looming executive shake-up
summary: Credit Suisse is considering replacing its chief risk officer, Lara Warner, amid billions of dollars in losses from the collapse of Archegos Capital Management, according to people briefed on the matter. The bank's CEO, Thomas Gottstein, is expected to be spared, while investment bank chief Brian Chin may face pressure due to the Archegos losses. A review of the bank's prime brokerage business is also planned. The bank's stock has been the worst-performing major bank stock this year, and S&P Global Ratings has downgraded its outlook to negative due to risk management concerns.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings' subsidiary, Aspen Glove, received a 100% investment tax allowance grant from Malaysia's finance ministry, allowing it to exempt income tax for designing, developing, and manufacturing nitrile gloves. New Silkroutes Group signed a non-binding agreement with Acclivis Technologies to design a cloud-based AI platform for genomic-driven healthcare. PropNex is set to acquire a 70% stake in online marketplace Ovvy for S$1 million, expanding its proptech footprint.

site_title: Malaysia accepts 14% higher cost due to longer route in China-led rail project
summary: Malaysia has accepted a 14% increase in the estimated construction cost of the East Coast Rail Link (ECRL) project, now totaling RM50 billion. The revised 665km route is longer than the original 640km, but the project is still expected to be completed within seven years, with services starting in 2027. Transport Minister Wee Ka Siong stated that the changes enhance the project's viability and provide economic, environmental, and social benefits. Construction is currently 21.4% complete.

site_title: Singapore PMI climbs to 50.8 in March, highest since March 2019
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded at a rate of 50.8 in March, the highest since March 2019, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management (SIPMM). The sector has been expanding for nine consecutive months. The electronics sector also saw expansion, albeit at a slower rate of 50.6. However, ongoing supply chain disruptions, including the Suez Canal blockage, are expected to impact the sector, with delivery costs and margins under pressure. Manufacturing growth is forecast to remain at 4% in the first half of the year.

site_title: Changing hands
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US stocks fell from records amid tariff threats, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore court delays decision on Hin Leong founder's assets freeze: sources
summary: A Singapore court has delayed a decision on freezing the assets of Lim Oon Kuin and his two children due to Hin Leong Trading's collapse. The court-appointed liquidators requested the freeze of assets worldwide, totaling millions, to recover debt from nearly two dozen banks globally. The delay followed a day-long hearing, and the judge's decision is expected at a later date. Lim Oon Kuin admitted to hiding hundreds of millions of dollars in losses during Hin Leong's restructuring efforts.

site_title: Godzilla vs Kong marks Covid-era box office breakthrough
summary: Godzilla vs Kong has broken the Covid-19 pandemic-era box office record, drawing in US$48.5 million in ticket sales over the Good Friday holiday period in the US. The film's success is a significant boost for the theatrical industry, which has seen ticket sales plummet over 85% from last year. With cinemas reopened in every major US market, the film's release is seen as a sign of pent-up demand for big-budget action movies, and analysts predict it will perform well internationally, with worldwide sales now at US$285 million.

site_title: Vietnam shifts leaders, keeps key policies in place
summary: Vietnam's National Assembly elected Pham Minh Chinh, 63, as the country's new prime minister, tasked with reviving the economy post-pandemic. Chinh, a former national security official, rose through the ranks and has a PhD in law. He will lead the country's interactions with the world, despite other powerful leaders. General-Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong was re-elected for a third term, while former prime minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc was elected president. Analysts expect Chinh to implement existing policies, including economic reforms and balancing relations with China and the US.

site_title: A*Star, ChemoPower open S$3.9m lab to study TCM herbs
summary: A*Star and ChemoPower have opened a S$3.9m laboratory to study traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) herbs. The lab aims to develop an integrated chemical analysis platform and create a molecular fingerprint database for 40 commonly used herbs. This will help overcome the lack of quantitative data on TCM herbs, enabling sellers to differentiate their products and potentially open up a new market for traditional medicine on e-commerce platforms. The collaboration will utilize ChemoPower's proprietary technology and AI-assisted analysis to quickly identify key ingredients and create quality indexes.

site_title: 120 SMEs get S$8,000 cash grant each from Salesforce, SBF
summary: 120 Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will each receive S$8,000 in cash grants from Salesforce and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) under the Salesforce Small Business Relief Grants Programme. The grant aims to support SMEs in addressing cash flow needs and preserving jobs amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Recipients were selected based on financial standing, hardship, survivability, and resilience. The grants will help SMEs sustain their businesses and position them for recovery and growth post-Covid.

site_title: Singa preserves principle of chronological fairness
summary: Singapore has introduced the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (Singa), a bill that allows the government to issue bonds for "nationally significant infrastructure" projects. The move is seen as a cautious approach to borrowing, with the government aiming to align expenditure with benefits and maintain financial discipline. The Act includes safeguards such as a gross borrowing limit of S$90 billion and an annual interest threshold of S$5 billion, and requires parliamentary approval for future changes. This approach preserves the principle of chronological fairness and aligns with the government's long-running commitment to prudence.

site_title: Every trade-reliant country should gear up for disruptions in trade flows
summary: A disruption in trade flows, such as the recent Suez Canal blockage, can have significant consequences for global trade and economies. The shipping industry is crucial for transferring goods and materials from production points to consumption areas, and trade choke points like the Suez Canal are critical. Disruptions can lead to supply delays, higher freight rates, and economic losses, as seen in the 1956 and 1967 closures of the Suez Canal. Trade-dependent countries should prepare for such disruptions by exploring alternative routes, such as the Arctic route, and diversifying their trade networks.

site_title: Singing opera in a surgical mask
summary: The Paris Opera's chorus has adapted to performing while wearing surgical masks during the pandemic, despite restrictions on breathing and articulation. The high-filtration FFP2 masks proved difficult, and the chorus opted for stiff surgical masks for performances. The opera house has live-streamed its performances, including a new staging of Faust, which included a masked chorus and soloists who performed without masks. Despite the challenges, the chorus has highlighted its importance in the opera, with director-general Alexander Neef stating that "if we don't perform, we don't exist."

site_title: US: Stocks jump amid signs of vaccine economic bounce
summary: US stocks jumped on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.9%, the S&P 500 up 1.0%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.0%, amid optimism about the US economic recovery due to an accelerating vaccination campaign. The employment outlook improved, with the US economy regaining 916,000 jobs in March and unemployment retreating. Analysts expect more growth ahead as vaccination rates increase and more states expand eligibility for jabs.

site_title: Made-in-US reflation trade is one export the world doesn't want
summary: The US bond market's reflation trade is causing concern globally, with US government bond yields more than doubling since the start of the year, leading to higher borrowing costs for indebted countries in Europe and emerging markets. This is threatening a flagging recovery in Europe and adding to the burdens of emerging markets, which rely heavily on dollar funding. Analysts warn that higher interest rates could undermine debt sustainability and require more stimulus from central banks, potentially harming economic recoveries.

site_title: Affordable housing shouldn't be an oxymoron
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a climate-centred infrastructure bill, dubbed the American Jobs Plan, with a focus on modernizing the country's infrastructure. The plan includes $213 billion for building, preserving, and retrofitting over 2 million homes and commercial buildings, with incentives to eliminate exclusionary zoning laws and promote affordable housing. The proposal aims to address the US' affordable housing crisis, where 37.1 million households, or 30% of all US households, are housing cost burdened. If passed, the plan would be the largest federal investment in affordable housing in a generation, providing a total of $115 billion for roads, bridges, public transit, and water infrastructure.

site_title: Posco weighs how to exit Myanmar military-backed venture
summary: South Korea's steelmaker Posco is reviewing its joint venture with Myanmar Economic Holdings Ltd, a firm controlled by the Myanmar military, amid growing international pressure on companies with ties to the military. Posco is considering selling its 70% stake or buying out its partner's 30% stake, citing concerns about potential sanctions and the need to exit the business. The move comes as the military regime continues its deadly crackdown on protests, with hundreds killed.

site_title: About 2.2m Singaporeans have not used their SingapoRediscovers Vouchers
summary: About 2.2 million out of 3 million eligible Singaporeans have not used their SingapoRediscovers Vouchers, set to expire at the end of June. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing said there's no extension planned, but the Singapore Tourism Board will step up efforts to encourage usage. The board will share promotions and create attractive bundles, and has worked to improve the user experience, including reminders for child discounts and booking time slots.

site_title: Bangkok to close 196 nightlife venues amid new coronavirus cluster
summary: Bangkok's governor announced the closure of 196 nightlife venues for two weeks due to a new coronavirus cluster with over 100 cases. The venues will be closed from April 6-19 in three districts linked to the outbreak. Thailand reported 194 new COVID-19 cases, including 45 from the nightlife cluster, and is considering labeling five provinces, including Bangkok, as "red zones" with restricted nightlife hours.

site_title: Postal Services Act amended to facilitate roll-out of 1,000 parcel locker stations
summary: Singapore's Postal Services Act has been amended to facilitate the rollout of 1,000 parcel locker stations islandwide, supporting e-commerce delivery. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will establish, install, and operate the locker network, with enforcement powers to ensure safe use. The stations will be located at HDB estates, public transport nodes, and community centers. The amendments also allow delivery service providers to deliver small packets via SingPost's infrastructure, further facilitating competition in last-mile delivery services.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records on latest strong US data
summary: US stock indices reached new records on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index surging 1.1%, 1.4%, and 1.7% respectively. The latest signs of a US recovery, driven by vaccinations and pent-up demand, boosted the market. The Institute for Supply Management reported an all-time high in US services sector activity, while auto companies like General Motors and Tesla saw significant gains. However, petroleum producers fell as oil prices dropped following OPEC's output decision.

site_title: Sri Lanka bans palm oil imports, tells producers to uproot plantations
summary: Sri Lanka has banned imports of palm oil and told producers to uproot existing plantations in a phased manner. The move aims to make the country "free from oil palm plantation and palm oil consumption." This decision is in response to environmental concerns about widespread deforestation and damage to ecosystems caused by palm oil production.

site_title: Singapore first to ratify Asean Trade in Services Agreement
summary: Singapore has become the first Asean member state to ratify the Asean Trade in Services Agreement (ATISA), a legally-binding agreement that provides preferential market access to Asean markets. This move will immediately activate Singapore's rights and obligations under the agreement. ATISA aims to strengthen services-related trading arrangements among Asean member states, enabling businesses to enjoy increased market access and reduced discriminatory regulatory barriers.

site_title: MAS expects to issue first tranche of SGS (Infrastructure) bonds in Q4 of 2021
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to issue its first tranche of Singapore Government Securities (Infrastructure) bonds in Q4 2021. The move is part of the government's Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA), which allows borrowing for major national infrastructure projects. The new bond category will rank pari passu with the existing SGS, and both will be priced along the same yield curve. The government aims to issue green bonds for environmentally sustainable projects, with a total borrowing limit of S$90 billion. The move is expected to reassure investors and provide financing for infrastructure projects.

site_title: Jordan's Prince Hamza defies the military in new recording
summary: Prince Hamza of Jordan, the half-brother of King Abdullah, released a voice recording stating he would disobey orders from the military to communicate with the outside world after being placed under house arrest and accused of trying to destabilize the country. Prince Hamza, who was removed from the royal succession in 2004, claimed he was being barred from activities and silenced, and vowed to continue communicating with his supporters. The move is seen as a power play by Prince Hamza to gain support among ordinary Jordanians, who have been increasingly frustrated with the government's corruption and mismanagement.

site_title: WTO rules must not block the developing world's access to vaccines
summary: The US may support India and South Africa's proposal to waive restrictive WTO provisions on Covid-19 vaccine patents, following pressure from American civil society groups and lawmakers. The waiver aims to ensure global access to vaccines and treatments, addressing concerns that unequal distribution could lead to further mutations and economic losses. Over 80 countries have backed the proposal, while the pharmaceutical industry and some governments in the US, EU, and Canada have raised objections. The White House is reportedly considering lending its support, which could help boost vaccine production and distribution to developing nations.

site_title: IMF says Fed surprises can trigger emerging-market outflows
summary: The International Monetary Fund warned that potential surprise tightening by the US Federal Reserve could lead to increased interest rates and capital outflows from emerging markets. This could occur if central banks in advanced economies signal greater concern for inflation risks. The IMF recommends clear, transparent communication from central banks to avoid triggering a deterioration in investor sentiment about emerging markets. A surprise tightening similar to the 2013 "taper tantrum" could occur, impacting emerging markets with lower credit ratings. The IMF advises further guidance on possible future scenarios to mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund warned that a potential surprise tightening by the US Federal Reserve could spur an increase in interest rates and capital outflows from emerging markets, underlining the need for clear central bank communication.

site_title: US service sector activity index hits record high in March
summary: The US service sector activity index reached a record high in March, driven by robust growth in new orders amid increased vaccinations and fiscal stimulus. The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey showed a reading of 63.7, the highest in its history. This follows the economy adding 916,000 jobs in March, the most in seven months, and is expected to boost economic growth this year, the strongest in nearly four decades.

site_title: MRT, bus commuters could be subject to frisk searches under proposed laws
summary: Singapore commuters taking the bus or train may be subject to frisk searches by police officers and authorized personnel under proposed laws. The Road Traffic (Amendment) Bill allows security checks at bus interchanges, MRT and LRT stations, and on board buses and trains. Commuters may be required to walk through a metal detector, pass belongings through an X-ray machine, and have their outer clothing inspected. Those who refuse to be screened may be asked to leave, and refusing or failing to comply without a reasonable excuse could result in a fine of up to S$1,000.

site_title: Straits Trading unit to acquire JL Family Office's 10% stake in Straits Real Estate
summary: Straits Trading's subsidiary, STC Capital, will acquire JL Family Office's 10% stake in Straits Real Estate (SRE) for S$105 million in cash. The transaction, set to complete on April 9, will make SRE a fully-owned subsidiary of Straits Trading. This acquisition is seen as a material investment in one of Straits Trading's key business units, providing enhanced long-term growth prospects and capital returns.

site_title: Relief period for options to purchase, S&P agreements extended
summary: The Singapore government has extended a relief period for options to purchase and sale and purchase agreements with developers until June 30, providing buyers more time to make payments. Construction firms facing Covid-19 difficulties now have an additional six months of reprieve, up to Sept 30. The relief measures aim to support the built environment sector, which has shown resilience during the pandemic, and help prevent industrial capabilities from being lost.

site_title: Singapore PMI climbs to 50.8 in March, highest since last March
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a 0.3-point increase in the PMI reading to 50.8 in March, its highest since March 2019. This marks the ninth consecutive month of expansion, driven by higher growth in new orders, exports, and employment. However, the sector's growth is expected to moderate in the first half of the year due to supply chain disruptions, including the Suez Canal blockage. Electronics sector also expanded for the eighth consecutive month, albeit at a slower rate, with potential impact from global chip shortages and supply chain issues.

site_title: Japan fears Covid-19 variants are behind possible fourth wave
summary: Japanese health authorities are concerned that COVID-19 variants are driving a potential fourth wave of the pandemic, with cases rising in Osaka and potentially spreading to Tokyo ahead of the Olympics. The variants appear more infectious and may be resistant to vaccines, prompting targeted lockdown measures in Osaka. Officials are now considering expanding these measures to Tokyo if needed, despite Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's insistence on carrying out the Games as scheduled.

site_title: KSH Holdings wins S$171.8m design and build contract for Biopolis Phase 6
summary: KSH Holdings secured a S$171.8 million design and build contract for Biopolis Phase 6 in Singapore. The project, expected to begin in April and complete within 27 months, involves constructing a 12-storey biomedical sciences development. The contract is expected to contribute positively to KSH's financial performance. This win brings KSH's order book to over S$615 million, with 44% consisting of public projects.

site_title: US factory orders decline in February
summary: US factory orders declined 0.8% in February, likely due to unseasonably cold weather, but manufacturing remains strong as the economic recovery gains steam. Orders increased 1.0% year-over-year. Severe weather disrupted consumer spending, production, and home building, but the Institute for Supply Management reported a jump in national factory activity in March, the highest since 1983. Job growth accelerated sharply in March, and economic growth is expected to take off this year, driven by the White House's pandemic relief package and the reopening of nonessential businesses.

site_title: Myanmar protesters clap to denounce junta as region focuses on crisis
