SPACs, which allow retail investors to invest in private companies alongside established sponsors, have seen record volume of issuances and prominent mergers in the US. However, investors need to be aware of the risks, including mixed track records, hidden costs, and lack of transparency. Existing channels in Singapore, such as retail bonds and private markets platforms, also offer exposure to private markets. As regulations evolve, it is expected that retail investors will have more access to private equity markets, with companies like Azalea Investment Management and CapBridge leading the way.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades First Resources to 'buy', raises target price
summary: RHB has upgraded palm oil producer First Resources to a "buy" from "neutral" and raised its target price to S$1.70 due to expected boosts in crude palm oil (CPO) prices. RHB forecasts CPO prices to rise to RM3,200 per tonne in 2021 and RM2,800 in 2022, despite a lower price environment. The research house also raised First Resources' earnings estimates, citing a rising stock to usage ratio trend and lower year-on-year CPO prices.

site_title: Scholar leader who dreams big
summary: Henry Zhao, chairman of Harvest Fund Management, predicts Chinese Reits will be a game-changer for the country's equity market. He believes the market will shift its focus to dividend payments and offer investors a steady yield. Harvest plans to launch its first CReit product in the second half of this year, aiming to tap into the growing demand for alternative investments. Zhao also forecasts growth in the tech sector, particularly business-to-business platforms, and sees opportunities in healthcare and pharmaceuticals. He is optimistic about the Chinese economy's prospects, despite challenges from an ageing population and low birth rates.

site_title: 'Dishonest' son of oligarch told to pay US$100m to his mother
summary: A UK court ruled that Temur Akhmedov, son of billionaire oligarch Farkhad Akhmedov, must pay his mother over US$100 million after being found "dishonest" in hiding assets from her during their divorce. The judge stated that Temur worked with his father to prevent his mother from obtaining a £450 million payout, and revealed he lost over US$50 million day trading while in college, attempting to justify his actions. The ruling comes after Temur argued he had lost money through bad trades, but the court found him liable for his father's actions.

site_title: 'Demon Slayer' sets US record for best foreign language film opening weekend
summary: The Japanese animated film "Demon Slayer" set a US record for the best foreign language film opening weekend, earning $19.5 million in the US and Canada. This milestone surpasses the previous record held by "Hero" in 2004. The film broke box office records in Japan, selling over $365 million in tickets, and marks a significant resurgence in cinema-going in the US due to reopenings and vaccination efforts.

site_title: Grocery price shock: coming to a store near you
summary: Global food prices surged the most in almost nine years, driven by a rally in crop futures, with staple crops influencing grocery shelves and fueling food inflation. The Bloomberg Agriculture Spot Index jumped the most since 2012, with corn prices doubling in the past year and soybeans up 80%. Emerging markets, particularly vulnerable to weaker currencies, are at risk of further stoking global hunger. Governments are taking steps to curb price spikes, while retailers and manufacturers are expected to pass higher costs on to consumers.

site_title: Jokowi orders all-out effort to find submarine as oxygen runs low
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has ordered a full-scale search effort to find the missing submarine KRI Nanggala-402, whose 53 crew members' oxygen supply is set to last until Saturday. A helicopter and five ships have been deployed to search waters north of Bali, but no signs of the vessel have been found. The navy chief of staff, Yudo Margono, confirmed that calm conditions are aiding the search, but warned that the crew's air supply is limited. Several countries, including Malaysia, Singapore, and Australia, have offered assistance in the search, which is being aided by sonar and an oil slick believed to be a signal from the crew.

site_title: Taiwan central bank says may revise 2021 growth forecast higher
summary: Taiwan's central bank governor Yang Chin-long announced that the country's 2021 growth forecast may be revised higher due to strong economic prospects. The bank previously raised its GDP growth estimate to 4.53% in April, up from 3.68% in December. This comes as Taiwan's economy continues to grow despite global challenges. The revised forecast suggests that the island's economy is performing better than expected, leading to a potential increase in economic growth.

site_title: WHO official spiked Italy report to avoid angering Rome: prosecutors
summary: A senior World Health Organization official, Ranieri Guerra, is being investigated for lying to Italian prosecutors about spiking a critical report on Italy's response to the coronavirus pandemic. The report, released in May 2020, found Italy's preparedness plan was outdated and hospitals reacted "improvised, chaotic and creative" to the virus. Guerra allegedly spiked the report to avoid a political confrontation with Rome and protect the WHO's relationship with Italy, which was set to chair the G-20 in 2021. Guerra has denied wrongdoing.

site_title: Supply, disrupted: How Singapore should prepare for the next crisis
summary: Singapore's reliance on global supply chains makes it vulnerable to disruptions, as demonstrated by the Covid-19 pandemic. To mitigate this risk, the government and private companies are exploring ways to increase self-reliance and resilience. Localized manufacturing of critical items, such as masks and vaccines, is being encouraged. Technologies like additive manufacturing and augmented reality are also being leveraged to improve supply chain resilience. Governments are also playing a crucial role in scenario planning and securing supply chains, and consumers can support local food production by purchasing locally grown food.

site_title: New SafeEntry system installed at more than 2,700 places across Singapore
summary: Singapore has completed the compulsory rollout of the SafeEntry Gateway device at over 2,700 locations, including malls, cinemas, and hospitals. The new system allows visitors to register their visit for contact tracing purposes using their TraceTogether token or app. This rollout paves the way for TraceTogether to be the only means of registration at 200,000 locations across Singapore. The new system offers faster check-ins and can detect working condition of TraceTogether tokens.

site_title: Australia-New Zealand travel bubble launches with lopsided demand
summary: Australia and New Zealand's travel bubble launched on April 19, 2021, with lopsided demand, favoring New Zealand. According to ForwardKeys, 59% of 5,200 passengers booked on Air New Zealand were traveling to New Zealand, while Qantas Airways' demand from the New Zealand end was initially sluggish. The initial results show that travel patterns have departed from pre-pandemic norms, with the two countries' travel balance expected to take time to return to normal. The bubble aims to promote tourism between the two countries, which was relatively equal before the pandemic.

site_title: Online trading pioneer
summary: Saxo Bank, an online trading platform founded by Kim Fournais in 1992, is expanding globally with over 2,000 employees across Europe, Asia, and other regions. The firm's mission is to democratize investing for the masses by offering transparent prices and a range of asset classes on a single platform. Fournais, a commercial pilot, has doubled his business and personal challenges by embracing technology and innovation. Saxo has achieved significant growth, with 238,000 new active clients in 2020 and over 10 billion euros in new client assets. The firm is now focusing on Asia, particularly China, and aims to be a leading alternative investment platform in Hong Kong.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust's H1 2021 distribution down 45.5 per cent
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's (FHT) H1 2021 distribution fell 45.5% to 0.179 Singapore cents, down from 0.3287 cents last year, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on global tourism. Gross revenue dropped 36.2% to S$39.9 million, while net property income fell 40.9% to S$26.7 million. Despite uncertainty, the trust retained 60% of distributable income and plans to position its portfolio for international tourism's eventual recovery, citing sufficient liquidity and a master lease structure to mitigate the pandemic's effects.

site_title: URA, HDB launch Lentor Central, Tampines Street 62 GLS sites for tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched two sites in Singapore for tender: Lentor Central and Tampines Street 62 (Parcel A). The sites, with a 99-year lease, can yield approximately 1,195 residential units. Property analysts predict high competition and top bids ranging from S$880 to S$1,050 per square foot per plot ratio for Lentor Central and S$550 to S$620 per square foot per plot ratio for Tampines Street 62. The sites were carried over from the reserve list of the second half of 2020 GLS programme.

site_title: Clean lines
summary: Patek Philippe unveiled its 2021 collection, featuring five new timepieces, including a perpetual calendar watch with a linear layout, and updated Calatrava models. The Ref 5236P-001 In-Line Perpetual Calendar boasts a sleek platinum case and a new automatic movement, priced at S$171,500. The Ref 4947/1A-001 annual calendar watch is also introduced, priced at S$63,200. Additionally, Patek Philippe released Calatrava models with a guilloche 'Clous de Paris' pattern, priced at S$39,000.

site_title: A taste of spring
summary: COMO Dempsey's two signature eateries, COMO Cuisine and The Dempsey Cookhouse & Bar, have revamped their menus to reflect a growing interest in healthy eating with a global perspective. Inspired by COMO Hotels & Resorts, the restaurants now offer a culinary tour of the world. Executive chefs Tshering Lhaden and her Bhutanese heritage bring a fresh perspective, focusing on simplicity, seasonal ingredients, and heart. The restaurants have introduced theme nights and cooking workshops to cater to this trend, offering a new outlook on dining.

site_title: Australia in no hurry to reopen borders: PM
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that the country is not in a hurry to reopen its international borders, prioritizing the nearly coronavirus-free lifestyle. Australia has successfully curbed the pandemic with strict measures, limiting cases to under 29,500 and 910 deaths. While vaccinated Australians may travel overseas for essential purposes in the second half of the year, a reopening is not imminent, with Morrison emphasizing the importance of maintaining the current way of life.

site_title: Japan's exports post largest monthly gain since late 2017
summary: Japan's exports surged 16.1% in March, the largest monthly gain since 2017, driven by strong shipments to China. The rebound in exports slowed significantly in the first quarter, and economists expect external demand to provide limited support to the economy's growth this year. Shipments to the US, however, rose 4.9% for the first year-on-year gain in five months, offsetting slower growth in other regions. The trade data suggests a fragile economic recovery remains intact despite a collapse in global trade due to the pandemic.

site_title: New Zealand trials 'early warning' virus app at border
summary: New Zealand has begun trialing a COVID-19 "early warning" app, "elarm", at its border to detect the virus before symptoms appear. The app, developed by Datamine, uses artificial intelligence to analyze wearable device data and can detect the virus with 90% accuracy up to three days before symptoms. The trial involves 500 border workers and aims to provide an early warning system for workers at high risk of exposure. If successful, it could help prevent the spread of the virus in the country, which has been largely successful in containing the outbreak.

site_title: Coinbase heads for US$94b valuation in Nasdaq debut
summary: Coinbase Global, a US-based cryptocurrency exchange, debuted on the Nasdaq with a valuation of over US$94 billion, surpassing the exchange operator Nasdaq's value. The company's stock opened at US$360 per share, up 44% from its reference price. This marks a significant milestone in the development of bitcoin and digital assets, with the world's largest cryptocurrency hitting a record of over US$63,000. Experts predict a correlation between the stock's price and bitcoin's value, but also highlight risks due to the highly volatile asset and patchy regulation.

site_title: The future of work in banking: How will bankers do business post pandemic?
summary: The pandemic has changed the banking industry's approach to work, with implications for workforce planning, office space, and organizational culture. Despite vaccines being rolled out, bankers are expected to return to offices and adapt to a new work environment. Singapore banks, for example, successfully implemented remote work during the "circuit breaker" period, with up to 90% of staff working from home. The future of work in banks will require a shift towards flexibility and remote collaboration, reshaping the industry's culture and operations.

site_title: China to conduct stress tests on 4,024 banks in 2021: central bank publication
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), plans to conduct stress tests on all 4,024 banking institutions in 2021 to identify financial risks. The PBOC will also closely monitor climate change-related financial risks and explore a prudential management framework with other financial regulators. This move aims to improve the country's financial stability and resilience to potential risks.

site_title: Global military spending rises 2.6% in 2020 despite pandemic hit
summary: Global military spending rose 2.6% to $1.98 trillion in 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a report by the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. The US accounted for 39% of total global military expenditure, reaching $778 billion, while China's spending rose 1.9% to $252 billion. Some countries redirected military funds to pandemic response, while others, like Brazil and Russia, spent less than planned. This marks the third consecutive year of growth in US military spending, following seven years of reductions.

site_title: WHO says against proof of vaccination for travel
summary: The World Health Organization's emergency committee has advised against requiring proof of vaccination for international travelers, citing concerns it could deepen inequities in global vaccine distribution. The committee emphasized the limited evidence on vaccine performance in reducing transmission and the potential for discrimination between young, old, rich, and poor. The WHO has only approved three vaccines for the coronavirus, and the committee urged accelerating research on vaccine origins and better regulations on animal markets.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization's emergency committee said Monday it was against international travellers being required to have proof of vaccination, partly on grounds such a measure would deepen inequities.

site_title: Enduring appeal
summary: A Lange & Sohne's luxury watches continue to draw strong demand despite the COVID-19 pandemic. CEO Wilhelm Schmid attributes the enduring appeal to the brand's fundamentals, including its design and production processes. The brand's latest releases, including the limited-edition Triple Split and Lange 1 Perpetual Calendar, have sold out quickly. Schmid notes that production challenges, rather than demand, have been the main issue. The brand's resilience has been boosted by 25 years of investment, with the best years ahead.

site_title: Biden sends unofficial US delegation to Taiwan
summary: US President Joe Biden sent an unofficial delegation of former US officials to Taiwan on April 14, 2021, signaling support for the democratic island amid increasing hostility from China. The delegation, consisting of former senator Christopher Dodd and former deputy secretaries of state Richard Armitage and James Steinberg, aims to bolster Taiwan's defenses. This move comes as China has increased pressure on Taiwan, breaching its air defense zone with fighter jets and nuclear-capable bombers on a near-daily basis. The visit coincides with the 42nd anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act, which the US signed in 1979.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end lower as virus resurgence hits risk appetite
summary: Japanese shares ended lower on Wednesday, weighed down by cyclicals and doubts over the economic rebound due to a resurgence in Covid-19 cases. The Nikkei share average fell 0.28% to 29,668.74, while the Topix slipped 0.23% to 1,953.80. Banking and insurer stocks declined due to falling interest rates, while Toshiba jumped 5.77% amid reports of potential bids. Experts warn that Japan's slow vaccine rollout and rising infections may lead to an "explosive" jump in cases before the Olympics in 100 days.

site_title: With 100 days to go, Tokyo scrambles to stage pandemic Olympics
summary: Tokyo is scrambling to stage the 2021 Summer Olympics with 100 days to go, amidst growing uncertainty due to the pandemic. The city faces challenges such as resurgent COVID-19 cases, slow vaccination rates, and restrictions on foreign spectators. The organizers have created a "playbook" with COVID countermeasures, but details on athlete safety, spectator numbers, and ticket sales remain unclear. The city's medical system is also under strain, and local health centers are concerned about caring for the 15,000 athletes in the village. Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike vowed to make the event a success despite difficulties.

site_title: A model of new masculinity
summary: Ryan Pang, owner of Habitat Coffee, emphasizes the importance of respect and honesty in building strong relationships, both in business and marriage. He believes that quiet revolutions are taking place in homes and marriages worldwide, with men striving to create a foundation of trust, respect, dialogue, and love. Pang's own marriage with his wife Esther has evolved over the years, with him learning to control his temper and channel his energy constructively. He also prioritizes spending time alone in nature to regain his sense of self and balance in his hectic schedule.

site_title: In living colour
summary: Zenith presents the Defy 21 Spectrum, a limited-edition collection of five watches featuring a radical colour approach, with hues incorporated into the case, band, and inner mechanisms, excluding the dial. The watches boast the El Primero 21 movement, capable of measuring 1/100th of a second, and are among the fastest chronographs in production. Each watch is limited to 10 pieces, showcasing Zenith's innovative design and exceptional timekeeping capabilities.

images.alt_text: Defy Extreme.
(Left) A384. (Right) Defy 21 Spectrum

site_title: Striking out on his own
summary: Daniel Day-Lewis's son, Gabriel-Kane Day-Lewis, is the new face of Ermenegildo Zegna's #WhatMakesAMan campaign, marking a departure from his family's acting legacy. The 26-year-old model, singer, and songwriter embodies a modern interpretation of masculinity, expressing introspection and vulnerability in a recent interview. His campaign features him alongside Isabelle Adjani, who praises his sensitivity and wisdom. The luxury Italian menswear label continues its exploration of traditional masculine virtues, with a second part of the campaign featuring Li Xian and virtual influencer Noonoouri discussing modern masculinity.

site_title: Timely facelift for a Rolex icon
summary: Rolex has given its popular Oyster Perpetual Explorer I and II a facelift to celebrate their 50th anniversary. The watches have undergone subtle yet practical changes, maintaining their winning formula. The updates include new designs, materials, and features. The changes are part of a timely overhaul for both the Explorer I and II, marking a significant milestone for the iconic tool watch brand. The redesign aims to appeal to a new generation of adventurers while honoring the heritage of the classic timepieces.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Rolex Oyster Perpetual Explorer.
Rolex Oyster Perpetual Explorer II

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the opening of Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,202.35. Despite a positive performance on Wall Street overnight, local banks were mixed, with DBS rising 0.2% and OCBC edging up 0.1%, while UOB lost 0.3%. Singapore Airlines was the top gainer, rising 1.4%, while ST Engineering was the top loser, falling 2.5%. Global markets also saw gains, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 reaching fresh records, driven by large tech companies ahead of earnings later in the week.

site_title: The Sound of Independence
summary: Singaporean singer-songwriter Jasmine Sokko, 25, has gained international recognition for her edgy and futuristic electronic music. Her debut single "1057" in 2016 caught an international audience, followed by a contract with Warner Music Singapore and a MTV music award. Sokko, who identifies as a "little alien" and has a tendency to push boundaries, is now releasing a new EP featuring songs that challenge traditional notions of female empowerment and independence. With a focus on self-expression and taking action, Sokko is determined to succeed and evolve as an artist.

site_title: The King's Gambit
summary: Yung Raja, Singapore's rising star rapper, recounts his journey from a tiny role on a local TV show to becoming the island's hottest young rapper. After losing confidence in his acting career, his friend encouraged him to pursue rapping, which led to the release of his debut single Mustafa in 2018. Now signed to Def Jam South East Asia and Universal Music Group, Raja is set to release three new singles and a debut EP. He credits his parents for their support and celebrates his bicultural identity through his music, fashion, and videos.

site_title: Passion of Youth
summary: Singaporean model and singer Iman Fandi Ahmad is making a name for herself in the entertainment industry. The 20-year-old, daughter of a footballer and a fashion model, has been pursuing a career in music since her debut single "Timeframe" was released in February. Inspired by personal experiences and relationships, Iman's electropop track showcases her passion for music and her desire to use her platform to raise awareness for social justice and body positivity. With a background in football and modelling, Iman is determined to follow her dreams and explore various interests, including acting.

site_title: Malaysia builder rally hots up as pump-priming signs appear
summary: Malaysia's construction sector is experiencing a surge in growth, with builders securing new contracts and mega infrastructure projects. The country's 2021 budget allocated a record RM69 billion for development expenditure, and recent announcements, such as the start of phase three of the Mass Rapid Transit project, are expected to boost related sectors. Shares of major contractors have risen, with Kerjaya Prospek Group's shares reaching a 20-month high. Experts attribute the growth to record-low interest rates and government pump-priming, which is expected to benefit sectors like transportation, power, and building materials.

images.alt_text: A rally in Malaysian builders is gathering pace in the wake of more contract wins and a revival in mega infrastructure projects in the country.

site_title: New faces on popular classics
summary: Rolex introduces bold dial designs on its Oyster Perpetual Datejust 36, featuring palm and fluted motifs inspired by tropical forests and geometric patterns reminiscent of boutique decor. The Datejust 36 also boasts a meteorite dial available on select 18ct gold models, showcasing unique crystallization patterns formed over millions of years. These designs showcase Rolex's continued experimentation with color and materials, following its 2020 introduction of vibrant colors to the Oyster Perpetual collection.

site_title: More than just telling time
summary: Louis Vuitton unveiled its groundbreaking watch collection, Tambour Carpe Diem, at Watches & Wonders 2021, blending ancient clock tower mechanics with 21st-century craftsmanship. The collection features intricate automata, including a jumping hour, retrograde minute, and power reserve display. The Tambour Curve GMT Flying Tourbillon, another notable entry, combines travel time and a flying tourbillon with a graphic signature. Both watches showcase exceptional skill and showmanship, with the Tambour Carpe Diem featuring a skull, snake, and hourglass on its dial.

site_title: Companies selling their real estate at fastest pace ever: JLL report
summary: Companies in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa sold a record 27 billion euros of corporate properties in 2020, according to a Jones Lang LaSalle report. This was a 10% increase from the previous year, with office properties accounting for just over a third of sales. The surge in sales was driven by companies seeking to shore up their balance sheets and reshape their portfolios to support post-pandemic business plans. The shift to home working also led to a reevaluation of real estate needs, with many businesses reconsidering their relationship with property.

site_title: Substantial shareholder of Procurri to vote against Novo Tellus' partial offer
summary: Substantial shareholder DeClout of Procurri, a substantial shareholder, plans to vote against Novo Tellus' partial offer of 36.5 Singapore cents per share. The offer, launched by OCBC on behalf of Novo Tellus, aims to acquire an additional 27.91% of Procurri's shares. DeClout, holding 20.1% of Procurri, plans to vote against the offer, which would have given Novo Tellus a 51% stake in the company.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, up 9.85 points to 1,612.25. Volume reached 6.582 billion lots worth RM4.144 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 558 to 511.

site_title: Japan wholesale prices rise for first time in over a year
summary: Japan's wholesale prices rose 1% in March, the first annual increase in over a year, driven by a rebound in global demand for commodities. This marks a sign that rising commodity costs are pinching corporate margins and adding inflationary pressure to the world's third-largest economy. Analysts expect the impact on consumer inflation to be more modest in Japan than in the US, citing soft wage growth and slow vaccine rollouts. The Bank of Japan will scrutinize the data in its quarterly review of growth and price forecasts on April 26-27.

site_title: Schwab sues former client after US$1.2m accidental transfer
summary: Charles Schwab Corp is suing a former client, Kelyn Spadoni, after a computer glitch transferred over $1.2 million to her account instead of $82.56. Spadoni used the funds to buy a house and car before being arrested and charged with bank fraud and other crimes. A settlement was reached, and most of the money was recovered. The case is similar to a 2019 incident where Citigroup mistakenly sent $504 million to Revlon lenders, with a judge ruling the asset managers were free to use the funds.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB positive on Digi, Axiata as companies pursue merger
summary: Malaysia-listed DiGi.com has been upgraded to "add" by CGS-CIMB, with a target price of RM4.55, and Axiata Group raised to "add" with a target price of RM4.20, following talks of a merger between Axiata and Digi's Malaysian telecoms business Celcom. The proposed deal, involving Norway's Telenor, would create a 52% market share in Malaysia, with Axiata swapping its Celcom stake for a 33.1% stake and an additional RM2 billion in cash. The merger is seen as simpler and more competitive due to the Malaysian government's 5G rollout plans.

site_title: Chanel goes electro-pop
summary: Chanel unveiled its J12 Electro collection at Watches and Wonders 2021, inspired by the 1990s electronic dance music era. The collection features four high-end watch creations: J12 X-Ray Electro, J12 Electro Dream, J12 Electro Star, and J12 Electro Box. Each piece boasts vibrant hues, graphic designs, and luxurious materials, including sapphires, diamonds, and white gold. Prices range from S$937,100 to S$1,710,600, with limited editions available. The collection pays homage to the iconic 90s aesthetic while also showcasing Chanel's expertise in fine watchmaking.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Wednesday lower, STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day 0.3% lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 8.51 points to 3,179.39. Despite this, the overall market remained stable, with tech names like Venture Corporation and Creative Technology gaining, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and local lenders lost ground. Global markets showed upbeat sentiment, with the KLCI, Hang Seng Index, and Kospi rising.

site_title: Yellen says global minimum tax needed
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is working with G20 countries to agree on a global corporate minimum tax rate, aiming to end a "30-year race to the bottom" on corporate tax rates. The proposed 21% minimum tax rate is part of President Joe Biden's $2 trillion infrastructure spending plan, which would increase the US corporate tax rate to 28%. A global minimum tax is seen as crucial to prevent companies from shifting profits to tax haven countries and to ensure stable tax systems.

site_title: Credit Suisse's 'unacceptable' loss has familiar ring
summary: Credit Suisse faces a nearly $5 billion loss and will remove two top executives after its involvement with Archegos Capital Management, the collapsed investment fund. This comes as a warning of the risks in the financial system amid low interest rates and frothy stock values. The bank's troubles echo those of the 2008 financial crisis, with opaque financial transactions and excessive risk-taking contributing to the losses. Regulators have been criticized for not doing enough to prevent such incidents, and the bank's CEO has promised to "learn serious lessons" and change for the better.

site_title: UIC proposes name change to Singapore Land in group-wide refresh
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) is set to change its name to Singapore Land Group as part of a group-wide refresh. The real estate developer plans to rejuvenate its aged office portfolio and kick-start its ESG roadmap. The company will also explore capital recycling platforms and potentially set up funds or real estate investment trusts. UIC's COO, Jonathan Eu, aims to optimize its portfolio, including upgrading its office buildings and revitalizing its aged assets. The name change is expected to be approved by shareholders, with the company looking to create value in its portfolio to narrow its discount to its book value.

site_title: Digital twin technology can open up vast new possibilities
summary: Digital twin technology is expanding its applications beyond government sectors, offering vast possibilities for industries such as facilities management, manufacturing, and transportation. A digital twin is a 3D model of a physical entity, driven by real-time data from sensors and machines. This technology allows for real-time monitoring and analysis of assets, processes, and workflows, enabling optimization of time and money. The global digital twin market is projected to reach $48.2 billion by 2026, with Asia-Pacific expected to record the highest growth. Companies that adopt digital twins can gain a competitive advantage by improving efficiency and making data-driven decisions.

site_title: Taiwan train derails, at least 36 dead, many injured
summary: A train derailed in a tunnel in eastern Taiwan on Friday, resulting in at least 36 deaths and over 72 injuries. The train, carrying around 350 people, hit a truck that was not parked properly, causing the derailment. Rescue efforts are ongoing, with some carriages hard to access. The incident is Taiwan's worst rail disaster in over three decades, occurring on the start of a long weekend for the traditional Tomb Sweeping Day.

images.alt_text: A train derailed in a tunnel in eastern Taiwan on Friday after apparently hitting a truck, with at least 36 people feared dead and more than 72 injured, as rescuers struggled to reach crushed carriages, the government said.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway returns to yen market with bond
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has launched a yen bond deal, offering multi-tranche notes targeting a four-part yen deal that may price on Thursday. The company plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes and has acquired stakes in Japan's biggest trading companies. The bond deal comes as demand for corporate bonds in the yen market has been solid this year, driven by the Bank of Japan's negative interest-rate policy. Berkshire Hathaway is offering 10-year, 15-year, and 20-year notes with expected ratings higher than those given to Japanese sovereign debt.

site_title: Waste management startup Blue Planet buys disaster recovery firm
summary: Singapore-based waste management startup Blue Planet Environmental Solutions has acquired Disaster Restoration Pte Ltd Singapore, a disaster recovery firm, as part of its strategy to create a sustainable and integrated waste management ecosystem in the Asia-Pacific market. DRS has completed hundreds of disaster recoveries annually, including industrial accidents and chemical spills. The acquisition will enable Blue Planet to provide an integrated hazardous waste management ecosystem, segregating, processing, and upcycling waste from disaster sites in an environmentally friendly and efficient manner.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: In South-east Asia, vaccination efforts face many roadblocks
summary: Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia face challenges in their vaccination efforts against Covid-19. In Thailand, a speedy rollout is crucial for tourism, while in Indonesia, vaccine shortages are a major concern. Malaysia is widening its approach to speed up its vaccine drive amid slow registrations. These countries need to overcome logistical and implementation hurdles to ensure widespread access to approved vaccines and control the spread of the virus.

site_title: What Singapore's ageing population could mean for the property market
summary: Singapore's rapidly ageing population may lead to new trends in the property market. With 15.2% of residents aged 65 and above, there will be increased demand for assisted/care facilities, potentially disrupting traditional development models. A "develop-and-operate" model, where developers pay land rent instead of an upfront lump sum, could help keep costs manageable. Mixed-use developments with amenities like healthcare facilities, cooking schools, and gyms may cater to seniors' needs. Empty nesters may downsize to HDB flats, driving up their value and supporting asset prices. Meanwhile, footloose millennials may opt for renting instead of buying, driven by a desire for experiences and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Myanmar 'traitors' hounded in online anti-coup campaign
summary: Myanmar's anti-coup movement is using online social punishment to target those with family ties to the military, with over 170 people listed as "traitors" on a website. The campaign, which includes doxxing and threats, has resulted in some victims shutting down their businesses and a university student quitting her studies. Facebook and Twitter have taken action against the pages promoting the campaign, but experts warn that social media companies struggle to keep up with the challenge, and the tactic has real-world consequences. The movement is pushing a "with us or against us" mentality, with some individuals sympathizing with the aims of social punishment as a way to pressure the regime.

site_title: Solar vision: Why it's not all sunshine and roses for Singapore's solar energy plans
summary: Singapore is abuzz with solar energy activity, despite challenges such as limited land and high cloud cover. The city-state aims to halve emissions by 2050 and hit net-zero by 2060. Solar energy has quadrupled in 5 years, with 428 MWp of installed capacity, and 1.5 GWp of solar power expected by 2025 and 2 GWp by 2030. The government is exploring importing clean electricity from neighboring countries, including Malaysia and Australia, to supplement local renewable investments. Key players in Singapore's solar game include JTC Corp, Sembcorp Industries, and Sunseap Energy, which are working to optimize space under PV panels and develop floating solar PV systems.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: S-Reits seek out green and sustainability-linked loans
summary: Singapore Reits have secured over $2 billion in green and sustainability-linked loans since 2020, with 12 Reits obtaining new or refinanced loans. The loans, which total 41% green and 59% sustainability-linked, support corporates in adopting sustainable business practices and meeting environmental targets. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Green and Sustainability-Linked Loan Grant Scheme has encouraged the adoption of green financing, with Reits such as Ascott Residence Trust and Mapletree-sponsored Reits securing green loans and sustainability-linked loans.

site_title: EU's investment bank set to use blockchain for bond sale
summary: The European Investment Bank (EIB) plans to use blockchain technology for its bond sale, marking a potential boost for the digital-ledger technology in the region's debt market. Goldman Sachs, Banco Santander, and Societe Generale will explore a digital bond in euros, registered and settled using blockchain. This move follows the EIB's previous innovation in green and sustainability bonds, and comes after European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde mentioned a potential digital currency launch in the mid-2020s. Several global issuers have experimented with blockchain-based issuance, but its use in debt markets remains limited.

site_title: Singapore precision engineering body to be helmed by woman for first time
summary: Singapore's Precision Engineering & Technology Association (SPETA) has elected Elise Hong, co-founder and CEO of JCS-Echigo, as its first female chairman. She succeeds Low Ming Wah, who will guide her for the next four years. Hong aims to tackle industry issues such as talent attraction and cost competition, while continuing SPETA's efforts to drive business transformation and digitally-advanced smart manufacturing. As the industry contributes significantly to Singapore's economy, the new leadership change is seen as a step forward for the traditionally male-dominated sector.

images.alt_text: Elise Hong, co-founder and chief executive of JCS-Echigo.

site_title: US targets Myanmar gem company, seeking to deprive funding
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Myanmar's state gem company, blocking assets and banning transactions, in an effort to deprive the military junta of a key revenue stream. The move comes as the US vows to restore democracy and promote accountability in the country. The sanctions target the Myanmar Gems Enterprise, which manages the country's jade and gemstone mining and marketing. The US has already imposed targeted sanctions on military leaders, and this move is part of increased pressure on the regime to cease violence and restore democracy.

summary:

The Singapore stock market saw various developments, including NTT DC Reit's public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed and Creative Technology warning of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. Additionally, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on hopes for robust earnings season
summary: Japanese shares closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 Index rising 0.2% to 29,768.06, driven by growing expectations of robust earnings and supportive comments from US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. The broader Topix gained 0.39% to 1,959.47, with Sony Group and Hitachi leading the gains. However, analysts warn that the Japanese government's plan to place Tokyo under a new "quasi-emergency" state could limit equity gains next week.

site_title: Wanted: the next Earth
summary: Swiss astrophysicist Didier Queloz is on a mission to find Earth's "twin," an exoplanet with similar features to our own. Queloz, a Nobel laureate for co-discovering the first exoplanet in 1995, is leading the Terra Hunting Experiment, a 10-year project to study stars closest to the Sun for signs of twin planets. He believes that discovering exoplanets is not just about uncovering new worlds, but also about understanding the origin of life and the prospects of life on other planets. Queloz advocates for more boldness in the industry, encouraging scientists to take risks and push the boundaries of discovery.

images.alt_text: "A lot of technology is being developed right now...we have never stopped. We are already thinking about the following innovation after the next innovation. It's a big push. It's curiosity-driven research. Nothing can stop that, because I think we're genetically designed to explore and understand things." - Didier Queloz.

site_title: Run out of milk? Robots on call for Singapore home deliveries
summary: A Singapore technology company, OTSAW Digital, has deployed two robots, "Camello", to deliver groceries to 700 households in a one-year trial. The robots use 3D sensors, a camera, and ultraviolet light to disinfect themselves after each trip. Users can book delivery slots and receive notifications when the robot is approaching. The robots make four to five deliveries per day on weekdays and are on call for half days on Saturdays. The service aims to provide contactless and humanless delivery, especially during the pandemic period, and could be particularly helpful for the elderly.

images.alt_text: Hoping to capitalise on a surge in demand for home deliveries, a Singapore technology company has deployed a pair of robots to bring residents their groceries in one part of the city state.

site_title: Higher prices, Covid-hit household income lower relative affordability of HDB resale flats in 2020
summary: In 2020, the median price-to-income ratio for HDB resale flats in Singapore reached 3.9 times the median household income, the highest since 2015 and 2016. This indicates that households would need to save for 3.9 years without spending on anything else to buy a public housing flat from the resale market. The ratio reflects the decline in household incomes due to the pandemic, with median monthly income from work falling 2.5% year-on-year to S$9,189. Analysts expect the HDB resale price index to increase 7-10% in 2021, driven by sustained demand and a potential new peak in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The 2020 price-to-income multiple suggests that a household, without spending on anything else, has to save for 3.9 years to buy a HDB resale flat.

site_title: Oil settles up more than US$2 despite Opec+ production cuts
summary: Oil prices surged more than $2 despite Opec+ agreeing to ease production cuts, with Brent crude up 3.4% to $64.86 a barrel and US oil up 3.9% to $61.45 a barrel. The cuts, which will be gradually implemented from May, aim to stabilize inventories and support demand growth. Despite renewed lockdowns and a trimmed oil demand forecast, Opec+ expects global demand to grow 5-5.5 million barrels per day this year, with Russian Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak citing a "stronger than normal seasonal improvement in demand."

images.alt_text: Oil prices settled up more than US$2 Thursday despite news that Opec+ reached a deal to gradually ease production cuts from May.

site_title: Lazada pop-up store at Raffles City takes over space occupied by Robinsons
summary: Lazada has opened a pop-up store at Raffles City Shopping Centre in Singapore, taking over the space previously occupied by Robinsons. The 10,000 sq ft store will showcase home furnishings and smart home products until April 16. Experts say this move can attract more shoppers to malls and offer consumers more choices, as online retailers adopt a physical presence to gauge interest. The pop-up aims to provide an offline space for brands to showcase their products and offer a more immersive shopping experience.

images.alt_text: Lazada will be showcasing home furnishings and smart home products at its 10,000 sq ft pop-up store.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up ahead of Fed minutes
summary: US stocks edged higher ahead of the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes, as investors remain optimistic about the economic recovery following COVID-19 shutdowns. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1% each, with JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon predicting a "likely boom" in the US economy. However, concerns about COVID-19 variants and inflation persist, and the Fed has not yet committed to shifting its support.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks edged higher early Wednesday ahead of the release of Federal Reserve meeting minutes amid rising confidence in the US economic recovery after Covid-19 shutdowns.
